title: SEAVER MASTERS MIX OF ART AND SCIENCE
description: TWO items caught the attention of a visitor at Tom Seaver's locker stall in the White Sox clubhouse. This was on a late afternoon before a recent ball game.

title: Eatman Tries to Star Against Generals
description: Irv Eatman of the Baltimore Stars is one of those United States Football League players coveted by the National Football League, and no wonder. Eatman, the right offensive tackle, has started and, according to his coaches, starred in all 59 games the Stars have played in their three seasons. The Stars, and Eatman, play their 60th game tonight - a playoff contest against the Generals at Giants Stadium.

title: Belgium Cyclist Wins Leg of Tour
description: Rudy Matthys of Belgium won the second leg of the 72d Tour de France cycling race in the final sprint today. His countryman, Eric Vanderaerden, was third and retained the overall lead.

title: Susan Sheresky Becomes Bride Of Bart Walker
description: Susan Sheresky, the daughter of Lyn Revson and Kenneth Sheresky, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bart A. Walker, a son of Norma S. Tucker and Roland Walker, both of Baltimore. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Ballroom restaurant in Manhattan.

title: A Helms-Weicker Rematch
description: A Congressional attempt to rescue the Small Business Administration from termination, as proposed by the White House, is being threatened by a resonant clash of Senate personalities, focused, at least ostensibly, on the issue of officially sanctioned prayer in the public schools.

title: POLICE TO OPEN BOOKING CENTER IN QUEENS COURT
description: The Police Department plans to move its central booking site for Queens from a station house in Forest Hills to the Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens to expedite arraignments and free more police officers for other duties.

title: MUSIC: SEASON OPENS FOR WATERLOO FESTIVAL
description: THE Waterloo Festival opened its 10th summer season at Waterloo Village in New Jersey Saturday night with music by Liszt, Schumann and Tchaikovsky. Gerard Schwarz conducted the festival's orchestra - which is staffed in strategic places by members of his splendid Y Chamber Symphony - and Janos Starker was the cello soloist.

title: Florida Thrift Units Backed
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has reached an agreement with Florida officials that allows new state-chartered savings and loan institutions to receive Federal deposit insurance.

title: Boston Excuses a Cat From Sitting on Jury
description: Cat Mousam has been allowed to skip jury duty after election officials discovered she could not speak English.

title: HOSTAGES' NEWS CONFERENCE IN SYRIA: 'THEY'VE ALL KEPT VERY COOL HEADS'
description: Following is a transcript of the news conference held yesterday in Damascus, Syria, by the former American hostages, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: Cindy Chazan Marries Jay Leipzig in Montreal
description: Cynthia R. Chazan, the special projects associate at JWB, the national organization in New York for Jewish community centers and Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.'s in North America, was married yesterday to Jay A. Leipzig, the executive director of the Greater Hartford Jewish Community Center in West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Sidney Shoham performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Montreal.

title: Catherine Carr Whittemore Married To Rand Franklin Levy in Minnesota
description: The marriage of Catherine Carr Whittemore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Whittemore of College Park, Md., to Rand Franklin Levy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Levy of Minneapolis, took place yesterday at the Everett Township Hall, a former rural schoolhouse in Battle Lake, Minn. The Rev. William Van Dyken, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: 53 HOUSES DESTROYED IN SAN DIEGO AS FIRES HIT COAST
description: Fire that began in heavy brush roared through a maze of canyons today, destroying at least 53 houses and sending hundreds of panicked residents fleeing, firefighters said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're all terribly anxious to get home and hug our loved ones and touch American soil again.'' - Allyn Conwell, a former hostage. [A7:1.]

title: OUTPOURING OF PATRIOTISM IN THE WELCOME HOME
description: The crowds had waited for hours, the hostages for 17 days. But the moment here passed in what seemed like an instant.

title: The Sans Souci
description: Once an institution, always an institution. The Sans Souci, a restaurant a block or so from the White House, was a fashionable gathering place for the Washington elite in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Administrations.

title: AIDS CHILDREN STRUGGLE WITH TRAGIC LEGACY
description: Dr. James Oleske pulled a plush rabbit from the pocket of his lab coat, but was unable to quiet his 4-year-old patient.

title: CONCERT: THE GOLDMAN BAND
description: THE Goldman Memorial Band has played in New York for 68 seasons. It has survived good times and bad, and it will survive the inconveniences that befell its 1985 opener Wednesday at Damrosch Park.

title: CBS PLANS NEW SERIES WITH MARY TYLER MOORE
description: How do you compete with people's memories of one of the best-loved shows in the history of television? That is the question that the writer-producers David Isaacs and Ken Levine will be wrestling with as they develop their new situation comedy, tentatively titled ''Mary'' and starring Mary Tyler Moore, which will have its debut on CBS-TV next season.

title: CONCERT: LEVINE AT RAVINIA
description: James Levine, not yet born when the Chicago Symphony took up summer residence at the Ravinia park grounds half a century ago, has already shaped the festival's identity for a quarter of its existence. He opened the 50th anniversary season Friday night with an exact repetition of the hefty 1936 opening program led by Ernest Ansermet.

title: NEW STUDY OF TICK-BORNE DISEASE
description: The national Centers for Disease Control have begun a study of whether Lyme disease, the nation's most common tick-carried disease, causes birth defects.

title: Father Tells Reporters Of Shooting Child
description: A distraught father said he stood over the crib of his comatose 3-year-old daughter and fired two bullets into her heart because ''my baby was trapped in a dead body,'' The Miami Herald reported today.

title: Statue of Liberty Coins
description: The United States Mint is preparing preliminary designs for a series of three commemorative coins that could raise as much as $137.5 million to help pay for restoration of the Statue of Liberty and the immigration museum on Ellis Island.

title: THE SPICY SIDE OF TENNIS
description: ''Taming Of The Brat,'' shouted a recent headline in The Daily Mirror, which then went on to tell its readers about the love affair between John McEnroe and the actress Tatum O'Neal. In the story, McEnroe was called ''megamouth'' by the reporter Nigel Clarke, who also gave his own account of why McEnroe's former girlfriend had left him:

title: Chairman Out At Imperial
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, the California savings and loan concern that is controlled by the Tamco Holding Company, said that Matthew J. Shevlin Jr., chairman and chief executive since May 1982, has resigned.

title: HOWE OF DODGERS ABSENT FROM GAME
description: Steve Howe, who was suspended during the 1984 season for cocaine use, was placed on the National League restricted list by the Los Angeles Dodgers after he failed to show up for his team's game today against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Better Ferry Needed For Hoboken Run
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 SUFFOLK JUDGES LOSE SUPPORT OF OWN PARTIES FOR RE-ELECTION
description: In a break with tradition, leaders of the Republican and Conservative Parties in Suffolk County have decided not to endorse two judges from their own parties seeking re-election.

title: HOSTAGE BOND TO CAPTORS IS COMMON
description: Experts in the psychological effects of terrorism said yesterday that the benign comments made by some of the 39 former Beirut hostages about their captors and their political cause, both during and after the ordeal, show signs of a condition called the Stockholm syndrome.

title: No Arrests in Slaying Of Pacific Island Leader
description: No arrests have been made in the assassination of the President of Palau, an official of the Pacific island chain said today. He said a mistaken report of an arrest had apparently stemmed from confusion over an unrelated investigation.

title: When Violence Comes Home
description: ''Women,'' a character in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives'' says blithely, ''should be struck regularly, like gongs.'' Once that may have seemed a funny line; today it's a sick joke.

title: He's Blind To Nothing
description: WHEN he was 8 years old, Craig MacFarlane earned a gold medal for winning a wrestling tournament. That evening at his home in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, he hung the ribboned medal on a bedpost in his room. And when he woke up every morning for several weeks, he reached over and caressed the medal as if it were a pet.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: GUERRERO SETS HOMER RECORD
description: Pedro Guerrero hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning today, setting the National League record with his 15th home run in June and leading the Los Angeles Dodgers over the Atlanta Braves, 4-3.

title: 3 QUARRELS: TV, PEACE AND BEARS
description: In the days before the ban on cigarette advertising on television, one of the tube's greatest uses for the Western landscape was as a backdrop for commercials featuring rugged cowboys lighting their favorite manly smoke.

title: Futures/Options;   Markets Upset Over Big Shifts
description: HEDGERS and speculators continued to abandon the futures markets in farm and industrial commodities in the first half of 1985. Not only did mounting surpluses of all basic raw materials discourage trading, but so did the growing realization that a fundamental structural change, rather than a cyclical one, was under way in the traditional commodities markets.

title: Bicycling, First Class
description: A misty rain was falling when Deborah Mitchell and her parents stepped out of the Alwyn Court after dinner at Petrossian, the caviar emporium at 182 West 58th Street.

title: That Sinking Feeling
description: ''The phone in the bullpen is ringing again, and this time it's for you. Last of the ninth in a tied, must-win game, bases loaded and only one out, so you can't afford to give up even a long fly ball.

title: T.W.A. PURSER IS HAILED AS COURAGEOUS
description: The purser of the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner, Uli Derickson, was praised today by two hostages at their news conference here.

title: The U.N. Today: July 1, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: HISPANIC GROUP ELECTS A TEXAS AS PRESIDENT
description: Oscar Moran, an insurance analyst, was elected president of the League of United Latin American Citizens here today and said he would shift the group's main lobbying efforts from Washington to state legislatures.

title: INSECT THAT RUINED VINEYARDS REAPPEARS IN CALIFORNIA
description: In the middle of the last century, a tiny aphid-like insect began a 40-year march across Europe that caused what the wine expert Alexis Lichine called ''the greatest single viticulture disaster since the Flood.''

title: THE PARTY OF GOD: A POWERFUL AND GROWING PRO-IRANIAN FORCE IN LEBANON
description: The Party of God, the pro-Iranian Islamic fundamentalist movement whose followers are believed to have been behind the hijacking of the Trans World Airlines jet June 14, is a growing, powerful force in this war-torn country.

title: Slaney to Race Against Budd
description: Mary Slaney of the United States and Zola Budd of Britain will meet again in a 3,000-meter race in London on July 20, track promoters announced today.

title: An i for an i. Or Is It an e?
description: The talent for misspelling the name of a city increases exponentially with the distance of the speller. Texans and Californians, for instance, struggle with New York State names like Canandaigua and Schenectady, while New Yorkers swap an ''e'' for an ''o'' in Los Angeles and give San Francisco two ''s'' 's and one ''c.'' At ground zero, on the other hand, even the worst spellers in Philadelphia can handle the Greek derivative, and people who live in Sarnia, Ontario -across the St. Clair River from Port Huron, Mich. - never confuse their city's name with that of Sonja, the famous Norwegian ice skater.

title: Century Brass Workers Authorize a Walkout
description: Union employees at Century Brass Products voted 377 to 71 today to authorize a strike if the company alters its existing contract.

title: Screams of a Hostage Were 'Bloodcurdling'
description: A freed American hostage today told of hearing ''bloodcurdling'' screams before Shiite terrorists killed a Navy diver in the early stages of the Trans World Airlines hijacking.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: REACTOR COOLING SYSTEM FAULTED AS SUBSTANDARD
description: None of the eight nuclear reactors of the same design as the one that failed at Three Mile Island met the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's standard for emergency systems that supply cooling water to a reactor as of April 1984, according to an internal commission memorandum.

title: PROBLEMS OF CHILDREN IN HOSPITAL
description: THREE-YEAR-OLD Natasha's esophagus was severely burned when she swallowed lye by accident, and she spent 230 days in a Florida hospital in 1983.

title: Paul Stops Blake in 14th
description: Jimmy Paul knocked down Robin Blake in the ninth round, then punished the challenger before stopping him at 2 minutes 14 seconds of the 14th round today to retain his International Boxing Federation lightweight title.

title: S.E.C. RULE EXPECTED ON BANKS
description: The banking industry is bracing for another round of regulation, but this time not from the Federal banking agencies. If the Securities and Exchange Commission acts as expected, it will vote Monday to require all banks that offer brokerage services to the public to register those operations with the commission.

title: A FEW SURPRISES AMID A SLOW START FOR WIMBLEDON
description: The first week of a grand-slam event is usually as unsettled as the weather was in London last week. Some of the big-name players invariably are forced to escape from close encounters like so many tennis Houdinis, while others are trampled by specialists who groom their game for a particular surface. The setting is a carnival of matches as the fans roam from court to court as if they were sampling from a box of chocolates.

title: ELIMINATING MISTAKES IS GENERALS' GOAL
description: THE playoff game tonight at Giants Stadium between the Generals and the Baltimore Stars is what Walt Michaels, the Generals' coach, calls ''an execution game.''

title: STATE AND CITY TAX CUTS START TAKING EFFECT TODAY
description: In this week's paychecks, New Yorkers will receive the first few dollars of the multiyear cut in state and city taxes enacted this year.

title: Lynd Ward, 80, Artist And Book Illustrator
description: Lynd Ward, the artist and book illustrator whose more than 200 works for children and adults included the ''The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge,'' died Friday of Alzheimer's disease at his home in Reston, Va. He was 80 years old.

title: CAMP STRESSES PREPARATION
description: The soft-spoken 21-year-old from Brooklyn hardly seemed the typical university professor, but Dwayne Washington, better known as Pearl, played the role of teacher at Princeton University today.

title: A LOOK AT WALL STREET RESULTS
description: Stocks of companies that posted better-than-expected earnings, those that were takeover targets and even one that owns a very fast horse led the gainers on the nation's major stock exchanges in the second quarter.

title: Burr-Lenehan Wins in Jump-Off
description: Leslie Burr-Lenehan turned in a successful jump-off round riding McLain to capture the Laurent-Perrier Lake Placid Grand Prix today, the closing event of the 16th annual Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: Statuesque
description: Phil Niekro, long a pillar of the community in Atlanta, is about to become a pillar of bronze outside the ball park where he pitched for 19 seasons. But it's certainly not of his doing.

title: Rain, Rain, Go Away
description: With enthusiasm generally dampened by stubborn rain during the first week at Wimbledon, the British nonetheless tried to maintain a positive outlook, as when, during one weather-caused delay, the public-address announcer said it was hoped that play would resume soon, since brighter clouds were approaching.

title: FOR THE FAMILIES, HOPE AND JOY OVERCOME THE FEAR
description: After 17 days of fear, they smiled again. They chilled champagne, a symbol of new beginnings, and festooned themselves in yellow ribbons, a bittersweet reminder of a past hostage ordeal.

title: BOTH SIDES SEE GAINS IN TEXAS CONGRESSIONAL VOTE
description: Democrats and Republicans each claimed gains from the results of a special Congressional election Saturday, in which the only Republican candidate outpolled his Democratic opponents but could not avoid a runoff.

title: Sutton Wins in Playoff
description: Hal Sutton sank a 30-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff against David Ogrin to win the $500,000 St. Jude Memphis Classic today at Colonial Country Club.

title: MARYLAND ASSESSES THRIFT UNIT WOES
description: Just over a month after deposit runs severely disrupted Maryland's 102 privately insured savings and loan associations, Maryland officials say they are pleased by the progress they have made toward restoring faith in that part of the state's financial system.

title: Lively Tax Hearings Expected
description: Congress is off on a long July 4 holiday, but when it gets back a week from today, sparks are likely to fly in the hearing room of the House Ways and Means Committee. The committee will be taking more testimony then on the President's tax plan.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Cuba Looks for Friends
description: No one I met in Cuba expects a real thaw in relations between Ronald Reagan and Fidel Castro. But two searing experiences - the Mariel exodus and the Grenada invasion -have caused Mr. Castro to open some windows in his island fortress. At the least, Americans ought to try to open them wider.

title: DEAL MAKER IN CHARGE AT ATLANTIC PETROLEUM
description: John Deuss, whose newly formed Atlantic Petroleum Corporation has agreed to purchase the Atlantic Richfield Company's Philadelphia refinery and 576 service stations in Pennsylvania and New York, is no stranger to major deals in the oil trading business.

title: SPACE ARMS PROJECTS IGNITE DEBATE ON U.S.-SOVIET SCIENCE EXCHANGES
description: Tensions are rising, because of the development of antimissile research programs, over the exchange of ideas and information taking place among scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: State Court Official Named
description: An assistant counsel to Governor Cuomo has been named deputy chief administrator for management support of the state court system. The appointment of the official, Matthew T. Crosson, will be effective July 15, according to the announcement by Joseph W. Bellacosa, the state's chief administrator of the courts.

title: A Top Chinese Warns About 'Money Worship'
description: A senior leader of the Chinese Communist Party's rectification commission delivered a strong warning today against what he called ''money worship'' and ''spiritual pollution,'' regarded as evils of capitalist societies.

title: Washington Watch;   Less Growth, Bigger Deficit
description: SOMETIME next month, or perhaps in early August, the Reagan Administration will have to recalculate its assumptions for an economy that it expected to grow at an average of 4 percent a year through 1988. Its problem is that the economy through the first half of this year has been growing at a rate of less than 2 percent. So meeting the 4 percent figure this year would require boom-like conditions in the second half.

title: Alberta Energy
description: The Alberta Energy Company said Friday that it plans two large oil and gas programs at a total cost of $82 million to drill another 500 wells on the Suffield block in southeastern Alberta. Construction is expected to continue through mid-1986.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S REMARKS ON THE HOSTAGES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's remarks yesterday on the hostage release, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Khomeini Derides U.S. For Beirut Aid Search
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said President Reagan had been ''going around with a cap in his hand begging'' for help in solving the Beirut hostage crisis, Iran's official press agency said today.

title: B.B.D.O. Wins Prize At Cannes Festival
description: Reports from Cannes, France, have it that Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn won the Grand Prix at the 32d annual International Advertising Film Festival this weekend, meaning that American agencies have won top honors two years in a row after five years of missing out.

title: Galina Datskovsky and Mark Moerdler Are Wed
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Galina Datskovsky and Mark L. Moerdler, doctoral candidates in computer sciences at Columbia University, were married by Rabbi George Finkelstein. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Ainbinder of New York, formerly of Moscow, and the bridegroom a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Moerdler of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: LOSE 5TH IN ROW
description: Neither angry words by Dave Johnson nor heat by Dwight Gooden spared the Mets today as they lost for the fifth straight time, and this one was a downer: The St. Louis Cardinals played Gooden to a 1-1 tie in eight innings and then beat Jesse Orosco in the 11th.

title: Catching Up
description: * Only two members of the 1984 United States Olympic boxing team - Jerry Page and Paul Gonzales -have not yet made the leap into the pro ranks, and that is about to change. Page, the 139-pound champion at Los Angeles, is now being managed by Angelo Dundee and will make his debut July 17 against Raul Torres in Akron, Ohio.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Wins Hyundai Account
description: Backer & Spielvogel is the winner in the race to become the ad agency for Hyundai Motor America, the United States marketing arm of the North Korean conglomerate. In Canada, its cars are the No. 2 import brand after Honda.

title: Lull Possible in Bullish Trend
description: Economists sifting through the recent economic data are generally concluding that the outlook is troubled, a perception that they say will sustain downward pressure on interest rates. But, according to the analysts, the bond market rally appears likely to lose some of its vigor.

title: Let's Reduce Regulations on Takeovers
description: As anyone who follows the stock market knows, one of the best ways to get rich is to be holding a large block of stock when a corporate ''raider'' comes to call. Some of our elected representatives, however, feel we need protection from such good fortune.

title: FOREIGN STOCKS ADVANCE 5.7%
description: Relaxing after the blistering pace of the first three months of 1985, stock prices on the world's major exchanges rose at more modest rates in the second quarter.

title: Miss Dahl, Literary Agent, Married to Richard Zacks
description: Kristine Yvonne Dahl, a daughter of Lieut. Col. Raymond H. Dahl, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Dahl of Silverton, Ore., was married yesterday to Richard Gordon Zacks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Zacks of New York. Judge John E. H. Stackhouse of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at Jerry's Bar and Grill in Manhattan.

title: RELATIVES OF 7 STILL MISSING SAY THEY WILL PRESS ON
description: Relatives of the Americans who are still missing in Lebanon are joyous over the release of the 39 hijacking victims but urged the country yesterday not to forget ''the other hostages.''

title: MUSIC: ST. LUKE'S ENSEMBLE
description: The Caramoor Festival holds its concerts in two delightfully intimate spots on an estate of heart-lifting beauty, but the really nice thing about it is that the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble plays there.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
description: The Hostage Release

title: GORDIMER'S STORIES OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: SOUTH AFRICA is clamoring for our attention again. ABC's Ted Koppel gets lauded, deservedly, for a series of live reports from the oppressive land. In this country, protests abound about the morality of having investments in South Africa.

title: Argentina Moves To Soccer Finals
description: Argentina squeaked into the World Cup soccer finals today by tying a hard-fighting Peruvian team, 2-2, in the final game of the Group 1 South American elimination series.

title: Soviet Team Beats Indiana for Title
description: Arvidas Sabonis, a 7-foot-2 1/2-inch center, scored 23 points as the Soviet national basketball team used its superior size and strength to trounce Indiana University, 74-54, today and capture the Kirin World Basketball Championship.

title: Laser Device to Find Range Of Moon Ends 16-Year Stint
description: A device using reflectors that astronauts placed on the moon to help substantiate Einstein's theory of relativity was retired Saturday after 16 years.

title: How to Win Friends and Lobby
description: Robert Mottice arranges a business lunch the way others arrange a first date.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: YEAGER: An Autobiography. By General Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. 342 pages. Illustrated. Bantam. $17.95.

title: Rescue From Tight Jeans
description: It took four firefighters 20 minutes Saturday to free a woman whose skin had become caught on the zipper of a pair of tight-fitting designer jeans. Using wire cutters and sharp-nose pliers, the firefighters carefully cut away the zipper from the rest of the pants. The woman had borrowed the pants from a cousin, officials said.

title: An Antidote for the Mengele Anticlimax
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN'S CAUCUS ELECTS NEW YORKER
description: Irene Natividad, a New York educator vowing to wage ''high-stakes, in-the-trenches'' battles for women running for office, was elected today to lead the National Women's Political Caucus for the next two years.

title: TOP CORPORATE POSITIONS ADDED AT CONTROL DATA
description: The Control Data Corporation, which has been suffering from the industrywide downturn in the computer business as well as from its own internal problems, said that to improve performance and profits it had added ''two critically important'' positions to its corporate staff.

title: On Real Estate
description: For an illustration of how lower mortgage interest rates can stimulate the housing market, members of Congress need look no farther than the other side of the capital. Georgetown real estate agents report 125 homes on the market, a radical increase in the last month or so. This is only 5 percent of the property in fashionable Georgetown, but a high figure historically for the slow-turnover area, where $200,000 buys only a fairly modest residence and homeowners tend to cling to their dwellings as the finest investments in town.

title: Labor Relations Board Is No Friend of Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS A Small U.S.-Soviet Step
description: In the midst of renewed stridency between Moscow and Washington, the two have managed to agree on how to face the possibility of nuclear terrorism.

title: LAWMAKERS ACT ON RENTS, AND RECESS
description: The Legislature recessed for the summer today after resolving the remaining major issue - whether rent controls would be continued for thousands of New York City apartments.

title: Some Costly Double Tokens
description: Anomalies abound on a waterfront where the North River is west, South Street is east and the fort between them never fired a shot in war.

title: MOOD SWING FOR ANDRETTI
description: WORD came through the crowd that Mario Andretti's car had been hit and that he may have been knocked out of the Meadowlands Grand Prix yesterday. Andretti, the defending champion, was leading at the time, the 35th of the 100 laps around the 1.68-mile circuit.

title: CARIBBEAN LEADER FACES VOTE TODAY
description: The Prime Minister of this tiny Caribbean nation faces the voters Monday after an election campaign in which her opponent criticized what he called her ''slavish'' ties to the United States.

title: Chief Executive Named by Mitsui
description: Mitsui & Company, the giant Japanese trading company, announced Friday that Koichiro Ejiri had been elected president and chief executive.

title: L.I. COUNSELOR HELPS CHILDREN DEAL WITH SHOCK OF DIVORCE
description: A guidance counselor at a high school on Long Island has developed a specialty in working with students whose parents are divorced or separated.

title: The Perfect Contraceptive: When?
description: Now that thousands of American drugstores maintain a ''family-planning center,'' it's hard to believe that state laws forbidding birth control by married couples were struck down only 20 years ago. Americans now assume that contraceptives are available to all. They are wrong.

title: Sally Jacobs Wed To Warren Baker
description: Sally Jo Jacobs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. Jacobs of New York, was married yesterday to Warren Alan Baker, the son of Gaye Baker of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Albert Baker. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at Le Club in Manhattan.

title: Looping Miles of Loop As a Nuclear Reminder
description: With a little help from her friends, Justine Merritt wants to tie this city together to remember another city that was torn apart.

title: ISRAEL SEEMS IN NO RUSH ON DETAINEES
description: The Israeli Cabinet today discussed the release of the American airliner hostages, but made no decision on when to free 735 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees whose freedom was the principal demand of the hostage-takers, the Cabinet secretary said.

title: YEAR-OLD STARS: CASTING CALL FOR BABIES
description: Susan Cagle wore pink flowered overalls for her audition and peered at her competition with large blue eyes. Dana Tropeano showed more interest in her bottle.

title: The Buck Stops There
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Positions Filled By 4 Executives
description: There were four executive changes of special note last week.

title: Moderate Schedule of Offerings
description: The second quarter saw a record level of corporate securities being issued into the markets, and the third quarter ought to get off to a relatively strong start, according to analysts.

title: SECURITY UNDERWRITERS BUSIER IN 2D QUARTER
description: The second quarter produced a heavy level of securities offerings for underwriters as a blizzard of offerings were made in the generally favorable market.

title: BARBER WINS OPEN
description: Miller Barber, finishing with a one-under 71, captured his third United States Senior Open Golf Championship today, winning by four strokes.

title: Shipbuilders Vote To Strike Maine Plants
description: The union representing 4,500 shipbuilders at the Bath Iron Works, faced with a contract expiring at midnight, voted overwhelmingly today to begin a strike. The union, Local 6 of the Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, represents workers at the company's facilities in Bath, Brunswick and Portland.

title: 37 MORE DEAD IN MOZAMBIQUE IN STALEMATED, PARALYZING WAR
description: Thirty-seven Mozambicans were reported killed and 62 wounded today when rebels attacked a convoy of buses under military escort south of here. It was the third attack of its kind in two weeks in a war that will not go away.

title: REPAVING SLIDING ON THROGS NECK BRIDGE
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority thought it had come up with a way to resurface the Throgs Neck Bridge that would save several million dollars. It did not work.

title: Occidental Mine in China
description: The chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Dr. Armand Hammer, will preside Monday at dedication ceremonies at the beginning of development of an open-cut coal mine in central China designed to produce 15.33 million tons of raw coal annually.

title: GO FROM LEBANON TO SYRIA AND HEAD HOME
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the final obstacle to the release of the 39 American hostages was removed Saturday night when the Administration accepted a proposal by Syria to issue an old policy statement on Lebanon.

title: THE SEVEN STILL MISSING ARE A DIVERSE GROUP
description: Here are sketches of the seven Americans reported kidnapped or missing in Lebanon in 1984 and 1985:

title: ZIMBABWE LEADER FURIOUS AT WHITES
description: Prime Minister Robert G. Mugabe today criticized white voters in this black-governed African nation as ''racists of the past'' for the impressive political victory they gave former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith last week.

title: Outdoors: Seeking Elusive Bass
description: HAVING George Waring invite us to go smallmouth-bass fishing with him on Pleasant Lake was an ideal way to launch our two-day venture after that species.

title: Deacon and Gunman Slain in Coast Church
description: An unemployed parishioner who was apparently distraught over his divorce opened fire today during services at a Baptist church in Chinatown, killing a deacon and seriously wounding a minister in front of hundreds of worshipers, the authorities said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albany Savings Bank has elected Herbert G. Chorbajian president, chief operating officer and a trustee.

title: The Great Crawfish Debate
description: Nothing fuels interstate chauvinism in Congress quite like rival claims on the merits of certain edible delights.

title: Sheila F. Taylor Married To Brett Flamm, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Sheila Florence Taylor, the daughter of Ona Taylor of North Haven, Conn., and the late Frederick Miner Taylor, to Brett Charles Flamm took place yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Howard Flamm, parents of the bridegroom, in Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Victor I. Rogers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC: OZAWA AND NAGANO CONDUCT AS SEASON BEGINS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Tanglewood's expanded, 10-week summer concert season got under way this weekend. There was the traditional opening chamber-music program in the Theater Thursday night, with the Beaux Arts Trio in an all-Beethoven program. The Boston Symphony's first concert followed on Friday in the Shed, with Seiji Ozawa in another all-Beethoven bill.

title: Pentagon;   The Life Of the 'Ops Dep'
description: Lieut. Gen. David L. Nichols is a fighter pilot who flew 100 missions in F-105 Thunderchief fighter-bombers over North Vietnam, but he hardly fits the mold of the silk-scarf-and-eye-goggles flyers of yore.

title: No Firm Evidence Found In Air-India Jet Crash
description: Investigators said today that nothing in the examination of wreckage recovered so far from the Air-India jetliner that crashed off Ireland last week has confirmed the initial suspicion that the plane went down because of a bomb explosion.

title: PATTI BOWN ON PIANO
description: PATTI BOWN, who played in the Kool Jazz Festival's daily series of piano soloists at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday, is a free spirit who is not bound by traditional ways of doing things.

title: 5 Jersey Hospitals Avert a Walkout
description: Union leaders and management at five New Jersey hospitals today reached a tentative contract agreement, averting a strike by 4,000 hospital workers, a state mediator said.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants played each other in the National Football League, which team held the advantage in the series? How long did the Dodger franchise exist and did any of its players make the Pro Football Hall of Fame?

title: Koch Plans Entry In Race on July 9
description: Mayor Koch, who calls himself an ''informal'' candidate for re-election, said yesterday that he would probably make his candidacy formal on Tuesday, July 9.

title: Oh, Possum
description: The subsidiary honors that come to the holder of high Federal office sometimes seem endless. When he was in Birmingham, Ala., last month for a speech, Francis S. M. Hodsoll, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, was made a member of the Possum Growers and Breeders Association of America and, in turn, pledged himself to ''educate the general public as to the value of the Didelphis virginiana as a source of highly nutritious and palatable food and quality fur.'' In what might seem a contradictory mission to some, the association is also dedicated to promoting the opossum as a pet.

title: BLUE JAYS, WITH 3 HOMERS, DEFEAT TIGERS
description: Toronto hit three homers, but it was a run-scoring double by Damaso Garcia that lifted the Blue Jays to a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

title: CHALLENGE ON PRICING FOR OPEC
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will begin its annual conference in Vienna on Friday amid growing skepticism in the world oil community that it can stop the current slide in oil prices or sufficiently temper the dissension within itself to even make a credible attempt.

title: A Young World's Fair
description: Dr. Cary Goodman was not satisfied with the kind of entertainment that children were getting. So three months ago, he and some other grown-ups took crayons to paper and drew a picture of what a world's fair for youngsters would look like.

title: LEADER OF EDUCATION ASSOCIATION BACKS TESTING FOR NEW TEACHERS
description: Mary H. Futrell, the president of the National Education Association, today urged the group to abandon opposition to the testing of new teachers, a position that has prompted criticism of the union.

title: FANS GIVE A SHOW OF SUPPORT TO PIRATES
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, helped by a jersey giveaway, sunny weather and intense promotion, attracted 31,384 fans for today's game against the Chicago Cubs, their second largest home crowd of the season.

title: NEW HALL FOR BAKETBALL'S BEST
description: Willis Reed driving to the basket, John Havlicek and Dave DeBusschere shooting jumpers, Wilt Chamberlain waiting to pass and Bob Cousy and Bob Pettit dribbling.

title: The Death Penalty Lottery
description: Thirteen years ago this week, the Supreme Court, in a landmark decision, declared unconstitutional the ''arbitrary and freakish'' application of the death penalty. But in Virginia last week, the execution of Morris Odell Mason, a mentally impaired black man with an I.Q. of 66, was determined by a death penalty system tantamount to a lottery in which life-and-death decisions depend largely on race, income or just bad luck.

title: Ari H. Roth Wed to Kate Sara Schecter
description: At Adas Israel Synagogue in Washington yesterday Kate Sara Schecter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold L. Schecter of Washington, was married to Ari H. Roth, the son of Walter and Dr. Chaya H. Roth of Chicago. Rabbis Jonathan Ginsberg and Julie Gordon performed the ceremony.

title: PICTURE OF WASHINGTON AS CAPTIVE OF THE CRISIS
description: From the first official crisis meeting on the hijacking of Trans World Airline Flight 847 to President Reagan's announcement today that 39 Americans travelers were ''free and safe,'' the hostage situation preoccupied the Administration.

title: Bridge: Hesitation by the Opponent Can Have Several Meanings
description: If an opponent hesitates, it is perfectly proper to draw conclusions but you do so at your own risk. The length of the hesitation may be relevant, and you may have to factor in the quality of the player.

title: AL UNSER JR. WINS MEADOWLANDS RACE
description: It seemed like a meeting of Jersey drivers and Sunday drivers. But these were some of the finest drivers in the world running into each other today for the entertainment of 43,567 sun-drenched spectators, and in the midst of it all was perhaps the finest, Mario Andretti.

title: Georgia Says 2 Men Broke Charity Law
description: A volleyball game for charity, featuring professional football players, failed to take place as scheduled today and the state of Georgia sued two of its promoters. The two, Scott Davis, a former computer graphics salesman, and Clarence Scott, a former defensive back for the Cleveland Browns, had formed a company called National Sports Charities to stage the event, which they said would raise money for handicapped children.

title: Market Place;   Stock Choices At Midyear
description: PICKING stocks at midyear for hoped-for superior performance over the next 12 months is becoming popular at brokerage houses. Shearson Lehman Brothers, which broke ground on this front in 1949, announces today its new roster of ''Ten Uncommon Values in Common Stocks.''

title: PITCHING FALTERS AS YANKEES LOSE, 7-5
description: The dog days now begin. The weather gets hotter, the games mount - in number and importance - and the true pennant contenders begin to step forward.

title: Labor Relations Board Is No Friend of Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH EXTENDS WELCOME AT AIR BASE
description: The 39 Americans who were held captive after the hijacking of their Trans World Airlines jet were welcomed early this morning at an American air base by Vice President Bush.

title: Woman Refuses Rescue and Dies
description: A 39-year-old woman, accompanied by her 13-year-old daughter, drove their car off a ferry pier on the Connecticut River Friday and for several minutes refused to open the locked doors of her car, despite the pleas of a rescuer, the police in Rocky Hill, Conn., said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 'YOUNG NEW ORLEANS' CONCERT
description: To the tourists on Bourbon Street, New Orleans jazz is old-time Dixieland. But the city has sustained a creative modern jazz community since the late 1940's, and now the young sons of middle-aged modernists like Ellis Marsalis and Kidd Jordan are introducing the new New Orleans jazz to the world.

title: BRAZILIANS TAKE 'LAND REFORM' AS FIGHTING WORDS
description: A jeep pulled up outside the local landowners' society and a stout figure climbed out, shifting the two pistols in his belt.

title: A VIGOROUS FEMINIST IN THE FRENCH CABINET
description: Yvette Roudy, France's Minister for Women's Rights, likes to show visitors the artwork by women that is on the walls of her office near the Arc de Triomphe. She says there has long been a prejudice against women in the art world that makes it more difficult for them to gain recognition.

title: Advertising;   Executive Changes At M.C.A.
description: ROBERT KAMERSCHEN, who arrived at the Marketing Corporation of America last September with a sackful of credentials, has been named its president and the first chief operating officer in the company's 14-year history.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. The teams last met in the first month of the season, and the Mets won four of six games. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto, 1:35 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. When the teams met last month, the Yankees won, 4-2, behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Shirley, making his first start of the season, with Dave Righetti getting the save. The Blue Jays took the last two, 4-1, in 11 innings and 3-2 in 10. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Dodgers vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Los Angeles. The Dodgers and Reds are both trying to catch the San Diego Padres in the National League West. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.) Giants vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Francisco (Television - WTBS 4:05 P.M.) Basketball Hall of Fame Enshrinement, at Springfield, Mass. Nate Thurmond, former star center for the Warriors, is being inducted along with six others: Margaret Wade, former women's coach at Delta State, whose name is given to the Wade Trophy, awarded to the country's top female collegian each year; Al Cervi, former pro star; Marv Harshman, former coach at the University of Washington; Bertha F. Teague, former coach at Byng High School in Oklahoma; the late Senda Berenson Abbott, contributor, and the late Harold Anderson, coach at Bowling Green.

title: Invaders Triumph On Last-Play Kick
description: Novo Bojovic kicked a 23-yard field goal on the last play of the game to give the Oakland Invaders a 30-27 victory over the Tampa Bay Bandits today in the opening round of the United States Football League playoffs.

title: Hiking Scout Falls to Death
description: Henry J. Herrman, a 16-year-old Boy Scout from Red Lion, Pa., slipped on a ledge while hiking on the Philmont Scout Ranch and fell 70 feet to his death, officials said.

title: GO FROM LEBANON TO SYRIA AND HEAD HOME
description: President Reagan welcomed the release of the American hostages today, but said the United States ''will not rest until justice is done'' in Beirut as well as El Salvador.

title: GO FROM LEBANON TO SYRIA AND HEAD HOME
description: Thirty-nine Americans were freed today by their Lebanese Shiite captors in Beirut, then were driven here in a convoy organized by the International Committee of the Red Cross. Within hours, the jubilant group was flying to West Germany, en route home after 17 days in captivity.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS AGAIN BATTLE NAMIBIAN REBELS IN ANGOLA
description: South African troops clashed again today with South-West African guerrillas in Angola, killing 16, the authorities here announced.

title: LOVED ONES GATHERING IN GERMANY FOR REUNION
description: Relatives of the 39 American airliner hostages celebrated here with champagne today after learning that the men had been freed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BROOKLYN CONCERT SERIES The third annual Martin Luther King Jr. Concert Series begins its 1985 season tonight at 7:30 with the Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, conducted by David Amram, and Nina Simone, the ''high priestess of soul.'' The concerts are scheduled on consecutive Mondays through Aug. 19 at the old Boys High School field, Troy Avenue and Rutland Road, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Admission is free.

title: IN BEIRUT, HOODED MEN TELL OF CAPTIVES' RELEASE
description: Two men who said they were the hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jet said today that they had committed the act to show the world ''the ability of the oppressed to confront America.''

title: What New York Pornography Bill Does
description: To the Editor:

title: In Argentina, Exhaustion and Fragmentation
description: I returned to Buenos Aires last month to take stock of Argentina's first 18 months of constitutional Government. I was looking for a coherent account, but I heard only a cacophony of complaints. The only tense used is a fitful present. Hyperinflation has been both the cause and the symptom of a futile bustle. Tempers are short, and the simple decencies of conviviality are shrugged away.

title: ARTISTS RECORD THE DEATH OF THE MILL'S WAY OF LIFE
description: The subjects of Tony Buba's films are unaffected - a woman washing windows and recalling her immigration from Italy, a used furniture salesman, steelworkers eating at Betty's Corner Cafe.

title: Elegant Lies, Harsh Truths
description: It took some elegant lies for Ronald Reagan, Nabih Berri, Shimon Peres and Hafez al-Assad to arrange the release of the 39 hijacked Americans from Beirut. But admiration for their agility should not obscure the harsh truths that linger.

title: TV STATIONS' LURE FOR BUYERS
description: Financial data on three television stations being auctioned by ABC and Capital Cities Communications on July 12 provide an unusual insight into why television prices have soared in recent years.

title: Walesa Says Workers Have 'Right to Protest'
description: Lech Walesa told thousands of cheering churchgoers in Gdansk today that workers ''have the right to protest,'' but he avoided a direct endorsement of a one-hour general strike on Monday.

title: SKETCHES OF AMERICAN HOSTAGES FROM HIJACKED T.W.A. PLANE
description: Victor Amburgy 31 years old . . . Worked as a letter carrier for the United States Postal Service in San Francisco for three years . . . Resigned in December to go on a world tour with a friend and roommate, John McCarty, who was also taken hostage . . . Had gone with Mr. McCarty to Hong Kong, Australia, Fiji, Thailand and the Greek islands and was headed back to the United States when hijacking occurred . . . Born in Langlade, Wis., a small farm town . . . Studied for the priesthood and attended St. Norbert College in West De Pere, Wis., for one year, but dropped out to work for the Postal Service in Green Bay, Wis. . . . Has performed with his guitar in coffeehouses and clubs in Wisconsin.

title: FAREWELL PERFORMANCE FOR BRYNNER IN 'KING AND I'
description: Yul Brynner said goodbye last night to the role that had become part of him.

title: MEHTA COMBINES NEW YORK AND ISRAELI ORCHESTRAS
description: Zubin Mehta combined his two orchestras - the New York Philharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic - into a 220-piece ensemble to perform Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' tonight in a rousing finale to the American group's five-week overseas tour.

title: Akers Joining Times Board
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that John F. Akers, president and chief executive officer of the International Business Machines Corporation, had been named a member of The Times Company's board of directors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
description: International

title: A.T.&T. Competitors Attacked
description: ''The Exploitation of Affection'' may sound like the title of a treatise on social mores. Not so. To the dismay of many companies trying to compete with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the title belongs to a Federal Communications Commission working paper attacking them.

title: Henry Hough, Editor, Recalled on Vineyard
description: Hundreds of friends and colleagues gathered Saturday morning in the Old Whaling Church here to recall the life of Henry Beetle Hough, the editor of The Vineyard Gazette for 65 years.

title: Twilight Ridge Scores
description: Twilight Ridge, the odds-on favorite, got up in the final strides to beat I'm Splendid in the $71,500 Astoria Stakes for 2-year-old fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: NINA SIMONE SINGS AT FISHER HALL
description: THE last time Nina Simone appeared at what is now known as the Kool Jazz Festival was in 1974 when it still had its original name, the Newport Jazz Festival. She was scheduled to perform in the festival again in 1977 but she failed to appear. That was the beginning of a period of increasing personal problems that were reflected in her performances (and in nonappearances) and that seemed to be taking her career steadily downhill.

title: Baxter's Bid Is Criticized
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, denouncing the revised offer by Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. to acquire the American Hospital Supply Corporation, said yesterday that aspects of Baxter's proposal raised serious questions of legality and ethics.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 1, 1985: *2*MONDAY Carolina Freight Nevada Power Central Vt Pub Serv *2*TUESDAY Ohio Mattress *2*WEDNESDAY Corning Glass Wks Sun Co Inc Houston Industries Utd Water Resources *2*THURSDAY Holiday *2*FRIDAY None Reported

title: RIKERS INMATE FOUND HANGED
description: A 32-year-old Queens man hanged himself yesterday at Rikers Island with shoelaces tied to a window lever, according a spokesman for the City Department of Correction.

title: Miss Hammond Weds Douglas S. Freeman 2d
description: Meryl Dunn Hammond and Douglas Southall Freeman 2d were married in New York yesterday at the home of Dr. Theodore F. Dunn, father of the bride. The Rev. Richard Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony.

title: Deborah Kanter Wed To Steven B. Jackman
description: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Deborah Ann Kanter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kanter of Lake Success, L.I., was married to Steven Bruce Jackman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Jackman of Boston. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: 17 DAYS: TERROR AND DIPLOMACY
description: Trans World Airlines Flight 847 was hijacked between Athens and Rome on June 14, and the hostages were released yesterday. Following is a chronology of the 17-day crisis:

title: China Dominates In Table Tennis
description: Jiang Jialiane rebounded from a rare loss in the singles semifinals to win two doubles titles today and lead China to a sweep of all seven major events at the United States Open Table Tennis Championships.

title: TRAILER BUFFS ASSEMBLE A VILLAGE OF FELLOWSHIP
description: The 9,000 members of the Wally Byam trailer club rose from their seats at the Olympic Arena here, took off their dress berets and bowed their heads as Dan Wilson, their chaplain, opened the 28th annual international rally with a prayer.

title: AS CONVOY TRAVELS BY: 'MAY GOD BE WITH YOU'
description: As the 39 freed hostages were driven from Beirut to Damascus today, Lebanese civilians came out along the mountainous, war-ravaged route to watch and sometimes to greet the Americans.

title: Facility Tries to Save Rare Whale and Its Baby
description: Trainers at Gulf World, a marine attraction, tried today to coax an ailing, 1,000-pound pygmy sperm whale into nursing her baby.

title: 'JAPANESE' NOVA'S SALES ARE DELIGHTFUL TO G.M.
description: To Hector Lima, the only American characteristics about the new Chevrolet Nova he purchased recently were the nameplate on its grill and the fact that it was manufactured in the United States. There, he contended, its Yankee traits ended.

title: A FIRST-TERM LEGISLATOR LEARNS ROPES IN ALBANY
description: There are still signs that Catherine T. Nolan is a novice when it comes to the business of legislating.

title: TENS OF THOUSANDS MARCH IN 16TH ANNUAL PARADE BY HOMOSEXUALS
description: Tens of thousands of people followed a lavender stripe down Fifth Avenue yesterday as they cheered, chanted and danced in the 16th annual Lesbian/ Gay Pride Day parade.

title: No Glitter for Goldin
description: The City Comptroller has every intention of leaving home without it.

title: PANEL, FAULTING MILITARY HOSPITAL PROJECTS, PROPOSES THREAT TO DENY FUNDS
description: A panel of health experts convened by the Pentagon urged today that the military services be denied funds for building new hospitals unless they adopted better methods for evaluating wartime and peacetime medical requirements.

title: Other Ways to Help Poorest of the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET DEFECTOR ACCUSED OF FABRICATIONS IN BOOK
description: A magazine article charging that a former Soviet diplomat made up important parts of his best-selling book, with the apparent complicity of the Central Intelligence Agency, has evoked heated denials from the American intelligence community. Moreover, defenders say that even if some dates in the book are incorrect and some passages embellished, the overall thrust - that the author spied for the United States while serving as the senior Soviet official at the United Nations, until his defection in 1978 -is essentially correct.

title: Tennessee Bank Fails
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday that the deposit liabilities of the First Bank and Trust, Tracy City, Tenn., have been assumed by the First National Bank of Shelbyville, Shelbyville, Tenn. The failed bank's two offices will reopen Monday as branches of the First National Bank of Shelbyville.

title: U-Haul Complaint
description: The Federal Trade Commission's complaint against U-Haul International, the nation's largest renter of trucks and trailers, is a ''gross injustice,'' a company official said.

title: Bill to Curb Takeovers Fought
description: The securities industry is mounting a last-ditch effort to defeat an anti-takeover bill passed by the New York State Legislature late last week, but it is off to a rocky start.

title: Cuomo Aide to Meet With Doctors on Bill
description: Governor Cuomo's counsel will meet here Tuesday with officials from local medical societies to discuss their concerns about the malpractice-insurance legislation that was passed in the closing hours of the legislative session.

title: CHEESE MICROBE UNDERSCORES MYSTERY
description: AT least 43 people died recently after eating a Mexican-style cheese containing the bacteria Listeria monocytogenes, one of the most mysterious of all microbes. The outbreak primarily affected California residents and is still under investigation. It highlights how much even the most sophisticated doctors have yet to learn about this microbe and all the others that cause the myriad infectious diseases. Many experts mistakenly believed that infectious diseases would no longer be important after the advent of antibiotics and immunizations.

title: New York City Prices $350 Million of Bonds
description: New York City tentatively priced $350 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: DULL AND BAFFLING GRAND PRIX
description: Automobile racing, the only sport in which changing a tire quickly is considered an athletic feat, poses a unique problem for television. In a sense, it is the most familiar sport in the country, since anyone who has ever changed lanes on the highway has participated at the amateur level. But the way the game is frequently played at the Grand Prix level, over winding courses the cameras cannot encompass and in the absence of much bumper-to-bumper drama, can make the sport seem both dull and baffling to viewers who are not devotees.

title: FOR MANY BUSINESSES, A 4-DAY WEEKEND IS DUE
description: Although most companies will conduct business on Friday, many have decided to give their employees the day off to create a four-day weekend for the Fourth of July holiday.

title: POLL BACKS RAISES IN TEACHERS' PAY
description: The public believes that teachers should receive higher salaries and is willing to pay higher taxes to provide them, according to a poll by the Gallup Organization. The poll, made public today by the National Education Association, also showed support for competency testing for teachers.

title: ORDER TO ADD BOYS UPSETS CITY HIGH SCHOOL FOR GIRLS
description: The valedictorian is always a girl. The student body president is always a girl. The captain of the softball team is always a girl, and the girls of Washington Irving High School want to keep it that way.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Women Advance in Agriculture
description: MORE women are studying for jobs in agriculture, in areas ranging from animal production and agricultural business management to horticulture and other specialties.

title: IN JERSEY CITY, THE MAYOR IS SWORN IN TWO TIMES
description: Anthony R. Cucci was sworn in twice today as Jersey City's 40th Mayor.

title: The Beach Boys Again
description: As long as Ronald Reagan is President, the Beach Boys seem to have a secure place at the celebration of the Fourth of July in the capital. They were featured performers on the Mall in 1980 and 1981, but were replaced by a rock group called Grass Roots in 1982.

title: RAMPAGING INMATES SEIZE TENNESSEE PRISON
description: Inmates armed with homemade knives and chains looted and burned three buildings at the Turney Center prison today and then took several other inmates hostage, in what began as a protest against a new law requiring them to wear striped uniforms, the authorities said.

title: SUPREME COURT DENIES RETARDED SPECIAL LEGAL STATUS UNDER LAW
description: While ruling that the Constitution does not give the mentally retarded special protection against official discrimination, the Supreme Court nonetheless concluded today that a Texas city's denial of a zoning permit for a home for the retarded was so irrational as to be unconstitutional.

title: Flexible Hours
description: Flexible work schedules, which allow 4 million Americans to choose shifts other than a standard 9 to 5 workday, can substantially improve productivity in cases where employees share the same work equipment, new research shows.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on June 18 with an article about a proposal for a domed stadium in Queens misidentified the hearing at which City Council President Carol Bellamy testified. It was a meeting of the city's Concessions Review Committee.

title: S.E.C. MAY BAR EXCLUSIONARY BIDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed yesterday barring any tender offer that does not apply equally to all shareholders. This action would prevent corporations from discriminating against certain shareholders - as Unocal Corporation did in its defense against T. Boone Pickens. It would also prevent raiders from adopting the same practice.

title: Cuban Aide Dropped, Continuing a Shake-Up
description: A senior Cuban minister was dismissed today in a continuing Government shakeup that is eventually expected to lead to a more prominent role for Fidel Castro's younger brother, Raul, and a change of foreign minister.

title: Science's Ethical Blind Spot on Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX PLAN: SMOKESTACK VIEW
description: Across the industrial belt, from the auto plants in the Middle West to the steel mills in the Northeast, the threat posed by President Reagan's tax plan seemed clear: Smokestack America was to be the sacrificial lamb in the effort to cut taxes for individuals and foster development of faster-growing sectors of the economy.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE Artwear gallery moved last week from 409 West Broadway to 456 West Broadway (near Prince Street), and the new location is a beauty. No more is it a little square box of a shop, but a two-story space fronted with a wall of glass that offers a tantalizing peek at a small pool with an ikebana arrangement of blue irises. Behind that, two jagged granite slabs form a broken frame through which one enters the gallery.

title: Deposits Up at Savings Units
description: Savers deposited $4.9 billion more at savings and loan institutions than they withdrew in May, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Whirlpool Amends Kitchenaid Plan
description: The Whirlpool Corporation has amended its plan to acquire the Kitchenaid business of Dart & Kraft Inc. and sell certain Kitchenaid assets to the Emerson Electric Company to overcome objections to the plan. Federal District Judge Alvin I. Krenzler issued a preliminary injunction on Friday in Cleveland to block the deal at the request of White Consolidated Industries and Magic Chef Inc., which claimed violations of antitrust law.

title: Masking Feelings
description: No one can accuse Mike Schmidt of lacking a sense of humor. The Phillies' first baseman returned to Philadelphia yesterday and mananged to turn a large round of boos at Veterans Stadium into cheers.

title: 10 TEACHERS ADVANCE TO SHUTTLE FLIGHT FINALS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named 10 teachers - six women and four men - as finalists for a berth on a space shuttle flight.

title: IN NEW ACCOUNT, AGCA TELLS OF A 4TH TURK AT SHOOTING OF JOHN PAUL
description: Mehmet Ali Agca reversed himself today and agreed to answer more questions in the trial of himself and seven other men on charges of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: Worst Opponent: The Weather
description: It may be America's largest state, but Alaska is singularly small-time when it comes to producing the very best athletes, and the chief reason is simple: cold, windy and snowy weather that trims the length of the competitive season in any number of autumn or spring sports and sometimes even makes travel impossible. So the way that Doug Herron has weathered the storms is really quite remarkable.

title: Not All Prostitution Is Forced Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SPIRIT OF JUNG, ANALYST CREATES THERAPY NEARER ART THAN SCIENCE
description: A CHINESE silk screen hangs over the couch in the consulting room of James Hillman, a Jungian analyst. The screen depicts a sage sitting on a bamboo deck, casting a doleful, cantankerous gaze at some exquisite birds. That image is a fitting emblem for Dr. Hillman, for he proposes to make one of the main goals of therapy the heightening of people's esthetic appreciation of the world around them. And in appraising the state of therapy in general, Dr. Hillman's outlook is as doleful and cantankerous as the Chinese sage's visage.

title: TV IN THE HOSTAGE CRISIS: REPORTER OR PARTICIPANT/
description: The role of television in the 17-day American hostage crisis promises to fuel debate that will be difficult to resolve. It is a matter that is troubling to many journalists because it appears to have set precedents for coverage of future such incidents.

title: Occidental Sale By Reuters
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had completed the previously announced sale of its Colombia-Cities Service Petroleum Corporation to the Shell Petroleum Company, a unit of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, for about $1 billion. Occidental said that it received $750 million in cash at the closing yesterday in New York and that it would receive an additional $200 million in cash as production reaches certain levels.

title: The Service You Get in a Service Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Amorous Pandas Renew Romance
description: Days after their decade-old romance appeared on the rocks, America's two giant pandas have surprised National Zoo keepers with a record triple tryst.

title: A Gallardo Play Wins Latino Contest
description: Edward Gallardo's ''Women Without Men'' yesterday was named the winner of the New York Shakespeare Festival's National Contest for Latino Plays.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BICKERSTAFF FINALLY ACHEIVES HIS GOAL
description: They were just trying to help. But during his 12-year tenure as an assistant coach for the Washington Bullets, Bernie Bickerstaff felt little consolation when friends tried to ease his frustration over never being offered a professional head coaching job. They sent him short, comforting notes, saying ''Good things come to those who wait,'' and ''Patience is a virtue.''

title: Homers Win for National
description: Hank Aaron, Bill Mazeroski, Joe Torre and Tommy Davis slugged home runs as the National League beat the American League, 7-3, in the fourth annual Cracker Jack Old Timers' Classic tonight. The five-inning game, which featured 20 Hall of Famers, was played before 26,770 fans.

title: Organ and Bells
description: The National Cathedral will offer its annual Fourth of July Organ Recital, with Douglas Major playing American music at 11 A.M. At noon the Washington Ringing Society will perform a complicated exercise in bell-rope pulling called a ''full peal attempt,'' which could last three and a half hours.

title: STATE LEGISLATURE'S SESSION IN ALBANY: WHO CONTRIBUTED WHAT
description: Governor Cuomo offered praise, sprinkled with criticism, to the leader of the State Senate as the Legislature straggled home Sunday for what the Governor described as ''a very long weekend.''

title: 65 STEPS FOR MAURICE CARTHON
description: In the catacombs of Giants Stadium, it is 65 steps from the Generals' locker room to the Giants' locker room. Maurice Carthon can take those steps now that he will be joining the Giants after three seasons as the Generals' fullback. Even as the Generals lost to the Baltimore Stars, 20-17, in a playoff game last night, the Giants had not yet acknowledged having signed him in March, but Maurice Carthon recently received a letter at his Teaneck, N.J., home from Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach.

title: YANKS WIN
description: Joe Cowley insists that it's nothing personal. The 26-year-old Yankee right-hander said that his success against the Blue Jays was not tied to the fact that Bobby Cox, Toronto's manager, was the manager of the Atlanta Braves for four of the eight years that Cowley languished in the Braves' farm system.

title: 3 EXECUTIVES GET 25 YEARS IN WORKER'S DEATH
description: Three former executives of a silver-recycling plant were sentenced today to 25 years in prison for murdering Stefan Golab, an employee who died after inhaling cyanide fumes on the job.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MINIATURE HARD DRIVE FITS ON A CARD
description: EVEN in the constantly shrinking world of computers, where a silicon chip the size of a fingernail can be etched with electronic pathways more complex than a street map of New York City, some technological feats are astonishing.

title: MILITARY OPTIONS IN RESERVE: A BOMBING AND A MANHUNT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were holding in reserve several military options in response to the hijacking of the Trans World Airlines plane. The options include a bombing strike against the Beirut airport, attacks on terrorist training camps and the use of agents to track down the hijackers.

title: Beame Was Real Hero of '75 Fiscal Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Delays Meeting Again
description: Eastern Airlines Inc. adjourned its annual meeting for a second time, saying it needs more time to count stockholders' votes on an anti-takeover measure proposed by the airline.

title: Accounts
description: Blistex Inc., to Stan Merritt Inc., for Kank-a, a home remedy.

title: Housing Bonds Set in Arkansas
description: The Arkansas Development Finance Authority yesterday tentatively priced $175 million of single-family housing revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Becker, at 17, Drawing Notice
description: The touts at the local betting parlors placed his photograph on a wall alongside the other Wimbledon favorites and tipped visitors that Boris Becker was certainly worth a wager of a pound or two. The crowds at the All England Club have also warmed to Becker, admiring a serve that can unstring an opponent's racquet and unravel his best laid plans.

title: MESA WILL POST GAIN ON UNOCAL
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, citing a number of complex accounting practices and tax rules, said yesterday that it would report an after-tax gain of about $83 million, or $1.22 a share, for the quarter ended June 30 as a result of its attempt to acquire the Unocal Corporation.

title: The Right Ounce of Prevention
description: Of course the United States is right to sponsor a boycott of Beirut's airport until some force in Lebanon deprives hijackers of that safe harbor. But let no one think this will add much to deterrence. Chaotic Lebanon is already boycotted by all but some small Middle Eastern airlines, and travelers need no further warnings about Beirut's hazards. Why not widen this campaign?

title: Coast, Jersey Financings
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company priced $207.8 million of municipal financings yesterday for the Modesto Irrigation District of California and the Cape May County Municipal Utilities Authority of New Jersey.

title: DOW RISES 1.68 IN LATE TURNAROUND
description: Wall Street stock prices moved to new highs again yesterday but did so reluctantly as most investors seemed to have focus much of their attention on the Fourth of July holiday.

title: ACID RAIN THREAT SHOWN ON NEW MAPS
description: Updated maps prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency show that broad areas of the Northeast and Middle West are susceptible to acid rain.

title: Guest-Worker Solution to Illegal Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A music review of Caramoor yesterday gave an incorrect date for the festival's end. Performances will continue through Aug. 25.

title: Wyse for Mattresses
description: The Cleveland office of Wyse Advertising has been named agency for the Stearns & Foster Bedding Company, also of that city. The agency will be doing both trade and consumer advertising for the mattresses with an annual budget of about $2 million.

title: Politics;   Presidential Candidates Anonymous
description: Contrary to published reports, nobody is running for President in 1985.

title: NOW COURTS ARE IN THE NEWS BUSINESS
description: The United States Supreme Court took a radical, though perhaps inadvertent, step a few weeks ago when it held that The Nation 671.6,0,165.6,2,1 65.6,0,174.8,2,515.2,0>magazine owes former President Ford $12,500 for quoting without permission and prior to publication approximately 300 words from his memoir, ''A Time to Heal.'' With this, it put the courts into the journalism business.

title: EARLY FAVORITES GIVE CLUE TO FALL FASHION TRENDS
description: While balmy days are spent seeking or avoiding a suntan, women all over the country are finding moments to check their local stores for the first shipments of fall fashions.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Co. has named Walter G. Montgomery senior vice president, corporate communications.

title: Shoe-Trade Ripples
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mexican Socialist Is Seized by Gunmen
description: Five gunmen kidnapped a former presidential candidate of Mexico's leading leftist party today, the party and a Government official said.

title: INTERVIEW: SEYMOUR PAPERT ON COMPUTERS
description: SEYMOUR PAPERT, a professor of mathematics and education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a major pioneer in the use of computers in elementary and secondary schools. Mr. Papert, a student of the late Swiss educator and psychologist Jean Piaget, is the creator of LOGO, the computer language most widely used with young children. His writings, including his book ''Mindstorms,'' published by Basic Books, have had considerable influence among educators in this country. Mr. Papert recently discussed his views on computers and education in an interview. Following are excerpts from that discussion:

title: MARTIN HORWITZ
description: Martin Horwitz, a lawyer and the former chairman of UV Industries Inc., died of cancer last night at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Zimbabwe Extends Vote Because of Lines at Polls
description: The Zimbabwean Government announced today that it would extend by two days the voting period in the first elections since independence because of an unexpectedly large turnout.

title: JERSEY RESERVOIRS GAIN, BUT RATIONING CONTINUES
description: The 12 reservoirs serving northeastern New Jersey have refilled steadily since mid-April, but state officials say they are still reluctant to relax water rationing there.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Letter: On Cargo Vessels;   The Cost of Repaying Ship Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-CAPTIVES SAY GUNMEN PLANNED TO KILL MILITARY MEN ONE BY ONE
description: The hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jet separated the American servicemen from the other passengers and intended to kill them one by one, some of the former hostages said here today.

title: Nehemiah Undecided
description: Renaldo Nehemiah said that a ruling by the International Amateur Athletic Federation arbitration panel allowing pro football players to compete in track and field has left him undecided whether to stay with the San Francisco 49ers or return to hurdling. ''I've waited three years for this ruling, and now I've got mixed emotions about what I'll do,'' said Nehemiah, the world record-holder in the 110-meter hurdles. A spokesman for The Athletics Congress, governing body of track and field in the United States, said he believed the I.A.A.F. Council must still approve the ruling.

title: RABBINICAL DIALOGUE: 3 BRANCHES OF U.S. JUDAISM TALK OF DIFFERENCES
description: American rabbis, deeply divided on such basic issues as how to define Jewish lineage and whether to ordain women, are beginning to discuss theological differences together on a national level for the first time in decades.

title: Come on Down!
description: Reporters and producers and sound men and hot-combed commentators who covered the Carter Administration and the Carter campaigns often numbed their friends and acquaintances by groaning about how boring it was to spend time in the Carter hometown, Plains, Ga. Now, however, enough time has passed so that an invitation to return to Plains might have some snob appeal in working-class-conscious Washington.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE BEACH Beach is not a word often associated with the Manhattan littoral, but the landfill for Battery Park City in lower Manhattan has given Creative Time Inc. a setting for ''Art on the Beach,'' which begins its seventh and final season there today.

title: EX-HOSTAGES TO GET PRESIDENTIAL WELCOME TODAY
description: President Reagan plans to welcome the returning American hostages on Tuesday afternoon in a ceremony at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland, the White House said today.

title: GROMYKO IS NAMED SOVIET PRESIDENT
description: The veteran Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, was named President of the Soviet Union today on the nomination of the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Advancing
description: President Reagan's new No. 1 advance man is James L. Hooley, a 34-year-old native of Albany who has been helping to get the Reagan show on the road since 1978.

title: RULING MEANS CITIES MUST WORK OUT HOW TO GET HELP TO PAROCHIAL PUPILS
description: Hundreds of school districts across the country have operated remedial programs in parochial schools like those of New York City and Grand Rapids, Mich., which the Supreme Court struck down yesterday.

title: STARS' DEFENSE RETIRES GENERALS
description: The Generals' season came to an end here tonight as the Baltimore Stars beat them, 20-17, in a first-round playoff game that was a mix of offensve blunders and defensive gems.

title: Beached Pygmy Whale Dies
description: A pygmy sperm whale that beached itself near here died today, but another whale believed to be its baby appears to have a ''better than 50-50 chance'' of survival, said Ron Hardy, co-owner of Gulf World, a marine attraction.

title: AUSTERITY IMPOSED ON ISRAEL IN PLAN TO CURB INFLATION
description: After a 20-hour Cabinet meeting, the Israeli Government declared an economic emergency today and imposed sweeping austerity measures intended to break the country's 260 percent inflation.

title: Gain From Pain
