description: Phil LoMedico of Bardonia, N.Y., was playing baseball for the University of Miami in 1974 when he bruised a bone in his left hand, an injury that caused no little sting at the plate if an opposing pitcher insisted on working him inside, especially when the temperatures turned chilly. So LoMedico patched together a crude little protector made of rubber and tape, finished the season at .354 and went about his business.

title: Iraqis Resume Raids
description: Iraqi planes resumed their raids on Iranian cities today after a 16-day respite, and Iran said a Kurdish refugee camp in the northwestern Ziveh region was hit. The Iranian press agency, in a report monitored in Cyprus, said one civilian was killed and 10 wounded. Iraq said a ''large maritime target'' was also attacked by Iraqi jet fighters near the Kharg Island oil terminal.

title: BOND PRICES END DAY MIXED
description: Interest rates edged higher yesterday as bond prices finished the day mixed in light trading.

title: Mary Kay Buyout
description: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc.'s board approved a sweetened leveraged buyout proposal that it valued at $19.25 a share, or a total of $404 million. The company said that it had entered into a definitive agreement with an investor group that includes Mary Kay Ash, the company's founder and chairman.

title: Just the Facts
description: When you're hot, you're hot. After Pedro Guerrero of Los Angeles had belted his 15th home run of June -and against Bruce Sutter, at that -he said: ''I don't know the location, I don't know what kind of pitch it was. I saw the ball, I swung at it, and I hit it.''

title: PRO-U.S. DOMINICA PREMIER WINS A SECOND 5-YEAR TERM
description: Prime Minister Eugenia Charles, a leading advocate of the United States invasion of Grenada in 1983, won a second five-year term today.

title: POLAND QUIET AS MEAT PRICES GO UP 15%
description: Meat prices were raised by as much as 15 percent today, completing a four-month cycle of food price increases that have been the focus of agitation by clandestine activists.

title: SUPERVISED NEW DEAL STUDIES
description: Ruth Eisner Brill, an economist who specialized in consumer, housing and labor issues during the New Deal era, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: Prosecution in Aquino Trial Will Appeal a Ruling on Ver
description: Prosecutors in the Benigno S. Aquino Jr. assasination case said today that they would appeal to the Philippine Supreme Court to reverse the trial court's rejection of evidence against Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the suspended Philippine Chief of Staff, and seven others charged with a cover-up in the killing of the opposition leader.

title: U.S. ANTIDRUG PLAN IS CRITICIZED
description: One of the Reagan Administration's principal efforts to stop drug smuggling has accomplished little in its first two years, a General Accounting Office report has concluded.

title: A March
description: In one of the not so predictable events, officials of the Daughters of the American Revolution, which at one time refused to accept blacks as members, will step off from the steps of Constitution Hall with officials of the Black Revolutionary War Patriots Foundation in a march to the edge of the Reflecting Pool. There they will reflect on the site of a proposed memorial for blacks who fought in the Revolutionary War. Then the D.A.R. will provide coffee, juice and doughnuts for the marchers in the lobby of Constitution Hall.

title: AILEEN DE GUNZBURG, BRONFMAN HEIRESS, DIES IN PARIS AT 60
description: Baroness Aileen Bronfman de Gunzburg, a member of the family that controls the Seagram Company and the wife of a prominent French banker and industrialist, died of cancer yesterday in Paris. She was 60 years old and maintained residences in New York and in West Palm Beach, Fla., as well as in Paris.

title: BEIRUT RETURNS TO NORMAL: SEVEN HOURS OF COMBAT
description: With the release of the 39 American hostages, Beirut returned to normal today.

title: MOSCOW EYE DOCTOR HAILS ASSEMBLY-LINE SURGERY AT CLINIC
description: SVYATOSLAV N. FYODOROV likes to call his clinic ''medical factory No. 1.'' The worker brigades are composed of doctors, and the row of supine figures on the conveyor belt are patients in need of eye surgery. It may not be what Henry Ford had in mind, but the idea is roughly the same.

title: OXYGEN ENRICHMENT CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to March 31
RKO Pictures Chairman
description: RKO Pictures Inc. has named its president, C. Robert Manby, 65 years old, to the newly created post of chairman, the company said. He will be succeeded as president by Mark Seiler, 37, who has been president of the company's RKO Film Group. Gerald Offsay, 31, formerly a partner in the Los Angeles law firm of Loeb & Loeb, will replace Mr. Seiler at the film group. RKO Pictures is a movie and video subsidiary of RKO General Inc., which is a unit of Gencorp Inc.

title: TAP DANCE: CHANGING TIMES
description: TAP happenings usually take improvisation to new heights, giving the participants free rein and creating a party mood at the same time. ''Sole Sisters'' lived up to that standard, in a performance presented by Jane Goldberg's Changing Times Tap Dancing Company on Thursday at Greenwich House Theater, 27 Barrow Street.

title: Approval Sought For ABC Merger
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. asked the Federal Communications Commission to approve its proposed merger with ABC Inc. and asked for a waiver to allow it to keep its lucrative Philadelphia TV station. The F.C.C. has never granted such a waiver.

title: FAILED CHINATOWN BANK DEFENDED BY CHAIRMAN
description: In his first public appearance since Federal authorities closed his bank on June 21, Kuang Hsung J. Chuang, chairman and president of the failed Golden Pacific National Bank, told a news conference yesterday that the bank's depositors, creditors and shareholders would get back all their money if the Government liquidated the bank judiciously.

title: The Levine School: Washington's Juilliard
description: Charles Williams, a baritone who is chairman of the voice department of the Levine School of Music in Washington, was in New York recently, sporting a ''Levine School'' T-shirt as he rehearshed the role of Sportin' Life for a Metropolitan Opera production of ''Porgy and Bess.''

title: RAY BRADBURY'S 'CROWD' ON HBO
description: LOOKING for material to supplement its basic movie service, Home Box Office has been flirting with the half-hour story form, which once was a staple of radio. The result has sometimes been embarrassing, as in the case of ''The Hitchhiker'' series. The serious little tales soon became a joke as viewers set about determining the exact moment the leading players would have to take off all their clothes. The pay-cable service has been more successful, however, with ''Ray Bradbury Theater,'' which features Mr. Bradbury's adaptations of his own short stories. This month's installment is ''The Crowd,'' which can be seen on HBO this evening at 10 o'clock.

title: A LOSS BUT NO REGRETS IN WADE'S FINALE
description: There was no tea and sympathy for Virginia Wade, just a glass of champagne to toast the recollections of good times spent at Wimbledon, many of them at Centre Court where Miss Wade made her farewell appearance in singles play today.

title: Iran Reports Air Attack By Iraq on Kurdish Camp
description: Iran said today that Iraqi warplanes attacked a Kurdish refugee camp, ending a 15-day Iraqi halt to raids on Iranian civilian centers in the Persian Gulf war.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
description: International

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Giants vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Francisco (Television - WTBS 3:05 P.M.) Basketball United States Basketball League All-Star Game, at Springfield, Mass. The Springfield Fame team, which is leading the new pro league, will meet a team of all-stars made up of players from the rest of the league that is expected to include 7-foot-6-inch Manute Bol. (Television - MSG Network, 8 P.M.) College: Elmcor Neighborhood League, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, tripleheader, 6 P.M., 7:15 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon, through July 7. (Television - Channel 4, 11:30 P.M. to 11:45 P.M.) Eastern Masters Circuit Men's 35 and Over, tournament, at the Cove Tennis Center, 60 Sea Cliff Ave., Glen Cove, L.I., 4 P.M. Early-round matches in the tournament, which runs through Saturday. There will be no competition Thursday. Track and Field Third annual National T.A.C. Youth Athletics Championships, at Mitchel Field, Uniondale, L.I., 9 A.M. Opening day of competition for boys and girls 9 to 18 years of age. More than 2,500 youngsters will compete today and tomorrow and then Friday, Saturday and Sunday. There will be no competition Thursday. Other Events BICYCLING: Tour de France continues through July 21.

title: COURT BIDS EXXON PAY $1.9 BILLION
description: A special Federal appeals court ruled today that the Exxon Corporation had overcharged customers who bought oil from a Texas field and that the company must pay about $1.9 billion in refunds and interest to the Government.

title: New System, New Rules
description: ''Eros and Venus - Locked Out.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MOUNTAIN OF NAMES: A History of the Human Family. By Alex Shoumatoff. 318 pages.

title: Ex-Diplomat Will Head The Americas Society
description: The Americas Society has appointed George W. Landau, a former diplomat, as its president, effective yesterday.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP 1.5% IN MAY
description: Construction spending, aided by continued strength in the business sector, climbed 1.5 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., said it acquired the brokerage transaction services division of Control Data Corp. for an undisclosed amount of cash and contingent payments based on business results for the next year.

title: Mine Planned Near Fire Site
description: About 40 laid-off miners have been recalled to create a new coal mine adjacent to the Wilberg Mine, where 27 workers remain buried after an underground fire last year. The Utah Power and Light Company said the miners, some of whom were laid off after the fire, will set up equipment for mining a 100-million-ton coal seam running perpendicular to tunnels where the 27 miners died.

title: IN PORTUGAL, POLITICS CAN WAIT, THE BEACH CANNOT
description: The Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares has all but fallen, but at the volunteer fire station on the Plaza of Happiness, there are few people who seem to care.

title: Rescuing the Numbat
description: Successful breeding in captivity of 10 numbats, one of the world's smallest marsupials, has raised hopes that the animals, so small that an adult can be held in one hand, can be saved from extinction. According to the Australian Science and Energy Newsletter, numbats were once a common sight in southern Australia, but clearing of their woodland habitat has left only two pockets in the southern part of western Australia.

title: CUSTOM CREAMERY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to MAY 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
description: International

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LASERS MAY REVOLUTIONIZE THE QUEST FOR EFFICIENT URANIUM 235 PRODUCTION
description: WHEN American physicists began racing to develop an atomic bomb before Germany or Japan could do so, one of their greatest challenges was producing the fuel needed for such a weapon. This had to be done either by extracting uranium 235, which occurs in tiny amounts in naturally occurring uranium, or by producing an artificial element, plutonium 239, in nuclear reactors.

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NOW FREE, 39 LOOSEN LAST BONDS
description: This was the day when the 39 Americans who are still popularly called hostages actually broke free of the last of their physical confines: the high metal fences of an Air Force medical base here.

title: OUTER SUBURBS CONFRONTING LIMITS OF GROWTH
description: After a decade of corporate relocations and business expansion, the outer ring of New York suburbs is being swept up in a home-building boom.

title: Hockey Signings
description: Mikko Makela, a right wing who was the leading goal scorer in the Finnish League last season, was signed to a multiyear contract by the Islanders.

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: STUART ADAMS LYMAN
description: Stuart Adams Lyman, former chairman of the board of the Franklin Savings Bank, died of cancer last Thursday at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Quogue, L.I.

title: The Airline Acquisitions
description: The airline industry has been roiled by the proposals of United Airlines to buy the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways and the Texas Air Corporation's agreement to acquire Trans World Airlines, creating the nation's second-largest air carrier.

title: Investors Set Lloyd's Suit
description: Investors in Lloyd's of London insurance syndicates have decided to sue in British and American courts against underwriting losses they face totaling almost $170 million.

title: NEW YORK CITY WEIGHS TAPPING HUDSON WATER
description: Rain was plentiful in the New York City area last month. But watershed areas upstate that supply most of the city's water were abnormally dry, and the prospect for even stricter water-conservation measures has increased, officials said yesterday.

title: Noncustodial Fathers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: THREE PLAYS IN WEST END
description: Like Broadway, the West End is longer on fluff, especially American musical fluff, than serious drama this summer. Fifteen months after its opening, Michael Frayn's ''Benefactors'' remains unchallenged as the London commercial theater's most highly regarded new drama. But if ''Waste,'' the best play I've seen in the West End since ''Benefactors,'' is not exactly new, it might as well be. Written by Harley Granville Barker in 1907 and promptly banned, ''Waste'' has rarely been seen anywhere since its belated London premiere in 1936. In its current Shaftesbury Avenue revival, which originated at the Royal Shakespeare Company last winter, the play seems a completely contemporary portrait of needlessly wasted public and private lives.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT RULING ON GRAND RAPIDS SCHOOL PROGRAMS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision today that declared unconstitutional a program of public aid to parochial schools in Grand Rapids, Mich. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the opinion, as he did in a companion case striking down a similar program administered by the New York City public schools. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor dissented in part. Associate Justices Byron R. White and William H. Rehnquist dissented.

title: Marietta to Buy 25% of Equatorial
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said that it had agreed to buy a 25 percent stake in the Equatorial Communications Company for $50 million.

title: MEDICARE PAYMENTS RAISED FOR HOSPITALS
description: Under pressure from Congress and a Federal judge, the Reagan Administration authorized higher Medicare payments today for hospitals serving large numbers of poor people.

title: 2 AIRLINE OFFICES ATTACKED IN MADRID
description: One woman was killed and at least 27 people were wounded today by a bomb that destroyed the downtown offices of British Airways here. Minutes later, two gunmen sprayed the nearby office of Alia, Jordan's national airline, with bullets, wounding two people.

title: Times Mirror
description: The Times Mirror Company said its board had authorized the company to buy up to 7.5 million of its common shares, or 10.4 percent of the total outstanding, at $60 each in cash.

title: JEW SAYS BEIRUT CAPTIVITY 'WAS NOT A PARTY'
description: ''I never thought I would be glad to see Germany,'' Richard P. Herzberg told his new wife over dinner in the restaurant of the Nassauer Hof Hotel here today.

title: PARK AIDE TESTIFIES HE USED FLAME TO CHECK FIREPROOFING OF CASTLE
description: The safety manager at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park testified today that he had held a flame to the facade of the park's fun house to make sure it was fireproof. He said he had not tested the separate main building that burned last year, killing eight teen-age patrons.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: OTHER FIRES RAGING ON COAST
description: As residents of the Mission Valley community of Normal Heights returned to pick through the remains of their charred neighborhood, fire officials announced today that Sunday's fire was caused by an incendiary device in the brushy canyon below.

title: U.S. OPENS DIPLOMATIC DRIVE TO 'ISOLATE' BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: The United States announced today that in response to the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines plane last month by Lebanese Shiite extremists, it was beginning a diplomatic campaign ''to isolate'' Beirut International Airport.

title: MOSELEY, HALLGARTEN, ESTABROOK & WEEDEN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Oilers Get Rozier
description: The Houston Oilers ended a year-long pursuit of the running back Mike Rozier yesterday, signing the former Heisman winner to a four-year contract that will pay him a reported total of $2.25 million. Rozier became available to the Oilers when he bought out his contract with the Jacksonville Bulls. Houston held his National Football League draft rights.

title: PBS'S LATIN JAZZ SERIES WITH PAQUITO D'RIVERA
description: THE Cuban alto saxophonist Paquito d'Rivera whizzes through jazz standards and his own Latin-flavored pieces in ''Heatwave,'' tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13. The half-hour program is the first of two shows featuring Latin jazz performers; next week's subject is the conga virtuoso Mongo Santamaria.

title: Move Member to Act As Her Own Lawyer
description: Ramona Africa, who survived the fire that destroyed the house of the radical group Move and killed 11 of its members, today called a judge a ''liar.'' She also insisted that she would act as her own lawyer at her preliminary hearing on charges growing out of the battle with the police.

title: NEW MAN IN SOVIET ELITE: A LOYALIST AND INNOVATOR
description: The man promoted today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the nation's ruling Politburo fits the new Soviet chief's profile for leadership: relatively young, tough, hard on corruption but open to economic experimentation.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to April 28
IS THIS THE AGE OF HYPERINVENTOR OR PONDEROUS PEDSETRIAN?
description: WHAT an exciting thing it is to be alive in this hyperinventive age!

title: Why the U.S. Was a Target
description: The hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 has once again raised the question of whether the United States' close association with Israel is a detriment to American interests in the Arab world. That, certainly, is what the hijackers were trying to impress upon us at the point of their rifles. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth. America is a target not because of who its friends are but because of what it is and what it represents.

title: COMPUTER-AIDED MARSHALS TRACK PARKING VIOLATORS
description: Herbert Engelhardt was, as they say, minding his own business and about to park his Chevrolet on a street in upper Manhattan when an unmarked car drove up beside him. ''Pull over please, we're city marshals,'' said a man inside the car.

title: Swiss Expel Soviet Diplomat
description: A senior Soviet diplomat accredited to the United Nations in Geneva has been expelled from Switzerland on charges of spying, the Federal Prosecutor's office said today. The diplomat, it said, had been engaged ''for a long period'' in espionage against Switzerland and ''third countries.'' It did not identify the diplomat or the other countries.

title: Trial Opens in Chicago For 4 Puerto Ricans
description: A Federal judge today refused to dismiss conspiracy charges against one of four people linked to the Puerto Rican terrorist group, F.A.L.N., the Armed Forces of National Liberation.

title: NEW LOOK AT AIDS SUSPECT
description: NEW YORK State health officials plan to test a small number of blood samples to determine what role, if any, African swine fever virus plays in causing acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Bridge: National Bodies Cooperate In Formation of Irish Team
description: It is perhaps remarkable that an island that has a world reputation for disharmony should be entirely harmonious in the matter of bridge organization. For 30 years, the Irish Bridge Union, a combination of the national bodies of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland with a membership of 21,000, has sent teams representing ''Ireland'' to European and world championships.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a reduction of income taxes of $239 in the latest quarter and $13,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $317,000. c-After a tax credit of $651,000.

title: A Gap in Anti-Bias Law
description: New York's highest court holds that Mayor Koch lacks the legal power to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals by those doing business with the city. It reversed an intermediate court's decision - which we found persuasive - that the Mayor's duty not to discriminate was ample authority for him to require social agencies to sign a no-bias pledge.

title: NEW YORK'S RESCUE: THE OFFSTAGE DRAMA
description: If there was one 24-hour period during New York City's long fiscal crisis when it seemed as if bankruptcy might finally be at hand, it began on the evening of Oct. 16, 1975.

title: COURT REFUSES TO LIMIT RICO SUITS
description: The Supreme Court today refused to set limits on using a powerful Federal anti-racketeering law as the basis for private lawsuits charging ordinary business fraud.

title: Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would gradually phase out elevator manufacturing in Randolph, N.J., eliminating about 300 jobs, and would look to foreign suppliers for elevator parts.

title: The U.N. Today: July 2, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: John Nyati Pokela, 63, Dies; South African Black Activist
description: John Nyati Pokela, the chairman of the Pan-Africanist Congress, an antiapartheid organization banned in South Africa, died here Sunday, Zimbabwe's state-run press agency reported today. He was 63 years old. Mr. Pokela was imprisoned in South Africa for 13 years for violating laws on sabotage and propaganda.

title: WALDRON AND HAIMSOHN
description: AS a performing duo, the veteran jazz pianist Mal Waldron and the experimental singer-dancer-poet Jana Haimsohn make an exceedingly odd couple. Mr. Waldron is an unsentimental, free-jazz minimalist who roams the lower end of the keyboard exploring elementary themes in a style that is at once rough and ruminative.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
Castle, Flexi-Van
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that its shareholders approved the company's merger with the Flexi-Van Corporation. More than 76 percent of the outstanding shares were voted in favor of the merger at a special shareholders' meeting in Honolulu, where the company is based. Flexi-Van shareholders meeting earlier in Los Angeles also approved the merger, which becomes effective Tuesday.

title: China Oil Royalty Shift
description: China, in an attempt to encourage foreign development of small offshore oilfields, will waive royalty payments on certain wells developed from its second round of international bidding, a Government spokesman said today. The Chinese Government normally collects a royalty of 12.5 percent of annual production. But Chen Bingqian of the China National Offshore Oil Corporation said that in the latest bidding, there would be no royalties on wells producing fewer than 7 million barrels of oil a year.

title: HIGH COURT BARS PUBLIC TEACHERS IN CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that public school systems may not send teachers into parochial school classrooms to provide remedial or enrichment instruction.

title: THE STAGE: 'MEASURE FOR MEASURE'
description: THE ''Measure for Measure''

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Planning in Plenty of Time
description: Christmas comes early in an election year.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TNR TECHNICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Compo Industries
description: Compo Industries, a specialty chemicals company based in Waltham, Mass., said that it had agreed to merge with the Ausimont subsidiary of the Milan-based Montedison S.p.A., a chemicals and industrial products concern. Under terms of the plan, shareholders of both companies will exchange their stock for an equal number of shares of the new company growing out of the merger, which will be based in the Netherlands. Compo shareholders will own about 13.5 percent of the new company and Montedison will own the remainder.

title: HOWE TERMED UNFIT
description: Steve Howe, the Dodger relief pitcher, was called ''incapable of handling his assignment'' by club officials today, one day after he failed to show up for a game against the Braves.

title: LISTENED TO ANY GOOD BOOKS LATELY?
description: On a recent weekend, as John deCsepel, a stock broker, pulled weeds from his garden in Connecticut, he switched on his portable cassette player and listened to a new chapter of ''Walden'' by Henry David Thoreau.

title: Koch Urges Retaliation By U.S. in the Mideast
description: Mayor Koch said today that despite the danger to the seven hostages still held or missing in Lebanon, ''we must take diplomatic, economic and military action against those countries which support terrorism within their borders.''

title: 11 PLEAD NOT GUILTY TO RULING ORGANIZED CRIME IN NEW YORK
description: Eleven defendants pleaded not guilty yesterday to a racketeering indictment charging them with participation in a ''commission'' governing organized crime in New York City.

title: President Is Appointed At Chicago Milwaukee
description: The Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, which last February sold the Milwaukee Road, its bankrupt railroad company, to the Soo Line Railroad Company for $571 million, said yesterday that Edwin Jacobson had been named president and chief executive officer.

title: International Post Filled by A.T.&T.
description: John E. Berndt, an A.T.&T. executive with little overseas experience, yesterday was named president and chief executive of A.T.&T. International, a subsidiary that sells company-built equipment overseas.

title: 60-Second Debate
description: Steven D. Symms Republican Senator from Idaho Enactment of the uniform speed limit had two positive effects. It saved fuel, and it saved lives.

title: The Anger of Mr. Mugabe
description: Like the man in the rhyme who isn't there but won't go away, Ian Smith lingers as a political presence in Zimbabwe. It was Mr. Smith, you will remember, who in 1965 proclaimed the illegal independence of what was then called Rhodesia. His white minority regime spurned all proposals for majority rule and waged a bloody war against two guerrilla armies until 1979, when Britain brokered a bargain that gave Zimbabwe independence under a multiracial Constitution.

title: Getting 'the Message'
description: There have been two major discoveries in the latest trial in Federal Court on the proposed Westway project. One is that the Army Corps of Engineers, the agency that earlier this year granted the go-ahead landfill permit for this 4.2-mile highway and real estate plan with its $4 billion price tag, kept no records of what took place at its internal meetings - in defiance of the Federal judge's order to do so.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
EUROPEAN PROBE IS AIMED AT HALLEY'S VEILED HEART
description: WITH Halley's comet drawing ever closer, now 400 million miles from the Earth out between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter, the Europeans are dispatching their first interplanetary spacecraft as part of an extensive international effort to visit and study the celebrated comet next March.

title: Lufthansa Orders 10 Boeing 737-300's
description: West Germany's national airline, Lufthansa, ordered planes today from the Boeing Company that are worth up to $500 million. The order came just days after Lufthansa made a major purchase from Airbus Industrie, Boeing's European rival.

title: Bank Names Merger Chief
description: David E. Dougherty, a senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, has been named to head the mergers and acquisitions group of the bank's corporate finance department, the company said. Mr. Dougherty, 35 years old, has been head of the bank's public finance group. He succeeds Howard Schneider, who will become senior vice president in the corporate strategic planning department.

title: 253d Captain
description: She became a captain in the Police Department yesterday. And that, she said, made her very happy but a little lonely.

title: Courier Preparing For Battle
description: A WEEK before Federal Express begins its six-market European service July 15, DHL Worldwide Express, now the dominant service there, will start to run an expensive, distinctive and memorable commercial that will promote the company's service here and abroad.

title: Indian Tribe Offering Is Held
description: The first tax-exempt municipal bond offering ever by an American Indian tribe to institutional investors was held last week, when $30.2 million of revenue bonds were issued by the Jicarilla Apache tribe of northwestern New Mexico through Boettcher & Company, a Denver-based investment banking firm.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results include gains from the sale of real estate of 21 cents a share in the latest year and 10 cents a share in the previous year.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE IN 3 WORKS
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM offered three works from its repertory on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Once again, the dancing was splendid.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Yr to March 31
Article 092907 -- No Title
description: Scoa Industries, a general merchandise and footwear retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, said that its board had received a leveraged buyout offer valued at $35 a share, or a total of $574 million, from a group including management.

title: METS ARE PUZZLED BY LACK OF HITTING
description: Dave Johnson, who once got the computers at Johns Hopkins University to produce a scheme titled ''Optimization of the Baltimore Orioles' Lineup,'' sat on the bench and wished that he could devise something called ''Optimization of the New York Mets' Lineup.'' But, he lamented, ''there's not much you can do when you don't hit the ball.''

title: EXPOS EDGE CARDINALS ON DAWSON'S HIT
description: Andre Dawson's 10th-inning single scored Jim Wohlford to give the Expos a 3-2 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Profit Estimate Fine-Tuning
description: WALL STREET analysts are fine-tuning their estimates for second-quarter earnings that will be announced in coming weeks. For the stock market, it promises to be a period of testing, inasmuch as a strong economic recovery turned the second quarter of 1984 into the most profitable three-month period for that year.

title: SYRIAN TV VIEWS TUNING IN, TOO
description: Syrian television today showed scenes of the American air hostages being released from captivity in Beirut, arriving here and then being greeting in West Germany by Vice President Bush.

title: CALIFORNA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Amdahl Pact With A.T.&T.
description: The Amdahl Corporation said today that it had agreed to supply the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with products for use in computer-to-computer communications networks. The products will be used by A.T.&T. internally and also resold by A.T.&T. to customers who want to build private data communications networks.

title: American Hospital To Consider Offer
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said its board would meet on July 12 to consider a revised buyout offer from Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. Meanwhile, American Hospital and the Hospital Corporation of America have delayed meetings at which their shareholders were to have voted on the proposed merger of the two companies.

title: State Welfare Workers Strike in Pennsylvania
description: Two public employee unions, objecting to proposed reductions in days off and sick leave, today struck the State of Pennsylvania.

title: BALL'S HUTTON ROLE SCRUTINIZED
description: George L. Ball, president of Prudential-Bache Securites, came under renewed scrutiny yesterday concerning what he did or did not know about the illegal check writing scheme carried out at E.F. Hutton & Company while he served as its president.

title: New York State
description: A $100 million issue of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation first-mortgage bonds was tentatively price yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds, due in 2015, are offered at a price of par, to yield 12 percent. They are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB-plus by S.& P. Proceeds will be used for retirement of debt and capital expenditures.

title: Beecham Ex-Chairman To Take Over at Thorn
description: Sir Graham J. Wilkins, who retired last year as chairman and chief executive of the Beecham Group at the age of 60, was named to those posts at Thorn EMI yesterday after Thorn's board forced the resignation of Peter Laister, who ran the troubled electronics and entertainment conglomerate for just over a year.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $467,000, or 9 cents a share, for an accounting change. The company said its 1984 revenue for 9 months has been restated.

title: TEACHERS REUNITE READING AND WRITING
description: ''I was amazed. I never really anticipated that these kindergarten children would learn to read without traditional teaching methods. Certainly, we'd been learning how to write, but we'd had no reading books, no groups, no workbooks, no flashcards.''

title: 'TROPICAL SURGE'
description: THE Jazz Festival's ''Tropical Surge'' concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday night began gloriously and went rapidly downhill thereafter. The first band to perform was Toure Kunda, a group from Senegal that is led by three brothers.

title: U.S. Radio Broadcasts Assailed by the G.A.O.
description: The General Accounting Office has reported that an obscenity was used to describe an unidentified Polish Government official in a broadcast financed by the United States Government.

title: New Carrier for British Navy
description: The Ark Royal, Britain's third aircraft carrier, entered service today. The 20,000-ton ship joins the carriers Illustrious and Invincible in Britain's scaled-down navy air arm.

title: Natalie Hammond, 81; An Artist and Inventor
description: Natalie Hays Hammond, an artist, inventor and founder of the Hammond Museum and Stroll Garden in North Salem, N.Y., died Sunday of heart failure at her home in North Salem. She was 81 years old.

title: Passport in a Pinch
description: When John O'Keefe tried to get a passport last week, the lines were too long. So he went to Philadelphia.

title: Avanced Reading
description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, at Comiskey Park last night, reiterated that he would not intervene at present to force a settlement in the labor negotiations between the players and owners.

title: U.S. REMAINS WARY DESPITE SYRIAN AID
description: American officials say that the role of Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, in resolving the Beirut hostage crisis has improved his image in Washington for the moment and led to hopes that better relations between the two Governments might be possible.

title: Chess: Kasparov Defeats Huebner In Title Preparation Match
description: Gary Kasparov, the challenger for the world championship, has won a decisive victory in a training match with the West German grandmaster Robert Huebner in Hamburg.

title: Ally & Gargano Makes Some Major Changes
description: Meanwhile at Ally & Gargano, long the Federal Express agency, there have been major changes of a non-traumatic nature.

title: MARRIAGE OF COMPUTER AND THE TELEPHONE CALL
description: TECHNOLOGIES and sciences have a tendency to merge:

title: World Bank Loans Off
description: Lending by the World Bank, the biggest international source of aid for poor countries, reached $14.4 billion for the fiscal year that ended Sunday, down from $15.5 billion the previous year, a bank spokesman, Thomas A. Blinkhorn, said today.

title: WARD ABOLISHES DESK SUMMONS IN DRUG ARRESTS
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has ordered a halt to a discretionary department practice of giving ''desk appearance tickets'' - or summonses - to some people arrested on misdeameanor charges of selling small amounts of marijuana.

title: Airport Bomb Jokes: Britain Is Unamused
description: An Arab diplomat and a Scottish diver were fined today for having told airport security officials in jest that their baggage carried bombs.

title: Hazards Vertical and Horizontal
description: The American economist John Kenneth Galbraith evoked the only spontaneous outburst of applause at an international colloquium on nuclear war and nuclear proliferation that concluded here Sunday. Mr. Galbraith, mildly rebuking a militantly anti-Soviet speech by Richard Perle, a Reagan Administration nuclear expert, observed that the conference would not ''get far on the assumption that one side is completely wrong and one side is completely right.''

title: SUDAN'S NEED: A FAST TRACK FOR FOOD AID
description: A sprinkling of rain fell here the other night, and it set off a flurry of activity.

title: JUANTORENA JOIN'S CUBA'S SPORTS EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: Alberto Juantorena, the Cuban track star who in the 1976 Montreal Olympics became the first runner to win gold medals in both the 400-meter and 800-meter events, has quietly become an executive in Cuba's sporting world.

title: Forstmann Unit President
description: Richard W. Vieser, formerly president and chief operating officer of the McGraw-Edison Company, has been named to head a new company formed by Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment partnership whose bid to buy McGraw-Edison failed last March.

title: SOME STILL SYMPATHETIC; OTHERS AREN'T SO SURE
description: The day after their release, some of the Americans held hostage in Beirut continued to express sympathy for the cause of their Shiite captors. But others said they were angry at the Lebanese and suggested that the level of good feeling would drop in a few days.

title: DRAWING THE BATTLE LINES
description: ARCHITECTURE has always had its star wars, and sniping is not unknown. But it was something of a shock when, in accepting an award recently from the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, Abraham W. Geller used the platform to condemn the proposed addition to the Whitney Museum and criticized the selection of Michael Graves, its architect.

title: People
description: Neal Martineau has joined Tucker Wayne & Co., Atlanta, as senior vice president and executive creative director.

title: Schroeder, Heart Patient, Goes on Two Outings
description: William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart patient, has taken his first outings since suffering a second stroke, and he may be discharged from the hospital, a spokesman said today.

title: EVEN FROZEN AND DUNKED IN ALCOHOL, LURKING BACTERIA MENACE TRAVELERS
description: AFTER a sweltering morning of traipsing through temples in Yucatan, or a parched afternoon of gazing at pyramids in Giza, a lukewarm soda just won't do.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was not a party.'' - Richard P. Herzberg, a freed hostage. [A7:3.]

title: Sovran Financial
description: The Sovran Financial Corporation, a bank holding company based in Norfolk, Va., said that it had agreed to acquire the D.C. National Bank Corporation in a stock swap valued at $64.5 million. D.C. National is the holding company of D.C. National Bank, the sixth-largest bank in Washington. The merger is contingent on the passage of an interstate banking bill by Washington's City Council and approval of shareholders and regulators. Under the agreement, D.C. National will operate as a separate unit of Sovran under the name Sovran Bank/D.C. National.

title: A Good Lesson for Church and State
description: The new Supreme Court ruling on aid to parochial schools will disrupt popular school programs in New York and other large districts. Coping with those difficulties, however, is preferable to teaching the wrong lesson about church and state.

title: PLAYWRIGHT CONFERENCE WILL DEVELOP 15 PLAYS
description: Fifteen plays have been chosen for development at the 21st annual National Playwrights Conference in Waterford, Conn., which opens Dunay and continues through Aug. 4. The conference, sponsored by the Eugene O'Neil Theater Center, is under the artistic direction of Lloyd Richards, who is also Dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Prepertory Theater.

title: Bath Iron Works Rejects Bid By Strikers to Resume Talks
description: Bath Iron Works officials, saying they would not be forced into a ''public chess game,'' today declined an open invitation by leaders of a striking 4,500-member union to resume contract talks at ''any date.''

title: ALO-SCHERER HEALTHCARE YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CENTURY MEDICORP reports earnings for Year to Feb. 28
WHITE HOUSE DENIES NEW FUNDS TO FIGHT TERRORISM, SENATOR SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration has rejected a request by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for $11 million in extra funds for counterterrorism programs, according to a member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Eye on Home Turf
description: Junket is still a dirty word in Washington, and sensitive members of Congress embarking on Government-financed travel are likely these days to make public a business itinerary as they depart.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 3, 1985
description: The Economy

title: AS AMERICAN AS A NEW ENGLANDER SHORE DINNER
description: ''A MAINE shore picnic may start off in bathing suits, but it almost always ends up in down vests,'' William Meisle says with a warning look at his visitors. ''By nightfall you're wrapped in blankets and huddled round the fire. But if it's been a good picnic, that's all part of the fun.''

title: THE PROJECTS' RESIDENTS ARE DIVIDED ON SWEEPS
description: When the heavy knock came on the door of Apartment 3-A, 300 Dumont Avenue in the Tilden Houses in Brooklyn, 23-year-old Cheryl Lynch hid in a closet.

title: Advice to Rookies
description: Stay out of bars.

title: European Craft Lofted To Meet With Comet
description: The European Space Agency today launched its Giotto spacecraft, Europe's first interplanetary probe, which is to sail to a rendezvous with Halley's comet next year.

title: The Limited Sells Convertible Issue
description: The Limited Inc. priced $125 million of convertible subordinated debentures at par yesterday, through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company.

title: AGCA ASSERTS BULGARIAN TOLD HIM WHEN AND WHERE TO ATTACK POPE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca testified today that a Bulgarian diplomat gave him and other Turkish gunmen instructions on when and where to kill Pope John Paul II and how to leave misleading clues for the police.

title: ISRAELIS SEEM TO ACCEPT AUSTERITY WITH RELIEF
description: About 1.5 million Israeli workers went on a nationwide strike today, bringing the country to a partial standstill in protest against Monday's Government-ordered austerity measures.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Transportation revenues were $1.4 billion for the latest quarter compared with $1.4 billion for the year- ago quarter. For the latest and year- ago 6 month periods transportation revenues were $2.7 billion and $2.8 billion respectively. Natural resource revenues were $469 million for the latest quarter compared with $573 million for the year-ago quarter. For the latest and year-ago 6 month periods natural resource revenues were $1.2 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
OCCIDENTAL BEGINS CHINA COAL PROJECT
description: With a roar from the exhaust of an earth-moving shovel, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation inaugurated its partnership today in the Pingshuo open-pit coal mine, establishing with China a prototype of the investment partnership that the leadership in Peking regards as crucial to its plans for a modern economy.

title: 'PALE RIDER' HEADS LIST IN THEATERS
description: Clint Eastwood rode into 1,700 theaters last weekend on a pale horse and proved that the western is not dead so long as Mr. Eastwood stars in it. ''Pale Rider,'' which is also directed by Mr. Eastwood, sold $9.1 million worth of tickets, the top-grossing movie of the weekend.

title: WHEN RICH AND FAMOUS ARE ALSO THE NEIGHBORS
description: Eddie Murphy is a household word here. So is Stevie Wonder. And Joe Piscopo.

title: Advertising;   New Path In Merrill Campaign
description: MERRILL LYNCH & COMPANY returns to network TV advertising tomorrow with a totally new bull-less campaign and a $30 million budget that should re-establish it as the biggest advertiser in all of brokerage land.

title: EXCERPTS FROM NOMINATING SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today nominating Andrei A. Gromyko as the Soviet President, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: S.&P. Raises City's Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised the debt rating of $7 billion of New York City's general obligation bonds yesterday to BBB-plus from BBB.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said all year-ago figures were restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid on April 29.

title: AN ENDURING RUSSIAN FACE
description: A Western diplomat, trying to break the ice with a poker-faced Andrei A. Gromyko at the start of a round of talks, once asked whether he had had a good breakfast. Pausing just long enough to make his questioner feel a bit uncomfortable, Mr. Gromyko answered, ''Perhaps.''

title: WITH DAM, THE GOOD TIMES EBB IN PARAGUAY
description: On a hillside within sight of the world's largest hydroelectric complex, hundreds of newly built homes now stand empty, their windows boarded up, their gardens overgrown and their tenants scattered in all directions.

title: Express Kicker Jumps
description: A day after Mike Rozier left the United States Football League to join the Houston Oilers of the National Football League, Tony Zendejas, the place-kicker of the Los Angeles Express, jumped leagues as well, signing a series of one-year contracts with the Washington Redskins. The signing was confirmed by Bobby Beathard, the general manager for the Redskins, who refused to disclose terms of the agreement.

title: Protectionism Won't Help U.S. Exports
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE ENCYCLICAL ON SLAVIC NATIONS
description: Following, in official translation from the Polish, are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's encyclical ''Slavorum Apostoli'' (''The Apostles of the Slavs''), which was issued today:

title: CAUCUS WITH ITS EYE ON THE HOOP
description: The Hardwood Caucus of the House of Representatives gathers, sometimes several times a week, in the subbasement of the Rayburn House Office Building.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-After a loss from discountinued operations of $4,106,000, a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7,954,000 and an extraordinary credit of $9.5 million from termination of a retirement plan.

title: Xerox Typewriter
description: The Xerox Corporation has announced a spelling checker and new communications features for its successful line of Memorywriter electronic typewriters.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Finale of the three-game series and last home game for the Mets until after the All-Star Game break. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. Phil Niekro will be opposed by Dave Stieb of Toronto on getaway day for the Yankees, who face the Minnesota Twins in Yankee Stadium tomorrow night. (Television - SportsChannel, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 12:30 P.M.) Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon. (Television - Channel 4, 11:30 to 11:45 P.M. update. HB0 cable, 5 P.M. to 8 P.M. tape). Eastern Masters Circuit, men's 35 and over tournament, at the Cove Tennis Center, 60 Sea Cliff Avenue, Glen Cove, L.I., 4 P.M. More early-round matches in the tournament that runs through Saturday. Track and Field Third Annual T.A.C. National Youth Championships, sponsored by the Metropolitan Athletics Congress, at Mitchel Field, Uniondale, L.I., 9 A.M. This is the second day of triathlon competition for bantam and midget boys and girls, heptathlon for girls and decathlon for boys. The competition, which ends Sunday, is for boys and girls 9 to 18 years of age from the United States. Other Events BASKETBALL: Lite/N.B.A. Pro-Am New York City Summer Pro League at Nat Holman Gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 7 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. BICYCLING: Tour de France. EQUESTRIAN: I Love New York Grand Prix Horse Show, second day, hunters, jumpers and equitation, at Lake Placid, N.Y., 8 A.M. The show ends Sunday.

title: BEIRUT CALLS MOVE BY U.S. AN OUTRAGE
description: Lebanese Government and political leaders expressed outrage today over the Reagan Administration's plan to take legal and diplomatic action to isolate the international airport here.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FINANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SURE, PUPS AND KITTENS ARE CUTE, BUT ANIMAL ADOPTION IS FOR LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Plot With a Twist
description: The story of the hijacked T.W.A. airplane brought a new group of characters into the lingo of the American news business. These were captors, often pronounced by the TV people to rhyme with ''cap doors.''

title: Abortion Clinic Blasts Bring 10-Year Sentence
description: Calling the bombing of abortion clinics ''cowardly and vicious,'' a Federal district judge today sentenced a lay minister to 10 years in prison for conspiring to bomb 10 clinics or offices of abortion supporters in three states and the District of Columbia.

title: LECONTE TOPPLES LENDL IN 4 SETS
description: There is an air of change at Wimbledon that is as fresh as the breeze stirred by Boris Becker's serve and has been as well received as the kiss Henri Leconte blew to his admirers at Centre Court today. John McEnroe may be entrenched at the top and Jimmy Connors refuses to concede to athletic old age, but the fans here have taken to Becker, the hard-hitting West German teen-ager, and Leconte, the charming Frenchman who gives the impression he can sweet-talk the ball over the net.

title: 3 Septuptlet Survivors Gain
description: The three surviving Frustaci septuplets are growing stronger and gaining weight, and their parents are shielding them from the publicity that marked their first weeks of life, a hospital official said Monday.

title: SAXOPHONES IN CONCERT
description: THE threat of rain on Friday evening caused the ''Celebrate Brooklyn'' series contribution to the Kool Jazz Festival to be moved from the band shell in Prospect Park into the park's Picnic House. The Picnic House is normally set up with 300 seats but almost 600 people managed to squeeze in to hear the World Saxophone Quartet and the singer Daniella.

title: Sator Debut Oct. 10
description: Ted Sator will make his National Hockey League coaching debut with the Rangers Oct. 10, when the New Yorkers begin their 60th season with a game against the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden.

title: ALASKA GRAND JURY SUGGESTS THAT GOVERNOR BE IMPEACHED
description: A grand jury recommended today that the Alaska Senate consider impeaching Gov. Bill Sheffield, saying his administration had not served the public interest in the way it handled bids for a state office building contract.

title: LONNIE HILLYER
description: Lonnie Hillyer, a trumpet player who was a close associate of Charles Mingus for many years, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan, He was 45 years old.

title: U.S. IS UPHELD IN CHARITY DRIVE CURB
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government may exclude legal defense funds from the annual charity drive conducted among Federal workers as long as the Government's goal is not to suppress a particular point of view.

title: A KENTUCKEY FOURTH OF JULY BARBECUE THAT INSPIRED AUDUBON
description: ''ALTHOUGH more than 20 years have elapsed since I joined a Kentucky barbecue, my spirit is refreshed every Fourth of July by the recollection of that day's merriment,'' John James Audubon wrote in ''Delineations of American Scenery and Character,'' a series of essays that accompanied his ornithological studies.

title: PAPAL LETTER ASKS RELIGIOUS LIBERTY IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: Pope John Paul II issued an encyclical today calling for ''solidarity'' with his fellow Slavs, religious tolerance in Eastern Europe and closer ties between Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: Topics;   Repeat Performances Lightning Luck
description: Two Colorado meteorologists, Raul Lopez and Ronald Holle, have cast new light on lightning. Not only does it often strike twice in the same place, they've discovered, but it's apt to show up with monotonous regularity.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BLOCKS FOR CHOPPING AND TENDERIZING MEAT
description: ONE of my first discoveries as a cooking apprentice was that professional chefs would no sooner be without a butcher block than they would be without knives since these items were so important to food preparation.

title: SANDRA BERNHARD ALBUM BLENDS COMEDY AND SONG
description: WHILE the worlds of stand-up comedy and ''serious'' popular music have co-existed happily on television for many years, they have rarely interacted on the same record album. Sandra Bernhard, the iconoclastic stand-up comic, singer and actress who is best known for her portrayal of an insane fan in the movie ''The King of Comedy,'' has broken down the barrier with an album that boldly interweaves the two.

title: LED STANFORD U.
description: J. E. Wallace Sterling, former president of Stanford University, who led his school through two expansive decades into the top ranks of research universities, died Monday at his home in Woodside, Calif., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Duff & Phelps Rating C.D.'s Issued by Banks
description: Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago investment research concern, has begun rating certificates of deposit of less than one year that are issued by major banks. The rating service is not restricted to subscribers.

title: Home Ports for 29 Ships Announced by Pentagon
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today announced a Navy plan to disperse 29 ships among nine home ports along the Gulf Coast over the next several years.

title: Unequal Health Care
description: After 15 years of skyrocketing health care costs, the Federal Government has lowered the boom on the health care industry. By replacing Medicare's cost-plus reimbursement system with a fixed-payment program, the Government dramatically slowed the cost spiral.

title: PRODUCER BUYS RIGHTS TO SHEVCHENKO BOOK
description: Motion-picture rights to ''Breaking With Moscow'' by Arkady N. Shevchenko, the best-selling memoir of the highest-ranking Soviet official ever to defect, have been purchased for $450,000 by Lester Persky Productions.

title: Market Place;   Ulcer Drug Competition
description: ALTHOUGH the anti-ulcer drug market is now dominated by a mighty few, several pharmaceutical companies are mounting a challenge to the current giants: SmithKline-Beckman, Glaxo Holdings, Marion Laboratories and A.H. Robins. David Saks, pharmaceuticals analyst for Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner, says that although these dominant concerns will continue to hold a major stake in the important ulcer drug sector, they soon could be competing with the likes of G.D. Searle, Syntex, Upjohn, Merck and Hoffmann-La Roche.

title: METS ESCAPE, END SKID AT SIX GAMES
description: It was nothing to write home about, but the Mets finally did a few things last night that they hadn't been doing lately - like score and win.

title: DIFFERENT COURSE FOR COACH
description: Monsieur Richard, the headwaiter at the restaurant Le Boeuf a la Mode on East 81st Street in Manhattan, does not care what the plat du jour is tonight or for the next three weeks. He has a bigger order to fill: to manage a United States bicycling team to another victory in the women's Tour de France.

title: Israel's Subtler Battle
description: ''We has met the enemy, and it is us.'' - Pogo ''Pretty soon we'll be eating rocks.'' - A Jerusalem shopper. Israel has often enough proved that it can mobilize against formidable military threats. Now it will learn whether it can mobilize to meet the subtler yet potentially deadly internal threat. The austerity plan just announced by its Cabinet is not likely to leave people hungry. But it must sharply cut living standards if it is to make a difference. Ideally, it must also jolt into flexibility an economic system long enfeebled by state intervention.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT'S always tough to look at an earnest young person and have to conclude that he or she really doesn't have much of a future. That's the way it is with the 1984 vintage. It's time to update the annual vintage chart, and adding the '84 is not a particularly happy task. In spite of good wines in most production areas, the overall ratings are not high. Unfortunately, there is no way to account for many variables in a vintage chart. A manageable chart cannot account for regional variations, much less vineyard and winery variations.

title: LEBANON OBLIGATED TO TRY 2, U.S. SAYS
description: The State Department said today that Lebanon was legally obligated either to put the two hijackers of an American airliner on trial or to extradite them to the United States.

title: Secular Humanism
description: To the Editor:

title: Steve Rogers Released
description: Steve Rogers, who won 158 games in 12 years with the Montreal Expos, has been released from the California Angels' affiliate in Edmonton, Alberta, after a 1-2 record in five starts with the minor league team. The 35-year-old Rogers signed with California June 3, three weeks after he was released by the Expos, where he had a 2-3 mark this year and a 6-15 record last year.

title: Egyptian Parliament Widens Women's Rights
description: Parliament today passed a law giving Moslem women the right to divorce a husband who takes a second wife.

title: TELLING LOCAL OFFICIALS THE ADMINISTRATION CARES
description: Mitch Daniels made a day trip to Anchorage, Alaska, last month to tell the nation's mayors that, despite some fundamental differences, the Reagan Administration was behind them.

title: GOVERNOR APPROVES BILL TO REDUCE MALPRACTICE-INSURANCE PREMIUMS
description: As work stoppages and slowdowns by physicians continued across upstate New York, Governor Cuomo signed legislation today intended to reduce malpractice-insurance premiums paid by doctors and increase their coverage against malpractice awards.

title: Saved by a Snake
description: Thanks in part to intervention from a thoroughly unexpected source, a party of 45 from the Southern California Road Runners Club is getting a bargain rate for its sleeping quarters this week while taking part in the outdoor junior nationals at Uniondale, L.I.

title: Carbide Gives Bhopal Cause
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that further investigation had confirmed its conclusion that a large volume of water set off last December's gas leak tragedy in Bhopal, India, by entering a storage tank holding a highly reactive pesticide ingredient.

title: Court Limits Tenants' Suits Filed After Blackout in 1977
description: New York City tenants injured in the common areas of their apartment buildings during the 1977 blackout do not have a right to sue Consolidated Edison, the State Court of Appeals ruled, 5 to 2, today.

title: 160 MINOR-CHARGE FUGITIVES SEIZED IN PREDAWN RAIDS AT BROOKLYN PROJECTS
description: A special force of 200 police officers seized 160 fugitives yesterday in a series of predawn sweeps at five city housing projects in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: WARSAW SAYS CALLS FOR A PROTEST STRIKE WERE MOSTLY IGNORED
description: The Government's chief spokesman said today that appeals for an hourlong strike to protest increases in meat prices Monday had been ignored throughout Poland.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had sold its Middletown, Conn., facility to an undisclosed partnership of institutional investors for $225 million in a sale-leaseback deal.

title: THE SCREEN: IN 'FUTURE,' BOY RETURNS TO THE PAST
description: THE people in Robert Zemeckis's films have the great fun of living out their craziest daydreams. And the crazier the better: Mr. Zemeckis, together with his screenwriting partner Bob Gale, has progressed from teen-age kamikazes willing to risk anything to meet the Beatles (''I Wanna Hold Your Hand,'') to salesmen ready to peddle any form of figurative snake oil (''Used Cars'') to a timid pulp novelist who travels to the tropics (''Romancing the Stone,'' with a screenplay by Diane Thomas) and becomes her own most adventuresome heroine.

title: FILM: DAY OF THE DEAD'
description: Greatly admired in some circles as the horror film sardonic enough to let its zombies go shopping, George A. Romero's ''Dawn of the Dead'' had a central metaphor Mr. Romero may never top. His use in that film of an immense, all-American mall, complete with fountains and Muzak, as the site of vicious fighting between the blue-faced dead and the living made ''Dawn of the Dead'' at least as ingenious as it was stomach-turning.

title: T.W.A. PILOTS IN PACT WITH ICAHN ON CONCESSIONS
description: The Air Line Pilots Association said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with the New York investor Carl C. Icahn under which the union would give pay and benefit reductions of up to 20 percent if he acquired control of Trans World Airlines.

title: Laker Test for Walton
description: Bill Walton, the free-agent center of the Los Angeles Clippers, was given a physical examination by the team doctors of the neighboring Lakers as a preliminary step to any negotiations between the two parties.

title: IN 'FUTURE,' BOY RETURNS TO THE PAST
description: THE people in Robert Zemeckis's films have the great fun of living out their craziest daydreams. And the crazier the better: Mr. Zemeckis, together with his screenwriting partner Bob Gale, has progressed from teen-age kamikazes willing to risk anything to meet the Beatles (''I Wanna Hold Your Hand,'') to salesmen ready to peddle any form of figurative snake oil (''Used Cars'') to a timid pulp novelist who travels to the tropics (''Romancing the Stone,'' with a screenplay by Diane Thomas) and becomes her own most adventuresome heroine.

title: Laos Aids U.S. Recovery Of 13 American Dead
description: The remains of 13 American airmen killed in the crash of their Air Force gunship in Laos more than 12 years ago have been recovered by a joint United States-Laotian excavation team and returned to the United States, the White House announced today.

title: Offering of Bonds By Suffolk County
description: Long Island's Suffolk County offered $32.1 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Roosevelt & Cross Inc.

title: NO ADDITIVES OR SECRETS, JUST FRUITY JAMS
description: Concern about artificial flavorings and additives in food is not as new as we may think. Exactly 100 years ago, a certain Arthur Charles Wilkin laid down the principles that were to guide his new company by quoting Thomas Carew, a 17th-century poet: No foreign gums nor essence fetched from far No volatile spirits nor compounds that are Adulterate, but at Nature's cheap expense With far more genuine sweets refresh the sense.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our joy at your return is substantial. But so is our pain at what was done to that son of America.

title: Creighton on Probation
description: Jeff Hurd, a spokesman for the Missouri Valley Conference, said the league had placed Creighton University's basketball program on a one-year probation without sanctions for what it said were violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Probation without sanctions means Creighton will remain eligible to compete in the regular season and participate in postseason tournaments.

title: HENDERSON LEADS ANOTHER TRIUMPH
description: Two hours before the Yankees went out to meet, and eventualy beat, the Blue Jays tonight, Rickey Henderson sat at his locker, reflecting on what he called his recent ''odd luck.''

title: Penalty Is Costly For Generals
description: Did Frank Mattiace, the defensive tackle for the Generals, ''encroach'' on the scrimmage line in Monday night's playoff game against the Baltimore Stars? Did he therefore deserve a 5-yard penalty that became vital to the outcome?

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss, reflecting a pretax loss of about $5.75 million in connection with the acceleration of payments on certain notes receivable.

title: TENNESSEE JAILS FACE UPRISINGS, LEAVING 1 DEAD
description: Convicts set buildings ablaze and seized hostages in uprisings Monday night and today at four state prisons in protests over new uniforms. An inmate died tonight after being beaten with a baseball bat in renewed violence at one prison.

title: BOB JAMES
description: BOB JAMES'S brand of keyboard-based fusion jazz is never less than pleasant, and that's the problem: It is also rarely more than pleasant. Whether performing original compositions or pop-jazz glosses of classical pieces, Mr. James's pianism - usually electric but occasionally acoustic - is fluent but bland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 3, 1985
description: International

title: APPEAL COURT CLEARS CHIEF MONEY RAISER OF EX-BOSTON MAYOR
description: A Federal appeals court on Monday overturned the misdemeanor conviction of former Mayor Kevin H. White's chief fund raiser, Theodore V. Anzalone.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Happy Fourth, You Guys!
description: Nobody can say on this Fourth of July, A.D. 1985, that the spirit of independence is not alive in America. We're so free - everybody with his own Declaration of Independence - that we're in danger of giving the jolly old notion a bad name.

title: A.T.& T. IN VENTURE IN JAPAN
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce today a venture with at least five leading Japanese companies, including Fujitsu and Hitachi, to offer sophisticated systems in Japan for transmitting computer data.

title: U.S. SAYS IT RETRIEVED SALVADOR COPTER
description: A United States Army helicopter flew into an embattled region of northeastern El Salvador last month to rescue a downed Salvadoran military helicopter, Pentagon and State Department officials said today.

title: STANLEY SEBASTIAN KRESGE, 85, RETAILER AND PHILANTHROPIST
description: Stanley Sebastian Kresge, who with his wife, Dorothy, channeled about $500 million to charitable, civic, religious, social, educational, medical and cultural beneficiaries, died Sunday of a heart attack while driving to a friend's funeral in Detroit. Mr. Kresge, who turned 85 last month, lived in Pontiac, Mich.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to MAY 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,800,000. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,850,000 for the quarter and $2,400,000 for the 6 months.

title: ORIOLES, DOWN BY 4, RALLY TO TOP TIGERS
description: Mike Young hit Baltimore's fourth home run of the game leading off the 10th inning to give the Orioles a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

title: Mr. Gorbachev on the Move
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is transforming the Soviet Government, trying to get his country moving again by drawing compatible and younger men to the top. That much is plain from his first 100 days as Communist Party chief. President Reagan is right to move toward a meeting with him next fall, to form his own first impressions.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: U.S. AGENCY ORDERS REMOVAL OF PCB'S
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered the removal of polychlorinated biphenyl compounds from commercial buildings over the next five years.

title: PROTECTIONISM WON'T HELP U.S. EXPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FREED HOSTAGE SAID PURSER WAS TRUE HERO
description: The purser on the hijacked flight ''saved lives, literally,'' according to one of the returning hostages, Thomas V. S. Cullins.

title: HOSTAGES RECOUNT DETAILS OF 17 DAYS OF CAPTIVITY AND TELL OF PLAN TO ESCAPE
description: The freed hostages from the Trans World Airline Flight 847 today offered new and sometimes harrowing details of the hijacking ordeal and their 17 days of captivity in Lebanon.

title: Kuwait to Deport 500 People It Considers Security Threats
description: Kuwait's Deputy Prime Minister said today that his Government would deport 500 people detained in a security crackdown after an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate the the Emir in May.

title: Attack in a Basque Town
description: A policeman was shot and wounded today, apparently by separatist guerrillas, in a bar in this northern Basque town, the police said. The assailants, a man and a woman, fled in a stolen car, authorities said.

title: CHURCH OF ENGLAND BACKS WOMEN AS DEACONS
description: The Church of England's policy-making body voted today to allow the ordination of women as deacons, the lowest rank of the Anglican clergy. But it stopped short of allowing them to become priests.

title: Power Failure in Pakistan
description: Karachi was paralyzed by a power failure today. The breakdown was caused by a fault in the transmission line outside Karachi early in the morning, a spokesman for the Electric Supply Corporation said.

title: Sperry Stock Moves Up $1
description: The Sperry Corporation's stock jumped $1 a share, to $53.75, in consolidated trading yesterday amid new speculation on a possible merger.

title: Sure, Pups and Kittens Are Cute, but Animal Adoption Is for Life
description: To the Editor:

title: GROMYKO MADE SOVIET PRESIDENT BY GORBACHEV
description: Andrei A. Gromyko wound up a 28-year career as Soviet Foreign Minister today and was named President of the Soviet Union, a prestigious but in the past largely ceremonial position.

title: Dow Drops 3.13; Volume Advances
description: The stock market failed to rise for the first time in more a week yesterday as prices closed mixed in uneventful although moderately heavy volume.

title: Empty Table
description: After they had helped Rick Reuschel to look like Cy Young on Monday night, the Mets were left with these on-base percentages among the players who have batted lead-off for them this season: Wally Backman, .314; Mookie Wilson, .304, and Kelvin Chapman, .246. The woefulness of those figures is particularly startling when you consider that for the entire National League - including pitchers, slow-footed catchers and every wild swinger in the book - the on-base average is .309.

title: Allied Sells 50% Of Union Texas
description: The Allied Corporation said that it had closed the sale of 50 percent of Union Texas Petroleum, its oil and gas subsidiary, to an investment group headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and including members of the management of Union Texas. In the previously announced sale, which will be effective upon the filing of merger papers Wednesday, and related transactions, Allied is receiving $1 billion in cash and $300 million of Union Texas preferred stock.

title: UNSETTLED TIMES FOR 'HAPPY HOUR'
description: At the end of the working day, Manhattan bars, like bars in other parts of the country, begin to buzz. From 4 P.M. to about 7 P.M. is the happy hour, celebrating the end of the workday. ''I like to unwind,'' said Rosie Stiles, who works as a maid on the Upper West Side and stops by Pat's Bar & Grill on Amsterdam Avenue and 67th Street a few times a week.

title: Old Newsletters
description: Delayed mail is nothing new, but 48,011 newsletters delayed for three months?

title: U.S. Clears Hospital Bid
description: The Justice Department has cleared the Hospital Corporation of America's proposed merger with the American Hospital Supply Corporation on antitrust grounds, the companies said yesterday. Hospital Corporation said that it planned to go ahead with the merger if its shareholders vote to approve it.

title: Man Accused of Crimes As Nazi to Be Moved
description: Andrija Artukovic, accused of being a Nazi war criminal, will be moved to a California Federal prison closer to his family while awaiting a United States magistrate's ruling on whether to free him on bail.

title: ABC SETTLES HARASSMENT SUIT
description: The American Broadcasting Companies and a former employee reached an out-of-court settlement today in her $15 million sexual harassment suit against ABC and one of its former vice presidents.

title: Ferraro Tests Water
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has hired a political poll-taker to help her decide whether to seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate from New York next year and the right to challenge Alfonse M. D'Amato's re-election bid. The 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee has engaged Harrison Hickman of Washington, to survey how she would run against potential Democratic opponents and against the Republican-Conservative incumbent in the general election.

title: SALVADOR REBELS URGED TO DEFECT
description: The Salvadoran Army, using leaflets, loudspeakers and radio and television, has begun a major effort to encourage anti-Government guerrillas to defect and receive an amnesty.

title: Mexican Socialist Candidate Said to Be Held by Gunmen
description: A member of the leftist United Socialist Party of Mexico, who was seeking office in elections held Sunday, was kidnapped from his home, a party spokesman said today.

title: JAPAN TO SELL U.S. ARMS TECHNOLOGY
description: After more than a year and a half of inaction, the United States and Japan have set in motion a 1983 accord under which Japan agreed to provide its main ally with advanced military technology.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RED SONJA'
description: ''Red Sonja'' is another live-action adventure film starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, who this time has a role that might as well have been played by a maple tree. He appears as the sturdy, sword-clanging sidekick of a heroine who, incredibly, is even more wooden than he.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Net loss.

title: Koufax Is No Garbo
description: There was something special about Sandy Koufax. On Monday night, in the Cracker Jack Old-Timers Baseball Classic at R.F. Kennedy Stadium here, he was chosen as the honorary captain of the National League team, a singular plum among such teammates as Henry Aaron and Ernie Banks and Warren Spahn. Koufax retains that special quality, apparently, even among his peers.

title: Well Completions Fall
description: Petroleum companies completed a total of 41,318 oil and natural gas wells in the United States during the first six months of 1985, down by a slim 120 wells from a year earlier, the Petroleum Information Corporation reported today.

title: TONES OF SYMPATHY IN BEIRUT TURN TO BITTERNESS ON RETURN
description: Several of the 39 freed American hostages began expressing feelings of bitterness and vengeance toward their captors yesterday, in sharp contrast to sympathetic statements made earlier by other hostages.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SMALL TYPES It is a small exhibition, occupying two cases in the lobby of the Nicholas Murray Butler Library at Columbia University, but that is appropriate, considering what is on view - miniature books.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ARPINE DOD was strolling along the promenade of Waterside Plaza, enjoying the seaside ambiance the East River can, on occasion, suggest. Her contentment was suddenly shattered when she felt something plop on her head. The something, she recalls, slithered slimily through her hair. She shrieked, tossed her head madly about, jumped up and down. The object fell at her feet onto the promenade. It was a live fish, flopping about in fright.

title: HEADED STATE PANEL BATTLING CORRUPTION
description: Goodman A. Sarachan, a former chairman of the New York State Investigation Commission, died Monday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 86 years old and lived in the Rochester suburb of Brighton.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of New Zealand has appointed Robert F. Hirten executive vice president and manager of its New York branch.

title: Marsh Picks Consultant
description: Marsh & McLennan Inc., the big insurance brokerage, said it had retained John R. Cox, a former executive vice president of the Cigna Corporation, as special consultant to a new liability insurance company being organized by Marsh. Marsh said the new company, the American Casualty Excess Insurance Company, would provide catastrophe liability insurance as well as liability insurance for directors and officers of industrial companies. Marsh said it had received commitments from 15 companies for capital investments totaling $140 million in the new company, which plans to be in operation by the end of the summer.

title: Readers Lost in the Nation Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: N. Carolina Hub For American Air
description: American Airlines said that it would open a new hub at Raleigh-Durham, N.C., beginning in mid-1987 with 40 to 45 daily flights to 25 cities. The airline now offers four flights a day from the airport and employs about 15 people.

title: THE STAGE: 'SINGIN' IN THE RAIN' OPENS
