description: WHEN we think of M-G-M's ''Singin' in the Rain,'' the happiest movie musical ever made, we think first of Gene Kelly, madly in love with his girl and his life and even his umbrella, as he dances about exultantly on a fantasy Hollywood street in the midst of a rainstorm. It says much about what's amiss with Broadway's new stage version of the film that it doesn't send us home with the image of a joyous man singing and dancing. What is most likely to be remembered about this ''Singin' in the Rain'' is the rain.

title: MOST CAPTIVES HAVE ARRIVED FROM EUROPE
description: Most of the former hostages left West Germany yesterday, Trans World Airlines said.

title: U.S. SAILING TEAM TAKES LIBERTY CUP YACHT SERIES
description: A sailing team from the United States won the Liberty Cup yacht racing series in New York Harbor yesterday by beating teams from seven other nations in the four-day regatta.

title: The U.N. Today: July 3, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M.

title: TEACHERS FIGHT PART OF TAX PLAN
description: Each morning this week, teachers from around the country have gathered to hear other teachers denounce the proposal in President Reagan's tax plan to end deductions for state and local taxes.

title: Midland-Ross
description: The Midland-Ross Corporation, a metal fabrication company, said that it had sold its National Castings division for $35 million to a new company to be known as National Castings Inc., headed by Joseph A. Seher of Chicago.

title: FILIPINO INSURGENCY: OUT OF RICE PADDIES AND INTO THE CITIES
description: For more than a year, the growth of the Communist insurgency in the Philippines has been a matter of increasing concern. Yet the rebellion has been mainly a rural phenomenon, adhering to the Maoist edict of capturing the countryside and isolating the cities.

title: RELEASE OF CAPTIVES BY ISRAEL BEGINS TODAY IN BORDER ZONE
description: Israel began releasing 300 mainly Lebanese detainees in a group today, busing them across the Lebanese border under an arrangement with the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ON HUTTON'S SCHEME
description: Congressional investigators have obtained internal E. F. Hutton documents that are said to raise the possibility that senior management knew of an elaborate Hutton scheme to overdraw its bank accounts by hundreds of millions of dollars to earn extra interest.

title:
Real Estate;

The Office Growth in Great Neck
description: WHEN Paul P. Schmergel asked New York City banks in 1962 for financing to put up a small office building on Northern Boulevard in Great Neck, L.I., he was turned away. The banks told him the suburban community just over the city line from Queens was not ready for office development.

title: BENNETT ASSAILS JUSTICES ON 'DISDAIN FOR RELIGION'
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett said today that the Supreme Court decision Monday barring public school systems from giving remedial and enrichment classes at parochial schools was a ''ridiculous'' expression of the court's ''fastidious disdain for religion that is hard to fathom.''

title: STERN DIFFERS WITH CUOMO ON U.S. TAX POLICY
description: William J. Stern, differing publicly with his old friend Governor Cuomo, has endorsed President Reagan's plan to change Federal tax policy and described it as a good impetus toward reform of ''archaic and inefficient'' state government.

title: Boathouse Rescued
description: ''I implore Mr. Newbold Morris to allow our Boathouse in Prospect Park to remain. We in Brooklyn admire it. No substitute for it would appease us.''

title: All-Stars Beaten
description: Michael Adams scored 18 points and collected seven steals to pace the league-leading Springfield Fame past the United States Basketball League All-Stars, 87-75, tonight in the new league's all-star game.

title: HAROLD S. TAYLOR
description: Harold S. Taylor, a journalist who worked at The New York Times, Barron's and The Wall Street Journal, died of a heart attack on Sunday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 84 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: TOM BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $390,000 in the most recent year and a loss from discontinued operations of $12,882,000 in the prior year.

title: What's Happened to Conscience?
description: Like many Americans, when I read of the check-kiting scheme at E. F. Hutton & Company, I shrugged it off with the easy explanation of a few rotten apples in the barrel. But then came news of more bad apples in high places. The Pentagon disclosed improper billing practices by the General Dynamics Corporation, the General Electric Company and other defense contractors. Days later came shocking charges of a respected Navy family allegedly caught spying for the Russians. In the same week, came news of six judges in Chicago charged with taking bribes from lawyers and clients. Most recently, Jake Butcher, a Kentucky financier and candidate for Governor, was imprisoned for fraud and tax evasion.

title: FUNDS LAG BEHIND THE INDEXES
description: Riding the new highs regularly set by the stock market in the last three months, mutual funds gained an average of 5.94 percent in the second quarter.

title: TECHNICAL EQUITIES CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to March 31
PACIFIC ISLANDERS WORRIED BY HOUSE
description: Micronesian leaders say they are concerned about proposals in a House committee to dilute the semi-independent status promised to two Pacific island groups in an agreement accepted by the Reagan Administration, the Senate and island voters.

title: 2 DEAD
description: A flash fire roared through the Baldwin Hills section of Los Angeles today, killing at least two people and injuring at least 11.

title: A 1:46.5 FINISH FOR WORLD'S MOST PROLIFIC ARTIST
description: There is a legend in these hills, the Catskills, of a man they say can paint a landscape in under two minutes and frame it in eight seconds flat.

title: NEW YORK'S TOP COURT REJECTS CONSERVATOR RULES
description: New York's highest court has rejected guidelines that were intended to curb favoritism and political influence in the appointment of guardians and conservators.

title: G.E. Aide To Police Contracts
description: John D. Peterson is the only person at the General Electric Company with his own ''800'' number to receive phone calls. And he is the only person at the company with an impersonal box number to get mail.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $20,000. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $2,679,000 for the quarter and $2,632,000 for the 6 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Released Steve Rogers, pitcher, from Edmonton farm club.

title: BUILDINGS CURBED BY SAN FRANCISCO
description: San Francisco's Board of Supervisors today approved a sweeping new zoning law designed to limit the construction of skyscrapers and reduce by half the number of office jobs projected for its congested downtown over the next 15 years.

title: BARONESS AILEEN BRONFMAN DE GUNZBURG, 60
description: Baroness Aileen Bronfman de Gunzburg, a member of the family that controls the Seagram Company and the wife of a prominent French banker and industrialist, died of cancer Monday in Paris. She was 60 years old and had residences in New York and West Palm Beach, Fla., as well as in Paris.

title: WINE AND THE VINE AS A DESIGN MOTIF
description: DIONYSUS stands in the center of a 2,500-year-old amphora, a red figure holding a shallow, flat-bottom drinking vessel while a woman fills it with wine. Bacchus sits atop an 18th-century porcelain urn, a cluster of grapes in one hand, a wine goblet raised in the other, a smile on his face. A Bacchanalian procession cavorts around a 20th-century glass bowl, a merry throng of revelers with trays of grapes and breakers and horns of wine.

title: Hostess Twinkie Creater
description: James A. Dewar, who created the Hostess Twinkie in 1930, died Sunday in Fairview Baptist Home in suburban Downers Grove. He was 88 years old. Mr. Dewar concocted the famous cake while manager of the Continental Baking Company's plant in suburban River Forest.

title: INVESTIGATOR SAYS HAUNTED CASTLE FIRE FATAL TO 8 WAS ARSON
description: A private investigator testified today that arson caused the fire that killed eight teen-agers last year in the Haunted Castle at the Great Adventure amusement park.

title: HUNGER CALLED MORE PREVALENT IN THE SUMMER
description: With emergency food assistance declining at the same time that demand for it is increasing, more New Yorkers than ever before will not get adequate food this summer, according to a report released yesterday by the State Committee Against Hunger.

title: 'EMERALD FOREST'
description: ''The edge of the world'' is a place that exists quite literally in John Boorman's films, sometimes as the site of farfetched fantasy (''Zardoz'') and more frequently, in Mr. Boorman's ''Deliverance'' and now his ''Emerald Forest,'' as a place of fierce, perilous beauty. That Mr. Boorman views this frontier in terms that are often extravagantly, even ludicrously, romantic does very, very little to diminish the breadth or intensity of his vision. Nor does it temper the excitement with which he brings that vision to the screen.

title: QUALIFIER FROM L.I. IN FINAL 8
description: She returned to Wimbledon to resume her tennis career, mindful of the disappointment that probably awaited her and the painful memories that would be revived. But it would be worth the effort, Molly Van Nostrand said, and there was always a chance she would surprise herself, perhaps even win a qualifying match or two.

title: Indiana Loses
description: The Japanese national team, led by 7-foot-9-inch Yasutaka Okayama, defeated Indiana University, 68-59, tonight in a four-nation basketball tournament.

title: 800 LINE HEARS CALLS POINTING TO RECALLS
description: A small room in the suburbs of Maryland, with four telephones and a view of a parking lot is the Consumer Product Safety Commission's link to the outside world.

title: THE TURNAROUND AT WESTERN
description: When Gerald Grinstein, chief executive officer of Western Airlines, boards one of its planes, he often takes the fourth seat in the cockpit so that he can talk to the crew. Robin H. H. Wilson, the president and chief operating officer, also uses his flight time to talk to employees.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. BEGINS PROCEEDINGS TO DEPORT AN EX-NICARAGUA REBEL LEADER
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has started proceedings that could lead to the deportation of a former Nicaraguan rebel leader who has been critical of Reagan Administration policies, an immigration official said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CARPENTER'S GOTHIC. By William Gaddis. 262 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/ Viking. $16.95.

title: Usher Prefers 12-Team U.S.F.L.
description: Harry Usher, commissioner of the United States Football League, said today at an owners' meeting that he had recommended the league have 12 teams in its future rather than 14.

title: OBSERVING DAILY LIFE ON CARRIER
description: ''SECOND HOME,'' to be shown on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock, is the apt title of a documentary about the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and the 5,800 men who live on it. The focus is on two members of the crew, the ship's executive officer and a boatswain's mate who supervises a flight-deck team, but its strongest moments come when a score of unidentified sailors work together at the demanding and dangerous job of bringing in the carrier's jet planes and getting them off again.

title: Sound the Trumpet (U.S.)
description: Pressing for his amendment to the military programs bill on the House floor last week, Representative John E. Grotberg, an Illinois Republican, resorted effectively to patriotism. ''During the orientation for new members,'' he told his colleagues, ''some of us had the rare opportunity to listen to the Navy Choir in Statuary Hall, among the monuments to the great heroes of our country.

title: A Chagall Valued at $290,000 Is Stolen From a Gallery Here
description: A Marc Chagall painting offered for sale at $290,000 as well as two bronze statues were stolen from a Madison Avenue gallery late Monday night or early yesterday, according to the police.

title: EXPORT CURBS ON THIRD WORLD CITED
description: Nearly a third of developing countries' agricultural exports to industrial countries are restricted by quota restraints or other nontariff barriers, and so are nearly one-fifth of their exports of manufactured goods, the World Bank said today in its annual World Development Report.

title: Bridge: Monroe Ingberman Brought Many New Tactics to Game
description: The game lost one of its leading theoreticians when Monroe Ingberman of White Plains died last week at the early age of 50.

title: Topics;   Repeat Performances Mexican Magic
description: Perhaps it's the altitude, or the air pollution, or the superior enchiladas. Whatever it is that Mexico City has that Washington D.C. hasn't, it strikes a panda's fancy.

title: Moon to Be Released From Danbury Prison
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, spiritual leader of the Unification Church, will be released Thursday from the Federal prison in Danbury, a prison official said today.

title: G.M. to Modernize Ohio Metal Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would spend up to $600 million to modernize its metal fabrication plant near Mansfield, Ohio. The project is part of G.M.'s continuing product development and investment program, which will total more than $9 billion this year.

title: Winthrop Terms
description: Winthrop Financial Associates said it had formed a partnership with a Trammell Crow Company subsidiary to buy the Fluor Corporation headquarters and its surrounding 162 acres for up to $340 million. Winthrop said Fluor would continue to maintain an interest in the property, which Fluor would initially lease back from the partnership. The headquarters, in Irvine, Calif., contains about 1.8 million square feet of office and retail space.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Commercial Paper Set Record in May
description: Commercial paper in the United States increased in May to a record $258.9 billion, seasonally adjusted, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Towns Feuding Over Native Son
description: It hasn't achieved all the notoriety of the big quarrel between the Hatfields and the McCoys, but down around Charlotte, N.C., there is indeed a decades-old feud, and it has to do with baseball. The parties are the towns of Cornelius (population 2,000) and, just 10 miles down the road, Huntersville (not quite 4,000), and if a resident of one has something belittling to say about the ballplayers from the other, he had better be smiling. Elderly natives of the area say that the rivalry dates from the turn of the century and that it has frequently been so fervent that, at least in the old days, a high school or semipro game between Cornelius and Huntersville was something to mark births by. And, of course, when a local youth got a crack at big-time ball, the citizenry was quick to make clear exactly which town he called his own.

title: LIBERIA'S SOUTHERN ACCENT SOUNDS AS STRONG AS EVER
description: The young man saw an American who was obviously lost and offered to accompany her to her destination. As they walked along the noisy, congested sidewalks, the visitor asked the youth if he had ever been to the United States.

title: Joe Niekro Captures No. 200
description: Joe Niekro, with the help of a tiebreaking pinch-hit double by Phil Garner in the eighth inning, notched his 200th career victory as the Houston Astros beat the San Diego Padres tonight, 3-2.

title: REMARKS OF PRESIDENT AND PILOT AT CEREMONY
description: Following is a transcript of remarks at Andrews Air Force Base yesterday by President Reagan and John Testrake, the pilot of the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Economic Scene;   Deficit's Effect On Growth
description: BUDGET DIRECTOR David A. Stockman, in his June 5 address to the board of the New York Stock Exchange, said, ''It is now nearly impossible to see where the political will and consensus will come from that is necessary to enact any plan big enough to balance the books -or even substantially close the gap.''

title: 'CREDIBLE' GROUP REPORTED READY TO BUY UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL
description: A group of ''credible'' investors, as yet unidentified, has made an offer to buy United Press International, the news agency's chairman said yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Seton Hall has given its basketball coach, P.J. Carlesimo, a two-year contract extension and has announced it would no longer play home games at Walsh Gym, which has a capacity of 3,200. The Pirates will play all their Big East Conference home games at Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands and their other home games at the South Mountain Arena in West Orange, a community near the university, located in South Orange. . . . The Jets have signed the first of their 14 draft choices, Jeff Deaton, a guard and tackle from Stanford, who was picked sixth by the team. . . . Tim Foli, 15-year major league veteran who was recently released by the Pittsburgh Pirates, was signed by the Miami Marlins of the Florida State League. The 34-year-old Foli will join the team in Tampa today for a doubleheader against the Tarpons. . . .

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I was growing up in Burgundy, pasta dishes were relatively rare and not very inventive. Today, I am increasingly using the various kinds of pasta on the market. Inventing new pasta dishes is comparatively simple, since this food almost demands the addition of other flavors - a good olive oil with garlic, a blend of vegetables, a variety of seafoods and more. And, there are always fresh herbs from my garden.

title: Purolator Courier Appoints President
description: The Purolator Courier Corporation yesterday named C. Howard Hardesty Jr., a director of the company since 1980, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds William H. Waltrip, who resigned last week to become president of the IU International Corporation.

title: PRESIDENT TO MEET GORBACHEV 2 DAYS IN FALL IN GENEVA
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have agreed to hold a two-day meeting in Geneva in late November, Administration officials said today.

title: Kosar Signs $6 Million Pact
description: Bernie Kosar, the former University of Miami quarterback, officially became a member of the Cleveland Browns today at the National Football League supplementary draft in New York, then was signed to a multiyear contract believed to be worth about $6 million.

title: Rates and Bond Prices Steady
description: Interest rates and bond prices were little changed yesterday as the credit markets slogged through an extremely quiet session in this holiday-shortened week.

title: NEW-HOME SALES RISE
description: Sales of new homes posted their biggest increase in eight months in May, the Government reported today. The Reagan Administration called the 9.7 percent gain evidence of a ''strong resumption of steady growth'' in the economy.

title: A SWEETNER'S EFFECTS: NEW QUESTIONS RAISED
description: In 1984 the G.D. Searle Company of Skokie, Ill. sold $600 million worth of the artificial sweetener aspartame, on which it holds the exclusive U.S. patent. Produced under the trademark NutraSweet as a food additive and Equal as a table top sweetener, aspartame accounts for about 80 percent of Searle's business. It is found in a wide variety of products from puddings and breakfast cereals to bubble gum and ice cream as well as some of the best known diet soft drinks made by Coca-Cola, Pepsi and 7-Up.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Assaults in the South
description: Iran and Iraq reported new attacks today against each other's forces along the southern war front.

title: Nabisco Shares Offered Reynolds
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries said it had been offered 91 percent of Nabisco Brands Inc. outstanding stock in its bid to take over Nabisco.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Radical Group Member Held on 20 Charges
description: A survivor of the fire at the quarters of the radical group Move was held for trial today, accused of threatening to kill city officials and of conspiring to terrorize neighbors as the police tried to evict members of the group.

title: Central Soya Set To Sell Foods Unit
description: The Central Soya Company said in a letter to its employees that it would sell its branded foods units, which include Fred's Frozen Foods and J.H. Filbert Inc. Last month, Central Soya's shareholders approved the acquisition of the company by a partnership led by California-based Shamrock Holdings Inc. Shamrock, which has interests in real estate and broadcasting and is owned by the Roy E. Disney family, had said that it will dispose of branded foods to concentrate on Central Soya's agribusiness operations.

title: Polish Architect Held In Military Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: FOES ACT TO BAR S.I. NAVAL BASE BY REFERENDUM
description: Opponents of a proposed Navy base on Staten Island presented the City Clerk yesterday with 60,000 petition signatures, the first legal step needed to place a referendum on the issue on the ballot in November.

title: Recovery of Black Box Is Said to Be Unlikely
description: Officials say the chances of recovering the flight recorder from the Air-India jumbo jet that crashed into the Atlantic off the Irish coast on June 23, killing all 329 people aboard, appear to be fading.

title: THE HOMECOMING: BITTERSWEET FINALE
description: The ordeal of the 39 airline hostages reached a bittersweet ending today. Their Presidential welcome was a moment of muted celebration because, as President Reagan said, the homecoming was incomplete.

title: Investment Group Head At Home in SCOA Bid
description: For Thomas H. Lee, a leveraged buyout specialist, Monday's announcement that an investment group he heads is near an agreement to purchase SCOA Industries for $637 million represented more than a sound business decision. In a sense, the deal sent Mr. Lee back to his roots.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about uranium 235 extraction incorrectly described the fuel in the nuclear bomb dropped on Hiroshima.

title: HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $381,837 and an extraordinary credit of $24,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit.

title: FACTORY ORDERS RISE 2.1%
description: Orders to factories, after falling for three consecutive months, posted a 2.1 percent gain in May, the strongest increase since November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN'S 'PATIENCE'
description: ''The Compleat Gilbert and Sullivan'' series on public television is finally coming around, tonight on PBS, to ''Patience'' or, as it is subtitled, ''Bunthorne's Bride.'' This being a W. S. Gilbert libretto, it is hardly surprising to discover that Patience, the ingenue dairymaid, is not the operetta's leading character, and that Bunthorne, the poet and esthete whose castle and gardens provide the settings, ends up without a bride. Mr. Gilbert would have his little jokes.

title: TWO MISSING BLACKS ARE FOUND STABBED TO DEATH IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The stabbed bodies of two black leaders were found by the police today, five days after they were reported missing.

title: CELEBRATING 4TH OF JULY IN THE CITY: FIREWORKS, PARADES AND FESTIVALS
description: The nation's 209th birthday party will be celebrated with a bang - and a bang and a bang and a bang - tomorrow, as Fourth of July fireworks, parades and various festivities take place throughout the city.

title: Death Sentence in Oklahoma
description: Jay Wesley Neill and Robert Grady Johnson, convicted of killing four people in the Dec. 14 robbery of a bank in rural Geronimo, were sentenced today to death by injection.

title: CROWNAMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 11
Michaels Had Fears for Flutie's Future
description: The game situations in the second half of Monday night's playoff game at Giants Stadium were ideal for Doug Flutie. The Generals' defense, displaying its best effort of the season, stopped the Baltimore Stars six times, three times with interceptions, and turned the ball over to its offense in reasonable or good field position.

title: Court Dismisses Suit On Sentencing Report
description: State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a suit by local governments seeking to set aside a state report on criminal sentencing.

title: For People Only
description: In this case, ringside means waterborne, so the city's Transportation Department will nearly the double the number of places available tomorrow for those who want to watch the Harbor Festival and fireworks from the Staten Island Ferry.

title: SUNNY FARE, BIKINIS FIRST
description: 1. Vibrant Swim Gear The Leggiadro boutique has bikinis and matching pareus made of hand-dyed, hand-painted batiks. The fabric is fine cotton and the colors are vibrant - red, royal blue, hot pink, coral, turquoise, purple and black.

title: MIDGETMAN PACT FOR MARIETTA
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation has won a $447.6 million contract from the Air Force to assemble and test the proposed Midgetman strategic missile, moving the company a step toward possible selection as a prime contractor.

title: Get It, but Get It Right
description: National associations representing powerful industries tend to hire ''big picture'' people as their chief Washington operatives, men and women who learn rapidly where Congress and the Administration are moving on key issues in their fields but may be a bit vague about office detail. One such high-powered lobbyist, having promised his executive secretary he would seek a raise for her, returned from a Florida directors' meeting with word that the board had approved a new figure, $36,000. Informed frostily that she was already getting $42,000, he is now trying to figure out how to keep her on the payroll at the old salary without going back, red-faced, to his directors.

title: 21 Ghana Aides Die in Crash
description: Twenty-one members of Ghana's Cocoa Marketing Board were killed Monday in a road accident 50 miles west of here, the Ghana press agency said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: CANCER of the ovary, the fifth leading cause of cancer deaths in American women, is a disease that is widely misunderstood and often mistreated. Currently, more than two-thirds of the cases are not diagnosed until the disease has spread beyond the site of origin, and only 15 to 25 percent of the victims ultimately survive it. However, clinical findings disclosed during the last decade or so indicate that ovarian cancer needn't be nearly so deadly if proper attention is paid to its early warning signs and if the best available therapies are routinely applied.

title: REAGAN WELCOMES EX-HOSTAGES, INSISTS ON 'JUSTICE'
description: President Reagan today welcomed home 30 of the passengers on the Trans World Airlines jetliner that was hijacked to Beirut, vowing that the killers of the Navy diver who had been among them ''must be brought to justice.''

title: Boxing Card of Maybes
description: A cavalcade of former champions, to take place Aug. 21 at Madison Square Garden along with a world title fight, was announced yesterday and immediately ran into problems. Vito Antuofermo, the former middleweight champion who was expected to be the leading ticket-seller on the card, said he would fight only if his contract was honored.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $3,260,000 in the latest quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $383,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Time to Test-Market Picture Week Magazine
description: Time Inc. management has given the ''go'' signal for an extended test-marketing planned for its latest entry, Picture Week magazine.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Truffles of Summer Summer is a rough time for truffle fanciers (we're talking tubers here, not chocolates.) Italian white truffles and French black truffles are available only in late fall and early winter. By July their intense flavor has become but a haunting memory.

title: 4 Macy Stores Sold
description: Macy's Atlanta, a division of R.H. Macy & Company, said the Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, had agreed to buy four Macy stores in the Toledo, Ohio, area.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Two dispatches from Dallas last week discussed a speech on Jewish-black relations by Rabbi David Saperstein at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: DANCE: MOVING SOUND CONCERT 1
description: SEVEN choreographers presented solos on a program called Moving Sound Concert N1, Saturday night at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery. Yet these solos were also duets, for each was a collaboration with a musician and several were set to commissioned scores.

title: CONFERENCE TO EXPLORE FOLK ART
description: IN conjunction with its summer exhibit on Southern folk art, the Museum of American Folk Art is holding a free four-day symposium next Monday through Thursday. The sumposium will include a dozen lectures on various aspects of Southern folk art, as well as a curatorial tour of the exhibit and two documentary films.

title: FORMER CAPTIVE PLANS TO REVIEW HIS STATEMENTS
description: Allyn B. Conwell, the square-jawed Texan who acted as spokesman for the 39 American hostages in Beirut, has said that he would review the statements in which he said some hostages had expressed ''sympathy'' for their captors' cause.

title: RURAL WALES IS THE BATTLEGROUND AS BRITISH POLITICAL SKIRMISHES FLARE UP
description: The most significant political skirmish of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's second term has been taking place these past two weeks in the bucolic hills and dales of southeastern Wales, and Mrs. Thatcher appears likely to be the big loser.

title: WHAT IT MEANS TO LOVE AMERICA
description: Birthdays inspire celebrations, and this July 4 holiday season will prompt many of us, in different ways, to affirm our love of country. Nor is that affirmed love necessarily a collective self-indulgence, an unwarranted assertion of nationalist egoism. Few Americans return home after a stay abroad without being reminded of the factual basis for their patriotism: Our wealth and power, of course, but most of all, our precious freedoms.

title: 2 NO. 1 FEMALE PLAYERS ADVANCE
description: Her eyes were watery but Pam Shriver held back the tears. She could not, however, contain her disappointment. Once again she felt victimized by the luck of a draw that usually places her in a bracket with her doubles partner and friend, Martina Navratilova. More often than not, their meetings across the net have been Miss Shriver's ticket home.

title: AGE LABELS SOUGHT FOR TOYS
description: Saying that children suffer more than 100,000 toy-related injuries each year, a committee of Americans for Democratic Action asked the Government today to require age and risk labels on all toys.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
Coffee Drops Sharply; Cocoa Moves Higher
description: Coffee futures fell sharply in New York today ahead of the long holiday weekend, weighed down by increasing supplies, lower prices and trade concerns over cold weather in Brazil, brokers said.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GREEK SECURITY TERMED AMPLE
description: A flight attendant on the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner, calling a United States Government travel advisory for Greece ''quite unjust,'' says that security at the Athens International Airport is completely adequate.

title: What Are Our Friends Trying to Tell Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: NO HARM TO CBS SEEN IN PLAN
description: The financial and competitive price that CBS Inc. will pay for its complicated $954.8 million recapitalization plan should not be excessive and probably will not significantly restrict the company's future options, analysts said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Friday about The Village Voice incorrectly described the departure of a Voice writer, Alexander Cockburn. Mr. Cockburn, a critic of Israel, was suspended in February 1984 for having accepted a $10,000 grant from the Institute of Arab Studies to write a book about the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. The Voice's editor, who had said the grant created a conflict of interest, later invited Mr. Cockburn to return, but the writer declined. He was not dismissed.

title: How to Fight Back
description: The torture and murder of an American because he was guilty of being a U.S. sailor, and the Nazi-like selection of four Americans for special abuse because they were suspected of being Jews, calls for a military-diplomatic-economic fireworks display soon after this Fourth of July. A half-dozen basic responses: 1. Close down the pirates' haven that is the Beirut airport. The previous Reagan reaction to terrorism -fist-shaking warnings and tiptoeing backdowns after embassy bombings and the massacre of marines - has been a disastrous failure. Since our restraint has been taken as weakness, this is the time for the ordering of all Americans out of the country, a final demand for the return of the kidnapped seven, a brief airport evacuation notice, followed by the destruction of the control tower, runways, garages and fuel storage tanks. 2. Get the killers. By wearing masks at their press conference, the murderers manifested their fear of capture. But their identities are no secret. A high monetary award posted for their apprehension, as lawyer Lloyd Cutler suggests, might prove attractive to associates who were not above stealing the hostages' jewelry and cash. Thieves fall out: a big bounty from a ''Stethem Fund'' would drive a wedge into Hezbollah ranks. 3. Let the Greek Government go it alone. Greece had one of the three original hijackers in its hands at Athens airport. Instead of interrogating him to obtain details of the terrorist organization to prevent future attacks, Prime Minister Papandreou made his craven side deal of appeasement, hastily trading him for the Greek passengers - thereby giving the hijackers their first success and increasing the danger to the rest of the international passengers.

title: 'PRESSURED' HOWE IS CUT BY DODGERS
description: Steve Howe, who said he could ''not effectively handle many of the pressures'' he felt playing in Los Angeles, was unconditionally released today by the Dodgers.

title: HOSTAGES OFFER MORE DETAILS ABOUT THEIR 17 DAYS IN CAPTIVITY
description: No longer constrained by their captors, the freed American hostages unburdened themselves yesterday of more of the details of their lives in captivity.

title: SALVADORANS FIND A HAVEN IN CANADA
description: A half-dozen refugees from El Salvador sit around a living room here, sipping coffee and watching their children playing on the floor.

title: POLICEMAN CLEARED IN THE KILLING
description: Until the night of June 12, when he lay dying outside Morningside Park of a gunshot fired by a plainclothes policeman who was not much older than he, 17-year-old Edmund Perry seemed bound for a destiny far removed from his Harlem surroundings. So, it seemed, was his 19-year-old brother, Jonah.

title: 3 SLAIN AND ANOTHER SHOT IN FLATBUSH
description: Three men were found shot to death yesterday in a basement apartment in a private house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: CHINA RELEASES A CATHOLIC BISHOP WHO WAS JAILED NEARLY 30 YEARS
description: The 83-year-old Chinese prelate recognized by the Vatican as Bishop of Shanghai, the Rev. Ignatius Kung, was released from prison on parole today after spending nearly 30 years in jail, the New China News Agency announced.

title: Xebec Sees Loss In Latest Quarter
description: The Xebec Corporation, which makes computer products, said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter, ended Sunday, on a drop in sales of about 30 percent from the second quarter's $44.8 million. The company said the sales drop ''was principally caused by a softening and changes in demand by customers.''

title: LEO H. JOACHIM
description: Leo H. Joachim, publisher and editor of Printing News, a weekly trade newspaper for the graphic arts industry, died of a heart attack Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a pretax loss of $1,065,771 on the sale of a marketable security, a pretax writedown of $350,000 of a safe harbor lease and a $140,769 pretax writeoff of a subsidiary. c-Net income including a tax credit of $81,000.

title: 10-Billion-Yen Financing Is Signed by Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced the signing of a 10-billion-yen, five-year financing, equivalent to about $40 million.

title: Sacco Will Fight Hatcher for Title
description: The World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title fight between the champion Gene Hatcher of Fort Worth, Tex., and the challenger Ubaldo Sacco of Argentina will be held July 21 in a hall of the gambling house of Campione d'Italia, organizers announced Tuesday. The fight will be a rematch of their Dec. 15 meeting in Fort Worth.

title: DR. PAULI MURRAY, EPISCOPAL PRIEST
description: The Rev. Dr. Pauli Murray, a lawyer, writer and civil rights activist who was considered the first black woman ordained to the Episcopal priesthood, died of cancer Monday at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 74 years old.

title: FILM: 'LIFT,' A MAD ELEVATOR
description: ''THE LIFT,'' a Dutch film about a diabolical elevator, doesn't have the kind of visual menace that could invest the title object with any real power. Written and directed by Dick Maas, and punctuated by the elevator's gruesome antics (it suffocates, squashes and beheads), the film is still remarkably tension-free.

title: NURTURING A CROP AND PREPARING THE NEXT
description: GARDENERS might now like to rest on their hoes and survey their spring planting, which they might view with either awe or misgivings. If their planning has been good, gardeners should be reaping a bountiful harvest or cutting a constant parade of blooms.

title: The 'Russians' at Columbia Peace Games
description: To the Editor:

title: PILOT PACT PUTS CURBS ON ICAHN
description: Concessions offered by the Air Line Pilots Association to encourage Carl C. Icahn to take over Trans World Airlines are tied to constraints on his ability to sell airline assets and to cut capital spending, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission show.

title: WITH THE DUKES AND DR. JOHN
description: AFTER a week of attending jazz events in concert halls where audiences sat in rapt, silent attention, it was a relief to board a Staten Island ferryboat on Saturday afternoon for a two-hour musical party. For all the seriousness that surrounds it in a festival context, jazz, after all, continues to be more a music of celebration than of cerebration.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Interest Seen in MGM Grand
description: A new investor has expressed an interest in acquiring undefined properties of MGM Grand Hotel Inc., according to Stephen D. Silbert, a spokesman for Kirk Kerkorian, who owns 70 percent of the stock of MGM Grand.

title: A SHOREHAM PERMIT IS ISSUED
description: A Federal appeals court today refused to stay the issuance of a low-power license for the Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power station. Afterward, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued the license, which allows the reactor to be tested at 5 percent of capacity.

title: Big Laws, Small Type
description: The smallest lawbook in the Library of Congress measures 1 1/2 inches by 1 3/4 inches, has a brass frame and a purple satin spine and bears the monogram of Alexander II of Russia. The bite-sized book is a 19-page compilation of documents important to the Czar: his 1861 manifesto emancipating the serfs; his provinical self-government proclamation of 1864; his judicial reforms.

title: HOME'S AGE CAN AFFECT RENOVATION
description: ALL old houses are old, but some are older than others.

title: SCOTT'S HOSPITALITY reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The company said the results don't include those of Black Photo Corp., which it acquired after April 30.

title: Tour Trivia
description: Quick, name five things that Jay Delsing and Chris Perry have in common.

title: Lieut. Col. Ruth Briggs, 74; Served Allied Headquarters
description: Lieut. Col. Ruth M. Briggs, retired, who was one of the first women sent abroad as an officer in World War II, died Tuesday at her home here. She was 74 years old.

title: FANS DECLARE INDEPENDENCE
description: In the upper right-field stands at Shea Stadium last night, the revolutionaries had assembled. Tommy Jeff, Jackie Adams and Benny Frank were there to celebrate the Fourth of July by writing a declaration of independence for baseball fans demanding relaxation without misrepresentation.

title: Tandy to Buy Eckerd Unit
description: The Tandy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the American Home Video Corporation, a subsidiary of the Jack Eckerd Corporation, for a yet-to-be determined amount of cash.

title: No Headline
description: Schneider Services Inc., Pittsburgh, won a $345 million Air Force contract for mission support at the Arnold Air Station Engineering Development Center in Tullahoma, Tenn., the Defense Department said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM NEWS CONFERENCE OF T.W.A. CREW
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference conducted in New York City yesterday by the three members of the cockpit crew of the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. The crew members were John L. Testrake, pilot; Philip G. Maresca, co-pilot, and Benjamin C. Zimmermann, flight engineer. Q. Did you develop sympathy for the captors? MR. MARESCA: No, I did not. I developed a sympathy for the Lebanese people in general. We are released now but many of the Lebanese people are still held captive in circumstances that are effectively anarchy. There is no government in Lebanon now and these people have to run a very thin line between these 18 or 19 various groups that control various aspects, various areas within Lebanon. It's these people we developed a certain empathy for in their daily lives. Q. (Unintelligible). MR. TESTRAKE: They had gone through the cabin looking for identities. They were alert for United States military. They had two of them that they tied up at separate times and brought forward and put them in the cockpit. They beat on them quite severely. They wrenched one of the arms off Mr. Zimmermann's flight-engineer's chair and used that as a club to beat these young men. They would jump on them with all of their weight on their bodies repeatedly. They did this off and on throughout the first stages of the hijacking.

title: STOCK PRICES EASE AS DOW FALLS 7.62
description: Stock prices sagged yesterday in surprisingly brisk pre-holiday trading. Wall Street's attention remained riveted on potential takeovers, especially those in the entertainment industry.

title: DOWNTOWN PITTSBURGH GETS 1.1-MILE SUBWAY
description: This city's 1.1-mile downtown subway was officially opened today, fulfilling a dream that Pittsburgh has had since 1906.

title: Artistic Freedom
description: Some drew hearts and self-portraits. Others scrawled messages proclaiming love for New York and the United States. But most of the 80 children drawing on the sidewalk in front of the Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on June 26 of Walter R. Staub, retired chairman of the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, erroneously located the firm's headquarters. It is in Manhattan.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All United States stock and commodity markets are closed today for Independence Day.

title: Required Reading;   President as Preacher
description: Excerpts from remarks by Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania at a breakfast with reporters June 27. Mr. Gray, a Democrat and a Baptist minister who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, was asked to compare the operating styles of President Reagan and President Carter.

title: A BANG-UP JULY 4, OLD-STYLE
description: About a hundred years ago, New Yorkers really didn't look forward to July 4.

title: Reagan Archive (Con't)
description: As he seeks public support for his plans on tax revision, President Reagan is sometimes using anecdotes from his personal past, others of unknown origin. Digging up a recollection from his acting career when the money was good and the taxes were high, he said: ''I remember back in those days in Hollywood when I was only getting 10 cents out of every dollar.

title: 3 ON T.W.A. CREW DESCRIBE THEIR 17-DAY ORDEAL IN THE HIJACKING BY SHIITES
description: The three cockpit crew members of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 gave a harrowing account yesterday of their hijacking and captivity, describing brutal beatings, surreptitious conferences about how best to do their jobs and alternating cruelty and kindness from their Shiite captors.

title: Dutchman Wins
description: Henri Manders of the Netherlands saw an 18-minute lead whittled to 11 seconds today but still held on to capture the 139-mile fifth stage of the Tour de France.

title: House Fire Kills 4 On Long Island
description: A mother and her three children were killed early today as a fire destroyed their home.

title: Foreign Bank Officer Picked for State Board
description: Flavian E. Zeugin, 58 years old, a first vice president at the Swiss Bank Corporation, has been named to the New York State Banking Board.

title: TIDE OF PROTECTIONISM IN CONGRESS
description: Reacting to a trade deficit that the Reagan Administration says could hit $150 billion this year, Congress is wading into a flood of bills to curb imports of everything from shirts, sweaters and shoes to ferroalloys and lumber in the postwar era's greatest deluge of protectionist legislation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I felt a little old. I know 26 is not old age but I've been on the tour eight years and at times, it catches up to you.''

title: THE INSIDE WORD ON THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR
description: Harry Kels Swan, the Swan collection's No. 1 item, would like to talk your ear off today. He talks fast, like a man who never learned punctuation and has little need to draw breath between words.

title: Paris Fashions
description: See the Emperor's new clothes: the clothes of a martyr to free speech. See the French President's new clothes: the clothes of a book-burner.

title: PAYSAVER CATALOG/SHOWOOMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 23
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax refund of $56,006. c-Net income.

title: SANDINISTAS' VISITORS: MOTIVES TOUCH OFF DISPUTE
description: For four nurse-midwives from New York City, a recent visit here was a chance to work in a Nicaraguan maternity hospital, sharing ideas and learning about health care in revolutionary society. But their mission was as much political as medical.

title: Slouching Toward Columbus Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Exports Drop
description: South Korea's exports fell in June from a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry said today. In the first six months of this year, South Korea exported $13.3 billion worth of goods, down 4 percent from the same period of 1984. Kum Jin Ho, the trade minister, told reporters South Korea is unlikely to achieve its export goal of $33 billion this year.

title: DONALD HIRST
description: Donald Hirst, a retired New York investment counselor, died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass.

title: AUDIO PUBLISHING IS CATCHING ON
description: A FEW years ago Jeffrey A. Hollender and Mitchell Deutsch had to coax booksellers to glance at their wares: non-music audio programming - from self-help to science fiction - on cassettes. No more. At the spring convention of the American Booksellers Association in San Francisco, ''suddenly the lights went on,'' Mr. Deutsch said.

title: Coleman's Tips
description: When the St. Louis Cardinals extended their first-place lead to a game and a half with a 4-0 victory Tuesday night at Montreal, they did it, as usual, with speed - and right from the start. Vince Coleman led off the first inning with a single, which caused such concern on the part of David Palmer that the Montreal starter proceeded to throw to first base 13 times.

title: SQUIBB HAS APPROVAL FOR DRUG
description: In a move that could make the Squibb Corporation a major player in the pharmaceutical industry, the Food and Drug Administration approved the company's Capoten drug for treating all levels of hypertension, Squibb said yesterday.

title: Family Ties Broken
description: The Stastny brothers, teammates with Quebec for the last four seasons, will not be together next season. The Nordiques have placed Marian Stastny, the oldest brother, on waivers without recall.

title: Ultimatum for Manges
description: Clinton Manges, the owner of the San Antonio Gunslingers, has 15 days to ''clean up his act'' or lose his financially troubled franchise in the United States Football League. Commissioner Harry Usher served notice of the pending action to Manges at the end of a meeting of the league owners the other day.

title: United, Lufthansa
description: United Airlines said it had completed a broad marketing agreement with Lufthansa German Airlines. The agreement calls for meshing the airlines' flight schedules at 10 American airports and enhancing automation features between the carriers' reservations systems.

title: LAWHON, JOHN F FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to APRIL 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS IN BEIRUT
description: Fighting broke out today around one of three Palestinian settlements in southern Beirut, ending a two-week-old cease-fire arranged by Syria between Shiite militiamen and Palestinians.

title: THATCHER SAYS SHE WILL WORK WITH U.S. TO STOP TERRORISM
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher agreed today to work with the United States to stop international terrorism, but she declined to join, at least for the moment, in President Reagan's campaign to ''isolate'' Beirut International Airport.

title: CALENDAR: CENTRAL PARK PRUNING
description: L.I.V.E., Central Park Administration Building, Fifth Avenue and 64th Street, Room 103, 212-535-1166 or 7255.

title: CURREN MAY GAIN RECOGNITION NOW
description: In 1979, he won the National Collegiate Athletic Association singles championship while attending the University of Texas. In 1983, he reached the semifinals at Wimbledon, beating Jimmy Connors in a fourth-round match in which he served 33 aces. He has won three tournaments and is ranked ninth in the world. And yet Kevin Curren thinks he is just another name on the tennis tour.

title: THEATER: KVARES'S 'DISTANT FRIENDS'
description: IN celebration of what he calls his centenary - his 100th production in New York - two one-act plays by Donald Kvares are being presented by the American Theater of Actors. Each is a woman-meets-man story, but the title given the evening, ''Distant Friends,'' is not entirely revealing. Mr. Kvares seems to want to say in both plays that men and women need one another as not-so-distant friends and in ways they do not always anticipate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aeroquip Corp. Jackson, Mich., a subsidiary of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Co., said Harry A. Bancroft had resigned as president, effective Dec. 31.

title: Chesebrough Division Post
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said yesterday that Charles B. Strauss had been named president and general manager of its packaged foods division, effective Aug. 6.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Blacks Still Need Help
description: Black unemployment and poverty remain unacceptably high and their corrosive effects remain all too apparent. Yet every discussion of how to assist blacks' economic development is overshadowed by debates about affirmative action and Government's proper role in the effort.

title: AFTER CRISIS, BOOKS ON MIDDLE EAST SURGE IN SALES
description: Several books on the Middle East have enjoyed a strong sales surge because of the hostage crisis, publishers said yesterday.

title: HARD TIMES IN BROOKLYN: HOW 2 NEIGHBORHOODS HAVE COPED
description: Rosemarie O'Keefe remembers life in Bay Ridge before the fiscal crisis as a halcyon time of officers walking the beat, sanitation workers sweeping steadily and park custodians waiting to hand out basketballs in the morning and lock up checkerboards at night.

title: SOME MEMORIES ARE MADE OF STERO RECORDINGS
description: AFTER participating in a recent panel discussion, I was approached by a reader who had a friendly objection to make - an objection that he was by no means the first to raise. He looked to be in his mid-60's, and he seemed a bit disappointed to see that I wasn't in mine. Hadn't I recently compared someone with Lotte Lehmann, who last sang in public in 1952? Well, yes, I explained, but I was basing the comparison on her records. ''Oh,'' he said, ''but that doesn't count.'' Does it? The question represents a relatively new problem for music criticism: It is only recently that many critics have started to regard records as much more than supplements or mementos of their own concertgoing experiences. Objections to the use of recordings in forming and articulating critical judgments persist.

title: Bryce Curry, 61, Dies; Led Home Loan Bank
description: Bryce Q. Curry, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, died of a heart attack Monday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Morris Township, N.J.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $4.96 billion, to $210.8 billion, for the week ended yesterday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: OPEC Price Report Denied
description: As OPEC leaders began arriving today for their midsummer conference, a report by the Government-supported Kuwait News Agency said a majority of the 13 ministers had reached tentative agreement to lower the price of OPEC's top-grade crudes by $1 to $1.50 a barrel.

title: FOR DRYING LAUNDRY
description: A NUMBER of small, portable drying racks now on the market can simplify the task of doing hand laundry in a small apartment. In the housewares department on the fifth floor of B. Altman & Company, are two drying racks made by Leifeit.

title: Players to Set Deadline
description: With negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement going nowhere, the executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association will meet in Chicago July 15 to set a date for a possible strike.

title: 'STAR WARS' JUST A STUDY, BUSH SAYS TO EUROPEANS
description: Vice President Bush, apparently trying to calm West European concerns about President Reagan's strategic defense initiative, today called it ''purely and simply a research program'' with possible deployment ''years off.''

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONCERT: GOSPEL
description: THE Institutional Radio Choir - the 40-member gospel chorus that received wide acclaim after its participation in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's production of ''The Gospel at Colonus'' - might well be the finest of all New York-based gospel choirs. Unlike many other local gospel groups, the choir does not utilize contemporary pop-soul arrangements and melodies.

title: CACHE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
COAST POLICE PRESS INQUIRY ON 2 THEY LINK TO CABIN DEATHS
description: After a month of searching, the authorities say they have found the remains of seven adults and two children near a remote cabin in rural Calaveras County that they believe was used by as a torture chamber and killing ground.

title: SENATORS HOPEFUL ON ARMS TALKS
description: A group of Senate observers at the Geneva arms talks, while pointing to what they called a lack of specific Soviet initiatives, along with a sharpening of Moscow's tone, said today that they had nevertheless found ground for ''cautious optimism.''

title: THE IMMIGRANT INFLUX STUDIED ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''DREAMS OF DISTANT SHORES'' begins, appropriately, by quoting Abraham Lincoln: ''Those who deny freedom to others deserve it not for themselves.'' Latter-day ideologists may interpret that to their own ends, but surely it applies to America and her immigrants. ''Dreams of Distant Shores,'' on Channel 13 today at 6 P.M., examines the immigrant experience.

title: BORDER CITY FINDS RICHES IN CHARMS
description: One might think that the Mayor of this border city, which is 92 percent Mexican-American, would have a name like Garcia or Lopez or be a descendant of the gunslingers who once shot up its famous streets. In fact, the Mayor of Laredo is an Italian-American from Rhode Island.

title: Sardi's Is Still Sardi's
description: Contrary to what has been written and said, Sardi's has not been sold. It is, however, for sale.

title: GARDNER STILL EXAMINES KEYS TO AMERICAN LIFE
description: John W. Gardner has spent much of his life wrestling with questions dealing with the quality of American life. He has been a psychology professor, a Government consultant, president of the Carnegie Corporation, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Johnson Administration, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, founder of Common Cause, the citizens' lobbying group, and the author of several books, including ''Excellence,'' which was published 23 years ago.

title: Baffled Pitcher
description: One of the most baffling slumps of the baseball season is under way in Kansas City, where Bud Black started out 5-3 but failed to notch a victory in the entire month of June and is now 5-8. Black, who won 17 games for the Royals last year and entered this season as the ace of their staff, has lost five of his last six starts, but among the things he has not lost is the confidence of Manager Dick Howser, who says: ''We have a tendency to look at the guys on our own ball club, but look around - Morris and Boddicker have been hammered at times this year.

title: Budd Lost on Purpose
description: Zola Budd, the South African runner, has told a Seattle television station she deliberately slowed down to avoid winning the 3,000-meter women's race at last year's Summer Olympics because she didn't want to be booed if she won the race after colliding with Mary Decker Slaney, who fell and had to helped off the track. Miss Budd said she heard the boos of the crowd in the Los Angeles Coliseum as she continued to run after the collision.

title: COUNTER SPACE IS ADDED
description: Martha Soler, a designer who had worked mostly on large residential interiors, said she looked forward to redoing a very small kitchen. ''I wanted the experience of building things with my own hands,'' she said. ''And this project was something I could handle.'' She agreed to a design fee of $800 and a renovation budget of $1,600.

title: Potential Buyers For Phillips Assets
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, which is trying to sell $2 billion in assets, said that potential buyers had expressed an interest in buying properties it values at $800 million to $900 million. When added to the $53 million in assets already sold and contracts to sell another $87 million, the sales are ''progressing as planned,'' a spokesman, Dan Harrison, said.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Missing a Mark
description: Less than 24 hours after his brother Joe had posted career victory No. 200, Phil Niekro got a no-decision in the Yankees' loss at Toronto yesterday and thereby missed a chance, if quite temporarily, to reach a milestone of his own. Not that he is in any hurry to get there.

title: REWARD PONDERED IN T.W.A. HIJACKING
description: Administration sources said today that serious consideration was being given to offering rewards of as much as $500,000 each for help in apprehending the two men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner to Beirut and murdered a hostage.

title: O.E.C.D. Split on Rules
description: Three members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development took the unprecedented step today of dissociating themselves from an O.E.C.D. report on taxation and the abuse of bank secrecy, according to an official of one of the countries. The official, Jean Zwahlen, Switzerland's Ambassador to the Paris-based body, identified the other members as Austria and Luxembourg.

title: CAPTIVE RECALLS SEPARATE IMPRISONMENT
description: A diagram of Lebanese politics drawn by a Shiite gunman provided the clearest indication to Robert G. Brown that he and three other Americans held separately from the majority of the hostages were under the control of the extremist Party of God, not the more moderate Amal militia.

title: BULGARIA'S AMBITIOUS HIGH-TECH GOALS
description: This small Balkan nation is moving ambitiously on several fronts to develop capabilities in the manufacture of computers and other advanced-technology products.

title: GOODEN DEBUT WAS PAINFUL
description: Who was Dwight Gooden's first catcher? Marlin McPhail doesn't mind being the answer to a trivia question, but he will always remember that his role as Gooden's first catcher lasted only one and two-thirds innings and ended with a broken thumb.

title: LONGER TOY SEASON SOUGHT
description: Last year's Christmas card from two employees of the Toy Manufacturers Association pictured an exhausted Santa Claus slumped against a hearth. A man with a briefcase labeled Consultant Inc. hovered nearby, telling Santa what he already knew so well: ''We've got to help you level out this seasonal peak.''

title: Home Loan Laggards
description: The number of Americans two months late in making mortgage payments to savings institutions declined sharply in May, the United States League of Savings Institutions reported today. The trade group said 1.68 percent of residential loans held by 900 thrift units were 60 or more days overdue, compared with 1.99 percent in April and 2.22 percent in January. The rates are based on dollar amounts.

title: BROCK EXPLORATION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MEESE, CITING SPY CASE, PRESSES FOR DEATH PENALTY
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said in remarks released today that the Reagan Administration would cite the case of a purported Navy spy ring in pressing for quick passage of a bill to reinstate the Federal death penalty.

title: PRISON DAMAGE SET A $11 MILLION
description: Four Tennessee prisons were under tight security today with prisoners kept in their locked cells after inmate uprisings that claimed one prisoner's life, injured five inmates and caused at least $11 million in damage.

title: FOREIGN MINISTER OF SPAIN TO GO IN CABINET SHAKE-UP
description: Spanish officials said today that the country's Foreign Minister was stepping down as part of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's first Cabinet shake-up.

title: Promotion at Times
description: The New York Times has named Melanie J. Rosen director of pre-press operations, with responsibility for its composing room and photoengraving department and satellite transmission of pages for the national edition. Miss Rosen, who is 33 years old, was previously administration manager in the operations department of The Times.

title: Toward a Safer Bang
description: Can a paper bag be as satisfying as a firecracker?

title: MUSIC: GOLDEN FLEECE OPERAS
description: SINCE its foundation 10 years ago, Golden Fleece Limited, under the artistic direction of Lou Rodgers, has produced over 40 new operas and works of musical theater. This is, in itself, a remarkable achievement; when one considers the lack of interest most larger opera companies have evinced for the music of our time, one's admiration redoubles.

title: 4-DAY BLITZ AND $800 FOR A FORMER CLOSET
description: GOING from demolition to completion of a small kitchen in four days was the challenge Donald Kindsvatter undertook for a friend who lived in a rental apartment of a converted Upper West Side hotel.

title: New Ford Engines
description: The Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary said that it would invest $204 million to produce up to 200,000 new ''lean burn'' engines, with production starting in 1987.

title: London Sugar Price Off
description: The London daily price of raw sugar for immediate delivery fell today to a 15-year low of $82 a metric ton, industry sources said. Analysts cite the surplus production of recent years.

title: WEARY FIREFIGHTERS ON COAST BATTLE FLAMES AND WEATHER
description: Firefighters battled more than a dozen major blazes in California today as a searing heat wave, low humidity, dry brush and wind combined to create explosive fire conditions in much of the state.

title: GORBACHEV'S RISE: ELEGANT AND STUNNINGLY SWIFT
description: Never in postwar history has a Soviet leader moved so fast to consolidate his control of Kremlin power. When the position of President was given Tuesday to someone other than Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Communist party leader, Soviet citizens and Westerners alike immediately assumed that this was a sign of Mr. Gorbachev's strength, not weakness.

title: Rail Unions Back Morgan
description: A group led by Morgan Stanley & Company won the support today of an influential committee of railroad labor unions for its bid to buy the Government's share of Conrail and resell it through public stock offerings.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OXFORD COMPANION TO ENGLISH LITERATURE. Fifth Edition.

title: Editing Nation's Attic
description: The new head of the Smithsonian is making clear what kind of an institution he wants it to be. Robert McC. Adams, who became secretary of the Smithsonian last September, says he is troubled by the attention given to some of the items collected from television shows that are now in the National Museum of American History, which is part of the Smithsonian. These items, which are extremely popular with tourists, include Archie Bunker's chair, J. R.'s hat, Mister Rogers's sweater and Fonzie's leather jacket, all on display in the museum's Division of Community Life.

title: RANGEL IS GIVEN F.B.I'S APOLOGY ON ACCUSATIONS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has dismissed as ''uncorroborated hearsay'' accusations in its files against Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, an aide to Mr. Rangel said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEE (AL) - Purchased the contract of Rick Waits, left-handed pitcher, from Vancouver in the Pacific Coast League.

title: Pennsylvania's Workers Vote to Accept Pact
description: State welfare and social service workers returned to work today after narrowly approving a new contract that cuts vacation and sick days but gives them a 3.25 percent pay increase.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: Share earnings figures have been restated to reflect a 3-For-2 stock split in December 1984.

title: PREPARING TO BUY AN AIR-CONDITIONER
description: IT happens every summer. A heat wave hits and people buy air-conditioners. But installing one in an apartment is not quite so simple as just bringing it home from the store and putting it in a window. Not only is it important to buy the right size unit for the space, but buyers should also first investigate the wiring in the building and any regulations established by landlords or co-op boards.

title: No Experience Needed
description: Although he has never run a team, Peter Mahovlich, who played in the National Hockey League for 16 years, has been hired to coach the Toledo Goaldiggers of the International Hockey League. ''I took a gamble on his having no coaching experience,'' Jerry Francis, the general manager of the Goaldiggers, said about the 39-year-old Mahovlich. ''It was a major move for me, but I was willing to take that gamble because of his name, his contacts and his vast playing experience in the N.H.L.'' Mahovlich worked as a commentator for the Madison Square Garden Network, a cable-television outfit, last season.

title: Stars of Doctrine, Stripes of Reason
description: America's freedoms are blends of passion and reason, vast in spirit yet grounded in practicality, often even rationed. The Declaration of Independence, which The Times reprints every Fourth of July, relied on reasonable argument for rejecting the Crown. Yes, there is a right of revolution, but not ''for light & transient causes.'' Reason is needed out of ''a decent respect for the opinions of mankind.'' Besides, as Garry Wills has noted, the resort to reason midst rebellion could solicit urgently needed help from France.

title: 'WHOLE THING IS LIKE A MOVIE'
description: He has been told, more than once, that life at the race track just does not work this way. Owning horses can't possibly be this easy. Harold Housman of Pittstown, N.J., nods and agrees. The owner of a construction firm, whose past trips to race tracks were just for fun, is not supposed to pay $14,000 for a broodmare that produces a colt that becomes the favorite in a $500,000 race.

title: SALVADOR JUDGE WON'T INDICT OFFICER
description: A Salvadoran judge ruled today that there was insufficient evidence to arrest an army captain accused by new witnesses of having taken part in the slaying of two American agrarian advisers and the head of the Government's land redistribution program here in 1981.

title: 'HEART' OF DODGERS BEATING STRONGLY
description: Pedro Guerrero was sitting in front of his cubicle in the Los Angeles Dodger locker room, looking down at the hands that had helped him hit a National League-record 15 home runs during the month of June.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BALLET: DAVID GORDON AT AMERICAN DANCE FESTIVAL
description: David Gordon appears to love folding chairs. He also seems to like making dancers look half asleep. These impressions were created by the performance that the David Gordon Pick Up Company offered Tuesday night at the American Dance Festival at Duke University.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Metropolitan Briefs column on Monday, about criticism of the Transit Authority's police radio system, incorrectly described communications between Officer Irma Lozada, who was slain on duty last September, and her partner. Only Officer Lozada carried a radio, and the transit police said there were no indications of transmission problems from the site where she was killed.

title: Barn-Burners Honored
description: When the 154th annual meeting of the International Platform Association convenes in Washington on Aug. 4, it will induct five new members into its Orators Hall of Fame.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE GELCO CORPORATATION-George R. May, director of Gelco Truck Leasing, sold 42,870 shares leaving him with a zero balance.

title: REMOVING A WALL BRINGS A VISUAL FOCUS
description: THE kitchen in Erika Franke's Upper East Side one-bedroom co-op was a disaster, dark and windowless. There was a pass-through in the wall to the living room, but there was only a foot of counter top, and the refrigerator, sink and stove were lined up on the back wall of the 6-by-3-foot space. ''There was just a foot between the kitchen equipment and that wall,'' Miss Franke said. ''You couldn't get two people in there at the same time.''

title: Koch Proposes Rules OnHorse Carriages
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced a plan to prohibit horse-drawn carriages from touring in congested midtown areas during peak traffic hours.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 4, 1985
description: Companies CBS offered to buy 21 percent of its stock, at a cost of nearly $1 billion, in a plan that appears to put Ted Turner's takeover offer in severe jeopardy. CBS would assume debt that would substantially increase the cost for anyone acquiring the company. Also, securities to be exchanged for the stock carry terms that restrict future debt CBS could assume. Mr. Turner's offer would raise CBS's debt far beyond the level permitted under these terms. [Page A1.] Analysts generally praised the plan, saying CBS had managed to buy protection from takeovers that involved a high level of debt without hurting itself financially. [D4.] Sales of new American-made cars fell 11.8 percent in late June. Figures for all of June showed a 3.2 percent decline, on a daily selling rate basis. Analysts cited a surge in imports, whose sales jumped 17.5 percent in the month. They also noted that many incentive programs, such as cut-rate financing, have expired. These incentives may soon be reinstated, some analysts said. [D1.] Global Marine, having suspended payments on $1.03 billion of debt, nonetheless expects to avoid bankruptcy proceedings. The company has been talking with its creditors since May in an effort to restructure the long-term debt. [D1.] Squibb got F.D.A. approval to market its hypertension drug, Capoten, for all stages of the disease. In reaction, the company's stock jumped $3.25, to $67.25. [D1.] Concessions offered by pilots to Carl C. Icahn to encourage him to take over T.W.A. are part of a deal that limits his ability to sell airline assets and cut capital spending.

title: Interest Rates Rise Slightly
description: Growing concern over the direction of Federal Reserve monetary policy sent interest rates higher yesterday, but the movement was small and trading in the credit market was extremely thin in advance of the Fourth of July holiday.

title: BIOLOGIST REVISES STATEMENT ON WESTWAY'S BASS IMPACT
description: A biologist who drafted an environmental statement that said Westway would have a ''significant adverse impact'' on striped bass testified yesterday that he had merely meant that it would have ''a measurable impact.''

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: AS a symbol of summer, the Adirondack lawn chair is as American as apple pie, ice cream sodas at the drugstore counter or the Stars and Stripes waving against a white clapborad house on the Fourth of July. Driving along country roads, one sees these wooden chairs flashing by on lawn after lawn, in clusters of three or four, usually painted white, dark green or occasionally red, their slanted, fanned-out, high slat backs and wide, flat arms the signs of ease and comfort.

title: Flour Deal With Egypt
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block announced today that the United States would subsidize wheat flour exports to Egypt in an attempt to displace sales by the European Economic Community.

title: A.T.&T. in Japan
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as expected, said that it had joined 16 Japanese companies to start a system to permit communication among dissimilar kinds of computers. The company said it expected to ''dramatically increase'' its sales share in a sector that the American Government sees as a key test of Japan's willingness to open its market wider to foreigners.

title: Full Employment, the Donkey Serenade for '88
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS, TRYING TO BLOCK TURNER BID, TO BUY $1 BILLION OF ITS OWN STOCK
description: CBS Inc., moving aggressively to thwart Ted Turner's takeover offer, announced yesterday that it would spend nearly $1 billion to repurchase up to 21 percent of its stock.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT might be just the thing for a rainy summer day, or for those who are thinking of moving furniture around but do not really have the energy to do it: ProCreations's Plan-A-Flex Home Designer, a home design kit by Lise Matthews and Bud Brimberg that includes a reusable floor plan and more than 400 quarter-inch-scale architectural symbols that represent beds, chairs, tables, sofas, desks and a piano; bathroom and kitchen appliances, and various building components. The vinyl symbols easily peel off an 18-inch-wide by 24-inch-long Mylar floor plan. The kit, which also includes a design manual and 1/4-inch rule, is $25 at the Museum Store, 11 West 53d Street.

title: ETHIOPIA'S MIDDLE CLASS INCREASINGLY FEELS PINCH
description: For a man who runs a small business, it means no longer being able to take his family on Sunday drives.

title: STUDY SAYS MEDICARE RULE BLURS COST OF TREATMENT
description: A new study from the Johns Hopkins University challenges the validity of a classification system used by the Government to decide how much hospitals are paid for treating elderly and disabled people under Medicare.

title: MCENROE IS ROUTED FOR HIS WORST LOSS IN WIMBLEDON PLAY
description: John McEnroe, the No. 1 seeded player and a three-time Wimbledon champion, was eliminated in a quarterfinal match today by the scorching serves of Kevin Curren.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 7.

title: 'CURRENTS,' ON PBS, EXAMINES PATRIOTISM
description: WHAT is ''The New Patriotism,'' and is it good, bad or something of both?

title: RESEARCHER SAYS FLAMES ENGULFED FUN HOUSE IN ABOUT 4 1/2 MINUTES
description: A fire researcher testified today that flames probably engulfed the Haunted Castle at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park last year about four and a half minutes after the blaze started.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses of $269,000 for the quarter and $1,108,000 for the year related to the company's subsidiary Metalworking Laser International and an extraordinary charge of $39,000 for the quarter. c-After losses of $160,000 for the quarter and $210,000 for the year.

title: U.S. SAYS EDWARDS OFFERED TO QUIT
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards told a United States Attorney he would resign if the official agreed to block an indictment of the Governor, a request that was refused, according to grand jury testimony released today by a Federal judge.

title: FOR JOHNNY OTIS'S BAND, A 30-YEAR REPRETORY
description: THE Johnny Otis Show, which rocked Carnegie Hall on Saturday, is an oldies act with a difference. Its repertory spans the 1930's through the 1960's, embracing swing tunes, electric blues, jazz ballads and rhythm and blues. With precision and old-fashioned showmanship, Mr. Otis's band of old hands and newcomers makes every selection jump and shout.
