title: Curtice-Burns Appoints An Official to Top Posts
description: Curtice-Burns Inc., a little-known but fast-growing food processing company, said yesterday that David J. McDonald had been named president and chief executive officer.

title: DOVETAIL JOINT IS STRONG AND DECORATIVE
description: In the construction of furniture, one of the truly serviceable joints is the dovetail. It is aptly named, for the interlocking teeth are in the shape of the spread of a dove's tail.

title: SHULTZ SUGGESTS MORE SOVIET TALKS ARE A POSSIBILITY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, might hold a rotating series of meetings in each other's capitals if their first session in Geneva next November turns out well.

title: ISRAEL RELEASES 300 OF THE 735 DETAINEES
description: Israel today freed 300 of the 735 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees it has been holding in Atlit prison south of Haifa, but reasserted that their release was in no way connected to any deals with the Beirut hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jetliner.

title: Gromyko Used to Smile
description: Almost everything has changed since Oscar Berger drew his first caricature of Andrei A. Gromyko in 1945. Everything but the Soviet official's face.

title: Westport Theater Sold; Conversion Is Blocked
description: A group of investors announced yesterday that it had purchased the Westport Country Playhouse for $1.2 million, preventing its conversion to condominiums.

title: T. E. Kalem, 65, Dead; Drama Critic for Time
description: T. E. Kalem, the drama critic for Time magazine since 1961 and former president of the New York Drama Critics Circle, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sudan Reports Meetings In London With Rebels
description: A minister in the new military-sponsored Government has reported meetings with rebels fighting a guerrilla war in the southern Sudan. It would be the first such contact since the uprising began two and a half years ago.

title: TARGET PROBLEMS DELAY TEST OF U.S. ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: The Air Force said today that its first test of an antisatellite missile against an object in space would be delayed because of technical problems with the target.

title: 2 Carolina Banks Agree to a Merger
description: The NCNB Corporation and Bankers Trust of South Carolina said yesterday that they would merge across state lines in a transaction valued at $307 million.

title: Grand Central Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Match Races May Be Back
description: Saturday is the 10th anniversary of one of the most vivid tragedies in thoroughbred-racing history: the death of Ruffian, who was destroyed after shattering her right front ankle in a match race against Foolish Pleasure at Belmont Park on July 6, 1975.

title: LATE-JUNE CAR SALES FELL 11.8%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles, hindered by increased shipments from Japan, fell 11.8 percent in the last 10 days of June, the manufacturers reported today. For the full month, sales of domestically produced cars slipped 3.2 percent, on a daily selling rate basis.

title: Wilson's Injury Repaired
description: Torn cartilage was discovered, and repaired, in Mookie Wilson's right shoulder yesterday during arthroscopic surgery at Roosevelt Hospital. But the 29-year-old Mets center fielder still was expected to miss at least six weeks of play and probably more.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bangladesh Appoints 7 Ministers to Cabinet
description: President H. M. Ershad appointed seven new ministers today, bringing the number in the Cabinet to 21, the Government announced. He also named three state ministers and one deputy minister.

title: Lucrative Weekend of Races
description: Is the third-best older horse in California better than the best in New York? Is Win ready to pick up where he left off last fall? Can Mom's Command become the first filly triple crown winner in six years? Can Stephan's Odyssey finally win a big race intead of running second? Those questions will be answered in the next four days at Belmont Park after four consecutive major stakes races that will showcase many of the sport's stars.

title: Darien Man Slain
description: A 67-year-old man was found beaten to death in his home here Tuesday night, and the police said today that they had begun a ''full-blown homicide investigation.''

title: Slide in Yields Eases
description: The rapid decline of rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds in the last few months appears to have abated, according to figures compiled for the week ended yesterday.

title: Defying Draft Registry Brings 6-Month Term
description: A 25-year-old man was sentenced Tuesday to six months in jail for refusing to register with the Selective Service System.

title: WEARING THE FAME OF JULY 4
description: To millions of Americans, the Fourth of July parades, picnics and fireworks. It has also been a significant date in other ways.

title: HERS
description: LATELY, I have been thinking about Warren Beatty and whether I could give him my unwavering support if and when he ever runs for public office. In all candor, I had not even considered this question until three weeks ago when I happened to come across an article in ''U.S.A. Today'' that suggested the well-known actor, who has long been active in Democratic politics, might one day throw his own hat in the ring.

title: FOR THE PARENTS, TOO, HEAD START CAN PROVIDE LIFE OPPORTUNITIES
description: THE success of Head Start, a Federal program combining classes for 3- and 4-year-olds with social services for low-income families, has been well documented. Young students attend Head Start do better than their peers through high school. But there is also evidence that the program can have a dramatic effect on parents.

title: 15 Hurt in Bronx Crash
description: A four-vehicle accident on the Cross Bronx Expressway injured 15 people and delayed thousands of motorists yesterday afternoon, traffic officials said. The accident, at 3:48 P.M., involved a tractor-trailer truck, two cars and a van and forced the closing of the westbound lanes of the expressway at Jerome Avenue, less than a mile east of the George Washington Bridge. The lanes were reopened at 5:48 P.M.

title: Alaskans to Consider Impeaching Governor
description: The Alaska Legislature will convene in special session July 15 to consider impeach proceedings against Gov. Bill Sheffield, the President of the State Senate said today.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATION: MEETING OVER, WORK STARTS ON A NEW IMAGE
description: The annual convention of the National Education Association, which ended here today, produced strong signals that the group was concerned about its image and how to refurbish it.

title: Stacking the Corporate Deck
description: With little notice and no chance for public comment, the New York Legislature has passed a bill that would make hostile takeovers of corporations in the state extremely difficult. Sponsors blandly label it a means ''to strike a balance between the interests of shareholders, management, employees, creditors and the general public.'' The real purpose is to insulate managements from unhappy stockholders, notably the managers of CBS, now being challenged by Ted Turner. Without concerning himself about the effect in any one case, Governor Cuomo should veto the bill.

title: NBC Leads Ratings For 6th Straight Week
description: NBC finished first in the Neilsen ratings for the week ended June 30, the sixth straight week it has won the ratings battle.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE GLORIOUS FOURTH Back in 1776, John Adams envisioned the future celebration of the Fourth of July. ''It ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bell-ringing, bonfires and illuminations, from one end of the continent to to the other, from this time forevermore.''

title: GLOBAL MARINE EXPECTS ACCORD WITH CREDITORS
description: Global Marine Inc., an offshore drilling contractor that suspended principal and interest payments this week on $1.03 billion of debt, nonetheless expects to avoid bankruptcy proceedings, company officials said yesterday.

title: CBS, Trying to Block Turner Bid, to Buy $1 Billion of Its Own Stock
description: CBS Inc., moving aggressively to thwart Ted Turner's takeover offer, announced yesterday that it would spend nearly $1 billion to repurchase up to 21 percent of its stock.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pat Eddery, the 33-year-old Irish jockey, captured the first European jockey championship in Hamburg, West Germany. Steve Cauthen, the British-based American, was second and Lester Piggott, the British legend, finished last in a field of 12 riders. . . . The Milwaukee Brewers have purchased the contract of the left-handed pitcher Rick Waits, 33 years old, who had a 10-5 record with the Vancouver Canadians of the Pacific Coast League. Waits also has a 76-90 record in nine major-league seasons.

title: Kurdish Rebels Release 22 of 26 Hostages in Iraq
description: Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq, who have held 26 foreign technicians hostage for months, have released 22 of their captives, but kept four others, a rebel spokesman said today.

title: SAILOR SAYS HIS MILITARY TRAINING HELPED HIME DURING ORDEAL
description: One of the Navy sailors held captive in Lebanon said today that his military training had helped him and his comrades survive their ordeal.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 7:05 P.M. Opener of a four-game weekend series and an 11-game, 11-day homestand. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. Opener of a four-game weekend series and the start of a trip that takes the Mets to 3 cities in 11 days for 11 games. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M., and WTBS, 7:40 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Canadian Open, at Oakville, Ontario. Opening round. (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M.) Ladies Professional Golf Association Mazda Hall of Fame Championships, at Sugarland, Tex. PGA Seniors Greenbrier Classic, at White Silver Springs, W. Va. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. On the Road Again is the early 6-5 favorite to become the first horse to sweep the World Cup Pacing Series. (Television - MSG, midnight.) Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, midnight.) Goshen, N.Y., 1:30 P.M. There is no parimutuel betting at rustic Historic Track, but four days of racing will begin. Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon. (Television - HBO Cable, 9 A.M. to noon live. Channel 4, 2 P.M. to 5 P.M.; 11:30 P.M. to 11:45 P.M. update and 12:45 A.M. to 2:45 A.M. tapes.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1 P.M. The $250,000-added Suburban, second leg of the handicap triple crown for 3-year-olds and up at a mile and a quarter is the feature.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 4, 1985
description: International A series of summit meetings between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachav might be scheduled if their meeting in Geneva in late November turns out well, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Mr. Shultz said the meetings might alternate between Washington and Moscow. [Page A1, Column 6.] Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit Paris in October before he meets with President Reagan in late November, Moscow announced. A spokesman gave the Soviet leader's visit to France more emphasis than the meeting with Mr. Reagan. [A4:3-5.] Syria devised the formula that led to the release of the 39 American hostages, United States officials said. They also disclosed that Iran, in an apparent effort to keep in step with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and thus hold Syria's support for its war with Iraq, also used its influence with the radical hijackers to persuade them to free the captives. [A1:3.] Crew members of the hijacked jet told a grim story of their 17 days in captivity, describing brutal beatings and an alternating cruelty and kindness by their captors. [A7:1-6.] The ex-hostages offered more details of their captivity. Several described the game of Russian roulette played by one hijacker, who loaded his revolver with one bullet, spun the chamber, aimed at a hostage and pulled the trigger. [A6:1-2.] Peking freed the Bishop of Shanghai, who has spent nearly 30 years in jail, the New China News Agency announced.

title: DESIGNS FOR SUMMER AT A SHOW HOUSE IN SOUTHAMPTON
description: IT'S just the kind of house, half hidden behind tall pruned hedges and shaded by 100-year-old trees, that one tends to drive by very slowly, hoping to catch a glimpse inside. And now that Wyndecote, the 25-room summer residence of Cordelia Drexel Biddle Duke Robertson, has been chosen as a decorators' show house, visitors will get a chance to see one of the most impressive mansions of Southampton from top to bottom.

title: Collegian on Probation
description: Craig Heyward, a freshman running back at the University of Pittsburgh, has received two years probation on a charge of assaulting another student with a wooden crutch.

title: Chief Executive Is Named by Sun
description: The Sun Company yesterday named its president and chief operating officer, Robert McClements Jr., to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Theodore A. Burtis, who remains chairman of the nation's 10th-largest oil company.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $98,681. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $266,952.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SYRIA DEVISED FORMULA TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: It was the United States that initially drew Nabih Berri, the Amal leader, into the T.W.A. hostage crisis but it was Preident Hafez al-Assad of Syria who conceived and proposed the arrangement that led to the release of the 39 hostages, American officials reported today.

title: Summit Talks Started in War
description: The session planned for Geneva would be the latest in a long series of Soviet-American meetings.

title: DeLorean Wins Jurisdictional Test
description: A Superior Court judge ruled here today that New Jersey should be the battleground for a dispute between John Z. DeLorean and his former wife, who are contesting the division of $10 million in property and the custody of their two children.

title: Bridge: Par at Card Table Is Found In an Assortment of Forms
description: Par on the golf course is a simple concept, but par at the card table is a complex one. Each deal has four pars: a North-South par, an East-West par, an absolute par, which assumes that both sides do their theoretical best, and a practical par, based on good play that is not, however, double-dummy.

title: Selling Western Water
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. GEORGE HALLETT OF CITIZENS UNION
description: Dr. George Hallett, a monitor of New York City government and the executive secretary and legislative representative of the Citizens Union for nearly 40 years, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at his office in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: METS TRIUMPH: YANKS FAIL IN 10
description: For all of the commotion over their recent baseball move toward the top, the Yankees were beaten by the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2, today because of a football move.

title: An ECU Issue Made by Disney
description: Walt Disney Productions is issuing 80 million European Currency Units of 9 1/8 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at a price of 100 1/4 through a group of underwriters led by the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a merger as a pooling of interests.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IF a chest, dresser or desk drawer that has been working smoothly suddenly becomes difficult to open at this time of year, the most likely reason is that the wood has swollen after absorbing moisture during periods of high humidity. If the drawer can be opened at least six inches and warping or swelling is suspected, there is a simple trick that often works:

title: REAGAN DELAYS PUSH ON TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan, who has spent the last month trying to drum up support for his tax plan, has decided to temporarily shift his focus from taxes and begin a new push to secure Congressional approval of a deficit reduction package, White House officials said today.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Year to March 31
INDIAN MUSEUM SHELVES NEGOTIATIONS WITH PEROT
description: Officials of the Museum of the American Indian said yesterday that they had suspended negotiations with H. Ross Perot, the Dallas computer executive who is seeking to relocate the museum in Texas, in order to pursue a plan to merge the museum with the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.

title: Reregister to Vote With Address-Change Form
description: To the Editor:

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a charge of $545,000 to recognize excess and obsolete inventory. c-After a charge of $100,000 for inventory chargeoffs and a tax credit of $1,055,000.

title: GORBACHEV TO VISIT PARIS BEFORE MEETING REAGAN
description: The Soviet Union announced today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would travel to France in October before holding a summit meeting with President Reagan in November.

title: Technology;   Software Fears On 'Star Wars'
description: THE Reagan Administration's scenario for nuclear defense in the year 2000 goes something like this: American satellites, scouring the earth's surface, detect hot flares of a mass of just-launched nuclear missiles. After confirming that the flares are indeed missiles - not just the burnoff from an oilfield - the satellites signal to a series of supercomputers, which begin the awesome task of tracking each incoming missile, and then firing blasts of laser beams that destroy them one by one.

title: BRIEFS
description: Belco Petroleum Ecuador Inc., a unit of Internorth Inc.'s Belco Petroleum Corp. unit, said it would invest $21.6 million in petroleum exploration in the Gulf of Guayaquil off the coast of Ecuador.

title: TINY KITCHENS REDONE ON A BUDGET
description: COPING with a tiny and inconvenient kitchen is a fact of life for many New Yorkers -particularly those who live in brownstones or apartments divided up out of larger spaces. Often the kitchens have been tucked into areas never intended as such: wall niches, former closets or dark windowless corners.

title: Reason to Celebrate
description: On the Fourth of July we often hear about feats of American power in the cause of freedom: battles won, enemies vanquished. This year we have reason to celebrate a more difficult achievement: victory by restraint in the use of power.

title: TIGERS TOP ORIOLES ON HOMER IN 10TH
description: Dave Bergman hit the first pitch from Sammy Stewart in the 10th inning tonight for a home run to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $23,170. c-After an extraordinary loss of $300,000 from a pension withdrawl liability assessment. d-Net income including a gain from discontinued operations of $139,901 and an extraordinary tax credit of $504,000.

title: Texas Runoff Election Set
description: An Aug. 3 runoff has been set in Texas' First Congressional District between Edd Hargett, a Republican, and Jim Chapman, a Democrat. State officials Tuesday certified a canvass of Saturday's election, showing Mr. Hargett the leader with 42 percent, 29,720 votes.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for 16 wks to May 18
ISRAEL, WOOING UNIONS, DELAYS PART OF AUSTERITY
description: The Israeli Government, in an effort to win the support of labor for its sweeping austerity plan, has agreed to postpone some of its tougher elements pending discussions on how to cushion the impact on wage earners.

title: The U.N. Today: July 5, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 15 HARPISTS TO OPEN THE SUMMERGARDEN SERIES
description: DURING the 1970's, the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden series became a New York institution, offering varied musical programs in the museum's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden.

title: G.E. Wins Contract
description: The Department of Water and Electricity of Abu Dhabi has decided in principle to award a major power contract to the General Electric Company of the United States, department sources said today. Sources said the contract was for supply and installation of three 85-megawatt gas turbines at the Taweelah power and desalination complex. A formal award is to be made next week, the sources said, ending a two-year bid process marked by several price revisions and retenderings.

title: TIJUANA RING WILL BE LEFT TO THE BULLS
description: There has always been a talent in boxing for throwing things, but this time it's gone a step further - they've thrown an entire bull ring.

title: Back on Top
description: As a once and future union leader, Nicholas Mancuso has spent an unusual two years - fighting labor fires as a city official and then fighting real fires with a ladder company in the South Bronx.

title: OFF-DUTY ABUSE OF DRUGS FEARED IN POLICE SURVEY
description: The Police Department's annual ''corruption assessment'' survey has found a growing concern among commanders over the possibility of drug abuse by off-duty officers.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS NEARING COMPLETION
description: After a flood of announcements of cancellations, cost overruns and safety problems, the nuclear power industry is looking eagerly to the next few months, when it expects to be able to announce the completions of a number of long-delayed plants.

title: Speakes Charges TV Violated Talks Vow
description: The television networks ''failed to honor their pledge'' regarding open microphones by broadcasting President Reagan's off-the-cuff remarks about handling the next hostage crisis like ''Rambo,'' the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, charged today.

title: MUST THEY TAKE THE SKY AWAY?
description: When I was growing up on a farm in a rural New Jersey village, there was no school bus to transport grade-school children to the two-room schoolhouse that was approximately two miles away from my home. Fields and woods separated the farmhouses and other family dwellings, bringing a sense of loneliness and isolation to my childhood. I remember walking to school, for the most part alone, carrying my books and a brown paper bag filled with thick lunch sandwiches and some of my mother's homemade cake or cookies that had been baked over the previous weekend.

title: Market Place;   As the CBS World Turns
description: IN a real-life drama, CBS Inc. has responded to the hostile takeover bid by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcasting entrepreneur, with an offer to buy back 21 percent of its stock for $954.8 million in cash and securities.

title: D.D.B., Toyko Agency Buy Stake in Coast Shop
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach of New York and Dai-Ichi Kikaku of Tokyo, each of which has an equity position in the other ad agency, now have each acquired one-third ownership of Kresser-Craig, a recently formed Los Angeles agency with about $20 million in billings. The Los Angeles shop will continue to operate independently as Kresser, Craig/D.I.K., with Robert Kresser, chairman and chief executive, and Jean Craig as president and creative director. And if you wonder about the lack of a D.D.B. in the new name, perhaps it has something to do with an existing D.D.B. office in town.

title: Soccer Restrictions
description: Graham Kelly, the secretary of England's 92 professional soccer clubs, has rejected a call by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to introduce a national membership card scheme intended to combat crowd violence. ''It can't be done,'' Kelly said after a two-hour chairmen's meeting in London.

title: Rachel D. Webb Wed in Vermont
description: Rachel Drake Webb, the daughter of Drs. Kempton and Nancy Webb of Ridgewood, N.J., and Vergennes, Vt., was married yesterday to William J. Scott Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Scott of Framingham, Mass.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday AN UP-TO-THE-MINUTE REVUE A topical revue dates quickly, but ''What's a Nice Country Like You Still Doing in a State Like This?'' has managed to keep on playing for 13 years, with fresh material inspired continuously by the day's news. The satirical musical revue begins performances this weekend in yet another incarnation, this time at the Actors' Playhouse, at 100 Seventh Avenue South, at Broome Street. Old favorites such as ''I'm Not Myself Anymore,'' ''How'm I Doin'?'' and ''Nuclear Winter'' - whose subjects are organ transplants, Mayor Koch and World War III - will be supplemented with such new numbers as ''Everyone Ought to Have a Gun,'' a look at modern modes of self-defense, and ''Born Again,'' which takes on religious cults. Performances are tonight and tomorrow night at 7 and 10 o'clock and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 and $15. Reservations: 691-6226. BACH IN NEW BRUNSWICK Bach lovers can celebrate the composer as well as the holiday weekend with a program called ''J. S. Bach and His World,'' sponsored by the Aston Magna Foundation for Music Inc. and held at the Douglass College campus of Rutgers University in New Brunswick. ''Bach, the Master'' is the title of an organ-recital program by Robert Parkins that includes the Toccata and Fugue in D minor. It will be given tonight at 8 o'clock in the Voorhees Chapel. Tomorrow at 4 P.M., Laurence Libin, an authority on 18th-century instruments, will give a lecture called ''The Keyboard Instruments for Which Bach Composed'' in the Nicholas Music Center.

title: 2 Tennessee Prisons Restore Privileges
description: Inmates at two prisons got privileges restored today in time for Fourth of July picnics as state officials relaxed the rule on new uniforms that led to two days of violence.

title: U.S. CREWS GAIN AT HENLEY
description: The Band of the Coldstream Guards roused the opening-day crowds with Sousa's ''Stars and Stripes Forever'' today as American crews in the 140th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta made it a star-spangled Fourth of July.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day June 25 accompanying an article on independent television stations misstated the call letters and market share of a station in Houston owned by Metromedia Inc. The station, KRIV-TV, has a 10 percent market share.

title: ARGENTINES WITH A MINT OF THEIR OWN
description: It is hard to tell if Saltenos are ahead of their time or a throwback to yesteryear, or if they simply live in their own world, for what happens in the rest of Argentina simply doesn't matter here.

title: Cheska Triumphs In Open Class
description: Donald Cheska of Waukesha, Wis., turned in two fault-free rounds on Eadenvale in today's $3,000 open power and speed class to win his first open class of the week at the ninth annual I Love New York Horse Show.

title: L.I. Driver Wins Firecracker 400
description: Greg Sacks, driving a Chevrolet Monte Carlo, overtook Bill Elliott's Ford Thunderbird today to score a surprising victory in the Pepsi Firecracker 400 Grand National stock car race. It was the first victory in a Grand National race for Sacks.

title: NORMAN AND GALLAGHER LEAD
description: ''I just want to get the Shark Attack going again,'' said Greg Norman, the Australian golfer who is known as the Shark.

title: PRESERVING ISLAND TRADITION
description: There are two main purposes to the cricket match Sunday between the national team of Grenada and the American All-Stars at Memorial Stadium in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: MISS LIBERTY OFFSTAGE, BUY CITY HAS A POPPING 4TH
description: The Statue of Liberty is closed for restoration, but all the rest of New York crackled and boomed with patriotism yesterday as crowds gathered to celebrate the nation's 209th birthday.

title: 'THE STUDENT PRINCE,' IN CITY OPERA'S NEW SUMMER SEASON
description: Deep in the heart of every tenor there lies, or at least used to lie, a sentimental urge to sing the songs of the student prince Karl Franz in Sigmund Romberg's lush 1924 operetta. Luciano Pavarotti and Placido Domingo don't seem to have discovered the ''Serenade'' yet; they should have a look. Household record shelves of the 1950's might have held versions by (at least) Jan Peerce, James Melton, Lauritz Melchior and of course Mario Lanza, whose dubbed voice was the chief success of the 1954 film version.

title: DEATH SQUADS ATTACKING BLACKS, SOUTH AFRICA OPPOSITION CHARGES
description: South Africa's principal nonparliamentary opposition group accused the Government ''or its agents'' today of starting a campaign of political assassinations against its enemies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STUBBORN CHILD. By Mark Devlin. 255 pages. Atheneum. $14.95.

title: MORE MARRIED WOMEN CHOOSING STERILIZATION
description: Seven years ago, when JoEllen Mayes was 36 years old and her husband, Gordon, was 44, they had a terrible fright: Mrs. Mayes thought she might be pregnant.

title: Two-State Sales Tax Posse
description: New York and New Jersey have begun a commendable collaboration to hunt down evaders of sales and use taxes. Together, in what many consumers consider an innocent cat-and-mouse game, they lose about $100 million a year. Interstate cooperation is the only way to stop it.

title: BRONXVILLE WOMAN SHOT IN HAND DURING GAME IN YANKEE STADIUM
description: A 34-year-old Bronxville, N.Y., woman was shot in the right hand last night as she watched a baseball game with her husband and two sons in Yankee Stadium, the police said.

title: W.A. VISSER 'T HOOFT, CHURCHMAN, DIES AT 84
description: The Rev. Dr. Willem Adolf Visser 't Hooft, who led the World Council of Chuches as its secretary general from its formation in 1948 until 1966, died of emphysema yesterday at his home in Geneva. He was 84 years old.

title: Pamela R. Sherrid Marries Lanny Schwartz, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Pamela Rose Sherrid, an associate editor at Forbes magazine, and Lanny Schwartz, an associate in the New York law firm of Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Harlan Wexler, assisted by Rabbi David Kahane, performed the ceremony.

title: Life Goes On On 11 4th Street
description: First thing yesterday morning, a band appeared on West 114th Street and played its heart out for two hours. Of course, everybody knew what the celebration was about: It was Pappy's 65th birthday.

title: PHILIPS EXECUTIVE FILLS 2 KEY POSTS AT SIGNETICS
description: At first glance, Norman A. Neumann's new job as president and chief executive of the Signetics Corporation, the sixth-largest semiconductor manufacturer in the United States, looks like a step down. But Mr. Neumann, who had been vice president-group executive of the North American Philips Corporation, does not see it that way. ''I'm not taking a pay cut,'' said Mr. Neumann, who had worked at Philips for 17 years and had helped engineer the purchase of Signetics in 1975.

title: Sudan Crowd Demands Egypt Return Ex-Leader
description: Hundreds of people marched on the Egyptian Embassy here today to demand the extradition of former President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, who has lived in Egypt since being deposed in a coup three months ago.

title: Puzzlements
description: Even when transit announcements are clear in tone, they are not always clear in meaning.

title: Iraq Reports Air Attack On Iran Military Camp
description: Iraq said its aircraft had attacked a military camp in western Iran today.

title: Ex-Norwegian Envoy Appeals 20-Year Sentence for Spying
description: A former Norwegian diplomat lodged appeals today against a 20-year jail sentence for spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq.

title: BRAZIL PLAN TO REDUCE INFLATION
description: Brazil's new Government announced a long-awaited package of austerity measures today aimed at reducing inflation and preparing the way for a credit agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Karen Zeitel Marries
description: Karen H. Zeitel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram E. Zeitel of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Mitchell Brand, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Brand of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Henry A. Sosland performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride will retain her name professionally as an account executive with L. F. Rothchild, Unterberg, Towbin. Mr. Brand is an associate in the New York law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen.

title: BRIGHTER, CLEANER Paint Container
description: For a long time in New York City, everyone has talked about the graffiti problem, but city officials have done little about it - a sad state of affairs for a town that prizes its public buildings and monuments and depends so heavily on the mass-transit system. Now there is evidence that impatience is overcoming indifference.

title: TRIBUTE TO ARMSTRONG
description: ON Sunday evening, with this year's Kool Jazz Festival drawing to a close and with just four days before what would have been Louis Armstrong's 85th birthday, the coronetist Ruby Braff and Dick Hyman, playing both piano and organ, performed a tribute to Mr. Armstrong in the Sanctuary of St. Peter's Church.

title: 'ALIVE FROM OFF CENTER,' A SHOWCASE
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION has long had its proper servings of establishment-approved culture in such series as ''Live From Lincoln Center.'' Now, KTCA-TV of Minneapolis-St. Paul and the Walker Art Center of Minneapolis have assembled a package of eight weekly half-hours that promises to ''offer the first on-going opportunity for television audiences to experience the innovative video being created by the country's most adventurous artists.'' ''Alive From Off Center'' gets under way on Channel 13 Sunday evening at 10:30.

title: Advertising;   Thompson Wins Beer Account
description: THE Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson has won the competition for the Miller Brewing Company's Lowenbrau beer account. The billings have been reported in the trade press to be around $20 million.

title: Latin Double Bill
description: The flutist Dave Valentin and the alto saxophonist Paquito d'Rivera will share a double bill of Latin jazz tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

title: SPAIN'S LEADER DROPS TOP AIDES IN A BIG SHUFFLE
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez appointed new foreign and economy ministers today in a Cabinet shakeup that dramatically altered his 31-month-old Government.

title: A West Coast Agency Toasts Two Victories
description: Much further to the West, Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein, Los Angeles, has had a week full of victory toasts thanks to two Japanese manufacturers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 5, 1985
description: International

title: JAPANESE TRUST BANK SET FOR U.S.
description: Daiwa Securities said today that it would open a trust bank in the United States. Daiwa will be the first Japanese securities company allowed to enter the trust business overseas, and its entry is expected to trigger a rush among its competitors to the United States market.

title: Musyoki, Waitz Win in Atlanta
description: The winners two years ago, Michael Musyoki of Kenya and Grete Waitz of Norway, won the 10-kilometer Peachtree Road Race today.

title: EX-SPOKESMAN SAYS HE BACKS HIS STATEMENTS
description: The former hostage spokesman, Allyn B. Conwell, said today that he stood by his statement that some hostages felt sympathy for the cause and plight of the Lebanese Shiite Moslems who took custody of 39 Americans from their two original hijackers, Much of the debate over his role as spokesman stemmed from a failure to clearly distinguish between the two hijackers and the Amal militiamen who ultimately took charge of the hostages and participated in negotiating their release, Mr. Conwell said at a news conference.

title: OPEC OIL MINISTERS MEET AMID DISCORD ON PRICING POLICY
description: OPEC oil ministers assembled here today for a critical meeting after weeks of informal discussions apparently failed to yield any agreement on how to strengthen their organization, according to officials arranging the meeting for Friday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical Buildings Inc. has named its president, John Lundeen, to the added post of chief executive officer.

title: GAMBLE ON GOODEN IS FOILED BY RAIN
description: Dave Johnson's master plan - to get three starts out of Dwight Gooden before the All-Star break - had some merit. But Johnson didn't plan on rain. The Mets' manager made Gooden a surprise starter tonight, using him on three days' rest for the first time in his major league career. But two rain delays totaling 2 hours 5 minutes finally forced Gooden out.

title: HAMIET BLUIETT QUARTET AT ST. PETER'S
description: THE Soundscape concert for the Kool Jazz Festival at St. Peter's Church on Saturday took on an odd dimension when the bassist in Jason Hwang's group, Glass Shadows, which was scheduled to open the program, was delayed by a bus breakdown en route from Saratoga Springs, where he had played for the festival earlier in the day.

title: LEBANON MOVES TO SECURE AIRPORT: ERECTS BARRIERS AND BANS MILITIA
description: The Lebanese Government said today that in an effort to restore confidence in Beirut International Airport, it had erected earthen barriers to prevent unauthorized cars from driving onto runways and would ban armed militiamen from the airport perimeter.

title: ZIMBABWEANS ENDURE DISCOMFORT TO CAST BALLOTS
description: Voting ended tonight in this southern African nation's first general election since it came under majority rule. For some this week, it was a test of will.

title: T.W.A. Pilot Leads Anti-takeover Fight
description: Harry R. Hoglander has spent the last 21 years flying airplanes for Trans World Airlines. But Mr. Hoglander, who is 52 years old, is not sure he would continue at T.W.A. if the Texas Air Corporation's $925 million acquisition of the carrier goes through.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Most of the wares auctioned here twice a year by Christie's and Sotheby's in sales totaling millions of dollars move in and out of Switzerland as swiftly and easily as many tourists do.

title: Bridge: A Fine Australian Magazine Gets New Expert as Editor
description: One of the world's best bridge magazines, Australian Bridge, had a change of editor recently. After 13 years in charge, Ron Klinger handed the editorial reins to an expert of equally high stature, Paul Lavings.

title: 3 Arrested in Taiwan Over Military Secrets
description: Two political dissidents and a junior Government officer have been arrested and accused of jeopardizing military secrets, investigators from the Justice Ministry said today.

title: THE TRAUMATIC TIRE BUSINESS
description: Once, the United States tire industry was all things to all people. The major companies found it easy to sell tires wherever they could: to Detroit, to the replacement market and to foreign markets. They also ran tire shop chains and auto service centers.

title: FRANK SELKE
description: Frank Selke, architect of the successful Montreal Canadien teams of the 1950's and a member of the Pro Hockey Hall of Fame, died Wednesday.

title: HOW '81 TAX INCENTIVES HAVE AFFECTED INVESTING
description: The tax incentives for capital investment that were central to President Reagan's supply-side economics - and which he now proposes to cut back - have not produced the surge of investment in plant and equipment that Congress sought to promote four years ago, according to some economists who study trends in business investment.

title: Buffalo Man Killed As Bomb Goes Off
description: One man was fatally injured and another was hurt here today when a bomb they were making in an apartment exploded, the police said.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Brighter, Cleaner Inner City Light
description: With electricity usage declining in rundown areas of New York City, Con Ed offered intelligent discounts to commercial customers willing to take a risk to overcome urban blight.

title: THOUSANDS OF ETHIOPIANS FORM A DIVERSE COMMUNITY
description: A number of East African restaurants have opened in recent years in Adams Morgan, a multiethnic neighborhood whose business listings often provide a tip to the latest influx of immigrants or political refugees.

title: VANLANDINGHAM WINS EASILY
description: It looked like John Ed Anthony and Shug McGaughey were going with the wrong horse when they scratched the stretch-running Pine Circle and decided to go with the front-running Vanlandingham in what had looked like a speed-packed Suburban Handicap. It turned out they knew what they were doing. Vanlandingham, regarded as the weaker half of their original entry, ran off to lead every step of the way and win the $301,000 Suburban by an astounding 8 3/4 lengths yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ART: 'PAINTERLY VISIONS' OF THE GUGGENHEIM
description: WHEN museums turn their permanent collections into summer shows, it is hard to know what to expect. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum certainly had enough important work to choose from. The title of this summer's show, ''Painterly Visions, 1940-1984: The Guggenheim Museum Collection and Major Loans,'' was auspicious. At the least the exhibition promised to show good paintings, give a clearer sense of the less celebrated and less developed part of the permanent collection and offer a preview of what the public will see when the museum's building expansion is completed, probably in 1987.

title: OLU DARA AND HIS OKRA ORCHESTRA
description: OLU DARA and his Okra Orchestra may well be the best unrecorded band in New York City, as their Jazz Festival performance at the Prospect Park band shell in Brooklyn on Saturday night demonstrated.

title: Puerto Ricans Demonstrate For Independence From U.S.
description: Thousands of Puerto Ricans, many shouting slogans against ''Yankee Imperialism,'' demonstrated for independence today in a parade countering traditional Fourth of July celebrations in this Commonwealth of the United States.

title: 5 Hurt as Boat Explodes on L.I.
description: A 40-foot boat exploded at the Manhasset Bay Marina today, critically injuring her owner and slightly injuring four others on nearby boats, the Nassau County police said.

title: AGCA SAYS HE ALTERED STORY OVER GIRL'S ABDUCTION
description: Mehmet Ali Agca said today that he had altered his testimony against Bulgarians accused of helping him in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II after he was convinced that they had engineered the kidnapping of an Italian schoolgirl to obtain his release from prison.

title: U.S. STUDY RAISES QUESTIONS ON BACTERIA-BASED PESTICIDE
description: A common grain pest that showed startling ability to resist the most widely used bacteria-based insecticide in a Government study raises ''a red flag'' about the effectiveness of genetically manipulated pest-killers, a researcher has concluded.

title: SUMMERPIER OFFERS JAZZ BENEATH THE STARS
description: PIER 16 juts out into the East River at the base of Fulton Street, between two venerable ships, the Peking and the Ambrose. Most of the time, it offers a fine view of harbor traffic -cars and subway trains on the Manhattan Bridge, small and large craft plying the river. And on weekends through the summer, beginning tonight at 8, it also offers criss-crossing patterns of sound - in the form of the free jazz concert series Summerpier.

title: Sherry Millman, a Lawyer, Wed to David L. Luckman
description: Sherry Jean Millman, a lawyer with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, and David Laurence Luckman, an accountant with Ernst & Whinney, were married yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein officiated, assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: LAST Labor Day, William Hickey was feeling down in the dumps because his apartment in the Village was going co-op, and he had to borrow the money from friends to buy it. Turning to his dog, Bucky, the veteran character actor said: ''We need $35,000 and a part in the big time.'' The next day, John Huston called. The result was the plum part of Don Corrado Prizzi, the frail, raspy-voiced boss of the Mafia family in the film ''Prizzi's Honor.'' Mr. Hickey is so convincing and has received such good notices that he is already being touted in columns and trade papers as a contender for the Oscar for best supporting actor of 1985.

title: Actors Flea Market
description: Financially ailing actors and other members of the theatrical community are getting a boost from the new 46th Street Gallery Flea Market, which is open today through Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M..

title: Boxer, 26, Dies Of Injuries in Bout
description: Shawn Thomas, a boxer from Detroit who lapsed into a coma after a May 29 fight, died Wednesday night. The Lake County coroner's office said Thomas was pronounced dead in Methodist South Lake Hospital in Merrillville at 11:40 P.M. He was 26 years old.

title: RODGERS MOTIVATES LIKE A SHOWBOAT
description: Coach Pepper Rodgers of the Memphis Showboats does not regard football's importance as life and death, a characteristic that is uncommon in his profession. Thus Rodgers is not always taken seriously, an attitude that may be in his favor.

title: Clown Princes Seek Princesses
description: It was several months ago that the Harlem Globetrotters, clown princes of the hardwood, announced that they would opt for variety by adding a princess or two for their 60th season this fall. Since then, the Trotters have grown increasingly impressed by the glut of talent among female basketball players who are all packed up but who, in the absence of a major pro league for women, have no place to go. And so now, having already undertaken one big break from custom, they are toying with the idea of going a step further and fielding a complete women's Globetrotter squad.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 5, 1985
description: International

title: Button, Button
description: The College Republican National Committee announced this week that it was distributing to Republican senators and representatives two-inch white buttons with red letters reading ''427 Days.''

title: INDUSTRIAL CHANGE CONQUERS UNIONIST
description: Donald Stazak is a soft-spoken union man who tried to persuade the steelworkers' local he headed to accept concessions to save and attract jobs. Today many of the jobs he tried to save are gone and new jobs have not been created. Much of the mill in which he worked so long and loved so much is closed, and Mr. Stazak no longer has a job, much less the union presidency.

title: Why Japan Won the Chip Race
description: The battle for the latest generation of computer memory chips is over. Japan has won. American companies, despite investments of hundreds of millons of dollars, cannot match the price at which Japanese 256,000-bit memory chips are flooding the market. An Idaho firm has accused Japanese chip-makers of dumping 64,000-bit memory chips at 50 percent below production cost. Yet another segment of manufacturing has fallen to Japan, and thousands more Americans have lost their jobs.

title: Unwed Teacher Who Lost Job After Baby Wins $3.3 Million
description: An unmarried mother who was dismissed from her teaching job after she decided to keep her baby was awarded $2 million in compensation and $1.3 million in punitive damages by a Federal jury Tuesday.

title: Economic Scene;   Rationality And Politics
description: JOSEPH A. SCHUMPETER of Harvard, the great historian of economic analysis, hailed capitalism for its contributions to rationality and honesty in dealing with the facts of society and nature.

title: HUSSEIN AND MUBARAK DISCUSS MIDEAST PEACE
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met for four hours in the Jordanian Red Sea resort of Aqaba today to discuss ways of reviving Middle East peace talks.

title: MCENROE SEEMS BEWILDERED
description: John McEnroe's unexpected loss to Kevin Curren in the quarterfinals Wednesday occurred when he and the All-England Club were enjoying a period of detente. During the first week of the tournament, McEnroe said he was making an effort to be more cooperative, and the club was no longer as rigid as he felt it had been in the past.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE will be something different going on at the American Jewish Theater late this year - dreamed up by Stanley Brechner, the theater's artistic director; Israel Horovitz, the playwright, and Jerry Zaks, the director. The trio is pooling its talents for a 16-week season of repertory, which will follow the revival of ''Green Fields,'' the Yiddish classic that opens Sept. 28.

title: Valuable Team
description: A baseball oddity:

title: Wage Discrimination Against Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Truman, the Bomb and Today's Peril
description: Forty years ago, America used two powerful bombs to end a bloody conventional war. But our leaders foresaw, even then, the mixed blessings that would come from splitting the atom.

title: Irish Navy Ship Detects Signal Near Crash Site
description: An Irish Navy ship has picked up a signal believed to be coming from the flight recorder of the Air-India jet that crashed off Ireland 10 days ago, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Sam Thurm Prepares To Retire Once Again
description: Sam Thurm, who as much as any man deserves the title Mr. Advertiser, is going to retire from his most recent job at the end of August.

title: Joel Suldan Married To Miriam Feldstein
description: At Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford, Conn., yesterday, Miriam Feldstein and Joel Suldan were married by Rabbi Macy Gordon.

title: NICHOLAS CHIARKAS
description: Nicholas Chiarkas, a labor-relations arbitrator and former officer of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: ART: CONTEMPORARY DRAWINGS AT THE MODERN
description: ''NEW WORKS ON PAPER,'' at the Museum of Modern Art, is the third in a series of shows focusing on recent or little-known drawings by prominent contemporaries. Chosen by Bernice Rose, a curator in the museum's Department of Drawings, the artists are on this occasion Robert Morris, Bruce Nauman, James Rosenquist, Robert Ryman, Pat Steir and Robert Wilson.

title: RACES
description: Connecticut: Bicyclists will swarm around race courses in Hartford's Bushnell Park tomorrow and New Britain's Walnut Hill Park on Sunday. Both races are free.

title: FIREWORKS
description: Connecticut: After sunset tomorrow, fireworks will light up the sky over New London (see Festivals listing).

title: Puica Wins Again
description: In her first race against Marcica Puica of Rumania since Miss Puica won the gold medal in the 3,000-meter women's event at the Los Angeles Olympics last summer, Zola Budd, the South African-born runner for England, fared just a little better yesterday. In a 5,000-meter race at the World Games in Helsinki, Finland, Miss Budd came in sixth, one spot higher than she did in the 3,000 last summer.

title: REAGAN POSTPONES TAX PUSH TO FOCUS ON REDUCING DEFICIT
description: President Reagan, who has spent the last month trying to drum up support for his tax plan, has decided to shift his focus from taxes temporarily and begin a new push to win Congressional approval of a deficit-reducing package, White House officials said Wednesday.

title: GRAND JURY INVESTIGATES U.S. AID TO PHILIPPINES
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating a $35 million contract, much of it financed by the Pentagon, to provide military communications equipment to the Philippines, according to American and Philippine officials.

title: SUMMERFARE FESTIVAL IN PURCHASE OFFERS CABARET
description: The difference between cabaret entertainment and serious music sometimes has more to do with the setting than with who is performing what. This weekend, Pepsico's Summerfare Arts Festival, at the State University of New York campus at Purchase, will present three acts that would not be out of place in a formal concert setting, only their performances will take place in the 250-seat Abbot Kaplan Theater, where there will be cabaret seating and a full-service bar.

title: MOON RELEASED AFTER 11 MONTHS IN A U.S. PRISON
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder and spiritual leader of the Unification Church, was released yesterday from a Federal prison in Connecticut after serving almost 12 months for income-tax evasion.

title: Pilot Union Plans Aid To Supporters of Strike
description: The Air Line Pilots Association announced Tuesday that it would increase its dues to provide funds to aid pilots and flight attendants who supported its recent strike against United Airlines.

title: NOT ALWAYS SUICIDAL
description: When the use of nuclear weapons was described as ''suicidal'' last week during an international colloquium on nuclear war and proliferation, a journalist inquired: ''Do you mean to suggest that if Iran or Iraq had a nuclear weapon, they would not use it against the other?''

title: Global Marine President Sees Challenging Times
description: For C. Russell Luigs, chairman and president of Global Marine Inc., these have been particularly challenging times. The Houston-based offshore drilling company, citing sliding oil prices and reduced demand for drilling activity, announced this week that it would suspend all interest and principal payments on its long-term debt of about $1 billion.

title: Bid Rejected in Clergy Suit
description: A Superior Court judge has rejected a retrial for a clergy malpractice lawsuit filed by parents of a 24-year-old man who killed himself after he received counseling at Grace Community Church. After Judge Joseph Kalin denied the bid for a new trial Wednesday, the attorney for the man's parents, Walter and Maria Nally, filed an appeal to the State Court of Appeal. Judge Kalin dismissed the lawsuit May 16, saying it would abridge constitutional rights to religious freedom.

title: Blown Fuse Halts Park Rides
description: All rides at the Six Flags Great Adventure Amusement Park here were brought to a standstill after a fuse blew on a utility pole at 2:45 P.M. today, according to the general manager of the park, David Paltzik. There were no reports of injuries, and the park offered complimentary return visits to the 20,000 patrons on hand. Mr. Paltzik said that workers were restarting the 45 rides one by one and that by 4 o'clock, 3 were still not working.

title: CROWDED RIVERS STIRRING DISPUTE ON U.S. POLICY
description: A sure sign of summer in the Rockies is the lines of men and women with gray rubber rafts waiting their turn to run some of the West's wild and scenic rivers.

title: GUIDRY WINS WITH EXTRA REST
description: Whatever concern might have surfaced among the Yankees because Ron Guidry was pitching out of turn last night was quickly put to rest with one of his better efforts of the season.

title: THE ORDEAL OF STEVE HOWE
description: Maybe, as Steve Howe says, he does need a fresh start.

title: astaing Victor In 6th Tour Stage
description: Francis Castaing of France was declared the winner of the 137.6-mile sixth stage of the Tour de France today after Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium and Sean Kelly of Ireland were disqualified for pushing in the closely bunched final sprint.

title: Spain Accepts Computer Rule
description: The United States Government has licensed the Spanish subsidiary of the Hewlett Packard Corporation to export sensitive computerware after the Spanish Government agreed to guard against shipments to the Soviet bloc, the company said today.

title: John De L. Greenwalt Wed to Suzanne Krick
description: The marriage of Suzanne Somerville Krick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Krick of Hamden, Conn., to John De Lano Greenawalt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sloan Greenawalt of Hartsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Revs.

title: LIPPER AND STEIN SQUARE OFF IN RACE
description: Kenneth Lipper, the former Deputy Mayor who is seeking the Democratic nomination for City Council president, has begun a radio advertising campaign that criticizes the acknowledged front-runner in that primary race, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan.

title: ON OR NEAR THE WATER
description: Connecticut: Point Counterpoint II, a 195-foot vessel billed as ''a floating arts center,'' will dock Sunday morning at Bond's Dock in Stratford. Designed by the architect Louis Kahn, the steel boat has a 125-seat theater and a hydraulically lifted acoustical shell over an orchestra stage. The American Wind Symphony Orchestra, which travels with the boat, will participate in the 10 A.M. Sunday services at the First Congregational Methodist Church, 2301 Main Street.

title: Public Power Is Not the Answer to New York's Energy Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA DEPICTS FREED CLERIC AS REPENTANT
description: Officials of the organizations that control the Catholic Church in China said today that the 84-year-old Shanghai Bishop who was paroled Wednesday after serving nearly 30 years in jail told a court that he was ''remorseful'' and promised he would have no further contacts with the Vatican.

title: Classic Film Programs
description: For the film buff, there are two programs of classics to choose from Sunday. At the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street, the Janus Film Festival continues with a double- bill of ''Pygmalion'' and ''The Importance of Being Earnest.''

title: THE MOUSETRAP AND OTHER INVITING IDEAS
description: gnarly (narl'<u1<u1<u1<u1-e) 1.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M., and WTBS, 7:40 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Canadian Open, at Oakville, Ontario, second round. (Television -ESPN 3 P.M.) Ladies PGA Mazda Hall of Fame Championships, at Sugar Land, Tex., second round. PGA Seniors Greenbrier Classic, at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., second round. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. Markim's Pride is the early 5-to-2 favorite to win the $500,000 New Jersey Classic Pacing Final. In a $25,000 open pace for 3-year-olds, Nihilator, five for five this year and tuning up for the July 19 Meadowlands Pace, is the early odds-on choice. Nihilator has won 17 of 18 career starts, earned $1.5 million in purses and set a mile record at the Meadowlands of 1:52. His sire, Niatross, has the only sub-1:50 mile ever clocked, a 1:49.1. (Television - MSG, 12:30 A.M.) Roosevelt, 8 P.M. The Peter Haughton Memorial Pacing Series is the feature. Goshen, 1:30 P.M. Second day of a four-day meeting at Historic Track in Orange County, about 60 miles north of New York City, which contains the Hall of Fame of the Trotter. There is no parimutuel wagering. Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Tennis All-England Championships, at Wimbledon. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M. to 5 P.M., men's semifinals; 11:30 P.M. to 11:45 P.M., update, and 12:45 A.M. to 2:45 A.M., men's semifinals highlights.)

title: People
description: * Edward H. Meyer of Grey Advertising and Chester Gore of Chester Gore/Eric Mower Associates have been named chairman of the eastern region and chairman of the New York Council, respectively, of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Dollar Mixed In Europe
description: The dollar was mixed in Europe today, and gold prices were little changed.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cincinnati Bengals have put Isaac Curtis, their career leading receiver, on waivers and will decide his future by Monday, according to Mike Brown, the assistant general manager. . . . Kevin Long, the former fullback of the Jets who was waived midway through the United States Football League season by the Arizona Outlaws, has filed a grievance with the league's players union to recover the unpaid portion of his contract. . . . Ron Kittle, a White Sox outfielder, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list with a shoulder injury he suffered April 20 when he ran into a wall chasing a fly ball at Comiskey Park.

title: Dining Out Guide: Dinner For 2, Under $50 (French)
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BISTRO BAMBOCHE, #1582 York Avenue, near 83d Street (249-4002) -

title: NEW LAW TO GIVE STATE UNIVERSITY SOME FREEDOM TO RUN OWN OPERATION
description: In a report last January, an outside advisory commission described the 37-year-old State University of New York as ''the most overregulated university in the nation.'' The State Legislature responded with legislation designed to streamline the university's operations.

title: Guy Bush, Ex-Pitcher, Dies; Gave Up Ruth's Last Homer
description: Guy Bush, the pitcher who gave up Babe Ruth's last home run, died Tuesday of cardiac arrest after working in his garden in Shannon.

title: No Winners In Lebanon
description: The crisis of the T.W.A. hostages has given the American public a glimpse of the hopeless, shifting imbroglio that has gripped Lebanon for a decade. The argument about who has won this round reflects intricacies of the murderous fight in the area and distortions of the limelight's glare.

title: Pacing Sweep
description: On The Road Again completed a sweep of the three-race World Cup Pacing Series by capturing the $150,000 final tonight by a neck in a stakes record time of 1:52 2/5 at the Meadowlands. The winner, driven by Paddy Gilmour, returned $3.20, $2.80 and $2.10. Tuff Choice was second and Guts was third.

title: Peat Marwick Named in Suit
description: The Justice Department has filed a suit on behalf of the National Credit Union Administration seeking as much as $6.1 million from Peat Marwick over its role as outside auditor of the Penn Square Bank, which failed in July 1982.

title: PUZZLE IN BROOKLYN: THE BIZARRE SINKING OF A 20-BLOCK AREA
description: Twenty blocks of Brooklyn are sinking, and no one can say why.

title: NUCLEAR FUEL SHIPMENTS HALTED IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The Federal Department of Energy has suspended shipments of spent nuclear fuel rods through New York City until the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approves the design of an expanded metal cask used to safeguard the rods, according to department officials.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEW YORK went outside this week with high-tech fireworks and down-home barbecues. At the opening of ''Measure for Measure'' in Central Park, the tempting scent of roasting coals began drifting across the Delacorte Theater just as Shakespeare's plot twists were reaching their peak in the second act. At the end of the performance, 500 invited guests followed their noses to the grills set up along the lake behind the theater for Joseph Papp's cookout, a tradition on the opening night of free Shakespeare in the Park.

title: GAPS IN MATERNITY INSURANCE
description: Although the cost of giving birth has reached an average of $3,200 for a normal delivery and thousands more when there are complications, significant numbers of American women have either no insurance or inadequate insurance to cover those fees.

title: OTHER EVENTS
description: Westchester: At Sunnyside, the former home of Washington Irving in Tarrytown, visitors are encouraged to tour the small gabled structure Sunday evening and then picnic on the lawn as Robert Olson of old Sturbridge Village re-creates the skills of Richard Potter, one of America's first successful magicians.

title: JULY 4TH TRIATHLON TRIES SOME SOULS
description: About 100 athletes and self-designated ''crazies'' gathered in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty today for a strange and patriotic ritual. With the scaffold-covered Lady shining in the early-morning sun, the group belted out a spirited rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' But their enthusiasm was tempered by the knowledge of what lay ahead.

title: Copeland Blues
description: Johnny Copeland will play and sing Texas blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street. Sets begin at approximately 9:30 and 11:30; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum. Information: 777-5077.

title: Restoring the Past
description: The airplane with which Wilbur and Orville Wright first achieved controlled, powered, heavier-than-air flight now looks just about the way it did 81 years ago last December at Kitty Hawk, N.C. Over at the National Air and Space Museum, experts spent four months removing dust, rust, oil and corrosion from the historic framework and replacing all the fabric with the nearest thing to the original obtainable. A 1928 substitute had been in place.

title: PRIVATE HOSPITALS ARE NOW OFFERING HEALTH INSURANCE
description: Several large private hospital chains have expanded into health insurance, a move that many experts predict will significantly alter the health care industry.

title: Radioactive House Called Safe After Cleanup
description: Stanley Watras, forced to evacuate his house in January because radioactive gas seeping from the earth had made it unsafe, was told Wednesday that after a $32,000 cleanup his family could return home.

title: THE OLD PLACE IS GONE
description: My son and his family are trekking back to the great Middle West this summer to visit grandparents and see my hometown. I'll have some explaining to do when they return. They will see South Milwaukee as it is today, not as the pleasant little blue-collar town in which I grew up or the one they might have imagined from the stories I've told. That place isn't there anymore. In the 1940's, this small, southern suburb of Milwaukee was the American Dream come true - a town of steady jobs and regular paychecks, where anyone who wanted could make a family and build a home. It was the Middle American, middle-income, small town, industrial-sector good life at its finest. It's mostly gone now, and what's left looks chilled, harsh and barren. The sprawling Bucyrus-Erie heavy metals plant looms as an eerie, nearly vacant, rusting industrial junkyard right smack in the middle of town. Today, South Milwaukee is like a lot of other Midwestern factory towns of the mid-1980's: The vigil is over and the funeral has begun.

title: A Hungry Fan
description: Howard Karasick is a confessed ''baseball freak'' who grew up in Brooklyn, spending too many of his childhood afternoons at Ebbets Field. It was there that he learned to fall in love with a ball club, and he fell in love all over again at spring training this year when he took a job as a sports broadcaster for radio station WQSA in Sarasota, where the White Sox have their camp as well as a farm club in the Gulf Coast League.

title: NAVRATILOVA AND LLOYD GAIN FINAL
description: Having dispensed with the formalities, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd now can get down to the business at hand. The early rounds at Wimbledon were like sparring sessions for these two friendly rivals, their progress measured by the length of the matches and number of games their opponents won. They spent more time talking about each other than the other players combined, and Mrs. Lloyd and Miss Navratilova chose their words as diplomats do.

title: SYRIA AND IRAN ARE NURTURING A WARY, AMBIGUOUS ALLIANCE
description: Women and children, the relatives of ''martyrs'' from the recent struggles of Iran, dismount from buses at a mosque on the southern edge of this city and, amid the pilgrims from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, pray before the tomb of a granddaughter of Mohammed.

title: ULSTER TENSION FOCUSES ON STREET CALLED THE TUNNEL
description: Obins Street, known here as the Tunnel, starts at the junction of a railroad overpass and a bombed-out bar and runs six-tenths of a mile past real estate that in recent years has been shot up, run down and blown up.

title: U.S. ENVOY TO SOVIET, MARKING JULY 4, TELLS OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: The United States Ambassador to Moscow told Soviet television viewers tonight in a speech marking the Fourth of July that the United States was expanding scientific frontiers because private citizens had easy access to information.

title: USING EDUCATION FOR A LONG-TERM WAR ON DRUGS
description: John C. Lawn is new on the job, and his approach is almost startlingly pragmatic.

title: 17-STORY FLUSHING BUILDING SHIFTS TO CONDOMINIUMS
description: Dealing with the problem of The Stanton was not the first item on the agenda for the Muss Development Company when it acquired that rental building and its neighbor, the vacant former Korvette's department store, five years ago.

title: Fireworks and Music In Philadelphia Fete
description: The city where American Independence was born 209 years ago celebrated the nation's birthday with patriotic pageantry, fireworks and a seven-hour concert that drew a million people to hear the Beach Boys and other rock groups.

title: ANDUJAR WINS 14TH AS CARDS TRIUMPH
description: Tom Nieto grounded a run-scoring single to right field with two out in the eighth inning tonight, giving Joaquin Andujar his 14th victory as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2.

title: 'Our Sacred Land,' About the Sioux Indians
description: ''Our Sacred Land'' pleads earnestly for the Sioux Indians and also explores their religion. The Sioux want their ancient lands returned, particularly the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: Taxing Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Hayes Recovering
description: Woody Hayes is expected to be released from a hospital in Columbus, Ohio, within a few days.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE cuisine of Burma is not one of the more celebrated foods in town. Bordered partially by Thailand on the east and the Indian subcontinent on the west, Burma has developed a style of cooking over the centuries that, to a Western palate at least, seems to have characteristics of Indian food combined with a few Thai accents, such as the use of lemon grass.

title: THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND: A CHOICE OF CELEBRATIONS
description: THE holiday exodus from New York has left lots of elbow room this weekend for those who remain, with many opportunities for ambling - on one's own or on tours that will explore everything from barnacles to a Victorian house with secrets.

title: T.W.A. PILOT TELLS HOW DIVER DIED
description: Hijackers killed Robert Dean Stethem, a Navy diver, to force the Amal wing of the Lebanese Shiites to participate in the holding of passengers and crew of Trans World Airlines Flight 847, the plane's freed captain says.

title: Sousa's Masterpiece
description: This seems an appropriate time to report that a movement is under way in Congress to make ''The Stars and Stripes Forever'' the country's official national march. There are a national bird, a national flower and, of course, a national anthem, but no national march.

title: Foolproof Shield Or Pie in the Sky?
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: 'ART ON THE BEACH,' WORKS AND PERFORMANCE
description: After six summers, in which it has grown from a relatively simple outdoor sculpture show to a complex orchestration of artists, architects and performers, the spectacular known as ''Art on the Beach'' is making its last stand. This fall, building apace, Battery Park City will finally devour the sandy landfill site at Manhattan's southern tip, and the show that swarmed over it will become a thing of memory. As a place for experiment, a launching pad for talent and an enjoyable public entertainment, it will be much missed. (A nice twist is that a permanent work by Patsy Norvell, a sculptor who appeared in the first show in 1979, has been commissioned for Battery Park City.) But ''Art on the Beach'' is going out with a bang; in fact, this year's incarnation (through Sept. 13) seems the most vigorous yet. Boasting no fewer than 10 collaborative groups - the largest number ever - it includes, besides the work of painters and sculptors, that of architects, engineers, composers, poets, choreographers, playwrights, directors, musicians and dancers. The utopian goal, as set out by Creative Time Inc., the organization that hatched and nurtured the show, is to wipe out ''the barriers that exist between art, architecture and theater,'' and so all of the structures created by artists and architects double as performance sites.

title: Free Shoppers' Magazine Set
description: A free magazine for supermarket shoppers is in the works at Family Media, already the publisher of The Ladies' Home Journal, Health, 1,001 Home Ideas, The Homeowner, Savvy, World Tennis and Golf Illustrated.

title: FOR ELLENVILLE, THE DAY TO RALLY 'ROUND A PARADE
description: In bad moments, Bob Mangels worried it might be a sad little parade that would go by too fast.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SECOND Avenue near St. Marks Place, the Tigris and Euphrates of the 1960's counterculture, slid into gritty obscurity after the energy of rock and resistance moved on. For more than a decade, it was just another down-and-out section of the city, a way station for drifters. Like many depressed neighborhoods in New York, however, lower Second Avenue is making a comeback, 80's style, with cafes and restaurants leading the way. They are attracting outsiders to the area for the first time since the heyday of the Electric Circus.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Independence Day has a whole new meaning.'' - Robert Peel Jr., former hostage from Trans World Airlines Flight 847. [A6:1.]

title: SPY HUNTERS SEEK TO TRACE FIFTH SUSPECT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying to determine if a person identified by the code name A in personal papers of John A. Walker Jr. belonged to a a purported Navy spy ring, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Waldron Quintet
description: The pianist Mal Waldron is leading an all-star quintet - with Charlie Rouse on tenor saxophone, Eddie Henderson on trumpet, Reggie Workman on bass and Ed Blackwell on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover today and tomorrow, an $8.50 cover Sunday and a one-drink minimum. Information: 255-4037.

title: It's a Mistake to Ask Congress to Reform Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Games People Play
description: A graphic indication of the rough road ahead for tax overhaul, or at least the current Reagan Administration version of it, can be obtained from the returns of a novel survey taken by Representative Bobbi Fiedler in her 21st District of California, which includes parts of Los Angeles and the San Fernando Valley.

title: THE LATEST CULT IN ICE CREAM
description: Even devotees complain that the Dove ice cream bar is too big and the stick too short and the chocolate coating so thick that the first bite often creates unwieldy slabs of chocolate that balance precariously on the chin.

title: Amish Sue on Color Rule
description: A court battle between the state and an Amish community over bright orange traffic warning signs on horse-drawn wagons has led state officials to agree that the signs may be changed. The Amish church objects to displaying bright colors, and the Amish community in southeastern Minnesota had filed suit against the requirement that slow-moving vehicles carry the signs.

title: Klosterman Out
description: Don Klosterman, a former quarterback, is out of the pocket and scrambling for a new job. Klosterman, who was responsible for signing the quarterback Steve Young and other high-priced players for the Los Angeles Express, was dismissed yesterday as president and general manager of the team by the United States Football League, which has been running the ownerless team since February.

title: U.N. Legal Framework
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO RECITAL BY JOHN LEWIS
description: John Lewis's program for the final recital in the Kool Jazz Festival's series of solo piano performances at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday was typical of Mr. Lewis - from blues to Bach, with stops en route for Thelonious Monk, Duke Ellington, some pop songs and several of Mr. Lewis's compositions.

title: FESTIVALS AND CONCERTS
description: Connecticut: For those who spent a humdrum Fourth of July, here is a weekend of elephants racing down a city street, cannons firing from the ramparts of a fort and from the deck of a tall ship, and 2,200 rockets exploding in a Saturday night crescendo of fireworks.

title: Mechanic Indicted In Three Murders
description: An Essex County grand jury has indicted a Montclair auto mechanic on charges of sexually assaulting and murdering three women who were slain in the same Montclair apartment during a two-year period.

title: Why International Hijack Sanctions Don't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfair to Ulster
description: A lofty but misguided proposition for opposing discrimination against Catholics in Northern Ireland has reared its head in Congress, three state legislatures and the New York City Council. Based on what are called the ''MacBride Principles,'' the proposal seeks to impose United States law on all hiring by the 24 American companies in that tormented province. The measure can only hurt an economy already crippled by strife and recession.

title: Official Says Bolivian Voting Will Not Have to Be Put Off
description: Presidential elections in Bolivia will be held on schedule July 14 following the provision of adequate funds to organize the vote, the nation's top election official said today.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE MENTALLY ILL
description: The greeting card read, ''Roses are red, Violets are blue, I'm schizophrenic and so am I.'' The black and white photograph showed a silly looking man, cross-eyed, with glasses askew.

title: FISCAL CRISIS STILL HAUNTS THE POLICE
description: From July 1975 until November 1979, no police officers were hired or trained in the City of New York.

title: CABINET DISPUTE SEEN AS BLOW TO SPANISH PREMIER
description: Spain's new Cabinet was sworn in today amid widespread assertions that Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez had been politically weakened by a dispute over the Government shake-up.

title: Ah, Tax Simplification
description: General Dynamics, the nation's biggest defense contractor, has owed no Federal income taxes since 1972. Unlike some of the other things it's allegedly failed to do, its tax calculations have been perfectly legal. But any fair tax reform certainly ought to close that large a loophole. President Reagan proposes only to narrow it, then wonders why anyone calls his plan unfair.

title:
Patents;

Controlling A Craft on Autopilot
description: AN invention that enables a pilot to control a helicopter or other aircraft whose flight is being regulated by a mechanical autopilot was patented this week for the Rockwell International Corporation of El Segundo, Calif.

title: BIRELI LAGRENE TO PERFORM
description: The trio of the jazz guitarist Bireli Lagrene will perform this weekend at Fat Tuesday's, 17th Street and Third Avenue.
