Sets tonight are at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight, and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. There is a $10 cover charge and a $7.50 minimum; $10 cover and no minimum at the bar. Information and reservations: 533-7902.

title: Teacher Alert for Dropouts
description: The president of the National Education Association, Mary Futrell, is starting a welcome national campaign to keep children from dropping out of school. She will take $1 in dues from each of the N.E.A.'s 1.7 million members for program grants and an endowment and challenges other groups to join in the effort.

title: Feline in Need And Human Nature
description: A study in human nature - New York style.

title: Legal Graft Abuilding
description: What to make of the recent glimpse at above-board graft in New York's building trades? It's outrageous, but not illegal, for construction unions to insist that major projects hire a part-time ''truck scheduler'' for perhaps $400,000 a year. The unions contend they speed construction, but what they really do is avert delays staged by the unions themselves. Obviously, builders would not agree to such extortionate contracts unless they felt threatened, by strikes or even violence.

title: Turner Requests F.C.C To Stop CBS Buyback
description: Ted Turner appealed yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission to stop CBS Inc.'s plan to buy nearly $1 billion of its stock.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $39,000. c-Including extraordinary income of $81,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Randi Mahler Betrothed To Mark Elliot Schlanger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Mahler of Willow Brook, S.I., and Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Allyne Mahler, to Mark Elliot Schlanger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Allen Schlanger of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: When a Hatpin Was a Woman's Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I saw everything tonight.'' -Keith Hernandez of the Mets. [1:3.]

title: Owners' Claims Disputed
description: Negotiators for major league baseball players told the owners' representatives yesterday that they differed significantly with them in their assessment of the owners' financial information. The players association indicated a reported $36 million industry loss for 1984 actually could have been more than a $9 million profit.

title: Calvin Carries On
description: Chris Calvin, a boxer from Nashville, says he will continue his career despite the death of his last opponent, Shawn Thomas of Detroit. Thomas was pronounced dead Wednesday night, five weeks after he collapsed in his dressing room following his fight with Calvin May 29.

title: LEGIONNAIRE BACTERIA THRIVE AT MOUNT S. HELENS
description: Scattered lupines and fireweed crop up, but the most plentiful creatures on Mount St. Helens's slopes and craters are too small to see without a microscope.

title: JOBLESS AT 7.2% FOR FIFTH MONTH: RATE CALLED SIGN OF SOFT ECONOMY
description: The national unemployment rate held steady in June for the fifth straight month, the Government reported today. It was the latest of several recent signs that declining interest rates have yet to reinvigorate the economy.

title: Successor to the Checker?
description: ''Are you a taxi?'' a potential passenger asked warily.

title: Bacon Producers Permitted To Use Vitamin E Additives
description: As part of a continuing drive to eliminate cancer-causing nitrosamines in bacon, the Agriculture Department, today gave meat processors permission to add vitamin E to bacon-curing solutions.

title: Cooke F.C.C. Filing Due On Multimedia
description: Jack Kent Cooke intends to file an application with the Federal Communications Commission, seeking its consent for his proposed takeover of Multimedia Inc., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Cooke, a Washington investor, holds 9.75 percent of the common shares of Multimedia, a South Carolina-based telecommunications concern. The S.E.C. filing did not specify when Mr. Cooke would file with the F.C.C. Mr. Cooke's proposal for a merger with Multimedia at more than $65 a share was turned down by Multimedia's board in May.

title: Hold the Jojoba, Please
description: President Reagan's vision for America delights his supporters and vexes his critics, and he has more than one way of expressing just what he thinks this country should be. He gave one vision recently, while promoting his tax-revision program, telling his audience that, ''I don't think the loopholes like 'jojoba bean shelters,' 'windmills,' 'racehorse write-offs' and 'Cayman Island trusts' are the foundation for a lean and mean America in the 80's and 90's and 21st century.''

title: THE ANNUAL FLIGHT OF THE THERAPISTS
description: Leslie Baines had worked herself into such a twit the other day that she finally picked up the telephone, called the other members of her therapy group and asked if they wanted to rent a bus and go out to the Hamptons and find their ''vacationing bum'' of a psychotherapist.

title: Elizabeth Tucker Weds
description: Elizabeth Saucier Tucker, an assistant buyer for Bonwit Teller's corporate office in New York, was married yesterday to Mark Hamilton Hurst, an account supervisor with Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, an advertising agency in New York. The Rev. Herbert W. Pieper performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Pillar in Creve Coeur, Mo.

title: PENTAGON AIDE GETS A NEW POST
description: The Defense Department today announced the appointment of James P. Wade Jr., a physicist and longtime Pentagon executive, to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for aquisition and logistics.

title: Alexandra C. Hubbard Weds Michael Gourlay
description: Alexandra Carson Hubbard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Hubbard of Shelburne, Vt., was married yesterday to Michael Wodrow Gourlay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Barron Gourlay of Lyme, Conn.

title: First Coach
description: Ralph McKinzie remembers Ronald (Dutch) Reagan as a mediocre athlete who ''worked tirelessly to improve,'' and President Reagan says he always will address his Eureka (Ill.) College football coach as ''Sir.'' Mr. McKinzie, at 90, is the nation's oldest college coach.

title: FROM MINORITY ACTIVIST TO FEMINIST LEADER
description: Ask Irene Natividad to describe herself and she responds without hesitation, ''I am a professional woman, a young woman, a minority woman, a mother and a volunteer.'' Now she is also the chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus, which means that for the next two years she will hold one of the most influential positions in the feminist movement.

title: Your Money;   Zero Coupon Variations
description: A NUMBER of variations of zero coupon bonds have been created recently that are drawing attention to an investment vehicle that has been around for more than a decade.

title: WAS PREMIER OF NETHERLANDS
description: Jan E. de Quay, Prime Minister of the Netherlands from 1959 to 1963, died Thursday. He was 83 years old. Mr. de Quay died at his home in Beers, in the southern part of the Netherlands, his family said today.

title: Listing Is Discontinued
description: The weekly listing of dual-purpose investment companies carried in Saturday's Business Day is being discontinued. Lipper Analytical Services said that Hemisphere Capital had become an open-end mutual fund as of June 30, meaning that only one fund, Gemini II, remained.

title: Mexico Tallies Debt Savings
description: Mexico has saved $1.8 billion in interest costs on its foreign debt over the past year because of falling interest rates on world markets, the Government announced.

title: 29 RUNS, 46 HITS, 19 INNINGS, 7 HOURS, 1 GAME
description: Seven hours, 46 hits, 29 runs and 19 innings after the first pitch was thrown Thursdaynight, the Mets finally beat the Atlanta Braves this morning, 16-13. No game had gone so many innings this season; no game in history had ended at such a late - or was it early? - hour.

title: Insurance Laws That Banks Must Heed
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS CENSURED IN BLACK'S DEATH IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A medical panel ruled today that two white physicians who examined the black activist Steve Biko before his death in detention in 1977 were guilty of improper conduct and that one of them displayed ''disgraceful behavior.''

title: BAKER FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sale by Lear Of Coke Shares
description: The television producer Norman Lear and his partner, A. Jerrold Perenchio, plan to sell 3.5 million shares of The Coca-Cola Company, or about 2.6 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: Keep Delta Force Closer to the Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Words of sympathy from George Steinbrenner: ''The poor Cleveland Indians. They were out of contention by Memorial Day.''

title: Some Markets Closed
description: The New York commodity exchanges remained closed yesterday, after the Independence Day holiday. They will reopen Monday.

title: THE GUERRILLA FIGHTER AND THE LOBBYIST
description: Sometimes it seems that all's fair in love and lobbying, particularly lobbying the Federal Government on issues involving safety and big money.

title: REPURCHASE BY JOHNSON CONTROLS
description: Johnson Controls Inc., which makes electronic instruments, bought 8.7 percent of its shares yesterday from companies controlled by Victor Posner for nearly $80 million.

title: WOMAN, 105, TELLS JURY SHE STOOD UP TO 2 YOUTHS
description: A 105-year-old Queens woman testified yesterday that she had confronted two teen-agers charged with barging into her home to extort money from her adoptive grandson.

title: Warsaw Pact Exercise Ends
description: Warsaw Pact maneuvers involving 23,000 Soviet, Hungarian and Czechoslovak troops ended in Hungary today, the official Hungarian press agency reported. The maneuvers, code named Danube 85, began three weeks ago and involve both conventional weapons and weapons of mass destruction, according to official reports.

title: Motel Fumes Kill 2, Fell 18
description: Carbon monoxide from a gas water heater seeped into the bottom floor of a downtown motel today, killing two people and injuring 18 others, the authorities said.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR FORCES: ARSENAL WILL BE STONGER BUT STRATEGY WON'T CHANGE
description: The United States' strategic nuclear forces consist of a bomber first produced 30 years ago, land-based missiles about 20 years of age and submarine missiles of marginal accuracy. Within the next few years, these legs of the ''strategic triad'' will be splinted with powerful new generations of nuclear weapons.

title: MORE BLACKS ON FACULTIES
description: Despite an increase in educational opportunities for blacks during the past 16 years, college teaching still remains an overwhelmingly white profession. Ironically, it would not be easy to ascribe this unfortunate possibility solely to racism. It seems, in fact, that talented blacks, like talented whites, are preparing for careers in more lucrative professions.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 2:20 P.M.) Indians vs. Chicago White Sox, at Cleveland. (Radio - WCBS 880, 7:20 P.M.) Football Showboats vs. Oakland Invaders, at Memphis, United States Football League playoffs, semifinal game. Novo Bojovic's field goal in the waning minutes gave the Invaders a 30-27 victory over the Tampa Bay Bandits in the first round last week, and the Showboats trounced the Denver Gold, 48-7. The Invaders won the only regular-season meeting with the Showboats, 31-19. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M.) Golf Canadian Open, at Oakville, Ontario, third round. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.) Ladies PGA Mazda Hall of Fame Championships, at Sugar Land, Tex., third round. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.) PGA Seniors Greenbrier Classic, at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., third round. Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon, women's singles final. ''Breakfast at Wimbledon,'' live. (Television -Channel 4, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M., live.) Eastern Masters Circuit tournament for men 35 years old and over, at the Cove Tennis Center, 60 Sea Cliff Avenue, Glen Cove, L.I., 1:30 P.M. Finals in singles and doubles. Volvo Hall of Fame Championships qualifying rounds, at Newport, R.I., 9 A.M. Johan Kriek and Tim Mayotte are the top-seeded players in the only major grass tournament left in the United States. Thoroughbred Racing Belmont, 1 P.M. Mom's Command will be trying for a sweep of the New York triple crown series for 3-year-old fillies in the $200,000-added Coaching Club American Oaks at a mile and a half.

title: RESEARCH ON MONKEYS MAY HELP CURB PARKINSON'S DISEASE
description: Researchers at Emory University's Yerkes Primate Center say they have transplanted fetal brain cells into the brains of monkeys suffering from Parkinson's disease, alleviating its devastating symptoms.

title: THE BIG RUBLES
description: Tireless Red spy masters are toiling day and night to ferret out Americans who want to make big bucks by ferreting out America's most precious secrets for the Soviet Union.

title: LAWYERS GATHER IN CAPITAL FOR BAR GROUP'S PARLEY
description: More than 8,000 lawyers from around the country are gathered in this city, which already has the world's densest concentration of lawyers, to debate issues ranging from homosexual rights to tax reform, to buy tax-deductible meals at expensive restaurants and to scout the landscape for new clients and referrals.

title: West German Woman Is Freed in Honduras
description: The Honduran Army today turned over to West German diplomats a West German woman captured June 14 by Indian rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Egyptian Oil Pact
description: Egypt has signed agreements with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Amoco Corporation for exploration in the Gulf of Suez area, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

title: United Reaches Accord With Flight Attendants
description: Nearly 700 flight attendants hired by United Airlines in a four-week pilots' strike honored by flight attendants will remain on the payroll under a new agreement.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
50,000 Gather to Celebrate 50th Year of A.A.'s Existence
description: Medical experts today addressed the largest international meeting ever of Alcoholics Anonymous, the group that brings together alcholics and former alcoholics to help problem drinkers recover.

title: MUGABE TAKES A SOLID LEAD IN ZIMBABWE VOTING
description: The party of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe took a solid lead today in Zimbabwe's first general election since the country gained independence in 1980, and it appeared that he would gain the clear majority he and political analysts had been predicting.

title: Dr. Edward Evarts, 59, Pioneer in Brain Study
description: Dr. Edward Evarts, who pioneered a widely used method for recording electrical activity of brain cells, suffered a fatal heart attack July 2 in his laboratory at the National Institute of Mental Health. He was 59 years old. Dr. Evarts joined the research program at the institute in 1953 and served as chief of its Laboratory of Neurophysiology since 1970.

title: CITY OPERA: 'THE STUDENT PRINCE'
description: IN reviving a faded theatrical blossom such as ''The Student Prince'' performers are always tempted to wink at the audience, at least figuratively if not literally, as if to say, ''I hope you don't think we are serious about this sort of thing.'' Depressingly often, the wink develops into a nudge in the ribs, followed by collapse into what is intended to be hilarious camp. Along the way, whatever intrinsic value the work may have had is either badly obscured or ground underfoot. It is a pleasure to report that the New York City Opera's performance of Sigmund Romberg's sentimental classic, which opened the company's season last night, avoided such miscalculations. The 61-year-old operetta has been not so much revived as lovingly restored.

title: ARMS PACT AFFIRMATION IS URGED BY GORBACHEV
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev suggested today that Moscow and Washington make a binding reaffirmation of their commitment to the antiballistic missile treaty.

title: Plessey Shutdown
description: The Plessey Company said it would close its Huyton factory, with a loss of about 700 jobs, in a reorganization of its telecommunications manufacturing plants in northern England.

title: APLHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-Net income.

title: Bernstein to Conduct Concert at Jones Beach
description: Leonard Bernstein will conduct the National Symphony in a concert of American works tomorrow night at 7:30 at the Jones Beach Theater.

title: Israel and the Geneva Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: 100 Lovely Miles
description: Amid all the larger sports news, not much note will be taken of the Western States Endurance Run, but it is nonetheless an event that a number of ultramarathoners consider their crown jewel: a stringent test whose demands are matched only by the natural beauty of its 100-mile course.

title: S. Carol Parry Married To Gregory C. Powell
description: At the Elberon (N.J.) Memorial Presbyterian Church yesterday S. Carol Parry, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lynn A. Parry of Interlaken, N.J., was married to Gregory Coughlin Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard R. Powell of Peru, Vt.

title: Deborah Ann Gill Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Gill, a personnel assistant with Pfizer Inc. in New York, to Kurt John Hilzinger, an accountant with Price Waterhouse in New York, took place yesterday at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Rochester.

title: CARDINALS TURNED BACK BY DODGERS, 4-1
description: Pedro Guerrero and R. J. Reynolds each tripled in the seventh inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored twice to break a 1-1 tie and beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-1, tonight.

title: SOLDIER UNFAIRLY CONVICTED IN 3 MURDERS, COURT RULES
description: A white Army private convicted of killing three black men in the Buffalo area in 1980 did not get a fair trial, the state's highest court decided today.

title: AIR-INDIA INVESTIGATORS SAY A SUB MAY HAVE FOUND JET'S RECORDERS
description: Several pieces of the Air-India Boeing 747 that crashed off Ireland June 23, including a panel believed to contain two recording devices, were located on the ocean floor today by an unmanned, remote-controlled submarine.

title: Applying the Test of Time to Public Sculpture
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillips Joins Pipeline Pact
description: The Phillips Alaska Pipeline Corporation has agreed to join in the proposed settlement of a multibillion-dollar dispute with Alaska over how much it should cost to transport oil through the trans-Alaska pipeline.

title: OPEC STILL AT ODDS ON PRICE, OUTPUT
description: OPEC ministers tried without success today to reach a consensus on how to strengthen their weakening grip on the world oil market. They will continue their efforts on Saturday.

title: JAZZ: TERUMASA HINO, CORNET
description: Although Terumasa Hino's cornet has a distinctively warm, mellow tone in the middle and low registers, the group that he is leading at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, between Bleecker and West Fourth Street) through tomorrow backs him with such volatile, eruptive power that he shouts his way through high, staccato bursts as often as he explores the softer, richer colors of his horn.

title: U.S. BID TO CLOSE AIRPORT IN BEIRUT GETS NO SUPPORT
description: The United States has failed to win any firm backing so far in its effort to enlist international support for closing down Beirut International Airport on the ground that it is a safe haven for terrorists, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Jackson Campaign Chief Gets Suspended Term
description: Arnold R. Pinkney, the manager of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1984 campaign for the Democratic Party's Presidential nomination, was placed on a year's probation today and was ordered to perform 60 hours of community service for his conviction for having an unlawful interest in a public contract.

title: Ever Optimistic
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt died 40 years ago and the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission was established by Congress 30 years ago, but the memorial it is supposed to build, on the Tidal Basin between the Jefferson and Lincoln Memorials, is still on the architect's drawing board.

title: A.T.&T. MOVING OUTPUT OF SOME PHONES TO ASIA
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, seeking to cut its manufacturing costs, said yesterday that it would move production of its residential phones from Shreveport, La., to a new plant in Singapore.

title: ON CARNEGIE HILL, FOOD GOES UPSCALE WITH NEIGHBORHOOD
description: Carnegie Hill was never a down-and-out neighborhood, so the changes taking place there are not as dramatic as those on a street such as Columbus Avenue. But the area, roughly between 89th and 96th Streets from Fifth to Madison Avenues, has gone from a virtual desert for serious food shoppers to an oasis of good food and produce in the last three years.

title: United Brands Is FMI Target
description: The FMI Financial Corporation, in which the Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner beneficially owns 65.1 percent, said today that it plans to buy at least 4 million, and as many as 4.5 million, shares of United Brands Company at $20 a share.

title: METS START ON TIME, WIN WITHOUT HITCH
description: Rick Aguilera was already in bed and fast asleep when the Mets finished their 19-inning marathon game with the Braves early this morning. He didn't even know who won until his roommate, fellow pitcher Sid Fernandez, returned to the hotel room and told him.

title: BAXTER RESPONSE TO CUTBACKS
description: For nearly three decades, Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. rode a wave of health care spending to become a major supplier of hospital products.

title: Ascent of the Native
description: President Reagan plans to nominate one of his White House aides, Michael E. Baroody, to be Assistant Secretary of Labor for Policy, a key job in the department. Mr. Baroody is now a deputy assistant to the President and director of public affairs, but in recent weeks he has been working at the Labor Department, trying to smooth the Reagan Administration's relations with organized labor. The new job pays $72,300 a year and requires Senate approval. Mr. Baroody joined the White House staff in 1981 as a deputy director of communications.

title: CARS THAT CRY 'WOLF!' IN THE NIGHT
description: Early the other morning, as I stumbled back to my apartment with my usual newspaper and bag of onion bagels, a large, loose-jointed furniture truck rumbled down my street in Brooklyn. A sleek blue Mercedes, parked majestically at curbside, apparently interpreted the truck's noisy approach as a threat to its safety and, responding in the way any other desirable automobile would, it tripped its own alarm, sending out a distress signal loud enough to raise Henry Ford from the grave.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
I.R.A. Bomb Wounds 7 On the Irish Border
description: A van packed with explosives blew up at a checkpoint on the Irish border today, wounding seven people, including three policemen. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility.

title:
PATENTS;

A Low-Calorie Cake
description: Inventors for the General Foods Corporation of White Plains recognized that for centuries people have been weight-conscious and have sought to control their diets.

title: F.D.A. Warns on Dried Fruit
description: The Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers that dried fruit and snack mixes sold under the ''Mountain Man'' label contain undisclosed sulfite preservatives that could cause an allergic reaction in some people.

title: Partitioned Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitler's 'Armenian-Extermination' Remark, True or False?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chris Woods, 59, Dies; Jazz Alto Saxophonist
description: Chris Woods, an alto saxophonist who played in jazz groups led by Dizzy Gillespie, Clark Terry, Sy Oliver and Buddy Rich, died Thursday at the Veterans Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 59 years old and lived in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Burger Lifts Court Bar On Personnel Policies
description: Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, has cleared the way Wednesday for sweeping new rules for Federal employment that would eliminate seniority rights for thousands of Government workers.

title: DANCE: JACOB'S PILLOW OFFERS 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: The Festival Dance Theater's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' performed on Wednesday at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, is an agreeable chamber production, staged by Charla Genn after the Marius Petipa standard. The tiny stage of the Ted Shawn Theater presented challenges, mostly unmet. Of greatest interest, however, was the ballet's casting.

title: Berkshire Drops Its Accountants
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the Omaha-based insurance and textile company controlled by Warren Buffet, has dismissed its accounting firm, Peat Marwick, the company disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Berkshire Hathaway said it took the action June 20 because Peat Marwick had recommended a different accounting treatment for two similar transactions that occurred over a two-year period.

title: NORMAN LEADS BY 3 IN CANADA
description: Greg Norman, the defending champion, chipped into the 16th hole from 25 feet for an eagle 3 today and finished with a three-shot lead after two rounds of the 76th Canadian Open.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 6, 1985
description: International The Government has failed to win firm backing so far for its effort to enlist international support for closing down Beirut International Airport. In addition, the move has prompted a wave of protest from the Arab world and objections from the Lebanese Government. One State Department official, commenting on the lack of support from West European allies, said ''the silence is deafening.'' [Page 1, Column 6.] An unmanned submarine found several large pieces of the Air-India Boeing 747 that crashed into the Atlantic Ocean southwest of Ireland June 23. A panel believed to contain recording devices that may hold clues about what destroyed the plane was among the chunks of debris found on a four-mile stretch of the ocean floor by the remote-controlled submarine. The pieces included parts of the cabin, galley and tail, and what appear to bodies of some of the 329 victims. [1:5-6.] A medical panel ruled that two white physicians in South Africa who examined the black activist Steve Biko before his death were guilty of improper conduct. The panel also said one of the doctors displayed ''disgraceful behavior'' while treating Mr. Biko during his detention. [1:3.] Loyal troops foiled a coup against Col. Lansana Conte, the President of Guinea. The troops conducted a house-to-house search in Conakry, the capital, to find the former Prime Minister who tried to seize control of the West African country while the President was out of the country.

title: A PERILED NUCLEAR PACT
description: This week marked the 17th anniversary of the signing of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, one of the most important documents of the nuclear age. The treaty comes up for review in August, with its future in peril.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. They are trailers. Wally Byam was the builder of the first Airstream trailer and a pioneer of trailer caravaning. 2.

title: Capital Advice
description: Rufus Jones, chairman of the Black Caucus in the Tennessee House of Representatives, said that college administrators have put sports ahead of education and urged them to get their priorities straight. ''Education should be their first priority,'' Jones said in Nashville.

title: Stocks Advance As Volume Falls
description: The stock market scored gains yesterday that sent some broad indicators to new highs as interest rates dropped sharply.

title: Swiss Storms Cause Floods
description: The first heavy thunderstorms in western and central Switzerland this summer caused flooding, knocked out power and telephone services and washed out roads and rail links. Hardest hit by the storm Thursday evening was the village of Schwarzenburg, where the waters pushed into basements and forced the evacuation of a shopping center. The rail link between Bern and Schwarzenburg, 13 miles away, was shut down.

title: Coast Study Under Way On Tainted Watermelon
description: Supermarkets in three states have stopped selling watermelons as an investigation into pesticide-tainted melons that sickened at least 72 people focused today on growers in two California counties.

title: Wiggins Stars in Debut
description: Alan Wiggins drove in a run, stole a base and scored in his American League debut as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the error-plagued Kansas City Royals, 6-3, tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, said it had consolidated five of its operating subsidiaries into one unit, American Petrofina of Texas Inc., which will now operate under the name of Fina Oil and Chemical Co.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Who's for Dinner Wins
description: Who's for Dinner, the oldest horse in a field of 12 and one of the few without a victory this year, scored a mild upset victory in the $126,600 Tidal Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: 3 FRANCISCANS HOUSING THE HOMELESS FIND SPENDING $2 MILLION A CHALLENGE
description: Three Franciscan priests have to spend $2 million by Aug. 15. The task, they are finding, is not easy.

title: Henry Ellenbogen Dies at 85; Longtime Judge in Pittsburgh
description: Henry Ellenbogen, who was a judge in Pittsburgh for 30 years after serving three terms in Congress, died Thursday at the Greenbriar Nursing Home in Miami. He was 85 years old.

title: CURREN ROUTS CONNORS WITH 17 ACES
description: With a look of resignation, Jimmy Connors awaited the serve that sounded like cymbals crashing in the score Kevin Curren composed at Wimbledon today. Curren was finishing with a flourish, pumping three aces past the player known for the best service return in tennis. But now Connors was in full retreat, standing several feet behind the baseline, willing to settle for simply getting his racquet on the ball.

title: Moving On
description: Jim Morrison, the infielder who had suggested that Pittsburgh didn't deserve the Pirates, responds to the booing he received from many of the 10,102 who attended the Independence Day loss to San Diego at Three Rivers Stadium: ''If the fans want to take it out on me, it's O.K. Either I'll move on, or the team will move on.''

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

PATENTS;

Identifying Microbes
description: A second patent on his technique for identifying microbes was granted this week to Dr. Robert E. Silman of London. Patent No. 4,526,865 gives added information on the process, including the use of radioactive agents. By coincidence, a process for preparing immobilized microbes for industrial use was patented this week by Ichiro Chibata and two other Japanese inventors for the Tanabe Seiyaku Company of Osaka, Japan.

title: A MATURING STORER'S GAINS
description: There were nights in recent years when Peter Storer lay awake wondering whether the expensive push by Storer Communications Inc. into the cable television business was going to pay off.

title: Strike Ruling Due At Argentine Ford
description: Officials of the Ford Motor Company today were waiting for a final decision by the Argentine Labor Minister on the legality of a 10-day-old strike by auto workers who have taken control of the company's main office and plant.

title: A GREEK SHIPOWNER FOUND SHOT TO DEATH ON UPPER EAST SIDE
description: A Greek shipowner who was sentenced to prison in 1983 in connection with a $60 million bank fraud was shot and killed as he stood on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 97th Street yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: TORIES FINISH THIRD IN WALES BY-ELECTION
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher suffered a nasty political shock today as her party finished a feeble third in a closely watched by-election in Wales.

title: NETWORKS PROMOTE COVERAGE OF HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: Television has had few more turbulent weeks than the one that began with the recent hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet and the taking of its passengers and crew as hostages. Television news organizations went into high gear, and when it was over, each of the networks made claims about its performance.

title: British Jet Diverted to France After Report of Bomb Aboard
description: A British Airways Boeing 737 made an emergency landing here today because of warnings that a bomb had been planted on board, the police said.

title: Taiwan Phone Project
description: Taiwan will spend $1.63 billion in the next four years to improve its telecommunications system, a spokesman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development said today.

title: Eckerd Plans Sale Of J. Byrons Stores
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent for the sale of its J. Byrons department store subsidiary to the Amcena Corporaion, a private company based in New York. The price was not disclosed.

title: POPULATION IN SCHOOLS TO RISE AS BABY BOOMERS REPRODUCE
description: A new crop of children will soon be expanding the school-age population, new Census Bureau figures indicate.

title: Urban Chinese to Get Raises for Hard Work
description: As promised by the Communist Party last October, urban Chinese will get pay increases this month in changes intended to reward hard work and talent.

title: U.S. Crews Gain
description: The American rowing teams competing in the second rounds of the Henley Royal Regatta set a sizzling pace today, and the first heats of Henley's premiere event, the Grand Challenge Cup, got under way with an easy victory for Harvard's varsity heavyweights.

title: Irvin Ehrenpreis Dies at 65; Authority on Jonathan Swift
description: Irvin Ehrenpreis, an authority on Jonathan Swift and 18th-century English literature, died Wednesday in a hospital in Munster, West Germany, of injuries resulting from a fall. He was 65 years old and lived in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Messerschmitt, Aerospatiale Pact
description: Aerospatiale, the French state-owned aerospace company, said it had concluded a research agreement with Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm of West Germany as part of the European Eureka research program.

title: Mets' Marathon: Why No Curfew?
description: Whatever great joy was instilled in those who witnessed it, whatever the merits of the argument that it now deserves its own special corner in Cooperstown, whatever the magnificence of its stupefyingly tortuous events, still there is a question to be asked about the ultramarathon in Atlanta: whether grown men, playing a boy's game to begin with, have any business doing so at 4 in the morning. Or, put another way, why has the National League never adopted a curfew rule, as the American League did in establishing a 1 A.M. cutoff years ago?

title: More Marathons
description: Doug Ault, the former major-league first baseman who now manages Syracuse in the International League, has some advice for the Mets and the Braves: ''Tell them what they need right now is to get their starters to take the bull by the horns and go the whole game.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STAR TIME For the first time, the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street (279-4200), is placing a performer's name above the show's title, an action indicating that the star is a luminous one, indeed.

title: RIGHTS ACTIVISTS ARE ACQUITTED OF VOTING FRAUD
description: A jury in Federal District Court found three black voting rights activists not guilty today of charges of voting fraud brought by the Justice Department.

title: 'UNDERSTANDING' WITH SOVIET ON WAR RISKS IS DESCRIBED
description: Administration officials provided details today of an ''understanding'' signed last month by the United States and the Soviet Union in which the two superpowers agreed to consult by way of the Moscow-Washington hot line in case of a nuclear explosion or a threat by a third party.

title: OTF EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: People Express
description: The Transporation Department said that People Express Airlines had been granted authority for nonstop flights to Zurich and Montreal from its base at Newark. These will be the airline's second and third foreign routes. Its only current foreign route is Newark-London.

title: Art on the IND
description: A Cubistic tower lighted by a crescent moon. Glowing Oskar Schlemmer-like slender figures. A multicolored Expressionistic face. A dappled, precise Klee-ish painting.

title: Didja Hear the One . . .
description: Senator Bill Bradley is aware that on the Washington after-dinner circuit he is not considered an all-star talker. But he is trying, and when he joined a recent roast of Governor Cuomo of New York he was able to hit the open man a few times.

title:
PATENTS;

Vegetable Oil Fuel For Diesels Developed
description: A substitute fuel for diesel engines has been invented by Arthur W. Schwab and Everett H. Pryde, employees of the Department of Agriculture's Northern Regional Research Center in Peoria, Ill.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HITLER DIARIES PLOT, IF THERE WAS ONE, THICKENS
description: In the last 10 months, 37 witnesses and experts at the Hitler diaries trial have lent their insights into one of the great journalistic frauds of the century. Yet those who have followed the marathon trial here have been left unsatisfied, as if they had read an elaborate whodunit without an ending.

title: Bridge: An Expert Can Be Betrayed By a Blind Spot in Strategy
description: Sooner or later every expert suffers from what is charitably described as a blind spot. After going down in a contract, he discovers, perhaps with the help of a perceptive partner or opponent, that he has missed a clearly superior line of play that would have succeeded.

title: Lewis Cancels Tour
description: The American track and field star Carl Lewis, who won four gold medals at the Los Angeles Olympics last summer, has pulled out of a British tour this summer because of an injury, according to a report in London by the Press Association, the domestic news organization. Lewis strained his right hamstring after the first Grand Prix track and field meeting of the season in May. He has withdrawn from the Amateur Athletics Association championships July 13-14 and the Peugot Talbot Games July 19-20, and the Edinburgh Games on July 23.

title: MAINE STRIKE ECHOES PLIGHT OF SHIPYARD
description: Three months ago the sprawling Bath Iron Works complex rang with cheers as thousands of workers heard the news that the shipyard had won a new Navy contract that could bring it billions of dollars of work in the decades to come.

title:
CONSUMER SATURDAY;

THE SNAGS IN KEEPING A SURNAME
description: WHILE it is no longer unusual for women to keep their family names when they marry, many who do so say they still encounter mistakes and added red tape, including problems with credit cards, car loans, the I.R.S. and even maternity wards.

title: DONALD P. BAKER
description: Donald P. Baker, a former personnel director for Consolidated Edison, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Sea Girt, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: Mexico Price Report Hailed
description: Consumer prices here rose 2.5 percent in June, a notch ahead of the previous month but well below the increases of earlier in the year, the Government announced today.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.6 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply increased by $2.6 billion in the week ended June 24, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. The rise was well above the market's expectations.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it would lay off up to 225 workers for at least six months at its Alymer, Quebec, plant this September because of reduced demand for the digital transmission devices made at the plant. Last April, the company indefinitely laid off 198 employees at the plant, which now employs 800.

title: Hitler's 'Armenian-Extermination' Remark, True or False?
description: To the Editor:

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER PLANS A 6% CUT IN STAFF
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 1,745 jobs, or about 6 percent of its worldwide staff of 32,000.

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
Early TV Rock
description: Early television appearances by Elvis Presley, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and the Monkees can be seen today at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: OLYMPICS A DISTANT GOAL
description: The rare spare moments in her calendar are filled with sports car rallies, and modeling appearances, and aerobics videos, and therapy for her surgically repaired knee. The injury is a result of her top priority. ''Judo is my life,'' said Ingrid Berghmans of Belgium. In her 24 years, she has certainly tried to find other things. But nothing has matched the sport that has given her four world championships since 1980.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42. 1. About 4,000 of these gathered at Lake Placid Airport for the annual Wally Byam international rally. What are they and who was Wally Byam? 2. The Iranian Government played a part in the last-minute negotiations that led to the release of the Americans held hostage in Lebanon. What did it do and what was the apparent reason? 3. In its third recent ruling on the relationship of government and religion, the Supreme Court said that public school systems may not send teachers into parochial school classrooms to provide remedial or enrichment instruction. True or false? 4. Visitors to foreign countries may safely use ice cubes in drinks because freezing kills most of the common bacteria in contaminated water that cause gastric distress. True or false? 5. The promotion of a Soviet official broke a pattern of leadership that had been set by Leonid I Brezhnev. Who is the official and what was the pattern? 6. In a 20-block area of Brooklyn, a bizarre phenomenon is upsetting residents and confounding experts. What is happening there? 7. ''I know 26 is not old age but I've been on the tour eight years and at times, it catches up with you.'' Who made this remark and what were the circumstances? 8. A major city approved a zoning change that, among other things, limits the construction of skyscrapers and halves the number of office jobs projected for its congested downtown over the next 15 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 6, 1985
description: The Economy The unemployment rate remained at 7.2 percent in June for the fifth straight month, the Labor Department reported. But analysts were disappointed by a decline in factory employment and slow growth in nonfarm payrolls. When taken with other recent figures - on car sales, trade, inventories and the ''flash'' G.N.P. - the report suggests that the economy is soft enough for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy further. There was, however, a small gain in the length of the factory workweek. [Page 1.] Employment rose in the New York metropolitan area, but job growth is slowing. [7.] Markets The basic money supply jumped $2.6 billion in the week ended June 24, far more than the market had expected. The news dimmed a bond market rally brought on by weakness in the unemployment report. Still, bond prices closed a point and a half higher than Wednesday, the previous day of trading. While economic weakness could encourage lower interest rates, the Fed is also concerned that rapid increases in the money supply would cause inflation. [27.] Stock prices marched higher in very light activity. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.06 points, to 1,334.45, just shy of the record on Monday of 1,337.14. Broader measures did set records. Trading was the slowest of the year, at 62.5 million shares. [31.] The dollar fell in light trading although a late upturn brought it above the day's lows. Gold edged higher overseas, gaining $1 an ounce, to $311.50, in London.

title: Irish Jobless Rate Up
description: DUBLIN, July 5 (AP) - Unemployment in Ireland rose to 17 percent in June, from 16.7 percent in May and 15.9 percent in June 1984, the Irish Government announced today.

title: No Headline
description: The BRNF Liquidating Trust said its certificate holders had rejected Braniff Inc.'s proposal for modifications of the lease under which BRNF leases planes to Braniff.

title: ANALYSIS OF A FAILURE
description: THE 25-YEAR WAR: America's Military Role in Vietnam. By Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr. 210 pages. Illustrated. The University Press of Kentucky. $24. The Vietnam War so stirred and confused the United States that writing about it has generally been equally stirring and confusing. There have been some good novels, but very few objective analyses of what went wrong and why in that long, ultimately fruitless conflict.

title: 4 Die in Colorado Fire
description: Four people were killed early today in a house fire near the Colorado State University campus. One woman escaped by climbing out a bedroom window onto a porch roof. The survivor was identified as Lisa Nolan, 23, of Fort Collins.

title: A DISPUTE ON NEIMAN FUR SALE
description: Call it a family spat or a lack of communication, but it was one of those contretemps that make for red faces. A recent fur sale by Neiman-Marcus of Dallas rubbed Andrew Goodman, the former owner of Bergdorf Goodman, the wrong way.

title: OWNER HAS CHANCE TO SETTLE OLD DEBT
description: At about 5 o'clock this afternoon, the past and present will meet at Belmont Park with an eerie anniversary.

title: Lawmaker Says U.S. Closed Pension Offices
description: The Reagan Administration has closed three Social Security offices and plans to close six more before the end of the year, Edward R. Roybal, the chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging said today.

title: CABARET: PEGGI BLU
description: Peggi Blu, a successful pop-soul backup singer with a tart, rangy voice and a flamboyantly gregarious personality, has created a cabaret act whose musical elements reflect the unmistakable influence of Patti LaBelle. Like Miss LaBelle, Miss Blu takes familiar songs and stretches them into extended, often dramatic exercises that show off her range and stamina and a high-pitched emotion.

title: HENDERSON BOOSTS AVERAGE AND TEAM
description: Floating around in baseball's sea of facts and figures is this bit of esoterica: the Yankees are almost unbeatable when Rickey Henderson scores in the first inning.

title: North Korea Agrees To Meeting With South
description: North Korea agreed today to preliminary contacts between South and North Korean legislators on July 23, the South Korean National Assembly announced.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $25 million, or $1.02 a share, for the quarter and year from the sale of assets. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $592,000 and an extraordinary charge of $2,692,000 from a conversion of subordinated debentures.

title: AMOS OZ, A KIBBUTZNIK IN THE COLORADO ROCKIES
description: Amos Oz, the Israeli novelist and essayist, dropped off some aphorisms and observations the other day while passing through New York on the way to Colorado, where he has been teaching and absorbing the American scene through the keen vision of a kibbutznik in the Rockies.

title: NEW YORK JOB GROWTH DROPS
description: The rapid increase in the number of jobs in the New York metropolitan area during 1983 and 1984 slackened significantly in the first half of 1985, according to unemployment figures released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Slogans
description: Themes in campaign commercials often sound alike, as in: ''Ed Koch works for all New Yorkers.''

title: SHOT AT STADIUM SAID TO BE FIRED INSIDE THE PARK
description: The gunshot that wounded a 34-year-old woman at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night was probably fired from inside the park, but the investigation so far has turned up few leads, the police said yesterday.

title: TESTS FIND SIGNIFICANT LEAD LEVELS IN U.S. WATER
description: A large number of Americans drink tap water that is contaminated with significant levels of lead, according to data compiled by a private company that tests water.

title: THE TESTIMONY DOESN'T WASH
description: ''You have an obligation . . . to want the truth. You are not doing that.''

title: SAVING IS PUT AT $225 MILLION
description: The Reagan Administration today announced an additional reduction in Medicare spending, amounting to what it said would be more than $225 million. The savings would be achieved through new limits on payments for medical education and home health care.

title: George Oldfield Is Dead at 61; Hunted the 'Yorkshire Ripper'
description: George Oldfield, the police officer who led the hunt for the so-called Yorkshire Ripper, died Thursday. He was 61 years old.

title: Pryor on Defensive
description: Aaron Pryor, fighting his mother's attempt to commit him to a drug treatment program and said by some to be in danger of throwing away his boxing career, says he will start training Monday for another bout. Pryor, 30 years old, who has left his Cincinnati home and now lives in Miami, rejected remarks by his Cincinnati-based manager, Buddy LaRosa, that he may lack the desire to box again.

title: THE CHANGING IMAGE OF I.B.M.
description: PERCHED ON A HILL JUST SOUTH OF THE LITTLE town of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., the Thomas J. Watson Research Center is a crescent of rough-cut stone and dark glass, the innovative heart of the International Business Machines Corporation. One of Eero Saarinen's last buildings, it looks as though a good wind would take it aloft - a fitting image for the most profitable industrial enterprise on earth. But on a warm day last month, the atmosphere inside was something less than upbeat as John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s president and chief executive officer, walked stiffly to the podium.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: July 7, 1985 Fiction

title: Pinning Blame In South Africa
description: South African critics have often accused the authorities of killing black activists. Last week, the latest accusations were denied, which is rare in itself; and culpability in a celebrated earlier case was partially confirmed, which is rarer still.

title: THE VAUNTED INVESTMENT 'BOOM' IS A BUST
description: DESPITE the latest negative flutterings of scattered indicators, the idea has taken hold that America in the second half of the 1980's is on the move again economically. Prices are more nearly stable, incomes are up and unemployment is at least steady.

title: MOSTLY MOZART BROADENS ITS SCOPE
description: Until some intrepid gourmet decided that those decorative love apples looked good enough to eat and actually ate one, so legend tells us, nobody dared to bite into this member of the nightshade family. Now the tomato is a fact of summer life, as indispensable as ice cubes. That's the way it is with innovations. In no time at all we have trouble remembering what life was like without them. Would you believe, for instance, that there ever was a summer when Mostly Mozart did not exist?

title: WHAT'S DOING ON MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: Martha's Vineyard is said to have been a haven of refuge for Leif Ericsson in the year 1003. The 20-mile-long chunk of land five miles off Cape Cod was also visited by Giovanni da Verazano in 1524, Bartholomew Gosnold in 1602, and Samuel de Champlain in 1606. All had words of praise for the natural beauty of the island, and the nourishment to be found in its waters and in its fields and woods.

title: WHEN BALLROOM DANCES TAKE TO THE STAGE
description: Some dance forms exist primarily for the fun of doing them, and the people who do them don't particularly care whether or not they're being watched. Other dances are meant to be watched. Into this category belong all examples of theatrical dancing from hoofing to ballet.

title: 'YOU'RE IN AMERICA'
description: In doing research, a reporter tries to draw information from all available sources. One of the sources for the Ellis Island article was my uncle, Joseph Parisi, a retired paving contractor from the Bergen County community of Rochelle Park.

title: EXPLORING THE WORLD OR RUMPOLE
description: To observe barristers in their natural habitat you must go to the Inns of Court; to the quadrangles of Gray's, enclosed and rather formal, on the north side of High Holborn; to the courtyards on either side of Middle Temple Lane, between the Strand and the river, companionably shared by the Middle and the Inner Temple; or to the leafy lawns of Lincoln's, west of Chancery Lane, separated only by the width of Carey Street from the rear entrance to the Law Courts.

title: A Chronology
description: June 14: The plane taken over by two gunmen and flown to Beirut, then to Algiers and back to Beirut, where Robert Dean Stethem, a Navy diver, is shot and killed.

title: RENOVATION OF COUNTY CENTER UNDER WAY
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, wearing a white hard hat and his shirt sleeves rolled up, stood beneath a scaffold outside the Westchester County Center as an audience of about 200 watched, cajoled and offered advice on how Mr. O'Rourke might remove a large windowpane from the building.

title: Spies and the Technology Edge
description: America's military secrets are poorly protected. The amateur spy ring allegedly run by John Walker is said to have operated for 20 years but was detected only when his wife decided to turn him in. The leakage may have shifted the balance of the critical strategic tussle by which the American and Soviet Navies strive to detect each other's missile-carrying submarines.

title: BRITISH INDIA AS SEEN THROUGH INDIAN EYES
description: We have been seeing a lot of India through English eyes lately. Sharp eyes, but ineffably English. In David Lean's respectful rendering of E. M. Forster's ''Passage to India,'' in ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' the estimable British television adaptation of Paul Scott's ''Raj Quartet,'' and, earlier, in Richard Attenborough's ''Gandhi,'' we found ourselves in an India where political struggle centered on the British presence or, in some ways more unsettling, the British absence.

title: MENGELE SON SAID TO BARGAIN ON RIGHTS TO FATHER'S PAPERS
description: The son of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele has preserved significant copyrights to his father's papers and is negotiating to sell them for almost half a million dollars, according to sources close to the son.

title: SAVORING THE TASTE OF BALSAMIC VINEGAR
description: BALSAMIC is one of the best vinegars to come along in a while. That makes it sound like something new, which, as far as the American market is concerned, it is. But actually, Balsamic vinegar is a product that is centuries old.

title: JANE BAKER WEDS DR. J. A. PASQUINI IN EPISCOPAL RITE
description: Jane Eliza Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Griffin Baker Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married at St. Mark's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Dr. John Aldo Pasquini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gino Amerigo Pasquini of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Margaret Minnick performed the ceremony.

title: SARA FISCHER IS WED TO THOMAS HULL, CONTRACTOR
description: Sara Fischer, the daughter of Elinor Moore of Lincolnville, Me., and Boston and George Fischer of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Thomas I. Hull, a son of Ma'Carry W. Hull of Portland, Ore., and Robert Buffinton Hull of Pinehurst, N.C. The Rev. Julian V. Hills performed the ceremony at the Emanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.

title: 'ANXIETY, NOT FEAR'
description: ''MY God in Heaven, how vast and beautiful this place is where we are to start our lives anew.' ''

title: VROOM! THE TRUE AMERICAN HERO
description: YEAGER An Autobiography. By Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: WISDOM IN THE SUN
description: THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A healthy-looking summer tan and a severe sunburn is common sense, which means protecting the skin and eyes from the sun's harmful ultraviolet rays.

title: Bad News For Thatcher
description: A by-election rarely seals a government's political fate. Nevertheless, the Conservatives who rule Britain had reasons to worry after one such election in Wales last week.

title: DEVELOPMENT OF NEWPORT WATERFRONT FORCES FISHERMEN TO FIGHT FOR SPACE
description: Tom Lazouras looked out from a deck on the fourth floor of the old Perry Mill to the harbor, already filling up with sailboats and gleaming in the sun.

title: OLD FRESH AIR HANDS LEAD THE NEW
description: Eight young men from the city rose early for their hike through the woods. This day their task was to clear a trail, and armed with tools, they began to swagger down a long road between two huge fields.

title: DENTISTRY PREFERRED
description: For John Geletka, the dentist who negotiated Bernie Kosar's five-year contract with the Browns for about $5 million, there is more to life than being an agent. Even though he proved his ability as an negotiator for the former University of Miami quarterback, Geletka said he would not actively seek to become an agent for other athletes.

title: LANCE RESIGNS GEORGIA PARTY POST TO CONTEST BANKING ALLEGATIONS
description: Bert Lance has resigned as chairman of Georgia's Democratic Party, three years after he was appointed to the post and less than two weeks after a report critical of his banking practices was made public.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM STRAVINSKY TO DR. SEUSS
description: Men at Work Live In San Francisco or Was It Berkeley? Featuring Men at Work CBS/Fox Video 58 minutes. $29.98 It must give Men at Work no few ironic chuckles when throngs of people dance to their songs about paranoia and alienation ( ''Overkill,'' ''Who Can It Be Now?'') or nuclear holocaust (''It's a Mistake'').

title: Even in Summer, The Hungry Suffer
description: In recent years, cold snaps have triggered concern for the hungry and the homeless in New York City. But while attention to them may diminish during the summertime, their need does not, according to a report released last week.

title: INNOCENCE ABROAD
description: To the Editor: Most of what Mr. Molotsky learned applies to men. Last April my husband and I had a similar experience on a bus in Mexico City, and here is what women can learn from it.

title: Hypersexism And the Feds
description: I am happy to report that during a recent computer project for the American Language Alliance the terms mail carrier and police officer were used in a story instead of mailman and policeman.

title: 10% of Army Women Pregnant at Any Time
description: One in 10 women in the Army is pregnant at any given time, and 17 percent are pregnant over the course of a year, leading a political scientist to recommend continuing the ban on putting women in combat.

title: LOSING IN TRAINING CAN BE DEVASTATING
description: You have to be sure of yourself to contest a training match before engaging in a world championship match.

title: BECKER, 17, GAINS FINAL
description: With a night of rest to refresh him, Boris Becker returned to Centre Court today to continue the pursuit of a championship his opponents have said he cannot win. And once again the 17-year-old West German was like rolling thunder, overpowering Anders Jarryd in the completion of their semifinal match and becoming the youngest player to reach the men's final at Wimbledon.

title: OVERALL TAX CUTS BY STATES EXCEED SUM OF INCREASES
description: For the first time in several years, the states have enacted a larger overall amount in tax cuts than tax increases. A number of legislatures have rolled back emergency taxes imposed in the recent recession.

title: VAMOOSE, YOU VARMITS, THE GOOD GUYS RIDE AGAIN
description: A covered wagon crossing an empty desert in the mid-day sun. A man on horseback at full gallop across a wide and lonely prairie with nothing but space and sky as far as the eye can see. These are scenes so ingrained in the American psyche that they form a part of our national self-image. They come from the westerns we all grew up with, but, according to the writer and director Lawrence Kasdan, they are as exotic to the young moviegoers of today as the landscape of the moon.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: STRANGE LEADS BY 2 IN CANADA
description: Curtis Strange, the leading money winner on the PGA Tour so far this year, dropped a 25-foot eagle putt from the fringe of the 18th green today to take a 2-shot lead over Greg Norman in the third round of the 76th Canadian Open.

title: CELEBRATING AMERICAN MUSIC
description: Over 200 participating organizations in more than 40 states will celebrate the first American Music Week this fall.

title:
ANTIQUES;

COLONIAL OPEN HOUSE IN LITCHFIELD
description: LITCHFIELD, ''a delightful village on a fruitful hill, is richly endowed with schools, with venerable governors and judges, learned lawyers and senators, and representatives,'' the Rev. Daniel Huntington wrote early in the 19th century. ''And the population is enlightened and respectable.''

title: JULIE LANDSMAN WEDS MICHAEL SALINGER
description: At the Rockdale Temple in Cincinnati yesterday Julie Landsman, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert S. Landsman and the late Mr. Landsman of Cincinnati, was married to Michael A. Salinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Salinger, also of Cincinnati. Rabbi Howard Simon performed the ceremony.

title:
Home Design;

TO A MANOR REBORN
description: HOUSES, AS well as people, can be survivors, and such is the case with a distinguished dwelling in Normandy called the Manoir d'Ango. Situated in Varengeville-sur-Mer, a few miles from Dieppe, the house has withstood four centuries of prosperity and then neglect.

title:
ART;

ART THAT BARES THE DEMONS WITHIN
description: ART, like life, is not all sweetness and light. Currently, the most ambitious contemporary artists are dealing with human concerns in emotional and psychological terms, and often the picture is not a pretty one.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Six isn't enough.'' - Martina Navratilova, on her latest Wimbledon singles championship. [Section 5, 1:6.]

title: AD HOC DECISION
description: Bridge-players en masse are about as law-abiding, no more and no less, than the general public: A tiny minority deliberately flouts the law; a larger minority meticulously observes both the laws and the proprieties; and in between is a large group that commits small misdemeanors, either through ignorance or because punishment seems unlikely.

title: Man Held in Hijack 'Threat'
description: A Maryland man has been charged with making terroristic threats after telling a flight attendant aboard a Forida-bound People Express Airlines plane that he wanted to hijack it, the police said today. The man, identified as Waleed M. Muaket, 25 years old of Silver Spring, was removed by security guards from the plane at Newark International Airport Friday night.

title: Israel Hits The Brakes; Labor Strikes
description: For one day last week, all of Israel's banks were closed. So were factories, schools, offices and markets. Hospitals accepted emergency patients only and utility companies cut power.

title: They Fought in Korea
description: Controversy over construction of a Korean War Memorial in Washington appears to have been resolved with a compromise under which a Government agency would build the memorial with a combination of Federal funds and private contributions.

title: WHAT DID THE GREYWACKE SAY?
description: THE GREAT DEVONIAN CONTROVERSY The Shaping of Scientific Knowledge Among Gentlemanly Specialists. By Martin J. S. Rudwick. Illustrated. 494 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $39.95.

title: GROTON GREETS NAUTILUS IN A FINAL HOMECOMING
description: Saluted by fireboats, balloons and cannon salvos, the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, the Nautilus, made its final voyage home today, an antique of the nuclear age.

title: The Loophole in Life Insurance
description: According to life insurers, one provision of President Reagan's tax revision would mean the ''slow death'' of their industry. That is probably overwrought, but the insurers are right to recognize that properly taxing the accumulating cash value of insurance and annuity policies - the so-called inside buildup - would make life insurance a much less attractive way to save money. There is no good reason, though, why the earnings on insurance should be officially favored over those on bank deposits or mutual funds. This reform is overdue.

title: UNIVERSITIES COME TO THE AID OF NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES
description: A growing number of colleges and universities in the Northeast are embarking on projects to bolster the economic health of their communities.

title: MISS MCCANCE PLANS TO MARRY
description: A Nov. 2 wedding is planned by Suzanne Valentine McCance and Martin Creighton Huguley, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McCance Jr. of New Haven and Fishers Island, L.I., have announced.

title: Television Isn't to Blame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PAULA WHITEHORN TO WED
description: Paula Barri Whitehorn and Carlos Arrom, both seniors at Northwestern University, plan to be married next summer, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Whitehorn of Short Hills, N.J., have announced. Mr. Arrom is a son of Dr. Orlando Arrom of Miami and Dr. Raquel Alvarez of Skokie, Ill.

title: SCARSDALE NATIVE JOINS 'LITTLE SHOP' CAST
description: BEING, by turns, a standby, understudy and replacement is paying off for Andrew Hill Newman. Just a month ago, the 25-year-old singer and actor, who was born and reared in Scarsdale, took over the role of Seymour, commonly called the ''cute and nebbishy'' character, in Off Broadway's ''Little Shop of Horrors.'' The show is a huge hit in a tiny theater: The Orpheum on Second Avenue (capacity: 310).

title: OPEC FAILS AGAIN IN EFFORT TO UNITE TO KEEP PRICES UP
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed again today to agree on measures to bolster world oil prices, despite a warning by Mexico that it might cut its oil prices next week.

title: EXPLORER SAYS HE HAS DISCOVERED REMAINS OF A JUNGLE CITY IN PERU
description: An American explorer says he has found an ancient pre-Columbian metropolis covering 120 square miles in the jungle-cloaked mountains of northeastern Peru.

title: CABLE TV
description: Bravo, the cable service that never seems to take a nap when it comes to creative and aggressive choices of new movie presentations, is giving Jean-Luc Godard's ''First Name: Carmen'' its television premiere on Sunday night at 8 and at 1:30 A.M. It ought to burn up the coaxial tentacles that carry it.

title: MEXICO'S RULING PARTY TO BE TESTED IN VOTING TODAY
description: Mexico's democracy, which for 56 years has largely served to ratify the ruling party and its policies, will be tested Sunday in nationwide elections.

title: TRENTON: A MOVING 'UNDOING'
description: WHAT an intriguing title for a play is ''The Undoing.'' Be it erasure, reversal, ruination or release - all dictionary definitions -the word says much and implies more.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

CRAFTS OF OLD
description: ''We are eager to see the response to what we call 'family afternoons' where people can drop by to see what life was like in this area during the 18th century,'' said Julie Mirsberger of Tarrytown, curator of the Westchester County Historical Society. The first such afternoon will be held next Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M., rain or shine, on the grounds of the Colonel Hammond House.

title: PAUL ZWEIG AND WALT WHITMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: STING MAKES A FORAY INTO JAZZ
description: Sting - leader and bassist of the Police, sometime movie star, and now a solo recording artist with his own handpicked jazz ensemble - has developed one of the most artfully controlled pop songwriting voices of the last decade. It is a voice that wants to appeal to everyone and at the same time to be taken very seriously with its message of pacifism and global unity.

title: But Let Insurance Companies Get Into the Banking Business
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AFRICAN CULTURE Two women who have figured prominently in the development of a black dance tradition in America will be featured in the Shoreline Alliance for the Arts' ''African Culture Day'' to be held in various locations around Guilford Saturday.

title: TWO 'ROMEOS' DISPLAY STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES
description: Of Shakespeare's tragedies, ''Romeo and Juliet'' has understandably been the most popular as a source of musical inspiration in virtually every genre, from opera and ballet to symphony and even string quartet: the second movement of Beethoven's Quartet in F (Op. 18, No. 1) was reputedly founded on the tomb scene. Though neither of the two most elaborate treatments of ''Romeo'' - Hector Berlioz's dramatic symphony and Charles Gounod's opera - has been a complete stranger to the recording studios, neither has been a frequent visitor. Gounod's contribution, in fact, has been distinctly underplayed. Therefore the new recordings of both works are more than welcome regardless of the problems each has to a greater or lesser degree.

title: After A Burglary
description: Albert Scardino's article ''After a Burglary'' (About Men, June 2) evoked fears I have tried to bury for 20 years. When I was a child, my home was robbed.

title: DEMOGRAPHICS MAY FORETELL SHIFT OF POWER IN NEW YORK
description: When political bosses used to pick the candidates in New York City, they made sure that every faction of the party - Irish, Italian, Jewish, black and Hispanic - had a face somewhere on the ticket. Balance was sometimes more important than competence.

title:
DINING OUT;

A SURPRISE OR TWO IN SUMMIT
description: THE opening five months ago of Toto, a restaurant associated with Chatham's three-star Tarragon Tree, was greeted with high anticipation in Summit, the neighboring town that has been notably short on top-notch dining spots.

title: WINNIFRED DUNNAN IS WED IN CAPITAL
description: The Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in Washington was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Winifred Barrett Dunnan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Weaver W. Dunnan of Bethesda, Md., to Thomas Ewart Faust Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Faust of Helena, Ark.

title: INTERIOR DEPARTMENT TAKES TIME TO LOOK AND LISTEN
description: When William K. Reilly, president of the Conservation Foundation, visited the office of Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel last month, he noticed that pictures of foxes that had been on the walls were missing. The pictures had been hung there by one of Mr. Hodel's predecessors, James G. Watt, to mock those who charged that he was a fox guarding a henhouse, because his policies favored exploiting public lands rather than protecting them.

title: BED AND BREAKFASTS WIN FAVOR
description: JUST three years ago, there were a handful of bed and breakfast accommodations in Connecticut. Now, more than 200 Connecticut homeowners make rooms available to paying guests, said Barbara Beeching, a spokesman for the State Division of Tourism.

title: CAN ALLEN BORN TURN AMAX AROUND?
description: LOOKING at the modern office building across from the railroad station in this serene suburb, there is no indication that it houses the headquarters of a company in deep financial trouble. But go inside, and see some of the empty desks at Amax Inc. The mining company has been operating under an austerity program for severalyears now. Some 560 people used to work here; now there are 318. There is plenty of room to park in the underground garage.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

40 YEARS OF MUSIC, UNLESS IT RAINS
description: SOME day, Dr. William Baker and his colleagues in the Huntington Community Band would like to complete the ''Unfinished Symphony.''

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

THE EYE OF THE STORM
description: THE pictures are literally awe-inspiring: White thunderheads, edged with the pink sun of evening, tower into a Wedgwood blue sky. Jagged lightning cleaves billowing black clouds. The wispy beginnings of a cone-shaped tornado emerge insidiously from a mass of gray.

title:
GARDENING;

A PROPER START FOR YOUNG TREES
description: PLANTING a tree is an investment in the future. With the exception of small trees planted primarily for their flowering effect, most trees require two or three human generations to mature and provide the effect, whether it be shade or landscaping, for which they were planted.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: GRANPA. Written and illustrated by John Burningham. Crown. $8.95. (Ages 2 to 5) Vignettes from the lives of an energetic little girl and her loving and often exhausted grandfather.

title: DEPRESSED TRENTON AIMS FOR ROAD TO RECOVERY
description: WHEN H. Roy Heath, a lumber-store owner, won a 1910 Chamber of Commerce contest with the slogan ''Trenton Makes, the World Takes,'' the words soon were emblazoned on the side of the Trenton-Morrisville (Pa.) Bridge.

title: MISS GRIFFIN HAS WEDDING
description: At Trinity Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Barbara Sargent Griffin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Quigley Griffin of Hopewell, N.J., was married to Christopher Alfred Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Cole of Guilford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Canon Timothy B. Cogan, the Episcopal chaplain at Princeton University, from which the bride graduated magna cum laude and the bridegroom cum laude.

title: ASSOCIATION YIELDS ON TEACHER TESTING
description: The National Education Association, often accused of impeding efforts to raise standards for teachers, took steps last week to alter its image. Two resolutions, one endorsing tests as part of the assessment of new teachers and the other backing the dismissal of experienced teachers judged to be incompetent, were approved by 7,500 teachers gathered at their annual convention in Washington.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;

PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Most summer shows are anthologies of work from the gallery's regular exhibitors. ''Off the Wall II,'' at Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, 568 Broadway at Prince Street, through July 31, is something different.

title: FAIRWAY LIVING
description: The greater part of a former country-club golf course in the Town of Kent in Putnam County is being transformed into a residential development with 216 country-style town houses.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

WINNING THE BATTLE OF THE BRAT
description: AN open letter to Alice Schultze, who wrote ''My Teen-Age Birthday Girl Wants Just One Thing: More'' [Opinion Page]:

title: AN INLAND EMPIRE BUILT ON ORANGES
description: Early in this century, Charles F. Lummis, the noted historian of Southern California, said that for the region the navel orange was not only a fruit but a romance as well. More recently, it was termed an esthetic. Indeed, the owners of groves cultivated not only the navel orange but also a healthy outdoor life and a tidy profit, all within a landscape of snow-capped mountains and foothills. Often living in elaborate homes set amid the groves, the ranchers were of the gentleman variety, originating from Back East.

title: EUROPE FALLS ONCE MORE INTO THE BREACH
description: Nationalist demons seemed to be interfering with Europe's dream of political unity again last weekend in Milan, where leaders of the Common Market countries disagreed about proposals to strengthen their community and increase its voice in world affairs. The quarrel at the European summit meeting was the latest setback for the goal of ''an ever closer union of the European peoples,'' which was set forth in the Treaty of Rome, which launched the Common Market in 1957.

title: A Foreign-Policy Alternative to Cold Warriorism
description: To the Editor:

title: GIVING PLAYS A 'BIRTH STAGE'
description: FOR the second season of play readings in the Summer Solstice Theater Conference, which has moved this year to Amagansett, some changes have been made. But the conference remains faithful to the philosophy of its founder and artistic director, Zachary Russ - that is, to provide a platform for new American works.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I plan to travel extensively in the United States. Lodging will be a major expense item, so I plan to stay in bed-and-breakfast facilities and/or guest houses. Where can I obtain a directory of such facilities? - A. F., Manchester, Vt. Answer:There are several bed-and-breakfast guidebooks, some listing facilities all over the country and others that concentrate on specific regions. The development of the B and B concept has also brought a growth in the number of referral services that act as agents for B and B places and guest houses.

title: NANCY JEAN QUICK IS MARRIED ON L.I.
description: Nancy Jean Quick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie C. Quick Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Craig Bradley Gibson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John S. Gibson of Winchester and Brewster, Mass. The Rev. James E. Collins performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: IVORYTON PLAYHOUSE HAS NEW PRODUCER
description: THE travails of the Ivoryton Playhouse are nothing new to observers of summer-stock theater.

title: Four Die in Kentucky, Apparently From Gas
description: A water district employee, apparently overcome by methane gas, and three-would be rescuers died Friday at an underground sewer pumping station, the authorities said.

title: Required ReadingOn 'Realignment'
description: Excerpts from remarks by Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, to the Republican Party Midwestern Leadership Conference, Grand Rapids, Mich., June 23:

title: NANCY R. WHITE TO WED LAYWER
description: Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court of the United States and Mrs. White of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Pitkin White, to Paul Maxwell Lippe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lippe of New York and Somers, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8. Miss White graduated from the Madeira School, Stanford University and the Radcliffe publishing procedures course.

title: Mixed Reviews for TV in Hostage Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: SUZANNE ROTHSCHILD ENGAGED
