description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Rothschild Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Trott Rothschild to John Wilkinson Baynard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Parks Baynard of Charlotte, N.C. The wedding is planned for September.

title: POPE TO WRITE WEEKLY COLUMN FOR TWO MURDOCH SYNDICATES
description: The Vatican and two news syndicates of Rupert Murdoch have concluded an agreement under which a weekly column by Pope John Paul II will be made available to hundreds of newspapers in the United States and other countries starting in September.

title: A WRITER RUNNING STRONG
description: ''I'M a hard worker,'' says Rozanne Knudson of Sea Cliff.

title: CASE AGAINST EXXON STICKS - TO THE TUNE OF $1.9 BILLION
description: The Government last week won its biggest victory yet in its effort to punish energy companies charged with violating the oil price controls of the 1970's. Affirming a lower court decision, a Federal court of appeals in Washington ruled that the Exxon Corporation had overcharged customers who bought oil from a Texas field, and ordered Exxon to pay the Government $1.9 billion in refunds and interest.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MARBURG CHRONICLES. By Alfred Coppel. (Dutton, $18.95.) Memorable characters are the principal strength of this fine historical novel, but its evocative descriptions of 19th-century Spain, Mexico and the United States are also impressive.

title: Moment of Silence and Its Uses
description: UNDER a bill approved by the Massachusetts Legislature's joint Education Committee, schoolchildren would begin the day with a moment of silence, but not one designated for prayer or meditation.

title: NEW 'CAMP' CATERS TO PAMPERED DOLLS
description: FIRST came Cabbage Patch Kids. Then Cabbage Patch ensembles and accessories. And now, two Old Saybrook families are offering Cabbage Patch vacations For $19.95, a Cabbage Patch doll can spend two weeks at Camp Cabbagepatch. For the money, the owner gets a personal letter ostensibly written by the camper, a Camp Cabbagepatch T-shirt, a picture of the doll with its bunkmates and a camp craft item.

title: IS BOXING DEAD BUT DOESN'T KNOW IT?
description: ONE does not mention rope in the house of a hangman or talk about the decline of boxing with fight managers. Consequently, we view the fight game the way one views the world from a train. To avoid dizziness, the eyes must be directed to that far horizon that moves only slightly - the future. Speculation as to what lies beyond that horizon is helpful in warding off a feeling of bewilderment.

title: LYNN DAVIDSON IS WED TO HOWARD SAFENOWITZ
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., last evening Lynn Meryl Davidson, an occupational therapist at the Shield Institute in Flushing, Queens, was married to Howard Bruce Safenowitz, an associate with the New York law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony.

title: Hypersexism And the Feds
description: I was greatly relieved to have William Safire settle once and for all the problem of gender in pronouns (''Hypersexism and the Feds,'' On Language, May 26). Knowing that he and his can be gender neutral, I shall no longer feel there is an odd image filtering through something like: ''The average American needs the small routines of getting ready for work.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Williamstown Theater Festival incorrectly characterized Laila Robins's career. She went from the Yale Drama School to acting at Williamstown and then appeared on Broadway in ''The Real Thing'' with Jeremy Irons and later with Nicol Williamson.

title: Fish Threatened By Lack of Rain
description: THE LACK of rain that has plagued much of the Northeast and caused New York City to restrict water consumption by industrial, commercial and private consumers is also threatening the well-being of cold-water fish, primarily trout, in the upper Delaware River, its East and West Branches and another of its tributaries, the Neversink.

title: Curtis to Retire
description: Isaac Curtis has told the Cincinnati Bengals' front office he plans to retire from pro football.

title: THE FIRST CONDOS
description: Battery Park City, until now the site only of rental apartment buildings and commercial structures, will soon have its first condominium high-rise.

title: AN 'ISLAND OF HOPE' FOR A NEW LIFE
description: EVEN on a warm spring day, the wind blows cold on Ellis Island, which is one-quarter natural and three-quarters landfill, the latter taken more than a century ago from the rubble of New York City's subway construction.

title: PLIGHT OF HOMELESS FEARED WORSENING AFTER BILL'S FAILURE
description: Almost 12,000 homeless people will have to remain in temporary shelters and hotels and 7,000 other New Yorkers will become homeless because of the State Legislature's failure to pass Governor Cuomo's housing plan, according to a report issued by the Partnership for the Homeless.

title: New Reductions In Medicare
description: Though the increase in health care costs has slowed, the drive to keep the cap on has not. Last week, the Reagan Administration announced more than $225 million in additional cuts in Medicare spending over the next three years.

title: Art and the Life Of India
description: One of the distinguishing features of most Indian art and music is that it is impersonal: one does not attach his name to his art.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Retailing Gloom As retailers prepare for their make-or-break second-half season, the best they can expect is for sales to match the somewhat dismal results of this year's first half, says Joseph H. Ellis, vice president of investment research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: EMIL THE ANTELOPE RETURNS
description: TO his left was one great home-run hitter, to his right was another great home-run hitter, and together the three of them had hit a career total of 1,034 major league home runs. Their lockers, simply by coincidence, had been placed in a row in the National League clubhouse for the recent Cracker Jack Old-Timers' Baseball Classic at R.F.K. Stadium in Washington.

title: ON LAKES, LIFE IS JUST A BREEZE
description: HERB and Mimi Horowitz of Dover are not sailors.

title: NEW YORK MARKING CENTENNIAL OF STATE PARK AT NIAGARA FALLS
description: The centennial observance of the creation of the first state park in New York, at Niagara Falls, has begun.

title:
DID REAGAN'S 1981 TAX INCENTIVES WORK?;

AFTER 1982, CAPITAL SPENDING SET RECORDS
description: IT has become fashionable in certain quarters to deny either that there has been a significant increase in capital investment under the Reagan Administration's tax policies or that current investment levels are significantly greater than those that prevailed earlier.

title: NEW MAN AT THE TOP IS CREATING A STIR AT L.I.A.
description: WHEN James L. Larocca, the former State Transportation Commissioner and Energy Commissioner, takes over the reins tomorrow of the Long Island Association, the Island's Chamber of Commerce, he will be seeking to turn the organization - often criticized as largely ineffectual - into the most influential group on the Island, with a strong presence in Albany and a voice in most important issues affecting Island life. The job won't be easy. In the last two years the L.I.A. has gone through a tumultuous reorganization that caused deep divisions in its ranks, pitted small businessmen against the giants of the Long Island corporate world and stirred other controversies.

title: DRESDEN SALUTES ITS NEW OPERA HOUSE WITH VINTAGE WORKS
description: As part of the celebrations surrounding the reopening of the Semper Opera in Dresden last February, the Japanese record company Denon, in conjunction with the East German state record company, recorded the opening night and the night after. As it happens, the resulting albums are not quite documents of the actual first two performances, and their musical quality is hardly up to the beauties of the opera house itself. Nonetheless, now that they have been released, to the international public, at least one is well worth hearing, and the sound - while not quite so epoch-making as Denon's publicity implies - is still pretty fine.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: OVERWHELMED by the powerful lobbying efforts of the State Chamber of Commerce, the New Jersey Food Council and other trade groups, the environmental movement sustained a major defeat in late June when the State Assembly turned down a measure that would have required the return of deposits on beverage cans and bottles.

title:
WHERE REGULATION HAS FAILED;

WARDING OFF AN ELECTRICITY SHORTAGE
description: THE electric utility industry, paralyzed by the traumas of the last decade, needs help to avert an electricity shortage in the early 1990's. What is needed, in the view of the industry as well as its regulators - who rarely agree on anything - is a Presidential commission that would bring both public attention to the growing problem and credibility to a plan to meet future electricity needs. Without the publicity that such a commission could generate, there is little hope that the industry and its regulators will emerge from their malaise before power shortages begin to appear.

title: DIRT-BIKE RACES TO BE HELD TODAY
description: WHEN it comes to backyard festivities on the Fourth of July weekend, few around the state can compare with the one scheduled today at the home of John and Marilyn Landon in Guilford.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

GAZEBO HALTED
description: In a perfect world, everything has its place. However, when it comes to the gazebo the New Castle Arts Council has proposed building for musical events and art exhibits, Lois Mitchell, the Town Supervisor, says, ''At this time, I wouldn't venture to guess where that place is.''

title: THE CAMARADERIE OF GOOD CITIZENSHIP
description: THE Central Jury Room in the Westchester County Courthouse, with its serried rows of seats, oddly upholstered in dark pink, and its golden oak stage from which officials can scan an audience with monitory glance, is reminiscent of a high school auditorium.

title: SOON-TO-BE RETIREE CONTEMPLATES THE FUTURE
description: I AM becoming a retiree, something I have never been before and hope to be for a very long time.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: TOWN CONCERTS It's summertime, and with the living so easy, it's B.Y.O.S. (or bring your own seating) time on Long Island, as this week two Nassau County towns open their free outdoor concert seasons. Hempstead does it tonight with a ''Musical Salute to Xavier Cugat,'' starring Andy Russell, Ada Cavallo and Gigi. This first of six weekly programs is at 8:15 P.M. at Newbridge Road Park in Bellmore. Subsequent segments, including the Summer Dance Festival on Aug. 4, will be distributed throughout the town parks.

title: China Frees Catholic Bishop
description: The man the Vatican knows as the Roman Catholic Bishop of Shanghai, the Rev. Ignatius Kung, was freed from prison last week after serving 30 years for refusing to recognize the legitimacy of the ''self-governing'' Chinese church. Whether Bishop Kung surrendered to demands that he sever his ties to Rome or the Government capitulated was a matter of conjecture.

title: FLIGHT 847: CAPTIVES DISCLOSE DETAILS OF TERROR
description: Jerome Barczak thought he was in luck.

title: LODES OF ART IN TEXAS
description: One of the most attractive aspects of a visit to Dallas and Fort Worth - the ''metroplex,'' as residents call it - is a tour of the art museums. They specialize in diverse areas, but three have notable holdings in Western Americana: the Sid Richardson Collection and the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth and the Dallas Museum of Art.

title: SEAT-BELT LAW: ALBANY REPORTS 4,822 TICKETED
description: The state police ticketed nearly 5,000 drivers and passengers for violating the state's seat-belt law in the first five months of this year, according to state officials.

title: WHY BLAME GREECE
description: Can I be alone in my exhaustion and irritation at the ''blame Greece first'' crowd? The Reagan Administration has gone in for a routine denigration of the Government of Andreas Papandreou -convincingly re-elected last month -and has made Greece a scapegoat for its own failures and weaknesses in foreign policy.

title: EYE EXAMS AND ROAD SAFETY
description: MANAGING a Stamford ophthalmology office for 11 years, I have seen my share of people who do not see very well. One of the things many of them have in common, besides poor vision, is that they drive themselves to their eye-doctor appointment. Perhaps some logical explanation is eluding me, but it seems to me that there is an inexplicable irony in driving to the eye doctor because you cannot see well enough to drive.

title: HOOT OWLS, FLATWORMS AND OTHER ENDEARING CREATURES
description: A cave drawing comes to life; the sun rises over Stonehenge. The backround music may be more suitable for ''Love Boat,'' but so what? A moment later, a portly man with pontoons on his feet is walking across a pond. Then a kayak hurtles through treacherous waters in Iceland; an undersea photographer rhapsodizes about taking pictures off the coast of Japan; a woman hoots back at an owl in Ontario. We have seen and heard things like this on television before, of course, but seldom in such profusion. The National Geographic has struck again, only this time at more length. Its ''Explorer,'' on the Nickelodeon cable service, runs three hours on Sundays, 5 to 8 P.M. It is the electronic version - a good one, too - of one of the world's most popular magazines.

title: LOUIS L'AMOUR'S HOMETOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK PEACH YIELD IS EXPECTED TO RISE 59%
description: With the opening of the fruit harvest season, the State Crop Reporting Service said this week that farmers in New York were growing more peaches but fewer tart and sweet cherries than last year.

title: JOSEPH M. ARMSTRONG
description: Joseph M. Armstrong, who was general counsel of New York City's Human Resources Administration from 1978 until last March, died Thursday at New York University Medical Center after a long illness. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEW FIGHT ON LYME DISEASE
description: RESEARCHERS at the State University of New York at Stony Brook are seeking new ways to detect and combat Lyme disease, a potentially chronic and debilitating illness transmitted by tick bites.

title: WITH PROPER CARE HOUSE PLANTS CAN SURVIVE ALONE
description: The plants that stay at home are the most difficult part of traveling for a gardener.

title: BLACK JAZZMEN MADE 30'S PARIS JUMP
description: For most Americans, jazz in the 1930's was represented by the swing bands - by Benny Goodman, Artie Shaw and Tommy Dorsey. It was a significant period for the growth of interest in jazz because these bands, which were essentially in the tradition of the dance bands that had developed in the 1920's with the addition of jazz coloration that has previously been associated with black bands, whetted an interest in jazz in many listeners who would otherwise never have been touched by it. It was, briefly, a period when the paths of jazz and pop music crossed.

title: Headliners;   The King's Last Bow
description: Yul Brynner gave an ''absolutely final'' performance on Broadway in ''The King and I'' last week. It was the 4,625th time he had played the King of Siam in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical since 1951 and presumably he could have gone on indefinitely.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MANNY & ROSE. By Joan K. Peters. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) ''Manny & Rose'' is a stirring first novel about the foundering relationship between a 73-year-old accountant named Manny and his radical daughter, Ellen, who confront each other after the death of his wife and her mother, the overpowering Rose.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN WESTON
description: RESIDENTS of Weston don't want anyone to know they are there.

title: WHEN A 3:58.6 MILE ADDED TO THE OLYMPIC FUND
description: A PROFIT of $215 million from the 1984 Summer Olympics is disclosed last month and the announcement draws a reaction slightly more rousing than a yawn.

title: Another View Of Nuclear Power
description: It is very easy and safe to predict what will happen 20 or more years from now. How can one refute such statements?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEN-GURION AND THE PALESTINIAN ARABS: From Peace to War. By Shabtai Teveth. (Oxford University, $17.95.) This sound, scholarly assessment of the aspirations and dashed hopes of David Ben-Gurion (1886-1973) concerning ''the Arab question'' adds important insights to the literature on the architect of modern Israel.

title: ANN ZACHARCHUK IS WED AT LEHIGH
description: Ann Elizabeth Zacharchuk and Roger Bryce Gorham, accountants who graduated last year from Lehigh University, were married yesterday at the Packard Memorial Church on the Lehigh campus in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Lyn Langkamer, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: CROISSANTS, COBBLERS AND FREE-MARKET FORCES
description: WHEN Mayor Koch formed a commission in May to study whether commercial rent controls should be imposed in New York City, many politicians predicted that serious consideration of the issue would be postponed at least until the commission reports to the Mayor next March - long after his re-election campaign will have ended. But the Mayor's action certainly has not squelched the debate. Retailers contend that huge rent increases are driving merchants out of business. They say that repair shops and many other small service businesses are being replaced by fast-food restaurants and ice-cream shops. Landlords deny that rising rents have forced many small businesses to close, and they contend that community services have not been curtailed. The groups renewed the debate two weeks ago at a City Council committee hearing. Several bills proposing forms of commercial rent regulation have been introduced in the Council and the State Legislature; their future is uncertain. Alan Finder, an editor of The Week in Review, asked three experts to discuss the implications of commercial controls. Excerpts follow.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We have reached a situation in which either we conquered inflation or inflation conquered us.''

title: Two Soviet Ministers Are Removed From Jobs
description: The Kremlin has replaced the Minister of Light Industry and the Minister of Ferrous Metallurgy, according to the official press agency Tass.

title: 14 JAIL GUARDS AND 12 INMATES INJURED IN FIGHT IN BROOKLYN
description: Fourteen city corrections officers and 12 inmates awaiting deportation to Cuba were injured yesterday during a disturbance at a Brooklyn jail, a Correction Department spokesman said.

title: Good Start for Wiggins
description: If his first game is an indication of things to come, Alan Wiggins and the Baltimore Orioles should have a happy and prosperous association. The second baseman, who was traded by the San Diego Padres 10 days ago after a return trip to a drug rehabilitation clinic, landed in the American League in a big way Friday night.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Fiction 1 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.50.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 2 '... AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Life in an Ohio hamlet, 1868-1932. 3 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $4.95.) One man's experience in the wars of the Holy Land. 4 LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A fictionalized accoaunt of the Civil War Presidency. 5 * DEEP SIX, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) One man copes with a sinister Asian shipping family and an even more threatening Soviet plot. 6 THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A wealthy Welsh family haunted by an ominous heritage. 7 THE WTICHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Fawcett, $4.50.) Three witches wreak havoc in a contemporary Rhode Island town. 8 THE MIRACLE, By Irving Wallace. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) Six strangers' lives are changed when they go to observe a miracle at Lourdes. 9 TENDER IS THE STORM, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A New York heiress's passionate encounter with an Arizona rancher. 10 * SWITCH, By William Bayer. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) The case of two women, murdered in Manhattan, whose heads are switched. 11 RAMBO: First Blood Part II, by David Morrell.

title: NEW UNITED STATES ISSUES ARE ANNOUNCED
description: The United States Postal Service has big plans for collectors in 1986. Next year's program, just announced by the Philatelic Sales Division, calls for a set of souvenir sheets for Ameripex '86, seven commemorative singles, three setenant blocks of four, three topical issues of undetermined format, a special stamp booklet, two Christmas stamps, one Love stamp, a 14-cent single for use on holiday postcards, four postal cards and seven Great Americans singles - a count of at least 70 stamps.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LA MERICA: Images of Italian Greenhorn Experience. By Michael La Sorte. (Temple University, $24.95.) On the morning of his departure a young emigrant named Carmine Iannace picked up his heavy suitcases and, accompanied by his father and other men from the village, walked slowly down the road toward the station to await the afternoon train for Naples, where he would later board a steamship bound for that magnetic land that the Italians called ''La Merica.'' Carmine Iannace's father, an impoverished farmer whose only asset was his family, had been devastated by his son's determination to leave; and even before reaching the train station the father abruptly turned around and, without a word or a handshake or a wave of goodbye, started back toward the village. The confused and saddened son, watching in tears, called out to his father. But the older man kept walking, and the only comment that followed came from one of the village men who explained: ''You are now an emigrant. From today forward you are completely on your own.'' What happened to Carmine Iannace in America at the turn of the century, together with the experiences of several other Italians who were sufficiently driven and desperate to break their village ties and their parents' hearts and to endure the abusive life at the bottom of the American pecking order, is the basis of this fine new book by Michael La Sorte. Although the author is a professor of sociology at the State University of New York, Brockport, this book is unburdened by academic language, excessive statistics and the distant view that many learned Italian-Americans take when writing about the humble life of their emigrating forebears.

title: The Moving Force At N.Y.U.
description: In his article on John Brademas, ''The Moving Force at N.Y.U.'' (June 2), J. Anthony Lukas points out the relative indigence of New York University, due, in part, to the lack of money contributed to the endowment by alumni.

title: AGUILERA CLINCHES PLACE IN ROTATION
description: One day later, Rick Aguilera said he felt a sense of finally belonging. It was only a complete game, but it was his first in the big leagues and it was smooth and quick and masterly. Like something a veteran might offer in a September pennant drive.

title: L.I. NEARS ACCORD ON TOXIC CLEANUP
description: The Purex Corporation has tentatively agreed with government officials to clean up a part of Mitchel Field that is considered one of the most chemically contaminated areas on Long Island.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Last week, at the end of a long day of interviews and travel, after an hour's ride in a press bus that gave no evidence of having shock absorbers, on a wet, dreary, chilly evening, I heard the Orchestra of St. Luke's play Beethoven at the Caramoor Festival. There was every inducement to be miserable, bored and homesick.

title: FOUR OCTAGONS
description: John Livanos owns six other restaurants that bear his name in Queens, Brooklyn and Nassau County, but none of them is like the one he opened recently in White Plains and calls his first Art Deco restaurant. It also is like nothing else in White Plains.

title: SUMMER SCHEDULE IS CHOCK-FULL
description: SUMMER is obviously no longer the off-season - not when you can find the Manhattan String Quartet and the New York Woodwind Quintet in chamber music performances, recitals for one, two and even four pianos, Spanish dance and African drum exhibitions, jazz concerts by the Artie Shaw Orchestra and Maynard Ferguson, all within a week.

title: BALLET TROUPES DISCUSS MERGER
description: THE expensive reality of running a ballet company hit home for the Connecticut Ballet last month, when it decided to suspend operations for the summer. Enrollment was off for its summer school in New Haven, and the troupe's directors did not want to enlarge its $100,000 deficit.

title:
ART;

WALL SCULPTURES BY ELLSWORTH KELLY ON EXHIBIT IN KATONAH
description: VISITORS to The Katonah Gallery will see, through Aug. 11, an exhibition by Ellsworth Kelly, a painter-sculptor with an international reputation. It consists of 11 painted aluminum wall sculptures or reliefs, one screenprint and one free-standing parabola of weathering steel that stands, 10 feet high, outdoors. All works date from 1974.

title: SALVADOR REBEL VOWS TO SPREAD WAR
description: The senior military commander of the Salvadoran rebel movement vowed today that the guerrillas would carry their attacks to the capital of San Salvador and spread the war to every part of the country. He said the new attacks would make El Salvador ungovernable within the next year.

title: A SUMMERTIME OASIS IN NORWALK
description: SIDEWALK cafes suggest a certain optimism that Connecticut's weather doesn't always reward. That may be why there are few such cafes visible around the state.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN PAPER CAN PROVE AN ASSET
description: AN EXHIBITION of handmade paper forms by Chris Craig of Hopewell is one of several reasons why a visit to the Newark Museum is worthwhile this summer.

title: SUFFOLK PONDERS WINDFALL FROM LILCO
description: THE FINANCIAL crisis confronting Suffolk County government ended abruptly when the Long Island Lighting Company recently paid $130.7 million in overdue taxes on the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Now county officials are trying to decide what to do with the county's share of the money, estimated at $92 million.

title: OEDIPUS IN VITRO AND OTHER SIGNS OF UTOPIA
description: IN ''The Redundant Male'' (Pantheon), Jeremy Cherfas and John Gribbin observe that if women chose to, they might get along without males as active fathers of their children. Men could be reduced to mere donors of sperm, which might be united with the egg in a petri dish, avoiding any physical contact between the parents. Even parthenogenesis - the female egg dividing and reproducing without sperm - appears to be a possibility in the near future.

title: SHOWCASE FOR CHINESE ANTIQUITIES
description: Since 1960, when Giuseppe Eskenazi opened his business in London, the taste in Chinese art has changed dramatically from what was then almost a total concentration on Ming and Ching ceramics to now include antiquities - Shang bronzes, Tang tomb figures, archaic jades and ancient precious art works. Mr. Eskenazi - one of the most important art dealers in the field - has gradually helped push back the historical parameters in this specialty by offering objects to museums and collectors that most people once considered too esoteric and unappealing.

title: MUSIC: 'GARDEN OF HARPS' AT THE MODERN MUSEUM
description: IT is hard to imagine a better fitting of event to environment than Friday evening's ''Garden of Harps'' in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art. Fifteen harpists, all in white, played music by four contemporary composers and were attended by a large nonpaying audience made up of city-bound New Yorkers and tourists who wandered in off the street.

title: IMPRISONMENT: BOREDOM AND HOPE IN A BATTLE ZONE
description: About 2 A.M. on June 17, 28 men were hustled off the plane and crowded into a sweltering windowless van that had been backed up to the plane's rear stairway.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FALL & RISE. By Stephen Dixon. (North Point, $17.75.) Like an old Woody Allen routine, Stephen Dixon's third novel is full of personal anxieties and social pratfalls.

title: RITA MARKS, ARCHITECT, TO WED IN SEPTEMBER
description: The engagement of Rita Nan Marks to Lawrence Jerome Lubitz has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Marks of Guilford, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lubitz of Jericho, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: ELDONOMICS CONQUERS ALL
description: HARD MONEY By Michael M. Thomas. 451 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $17.95. THIS is Michael Thomas's third novel. His first, ''Green Monday,'' was about the Arabs and Wall Street and was a mild commercial success. The second, ''Someone Else's Money,'' was set in the art world, and did less well. His latest, ''Hard Money,'' is a particularly topical book about a takeover in the broadcasting industry and is being heavily promoted.

title: LOVE WITH THE PROPER CHAUFFEUR
description: MAINLAND By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. 285 pp. New York:

title: PRINCETON IS HOST TO BRITISH CHOIRSTERS
description: The Trinity College Choir of England's Cambridge University is currently on its first American tour and will make its New Jersey debut tomorrow night with a concert of sacred music in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: ANTISMOKING EFFORT TO FOCUS ON NEW HAVEN
description: WHEN Janet Stearns began attending local government meetings, she often found herself switching seats ''so I wouldn't have smoke blown in my face.''

title: 'FAMILY FARM' ON WATER: A TEST IN RAISING OYSTERS
description: WITH only his wind-chafed hands as tools, and riding a simple wooden raft above the even rows of submerged wire trays, Carey Matthiessen begins his day as an oyster farmer on Fishers Island.

title: CORRECTION
description: The June 16 article about Miles Davis in this magazine misspelled the name of the jazz cornetist Olu Dara.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Bargains and Raffles And Other Surprises The Eleventh Annual Scotts Corners Sidewalk Sale will be held Saturday beginning at 10 A. M., rain or shine, with special promotions and summer clearances. Beginning at 9 A.M. free raffle tickets will be available in shops and offices and participants must fill them out and place them in boxes at the announcer's stand, or at the shopping center, to be eligible for the hourly drawings until 1 P.M.

title: RANDI MAHLER BETROTHED TO MARK ELLIOT SCHLANGER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Mahler of Willow Brook, S.I., and Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Allyne Mahler, to Mark Elliot Schlanger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Allen Schlanger of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: SOUPS FOR SUMMER
description: THE PASSING SEASONS NEED NOT DICTATE menus. We can dine on cold salads in midwinter, provided they are competently made, and we can feast pleasurably on a bowl of chili con carne in midsummer, provided it is created by a conscientious cook.

title: POLIO'S PAINFUL LEGACY
description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1955, when he was 6 years old, Gary West was struck with polio, which left him paralyzed from the neck down. Through painful rehabilitation, he regained the use of his left arm and both legs, and in high school in Houston he made the all-state tennis team and won awards for playing trumpet in an all-state band.

title: MORE THAN LAW BOOKS AND WIGS
description: ''Considering it's a place where such sad and terrible things occur,'' my learned friend Mr. Horace Rumpole often says, ''it's extraordinary that the Old Bailey is such a cheerful place.'' It is true that the court attendants, the lawyers, the warders, even the old offenders on trial, are often full of jokes. Perhaps it's the only way they can keep entirely sane; when life becomes sufficiently appalling there is really nothing anyone can do except make jokes about it.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta, doubleheader (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M., first game only, WTBS, 1:05 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Bicycling Tour de France. The three-week race covering 2,519 miles concludes next Sunday. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. to 6 P.M. Boxing Julio Cesar Chavez, champion, vs. Roger Mayweather, 12 rounds for the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title at Riviera Hotel Las Vegas, Nev. This is the second title defense for Chavez (46-0, 39 knockouts) since he won the title from Mario Martinez last September. Mayweather is 21-2 with 14 knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Equestrian I Love New York Grand Prix, at Lake Placid, N.Y., 8 A.M., for hunters, jumpers and equitation. Football Stallions vs. Baltimore Stars, at Birmingham, Ala., semifinal of the United States Football League playoffs. (Television - 2:30 P.M., Channel 7) Golf Canadian Open, at Oakville, Ontario, final round (Television - ESPN 3 P.M.) Ladies' Professional Golf Association Mazda Hall of Fame Championships, at Sugar Land, Tex., final round. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.) PGA Seniors Greenbrier Classic, at White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, final round. Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon, men's singles final. (Television - Channel 4, 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. live.) Volvo Hall of Fame Championships, at Newport R.I. 9 A.M. Qualifying rounds. Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1 P.M. The $125,000-added Dwyer for 3- year-olds at a mile and an eighth is the feature.

title: PARK-FIRE LAWYER A TV ANALYST, TOO
description: ON SOME days, the Great Adventure trial here adjourns a little earlier than usual so that one of the lawyers can catch a helicopter to New York City for television appearances.

title: FRANCES MIDDENDORF TO WED
description: J. William Middendorf, United States representative at the Organization of American States in Washington, and Mrs. Middendorf of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Frances Paine Middendorf to Robert Otis Read 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Read Jr. of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24.

title: VIETNAMESE SPICE IN BRENTWOOD
description: THE Anh-Hong Vietnamese Kitchen in Brentwood may be the only Vietnamese restaurant on Long Island. There was one in Patchogue that closed a few years ago.

title: 'Rapping' the Visitors On Cape Cod Radio
description: A two-minute song spoofing annual summer visitors is moving up the Cape Cod hit parade.

title: Is Gromyko Really Out?
description: The announcement that Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko had been named President of the U.S.S.R., a few days before his 76th birthday, came as a surprise to official Washington. He had been around the Soviet Foreign Office for so long that few people around here could imagine his leaving that center of power for a ceremonial job. And maybe he hasn't.

title: But Let Insurance Companies Get Into the Banking Business
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS BETS ON BONDS AGAIN
description: LIKE a cat waiting to pounce, the Scott Paper Company filed a registration statement for a $200 million debt offering in late March and kept its eye on the direction of interest rates. The steady slide in April and May was tempting, but not until early June, when long-term bond rates neared 11 percent, did Scott make its move.

title: JUDGE'S SPOUSE CANNOT WORK IN CAINO, JERSEY COURT HOLDS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled that people married to judges may not work for a casino.

title: MEDICAID TESTS A CHILDREN'S PROGRAM
description: A CENTRAL ISLIP mother, assured that her three young children will receive medical care even though she herself is no longer eligible for Medicaid benefits, says she can now afford to work at a temporary job that does not provide health insurance until she is able to find permanent employment.

title: MEASURES SOUGHT TO REDUCE STRAY DOGS
description: DOG wardens and canine control officers throughout the state are calling for measures to reduce the number of stray dogs, many of which cause accidents, dog bites, damage to livestock, lawns and gardens, and are a general nuisance.

title: HILARY C. DOWNE PLANS TO WED IN SEPTEMBER
description: Hilary Campbell Downe, a daughter of Susan Campbell Downe and Edward R. Downe Jr. of New York, and Richard Carey Hayes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hayes of Battlecrease Hall, Shepperton, England, plan to be married Sept. 7. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: LISA OGREN WEDS WILLIAM GADSDEN
description: Lisa Emily Ogren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Theodore Ogren of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Fuller Gadsden, a son of Mrs. Henry W. Gadsden of Gladwyne, Pa., and Mountain Lake, Fla., and the late Mr. Gadsden. The Rev. David S. Marshall, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Grace Church.

title: TRANSITION NOT EASY FOR JERSEY CITY MAYOR
description: THE transition of power here last week was anything but amiable and orderly. Former Councilman Anthony R. Cucci, who defeated Mayor Gerald McCann by 7,000 votes on June 11, took the oath of office on Monday, but instead of waiting for the appointed hour of noon, he slipped into City Hall around midnight to be sworn in and to pick up the reins at the earliest possible moment.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN YOU WANT TO CANCEL YOUR TOUR
description: In the wake of the international flight tragedies of recent weeks, questions arise about the rights of travelers to change their minds once they have committed themselves to trips far from home. As Maria Theofanous, president of Guaranteed Travel/Greece Your Way Tours of Morris Plains, N.J., put it in a telephone interview: ''Obviously the state of the world is a serious consideration for anyone traveling abroad.''

title: SARAH M. LARKIN PLANNING TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Larkin Jr., of Middlebury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Meigs Larkin to Peter Ashforth Harvey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Harvey Jr. of Stonington, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;

A PROPER START FOR YOUNG TREES
description: PLANTING a tree is an investment in the future. With the exception of small trees planted primarily for their flowering effect, most trees require two or three human generations to mature and provide the effect, whether it be shade or landscaping, for which they were planted.

title: Half Freedom
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon was out of prison last week because of good behavior after serving 11 months of an 18-month term for tax evasion. But he is not completely free.

title: WIRING MADE SIMPLE OUTSIDE THE WALL
description: WHEN additional wall switches or electrical outlets are needed for appliances, lighting fixtures or ceiling fans, the usual procedure is to run wires or cables through the hollow wall spaces, then cut openings in the walls to accommodate the new outlets or switches.

title: WEAK START, STRONG FINISH
description: She had to wait four weeks for the opportunity to get even, to put her tennis world back on its proper axis. Martina Navratilova lost her No. 1 ranking to Chris Evert Lloyd in the meantime and had to go Dutch treat at Wimbledon, sharing the No. 1 seeding. She felt the balance of power shifting again and if it continued, she stood to lose the championship she treasured the most.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: The rewards of watching prominent films like ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner'' and ''Exodus'' - both due this week - are obvious. But don't underestimate those lesser-known movies.

title: PLAN TO WIDEN BRIDGE SPLITS TOWN
description: THE MEETING was public and impromptu, and John Daley, one of this town's 1,000 residents, and Larry Lewis, who lives in nearby Lebanon Township, were standing outside Keefe's Corner Luncheon, between Rambo's Country Store and a stream-like branch of the Raritan River, holding forth on plans to widen the Califon Bridge.

title: ANN HERKNESS ENGAGED
description: Ann Morris Herkness, retail merchandise manager of Bride's magazine, and Anthony Gambrill Villa, a member of the international corporate finance department at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, plan to be married in October. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Evans Herkness of Rydal, Pa., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lippincott Villa of Peapack, N.J.

title: PARTNERS IN ARTS
description: A community arts project involving the Westchester Council on the Arts and Pepsico Inc. is one of six programs in the state chosen as national models to encourage other arts councils and businesses to create similar projects. The six were chosen by the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils and President Reagan's Committee on the Arts and Humanities.

title: Nemesis of Nemesis
description: No one has yet figured out the longstanding mystery of who murdered the dinosaurs, but the plot recently thickened when a new batch of suspects was added to the usual list. They were various extraterrestrial mechanisms, headed by a mysterious death-star named Nemesis, which supposedly dispatches squads of meteorites to crash into Earth at regular intervals of 26 million years. Disappointingly, Nemesis and fellow colorful characters have now virtually been ruled out of existence by new evidence published in Nature magazine.

title: AT LYNCHBURG, 'DREAMS DIE HARD'
description: A COOL rain fell across the Blue Ridge Mountains, temporarily banishing summer from this quiet city of 67,000, which is best known as the home of the Rev. Jerry Falwell of the Moral Majority and his Liberty Baptist College.

title: AID TO FARMERS SAID TO SURPASS BANK FORECASTS
description: After a winter of worry over debt burdens and threatened bankruptcies, there are several indications that more farmers than expected have obtained the credit they needed to continue farming for another year.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: DAVENPORT HOUSE IS CENTERPIECE FOR A 'FAMILY REUNION'
description: THE star of Louis and Charlotte Ferguson's recent garden party was the house where the party was held -the Davenport house, the oldest one in New Rochelle, dating back to 1708 and possibly as early as 1696. Owned by only three families in its first two centuries, the house was the ancestral home of five of the guests at the party.

title: OIL TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentuckian Held on Charges In Hatchet Attack on Family
description: Bobby Chester Brown, 34 years old, was charged with two counts of murder today in in the deaths Friday of his father, John Alexander Brown Sr., 52, and his brother Ura Brown, 20, who were assaulted with a hatchet in their home in Valley Station, near Louisville.

title: MOURNING THE LOSS OF ICE CREAM, NACHOS AND QUICHE
description: ''ABSENCE makes the heart grow fonder.'' Or so they say. I never had much faith in that old bromide.

title: STEERING CLEAR OF 'ABUSIVE' TAX SHELTERS
description: TAX shelter promoters are pushing their offerings hard this year, calling 1985 a ''window of opportunity'' to get tax breaks while they are still available, or to defer taxes until tax revision establishes lower brackets for all.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ ON STATEN ISLAND Maynard Ferguson - the jazz trumpeter who received a Grammy nomination for his version of ''Gonna Fly Now,'' the theme of the movie ''Rocky'' - will perform at an outdoor concert Friday evening on Staten Island.

title: AN ISLAND OF NEIGHBORS, BUT NO ONE IS NEIGHBORLY
description: AN open letter to Claire Nicolas White, who wrote ''In Fear of the Folks Next Door'' [Opinion Page] :

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Are the Powerful Lovable?

title: RAY OF HOPE FOR CANCER PATIENTS
description: ON A television talk show several years ago, five cancer survivors spoke about their experiences as patients at New York's Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. It was a good program that helped dispel many misconceptions about cancer, notably those concerning chemotherapy and curability.

title: SUSAN GOWDIE IS WED TO THOMAS A. DANZIG
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I., yesterday Susan Marie Gowdie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Gowdie of Huntington, was married to Thomas Allison Danzig, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allison C. Danzig of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. Peter L. Duvelsdorf performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE TUITION OUTPACES INFLATION, U.S. SAYS
description: Education at public colleges and universities cost an average of $4,522 a student in the 1984-85 school year, 11.1 percent higher than last year, with tuition expenses rising faster than the inflation rate, the Department of Education has reported.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EXPERIMENTAL CONCERTS Thornton-Donovan, the 85-five-year old private school in New Rochelle that was the inspiration for former student Robert Anderson's play ''Tea and Sympathy,'' inaugurates a summer concert series at 4 P.M. today. On the lawn at 100 Overlook Circle, the Masterwork Chamber Ensemble will perform music of Beethoven, Mozart, Haydn, Scott Joplin and Cole Porter. Three additional concerts scheduled on the remaining Sundays in July feature, in sequence, the Eastchester Town Hall Players, the Soundview Brass Quintet and the Stephen Roane Quartet.

title: FOUNDING FARMER
description: 'THOMAS JEFFERSON stil survives,' John Adams said, as he expired, dramatically, on the 50th anniversary of the Declaration, in fact, died on that same Fourth of July, he does indeed survive, as Merrill D. Peterson's selections from Jefferson's writings testify. It was courageous of the editors of the Library of America to try to give us Jefferson in one volume. They have managed to make available the largest and most skillfully edited single-volume Jefferson ever published, one that contains almost three times the documents and letters in the 'Portable Thomas Jefferson' Mr. Peterson gave us a decade ago. This useful collection contains Jefferson's autobiography, public papers, messages to Congress and addresses as well as innumerable letters - 785 pages of them. Taken togehter, these works are a remarkable demonstration of why - after more than century and a half - Jefferson still lives.

title: BARRISTERS ON THEIR OWN GROUND
description: English lawyers are a conservative lot on the whole, even the liberal ones.

title: SWEEP FOR MOM'S COMMAND
description: The time was painfully slow and the competition was dismal, but Mom's Command became the sixth winner of the New York filly triple crown yesterday by winning the $237,600 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park.

title: SOUTH ORANGE IS DIVERSIFYING ITS HOUSING
description: MATURE suburbs like South Orange have loads of charm and block after block of big, beautiful houses. This is fine for large families looking for a place to live, but it severely restricts singles, first-time buyers and older homeowners who no longer need a third, fourth or fifth bedroom.

title: Woman Trying to Ride An Elephant Is Killed
description: A 47-year-old New London woman was killed early this morning when she was thrown and trampled by a circus elephant she tried to ride in the parking lot of the New London Mall, the police said.

title: MISS BOOZIOTIS WED TO DANA YOUNGER
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Evalina Booziotis and Dana Reed Younger took place yesterday in Sorrento, Me., where the bridegroom's family maintains a summer residence. The Rev. George E. Todd, a Presbyterian minister, performed the interfaith ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: THE TRIBAL SIDE OF MIDEAST TERRORISM
description: To avoid falling victim to furthur Syrian blackmail of the kind witnessed in the last few weeks, Western leaders would do well to consider the tribal character of the Shiite terror that Syria manipulates.

title: Agents Get Together
description: Player agents are often as antagonistic toward each other as linemen after the snap, but a sharp slash in the money being offered their clients by National Football League teams has unified them for the time being. Agents for most of the N.F.L.'s 28 first-round choices will gather in Chicago tomorrow in a session that will attempt to counter what agents say is a cutback to 1982 salary levels by teams no longer threatened by rival bidding from the United States Football League.

title: HINAULT ANSWERS DOUBTERS
description: If there were still doubts that Bernard Hinault had regained top form as a bicyclist, they were put to rest today when he easily won a long time trial in the Tour de France, regaining the yellow jersey as the overall leader.

title: A COMPOSER WHO DEFIES CATEGORIZATION
description: On a Sunday afternoon last May, Gerard Schwarz conducted the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in the first New York performance of David Diamond's Suite No. 1. The work was culled from a two-and-a-half-hour score for a ballet, ''Tom,'' with a scenario by E. E. Cummings which Mr. Diamond composed almost 50 years ago. After acknowledging the warm response from the audience, Mr. Diamond leaned toward a friend and whispered, ''Not bad for a 20-year-old.''

title: FOOD CRISIS SAID TO END IN 8 AFRICAN COUNTRIES
description: A United Nations agency dealing with Africa's famine said Friday that the crisis was over in 8 of the 21 nations that faced exceptional food supply problems in 1984-85. But it said the emergency remained acute in five countries.

title: Fashion;   SUMMER CLOTHES NOW
description: BUYING SUMMER clothes in summer can be easier said than done. Indeed, stores often seem to have more wool pants in midsummer than cotton shorts.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TRAVEL ADVISORY: POLYNESIAN EXPEDITIONS, CARIBBEAN CRUISES
description: Pacific Journey For Vacationers With a Purpose A simple life of fishing and relaxing on a Pacific island is the fantasy of many people who live and work in the metropolises of North America. In August and again in January a 25-day tour to remote villages of the Cook Islands, Fiji and Samoa, is being offered to travelers who would like to stay in traditional homes and participate in fishing, food preparation, games, dances and rituals.

title: STATE TAX FIGHT WITH GLOBAL IMPLICATIONS
description: You can hardly walk down a corridor of California's Capitol these days without bumping into a lobbyist from Japan, often with a campaign contribution in his pocket destined for a state legislator. The British are here too, spreading the news that 212 years after the Boston Tea Party the House of Commons is denouncing California for practicing taxation without representation. Arriving later this month are the Canadians, the West Germans and the Dutch.

title: Elite Powerboaters to Race Off Jersey
description: A pair of binoculars and a beach umbrella may prove to be the winning ticket next week for anyone interested in watching the elite among United States powerboat drivers compete in one of seven circuit races that count for the national offshore title.

title: CAPITALISM'S STING
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

A YOUNG RESTAURANT IN ROCKLAND
description: ONE of the great pleasures of dining out is the discovery of good food in unexpected places. Thus we were surprised and pleased to find, in the middle of the flats between Orangeburg and Pearl River in Rockland County, Images, a mauve and mirrored jewel box of a restaurant at the foot of a sleek tower.

title: GONZALEZ REALIGNS HIS FORCES IN BATTLE OVER THE ECONOMY
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, after nearly three years in office, remains extraordinarily popular despite Spain's depressed economy. But the problems have begun to take their toll. Last week, Mr. Gonzalez gave his squabbling Cabinet a radical shakeup, replacing six of 15 ministers, including the most powerful one, Miguel Boyer, Minister of the Economy.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE CONTESTS
description: DIAMONDS. One-hundred-inch fur coats. A day with Ted Turner. Barry Manilow's white baby grand piano. Trips to anywhere and everywhere. A chunk of cold cash.

title: DODGERS BEAT CARDINALS, 8-3
description: Ken Landreaux hit two home runs, including the Dodgers' first inside-the-park home run in six years, and Pedro Guerrero also homered, doubled and singled today to power Los Angeles over the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-3.

title:
GARDENING;

A PROPER START FOR YOUNG TREES
description: PLANTING a tree is an investment in the future. With the exception of small trees planted primarily for their flowering effect, most trees require two or three human generations to mature and provide the effect, whether it be shade or landscaping, for which they were planted.

title: Aide in Western India Resigns After Clashes
description: The Chief Minister of the west Indian state of Gujurat resigned today after failing to curb four months of violence, and the state's Interior Minister was chosen to replace him.

title: MARY A. MIKULICH BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass., yesterday Mary Ann Mikulich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mikulich of Sherman, Conn., was married to Bertrand Mark Patenaude, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand A. Patenaude of Somerset, Mass. The Rev. David Hare performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: A Way to Avoid Summer Brownouts
description: I read with interest the article ''Will There Be Brownouts This Summer?'' Lilco on the one hand is claiming inadequate capacity to meet summer peaks. Lilco critics on the other hand suspect that the utility is playing politics to pressure regulators into approving Shoreham.

title: Mixed Reviews for TV in Hostage Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: LUSH NORTHEASTERN FORESTS ARE AT 150-YEAR PEAK
description: As Northeasterners head for the region's forests on these early summer weekends, the trees may seem a lot bigger and the woods deeper, thicker and more darkly primeval than they did only a few years ago.

title: MISS MARTIN WED IN LEESBURG, VA.
description: The marriage of Angenette Carroll Martin, the daughter of Angenette Vail Martin of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Erle Martin, to Eugene Eidenberg, a son of Nathan Eidenberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Eve Rosenbaum, took place yesterday. Judge John Ryan of the Loudoun County (Va.)

title: FOR SUMMER, TIES TAKE A BRIGHTER TURN
description: MORE than 100 million of them are sold annually and they are, according to the designer John Weitz, ''the only free form of personal expression a man has, except for cologne.'' They, of course, are neckties, and the favorite expression of the moment, according to informal on-the-street surveys, is red running neck-and-neck with yellow.

title: IS SOME PROTECTION BETTER THAN NONE?
description: HOW TO MAKE NUCLEAR WEAPONS OBSOLETE By Robert Jastrow. Illustrated. 175 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95.

title: Checkpoint Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: Rain Halts Yankee Game
description: After the Yankees fell behind the Minnesota Twins, 6-2, in the first two innings last night at the Stadium, their game was rained out. It will be made up today as part of a doubleheader, beginning at 2 P.M.

title: The Perry Case: Brother Indicted On 3 Counts
description: Last month, when a white New York City police officer shot and killed Edmund Perry, a black 17-year-old, police officials said that a second person had joined Mr. Perry in attacking the officer. Last week, the police arrested a youth who they said had participated in the assault: Mr. Perry's brother, Jonah, a 19-year-old sophomore at Cornell University.

title: ARTS COUNCIL SHOULD ENCOURAGE STATE'S PLALYWRIGHTS
description: IN 1980, I received a literary fellowship from the State Council on the Arts to allow me to complete revisions on my three-act play. That play, ''The Scrapbook,'' was produced by Atlantic Community College in Mays Landing during its 1983 Playwrights Weekend.

title: COORUPTION, CRUELTY, CAMBODIA
description: A WILDERNESS CALLED PEACE By Edmund Keeley. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: DAVID SIEGEL, A CONSULTANT, IS MARRIED TO MONA BACHE
description: Mona Sharon Bache, a daughter of Theodore S. Bache of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Charles Siegel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Siegel of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Stephen S. Pearce officiated at the Hotel Stamford Plaza.

title: Poverty on Farms
description: HUNDREDS of farmers in Iowa marched in December to state welfare offices and lined up for food stamps to show that the farm crisis was so bad some farmers could no longer afford to feed their families.

title: KITTY KEAN TO MARRY DAVID CZARNECKI
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Morris Riley Eddy 2d of Chicago and Hobe Sound, Fla., and John Kean of Bedminster, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Katharine Jessup Kean to David William Czarnecki, the son of Mrs. William J. Czarnecki and the late Mr. Czarnecki of Wilmington, Del. The wedding is planned for Sept. 7.

title: TO PRINT OR NOT TO PRINT: TELEVISION WILL TELL
description: THERE are innumerable color and black-and-white negatives stacked away in closets, darkrooms and basements throughout the country. Few of these negatives will ever get back to the processing lab for printing, but now a new device will make it possible for them to be viewed easily as a positive image on the family television set.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

STATUE OF LIBERTY COINS AUTHORIZED
description: Three new United States coins honoring the Statue of Liberty will be issued early next year in time for the statue's centennial celebration. This was assured late last month when Congress authorized the coins after months of behind-the-scenes maneuvering.

title: Woman Wins Tenured Spot At Harvard's Divinity School
description: The Harvard Divinity School has awarded tenure to a woman for the first time in its 169-year history.

title: About Men;   Fitting In
description: NOT QUITE two miles and 30 years from the church where these thoughts came to me, is a small, graveled parking lot cut out of the New Jersey pines, behind a restaurant and a dance hall. On road signs, the town is called Cassville. But to the several generations of Russian-Americans whose center of gravity tipped to the Old World, it was known as Roova Farms. I think the acronym stands for Russian Orthodox Outing and Vacation Association. In the summers, the place might as well have been on the Black Sea.

title: VICTORIA'S PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVING HARTZ MOUNTAIN INTO MEDIA
description: WHY would a 47-year-old entrepreneur, after amassing a personal fortune of more than $500 million by cornering the pet supplies market and engineering the development of once-desolate Northern New Jersey swamps, direct his energy to publishing an advocacy newspaper that loves to make mincemeat of people like him?

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM STRAVINSKY TO DR. SEUSS
description: Stravinsky's 'Rake's Progress' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Felicity Lott, Leo Goeke, Samuel Ramey and Rosalind Elias, with Bernard Haitink conducting the London Philharmonic Orchestra; 1977 Video Arts International 144 minutes. $79.95 Igor Stravinsky's last and most ambitious opera, ''The Rake's Progress,'' a collaboration with W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman, has always been controversial.

title: BUSY WAITING FOR THE ELVES
description: NOTHING was getting done, I complained to whoever had the misfortune to ask how my summer was going. Despite my nightly wishes, the tidy, helpful elves who had done the shoemaker's work while he slept never made it to my house.

title: Innocence Abroad
description: To the Editor: Referring to Irvin Molotsky's article on being victimized by pickpockets (Travel, June 16) on the Metro, I offer a simple system that has served me well in travels around the world.

title: A Sale, But at What Price?
description: Susan Seidman's recent article, ''Revelations of Selling Without a Broker'' [Opinion Page] , is both amusing and revealing from the standpoint of a real-estate salesperson such as myself.

title: LOOKING FOR THE CATHOLIC VOTE IN POLAND
description: The stakes in the three-cornered struggle involving the Polish state, the Roman Catholic Church and supporters of the outlawed Solidarity union have risen dramatically. A showdown is expected Oct. 13, when elections to Parliament are to be held.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Paperback Best Seller list in today's Book Review misidentifies the compiler of ''The Great Thoughts.'' He is George Seldes.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: READINGS IN WATERFORD An old man awakes to find a teen-ager in his house. The boy is fleeing a gang, which threatens to kill the man and his wife unless they turn him over. What choice is there? The teen-ager leaves and is murdered. Editorials assail the man's ''savage indifference.''

title: Ballesteros Leads by 7 In the French Open
description: Severiano Ballesteros built a commanding seven-shot lead today after three rounds in the $100,000 French Open Golf Tournament.

title: An Unusual Display
description: Probably only one place in Washington displays a genuine huipil, as well as a tzut and a smadeh. No, it's not the Smithsonian but the Textile Museum, well away from the usual tourist lanes but still one of the city's prouder and more elegant institutions.

title: The Moving Force At N.Y.U.
description: In his account of John Brademas's rare encounter with student activism, J. Anthony Lukas leaves the impression of a negative and confrontational chance meeting between Mr. Brademas and the ''black student'' who was representing Students Against Policies of Apartheid: ''As Brademas leaves the ceremony, a black student intercepts him and says, 'I'm with Students Against Policies of Apartheid. We wrote you a letter.'

title: ON THE PLANE: SCREAMS, SHOTS AND DEATH
description: Two wild-eyed hijackers barrelled up the aisle of the Boeing 727 within 20 minutes after its takeoff from Athens. One carried a hand grenade with its pin pulled and the other a 9-millimeter pearl-handled automatic pistol. They burst through a locked door on the cockpit where John L. Testrake, the pilot, Mr. Zimmermann, the flight engineer, and Mr. Maresca, the first officer, were calmly going about their business.

title: PEGGY CATRON MARRIES JEROME PREMO
description: The marriage of Peggy Catron, director of equipment and service contracts for the New York City Transit Authority, to Jerome C. Premo, executive director of the New Jersey Transit Corporation, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Faith in Santa Fe, N.M. The Rev. Jacquelin M. Washington performed the ceremony, The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Benton Catron 3d of Santa Fe, graduated magna cum laude from the University of California at Santa Barbara and received a master's degree in public administration from the American University. Her father is the senior partner in the Santa Fe law firm of Catron, Catron & Sawtell and former chairman of the Santa Fe Opera.

title: A Taxing Relationship
description: WHAT I HAVE missed most since moving from New York last month is the company of Mr. Deauville, our Federal tax auditor. It is hard to believe he occupied our lives for a mere six months. I tried to tell him of our affection on the day the movers were taking our furniture away.

title: A RARE TALK WITH NELSON MANDELA
description: WHEN I TRAVELED TO SOUTH AFRICA last January to speak at a conference on the sentencing of criminal offenders, I hardly expected to become the first American permitted to visit and interview Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress. I made it clear in my speech that I consider South Africa's apartheid system to be an unacceptable basis for criminal punishment, and I was aware that the South African Government had rejected a request by the visiting Senator Edward M. Kennedy to see Mandela only days before.

title: CRAXY NIGHTS AND DAYS IN NEELY
description: A SHORT HISTORY OF A SMALL PLACE By T. R. Pearson. 381 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95. THE subjects of this beautiful first novel are Momma and Daddy and madness, and they reside - or ''endure,'' the tone being somewhat Faulkneresque - in a town that many readers would find dreadfully boring but which T. R. Pearson brings movingly to life. Poor children decorate themselves with Cheez Whiz and peanut butter; rich kids grow up a little bit crazy; and adults (oh the adults who cause trouble in these pages) preoccupy themselves with gossip and trivia and monkeys that are not quite toilet trained.

title: EGYPT TRIES TO CURB FUNDAMENTALISTS
description: The Egyptian Government, in a distinct shift of policy, has started a campaign to stem the growth of Islamic fundamentalist forces here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TESTAMENT TO THE BUSHMEN. By Laurens van der Post and Jane Taylor. (Viking, $20.) In ''Testament to the Bushmen,'' published in conjunction with a BBC television series, Jane Taylor, a journalist and photographer, outlines the traditional life of the Bushmen, or San hunter-gatherers of Africa's Kalahari Desert, and recent changes in their culture.

title: Drought Worse Despite Rain
description: Drought conditions worsened in the Delaware River Basin despite above-normal rainfall in some areas in June, the Department of Environmental Resources said Wednesday. ''Frequent rains will be needed in the coming weeks,'' said Secretary Nicholas DeBenedictis. Most June rainfall was in the first 20 days of the month and the lower area of the basin suffered below-average precipitation levels.

title: CULTIVATING THE PLEASURES OF GARDENING
description: I was brought up thinking that gardening was women's work - well, not so much work, as concern. It was my mother who fussed about raising and arranging flowers, freeing the lawn of crab grass, pruning and planting shrubbery. True, my father did throw a few vegetable seeds into the ground every spring, but then he quite sensibly let God decide whether and how they'd grow while he played golf. But mother believed in helping God along and even more firmly in having me help her. As a result, gardening became for me a boring and unwelcomed intrusion on the time I'd otherwise be able to spend playing tennis, sailing or just goofing off.

title: MOTIVE IS SOUGHT IN STREET SLAYING
description: The police said yesterday that they had ruled out robbery as a motive for the shooting death of a Greek businessman at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 97th Street Friday afternoon. They declined, however, to speculate further on a motive.

title: INVADERS OUST SHOWBOATS TO GAIN FINAL
description: Anthony Carter and Bobby Hebert provided the show as the Oakland Invaders defeated the Memphis Showboats, 28-19, in a United States Football League semifinal playoff game today.

title: PRAYERS OF THANKS, DREAMS OF VENGEANCE
description: ''GO HOME,'' President Reagan finally told the freed hostages on American soil. And they did, pausing long enough in their last moments of group celebrity to express patriotic words of thanks, farewell and vengeance.

title:
NATURE WATCH;

BUMBLEBEE
description: Bombus sp.

title: Henry Sets Jump Mark
description: Sonya Henry became the first female high school long jumper in New York State to go over the 20-foot mark today. Miss Henry, who completed her freshman year at Freeport (L.I.) High School last month, did 20 feet 1 inch on her final attempt to win the girls intermediate long jump at the The Athletics Congress National Youth Track and Field Championships at Mitchel Park here.

title: FOR EVELYN ASHFORD, NEW IMAGE AND NEW HORIZONS
description: EVELYN ASHFORD can barely catch a nap these days. Not so for Raina Ashley Washington, Miss Ashford's newborn daughter, who was snoozing comfortably in her mom's arms recently in the bustling lobby of a Los Angeles hotel as the two took a break from what had been a normally hectic day.

title: SUSAN GALBRAITH WED TO FRANK M. JOHNSON
description: The marriage of Susan Howes Galbraith, a senior financial specialist with the Continental Insurance Company in New York, to Frank Morse Johnson, an assistant secretary of the Mutual of New York Reinsurance Corporation, took place yesterday in Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Donald D. Marsden Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew White Galbraith, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Johnson of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: COULD THE NAVY KEEP 600 SHIPS AFLOAT?A CORRECTION
description: As the defense-budget debate has demonstrated, Congress is by no means ready to scuttle the Navy's ambitious ship-building plans. But an increasing number of questions are being raised around Capitol Hill and elsewhere about the long-range effects of the service's expansion plans.

title: G.M. ENTERS MINIVAN FIELD
description: It is more than a year now since Chrysler stole a march on the rest of Detroit with its extremely popular minivan, but the competition is catching up, and the latest example comes from General Motors.

title: TWINS MANAGER A STUDENT OF THE GAME
description: One of the first problems Ray Miller encountered after he was named manager of the Minnesota Twins last month was learning the names of his players.

title: The Hatch Act Comes Alive
description: A law adopted when Washington was backing controversial experiments with school curriculums is becoming a source of controversy even though such projects are no longer in vogue. The Protection of Pupil Rights Act, known as the Hatch Amendment after its sponsor, Sen. Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, specifies that parents must be allowed to inspect curriculum materials used in Federal programs designed to explore ''new or unproven'' teaching techniques. It also says that schools must obtain parents' consent before giving students ''psychological tests or treatments'' in research programs dealing with such ''sensitive'' areas as political affiliation and sexual behavior.

title: DANCE: WORKS BY CHARLES WEIDMAN
description: DURHAM, N.C., July 5 -

title: Of Women and Law
description: ''Women in Law,'' a painting by Linda Hawkin-Israel, will be unveiled and presented by the artist to Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court in a ceremony Monday in the ground floor lobby of the Court. The ceremony is being sponsored by the National Asociation of Women Judges and the Foundation for Women Judges, whose members will be in town for the annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JULY 7, 1985

title: NO PLACE TO PUT HER LOVE
description: WHITE WATER By Joyce Reiser Kornblatt. 217 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. 6.95.

title: EVERYBODY SACRIFICED, EVERYBODY PROFITED
description: NEW DEALS The Chrysler Revival and the American System. By Robert B. Reich and John D. Donahue. 359 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: FEASTING ON SALMON IN ALASKA'S WILDS
description: There are several regions and even some countries that I have little desire to visit because, by reputation, their food is notably undistinguished. But I will willingly travel great distances to sample one regional or national specialty.

title: BEHIND THE FACADES, OR 'ADVENTURES' ON E. 79TH
description: IT looks like something off a movie studio's back lot, or perhaps a piece of satirical urban art: two false-front brownstones with nothing behind them but a vacant yard strewn with concrete rubble and a bit of grass. In the late afternoon, sun streams through the windows the wrong way - out, onto the sidewalk.

title:
INVESTING;

A COOLING IN THE BOND MARKET?
description: GIVEN the dramatic rise in the bond market over the past year, many investors are wondering if it still makes sense to buy bonds. Naturally, bond experts are divided on the question, but a majority seems to believe that the bond market's best days are past.

title: CHRISTA R. DINALLO WED TO LIEUT. A. C. MOGER
description: Christa R. Dinallo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Dinallo of Verona, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Boca Raton yesterday to Lieut. Adrian C. Moger, U.S.N., Medical Corps, a son of Dr. Claudina F. Moger of New York.

title: ROONEY TRIUMPHANT IN 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: THE best thing about a variety show like ''Sugar Babies'' is that there is something for everyone. One act follows another in rapid succession so that if you don't like low comedy, maybe you'll like the juggler or the singer or the ventriloquist or the belly dancer. And in the current Westbury Music Fair production of ''Sugar Babies,'' no matter what your taste, you will like Mickey Rooney.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHANGHAI. By Christopher New. (Summit, $19.95.) ''So this is China,'' the Englishman John Denton thinks as he approaches Shanghai for the first time. We hope so. After all, this is no ordinary city he is entering. It is Shanghai at the turn of the century, a city with about as strong a romantic and mysterious resonance as one can find - it even gave its name to a form of kidnapping. This is the city we expect to find, reflecting the atmosphere of Josef von Sternberg's film ''Shanghai Express.'' The massive novel follows Denton's career as it ebbs and flows and intertwines with 50 years of Shanghai's turbulent political and economic history. On the surface, it would appear that Christopher New has provided enough color to sustain his nearly 900 pages. Among other things, Denton takes a gorgeous Chinese mistresss; gains, loses and regains a fortune; marries an American socialite; gets elected to the city council; races ponies; and even, at one point, hides Zhou Enlai in his kitchen. There is also an assorted cast of British and Chinese characters from the straitlaced to the devious, the most vivid of whom is Denton's Chinese mistress, the worldly-wise singsong girl Su-mei. But ultimately what is lacking in this book is not the right character types or even the correct street names but passion. Mr. New seems unwilling, or perhaps unable, to throw himself into this teeming world. Although we learn something about the ways and means of this city, particularly about the British Customs Service, these are just facts.

title: A Candidate Responds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MISS MOORE HAS WEDDING
description: Marcia Monroe Moore, the daughter of Dr. Charles F. Moore and the late Annabel E. M. Moore of Seaford, Del., was married yesterday to John Zeller Imbrie, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Imbrie of Seekonk, Mass. The Revs.

title: Possible Cancer Tie Studied
description: Massachusetts will begin a street-by-street study of cancer deaths in this town south of Boston to see if there is a link to a toxic waste site. The study will determine how far the cancer victims lived from the waste site, which was once the Baird & McGuire chemical plant, where extensive pesticide and other chemical pollution has been found.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WOMAN DRIVER. By Jean Thompson. (Franklin Watts, $15.95.) Flora, ''half of a sundered couple,'' lives in a small, bright Middle Western town where everyone owns a car and no parking problems exist.

title: COVENANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: AN INSIDER'S VIEW OF BLACK POLITICAL GAINS
description: Sitting in a busy Congressional office where compromise is the only art, Julius W. Hobson Jr. remembers his father, Julius Sr., now dead, as something of a litigious firebrand in the black community in the 1960's when a generation of civil rights pioneers led the city back from the wilderness of disenfranchisement.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SLAVE'S NARRATIVE. By Charles T. Davis and Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Oxford University, $27.95.) American slavery may have produced the largest and most controversial body of slave narratives in history. ''The Slave's Narrative'' - edited by Charles T. Davis, who before his death in 1981 was a professor of English and chairman of Afro-American studies at Yale University, and Henry Louis Gates Jr., a professor of English and African studies at Cornell - presents a sample of the critical response to that literature. It contains a variety of documents ranging from 18th-century book reviews to recent scholarly essays. Among the generally first-rate previously unpublished articles, Jean Fagan Yellin's is outstanding. Not only does her authentication of a female slave's narrative have vast implications for narrative scholarship, it is the only essay that deals with a female writer, even though 12 percent of the antebellum publications were by women. Perhaps the neglect of slave women's narratives results from the editors' choice of ''a certain 'structural' approach'' to unify this interdisciplinary volume. Still, this neglect weakens the claim of representativeness. The omission of slave autobiographies published after 1865 is also surprising. Mr. Gates's argument that when slavery was abolished the slave-narrative structure and rhetorical strategies changed, is a curious reason to ignore years of slave testimony. Furthermore, the book contains a bibliography of antebellum narratives that includes life histories of free blacks who do not mention slavery and five essays about the Works Progress Administration interviews collected in the 1930's.

title: 43 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED FOR INFRACTIONS BY NEW YORK
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 43 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Indians' Fans Show Empathy As Thornton Struggles Back
description: THE POSITION of Peter Bavasi was like a commander-in-chief who might be instructed to wage a nuclear war, then have his most explosive weapon snatched from him. Bavasi was named president and chief operating officer of the directionless Cleveland Indians last Nov. 29, and five days later he signed Andre Thornton to the most lucrative contract in the Indians' history. Thornton, though, needed knee surgery two weeks before the season began.

title: INDEX OPTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMERS' HOPES RUN HIGH
description: A WETTER-than-normal June this year helped Connecticut's farmers, who had been facing the same drought that has affected the New York area.

title: Navy 'First'
description: WHEN she graduated from the United States Naval Academy in May 1984 at the head of a class of 1,005 midshipmen, Kristine Holderied shrugged off the honor. ''This kind of thing is going to happen, and it's going to continue to happen,'' she said as the first woman to finish No. 1 at an American service academy.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $109,900 54 Brookview Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; security *2* system, in-ground sprinkler, fenced yard; taxes $2,089.
