Bergenfield $140,000 103 Pleasant Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split-level; *2* covered patio, 1-car attached garage; taxes $2,775. title: WORKERS BUYING TORRINGTON FACTORY
description: WORKERS and management in Torrington last week acted on the formal details of the state's second major employee buyout this year, continuing what one state official says is an evolving trend.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines Are Bomb Targets
description: At various times, Madrid, Rome and Athens have been centers of terrorist attack by Arabs and others. Last week, a world just starting to unwind from the T.W.A. hostage drama was kept on edge by bloody incidents in all three capitals. In Madrid, a woman was killed and at least 27 people were injured by a bomb that destroyed the downtown office of British Airways. Five minutes later and two blocks away, two men shot up the offices of Alia, the Jordanian national airline, wounding two. Eight hours after that, a dozen people were injured in an explosion in the baggage loading area at Leonardo da Vinci Airport in Rome. And in yet another incident on Monday, a bomb exploded under a car outside an Athens hotel where United States military officers are housed.

title: MISS FRENCH, G. H. EVARTS ARE ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. V. French of Hopkinton, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Bliss French, to George Hammond Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove, Vt. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24.

title: MEN IN SEQUINS, GRANDMOTHERS WITH BATONS
description: America is a place where odd and outlandish things happen. In Daytona Beach, Fla., the harbingers of spring are not songbirds but bikers in black leather jackets.

title: CBS Offers A Poison Pill
description: For three months, CBS Inc. has been fighting off Ted Turner, the 46-year-old cable-television innovator, sports entrepreneur and champion yachtsman who would like to be the network's controlling owner. Last week, CBS made itself more than a little harder to get by announcing a $954.8 million recapitalization plan that will substantially increase the cost of acquiring the network.

title: WHEN A FRIEND CRIES OUT FOR HELP
description: IT'S about 9 o'clock on Saturday morning on a holiday weekend, and I'm asleep, the kind of complacent sleep where you know it's a beautiful day but you feel entitled to lie abed a bit longer, when my friend Annabelle calls.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A VICTORIAN SETTING AT THE SHORE
description: WHEN Beth Johnson came across a boutique a few years ago that embodied many of her ideas, a new career path seemed obvious.

title: FRESH VISIONS BASED ON A GRAND TRADITION
description: Representation Abroad'' - at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden through Sept. 2 - is a welcome but seriously flawed show.

title: IN PRAISE OF PAPER: LITTLE BITS OF VENICE
description: One of the special pleasures of Venice is exploring the beautifully appointed small shops that nestle in small squares or between canals and curving streets, as well as in the arcades of the famous Piazza San Marco. Every part of the city has its share of the artisans' shops that help make Venice unique.

title: FOREVER YOUNG WALKING ON THE BEACH
description: TO live on Long Island is always to be within easy distance of a beach, and many of us will admit to a special affinity for our beaches, not just in the summertime when the lazing is easy and the cotton clouds float by in a blue sky, but in all seasons and in all kinds of weather when the sand and sea offer a menu of experiences.

title: 'Goldkorn Tales'
description: In writing of the adventures of Leib Goldkorn, an Austrian-born flutist, Leslie Epstein picks up where he left off in 1976 in the novella ''The Steinway Quintet,'' for that work, slightly revised, is the first of the three interrelated parts of ''Goldkorn Tales.'' Goldkorn is working as a house musician at the Steinway Restaurant on New York's Lower East Side on the night two gun-wielding Puerto Ricans hold the staff and patrons hostage. The tale, a melange of comedy, pathos and subdued horror, is thematically linked to the Holocaust. The narrator writes: ''Our antagonists stepped into the crowd of Jews and began to rip from their bodies the last shreds of their garments. Now there were plentiful screams, wailing, and exclamations. . . . All of us, musicians, waiters, patrons, were huddled together, as if on the lip of some common grave.'' Yet at this grim moment, one of the naked men, a psychiatrist, speaks: ''What is the cause of the fear of death? Let us think of it in a rational manner. Is it not in reality the childish fear of losing the penis?''

title: BETTER COVERAGE FOR CO-OP OWNERS
description: SHAREHOLDERS in cooperatives may now purchase increased insurance coverage for their apartments and personal possessions for up to 40 percent less than they are now paying, according to the New York State Department of Insurance.

title: RESCUE UNIT IS SECOND HOME TO FAMILIES
description: THE spirit of volunteerism and family are combined in the Town of Lewisboro in a spacious white building off Route 35 in the hamlet of Cross River.

title: MUGABE MAY BE FRUSTRATED, EVEN WITH A NEW MANDATE
description: Double lines of humanity curved and twisted outside a small tent in an open field in this township 12 miles south of Harare last week, as black voters waited to cast their ballots in Zimbabwe's first national elections since independence five years ago. After waiting nearly five hours in the chill of the Southern African winter, Alex, a young man who declined to give his last name, entered the tent and selected the parliamentary candidate of the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front.

title: Art and the Life Of India
description: To limit the appraisal of Indian art to Mogul art, as its supposed highest expression, is to demean the indispensable contributions of Buddhist, Rajput and Hindu art and architecture.

title: Summerfare Changes: A Word of Protest
description: If Christopher Hunt assumes there is no dissent to his changes in the Summerfare program at the State University of New York in Purchase because he has not heard any protests, please publish this protest on my behalf and that of many friends and relatives with whom I have discussed them. The higher prices, shortened season, lack of subscription offerings, and abolition of the ''Noah's Flood'' pageant, complete with participation by local children, have met with many negative comments.

title: OPERETTA: 'STUDENT PRINCE'
description: IN reviving a faded theatrical blossom such as ''The Student Prince'' performers are always tempted to wink at the audience, at least figuratively if not literally, as if to say, ''I hope you don't think we are serious about this sort of thing.'' Depressingly often, the wink develops into a nudge in the ribs, followed by collapse into what is intended to be hilarious camp. Along the way, whatever intrinsic value the work may have had is either badly obscured or ground underfoot. It is a pleasure to report that the New York City Opera's performance of Sigmund Romberg's sentimental classic, which opened the company's season Friday night, avoided such miscalculations. The 61-year-old operetta has been not so much revived as lovingly restored.

title: Isn't It Time to Start Trading With Cuba?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM STRAVINSKY TO DR. SEUSS
description: The Heiress Starring Olivia De Havilland, Montgomery Clift, Ralph Richardson, Miriam Hopkins, Selena Royle; directed by William Wyler, 1949 MCA Home Video 115 minutes. $59.95 Herewith a Hollywood work of art - an intelligent expansion by Ruth and Augustus Goetz of their Broadway drama (from Henry James's novel ''Washington Square'') with a fine cast and a master director.

title: WHEN ACCOUNTING GOES ELECTRONIC
description: Thorough pLanning and step-by-step Implementation will ease the tension For a small business, probably the most tantalizing promise made on behalf of the personal computer is automated accounting. Word procesing is fine, even necessary, in certain professions such as law that generate lots of words. Spreadsheets offer anyone involved in planning a visual panorama of future alternatives. Data bases handle mailing list maintenance and similar electronic filling tasks. All of these functions can be very useful.

title: SAUDI INFLUENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STORMS & SON. By Anthony Caputi. (Atheneum, $14.95.) If you've ever spent a long afternoon in a dark bar with a friend whose troubles are worse than your own, you have some idea of how Anthony Caputi's novel will make you feel.

title: RESTORATION TAX CREDITS AT RISK
description: PRESERVATIONISTS and developers -two groups that do not always think alike - are saying the same thing these days: President Reagan's proposed repeal of investment tax credits would imperil the restoration of landmark buildings, blighted historic neighborhoods and older commercial districts.

title: U.S. CITES TWO SCHOOLS IN COUNTY FOR EXCELLENCE
description: AS their boisterous students headed off for summer vacations, two schools in the county have learned that they have been cited by the Federal Government as model institutions.

title: ELLEN SOLEY ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Soley of Seaford, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Rose Soley, to Dr. Elijah Stanton Adkins 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Stanton Adkins 2d of Salisbury, Md. Miss Soley, a graduate of the Columbia University School of Nursing, is a head nurse at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Los Angeles. Dr. Adkins, a graduate of Princeton University and Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, is an intern at the University of California Medical Center at Los Angeles.

title: PRIZES FOR SLEUTHS AND YACHTSMEN
description: As giveaways have proliferated, so have the attempts by companies to make theirs stand out from the crowd. Some contests would indeed be hard to replicate. Here are some examples. *Philip Morris for the past 3 years has awarded a series of prizes in a sweepstakes to promote its Benson & Hedges 100's cigarettes. The prizes are always in the 100's -- 100 pounds of frog's legs, 100 hours at the Vienna Opera, 100 mutual fund shares, and a 100-inch mink coat, to name a few. *Showtime/The Move Channel, trying to attract viewers to a concert it was running, gave away Barry Manilow's piano. Joanne Black, Showtime's senior vice president of marketing, said the game was ''a smash,'' with more than 100,000 viewers sending in entries. *In the murder-mystery book, ''Who Killed the Robins Family?'' readers were asked to solve the crime. The reader who provided the best solution won $10,000 in cash. What was a run-of-the-mill whodunit ended up selling 300,000 hardcover copies at $9.95 each and was on the best-seller list for 36 weeks. *When Ted Turner was starting Cable News Network, he ran a sweepstakes to entice cable operators to buy his program. The prize was a day on Mr. Turner's yacht, Tenacious, watching Mr. Turner race his other yacht, Corageous, in the America's Cup trials.

title: A HILTON THAT FITS
description: In an effort to capture a share of the tourist and corporate market in southeastern Connecticut, a new Hilton hotel is rising on nine acres in Mystic, the 18th century whaling and ship-building center on Long Island Sound.

title: MOTHERS WHO TAKE THE BLAME
description: WHAT DID I DO WRONG? Mothers, Children, Guilt. By Lynn Caine. 296 pp. New York:

title: NEW YORK TRADING SPACE TO BUILDER FOR YOUTH JOBS
description: In an unusual zoning agreement, New York City has granted a real-estate developer permission to build extra floor space for a West Side condominium in exchange for funds to create jobs for disadvantaged youths.

title: THE MAN NOBODY KNOWS
description: FOR ALL HIS INFLUENCE, NEL-son Mandela is all but invisible. Since August 1962, the man most black South Africans look up to as their leader has been out of view - imprisoned for leading the banned African National Congress in its armed resistance to the apartheid system. During his confinement, Mandela's fame has grown into legend, assuming an almost mythical importance in the litanies of the nation's defiance. Yet he is visited regularly only by his family, and he remains unseen by his millions of supporters.

title: NANCY KUSER LANE PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Lane of Harbourton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Kuser Lane to Thomas Frederick McNamara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. McNamara of McLean, Va., and Cataumet, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Pitfalls Of Progress
description: Please inform Russell Baker that a distaste for 97 percent of so-called progress is not an embarrassment limited to one age group (''The Pitfalls of Progress,'' Sunday Observer, June 2). The words automatic, remote, cellular and digital make me sweat.

title: WHEN SCANDAL HAUNTS THE CORRIDORS
description: HE cannot think about it without irritation. He was loath to go on at any length. Frankly, he was sick of it.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on June 16 incorrectly characterized an investigation into military spending established in 1941 under Senator Harry S. Truman. It was a special Senate committee.

title: MONTCLAIR: 'THE HORSEY SET'
description: FOR the last two months or so, the Montclair Art Museum has been host to ''The Sport of Kings,'' an exhibition of race-horse canvases by Richard Stone Reeves.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya and Morocco Move Toward Union
description: Libya and Morocco took a step closer to formal union today by setting up a joint legislature.

title: MANMADE PONDS CALLED PERIL
description: OFFICIALS and residents of Smithtown are questioning the safety of manmade ponds, which many developers are seeking the town's permission to build.

title: FULL-TIME SPONSORS ARE SHOPPING FOR QUALITY SHOWS
description: On an English country road a few days ago, a 1940's sedan careened into a World War II army truck, in a precise reenactment of the accident that killed Gen. George C. Patton 40 years ago. As the cameras rolled to record the climactic scene of ''The Last Days of Patton,'' a movie starring George C. Scott and a sequel to the 1970 theatrical film, a vice president of a New York advertising agency stood and took careful note of the proceedings.

title: China and Japan Initial Pact On the Use of Nuclear Energy
description: China and Japan have initialed an agreement on cooperation in the peaceful use of nuclear energy, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: HOW TO MAKE A BEAUTIFUL CORPSE
description: NOTES OF AN ANATOMIST By F. Gonzalez-Crussi. 134 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: CATHLEEN PURNELL MARRIES MARK FARRELL IN OREGON
description: Cathleen Margaret Purnell, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Purnell of Salem and Sunriver, Ore., was married yesterday to Mark Macaulay Farrell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Farrell of Troy, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Jacobberger performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Salem.

title: ELLIS ISLAND: WELCOME OF OLD BEING DUSTED OFF
description: BROKEN windows are being replaced, walls are being resurfaced and bits and pieces of the past are being hauled out of forgotten crannies.

title: KABUKI CHAMPIONS COME TO THE MET
description: As grand ceremonies go, the Kojo is not spectacular. Mostly, it involves 20 minutes of praise for the principal actor from his fellow performers, speeches delivered in the familiar, exaggerated manner of Japanese Kabuki, with voices ranging from low-range rumbles to supersonic screeches. When they have finished and he himself has spoken, the principal actor rises from a deep bow. Half-standing, half-sitting, he thrusts out his right leg, holds aloft a small lectern and scroll and, from that uncomfortable position, glares at the audience. That is all. He just glares, a defiant gaze, if slightly cross-eyed.

title: New Sleepers for Amtrak
description: ALTHOUGH President Reagan would like to slash its Federal subsidy, Amtrak is looking to its future with the first prototype of a new generation of passenger rail cars. A shiny stainless steel shell glided out of the Budd Company's technical center in Fort Washington, Pa., last week and was transferred to the company's testing site in Philadelphia.

title: Extradition Fight
description: IN a ruling that angered the Justice Department, a Federal judge in Manhattan refused in December to extradite a member of the Irish Republican Army who had been convicted of killing a British soldier.

title: Plant Executives Get 25 Years
description: After comparing the silver-recycling plant they once operated to a ticking time bomb, Cook County Circuit Judge Ronald J. P. Banks last week sentenced three of the plant's former officials to 25 years in prison for the death of one of their employees. The defendants - Steven J. O'Neil, who was president of Film Recovery Systems Incoporated, which has gone out of business; Charles Kirschbaum, the plant manager; and Daniel Rodriguez, a foreman - were also fined $10,000 each.

title: FORGING A NEW DRAMATIC LANGUAGE
description: Sometimes, when you listen to people in and around theater talk, you can get the notion that progress is from wake to funeral. Well, American theater may be threatened by all kinds of economic difficulties, but it is surviving a much more serious threat - the loss of an authentic theatrical language. David Mamet's ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' and David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly'' lately on Broadway and two of Sam Shepard's plays, ''Fool for Love'' and ''Curse of the Starving Class,'' currently running a few doors from one another in Theater Row on West 42d Street are powerful reminders not only of what good writing there is in current theater, but of the struggle by a handful of first-rate playwrights to find a new dramatic language. If, as Marsha Norman said recently in these pages, ''writing is what the theater cannot do without,'' that effort is the most important thing going on in theater.

title: WAKING UP WITH A SMILE
description: For anyone with a musical ear, a typical clock radio just isn't a nice way to start the day. The tinny blare reinforces the urge to knock the radio off the night-table, turn over in bed, and hold back the dawn.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEW KGB: Engine of Soviet Power. By William R. Corson and Robert T. Crowley. (Morrow, $19.95.) Despite its title, this book is mainly a history of the Soviet security and intelligence apparatus, rounded out by a retelling of some of the organization's more notorious exploits in Britain and the United States. The chapters on the methods employed by Soviet agents in ferreting out the West's industrial and military secrets are particularly timely, what with recent arrests of a number of Americans accused of spying for Moscow. But the book's message lies elsewhere. The authors, who claim a combined 70 years' experience in military intelligence, contend that the K.G.B. has taken over control of the Soviet Communist Party and ''now operates the U.S.S.R.'' They concede that this view puts them at odds with many ''traditional'' American scholars who see the party as still firmly in charge, and they provide little real evidence in support of their own opinion. Their conclusions are more a matter of interpreting Soviet political dynamics as holding out little hope for any improvement in East-West relations. American ventures in detente, trade and scientific exchange are dismissed as delusions that have made it that much easier for the K.G.B., beefed up before his death last year by the Soviet leader Yuri Andropov, to carry out his ukase -massive filching of Western high technology to modernize and expand the Soviet armed forces. Soviet professions of reasonableness are pretense, a smokescreen behind which Russia under its new K.G.B. masters reverts to harshest Stalinism.

title: AL E. SPERBER
description: Al E. Sperber, an advocate for the blind, died Monday at Florida Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale. He was suffering from complications following heart bypass surgery.

title: DEAR FRIEND, THIS IS WHY I HAVE NOT WRITTEN
description: WHEN I was 13 years old, I had 34 pen pals. No more than 48 hours would go by before each letter was answered. As I was growing up, every gift I ever received, even if from my parents, was acknowledged with a lengthy thank-you note. I was so conscientious about sending them that my mother started giving me boxes of thank-you notes as Christmas presents (and of course, I used my new stationery to thank her).

title: Pharmacists in Philadelphia Ratify Pact With University
description: After a nine-hour meeting with officials of Temple University and a hospital workers' union, 17 hospital pharmacists have ratified the two-year contract reached between the union and Temple, averting a possible strike.

title: JULIA HARRIS ENGAGED TO EDWARD Z. HUGHES
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Crawford Harris of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julia Craig Harris to Edward Zeller Hughes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bantley Hughes of New Canaan, Conn.

title: A BUSY TELEPHONE LEADS TO COMMUNICATIONS BREAKDOWN
description: TWELVE years ago I married a widower who lived in Westchester. He had three teen-agers and two telephone lines. I've managed fine with the kids. But one of the phones has been a worry from the start.

title: ANTONIA LEVITT, AN ARTIST, WEDS ALLAN JULIER, TEACHER
description: Antonia Leavitt and Allan J. Julier were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Scot Leavitt, parents of the bride, in Pound Ridge, N.Y. Town Justice Robert Eichelburg performed the ceremony.

title: Spirits;   COOLING AND RELAXING
description: A WINE MERCHANT TOLD ME this story:

title: British Paper Charged Under Corruption Act
description: The Observer, Britain's oldest Sunday newspaper, said today that it had been charged with corruption for buying documents from a senior Defense Ministry official.

title: BARRY CRANE, BRIDGE EXPERT, FOUND SLAIN IN LOS ANGELES
description: Barry Crane, the contract bridge expert who won more titles than anyone else in the history of the game, was found slain Friday in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old and by profession was a television producer and director.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THERE is a place in Somerset County that is home for almost every human need.

title: CRIME WAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: BAR GROUP MEETS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Judges and civil rights lawyers from South Africa and the United States gathered here today to discuss South Africa's policies of strict racial separation and to devise a legal strategy for combating them.

title: NEW EAST END HOMES: 'NOSTALGIC '80's?'
description: THE work of 28 architects will be on display next weekend at the third annual ''Beaux Arch'' exposition at the Hampton Day School in Bridgehampton. The architects will show projects completed in the last five years on the East End that relate to the theme of this year's exposition, ''Reinterpreting Tradition: The Nostalgic 80's?''

title: A SHOW THAT PUTS A SOCIAL CRITIC IN A LARGER CONTEXT
description: It was 30 years ago that Robert Frank, a Swiss-born emigre armed with a Leica camera and a Guggenheim grant, set out on the photographic odyssey across America that resulted in ''The Americans,'' a book that did as much to change the face of photography as any other single collection of pictures before or since. The 83 pictures of ''The Americans'' were immediately recognized as politically charged and formally innovative, although not in ways that jibed with the cautious climate of the 1950's. Today, however, ''The Americans'' is a universally acknowledged classic, a watershed in the medium's postwar evolution from putatively objective to openly subjective ways of envisioning the world.

title: LIKE DREAMS OR STUPORS
description: MIGRAINE Understanding a Common Disorder. By Oliver Sacks. 270 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $17.95.

title: ALBANY TAKES STOCK, AND A BREAK
description: In the leisurely days when the New York Legislature was like a men's club, members would spend the winter in Albany, then go home. As Assemblyman Richard J. Conners said last week, ''They'd expect to get out by St. Patrick's Day.'' Mr. Conners, a Democrat, has been in the Assembly only since 1977, but he has been a courtly presence in Albany politics for decades.

title: CAROLINE LAKAH WEDS HANS PETER ANDRESEN
description: Caroline Lakah and Hans Petter Andresen were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Port Chester, N.Y. The Rev. William J. Bradley performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Reidar A. Kirkvold of the Norwegian Seamen's Church.

title: GORBACHEV SHAKES UP THE KREMLIN AND SETS A DATE WITH REAGAN
description: AMONG the Kremlin customs Mikhail S. Gorbachev has abandoned since coming to power in March is sitting still through interminable official speeches. While the grim-faced veterans around him sat stoically and motionlessly through the drone of the Supreme Soviet last week, Mr. Gorbachev was positively rambunctious, chatting, drumming his fingers, fidgeting and even slipping out for a while.

title: Cooney Weiland Dies at 80; Ex-Hockey Player and Coach
description: Ralph (Cooney) Weiland, a member of the first Boston Bruin team to win a Stanley Cup, in 1929, and a successful hockey coach at Harvard University for 21 years, died last Wednesday at New England Deaconess Hospital.

title: ZIMBABWE VOTE GIVES MUGABE 63 OF 79 SEATS
description: The party of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has gained an overwhelming victory in this nation's first general election since independence, winning 63 of the 80 seats reserved for blacks in the 100-member Parliament.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF COTTON MATHER, by Kenneth Silverman. (Columbia University, $14.50.) Cotton Mather entered Harvard in 1674, when he was 11 1/2 years old - the youngest student in the college's history. As pastor of Boston's North Church, he wrote 70 sermons a year and published 388 historical, polemical, scientific and theological works. The archetypal Puritan, he is remembered for having helped create the witchcraft furor of the 1690's. This is his first comprehensive biography, according to our reviewer, Larzer Ziff, and ''a remarkable achievement.'' It won the 1985 Pulitzer Prize for biography and Bancroft Prize. PILGRIM'S WAY, by John Buchan. (Carroll & Graf, $10.95.) The thriller writer John Buchan (Lord Tweeds-muir) was at various times an intelligence officer, a Member of Parliament, Lord High Commissioner to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland and Governor General of Canada. He wrote the classic ''Thirty-Nine Steps'' as his 39th book. In 1940 our reviewer, Peter Monro Jack, described ''Pilgrim's Way'' as ''a book of great beauty and strength, the book of the year in autobiography, and a distinguished additon to the few first-rate autobiographies in the English language.'' Buchan died in 1940 at the age of 64. WALL TO WALL, by Douglas Woolf. (The Dalkey Archive Press, Elmwood Park, Ill., $4.50.) The protagonist of this novel, an ''unreadjusted'' soldier seven years out of the service, drives from Los Angeles to Oklahoma City and then to New York. On the way he looks in on his now abandoned base, visits college friends and former sweethearts and generally reappraises his past.

title: Art and the Life Of India
description: I am Indian, both my heritage and culture, and I am pleased at the awareness of my beautiful country that is taking place (''Art and the Life of India,'' by John Russell, June 2).

title: PROBLEMS IN SELLING FIXTURES
description: THE new regulations governing situations in which New York City loft renters may sell their fixtures to outsiders raise important issues for tenants moving into and out of about 5,000 loft dwellings in Manhattan and Brooklyn, as well as for their landlords.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Also on June 23, an article about Kurashiki incorrectly named the terminal in Tokyo for taking the bullet train to Okayama. The bullet train for Okayama leaves from Tokyo Station.

title: DEBORAH LYETH IS MARRIED
description: Deborah Dobson Lyeth, a daughter of Mrs. Jervis Campbell Webb of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and the late John Mortimer Richardson Lyeth Jr., was married in Bloomfield Hills yesterday to David James Master, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Andrew Master of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Robert Lindsey performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Kirk in the Hills.

title: AN AMATUER COMPANY OF DEVOTED SAVOYARDS
description: FOR 38 years, the Troupers Light Opera Company has presented its annual Gilbert and Sullivan operettas in Stamford. But when two productions of ''The Mikado'' opened April 20 in the city, comparisons with the professional New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players version were inevitable.

title: CHAVEZ: TOO MUCH TALENT TO HIDE
description: JOHNNY TOCCO raised his eyebrows and shook his head. If this was the best fighter in the world he was watching, maybe there was something wrong with his eyes.

title: AN ARTS POTPOURRI IN YONKERS
description: LOOKING across Untermyer Park in Yonkers toward the Grecian Gardens, visitors are filled with a sense of opulence of times past. They pass a portal topped by a statue of the Greek goddess Artemis and stroll by fountains, canals with flowers and footbridges. There are Greek-style columns, mosaic Gorgons, gargoyles, stone murals, a reflecting pool and an amphitheater. A feeling of elegance and anticipation is in the air.

title: Woman, Raped by Five, Escapes in West Virginia
description: Five men were accused Friday of the rape and abduction of a New York woman who the police said escaped after six hours.

title: HARTFORD'S EXPERIMENT WITH ENTERPRISE ZONES GATHERING MIXED REACTIONS
description: When Venoal M. Fountain was looking for a place to start his own company in 1983, he chose the shabby East End of Bridgeport, Conn., where he had grown up, to take advantage of the financial incentives available because of the area's designation as an enterprise zone.

title: WHAT WAS BLOWING IN THE WIND
description: UNCOVERING THE SIXTIES The Life and Times of the Underground Press. By Abe Peck. Illustrated. 364 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $12.95.

title: NEW LIFE FOR RETIRED GREYHOUNDS
description: PAUL BOTTICELLO'S greyhounds have won prizes at Plainfield Greyhound Park, the state's only dog track, and at tracks in New Hampshire, West Virginia and Florida.

title: ROCK PERFORMERS MOBILIZE FOR A TRANS-ATLANTIC CONCERT
description: ''It's the most complex thing we've ever done,'' said Les Garland, senior vice president of programming for MTV, and he is not alone in his assertion. According to many people participating in ''Live Aid,'' Saturday's 17-hour, bi-continental rock concert in support of the beleaguered peoples of Africa, the event is the most complex thing that any of them has ever done.

title: GLIMPSES OF A LEGENDARY PIANIST
description: Josef Hofmann's art should need no introduction, but -partly his own fault, partly that of the changing tides of musical taste - it probably does, and a new issue from the International Piano Archives at the University of Maryland offers a good one. Hofmann, born in 1876, was at the height of his peculiar and fascinating career hailed by many as the greatest pianist in the world. This was a serious estimate: Rachmaninoff, for instance, was one of the hailers. But his highly personal style, rooted in 19th-century assumptions about music, was on its way out of favor, and after the final, troubled phase of his public activity, his name and way of playing were quietly set to one side by the shapers of postwar musical opinion. He himself was not exactly forgotten, but what he had embodied was.

title: A Victory for Mrs. Charles
description: An opponent accused Prime Minister Eugenia Charles of ''slavish'' support of the United States, but most of the voters of the small Caribbean country of Dominica didn't seem to mind.

title: San Francisco Puts a Cap On the Boom
description: San Francisco enacted perhaps the most stringent growth restrictions of any American city last week, but only over the objections of some city officials who thought they were not nearly stringent enough.

title: WIMBLEDON WITHOUT MCENNUI
description: WHEN the gentlemen's singles final is played at Wimbledon today, John McEnroe will not be on Centre Court. The three-time champion lost in the quarterfinals last Wednesday - the first time since 1979 that the world's best tennis player failed to reach the title match. His departure from the world's most prestigious tennis tournament was mourned by some tennis devotees, but many more seemed to be smiling the way people do when the neighborhood spoiled brat finally gets spanked. Even when the spoiled brat doesn't understand why they're smiling. Or why he's being spanked. ''In this country, I'm an easy target,'' John McEnroe said of England the other day. ''And I don't think I'm that interesting a person to warrant the attention. I thought I had more to offer the game.''

title: Q AND A
description: Extending Insiders' Period Question: If an amendment to a co-op or condominium offering plan is presented before the 90-day exclusive purchase period for insiders expires, must that period be extended? What if the amendment is presented after it expires? . . . H. H. P., Manhattan Answer: Part 18 of the Attorney General's regulations says that if the amendment is ''substantial,'' the exclusive purchase period is extended for an additional 30 days if there are less than 30 days remaining in the exclusive period when the amendment is accepted for filing, says Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general.

title: CHURCH-STATE LINE FURTHER CLARIFIED
description: IN the final week of its session, the Supreme Court issued a third major rebuff to the Reagan Administration's views on the relationship between religion and government. The Court ruled that public school systems may not send teachers into parochial school classrooms to provide remedial or ''enrichment'' instruction. Such programs, wrote Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. for the majority of five, forge a ''symbolic union of government and religion'' that is forbidden by the Constitution.

title: California Firefighters Get Help from Weather
description: Moist fog and calming winds yesterday aided firefighters trying to contain brush fires that have blackened more than 200,000 acres of canyons and hillsides in 10 Western states.

title: A LESSON LEARNED ON THE GOLF RANGE
description: THERE was reason to feel good. The day was gorgeous.

title: Verbatim: Police and drugs
description: 'For the third consecutive year, narcotics is perceived as the department's No. 1 corruption hazard. The commanders believe that because this new, younger group of officers grew up in a more liberal drug-cultured society, their perceptions of drug usage may be far more tolerant than that of their predecessors.'

title: AN EPILOGUE TO THE TIMELESS STORY OF THE 6 MILLION
description: The war is long over, but the story of the six million will always go on. It is being told again here and elsewhere by voices that are getting old now. Some have been speaking for 40 years and some have come forward for the first time.

title: QUESTION IN PITTSBURGH: ANYBODY WANT A TEAM?
description: THE Jones & Laughlin steel mills, their blast furnaces once boiling in abundance, sit silently on Second Avenue. The gates are shut, the steelworkers out of jobs. A few miles away, Three Rivers Stadium, where a baseball team once thrived, faces a similar summer fate. Before long, its gates may be shut during the baseball season, its players working elsewhere.

title: Mr. Reagan's Slippery Words
description: The contrast this past month between President Reagan's words and deeds - on observing SALT II, on responding to terrorism - reveals a cavernous hyperbole gap. It's as if we have two Presidents - a President Pat Buchanan using overheated conservative rhetoric and a President Walter Mondale contouring moderate policies to complex situations.

title: NEW PAPER FOR RIDE SHARERS
description: WITH the distribution in Fairfield County this week of 10,000 copies of the Commuters' Register, this monthly newspaper for ride sharers is now available throughout the state.

title: NANCY JOSEPHSON PLANS TO BE MARRIED IN FALL TO DAVID BAUER STERN, LAYWER
description: Announcement has been made by Marvin Josephson and Ingrid Bergh Josephson, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Alexandra Josephson to David Bauer Stern, a son of William Stern of Ridgewood, N.J., and Barbara Miller of Fair Lawn, N.J. The wedding is planned for November.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NEW IN COURT BLOOD tests in court? It's happening in Nassau County.

title: SWEEPSTAKES TO WOO CLIENTS
description: Contests are not just for houewives. They can lure wholesalers, distributors and corporate buyers as well.

title: FOUR SEASONS TRIES TO PAMPER ITS WAY TO PROFITS
description: IT is early on a weekday morning at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON OUR FIRST CENTURY
description: WHAT was America like in the century before independence? To judge from most accounts, it was a stable, prosperous place where nothing much happened. Take almost any American history textbook in print - the story is event-filled for the 17th century, when the first British colonies were founded, and then again for the years after 1763 as the Revolution began to develop. But accounts of the period between have a curiously static quality. Dates all but disappear, as if there were no continuous narrative to tell; chapters are organized not chronologically but topically, with units on society, politics, religion. The character of the early 18th century is conveyed more pointedly through images, drawn, until very recent times, almost exclusively from white, British America - Benjamin Franklin in a beaver hat, a placid Pennsylvania countryside, the balanced facade of a James River plantation house. Such an America could produce only the conservative Revolution described by historians of a generation ago, a Revolution meant not to bring change but to preserve an established good life from the threat of change.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. ANNE M. SCHNEIDER TO WED H. B. MCNULTY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Schneider of Newington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Anne Margaret Schneider to Henry Bryant McNulty, a son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Bard McNulty of Glastonbury, Conn.

title: AMERICA AS FAIRYLAND
description: NEVER having read the Oz books as a child, I recently picked them up and began the 14-book journey through L. Frank Baum's queer country wondering what all the fuss was about. Because there is, of course, a fuss. An enormous, frenzied fuss that has existed since the first Oz book appeared 85 years ago. Pinch-lipped librarians patrolling their domains in a mysterious national campaign against scarecrows and tin men; novelists and distinguished academics combing the Oz texts for echoes of Hawthorne and Stephen Crane; 26 more sequels by six writers; collectors auctioning off scraps of Ozabilia; an International Wizard of Oz Club with thousands of members; a new movie, ''Return to Oz,'' and most important, I suppose, all these people, adult people, sitting around daydreaming of the times they sat around daydreaming, as children, looking up from yellowed pages describing the wonderful Land of Oz.

title: INNOCENCE ABROAD
description: To the Editor: I read Mr. Molotsky's account of his being pickpocketed with interest and compassion, for the same thing happened to me in early June on the Paris Metro.

title: Delaware Detente by the Flowerbeds
description: A rose by any other name may smell as sweet, but when it comes to the wildflowers that blossom along Delaware roadways this time of year, one person's beauty is another's blooming nuisance.

title: Ulster Protestants Allowed To March in Catholic District
description: The police said today that Protestants could march through a Catholic neighborhood of this market town Sunday despite a British order banning parades likely to incite violence.

title: Topics;   Missed Connections Getting There
description: The Association of State Transportation Officials decided last week that Route 66 is no longer an official highway. The Interstate Highway System now offers the fastest cross-country routes, so all ''66'' signs will soon come down.

title: AGAIN, THE MAN TO SEE IN LEBANON IS SYRIA
description: In a twist that was very Lebanese, the Shiite Moslem leader, Nabih Berri, who is Justice Minister in this lawless land, and whose bearded Amal miliiamen held most of the 39 American hostages until their release last weekend, angrily threatened to bring suit in the World Court against what he contended was an illegal American effort to shut down the Beirut airport by international boycott.

title: SUDDEN SUCCESS, SUDDEN PRESSURE
description: In the cities and villages across West Germany these last two weeks, all activity came to a halt whenever Boris Becker played at Wimbledon. People followed the progress of his matches on the radio and relived his exploits in the daily newspapers. At 17 years of age, with reddish blond hair, a disarming smile and a serve that earned him the nickname Boom-Boom, Becker has become a hero in his homeland and the favorite of the crowds at the All-England Club.

title: GRAND PARISIAN ROOMS ON A LEGENDARY SQUARE
description: You could put almost anything behind the facade of the Hotel de Crillon and it would be all right. For no other hotel in the world has a front like the Crillon: it sits behind the great flank of classical facades designed by Jacques-Ange Gabriel in the mid-18th century for the northern side of the Place de la Concorde. It is as noble a site as exists in Paris, directly on the square that is the city's physical and spiritual heart.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Unusual Catch
description: Although Rick Miller, the good-fielding Boston Red Sox outfielder, did not get into Friday night's game against the California Angels in Anaheim Stadium, he did make a catch from the dugout, helping to bag an unruly fan. Miller became involved briefly in a fight that broke out near the Red Sox dugout in the eighth inning of the team's 13-4 loss because, the outfielder said, his wife, his 5-year-old son and some friends of the family were in the area and needed protection.

title: QUEEN MARIE
description: To the Editor:

title: G. L. CALDWELL JR. WEDS SUSAN WOJCIECHOWICZ
description: Susan Elizabeth Wojciechowicz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Wojciechowicz Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to George Leonhard Caldwell Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Caldwell of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Dudley Rapp performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: BETH MARTIN HARVEY WEDS JAMES FURMAN OSTEEN
description: Beth Martin Harvey, a daughter of Mildred C. Martin and the late Aubrey E. Martin of Fayetteville, N.C., was married yesterday to James Furman Osteen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Osteen of Cape Coral, Fla. The Rev. Harry Price performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the University Chapel at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

title: LEBANON SEEKING ALLIES ON AIRPORT
description: Lebanon called today for a special meeting of Arab foreign ministers as part of its effort to counter steps taken by the Reagan Administration to isolate Beirut International Airport.

title: ON THE GROUND: 2 GROUPS HELD APART
description: It was in the fearful minutes after Bob Stethem died that gunmen began singling out two five-man groups of hostages. One of the original two hijackers called for Tony D. Watson, crying ''You, You,'' and Mr. Watson recalled later, ''I thought I was next'' to die.

title: Hypersexism And the Feds
description: The words ''man'' and ''mankind'' are gradually dying of their own ambiguity. The fact is that we no longer are sure what these words mean, so they are no longer very useful.

title: Correction
description: In an article about Cape Cod on June 23, a business called House Guests Cape Cod was not fully described. It is a bed-and-breakfast reservations service with listings of rooms ($36 to $80 a night) in private homes on Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

title: PUTS TOLL AT 15
description: The Government said today that several present or former Government officials had been arrested in connection with a coup attempt but that the leader of the plot was still at large.

title: No Headline
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., July 5 -

title: SOUTH KOREA GOES FROM WASTELAND TO WOODLAND
description: SEOUL, South Korea -

title: FAKERY AND STONY TRUTHS
description: CARPENTER'S GOTHIC By William Gaddis. 262 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: BATHING SUITS FOR THE LANDLOCKED
description: One of the many attributes of bathing suits is that one really doesn't need to go swimming to wear one. Not too many waves have lapped the edges of the parks in New York lately, but that hasn't stopped a seaful of bathing suits from showing up at the city's green spots on the warm summer days.

title: THE GEOGRAPHY OF MEMORY
description: Like many travelers, I'm bound to ask myself sooner or later in the course of any long trip why I'm on the road again. What is it, really, I have such desire for that, again and again, I find I've taken some passage of days into my hands to shape them into a ''journey?'' Then I'll remember how the word comes from the French journee and refers to the distance a traveler might cover in 12 hours. And so etymology instructs me it's really time I'm traveling through; or rather that, traveling, I'm released from the normal routines of life to play a game with time's shape, that great helix whose backward extension we call memory.

title: INTEGRATION?
description: To the Editor:

title:
ON LANGUAGE;

HAMBURGERS AND AMERIKANERS
description: I HAVE BEEN WORKING as a journalist in Hamburg, West Germany, for almost two years, during which time friends and relatives back in the States never tire of asking just how it is to ''live over there with all those Hamburgers,'' as the local inhabitants call themselves. But it wasn't until Walter F. Mondale challenged Gary Hart with ''Where's the beef?'' that I was prompted to delve into the origins of the word ''hamburger.''

title: PORT AUTHORITY FASHIONS A BRONX INDUSTRIAL SHOWCASE
description: THOSE who are working to find productive uses for vacant city-owned land in the Bronx have reason to cheer the results of public effort so far at the Bathgate Industrial Park, the new industrial showcase off the Cross-Bronx Expressway.

title:
GARDENING;

A PROPER START FOR YOUNG TREES
description: PLANTING a tree is an investment in the future. With the exception of small trees planted primarily for their flowering effect, most trees require two or three human generations to mature and provide the effect, whether it be shade or landscaping, for which they were planted.

title: DIAMONDS BRING SPARKLE TO SALES
description: NANCY MARTIN did not swear by Spic and Span. She had used it, but she had also used other household cleansers. She saw no real difference among them.

title: Ellsberg Gets 2 Days in Jail
description: Daniel Ellsberg, the antiwar activist, will serve a two-day jail sentence in mid-July for his part in a demonstration against the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America, according to the authorities.

title: MAN SOUGHT IN CABIN DEATHS IS ARRESTED IN CANADA
description: The fugitive wanted in connection with the discoveries of bodies, weapons and torture videotapes at a remote California cabin was arrested today in Canada, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: HAWLEY MASS., BATTLING AIR FORCE OVER USE OF A SCENIC RIDGE
description: Until a few weeks ago the tiny town of Hawley in the Berkshire hills was best known for being the only settlement in Massachusetts without a store, post office or traffic light. Among hunters, fishermen and tourists, it was also celebrated for an 1,800-foot forested ridge that is officially designated one of the 10 most beautiful spots in the state.

title: Topics;   Missed Connections Casual About Kids
description: Concern about child abuse has prompted many agencies dealing with children to look more closely over their employees. In their recent session, New Jersey legislators tried to mandate such care for school systems, day-care providers and state institutions.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM STRAVINSKY TO DR. SEUSS
description: Father Guido Sarducci Goes to College Starring Father Guido Sarducci; with Billy Vera and The Beaters; produced by Don Novello, 1984 Vestron Video 60 minutes. $59.95 Best remembered for his flippantly irreligious ''Saturday Night Live'' routines, Father Guido Sarducci (the alter ego of Don Novello), in clerical collar, surplice and long, black velvet cloak, is at his wildest, off-the-wall best in this concert at the University of California in Santa Barbara.

title: Back on the Beat in Providence
description: PATROLMAN James K. Hassett is back on the job in the patrol division of the Providence, R.I., Police Department, according to Deputy Chief Walter J. Clark.

title: JOINT G.O.P. EFFORT PLANNED TO REGAIN COUNTY CLERK POST
description: WHEN Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, ran for County Clerk three years ago, he said that one of his major tasks would be to educate the public as to how the office functioned. The Republican incumbent, George Morrow, who had held the post for nine years, agreed that the job was not widely understood.

title: Stanley S. Kresge
description: By most accounts, Stanley Sebastian Kresge, who died June 30 at the age of 85, was a man of strong principles. In 1977, the S. S. Kresge Company, founded by his father, was voting on changing its name to the K Mart Corporation.

title: AS COMMON MARKET GROWS, SO DOES EUROPE'S PESSIMISM
description: The expansion of the European Economic Community to include Spain and Portugal comes at a time of deep doubt and discomfort among many Europeans about the Community itself.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM STRAVINSKY TO DR. SEUSS
description: Dr. Seuss Tales ''The Cat in the Hat'' and ''Dr. Seuss on the Loose'' Playhouse Video 51 minutes. $29.98 ''You will watch it in a house - You will watch it with a mouse! You will watch it here and there - You will watch it everywhere!''

title: HUNGER TELETHON TO BE HEARD AROUND THE GLOBE
description: SELLING 90,000 seats at John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia was easy for a benefit concert called Live Aid. This Saturday, the arena will be the site of a 14-hour program - from 9 A.M. to 11 P.M. - to benefit Ethiopian famine relief, with more than 35 top rock and pop performers, including Tina Turner, Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger. Tickets for the show, at $37 each, sold out in less than four hours.

title: FRANCE IS EXPERIENCING A MODERN-DANCE EXPLOSION
description: Two years ago the American Dance Festival introduced American audiences to five young French companies, providing surprising evidence of an unsuspected vitality, variety and individuality of modern dance in a country where this art form hardly existed a decade ago.

title: HANOI WELCOMES M.I.A. DISCUSSIONS
description: Vietnam has offered to hold high-level talks with the United States to resolve questions within two years on Americans missing in action, State Department officials said today.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

SOME HOUSEWIVES DESERVE TO BE BORED
description: I'M REALLY getting annoyed. I just read the television listings, and there is yet another movie about a bored New Jersey housewife.

title: U.S. CREWS REACH 4 FINALS IN HENLEY
description: American competitors today reached finals in four of the nine events in which they were entered, and the most notable one will see Harvard and Princeton meet Sunday in an all-American matchup for the Grand Challenge Cup, the most prestigious event of the 140th Henley Royal Regatta.

title: DELETIONS FOR THE CIA
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ISLAND AND A LAB
description: EXCEPT for a smattering of real-estate brokers, two golf courses and a driving range, and a few general stores, Fishers Island has no real industry or commerce. Farmers found the soil unsuitable for agriculture and left. A handful of lobster boats still go out every day, but the one commercial fin fisherman on the island sold his boat earlier this year.

title: Letting Judges Choose Guardians
description: New York's highest court last week rebelled at the idea of turning over discretionary authority to a computer and instead offered it to the Legislature.

title: FOUR THAT MOVED INTO MARKET
description: The record spate of bond issuers this spring included a braod cross-section of American industry. Just as varied were the reasons why these companies' treaurers turned to the fixed-rate market. Following are some examples. EASTMAN KODAK When it issued fixed-rate, 30-year bonds in late March, the Eastman Kodak Company gambled that interest rates would not decline sharply over the long haul.

title: SUTTON OF A'S WINS 288TH
description: Don Sutton scattered five hits over eight innings for his 288th career victory, and Carney Lansford scored three runs and doubled home another today to lead the Oakland A's over the error-plagued Toronto Blue Jays, 5-1.

title: Road Show
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art is taking the relatively unusual step this week of opening one of its shows out of town. The reason: the 100th anniversary of the Niagara Reservation, the park surrounding the historic falls, is being celebrated there this week.

title: A STUBBORN PLATEAU IN THE JOBLESS RATE
description: Unemployment remained flat for the fifth month at 7.2 percent overall, and the manufacturing segment, which lost 45,000 jobs, continued to take the blame. The figures were a bit of a setback to a resurgent economy. Without a big surge of jobs in manufacturing, economists say, the economy cannot truly recover. In addition, ''There seems to be a shift out of lower-paying occupations into higher-paying occupations,'' said Janet L. Norwood, the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Some economists say that means workers who might have filled manufacturing jobs are being shut out of the job market altogether. And that, they note, may mean that unemployment much below 7 percent will be unattainable.

title: Tax Reform First, Then Deficit Reduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 105049 -- No Title
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, where new issues totaling $22.9 billion will be offered, with maturities of 3 months, 6 and 12 months. Proceeds will refund maturing bills and raise about $525 million of new cash to help reduce the Federal deficit.

title: Score on Mall Celebration
description: The capital finished cleaning up the Mall over the weekend after its annual mass revel in the rocket's red glare, and National Park Service officials will soon decide whether to try to repeat the Beach Boys' good vibrations in next year's Fourth of July celebration. Some officials say a return to military marching bands might be worth considering, but they stress that it has nothing to do with the controversy caused, to his regret, by James G. Watt when he was Secretary of the Interior.

title: A Good Deed
description: This is the story of a good deed that did not go unnoticed.

title: Top Lebanon Moslems Are Gathering in Syria
description: Senior Lebanese Moslem and Druse leaders have been converging on Damascus for Syrian-sponsored talks designed to end the breach among the various factions in Lebanon.

title: 150,000 Catholics Rally In Czechoslovak Village
description: In one of the biggest church festivals in Czechoslovakia since the Communist takeover in 1948, about 150,000 Roman Catholics today reaffirmed the popular strength of the Czechoslovak church despite decades of suppression.

title: AL UNSER JR. WINS CLEVELAND PRIX
description: Al Unser Jr. raced to his second Indy-car victory in eight days as Mario Andretti's engine burst into flames and stopped while he was leading the Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix today with three laps remaining.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Beginner's Luck
description: There is no more impressive way for a hitter to begin his major league career than by smacking a home run in his first time at bat. On the other hand, history affirms that it's nothing to get a swelled head about.

title: Lebanese Swimmer Slain
description: A 14-year-old Lebanese boy was killed today when teen-agers swimming in the Litani River on the edge of what Israel calls its ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon came under fire, sources said. The sources, who refused to be identified, said they believed the firing came from positions of the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army. A seriously wounded teen-ager and three others with minor injuries were hospitalized in Sidon.

title: 81 Are Injured in Idaho As Amtrak Train Derails
description: Amtrak's Seattle-to-Chicago passenger train, traveling at 70 miles per hour, jumped the tracks near this town in the northern tip of Idaho early today.

title: STATES CRACKING DOWN ON PARENTS FAILING TO PROVIDE CHILD SUPPORT
description: States across the country are passing laws to crack down on parents who fail to pay child support.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KLASS: How Russians Really Live. By David K. Willis. 355 pages. St. Martin's. $16.95.

title: SWITCHER, SMOKERS, SQUATTERS
description: Last month three longtime members of the Honolulu City Council switched their party registrations from Democratic to Republican.

title: BAR GROUP DROPS 3 FOREIGN POLICY PROPOSALS
description: Three resolutions pending before the American Bar Association's House of Delegates concerning American foreign policy have been removed from the agenda.

title: COLLECTING THE LESSONS OF HISTORY
description: The nation's capital is filled with people trying to analyze today's events. Wayne Rasmussen, on the other hand, is trying to analyze what happened yesterday.

title: A CONFERENCE ON MENOPAUSE
description: Should women suffering from hot flashes and other debilitating symptons of menopause take estrogen replacement therapy, which has been linked with endometrial cancer and other serious health problems?

title: OUTDOORS: ANGLING FOR RECORDS
description: I have been perusing the 1985 edition of the International Game Fish Association's annual ''World Record Game Fishes'' to see what listings an ordinary angler has a good chance of supplanting.

title: CITY, CITING REBELLION AT JAIL, TO SEEK CURBS ON DEPORTEES
description: The City Department of Correction said yesterday that it would ask Federal immigration authorities to screen more carefully the detained aliens it sends to a Brooklyn jail where a dozen Cubans awaiting deportation attacked and injured 18 guards Saturday.

title: Brett Leads Royals Past the Orioles, 8-4
description: The Royals defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 8-4, today to avert being swept in a four-game series for the first time ever at home.

title: PROFILES OF TOP CONTENDERS IN OPEN
description: The following profiles of some of the top players in the United States Women's Open were written by Gordon S. White Jr. Amy Alcott Anyone else might have been waiting impatiently to prove she did not buckle under pressure the way it appeared Amy Alcott did on the final hole of the 1984 United States Women's Open Championship at Salem (Mass.) Country Club. Miss Alcott, who needed par 4 on that difficult hole to tie Hollis Stacy, took a double-bogey 6 following a horrible drive. Miss Alcott finished tied for third as Miss Stacy won her third Open championship.

title: 1 Dies and 4 Are Hurt in Fire At 3-Family House in Jersey
description: One man was killed and four people were injured last night by a two-alarm fire that swept through a three-family wood-and-brick home in Union City, N.J., last night, authorities said.

title: Donald B. Abert, 78, Is Dead; Headed Milwaukee Journal
description: Donald B. Abert, the retired board chairman of the Journal Company, which owns The Milwaukee Journal and The Milwaukee Sentinel, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at a Milwaukee hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: YOUTH IS SERVED A WIMBLEDON TITLE BY BECKER
description: For two weeks he beat a path on the grass courts at the All-England Club, defying tennis tradition and the logic that said he was too young to win. Boris Becker argued logic with a serve that earned him the nickname Boom Boom, and ignored tradition with the irreverence of youth. And today, the 17-year-old from West Germany wrote a storybook ending when he became the youngest champion in the history of the men's singles at Wimbledon.

title: E.E.C. Head Criticizes U. S.
description: The Commissioner of the European Economic Community, Claude Cheysson, accused the United States Friday of betraying the free market ideal and spoke of the ''total despair'' of debt-burdened Latin American countries.

title: Canadian Joblessness
description: Canadian unemployment remained at a three-year low of 10.5 percent seasonally adjusted last month, with the actual number of jobless dropping slightly from the previous month, to 1.3 million, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday. The agency said seasonally adjusted figures show employment dropped to 11,282,000 last month, from 11,324,000 in May.

title: One A.M.C. Local Balks In Approving Wage Cuts
description: Wage and benefit concessions sought by the American Motors Corporation have won overwhelming approval from the company's Milwaukee employees, but workers at one of the city's A.M.C. plants rejected a proposed local agreement.

title: Woman Shot at Park Finds Bullet in Purse
description: A woman who was shot in the hand at Yankee Stadium last Thursday found a bullet in her handbag as she was being released from Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: JAZZ: EARL WARREN, SAXOPHONIST
description: EARLE WARREN, the alto saxophonist who played and sang in the original Count Basie Band in the late 1930's, has been living in Switzerland since 1981 but he returned to the United States for a brief visit and an appearance at the West End Cafe, 114th Street and Broadway, through last night. He led a quartet that on Saturday night was expanded to a quintet with the addition of another Basie veteran, the trombonist Eddie Durham.

title: ERA OF 6 DOMINANT AIRLINES IS SEEN
description: Six huge airlines with the power to control fares and routes could emerge from turbulent forces that are reshaping the industry, many Wall Street analysts and airline executives believe.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: VIETNAM PROMISES TO RETURN BODIES OF 26 AMERICANS
description: Vietnam has promised to return the remains of 26 more American servicemen who died in the Vietnam War, the largest such turnover since the fighting ended, Americans officials said today.

title: 20 YEARS LATER, INDONESIA MOVES TO MAKE PEACE WITH ITS PAST
description: Indonesia took two significant steps this week toward narrowing 20-year-old rifts that have separated the nation under President Suharto from the stormy Sukarno era.

title: THE STACYS ARE READY
description: AS she walked off the fourth green in the final round of the United States Women's Open last year, Hollis Stacy was declared ''out of it'' by some prophets. She trailed by five strokes. Quickly, she birdied the fifth and the eighth holes. But on the 13th, she pushed her tee shot into the rough under tree branches, 121 yards from the cup. Annoyed, she grabbed her 7-iron.

title: INQUIRY INTO PENTAGON'S SPENDING OF 'DIVIDEND' IS SOUGHT IN HOUSE
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee today called for an investigation of how the Defense Department has spent what he calls an unplanned ''dividend'' caused by overestimates of inflation.

title: SRI LANKA AND REBELS TO BEGIN TALKS
description: After two years of rising violence, the Government of Sri Lanka and leaders of the country's major Tamil insurgent groups are to begin talks Monday to seek a settlement of their differences.

title: Rock Shows Called Unlikely in Park
description: Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that it was ''highly unlikely'' that any more rock concerts would be permitted in Central Park.

title: DEFENDANT IN PLOT ON POPE SEIZED IN TURKEY AFTER LEAVING BULGARIA
description: Bekir Celenk, one of eight people being tried here for purportedly conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981, was detained by the Turkish police late Saturday night after he arrived unexpectedly in Istanbul from Bulgaria.

title: Catching Up
description: In 1983, having relocated from Springfield, Ill., the Louisville Redbirds turned in a record minor league home attendance. The season total was 1,052,438, which meant an average of 15,253 a game, the kind of number that the Pittsburgh Pirates might envy.

title: STEPHAN'S ODYSSEY TAKES THE DWYER
description: Creme Fraiche and Stephan's Odyssey, the stablemates who finished one, two, in that order, in the Belmont Stakes completed a sweep of major weekend stakes for 3-year-olds when Stephan's Odyssey won the Dwyer Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday after Creme Fraiche had won the American Derby at Arlington Park Saturday.

title: World Bank's Profitability
description: Although the World Bank's earnings are not scheduled to be published for another week or two, its officials say they have almost doubled, to more than $1 billion, in the year ended June 30. This may prompt complaints from third-world borrowers that the institution charges too much for loans.

title: Space Choice: Coke or Pepsi
description: The cola war is heading for space as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is planning to stock the space shuttle Challenger with both Coke and Pepsi for its weeklong mission that begins Friday, officials said.

title: A.T.& T.'S RIVALS GO ABROAD
description: ''Save on calls down under,'' says GTE Sprint in advertisements promoting Sprint's recently inaugurated long-distance phone service to Australia. An MCI ad showing a family of penguins in the Antarctic says, ''This is the only continent you can't call right now with MCI International.'' An A.T.&T. television ad filmed in Italy shows a doleful, American teen-ager bidding farewell to her Italian boyfriend. A voice in the background offers a cheerful note: ''Saying goodbye is never easy, but saying hello is, with A.T.&T.''

title: WORLD WHEAT GLUT HITS CANADA FARMS
description: Ray Gill has farmed the table-flat prairie south of here for 48 of his 60 years. Seldom have things looked so bleak.Last year, drought and grasshoppers wiped out his crop. This year, the grasshoppers are worse - so bad that whole fields of sprouting wheat sound like rain on a tin roof as the growing predators munch their way through. A dozen can do as much damage to a square yard of farmland as a cow, and seemingly hundreds of jumping insects now occupy each one.

title: Dutch Cyclist Takes Tour Stage
description: Maarten Ducrot of the Netherlands took the lead well before the final sprint today to win the 107.8-mile ninth stage of the 72d Tour de France cycle race by 37 seconds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Hart's Old Bills
description: Like most politicians who expect to run for office again, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado has a money problem. His unsuccessful campaign for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination left him several million dollars in the red, and advisers feel he must wipe out past political debt by early next year, whichever of his major options he exercises: seeking re-election to the Senate or dropping out of elective office to concentrate on the 1988 Presidential race.

title: PLANE BUFFS' FAVORITE CAPITAL VANTAGE
description: An Eastern Airlines jet thundered barely 100 feet overhead, the number N40E3A clearly visible on its tail, the sketchy outline of the pilot visible through the windshield. The ground trembled. The acrid rush from its engines was like a hot breath on an already steamy day.

title: THE SEQUEL BECOMES THE NEW BANKABLE FILM STAR
description: At last Hollywood has found a star who won't throw tantrums, demand a higher salary or insist on first-class airplane tickets home from location every weekend.

title: 4 Killed in Helicopter Crash
description: A helicopter taking sightseers on rides over Mount Rushmore National Monument crashed into a wooded hillside as it came in for a landing Saturday, killing the four passengers, the authorities said. The pilot was hospitalized in critical condition. Jerry Moore, the Pennington County Chief Deputy, said witnesses saw something fly from the helicopter before it crashed.

title: LOOKING FOR A NEW LIFE IN A NEIGHBORHOOD'S ASHES
description: A 71-year-old woman raked through broken plaster with a piece of melted glass this weekend, looking for anything left from the fire that roared through her house a few days before.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 8, 1985
description: International

title: Municipal Index A Success
description: SCARCELY a month after it introduced the controversial futures on an index of 40 municipal bonds, the Chicago Board of Trade finds it has another winner on its hands. The new contract has attracted support not only from dealers in tax-exempt issues but also from the public, which many doubters in the trade had said would prefer to use the Treasury bond futures to speculate on long-term interest rates.

title: Business Digest: MONDAY, JULY 8, 1985
description: International OPEC oil ministers failed to agree to any changes in pricing or production after three days of meetings in Vienna. Oil industry analysts, oil company executives and some oil ministers said the lack of a clear solution to the group's problems could lead to a further decline in oil prices. However, the 13-member organization will meet again July 22 in Geneva, where some of the suggestions made over the weekend may be discussed again. [Page A1.] Competition for international long-distance calls is heating up as A.T.& T.'s rivals fight to cut into the telephone giant's 97 percent share of the $5 billion overseas market. [D1.] Sinking oil platforms may threaten European gas production from the Ekofisk field in the North Sea. [D1.] High-technology investments by foreign companies in Malaysia have disappointed officials there, who had hoped for greater stimulus to local development. [D4.] Canada's grain farmers are facing a quiet crisis as pests threaten crops and worldwide oversupply hurts prices. [D4.] The Economy Economic activity among manufacturers continued to sag last month, the nation's purchasing managers reported. They said overall activity last month fell to its lowest level since December 1982 -a finding that was in sharp contrast to other recent reports that suggest the economy may be regaining lost momentum. [D1.] Companies Six huge airlines could result from industry consolidation, according to analysts and airline executives, who said the giant carriers would have the power to control fares and routes.

title: LEADER OF GUINEA UPRISING TO BE SHOT, PRESIDENT SAYS
description: The President of Guinea told thousands of cheering people today that the chief plotter behind the foiled coup last week was arrested earlier in the day ''and will be tried and executed shortly.''

title: Consultant's Founder Agrees to a Novel Sale
description: Theodore M. Barry, the 62-year-old chairman and founder of Theodore Barry & Associates, one of the nation's largest management consulting firms, has come up with a novel solution to a problem common to many in his business: In a deal that is half leveraged buyout and half employee stock ownership plan, he sold the bulk of his stake in the company to its management and employees, thereby liquefying his assets without jeopardizing the independence or future existence of the firm.

title: ANDUJAR PITCHES FOR ESTEEM
description: THERE is no doubt they are the two most dominant pitchers in the National League.

title: METS, YANKS WIN 2 FOR SERIES SWEEPS
description: Six days ago, the Mets had tumbled all the way to fourth place, their season reduced to a six-game losing streak and their offense slumbering quietly in the final days of June.

title: 'We Married While My Husband Was an Ensign'
description: To the Editor:

title: SALES OF TV DISH ANTENNA RAISING PROBLEMS
description: In 1979, Neiman-Marcus, the Dallas-based luxury retail store, offered a satellite dish antenna that, for $36,500, would provide a cornucopia of television programming, including ''10,000 top movies a year'' and ''sessions of the United States House of Representatives.''

title: Ulster Protestants March In a Catholic District
description: More than 1,000 soldiers and policemen sealed the route of a Protestant parade through a Roman Catholic neighborhood of this market town today.

title: FORENSIC SCIENCE TESTED BY PHILADELPHIA INQUIRY
description: Using some of the most sophisticated techniques in forensic medicine, scientists are working to identify 11 bodies recovered from a barricaded house the police bombed in May.

title: BANKING BILLS RUN INTO SNAG
description: AFTER two pieces of hotly debated legislation struggled their way to approval by the House Banking Committee, its chairman, Fernand J. St Germain, may have to watch them languish for a couple of months because of opposition in the Rules Committee, which decides when and under what conditions bills go to the floor.

title: Taiwan Blaze Wrecks A Nuclear Generator
description: A fire destroyed a generator at a nuclear power plant today in southern Taiwan and caused the reactor's water temperature to rise but there was no radiation leak, a night duty officer said.

title: Toyota Weighs Plant in U.S.
description: Japan's largest car maker, the Toyota Motor Corporation, is considering a plan to build a plant to produce cars in the United States, the Kyodo news agency reported today.

title: Fewer Corporations Changing Their Names
description: There were fewer corporate name changes during the first half of 1985 than in the same period last year, reports Anspach Grossman Portugal, the design firm that keeps track of such things.

title: CABARET: WALLOWITCH AND ROSS
description: WHEN they teamed up a year and a half ago as a cabaret duo, John Wallowitch, the serio-comic songwriter and performer, and Bertram Ross, the veteran modern dancer who also sings, created an act that wove more than 50 years of whimsical pop esoterica into a witty living-room musicale. Weaving amusing patter with low-keyed performances of obscure songs that are often too eccentric or naughty to have become standards, the pair specializes in paying homage to a genre of sophisticated pop that, except for the work of Stephen Sondheim, has all but vanished from the theater.

title: NCNB's Chief Sees Big Regional Banks
description: Although he considers his agenda full for the moment, thanks to the announcement last week of the proposed acquisition of Bankers Trust of South Carolina, Hugh J. McColl Jr., chairman and chief executive of the NCNB Corporation, is looking ahead to the day when regional banks like his will challenge the institutional giants of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

title: DOMINICA FIXES POTHOLES BUT OWN PATH IS ROCKY
description: For years the roads that circle the spectacular cliff-faced coast of this island and wind through the jungle-covered volcanic mountains in the interior were regarded as the worst in the Caribbean.

title: Chicago Tribune and Unions Negotiating on Labor Pacts
description: The Chicago Tribune and some of its production unions continued to negotiate past a midnight strike deadline today with newspaper officials expressing optimism that a walkout could be averted.

title: MALAYSIAN HIGH-TECH INDUSTRY
description: High-technology industries, once hailed as the answer to many of Malaysia's development needs, are turning out to be something of a disappointment to this Southeast Asian nation, officials say.

title: CHAVEZ, IN ROUND 2, STOPS MAYWEATHER
description: It was only a glimpse, but Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico showed his first United States national television audience just why some boxing people believe he may be the best fighter in the world.

title: The U.N. Today: July 8, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Scientists Started in '67 On Squibb's Prize Drug
description: The heroes at the Squibb Corporation these days are the two men who invented a drug that promises to become one of the leading medications for treating high blood pressure. But Miguel A. Ondetti, vice president for preclinical cardiovascular research at Squibb, and David W. Cushman, assistant director of the company's department of pharmacology, are trying not to let their celebrity status go to their heads.

title: RULINGS OF HIGH COURT'S TERM REAFFIRM CHURCH-STATE BARRIERS
description: The Supreme Court strongly reaffirmed its traditional insistence on the separation of church and state in the term that ended last week.

title: IN CENTRAL ASIA, AGE-OLD ISLAM MEETS SOVIET RULE
description: The mud walls, marketplace and grand mosques speak of exotic Asia, but the street names tell a Soviet story here.

title: JUSTICE STEVENS ASSAILS COURT VOTE AS IMPUGNING THE ROLE OF LAWYERS
description: Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court told an audience of civil rights lawyers today that he found a Supreme Court decision last month disturbing because it seemed to suggest that lawyers may ''do more harm than good.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Electric Power Co., Columbus, Ohio, as elected to its board Robert M. Duncan, a partner in the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees have won five of six games against the Royals this season.

title: PARENTS WHO MOVE BACK IN
description: IT has become a circumstance that can, and often does, create excessive family tension: elderly parents, more usually one elderly parent, after some years of independence and living apart from their child, move into the home of that child, who now is an adult.

title: LILCO STARTS UP SHOREHAM UNIT AT LOW POWER
description: At 2:35 A.M. yesterday, engineers at the Shoreham nuclear power station on Long Island raised control rods from between bundles of uranium fuel and began low-power testing of the plant, according to a spokesman for the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: THE REBELS GIVE SHOW IN SALVADOR
