description: Peasants carried signs condemning aerial bombing, a revolutionary priest spoke of ''the oppressed'' and guerrillas dressed as clowns pranced through political skits before a crowd of young children.

title: POP: REDDS AND BOYS, AT RITZ
description: NEW YORKERS may not have the schedules or the stamina of go-go music fans in Washington, where quadruple bills of go-go bands regularly play until 4 A.M. for dancers. But there was an abridged taste of the capital's nonstop funk on Friday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, when Redds and the Boys headlined a double bill of go-go with the Pump Blenders.

title: Newsweek's Publisher Gives Up That Title
description: S. H. (Steve) Price, 47 years old and publisher of Newsweek magazine since 1981, has relinquinshed that title to Gerard Smith, 42, a former agency man who joined Newsweek in January 1984, according to an announcement by Mark Edmiston, president.

title: LISTENING IN ON REAGAN: UNSANCTIONED PROGRAM
description: On Jan. 20, the day of the Super Bowl, Harry Shearer was watching television in his living room in Santa Monica, Calif., when President Reagan sauntered onto his screen and began reminiscing and telling jokes to technicians who were preparing to broadcast the President flipping the coin for the start of the game.

title: 2 Bombs Explode in Tel Aviv; Later a Mosque Is Attacked
description: Two bombs went off in the Tel Aviv area early this morning, one wounding five people and the other causing no casualties, a police spokesman said.

title: Letter: On Imports;   Oil Refiners Need Sure Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa M. Ludwig Marries H. E. J. Kahn, a Lawyer
description: Lisa Margaret Ludwig, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Warren Ludwig of New York, was married yesterday to Harold Ernest Joseph Kahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Albert Kahn of Northridge, Calif. Rabbi Gerald Raiskin performed the ceremony at the Kohl Mansion in Burlingame, Calif.

title: Filling Energy Agency Job
description: A confirmation battle looms in the Senate over the nomination of Charles Trabandt to the five-member Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the natural gas industry and wholesale transactions in electricity. The main supporter of Mr. Trabandt, formerly chief counsel of the Senate Energy Committee and currently a lawyer at the Interior Department, is said to be William Clark, former Secretary of the Interior, who has left the Government. Mr. Trabandt hopes to succeed Georgiana Sheldon, whose second term expired in October.

title: BASEBALL'S STORIED BOOKS
description: FOR nearly two decades, the Major League Baseball Players Association has been dogging the owners to open their financial ledgers. The association wanted the owners to prove that the facts backed up their contention that if they pay the players a farthing more, they'll go bust.

title: Climbing To the Summit
description: Now that President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have made a date in Geneva, planning can begin in earnest.

title: Hillary Schutzer Weds
description: Hillary Robin Schutzer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Schutzer of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin John Lent, a son of Mary Lent of Stony Point, N.Y., and the late William Lent. Rabbi David E. Fass performed the ceremony at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. The bride's father, a former State Senator from the Bronx, is assistant vice president-legislative counsel with the New York Telephone Company.

title: GORDIMER'S 'DRAMAS OF SOUTH AFRICA' ON WNET
description: Living in a poor neighborhood, the woman is a conscientious housewife - cleaning, tending to the children, trying to make life comfortable for her husband when he comes home from work exhausted. But she has also become interested in some student protests at her 15-year-old son's school. Her curiosity and common decency are her ruin. For this woman lives in South Africa, and she is Indian, a person of ''inferior'' color in a white supremacist society. Her story is told in ''A Chip of Glass Ruby,'' tonight's installment in the seven-part public television series, ''The Nadine Gordimer Stories: Dramas of South Africa.''

title: STRANGE WINS CANADIAN OPEN
description: Curtis Strange today passed the half-million dollar mark in earnings for this year when he beat Jack Nicklaus and Greg Norman by two shots and won the 76th Canadian Open.

title: The Price of Staying Home
description: A weekend visitor to an Upper West Side gym took comfort in his suffering.

title: Gentrification Actually Integrates City Neighborhoods
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 HELD IN COSTA RICA TELL OF TRIP FROM U.S. TO JOIN 'CONTRAS'
description: Two foreigners being held here on weapons charges have given detailed accounts of how, they say, they volunteered to join anti-Sandinista forces, traveled to Central America from Florida aboard a plane loaded with weapons and took part in raids in Nicaragua.

title: Obscured View Ticket
description: President Reagan, well-known as a recreational wood-chopper, may have to take up pruning as well. When the July 4 fireworks display went up Thursday evening over the Mall, hundreds of guests on the White House South Lawn moved their blankets because an enormous tree was blocking the view, but the Mr. and Mrs. Reagan, up on the Truman balcony, had to peer through and above the leaves.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POPPING UP The Boston Pops' playing fields are usually in Massachusetts, but today Boston plays New York in Central Park. The 90-piece orchestra, led by John Williams, is making its first appearance in concert on our town's central greensward, at 8 P.M. The band will perform on the Great Lawn, which is accessible through park entrances at West 81st, West 85th, East 79th and East 85th Streets.

title: GEORGIA DEMOCRATS HAIL LANCE MOVE
description: Leading Georgia Democrats said yesterday they hope to close ranks now that Bert Lance has resigned as the chairman of the state party, and turn their attention to the increasingly aggressive Republicans.

title: LOPEZ 3-SHOT WINNER
description: Nancy Lopez sank a pair of long putts and birdied four holes on the back nine today to rally from a three-stroke deficit and capture the $300,000 Hall of Fame Championship.

title: PURCHASERS CITE JUNE DOWNTURN
description: Economic activity among manufacturers continued to sag last month, the nation's purchasing managers said in their latest report, released today.

title: Missing Persons
description: The current season on the New York racing circuit has been marked by the absence of two elements that had become customary during much of the last decade: a dominant young apprentice jockey and a significant roster of women who ride regularly.

title: A Bold Deed
description: This is the story of a good deed that inspired respect and enthusiasm.

title: CAMPS OF THE SUDAN ARE FILLED BY AFRICA'S WARS AND WANT
description: It takes an experienced eye to discern order among the tiny straw-and-mud huts sprawled across the overheated desert floor southeast of the Sudanese town of Kassala.

title: IN ALGONQUIN, ILL., BALLOONS AND HUGS FOR FREEDOM
description: It began with a baptism. It ended with a hug. And in between on a day of thanksgiving, many former hostages from Trans World Airlines Flight 847 sang, prayed, chatted, ate, laughed and cried among friends, free of fear and full of joy.

title: THE COURSE: TOUGH FOR GOLFERS, EASY FOR SPECTATORS
description: THE Upper Course at Baltusrol Golf Club has two obvious attractions for the on-site spectator:

title: UNDER GORBACHEV, THE OLD REPRESSION
description: Articles appeared in the press last month about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's first 100 days. They described the Soviet leader as energetic. They told about his willingness to get out among the Soviet people and exchange views with them. They portrayed him and his family as attractive and intelligent. Yet what have these same 100 days brought for Soviet citizens who tried to express their ideas freely?

title: A Good Deed, Harshly Received
description: This is the story of a good deed that went unrewarded.

title: 17-YEAR-OLD CHAMPION: BORIS BECKER
description: In Delray Beach, Fla., last February, Boris Becker was just another promising player on the tennis tour. He walked the grounds of the condominium complex where he was staying, wearing stereo headphones and listening to music, unnoticed by those around him. He was a teen-ager far from home yet comfortable in unfamiliar surroundings.

title: PENNZOIL'S TEXACO SUIT TO START
description: The Pennzoil Company's $14 billion lawsuit against Texaco Inc. is scheduled to go to trial here Monday. The case, to be heard in state court, arises from an 18-month-old dispute over Texaco's tactics in acquiring the Getty Oil Company. Pennzoil is seeking actual damages of $7 billion plus punitive damages of $7 billion.

title: Q&A
description: QUESTION: When Bobby Riggs was a triple champion at Wimbledon in 1939, who were his opponents and partners?

title: NEW HAVEN VS. A MALL: DEFENDING DOWNTOWN
description: In the nine years since developers first proposed a major shopping mall nine miles north of this city's central business district, the only things going up have been lawyers' fees and emotions.

title: ZIMBABWE AFTER VOTE
description: At its congress last August, the ruling party adopted a plan calling for transforming this Western-modeled democracy into a socialist, one-party state ''in the fullness of time'' and in accordance with the nation's British-drafted Constitution.

title: FOR SPAIN AND PORTUGAL, ISOLATION IS ABOUT TO END
description: The entry of Spain and Portugal into the European Economic Community is expected by Iberian leaders to fundamentally change the two nations, giving rise to both hopes and concerns.

title: BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: Forty-four thousand alcoholics converged on Montreal this weekend looking for a good time, and nobody had a hangover.

title: Extend Tax-Bracket Indexing
description: New Yorkers have a bigger tax gripe than President Reagan's plan to deny deducations for state and local taxes. The real problem for people living in high-tax states is the failure to take into account the wide variations in the cost of living around the country.

title: Lenehan Winner In a Jumpoff
description: The Olympic gold medalist Leslie Burr Lenehan won her third Grand Prix horse show event of the year today, riding McLain, a black gelding owned by Debbie Dolan.

title: FARRELL ACCUSES MAYOR OF TRIGGERING VIOLENCE
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. accused Mayor Koch yesterday of fostering a climate of violence in the city and warned that widening differences between rich and poor New Yorkers could lead to ''war on these streets.''

title: FOR 'BONACKERS,' A CENTURIES-OLD LIFE ON L.I. IS FADING
description: At dawn, Stewart Lester's skiff skimmed the gold-mottled waves of Gardiners Bay, his creased eyes scanning the horizon for a telltale cloud, his senses alert to the rise of a sudden wind.

title: Hmong Pushed Back At Laos-Thai Border
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMY VIEWED AS WEAKER
description: Economists are becoming more convinced that the economy is much weaker than the data suggested only a few weeks ago, but they are less convinced that the Federal Reserve is ready to step in to perk things up right away.

title: Waste No More Time on Waste
description: It is decision time for New York City's new resource-recovery plant - a modern solution to the problem of dwindling space for the city's solid wastes. Against understandable but misguided fears that a recovery plant would be a noisome nuisance, the Planning Commission will hear disinterested experts pronounce the proposal sound. It should give their testimony full credence.

title: PHILLIPS FIGHTS SINKING OF SEABED OFF NORWAY
description: Last November, just before top executives at the Bartlesville, Okla., headquarters of the Phillips Petroleum Company became preoccupied with fighting off a takeover attempt led by T. Boone Pickens, they got some bad news from company officials responsible for operating the Ekofisk field in the North Sea southwest of here.

title: Ambitious Agency In Seattle
description: LIKE the people who run Fallon McElligott Rice of Minneapolis, Roger Livingston of Livingston & Company, Seattle, is determined to force his agency into the consciousness of the industry through success at award shows.

title: Miller: More to Learn and More to Earn
description: DESPITE four victories so far this year, including the Nabisco Dinah Shore Tournament, and a Ladies Professional Golf Association one-year earnings record of $318,250, with more to come, Alice Miller still does not whack the golf ball as well as she can, according to her teacher, Ed Oldfield. Miss Miller agrees.

title: '75 BANKRUPTCY SCARE ALTERS CITY PLANS INTO 21ST CENTURY
description: New York's brush with bankruptcy a decade ago has changed not only the city, but also the way the people responsible for the city's future are charting its course into the next century.

title: Now Find Wallenberg
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Guerrilla Suspects Seized in Basque Area
description: The Spanish police have arrested 18 suspected members of the Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: BUSH'S TRIP TO EUROPE: GOALS, HOPES, LOGISTICS
description: A traveling party of 120, four aircraft and seven advance groups working with scores of embassy officials to plan a virtually minute-by-minute schedule - that is what it took to get Vice President Bush around seven Western European countries from June 23 to July 4.

title: Bridge: Busy Career of Barry Crane Led to More Than 500 Titles
description: The death Friday of Barry Crane, who was found bludgeoned at his home in Studio City, Calif., ended one of the most remarkable careers in the history of bridge.

title: Expos Beat Astros By 6-3 in 19 Innings
description: An error by the Houston first baseman Enos Cabell with two outs in the 19th inning allowed the tie-breaking run to score, and Mike Fitzgerald's single provided two more runs as the Montreal Expos beat the Houston Astros, 6-3, tonight.

title: RAILROAD ISSUES AND ECONOMY
description: ALTHOUGH railroad traffic has been disappointing so far in 1985, stocks of several leading railroads are selling at near-record prices. Their renewed popularity, Wall Street analysts said, mainly reflects investor hopes for an extension of the economic recovery.

title: FROM KABUKI TO MOZART, SUMMER OFFERS DIVERSITY AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: At Lincoln Center, the seasons change a little differently than for the rest of us. New York's weather watchers might disagree, but today really marks the center's own personal equinox - when one rush of events ends, fresh breath is quickly drawn and a whole different set begins.

title: Sugar Study In Philippines
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, President of the Philippines, today ordered a new study to restore the viability of the distressed sugar industry.

title: SIMILARITIES ADD TO RIVALRY OF BUSINESS TABLOIDS
description: The newspaper vendor at Grand Central Terminal was adamant. ''Crain's New York City Business,'' he said, pushing the tabloid toward the customer who had asked for a copy of ''City Business.''

title: MELONS ORDERED DESTROYED IN WEST
description: Ten million watermelons on grocery shelves were ordered destroyed today because of a wave of illnesses in the West that was linked to a pesticide used on some of the fruit, officials said.

title: HARVARD DEFEATS PRINCETON AT HENLEY
description: In the first all-American final of the Grand Challenge Cup in the 146-year history of the Henley Royal Regatta, Harvard University defeated Princeton today and gained the most prestigious title in this oldest of all rowing regattas.

title: AS MEXICANS VOTE, OPPOSITION PARTY IS HOPING FOR A BREAKTHROUGH
description: In urban centers and dusty villages, Mexicans voted today in nationwide elections that are viewed as an important midterm test of the policies of President Miguel de la Madrid.

title: Lynch Wins 1,500 Race In National Youth Meet
description: Shola Lynch, running ''with more confidence than I have had all year,'' won the 1,500-meter run today in the intermediate girls' division (15-16 years old) as The Athletics Congress National Youth Track and Field Championships ended at Mitchel Park here.

title: FUGITIVE'S RETURN TO COAST IS SOUGHT
description: ULaw-enforcement officers from the United States flew to Canada today to seek the extradition of Charles Chitat Ng, the fugitive sought for a month by the authorities in connection with the discoveries of bodies, weapons and torture videotapes at a remote California cabin.

title: U.S. Team Wins
description: The American All-Stars cricket team scored 98 runs in just under two hours to defeat the national team of Grenada today at Memorial Field in Mount Vernon. Strong bowling by Arthur Joseph, Ian Grant, and Richard Weir helped the Americans hold Grenada to 97 runs in the first three hours of play. Ralph Weekes led the American attack with 40 runs.

title: MUSIC: ELLEN FOLEY AT GREENE STREET
description: ELLEN FOLEY, who plays a defense attorney on the television series ''Night Court,'' is showing another side of her talent on Friday nights at Upstairs at Greene Street, the cabaret room above the Greene Street Cafe. Miss Foley, who is lithe and lively and blonde, is performing an act that is an unusual mixture of material notable not only for its sources, which include Rodgers and Hart, Bernstein and Sondheim, Weill and Brecht, as well as Randy Newman, Harry Nilsson and the team of Dave Frishberg and Blossom Dearie, but for the way in which she uses their songs.

title: An Oil Surplus - for Now
description: The crisis in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is clear to everyone. Hardly recognized, however, is the extent to which the second oil price shock - the rapid rise in prices between 1979 and 1981 - is almost over, at least for the American consumer.

title: BURGER CONDEMNS SOME LAWYER ADS
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger told an American Bar Association panel today that some advertising by lawyers is ''sheer shysterism,'' according to those familiar with his remarks. Furthermore, he recommended that people ''never'' hire lawyers who advertise.

title: Pontiac to Smithsonian
description: For the first time, the Smithsonian Institution has officially recognized the stock car as a significant form of American transportation. For inclusion in the National Museum of American History's Hall of Transportation, along with the locomotive, the covered wagon and the high-wheel bicycle, the institution accepted this week the 1984 Pontiac in which Richard Petty won his 200th Grand National race, the Daytona Firecracker 400, on July 4, 1984.

title: Scattershot Approach To Sassoon Men's Line
description: For its client Vidal Sassoon, Peter Rogers Associates will use a bit of a scattershot approach to promote products in the Styling Group for Men.

title: Philippine Bank Closure
description: The Pacific Banking Corporation, a major Philippine commercial bank, was put into receivership Friday, the central bank announced today. Pacific was the third major bank to be closed down this year. The central bank said it had 60 days to decide whether the bank should be permitted to resume business or be liquidated.

title: OPEC ENDS MEETING WITHOUT DECISION ON POLICY CHANGES
description: OPEC oil ministers left for home tonight, having failed in three days of talks to agree to any changes in the group's pricing or production of oil.

title: Canada Acts on Apartheid
description: Canada has tightened the rules for companies doing business with South Africa to reflect what officials say is a ''rising tide of revulsion'' against apartheid.

title: Storm Causes Blackout In Almost All of Utah
description: Power was knocked out for about eight hours in much of Utah Saturday night when lightning struck a substation that exploded, sending a ball of fire 70 feet high.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Now, we can get on with the rest of our lives.'' - George Lazansky, former hijacking hostage. [A12:2.]

title: Pittsburgh Trolley Fans Take One Last Ride
description: Trolley fans from across the country took a final ride on Pittsburgh's streetcars today as the electricity that has powered the system for 126 years was turned off for the last time.

title: 2 L.I. Men Are Killed In Car After $4 Theft
description: Two Long Island men fleeing with companions from a $4 robbery were killed early today when their car overturned after being chased by a vehicle driven by the victims of the theft, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Where to Fix the Rackets Law
description: Alarmed that a law aimed at mobsters was being used more against legitimate businesses, the U.S. Court of Appeals in New York performed legislative surgery last year. It construed ''Rico'' - the 1970 Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act - in a way that eviscerated its provision for private lawsuits by victims of organized crime.

title: LLOYD RIVALRY MOTIVATES NAVRATILOVA
description: The preparation is the toughest part, Martina Navratilova said. Finding the motivation to practice every day for long hours doesn't get any easier when a player gets older and has achieved most of her goals in tennis. It may be human nature to slack off and look for a short-cut or two, but Miss Navratilova has avoided that pitfall thus far.

title: Soft On Brokers
description: In excoriating the Meese Justice Department last month for its criminal-coddling disposition of the E. F. Hutton check-kiting case, I noted that the errant firm's former president, George L. Ball, left Hutton only a few months after the grand jury investigation began, to take the job as chief executive officer at Prudential-Bache Securities, Inc.

title: STARS WIN, GAIN CHAMPIONSHIP BERTH
description: Four big plays for touchdowns, two scored by Kelvin Bryant, gave the Baltimore Stars an easy playoff victory over the Birmingham Stallions in 90-degree heat at Legion Field today.

title: People
description: Bob Fudge, Peter Kellogg, Deborah Kushnick, Laurie Ellen Murphy and Ralph Palamidessi have been promoted to senior vice presidents at SSC&B:Lintas USA, where John Lerch, a senior vice president, has added the title of group creative director.

title: Terrorism Is a Specialized Kind of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: SPENCE-CHAPIN ENDING FOSTER-CARE PROGRAM
description: One of the city's oldest private welfare agencies is facing cutbacks in both personnel and programs because of financial difficulties, according to its executive director.

title: Dogfight of the Decade
description: In the torrid skies above Capitol Hill there rages an extraordinary dogfight. The contenders are the F-20 fighter made by Northrop and the F-16 built by General Dynamics. Spectators can watch with awe as the two planes make maneuvers seldom before seen in Washington. It's an instructive sight.

title: Tests Indicate Cocaine Is Deadlier Than Heroin
description: Laboratory animals given free access to cocaine died at almost three times the rate of those given access to heroin, a new study has found.

title: FOR ARCTIC BASE, SATELLITE TV PROVIDES THE OUTSIDE WORLD
description: Satellite television fought depression at Mould Bay, 76 degrees north latitude, 900 miles from the North Pole, an isolated base so cold but windless that it's sometimes called ''the garden spot of the Arctic.'' Eleven Canadian officers of the Atmospheric Environment Service use the 10-foot dish that sits on the tundra as a social link to the outside world.

title: Dream Doesn't Die
description: He played as a freshman at Auburn when the stars of Southeastern Conference basketball were Dan Issel and Pete Maravich. And, with a team-leading 16.7-point average, he was certainly not just another guy on the court. But Gary Franks attended fewer classes than basketball practices and quickly flunked out.

title: MUSIC: LES MISERABLES BRASS BAND AT THE PUBLIC
description: FOR Les Miserables Brass Band, oompah is the universal language. Last Monday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, the 10-member group and its guest, the trumpeter Lester Bowie from the Art Ensemble of Chicago, played music from Serbia, Bolivia, Italy, Macedonia, Brazil and West Africa, along with selections from the Eureka Brass Band in New Orelans and Kool and the Gang.

title: Emmerling Shop Wins Italian Leather Account
description: John Emmerling Inc. has just won a five-agency competition for a $1 million assignment from the Italian Trade Commission to promote leather goods. And that competition, Mr. Emmerling reported yesterday, was conducted without meeting the prospective client.

title: Topics;   Open Doors Contra Justice
description: It sets a poor example for the conduct Americans expect of Nicaragua to have the Immigration Service harass a Nicaraguan exile who dares to criticize ''contra'' rebel operation.

title: Drug Helps Stem Pathologic Crying
description: FOR some victims of multiple sclerosis, strokes, brain injury or other diseases that damage the part of the brain that controls the motor system for emotional expression, there is a cruel but common side effect: uncontrollable laughing or weeping.

title: Jefferson County
description: Jefferson County, Ky., yesterday tentatively priced at par, $65 million of pollution control revenue bonds, 1985 series A, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Lord, Geller, Federico Promoting Health Plan
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein is one of the few New York agencies blessed with a Boca Raton, Fla., office.

title: CITICORP, THE INVESTMENT BANK
description: Running the world's largest commercial bank has never stopped Citicorp executives from dreaming of other new - and profitable - frontiers to conquer. For years, despite Federal laws prohibiting commercial banks from underwriting corporate securities, the bank has tried to become an investment banking powerhouse. Now, after a sputtering start, it believes it has hit upon the right strategy.

title: CHRISTIE'S FALSE AUCTION REPORT REVIVES DEBATE IN ART WORLD
description: An admitted false statement by the chairman of Christie's that the auction house had sold three paintings instead of only one in a major Impressionist sale in 1981 was an isolated incident, art world professionals said yesterday. But it has revived a longstanding debate by art buyers, art dealers and auction houses over fair auction practices, and renewed concerns that similar cases may have gone undiscovered.

title: 10 TO 20% RENT RISES SEEN WITH TAX PLAN
description: Apartment dwellers could see rent levels rise by as much as 10 to 20 percent over the next several years under President Reagan's tax revision plan, according to recently completed studies.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Transsexual Loses Election
description: A decorated Korean War veteran who had a sex-change operation 12 years ago was defeated today in an election to head an American Legion post here. The veteran, Bridgette Poi, 50 years old, who is the senior vice president of John Coleman Prince Post 9, lost by a vote of 23 to 13 to Joseph Ottaviano, the incumbent commander. A third candidate, John Cables, received 10 votes. Mrs. Poi said, ''When the membership is 325, those numbers tell me nothing.''

title: CLUB MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
POPULAR BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains made on the sale of securities of $516,618 in the quarter and $859,911 in the six months. c-Including gains made on the sale of securities of $99 in the quarter and $31,640 in the six months.

title: Soil Temperature and Roots
description: Department of Agriculture scientists have discovered that if the soil in which food crops grow is relatively chilly, the mature plants will contain less zinc and other trace minerals than normal. Such trace minerals are necessary for human health.

title: BENNETT MARKS OUT NEW RESEARCH PATH
description: EDUCATION Secretary William J. Bennett has asked education researchers to study new questions about course content, student conduct and parental choice that he believes are central to improving American schools.

title: REDEFINING 'BABY BOOMERS'
description: I am a charter member of the postwar ''baby boom'' generation. I live in a city and use a computer at work. Several times a week, I jog to a health club where I work out on Nautilus machines. I may be a young urban professional, but I'm no yuppie.

title: Bank Group Head Named at Hanover
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday named C. William Schroth, a senior vice president and head of its United States merchant banking activities, to head its merchant banking group worldwide. He succeeds Stephen Antony Constance, 45 years old, who plans to leave the bank in September.

title: Short-Term Rates Mostly Up
description: Short-term interest rates rose sharply in light trading yesterday, as doubts arose again among traders about possible monetary policy action by the Federal Reserve and the future course of the economy.

title: RATE CONCERNS SEND DOW DOWN 6.04
description: The stock market yesterday stumbled through another session of moderate volume in which prices dropped as investors debated the leanings of the Federal Reserve toward interest rates.

title: Moody's Posts Rating Shifts
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered the debt rating of the International Paper Company and raised the rating of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company. The companies have a total of $2.4 billion of debt outstanding.

title: Sandinistas Would Fight Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Stop and Shop
description: Stop and Shop Companies, a Boston-based retailer, is offering $125 million of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The notes carry a 10 3/4 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99 3/4, to yield 10.79 percent. They are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: LUFKIN UNIT IS BOUGHT BY REFCO
description: Refco Inc., one of the world's largest futures brokers, today purchased the futures division of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.

title: S.E.C. Report On Carnation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Carnation Company had permitted the dissemination of false and misleading information relating to the 1984 acquisition talks between Nestle S.A. of Switzerland and Carnation.

title: Not a Pseudo-Event
description: Back in the 1950's, someone coined the term ''pseudo-event'' to describe happenings contrived solely to appear on television. Pseudo-events, in this usage, would not have happened had there been no cameras available to film them. But 30 years later, it's the other way around - events outside our private lives lack a certain reality, they become for most of us pseudo-events, if they do not appear on television.

title: S.E.C. Commissioner Leaves After 13 Months
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is losing another commissioner, Charles L. Marinaccio, leaving only three members on the five-member board.

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Cellular Telephone Co. Chooses Levy, Flaxman
description: There was much jubilation at Levy, Flaxman & Associates yesterday when the troops found out that the agency had just landed its biggest account, the Cellular Telephone Company of New York.

title: Man Is Arrested In Darien Slaying
description: A young South Norwalk man was arrested today and charged with murdering a Darien man and attacking his wife last week, the police said.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of Alliance Mortgage Co. of $41,313,000, or $3.43 a share.

title: WIMBLEDON BREAKFAST: A DASH OF CREAM
description: The indigestion arrived before room service did. ''Breakfast at Wimbledon,'' NBC's annual morning celebration of tennis that, because of the time difference between here and there, usually interferes with mornings-after, began Saturday with one of television's most ancient and hallowed re-runs, Martina Navratilova against Chris Evert Lloyd.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
EDITED ARCHITECTS' MAGAZINE
description: Walter Frederick Wagner Jr., longtime editor in chief of the magazine Architectural Record, died of heart disease Saturday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $22,000.

title: Peking Finance Talks
description: Twenty senior executives from London's financial district, led by the Earl of Limerick, opened a two-day seminar here today to instruct Chinese officials about international finance.

title: Zimbabwe Is Still Special, for Now
description: Zimbabwe's ethnic majority, the Shona-speaking tribes, have now given a strong vote of confidence in a free election to Prime Minister Robert Mugabe. Meanwhile the country's minorities, the Ndebele-speakers and the whites, have celebrated their constitutional rights by electing representatives Mr. Mugabe finds distasteful.

title: Cancer in Passive Smokers
description: Living with people who smoke greatly increases a person's risk of developing cancer, a survey by the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences has determined. The increased risk applied to smokers and nonsmokers alike.

title: Topics;   Open Doors Summer Job
description: The plight of the homeless is most compelling in winter. But though public interest fades in summer, not all the homeless do.

title: SOME ISSUERS REMOVE HUTTON AS UNDERWRITER
description: E.F. Hutton & Company is facing the loss of some important customers in its municipal finance division, traditionally one of its strongest lines of business, as a result of the firm's plea of guilty in May to charges that it had defrauded a number of banks through a check overdraft scheme.

title: Borg to Return Home
description: Bjorn Borg plans to leave Monte Carlo, Monaco, and move back to his homeland because ''my heart beats for Sweden.''

title: DEAN WITTER AGREES TO LEASE 24 FLOORS OF THE TRADE CENTER
description: The Port Authority, seeking private tenants to replace state agencies in World Trade Center offices, yesterday announced a $700 million, 20-year lease with Dean Witter Financial Services.

title: ICONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Strawberry Is Swayed
description: Darryl Strawberry said he gave considerable thought to passing up the All-Star Game next Tuesday night in Minnesota because of a thumb injury two months ago that cost him and the Mets a good part of his season. But he has changed his mind, if he is selected.

title: First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp sold $100 million of five-year extendible notes. The notes, which carry a final maturity of Aug. 15, 2000, were won at competitive bid by Shearson Lehman Brothers. They were reoffered with a 9.70 percent coupon at a price of 99.583 to yield 9.80 percent. The offering has been rated A-minus by McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, AA-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

title: SHOUTING CALLED BEST FIRE ALARM FOR JERSEY PARK
description: A fire-protection engineer testified today that heat or smoke detectors would have been less ''credible'' alarms than ''a shout of 'Fire' '' during the fatal blaze at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park last year.

title: ALBANY REPUBLICANS OFFER PLAN TO MERGE TRIAL COURTS
description: New York's hodgepodge of trial courts would be merged into one statewide system under a proposal made today by Republican leaders of the State Senate.

title: Chess: 2 BOROUGH PLAYERS AND ISRAELI WIN BROOKLYN COLLEGE OPEN
description: Dimitri London, a 22-year-old master, and Joel Benjamin, a 21-year-old international master, both of Brooklyn, and Yehuda Gruenfeld, a 29-year-old Israeli grandmaster, tied for first in the Brooklyn College Open. Each scored 3 1/2- 1/2 in the four-round, 34-player Swiss-system tourney.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 9, 1985
description: International

title: Melville Unit Names Chief
description: Gerald L. Kanter, who resigned as president of Ames Department Stores Inc. in May, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Melville Corporation's Marshalls Inc. subsidiary, the company said today.

title: Ladbroke Buys Rodeway Inns
description: The Ladbroke Group P.L.C., a British-based hotel, realty and racing concern, said that it had acquired Rodeway Inns International, which runs a chain of 138 franchised hotels in the United States, for $13 million.

title: . . . and Tough Cans
description: While the Sanitation Department was looking for a better bag, We Care About New York Inc. was looking for a better basket.

title: Baxter Pact Is Canceled
description: In a retaliatory move, the Hospital Corporation of America canceled a $100 million contract with Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., a company that so far has successfully blocked Hospital Corporation's planned merger with the American Hospital Supply Corporation.

title: A WINDOW SCENE: THE SHORT STORY A LA GALLANT
description: Sitting on a sofa in her apartment, next to a large window overlooking the Rue Jean Ferrandi on the Left Bank, Mavis Gallant was talking about the short story.

title: Matchmaking Continues
description: The Nets are the only coachless team in the National Basketball Association, but they are making progress. According to Bernie Mann, president of the team, the list of candidates has been narrowed to four men.

title: JOHN SCARNE, GAMBLING EXPERT
description: John Scarne, an international authority on games and gambling, died Sunday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in North Bergen, N.J.

title: Southwestern Bell Acquisition Terms
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation's $120 million purchase of Continental Telecom Inc.'s Mast Advertising and Publishing Inc. will expand the company's Yellow Page directories business from 5 to 48 states, Southwestern Bell said.

title: U.S., REBUFFED BY ALLIES, SOFTENS LANGUAGE ON BEIRUT AIR BOYCOTT
description: The Reagan Administration, in an effort to head off a possible Arab boycott of American airliners and ships, said today that its plan to isolate Beirut airport was not meant to punish Lebanon.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Theft Rings Said To Recruit Youths
description: Juveniles are being recruited from playgrounds and schoolyards to steal cars in exchange for drugs and money, the police said today.

title: I.B.M.'s 30-Year Bonds Set to Yield 10.572%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, like hundreds of companies that have jumped into the bond market in recent weeks for relatively low-cost financing, is offering $500 million of 30-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: New Posts For Editors At Times
description: The New York Times yesterday named John M. Lee, business/financial editor, to be an assistant to the executive editor.

title: New York Adds New Weapons In the War Against Dropping Out
description: WHEN school starts in New York City in September all 80,000 high school freshmen will get a certificate of admission to a college of the City University redeemable upon graduation. In addition, efforts are under way to pledge jobs in the private or public sector to these 9th graders if they complete high school.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in some editions yesterday on the convention of the American Bar Association incorrectly listed the only living former members of the Supreme Court. They are Arthur J. Goldberg and Potter Stewart.

title: Careers;   Promoting Shelved Products
description: MORE and more companies with products that they never got around to introducing are eyeing these shelved items with renewed interest, wondering how to unleash their commercial possibilities.

title: L.I. Building Inspector Fined And Given a 30-Day Jail Term
description: A Hempstead town building inspector who was convicted of accepting $50 to approve a construction project was sentenced today to 30 days in jail and fined $1,000.

title: Artificial Heart Patients Take Short Excursions
description: The two surviving artificial heart patients in Louisville, Ky., went for short excursions Sunday, according to a hospital spokesman.

title: Williams Trial Set
description: A judge refused yesterday to throw out sports bribery charges against John (Hot Rod) Williams and set an Aug. 5 trial date for the former Tulane basketball player.

title: Social Security Is Not Federal Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ROCKHOPPER,' SECRET AGENT, ON CBS
description: Television is desperate for a laugh these days. That's the message to be plucked from the scattering of situation-comedy pilots for shows that have not been - and may never be -selected for the regular weekly schedule. For instance, tonight's ''Rockhopper,'' on CBS at 8:30 o'clock, tries to be funny about working for an organization resembling the Central Intelligence Agency. The Americans may be silly, but oh those Russians!

title: Escapist Software
description: INSTEAD of stocking up on escapist novels to pass the time this summer, computer owners might consider stocking up on escapist software. Here are some unusual games and diversions.

title: ART COMMISSION APPROVES TRACK IN CORONA PARK
description: The city's Art Commission last night gave narrow approval to the construction of a Grand Prix auto race track in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Making Sense of Gun Control
description: The reasonable foundation of America's gun policy is that localities may control who owns a gun by controlling who may buy one. Ideally, by stressing local interests it should be possible to reconcile the needs of rural hunters and collectors and the desperate need of cities to limit handguns.

title: John Joining A's
description: Tommy John has agreed to join the Oakland A's and was to be in uniform last night for the game against the Red Sox.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bond Offering By Minnesota
description: Minnesota is offering almost $52 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: Results for the latest quarter include operations of Foodarama retail stores aquired in January 1985.

title: INTELLIGENCE EXPERTS GIVE ACCOUNT OF HOW THEY THINK SPIES WORKED
description: Federal officials and intelligence analysts say that John A. Walker Jr. passed Navy secrets to the K.G.B. in an elaborate scheme that they believe involved espionage training in Austria and the use of Soviet couriers in Washington.

title: No Spoils for Victor
description: Floyd Youmans, the former Met minor leaguer who was sent to the Montreal Expos as part of the trade for Gary Carter, pitched the last three innings of the 19-inning 6-3 victory over the Houston Astros for his first major-league victory Sunday. That was hours after he learned before the game that he would be sent down to Indianapolis, the Expos' American Association affiliate, to make room for the pitcher Bill Gullickson, who is due to come off the 21-day disabled list. A dropped ball at first base helped end the game that lasted 5 hours 12 minutes.

title: THERMODYNETICS INC(0) reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $22,757 for the latest year and $60,699 for the previous year.

title: Article 107428 -- No Title
description: The Kaypro Corporation, citing inventory valuation changes, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $6.2 million in the third fiscal quarter of 1985 in contrast to earnings of $3.2 million, or 9 cents a share, in the corresponding three months a year earlier.

title: 2 Cubs Disabled
description: The Cubs placed the Cy Young Award winner, Rick Sutcliffe, and the outfielder, Gary Matthews, on the 15-day disabled list, each for the second time this season. Sutcliffe (7-7), who has a strained groin muscle, was put on the list the first time May 20 because of a hamstring injury.

title: Woodside Heads Whitney
description: William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Can Company, was named president of the Board of Trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art at a special meeting of the board on June 26. Mr. Woodside succeeds Flora Miller Biddle, who was elected chairman on the retirement of Howard Lipman, who will remain a trustee.

title: THORPE POSTS 67
description: Jim Thorpe and Lonnie Nielsen, neighbors in the Buffalo region and veterans of the PGA Tour, tied for the lead today in the first round of the three-day Michelob New York State Open. They each shot four-under-par 67s over the Big G course of Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club.

title: PUBLISHERS PLAN STAKE IN TELERATE
description: In a move expected to intensify competition among suppliers of financial information to brokers and dealers, Dow Jones & Company and the Oklahoma Publishing Company said yesterday that they would buy a majority interest in Telerate Inc.

title: Health and Business;   Labor's Effort To Curb Costs
description: IN the struggle to contain health-care costs, labor unions have often been attacked as being part of the problem. Labor leaders have always disagreed, obviously, and now many unions are working with managers to eliminate waste and stretch the health dollar.

title: MUSIC: BERNSTEIN AT JONES BEACH
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN is not shy about his patriotism, and his concert with the National Symphony at Jones Beach Sunday evening was a long, enthusiastic, occasionally uproarious, if slightly delayed, tribute to the Fourth of July. Mr. Bernstein conducted his ''Songfest'' - which he wrote for the United States Bicentennial - his Symphonic Dances from ''West Side Story'' and finally one of his favorite pieces of Americana, ''The Stars and Stripes Forever'' by John Philip Sousa.

title: Market Place;   Stocks Seen Topping Bonds
description: MARTIN D. SASS, who heads the money management firm of M.D. Sass Investors Services, believes that stocks will outperform bonds in the second half of 1985. Accordingly, he has changed the mix of the $1.7 billion of assets tended by the firm slightly in favor of equities.

title: PRECISE ESKIMO DIALECT THREATENED WITH EXTINCTION
description: THE Inuvialuktun Language Project has embarked on a venture more curious than selling iceboxes to Eskimos. It is teaching them how to speak their own disappearing dialects.

title: Offshore Drilling Up
description: Utilization of offshore mobile drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico this week rose to 73.8 percent from 72.4 percent last week with four fewer rigs idle and 189 contracted in the fleet of 256, Offshore Data Services said today.

title: 'Art of Insane' Extended
description: ''Selections From the Prinzhorn Collection: The Art of the Insane'' will be shown at the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York in Purchase, N.Y., from Sept. 22 to Dec. 22. On June 30, the collection finished what was to have been its last showing, at the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art in Ithaca, N.Y. Because of the exhibition's popularity, however, the Neuberger Museum extended its run in its own galleries.

title: Montedison Purchase
description: Montedison, Italy's largest chemical concern, confirmed today that it had gained control of a sizable stake in one of the country's most powerful finance groups, Bi-Invest. A Montedison spokesman said the company chairman, Mario Schimberni, had informed the Italian stock exchange authority, Consob, that it now held 36.8 million shares, or 37 percent, of Bi-Invest, a group with interests in insurance, property and industry.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net income. Corrected from Tuesday, July 2.

title: Prudential Plan
description: The Prudential Insurance Company and the Great Western Financial Corporation have agreed to a nationwide, adjustable-rate residential mortgage loan origination program, the companies announced.

title: Toyota Seen Close To Plant Decision
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan is close to a decision on building an auto assembly plant in the United States and has discussed sites near Nashville and Kansas City, Mo., sources said today.

title: A PLAN FOR LINCOLN CENTER THEATERS
description: Several artistic and financial initiatives involving the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse Theaters are under way, one week after Gregory Mosher and Bernard Gersten assumed control of the two Lincoln Center houses.

title: British Lift Argentine Ban
description: In a bid to normalize relations, Britain announced today that it was lifting a ban on imports from Argentina, imposed at the start of the 1982 Falkland war.

title: Goodrich Plant
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said it was closing its Exeter, Pa., nylon tire fabric plant, which serves mostly truck, off-road and farm markets and employs 160. It said it has excess capacity for nylon tire fabric, which will continue to be produced at Thomaston, Ga. Goodrich said the closing was part of its previously announced restructuring.

title: Beachbound
description: The temperature was already near 90 degrees, and it was not yet noon.

title: HUMAN TESTS BEGIN IN EFFORT TO MAKE CANCER CELLS MORE NORMAL
description: Tests have begun in humans of a new anticancer drug that operates on a radically different principle than conventional cancer drugs. Instead of killing cancer cells with toxic chemicals, the standard approach, the new drug seeks to change the cancer cells so that they stop their uncontrolled proliferation and resume more normal behavior.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Pantry Pride Fills Key Post
description: Pantry Pride Inc., said it had named Bruce Slovin, 49 years old, as president of the supermarket and retail chain. Mr. Slovin is also president of MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., the closely held New York company that controls Pantry Pride.

title: OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results were translated at the rate of 3.483 Dutch guilders per $1.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FEATHER-LIGHT PLANE POINTS TOWARD A GLOBAL RECORD
description: NEARLY a quarter of a century ago, a B-52H jet bomber flew 12,532 miles from Okinawa to Spain to establish the distance record for nonstop, unrefueled flight. That record has never been beaten, and all attempts since 1962 have been thwarted by the performance limitations inherent in conventional aircraft.

title: G.M. to Upgrade Assembly Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would spend $600 million on modernizing its assembly plants in Linden, N.J., and Wilmington, Del.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cray Research Inc., Minneapolis, said British Petroleum Co. had awarded it a contract for the installation of a computer valued at $7.5 million.

title: Orderly Government Is the Issue in Head Start Dismissal
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Tough City, Tough Garbage Bags . . .
description: When it comes to plastic garbage bags, the Sanitation Department has just about reached the breaking point.

title: Bridge: A Favorite Partner of Crane Leads His Team to Victory
description: A favorite partner of Barry Crane, the bridge master who was killed last week, took his place at the knockout event in the Bridge Week regional tournament at Pasadena, Calif., and helped lead Mr. Crane's team to victory.

title: EALING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No New Offer, Storer Says
description: Storer Communications Inc.'s stock rose yesterday on rumors that a new bidder might emerge for the company, but a spokesman said no new offers had been received.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HAILE SELASSIE'S WAR. The Italian-Ethiopian Campaign, 1935-1941. By Anthony Mockler. 454 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $24.95. FOR most of us, if we think of it at all, the war between Italy and Ethiopia in the 1930's - the Abyssinian War, as it used to be called - is chiefly memorable as a landmark on the road leading to World War II. It conjures up images of Mussolini vociferating from a balcony, or of Haile Selassie addressing the League of Nations; but beyond a vague impression of defenseless natives being bombed, few people today are likely to have much idea of what happened in Ethiopia itself.

title: Fish Kill Reported in Texas River
description: A long stretch of oxygen-poor water in the Trinity River suffocated so many fish over the weekend that wildlife officials predicted the kill would surpass a series of 1984 kills that wiped out some 171,000 fish.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Danish Bicyclist Wins Tour Stage
description: Jorgen Pedersen of Denmark won the 10th stage of the Tour de France today in 5 hours 6 minutes 27 seconds.

title: CORRECTION
description: A San Francisco dispatch last Thursday on deaths linked to a cabin in rural California misstated the location of Sudbury, Ontario, where a suspect in the case was reported sighted. Sudbury is about 250 miles north of Toronto.

title: Unsers Excel
description: For the second straight week, this time at the Cleveland Grand Prix Sunday, Al Unser Sr. finished third behind his son, Al Unser Jr. No father-son team has finished better in an Indy-type car race.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL ADOPTS NEW RULES ON RESUSCITATION
description: New York Hospital, in an agreement in the case of a woman who died after emergency lifesaving measures were withheld without her or her family's consent, said yesterday that it was adopting written rules for witholding such procedures.

title: WAYS OF STOPPING HIJACKINGS FOUND READY BUT LITTLE USED
description: Nearly all airline hijackings and terrorism could be foiled by currently available security devices and procedures, but few air carriers or countries apply them sufficiently, security experts say.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Trial Setback For Texaco
description: A state district judge granted a Pennzoil Company motion today to sever a Texaco Inc. counterclaim from Pennzoil's $14 billion damage suit against Texaco.

title: Advertising;   Autonomy for Agencies
description: HAVING subsidiary ad agencies that are totally autonomous is not the great idea it was once thought to be, as far as Robert E. Jacoby is concerned. And agencies that in the future snuggle up to what he calls ''mother cow'' will not be treated quite so distantly, the chairman, president and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide suggests.

title: Ex-Sunkist Chief Finds Niche at Haagen-Dazs
description: Mark L. Stevens says he has always liked Haagen-Dazs ice cream. But it was not his favorite flavor, coffee, that lured him to Haagen-Dazs as president and general manager.

title: 'CREO,' AS IN 'I CREATE'
description: THE score is 14 musicales down and 12 to go before the celebration of Johann Sebastian Bach's 300th birthday ends this year. Yet the rain of invitations for these private concerts still has some would-be guests confused.

title: CONCERT: A U.S. PREMIERE FOR MOZART
description: THE opening concert of the Mostly Mozart Festival did not stint on attractions. In fact, Gerard Schwarz, the festival's music director, filled the cookie jar to the brim. Last night's program began with the American premiere of a Mozart symphony, then brought on Horacio Gutierrez as piano soloist in a Mozart concerto, continued with Elly Ameling as soprano soloist in two Mozart concert arias and finished with another Mozart symphony, not a premiere.

title: STIEB AND BLU JAYS SHUT OFF MARINERS
description: Dave Stieb and Jim Acker combined on a seven-hitter tonight, leading the Toronto Blue Jays to a 4-0 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Disservice Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in SportsMonday in some editions yesterday of the Dwyer Stakes at Belmont Park showed an incorrect winning margin for Stephan's Odyssey. He won by a neck.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CROSSING over has become a fairly common phenomenon in the fashion world, with clothing designers doing lines of accessories and accessory designers doing lines of ready-to-wear. The theory is that if you can design one thing, you can design anything. One of the latest to try crossing over into sportswear is Arlene La Marca, who made her name designing sexy shoes. She has now added a collection of sportswear that is, in its own way, equally sexy.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ANKLE SOCKS KICK UP HEELS
description: They've been making their appearances rather slowly over the last few months - but the recent good weather seems to have brought them out in droves. Ankle socks are making a comeback.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SHIFT SOUGHT FOR STATES TAXING MULTINATIONALS
description: The Reagan Administration today suggested legislation that would discourage states from taxing multinational corporations on profits earned outside the United States.

title: Mesa to Buy Back 10% of Stock
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it would spend up to $100 million to purchase 6.9 million of its shares, about 10 percent of its outstanding common stock. The amount allocated for the buyback plan is based on the $14.50 Friday closing price of Mesa shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A SEQUEL TO 'ALIEN' READY TO GO INTO PRODUCTION
description: As another proof that sequels are big business in Hollywood right now, James Cameron, the co-writer and director of ''The Terminator,'' has written and will direct ''Aliens,'' a sequel to 20th Century-Fox's 1979 science fiction horror movie, ''Alien.''

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $175,000, or four cents a share, for the quarter and $264,000, or seven cents a share, for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $91,000, or five cents a share, for the quarter and $167,000, or eight cents a share, for the six months.

title: Topics;   Open Doors Teen-Age Champ
description: Boris Becker, the youngest winner of the men's singles title in the history of Wimbledon, isn't perfect. Powerful, energetic, even-tempered, he is also a bum - a strawberry blond 1985-style tennis bum.

title: DOLLAR FALLS BROADLY TO '85 LOW
description: The dollar tumbled yesterday to its lowest level in almost eight months, amid widespread sentiment that a weak economy is likely to push it significantly lower in the coming weeks and months.

title: The Oil Glut's Not for Gloating
description: With petroleum prices tumbling, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is reduced to a quarreling club of cousins, each trying to avoid the lunch check. But the temptation to gloat should be resisted. Oil gluts have come and gone before. The price of prolonging the present one is, for a change, sensible planning.

title: At the Head Of the Petition Parade
description: This is petition week for politicians.

title: HELPED BUILD PUBLISHING EMPIRE
description: Gardner Cowles Jr., founder and publisher of Look magazine and head of one branch of a family communications empire that included newspapers, magazines, book publishing and television stations, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital.

title: SALES DECLINE JOLTS CONNECTICUT GUN MAKERS
description: Americans are buying far fewer new firearms in the 1980's than they did in the 1960's and 1970's, and the turnaround has shaken the nation's major manufacturers of pistols and rifles in central Connecticut.

title: 2 SAY SUSPECT SEEMED DISTURBED ON THE DAY OF BROOKLYN SLAYINGS
description: The man charged with killing 10 people in Brooklyn last year appeared disturbed on the day of the killings, two people testified yesterday.

title: SYRIAN INTENTIONS SHOULD BE TESTED
description: Gratitude is not a basis for foreign policy. Self-interest is. Syria acted decisively on this basis to help resolve the hostage crisis. And it is on the basis of self-interest - Syria's and ours - that we must approach our future relations with Damascus. In some instances our interests converge, in others they conflict.

title: Natural State
description: The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club course at the far eastern end of Long Island is one of the most beautiful courses in the Northeast - a panorama of sand dunes, high sea grass and gnarled, thorny bushes waiting to clutch at anything that strays from the beautiful, big fairways and greens. And it may also prove to be one of the most challenging United States Open courses when the 86th Open is held there next June.

title: Stickball Redux
description: Derrick Tinsely, a 23-year-old stickball player from Far Rockaway, has accepted a number of invitations to professional baseball tryout camps this summer, including one this month from the Montreal Expos. And one of the keys to getting him into the majors.

title: New City Museum Director
description: Robert Rigg Macdonald has been elected the new director of the Museum of the City of New York by the museum's board of trustees. He will succeed Joseph Veach Noble, the current director, who retired June 30 after serving 15 years in that position. Mr. Macdonald is currently director of the Louisiana State Museum in New Orleans, and is president of the American Association of Museums.

title: U.S., EUROPE REACH TRUCE IN PASTA RIFT
description: The United States and the 10-nation European Economic Community reported a one-week truce today in a bitter trade dispute over pasta, citrus fruits and walnuts. Both sides said the conflict could be resolved by the end of the week.

title: 'Where Are the Indians?'
description: There are few subjects in New York City as likely to move people to violent language as the issue of housing. ''Rent control is the opiate of the masses,'' some people shout. ''All landlords are evil,'' others respond. I don't usually pay much attention to extremist rhetoric, but some comments that appeared in this newspaper's Week in Review section on Sunday had such a flair that they struck my eye.

title: SOVIET MAY EASE 'STAR WARS' STAND
description: Soviet negotiators in Geneva have indicated for the first time that they would be willing to accept an arms treaty allowing research on strategic defense, high-ranking Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RHYTHM READING So you have a bassoon or a violin or a trumpet or some other instrument and you'd like to ''read'' through, in company with other musicians with the same wish, some classical pieces unfamiliar to you. In that case, you should be spending Tuesdays, through July 23, at the McBurney Young Men's Christian Association on 23d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, where that is exactly what evening sessions starting at 7:30 are designed to let you do.

title: TERRELL'S TRADE IS PAYING OFF
description: Before the 1984 season, Bill Lajoie, the Detroit Tigers' general manager, made a trade that helped the Tigers win the American League East title, the pennant playoff and the World Series.

title: AGENTS FIGHT N.F.L. ROLLBACK
description: Agents for many unsigned National Football League draft picks, including more than 20 taken on the first round, vowed yesterday not to let their clients sign contracts for sums vastly below amounts paid to comparable draft choices of the past several years.

title: SUMMARY OF MAJOR ACTIONS BY THE NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN '85
description: The 208th session of the Legislature acted on a range of issues and put off resolution of others. By the time the Assembly recessed at 5:09 P.M. on Sunday, June 30, legislators had passed 2,094 bills. Some 1,700 await Governor Cuomo's signature or veto. These are the major actions of the session: The Budget Tax cuts, detailed spending programs and a restrictive and expensive accounting system were wrapped into the $39 billion budget.

title: KEY CALVING GROUND OF RARE WHALE FOUND OFF GEORGIA AND NORTH FLORIDA
description: SCIENTISTS from the New England Aquarium in Boston have discovered the principal calving ground of the rarest of the great whales, a quiet, shallow section of the Georgia and northern Florida coasts.

title: FASHION FORECASTERS FLIRT WITH THE FUTURE
description: ''I know how to imagine now what I'd like to wear in two years,'' said Ferry Schoew, a young designer with Promostyl, an international concern of fashion forecasters and stylists based in Paris.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 9, 1985
description: Markets

title: Parity: An Elegantly Simple Approach to Errors
description: ONE of the most important facets of data processing, yet one with which the average user is rarely directly involved, is error checking. People make mistakes, computers don't, or so the story goes.

title: A RESOLUTE BELLAMY STRIVING TO BE NOTICED
description: The woman who would be Mayor sticks out her hand.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CONCERT: GRETCHEN LANGHELD
description: THE Battery Park Landfill, a manmade beach on the Hudson River near Chambers Street, is a spectacular sight for a concert; it calls to mind nothing so much as a Dadaist postcard -imagine the skyline of Manhattan superimposed above tropical sand. For the past few years a group called Creative Time has been sponsoring summer events at the Battery Park Landfill in a program called ''Art on the Beach.''

title: Sale of O'Keeffe Work Finances a Fellowship
description: A $315,000 permanently endowed fellowship at New York University's Irvington House Institute for Medical Research is being financed with the proceeds of the sale of a painting by Georgia O'Keeffe.

title: ANDUJAR RUNS MARK TO 15-3
description: Joaquin Andujar scattered 12 singles tonight to win his major-league leading 15th game and help the St. Louis Cardinals defeat the San Francisco Giants, 6-1.

title: Western Airlines
description: International Air Leases Inc. said it had bought six of the Boeing Company 727-200's from Western Airlines Inc. for undisclosed terms and would lease them back to Western for two years, until Western takes delivery of new 737's from Boeing. International said it will receive the planes from Western between March and June 1987 and then sell or lease them to other airlines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The American people are not - I repeat, not - going to tolerate intimidation, terror and outright acts of war against this nation and its people.'' -President Reagan. [A1:6.]

title: People
description: * Lynn Fantom and Glenn Peters promoted to senior vice president at Kobs & Brady Advertising.

title: JOAN WILSON, 'MASTERPIECE THEATER' PRODUCER
description: Joan Wilson, the producer who brought ''Masterpiece Theater'' to American television, died of cancer Thursday in Boston. She lived in Marblehead, Mass.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Stop Debating Illegal-Immigrant Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Petro-Lewis Stake
description: Jakobson, Kass Partners, a New York investment concern, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would seek the liquidation of the Petro-Lewis Corporation, a Denver-based oil and gas concern. In its S.E.C. filing, Jakobson said that it had increased its stake in Petro-Lewis to 10.2 percent and that it would present a proposal at the company's annual meeting requesting that the board liquidate the company. On the American Stock Exchange yesterday, Petro-Lewis closed unchanged at $2.875.

title: DISNEY SET TO BUILD FLORIDA FILM STUDIO
description: Walt Disney Productions plans to build a $300 million film studio adjacent to Walt Disney World and Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla. The studio, which will have four sound stages, will be developed as a tourist attraction with a separate admission from the adjacent parks as well as a production site for Disney films.

title: SERIES ON WAR IN SPAIN
description: IF World War II was the last patriotic, or just, war, then surely the Spanish Civil War was the last romantic, or sentimentalized, war. It was either a struggle against repression or a crusade for Western civilization. Certainly it was misreported and misunderstood. ''The Spanish Civil War,'' a six-part series that begins tonight on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, addresses a worthy subject.

title: The Killings In El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: STRAPLESS ON FESTIVE NIGHTS
description: The short bare-top dress is gaining ground for black-tie evenings, or whenever the mood is festive. It is appropriate for dressy cocktail parties, dinner parties and even dances.

title: PHIL FOSTER, 72, THE COMEDIAN AND ACTOR IN 'LAVERNE' SERIES
description: Phil Foster, the stand-up comedian who later became an actor in the legitimate theater and in the television series ''Laverne and Shirley,'' died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., after having had a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,377,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,141,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Friday about Sunset Park, a Brooklyn neighborhood where some buildings are tilting, buckling or sinking, included an incorrect quotation of remarks by Julian Soren, a geologist with the United States Geological Survey, who offered an explanation for the phenomenon. Mr. Soren said: ''This is an area of glacial till, where you have an unsorted and random mixture of sand, clay, gravel and boulders.''

title: UNION NATIONAL CORP (MET LEBANON, MD)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock-split paid May 10.

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSES 5 'OUTLAW STATES' OF WORLD TERROR
description: President Reagan today characterized Iran, Libya, North Korea, Cuba and Nicaragua as ''a confederation of terrorist states'' that had carried out ''outright acts of war'' against the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AT&T International Japan Ltd., Tokyo, has appointed William J. Moody managing director and president.

title: THE KIM DYNASTY'S NORTH KOREA: A NATION CENTERED ON ONE FAMILY
description: When the summer sun washes over the broad boulevards and monumental buildings of this riverside capital, there is a quiet, almost deserted quality to the place, as if most of the population of 800,000 had left town for the day.

title: CHILDREN AND FOOD: HOW TASTES ARE FORMED
description: ON the occasion of her fourth birthday last week, Lindsay Scherr of Washington, stated her culinary preferences in no uncertain terms. What's your favorite food? ''Ice cream.'' What do you really hate? ''Spaghetti.''

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Report Says Rents Take Larger Share of Income
description: Families are paying a substantially higher proportion of their income for housing than they were 12 years ago, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Yiddish Stardom
description: Look out, Grauman's Chinese Theater.

title: Which Way Will Fed Go?
description: THE cardinal problem facing the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee during the two-day meeting now going on in Washington is whether the economy is weakening and requires further support or whether the Fed has already done enough, or more than enough, to stimulate growth and would generate inflation if it did more.

title: Ohlmeyer Adds Unit For Fashion Videos
description: Ohlmeyer Communications Companies has added a new division to its melange.

title: CRITIQUING THE CRITICS - IN SOFT COVER
description: Mayor Koch, William F. Buckley Jr., Graig Nettles and Joan Collins may have little else in common, but they are helping to reshape paperback publishing. All four have written new material especially for the recent paperback editions of their best-selling books, and many other authors are about to follow suit.

title: Iraqi Missile Hits Tanker In the Persian Gulf
description: An Iraqi missile struck a supertanker loaded with Iranian crude today, turning it into a fireball that spewed tons of flaming oil into the Persian Gulf.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for latest second quarter reflect the aquisition of Continental Fibre Drum Inc. which was consumated April 1.

title: SENATE VOTES SWEEPING BILL TO LOOSEN CONTROL OF GUNS
description: The Senate tonight decisively approved a sweeping overhaul of Federal gun control laws that would generally make it easier for Americans to buy, sell and transport firearms.

title: MANTLE IS STARRING IN DIFFERENT ROLE
description: Coolly, and forthrightly, the boy with the satiny blond hair stood at the opposite side of the table. He had a presence and a charm far beyond his 9 or 10 years.

title: FILM: GIBSON IN A 'MAD MAX' SEQUEL
description: Apocalyptic fiction generally has an easier time destroying the world than putting it back together. So watch out as Mad Max, the hero of George Miller's post-nuclear fantasy films, assumes greater and greater mythic dimensions in the third film in the series. For the fourth - and on the basis of this one, there will and should be another - he appears to have messianic, civilization-founding responsibilities in his future.

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Aug. 30 to holders of record on Aug. 1.

title: Letter: On Electric Power;   Co-generation Has Its Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: MERGE TECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Legal Perspectives on New York's Medical-Malpractice Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Reported Killed By Philippine Guerrillas
description: At least 18 people were killed in raids by Communist guerrillas in five provinces over the weekend, the police and newspaper reports said today.

title: KNOWLEDGE IS CLOUT
description: David A. Stockman understood, even memorized, the minutiae of the Federal budget. That, along with his mastery of the larger issues, made him President Reagan's No. 1 agent in forging the most important changes in Government economic policy since the Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: ARMY BIOLOGIST DEFENDS AS MINOR THE REVISIONS HE MADE IN WESTWAY REPORT ON BASS
description: A biologist underwent extensive cross-examination yesterday as he defended the official environmental statements that he wrote on the Westway highway and development project.

title: Save, and Think About, Water
description: For the third time in 20 years, fences and foundations that are ordinarily submerged under New York City's reservoirs of water stand high and dry. That the city has been exposed to three droughts in so brief a span is a sure sign that its strategic water planning is remiss.

title: MGM/UA Appoints Lerner to Film Post
description: Karen Lerner has been appointed vice president of motion picture production, East Coast, for MGM/UA, it was announced yesterday.

title: AVACARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Net Up 2.1% At Dow Jones
description: Dow Jones & Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1985 edged up 2.1 percent on a 7.2 increase in revenue.

title: Legal Perspectives on New York's Medical-Malpractice Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Home
description: Warren Young graduated from Michigan Tech six years ago, and now he is going back to play hockey in Michigan again.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 10, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Roger Clemens, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list.

title: Dow Falls 6.50 in a Broad Decline
description: Snags in the Federal budget reduction talks and concern over poor corporate earnings trimmed stock prices on Wall Street yesterday, but some companies with overseas operations rallied on the recent weakness of the dollar.

title: KOCH BEGINS CAMPAIGN FOR 3D TERM
description: Edward I. Koch asked yesterday for the opportunity to keep what he called ''the best job in America'' - mayor of the city of New York.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago per share figures adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 1.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Steve Jacobson Wed To Madeleine Fischer
description: The marriage of Madeleine Fischer to Steve A. Jacobson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jacobson of Larchmont, N.Y., took place yesterday in New Orleans. Judge Louis A. DiRosa of the Civil District Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAR GROUP REJECTS RIGHTS RESOLUTION
description: The American Bar Association's House of Delegates today narrowly defeated a call for legislation barring discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FEW people give their back a second thought until the day it starts ''acting up.'' For four out of five people, sooner or later that day will come. In this era of sedentary occupations and weekend athletic excess, back problems are more common than ever. And they seem to be afflicting an ever-growing number of young people.

title: Walker's Prediction
description: ''The United States Football League,'' said its brightest star, Herschel Walker, ''will be around, I'll guarantee. And I'll be here for a few more years.''

title: ERRORS HELP GUIDRY GAIN 10TH IN ROW
description: When it comes to fielding, there have been few better second basemen over the years than Kansas City's Frank White. He is the only American League second baseman ever to win six Gold Gloves.

title: AUDITORS TESTIFY AT TRIAL OF A GENERAL
description: Government auditors used flow charts today to help explain the arcane world of Swiss banking to a jury hearing the case of a retired Air Force major general accused of embezzling funds from a fund used to bankroll spy operations.

title: Oak Ridge Atomic Waste Is Found Not Dangerous
description: The 50 million pounds of buried radioactive waste near the Government's nuclear weapon and research facilities at Oak Ridge, Tenn., pose no health threat to nearby residents, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company is offering cash payments to all of its 3,000 nonunion workers if they quit their jobs, a spokesman for the railroad company said. The offer, which takes effect Aug. 16, covers about 10 percent of the company's employees. A spokesman, Andrew Anderson, said the offer had been made because of a slump.

title: CONCERN FOR GRAPE GROWERS
