description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has told the Agriculture Department to expect heavy loan demands from New York's grape growers because reductions in grape purchases have caused them ''severe financial stress.''

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Latest year results include a gain of $500,000 from the sale of non-operating assets.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
Joseph Willen Is Dead; A Jewish Fund-Raiser
description: Joseph Willen, a former executive vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Armstrong World Industries, Lancaster, Pa., said it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Dixie Yarns Inc.'s Chatsworth, Ga., yarn spinning plant for use in producing tufted carpet. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Steinbrenner Calls Victim
description: The woman who was shot in the hand at Yankee Stadium got a call today from the Yankees owner, George Steinbrenner, and later said she had changed her opinion of him from ''callous and ignorant'' to ''nice.''

title: ONE OF 3 CLEARED OVER NAVY'S $659 ASHTRAYS
description: The Navy announced today that it would reinstate an admiral who was relieved of duty after disclosures about high prices that a supply depot under his command paid for airplane ashtrays and other spare parts.

title: Coaches Chosen
description: Dick Williams of the San Diego Padres, the manager for the National League all-star team, has named Jim Frey of the Chicago Cubs and Bob Lillis of the Houston Astros coaches for the All-Star Game next Tuesday. Last week, Sparky Anderson of the Tigers, the American League manager, named Bobby Cox of Toronto and Dick Howser of Kansas City as coaches.

title: Checking the Cuts
description: A lot of New Yorkers have been wondering what exactly Eric Fergerson is doing for his summer job.

title: James Craig, Actor, 74, Dies; Once Called Gable Successor
description: James Craig, the actor once promoted as a successor to Clark Gable, died of lung cancer June 27 at Western Medical Center here. He was 74 years old.

title: Weinhauer Dropped
description: The Arizona State University president, J. Russell Nelson, announced that the school would not renew the contract of the basketball coach, Bob Weinhauer, whose program has had two straight losing seasons and currently is under Pacific-10 Conference investigation for alleged violations. Weinhauer, 45 years old, was hired in 1982 from the University of Pennsylvania, where his Quaker teams had a 99-45 record over a five-year span.

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect a pooling of interests.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about Eskimo dialects incorrectly described the inflection of verbs. They are conjugated; it is nouns that are declined.

title: RCA, MCA REPORTEDLY HELD TALKS
description: The RCA Corporation, the giant broadcasting and electronics conglomerate, and MCA Inc., parent company of Universal Pictures, have held a number of informal merger discussions over the last year, a source close to RCA said yesterday.

title: Finn Admits Drug Use
description: A Finnish runner who was stripped of his Olympic medal after failing a drug test has admitted that he used banned drugs for more than a year before last summer's Los Angeles Games.

title: A PENTAGON STUDY DESCRIBED 1960 DESTRUCTION OF WARHEAD
description: A study published by the Pentagon in 1981 listed the nuclear-weapon accident at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey among 32 such incidents dating back to 1950.

title: Lebanese Chiefs Reach An Accord on Airport
description: Moslem and Druse leaders announced agreement today on a plan to tighten security in West Beirut and the international airport, and they invited Syrian observers to take part in putting the plan into effect.

title: Nkomo Says Killings Had Official Backing
description: The Zimbabwe opposition leader Joshua Nkomo said today that two officials of his party were slain Monday night in what he called a campaign of official killing by supporters of the ruling party.

title: VIEWS ON 'SOCIAL PORK BARREL' AND PENTAGON INEFFICIENCY
description: For some time now, the built-in momentum of the Federal budget and the exigencies of fiscal politics have produced expenditure growth rates that not only outpace current-year revenues but also absorb the ''fiscal dividend'' of economic growth up to a half decade into the future. As a consequence, it has almost become fiscally irresponsible even to discuss enactment of these measures.

title: Looking to Close a Gap
description: It's a matter of some embarrassment to Democratic feminists that no woman in their party has been elected to the Senate in her own right. Hattie W. Caraway of Arkansas made it, and so did Rose McConnell Long of Louisiana and Maurine B. Neuburger of Oregon, but all of them succeeded Senator-husbands who died in office, which is not regarded as the same political achievement as running on one's own and winning.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: RICH LODE OF FOSSILS FOUND IN TEXAS
description: Scientists in Texas have uncovered an unusually rich lode of dinosaur bones and other fossils of creatures that lived more than 100 million years ago, a period from which few large fossils have ever been found.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.M. to Modernize Its Plant In Linden to Make New Car
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would spend $300 million to retool its 48-year-old automobile assembly plant here and make it a ''state of the art'' factory for producing a new line of L-body Chevrolets beginning next year.

title: AS THEIR 'DECADE' ENDS, WOMEN TAKE STOCK
description: More than 11,000 women are converging on this city from at least 130 countries to bring the United Nations Decade for Women to an end. In the next three weeks, they will assess the achievements and failures of the last 10 years and plot strategy through the year 2000.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER
description: The International Paper Company reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter plunged 47.5 percent as sales remained flat at $1.2 billion. The world's largest paper producer said that net income in the latest three months dropped to $35.2 million, or 57 cents a share, from $67 million, or $1.2 a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: Accountants Debate Losses
description: Baseball's club owners presented a New York University accounting professor yesterday to bolster their view of their financial figures. The players' labor leader was not impressed with the effort, and that left the effort to reach a new basic agreement as stalled as they have been for nearly eight months.

title: Sentences Put Off In Tulane Case
description: The first sentences in the Tulane University point-shaving scandal were postponed today in Orleans Parish Criminal District Court.

title: Too Many Mouths to Feed
description: In many parts of the world, death, not birth control, determines the size of a family. When a country has too many mouths to feed, its children are the first to die.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS STAKES INVESTIGATED BY U.S.
description: The Pacific Telesis Group is under investigation by the Department of Justice's antitrust division regarding the company's purchase of companies involved in the cellular mobile telephone business, Government and company officials acknowledged today.

title: SURPRISES ON CHURCH AND STATE
description: The books are now closed on the latest Supreme Court term, but the fascinating question remains: What accounts for the Court's reversal of form on matters of religion?

title: CRAFT HOUSE CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
A THREAT BY SAUDIS IS REPORTED
description: Saudi Arabia is threatening to double its oil production, to 4 million barrels a day, and then to increase it to 9 million barrels by the end of the year if other OPEC members do not accept its terms when they meet again on July 22, a high Western official said in an interview here today.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago per share figures adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1984.

title: CITY WINS A $1.2 BILLION TAX DECISION
description: In a decision that saved New York City from having to refund $1.2 billion in taxes, the state's highest court today upheld the standards used to calculate the value of utility mains and pipes that run under streets.

title: THE PAIN OF A FARM BANKER
description: Outwardly, life does not seem to have changed much for John C. Schmidt, the relentlessly casual 43-year-old president of Marysville's dominant bank, the Exchange Bank of Schmidt & Koester that was founded by his great-grandfather soon after the Civil War.

title: Allied's Signal Bid
description: The Allied Corporation said that shareholders of the Signal Companies had tendered nearly four times as many shares as Allied had sought in a May takeover bid.

title: TEXT OF KOCH'S STATEMENT DECLARING CANDIDACY FOR RE-ELECTION
description: Following is the text of Mayor Koch's statement announcing that he is a candidate for re-election:

title: ANTISATELLITE WEAPON IS REPORTED SENT BACK TO ITS MAKER FOR REPAIRS
description: The Air Force sent its only available antisatellite weapon back to the manufacturer for repairs late last month, according to Congressional sources, putting an already delayed testing program into further uncertainty.

title: The U.N. Today: July 10, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Symposium on the Palestinian issue - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: KOCH PLEDGES AID FOR PAROCHIAL-SCHOOL PUPILS
description: Mayor Koch said last night that he had asked the city's religious leaders to help him explore ways that public-school teachers could continue to provide remedial instruction to parochial-school students.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACK AGAIN It has been 10 years since Peggy Lee, the pop-jazz star, has sung in the companionable surroundings of a New York cabaret, an interim that draws to a close tonight when Miss Lee starts a four-week club date at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005).

title: A SHIFT AWAY FROM THE WEST IS SENSED IN SUDAN
description: A Sudanese-Libyan military agreement, the signing of which was reported Monday, is being widely viewed here as a symbol that relations between the two countries are warming while the Sudan's ties with both Egypt and the United States are weakening.

title: U.S. TELLS SUDAN OF CONCERN OVER LIBYA MILITARY ACCORD
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had told the Sudan of its ''grave concern'' about reports from that African country that it had signed a new military agreement with Libya.

title: Let South Africa Rectify Its Own Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR A CAROLINA CHEF, HELPINGS OF HISTORY
description: BILL NEAL, considered by many to be one of today's finest young Southern chefs, takes a decidedly historical approach to cooking. That is because he considers the regional dishes of this country as important and worthy of preservation as the nation's monuments and architecture.

title: Heston in ''Dynasty II'
description: Charlton Heston will star in his first television series, ABC's ''Dynasty II: The Colbys,'' network executives said today. The Academy Award-winning actor will play Jason Colby, patriarch of the Colby family, in a spinoff of the highly successful prime-time soap opera ''Dynasty'' this fall, according to Aaron Spelling, the executive producer. Mr. Heston recently directed and starred in ''The Caine Mutiny Court Martial'' on stage in London.

title: UNION PROPOSING INNOVATIVE PLAN FOR WORKERS AT A NEW AUTO PLANT
description: Production workers at the proposed General Motors plant for the small Saturn car would be paid salaries rather than hourly wages, share perquisites with management and participate in decision-making under a proposal of the United Automobile Workers, made public today.

title: THRIFTY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADMIRAL REPORTED IN LINE FOR HEAD OF MILITARY CHIEFS
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. will resign as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on Oct. 1, and will be replaced by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., commander of American forces in the Pacific, sources in the Reagan Administration said today.

title: FOR NORTH KOREANS, SPONTANEITY IS IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: One of the most striking things about daily life in North Korea is the tedious routine that Kim Il Sung appears to have imposed on the almost 20 million inhabitants of this ''worker's state.''

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: Results for the latest quarter include $252,000 from pre-tax non-operating income.

title: MEESE, IN BAR GROUG SPEECH, CRITICIZES HIGH COURT
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the framers of the Constitution would have found ''bizarre'' the Supreme Court's recent reaffirmation that the First Amendment requires government to maintain ''strict neutrality'' toward religion.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the Henley Royal Regatta incorrectly characterized the final of the Grand Challenge Cup. It was not the first between two American crews; that occurred in 1957, when Cornell and Yale raced.

title: KILLER PUT TO DEATH IN TEXAS
description: Henry Martinez Porter, calling society ''a bunch of cold-blooded murderers,'' was executed early today for the slaying of a Fort Worth police officer nearly 10 years ago.

title: FIRST COLONIAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARION M. KELLERAN
description: A memorial service for Marion Macdonald Kelleran, an Episcopal churchwoman who advocated the ordination of women to the priesthood, was held Monday, July 1, at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria. Dr. Kellerman died June 27 at the age of 80.

title: United Reports Ridership Up
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that ridership on the airline in the first week of July had returned to normal after a 29-day nationwide strike by the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DISCOVERIES
GOV. EDWARDS OF LOUISIANA DENIES HE OFFERED TO RESIGN
description: Governor Edwin Edwards of Louisiana denied today that he offered to resign in order to head off a Federal indictment and he accused United States Attorney John Volz of distorting their conversation to a grand jury.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: New Frozen Desert American Glace, a new frozen dessert, does not fit easily into the established categories. While creamier than sherbet and similar to a gelato, it contains no dairy products. But it is not made with tofu or other soy products. It is low in calories but without artificial sweeteners. Finally, it tastes simply and deliciously of the fruit from which it is made.

title: HUMANITAS PRIZES GIVEN FOR 1984-5 TV SEASON
description: The writers of ''The Dollmaker,'' an ABC television movie starring Jane Fonda as the poverty-stricken mother of five children, and episodes of NBC's ''St. Elsewhere'' and ''The Cosby Show'' were awarded the Humanitas Prize today for the 1984-85 television season.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EDNA R. MACDONOUGH
description: Edna R. MacDonough, founder and executive secretary of the what is considered the largest exchange program in the world, died Saturday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: ERNST, E C INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
THE POP LIFE
description: BRYAN FERRY, who spent 10 years as lead vocalist and chief songwriter for the innovative British band Roxy Music and is now enjoying a successful solo career, spent some 18 months making ''Boys and Girls,'' his new Warner Brothers album. So it wasn't really surprising to hear him say the other day, ''You just have to try and live a life in between records, and the records are a response to that.'' The idea that other people make records during temporary hiatuses from living their lives doesn't seem to have occurred to him.

title: The Bad New Days
description: A lot of the fretting and fuming about terrorism is based on the naive belief that it will go away if only a few disagreeable men are disposed of.

title: NAT KIEFER
description: State Senator Nat Kiefer of New Orleans, who carried a brash style into the Louisiana Senate to become one of Gov. Edwin Edwards's most effective floor leaders, died in Los Angeles today.

title: JEC LASERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $26,810, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $70,203, or 6 cents a share, for the nine months. c-Net loss.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the year-ago six months include a first quarter pretax gain of $16,800,000 from the sale of land in northern Maine.

title: HEAD OF F.B.I. TELLS OF THWARTING 17 OF 19 TERRORIST PLOTS THIS YEAR
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the bureau had thwarted 17 terrorist plots in the United States this year and there were only two completed terrorist incidents. He also said the bureau was having increasing success in gathering intelligence about terrorists here and abroad.

title: Puerto Rico Issue Of Revenue Bonds
description: The Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority is offering $275 million of revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc., with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9.17 percent for bonds due in 2015.

title: FREDERICK KAUFMAN
description: Frederick Kaufman, a chemist whose research contributed to a ban on the use of chloro-fluorocarbon aerosol propellants in the United States, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering hospital in New York City from complications of a respiratory infection.

title: Why a Human Life May Well Be Priceless
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Housing Slows
description: Canadian housing starts in June fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 139,000 from May's rate of 152,000, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium. (Television - SportsChannel, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. The Mets' Rick Aguilera will try to follow up his impressive performance of last Friday when he pitched a complete game and allowed no earned runs in a 6-1 victory over Atlanta. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Anderson Memorial, at Winged Foot Country Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., 8 A.M. Opening round of the better-ball team tournament. J. P. O'Hara and Neil Christie of Winged Foot, the defending champions, have a bye into the round of 16 on Friday. New York State Open, at Grossingers Country Club. Third and final round, with 18 holes of medal play. New Jersey State Golfers Association Open Championships, at Echo Lake Country Club, Westfield, N.J. Opening round, 8 A.M. Dave Glenz of the Morris County Golf Club is the defending champion of this 72-hole tournament. There will be 18 holes today, 18 tomorrow and 36 on Friday. Tennis $117,000 Volvo Tennis Hall of Fame Championships, at Newport, R.I., noon. The last major grass competition in America continues through Sunday. Union Savings Bank Huntington Clay Court men's singles championships, at Old Field Tennis Club, 400 Greenlawn Road, Greenlawn, L.I., 2 P.M. Admission is free. Other Events BASKETBALL: Westchester Golden Apples vs. Springfield Fame, at County Center, Yonkers, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WFAS, 1230, 7:30 P.M.). Lite/N.B.A. Pro-Am Summer League at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 7 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. BICYCLING: Tour de France, 12th stage of race that ends July 21.

title: COHALAN ORDER OVER SHOREHAM VOIDED BY COURT
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that the Suffolk County Executive had exceeded his authority when he ordered a test of plans to protect Long Island residents in case of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: STOCKMAN RESIGNATION IS SEEN AS 'REAL LOSS'
description: Economists and members of the financial community expressed sharp regret at the announcement yesterday that David A. Stockman was leaving the Administration. Some voiced concern that his outspoken advocacy of reduced budget deficits and higher taxes might not be heard during the remainder of the Reagan term.

title: CHARLOTTE, LONGTIME LUXEMBOURG RULER, DIES
description: Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, a beloved constitutional ruler for 45 years and beacon of liberty to her country under German occupaion in World War II, died yesterday after an illness of several weeks. She was 89 years old.

title: Research Center Is Suspended
description: Construction of a $26 million microelectronics research facility has been suspended by the United Technologies Corporation, which is reassessing its investment in the semiconductor business, a company spokesman said.

title: Denial Issued By Hutton
description: E.F. Hutton & Company yesterday denied reports published in The Los Angeles Times that its senior officials were aware of and encouraged illegal overdrafting of its bank accounts, to which it pleaded guilty in May.

title: Douglas W. Gorsline, 72, Dies; Book Illustrator and Author
description: Douglas W. Gorsline, a book illustrator, painter and author, died of a stroke June 26 in Dijon, France. He was 72 years old and had lived in France for 15 years.

title: Bridge: International Title Is Taken By Austria for Only 2d Time
description: Almost half a century after it won its first international team title, Austria captured its second last week: the European Championship in Salsomaggiore, Italy. In 1937, before any of its new champions were born, Austria won the first multiteam world championship in Budapest, Hungary.

title: 2 More Bodies Found in West
description: Two bodies have been unearthed from a newly discovered gravesite near a cabin used by a survivalist and his companion, bringing to at least 11 the number of victims buried in the area, investigators said today. The find prompted investigators to expand the search area to a five-mile radius around the remote cabin, a sheriff's spokesman said. Authorities previously have linked 22 dead or missing people to the investigation of the two, Leonard Lake, who commited suicide while in custody, and Charles Ng, who is being held in Canada after his arrest Saturday.

title: SOPHISTICATED CAST IRON
description: I HAVE often praised the qualities of old-fashioned cast-iron pots and pans, even in this age of multilayered metals and exotic alloys. Cast iron distributes heat evenly, which is important for all kinds of cooking, and the iron retains the heat longer than other metals.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Sign Here If You Want Them to Pull the Plug
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Tough
description: President Reagan is backing out of the saloon with his rhetorical guns blazing. But the fireworks cannot hide the fact that he is backing away from dealing with airline safety just when he should be standing coolly firm.

title: MAUREEN REAGAN CRITICIZES MEESE
description: Maureen Reagan criticized Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today for blocking a $625,000 Federal grant to a group that runs shelters for battered women.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect the 3-for-2 split of Decemeber 1984 as if it had occurred at March 1, 1985, the beginning of its latest fiscal year.

title: Group May Raise Sea-Land Holding
description: A group of companies controlled by Harold Simmons, a Dallas investor, said it holds the equivalent of a 9.1 percent stake in the Sea-Land Corporation and might increase its holdings to more than 15 percent. Joseph F. Abely Jr., Sea-Land's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the development was ''most unwelcome.'' He did not elaborate.

title: Florida Agency Offers $293.2 Million of Bonds
description: The Florida State Board of Education is offering $293.2 million of bonds through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: A CHILD'S-EYE VIEW OF RESTAURANT DINING
description: THE children in one of Rachel Boff's fourth-grade classes at the Dalton School wanted to know: ''What do you do if the dish you ordered is well made, but you just think that kind of food is yucky?'' So their guest lecturer, Bryan Miller, The New York Times's restaurant critic, told them, going on to explain many of the finer points of reviewing restaurants.

title: Analysts Differ On Fast Food
description: WHAT lies ahead for convenience-food restaurant stocks in today's era of frozen dinners and microwaves?

title: 2 SUICIDE BOMBERS KILL 12, WOUND 6 IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Suicide attackers detonated two car bombs today at checkpoints leading to Israel's so-called security zone in southern Lebanon.

title: COURT OF APPEALS TELLS CITY TO $2 ILLION TO GIRL FATHER STABBED
description: Because the New York City police failed to protect a 6-year-old child against her father, who tried to murder her, the city must pay her $2 million, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including an after-tax investment gain of $4,344,000.

title: President Chosen In ITT Reshuffling
description: The ITT Corporation, the subject of merger and takeover rumors in recent months, said yesterday that Edmund M. Carpenter had been elected president and chief operating officer. Mr. Carpenter, who is 43 years old, joined ITT as an executive vice president in 1981.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Bankrupt Environmentalism
description: The Superfund is a fiasco, and the debate over the terms of its renewal after its expiration Oct. 1 reveals the bankruptcy of the environmental movement.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a net after-tax charge of $904,000, or 27 cents a share, related to the closing and sale of a plant.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 15.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE KILL 7 BLACKS IN A TOWNSHIP NEAR JOHANNESBURG
description: At least seven blacks were shot dead by the police early today in this black township set amid the gold-mining dumps that fringe Johannesburg.

title: A White House Fable
description: What is it now, Buchanan?

title: U.S. OFFICIAL REPORTING GAINS ON A CHINESE NUCLEAR ACCORD
description: A Reagan Administration official said today that the United States and China had made progress on a nuclear energy accord that has been held up for a year.

title: Becker's Ankle Injured
description: Boris Becker, the 17-year-old West German, who became the youngest Wimbledon men's singles champion Sunday, has an injured ankle and may withdraw from next week's tournament in Washington. ''His ankle is very swollen, it's the same leg he had an operation on last year,'' Becker's father, Karl-Heinz Becker, was quoted as saying in The Washington Post.

title: California's Issue Of Veteran Bonds
description: A $200 million issue of California general obligation veteran bonds was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the Bank of America.

title: SCREEN: 'SILVERADO,' A WESTERN
description: ''SILVERADO'' is a sweeping, glorious-looking western that's at least a full generation removed from the classic films it brings to mind. Lawrence Kasdan, who produced, directed and co-wrote the film - and presumably came up with its wonderful title -doesn't seem to be commenting ironically on the western form. Nor is he determined to update it. He simply approaches it from a present-day standpoint, and the result is an energetic revival with some significant differences in scale. ''Silverado'' is sufficiently modern to make its landscapes bigger, its people smaller and its moral polarities less powerfully distinct than those of simpler, more starkly beautiful westerns gone by.

title: No Headline
description: Claude B. Sharp, vice president of engineering and operations at Bell Communications Research, died last Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, while walking near his home in Summit, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At least he knew what he was talking about, and that is refreshing around this town.'' - Senator Bob Dole, about David A. Stockman. [A14:5.]

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Beating the Drum
description: Miss Shriver was joined by Miss Navratilova and 67-year-old Bobby Riggs at the news conference, whose purpose was to drum up interest in next month's great-battle-of-the-sexes doubles match between Navratilova-Shriver and Riggs-Vitas Gerulaitis. As every son of a p.r. man could have predicted, each side got in its digs at the other, but there was one surprise: Among those who showed up was Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist extraordinaire for Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, who met Miss Navratilova during the group's recent tour of England. Clemons, bedecked yesterday in a typically bright red suit, presented to the Czechoslovak emigre a poster that said, ''You don't have to be 'Born in the U.S.A.' to be an American.''

title: PREPARING FOR ARREST ON SOUTH AFRICA'S STEPS
description: For eight months, almost on a daily basis, demonstrators have been going to the South African Embassy here to protest the country's racial policies. There have been 2,900 arrests.

title: Gulfstream Land Backs Its Takeover
description: The Gulfstream Land and Development Corporation said yesterday that its board would recommend that stockholders approve a bid by Kenneth M. Good, a Denver real estate developer, to acquire the company for $37 a share, or $172.1 million.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MAN IN QUEENS PUSHED TO DEATH ON IND TRACKS
description: A 25-year-old man was killed yesterday morning when another man, apparently a stranger, shoved him off a Queens IND elevated platform in front of an oncoming train, the police said.

title: A COURT PANEL FINDS ROY COHN MISUSED FUNDS FROM CLIENTS
description: A disciplinary panel of the New York State court system has found wrongdoing by Roy M. Cohn involving fees or accounts of two of his law firm's clients.

title: CARDS' COX STOPS GIANTS, 3-1
description: Tom Herr drove in two runs, and Danny Cox pitched a five-hitter as the Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-1, tonight.

title: LET SOUTH AFRICA RECTIFY ITS OWN MISTAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hiring Path Taken By Salomon
description: Although rival investment banks have often reached into the top echelons of the Federal Government to give their business a special cachet, Salomon Brothers has preferred to rely on home-grown talent. Yesterday, however, the giant securities firm broke with tradition when it announced that David A. Stockman would become its 88th managing director.

title: Charles R. Clason, 94, Dies; Ex-Bay State Congressman
description: Former Representative Charles R. Clason, the first Rhodes Scholar to hold a seat in Congress, died here Sunday. He was 94 years old. Mr. Clason, a Republican who represented Massachusetts' Second Congressional District from 1937 to 1949, helped establish a navigation and power project system on the Connecticut River and was one of the most vocal opponents of President Roosevelt's attempts to increase the number of Supreme Court Justices.

title: Support for State
description: A bipartisan group of foreign policy experts, headed by Edmund S. Muskie, a former Secretary of State, and Kenneth Rush, a former Ambassador to Germany and France, has called for a reassertion of the authority of the Secretary of State as Presidential spokesman on foreign policy over that of the White House national security adviser.

title: Shultzes' Gift to Chorus
description: The 37-member Woodrow Wilson High School chorus is taking off today for Vienna to compete in the 14th International Youth Music Festival, but it might not have made it without the help of Secretary of State and Mrs. George P. Shultz. The Secretary's executive assistant at the State Department, Charles Hill, has a daughter, Emily, in the chorus, and he told Mr. Shultz several months ago that the students were trying to raise $80,000 for the trip so they could be one of nine schools representing the United States at the 43-nation contest.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $211,000 for the quarter and $3,551,000 for the nine months. c-Including tax credits of $3,984,000 for the quarter and $9,944,000 for the nine months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Nurseryland Garden Centers Inc.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Community Guardian Bank, Elmwood Park, N.J., has named William L. Griffin Jr. president.

title: On the Way in Paris: The Space-Age Taxi
description: Paris will soon have a new fleet of custom-built taxis sporting the city's red and blue colors, the manufacturers said today.

title: INDIANAPOLIS FACES NEW TEST
description: The 1987 Pan American Games were scheduled for Santiago, Chile, until political unrest and a lack of money led the organizers to relinquish them. They were transferred to Quito and Guayaquil, Ecuador, until Ecuador decided last November it could not afford them.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stephan's Horse Ends an Odyssey
description: The rangy, bay-colored 3-year-old named Stephan's Odyssey, runner-up in both the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, competed in the Dwyer at Belmont Park on Sunday, and it was then that his staunchest fan saw him run for the very first time. The fan's timing was good, since Stephan's Odyssey finished first, something he had been able to do only once since December. The fan had been spared the six defeats since then because he had been busy with his studies at a private school in Switzerland. But summer vacation gave 16-year-old Stephan de Kwiatkowski a chance to root home the Danzig colt that his father, Henryk, had named for him.

title: White Signed by Rams
description: The Los Angeles Rams have signed the free-agent running back Charles White to a contract for the 1985 season.

title: Long Shot
description: He is no longer just a curiosity, a 7-foot-6 3/4-inch spectacle who has killed a lion with a spear in his native Sudan and played college basketball for the University of Bridgeport in the same lifetime. Nor is he merely a gate attraction for the Rhode Island Gulls in a modest summer diversion called the United States Basketball League.

title: Shifts in Soviet Foreign-Policy, Maybe
description: The agreement between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to meet in Geneva next fall coincided with a major shake-up - Andrei A. Gromyko's election as President of the Soviet Union and Eduard A. Shevardnadze's appointment as Foreign Minister. This could portend major changes in Soviet foreign policy. It may also require Mr. Reagan to rethink his arms control strategy.

title: OLD MISSILE SITE AT MCGUIRE IS STILL TAINTED, KEAN SAYS
description: Governor Kean said today that his administration had learned from the Department of Defense that radioactive material from a nuclear weapon that burned at McGuire Air Force Base in 1960 was still contaminating a ''sizable'' part of the former missile site.

title: Bond Prices Little Changed
description: Bond prices finished little changed yesterday despite pessimism over the prospects for swift deficit reduction action or easier credit from the Federal Reserve.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dance listing last Sunday in The Guide gave incorrect performance days for the New Performing Dance Company at the Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street. It will appear this Thursday and Friday at 8:30.

title: Photo Restored to Wall
description: At the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs, the picture of Leslie H. Gelb, who was director of the bureau from 1977 to 1979, is back on the wall. It was taken down in February after publication of an article by Mr. Gelb, now a correspondent of The New York Times, that the bureau director, Lieut. Gen. John T. Chain Jr., objected to as damaging to national security.

title: ST. BART'S LOSES 2d BID TO BUILD AN OFFICE TOWER
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, which has been seeking for years to build an office tower on its Park Avenue site, was rebuffed again yesterday as the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission rejected a second proposal for the addition.

title: VALUE OF SPRINKLERS DISPUTED
description: A fire-protection engineer testified today that a sprinkler system would have saved property but not lives in an amusement park fun-house fire that killed eight patrons last year.

title: MILITARY MALPRACTICE LAW OPPOSED
description: A proposed law to allow military personnel to sue the Government for medical malpractice would undermine military morale and discipline but would do little to improve the quality of medical care, officials of the Reagan Administration said today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always been intrigued with how a simple side dish can become the centerpiece for an entire meal - as when the green beans I served as a meal accompaniment one day became the focus of a meal served another day.

title: DILLARD MAKES A HIT AT SUMMER CLINIC
description: He was walking around with about 300 other youngsters, all wearing identical T-shirts and hats, on a baseball field in lower Manhattan. The East River was 50 yards to the front, the Manhattan Bridge above on the left, the Brooklyn Bridge on the right.

title: JUDGE IN ONE NAVY SPY TRIAL SAYS HE'LL TRY FOR A FAIR JURY IN NORFOLK
description: A Federal district judge today refused to move the trial of Arthur J. Walker, charged in a Navy spy case along with two other members of his family, out of this Navy town.

title: JAPAN PLEDGES ACTION ON MARKET ACCESS
description: Japan's Government today promised to simplify product standards, ease import procedures and increase its purchases of foreign-made goods as part of an overall program to improve foreigners' access to Japanese markets.

title: The Great Gap
description: Perhaps the greatest compliment that Chris Evert Lloyd could have paid Martina Navratilova was the one she did pay her after bowing in the Wimbledon final last Saturday, when she said she was simply glad that her game had been up to Miss Navratilova's level. As for the champion, she affirmed that Mrs. Lloyd was in the same class.

title: CAFE REGULARS SHARE AN 8 A.M. CIVILITY
description: THE earliest begin arriving even before the front door is unlocked at 8 A.M. on the dot.

title: UNION CARBIDE PESTICIDE DRAWING NEW SCRUTINY
description: The illness of hundreds of California residents in the past week from pesticide-tainted watermelons has again turned the spotlight on Temik, the highly effective but controversial insect killer made by the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Activist Criticizes U.S. Over Miscarriage Drug
description: A study group's recommendation that women exposed to a dangerous drug in pregnancy be warned that they and their daughters may face a heightened risk of cancer has been buried at the Department of Health and Human Services, a public health activist charged today.

title: Weekly Concert Series At Rockefeller Center
description: ''Music For A City Evening,'' a free weekly summer series of concerts, will begin its 13th season tonight with the jazz flutist Herbie Mann, at Rockefeller Center's Channel Gardens, the walkway between 49th and 50th Streets and Fifth Avenue and the Lower Plaza, from 5 to 6:30 P.M.

title: AMERICAN HOSPITAL CREDIT SEEN
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation, fighting an unwanted takeover proposal from Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc, has signed a new $3 billion line of credit, according to Wall Street sources.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MGM-UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WINE MAKING NO LONGER MALE DOMAIN
description: Frank J. Prial is on vacation. The Wine Talk column will resume when he returns.

title: LOPEZ FAVORED IN U.S. OPEN
description: Nancy Lopez's caddie, Dee Darden, keeps statistics on his boss's golf game that can be of use from time to time. Mostly it is a matter of yardage and which clubs are used.

title: World Bank Official Moving to Mellon Post
description: James Burnham, the United States' executive director of the World Bank, has been named manager of international treasury operations at the Mellon Bank, it was announced yesterday. The appointment is effective later this month.

title: TWISTING TOKYO'S TAIL ON BALANCE OF TRADE
description: Here was John C. Danforth, the normally well-mannered lawyer-clergyman-Republican Senator from Missouri, sending word to the Japanese Prime Minister, saying, no, he would not see his special envoys.

title: THE CHOICE IN LEBANON
description: Since the Israeli Army completed the withdrawal of most of its troops from Lebanon last month, a debate has been raging inside the Israeli defense establishment over whether Israel should continue to maintain a security zone in southern Lebanon.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Knowledge Denied
description: Set among other imponderables of the subway system is this graffito, written on a poster on the uptown side of the Eighth Street BMT station:

title: STAGE: KABUKI, AT THE MET
description: A POTENTATE in a voluminous silvery robe sits on a platform center stage, flanked by bodyguards with red skin and blue pates or nobler warriors in shimmering gold gowns with painted downturned mouths. A contingent of grotesque pink troops sits, feet apart, on a level below, while one tier down the captives -women with pursed lips, men with impassive countenances but eyes aglow - remain equally immobile. Ceremony hangs in the air - the main characters speak, lips barely moving but eyes burning until a hero bursts in, enveloped in a massive costume topped by his own mask-like face.

title: 1 POTATO 2 INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
TURNER TERMS BID IN JEOPARDY
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast entrepreneur, said today that recent moves by the management of CBS Inc. and the New York State Legislature may have made his efforts to acquire the network impossible.

title: Summer Games
description: Joseph M. Ramos was turning one-handed cartwheels in the street, his establishment-brown tie flapping around his neck. Speaking in rapid Spanish with the admiring youngsters who surrounded him, he nimbly dropped on his heels and demonstrated a few leg circles, swirling his outstretched leg around under his body, Cossack-style. Mr. Ramos looked pleased with himself.

title: Justice Powell Has Surgery
description: Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court underwent surgery for a hernia Monday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., a spokesman for Justice Powell confirmed today. The spokesman, Virginia Eggleston, said the 77-year-old Justice had ''no complications'' in surgery, described as a follow-up to an operation last January for removal of a cancerous prostate.

title: A DIPLOMAT AND A FEMINIST: LETICIA RAMOS SHANHANI
description: When she was 22 years old, Leticia R. Shahani fell in love with a man 15 years her senior. She spent the next 10 years finishing her studies and shaping her career before she married him. ''My feminist philosophy has been shaped by my own life,'' she said in an interview.

title: New Stands For Columbia
description: Lawrence A. Wien, who has already donated $4 million for the construction and renovation of Columbia University athletic fields, announced yesterday he was donating an additional $2 million to build visitors' stands at Wien Stadium.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A MEASURE TO AID CAMBODAIN REBELS
description: The House voted today to approve $5 million in military and economic aid to the non-Communist rebels in Cambodia. The vote was 288 to 122. On the same vote, the House rejected an amendment that would have limited the $5 million to humanitarian aid, including food and medicine.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Shearson Lehman In China Venture
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers and the First Commercial Bureau Friendship Corporation of Peking yesterday announced a $150 million agreement to develop a luxury hotel with a ''friendship store'' and a two-tower apartment and office complex in Peking.

title: Atari Is Shipping 520 ST Computer
description: Atari Inc. has begun shipments of its 520 ST computer to distributors, a company official said. But it might take a week or so for the machines to reach dealers' shelves, according to James Copland, vice president of marketing, who added that Atari planned to ship ''well in excess of 25,000'' units in the next three or four weeks.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLIGHT OF EDITOR FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: ONE of the more curious British series floating around the schedule of cable's Arts & Entertainment network is a 1980 BBC production called ''Escape.'' It consists of docudramas about assorted people getting out of tight situations. But for the British, evidently, the element of suspense is foremost. It really doesn't matter who is escaping to where. One of the programs breathtakingly details, for instance, the defection to Moscow of Kim Philby, the spy, as British Intelligence closes in on him. The British attitude to spies can sometimes be surprisingly tolerant.

title: Top Yield 9.424% For Texas Agency
description: The Texas Housing Agency yesterday tentatively priced $200 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9.424 percent for bonds maturing in 2016, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 10, 1985
description: International

title: Afghan Rebel Attacks On Convoys Reported
description: Western diplomats said today that Afghan rebels attacked two Soviet-Afghan military convoys last month, killing hundreds of soldiers, and mounted their heaviest rocket assault in months on the suburbs of the capital of Kabul.

title: 12TH FOR GOODEN
description: By the eighth inning tonight, Dwight Gooden was caving in to the heat and humidity. By the ninth, he was happy to come out of the game.

title: Communications Area: 2 New Books Offered
description: Newcomers between the communications industry bookends are contributions from both a public relations man and an ad guy.

title: THE PLUCK OF THE CITY'S GUERRILLA GOLFERS
description: In golf, as in life, almost everything is a little different in New York. Take golf-course hazards, for example, which tend to be of the sand and water variety elsewhere, but are far more diverse on New York City courses.

title: Coke Cuts TV Tie to Rock Show
description: COCA-COLA, which was to have been the major advertiser on the ABC-TV Network's three hour prime-time coverage of the highly publicized Live Aid telethon of rock stars Saturday, withdrew its involvement yesterday.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REPUBLICBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THORPE HOLDS STATE GOLF LEAD
description: With a round that he described as ''the best I've played this year, tee to green,'' Jim Thorpe today retained his share of the lead in the second round of the Michelob New York State Open.

title: WHY THE SAATCHI AGENCY WILL MOVE TO HUDSON ST.
description: The 18-story granite and glass office building that Tishman Speyer Properties plans to build at 375 Hudson Street has been marketed as a ''smart'' building that incorporates the latest innovations in telecommunications and computer operations.

title: OPERA: 'LA RONDINE' RETURNS TO CITY
description: WHEN the New York City Opera first produced ''La Rondine'' last summer, audiences greeted it with gasps of pleasure and noisy ovations. Puccini's most underappreciated opera had found a public. One had to wonder, however, whether such a fragile connoisseur's item would hold up the second time around, when the delightful surprise and novelty of the premiere had worn off.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SAVAGE GRACE. By Natalie Robins and Steven M. L. Aronson. 492 pages. William Morrow. $17.95. WHEN Tony Baekeland, great-grandson of the man who made millions by inventing the first commercially successful plastic, stabbed his mother to death in 1972, it was the final chapter in a family saga with plot twists worthy of ''Dynasty'' - or perhaps Tennessee Williams. For one, there was Tony's homosexuality; by 14 he was seducing other boys. While Tony's sexual preferences are not so remarkable, his mother's response was: she tried, it seems, to save Tony from his homosexuality by seducing him. Then, when Tony finally managed to bring home a girlfriend, his father ran off with her.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
G.M. CHALLENGES PROPERTY VALUATIONS IN MICHIGAN
description: The General Motors Corporation, in what it calls the largest challenge to property taxes in towns in which it owns factories, is contesting $750 million in assessments of its property values in 17 Michigan communities.

title: SHULTZ AT CAMBODIA BORDER: A 'GUT' UNDERSTANDING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz took his message of American support for non-Communist Cambodian rebels and for Thailand's national security to the border of Cambodia today, touring refugee camps, a relocated village and a military base within a few miles of massed Vietnamese troops.

title: GOING TO WALL ST.
description: David A. Stockman, the White House budget director and a key architect of the Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce the size and scale of the Federal Government, announced today that he would resign Aug. 1.

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Fiber-Optic Product for Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will enter the fiber-optics market with a connector for single-mode optical fibers produced by its newly formed division, Lamdek Fiber Optics, the company announced.

title: Schaak Chairman Says He Was Forced to Quit
description: Larry H. Welch has resigned as chairman, chief executive and a director of Schaak Electronics Inc. after less than two months in the posts, the company said yesterday. Richard L. Schaak, the former chairman and chief executive of the troubled chain of retail electronics stores, resumed both jobs.

title: Rabbi Moshe Roginsky, 76; Led Worldwide Relief Group
description: Rabbi Moshe Roginsky, a Talmudic scholar and executive director of Ezras Torah, an international relief organization, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 76 years old.

title: TIGERS GET 4 IN 9TH TO BEAT WHITE SOX
description: Chet Lemon's bases-loaded single scored Alan Trammell and capped a four-run ninth inning tonight that lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 6-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALICE TAYLOR
description: Alice Taylor, the founding editor of Focus, the magazine of the American Geographical Society, died of cancer last Friday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm Bank Rate
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday announced an average interest rate of 9.55 percent on $533 million of five-year bonds sold through various securities dealers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Century Corp., a San Antonio-based company involved in real estate investments and loans, has named Roger D. Harrison president and chief operating officer, succeeding John C. Kerr, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Slain Man Linked To Big Drug Theft
description: A man shot to death in gangland fashion was a former narcotics detective and a suspect in the ''French Connection'' drug theft case, authorities said yesterday.

title: LIBERTY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISLAND PICKED FOR SEWER PLANT IN CLEANUP OF BOSTON HARBOR
description: A new regional water and sewer authority this afternoon chose a site for a $2 billion sewage treatment plant for the Boston area, a key step in an effort to clean up the harbor, which is expected to take the rest of the century.

title: STATE CHECKING COAST MELONS
description: New York State inspectors are spot-checking all shipments of melons from California for traces of a pesticide that is believed to have made almost 300 people sick in the West.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Continental Corp., Phoenix, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reduced its stake in Gulf Broadcast Co. common stock to 20.3 percent of the total outstanding.

title: DEMOCRATS STILL TINKER WITH PUBLIC PERCEPTION
description: The political talk in Washington lately has been about how the Democratic Party is becoming publicly presentable again.

title: Car Bomb Kills Woman And Son in Florida
description: A car bomb killed a multimillionaire woman and her son Tuesday and injured the woman's daughter, the authorities said.

title: Wings Accused
description: Two National Hockey League general managers said yesterday they had filed tampering charges against the Detroit Red Wings with the league.

title: MOVIES IN NEW YORK ALL THE CITY'S FILM SET
description: Even in a city accustomed to film crews in its midst, the recent activities of the ''Miami Vice'' production team were the kind of thing that stopped traffic.

title: Roots of Wife Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN, 25, SEIZED IN RIDER'S DEATH ON QUEENS IND
description: A 25-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with pushing a stranger to his death in front of an oncoming train Tuesday in Queens, the police said.

title: PENTAGON SEEKS CURBS ON BIOTECHNOLOGY FLOW
description: The Defense Department said yesterday that it would seek cooperation from the nation's allies to keep the Soviet bloc from obtaining important biotechnology products and manufacturing processes. The announcement brought immediate protests from industry executives and academics who fear the move could hamper international research.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bridge: Another Application of Rule On Touching Honor Cards
description: A well-known principle of practical play concerns touching honor cards in the closed hand: Declarer should lead high if he wants the next player to cover, but low if he does not.

title: CHRISTIE'S 'REGRETS' SALE ERROR
description: The board of directors of Christie's said yesterday that the auction house ''took the gravest view'' of an incident in 1981 in which a top Christie's official falsely reported the number of paintings that were sold at an auction.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: JAPANESE FOLK ART
description: Mingei: Japanese Folk Art, the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, 718-638-5000.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $4,400,000, or 69 cents per share, for the quarter and $7,332,000, or $1.87 per share, for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $2,792,000, or 44 cents per share, for the quarter and $4,084,000, or $1.05 per share, for the 6 months.

title: Twice-Told Name
description: Who's who at N.Y.U?

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BENIGN GROWTH WILL BE REMOVED FROM PRESIDENT'S LOWER INTESTINE
description: President Reagan is scheduled to have a benign, or noncancerous, polyp removed from his lower intestine Friday at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center, the White House announced today.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY IS CRITICIZED ON EARTHQUAKE SAFETY ISSUE
description: Democrats accused the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today of ''playing a giant shell game to keep the public confused and in the dark'' on important issues involving the safety of nuclear reactors.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Friendly Ice Cream Appoints Chairman
description: The Friendly Ice Cream Corporation yesterday named John F. Cauley chairman and chief executive of the company, a subsidiary of the Hershey Foods Corporation that operates a chain of 725 restaurants primarily in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Market Place;   Liz Claiborne's Many Fans
description: WHILE securities analysts are trimming earnings estimates for various apparel companies, they envisage another year of solid gains for Liz Claiborne Inc. Shares of this innovative designer of women's clothing have climbed from a low of 12 3/8 in February 1984 to a record high of 49 1/2 last month.

title: CONGRESS STREET PROPORTIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $32,000 for the quarter and $125,000 for the 9 months. c-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $200,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLYWOOD is frequently used for home projects, but many people are not familiar with other types of structural panels made of wood particles. They often cost less than plywood but are more dense and thus much heavier.

title: SUFFIELD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for the year-ago periods are not available because the company went public on June 1, 1984.

title: Champion Sale Of Units Set
description: The Champion International Corporation, in a move to reduce the debt it incurred from its acquisition of the St. Regis Corporation last year, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell several of its building products operations to current management in a leveraged buyout. Industry analysts placed the value of the transaction between $155 million and $175 million.

title: Books: Saudi Influence
description: THE AMERICAN HOUSE OF SAUD: The Secret Petrodollar Connection. By Steven Emerson. 450 pages. Franklin Watts. $18.95.

title: XICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Public TV Demonstrates Press Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: MOYNIHAN ASSERTS STOCKMAN SAID REAGAN DOUBTED TAX-CUT THEORY Friends of David Stockman, the departing budget director, say he has in mind a blockbuster book on Government. Washington Talk, page A20.
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that in 1981 David A. Stockman, the Federal budget director, confided to him that President Reagan did not believe in the supply-side economic principles upon which the Administration's tax cut was based.

title: Comeback Begins
description: Mike Flanagan was a bit wild, but he passed his first test in Hagerstown, Md., last night as he began his comeback from a torn Achilles' tendon he suffered in an offseason basketball game.

title: OWNERS MINIMIZE NEED OF STRIKE DATE
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners told their labor counterparts yesterday they didn't think it was necessary for the players' executive board to set a strike date next Monday, but there is virtually no chance that will deter the players from establishing a negotiating deadline.

title: NOBEL LAUREATE IN ECONOMICS
description: Simon Kuznets, the Harvard University economist who won a Nobel memorial prize for pioneering the measurement of national income and economic growth, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 84 years old.

title: Pastor Guilty of Using Violence to Discipline
description: A minister accused of using sex, degradation and violence to keep his parishioners in line was convicted of a series of criminal acts today, and his wife, two children and seven other followers were found guilty of lesser offenses.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Reactivated Len Barker, pitcher. Optioned Steve Shields, pitcher, to Richmond of the International League.

title: TALKING BACK Words for Willa
description: E.A. Mares, an administrator at the Albuquerque, N.M., Museum, is not happy about ''esa mujer . . . that woman,'' Willa Cather. That's because in her novel ''Death Comes for the Archbishop'' Miss Cather was unkind to Mr. Mares's great-great-uncle, Padre Antonio Jose Martinez de Taos, about whom he offers a 45-minute dramatic monologue.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GEORGIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUMMIT BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOME VOICE DOUBT ON GAINING ACCORD ON BUDGET DETAILS
description: White House officials and Congressional budget negotiators agreed today that a framework was emerging on a 1986 budget compromise, but they provided varied assessments on whether it could yield a House-Senate agreement.

title: FREE SUMMER MEALS LURE CHILDREN BACK TO SCHOOL IN CITY'S POVERTY AREAS
description: When summer arrived and classes let out in late June, 10-year-old Angelique Medrano looked forward to two whole months without having to set foot in school. But yesterday, Angelique, who will enter fifth grade in the fall, was once again at Public School 2, at 122 Henry Street on the Lower East Side.

title: AN OLD FAVORITE REVITALIZED IN PARIS
description: THERE is a secret society, worldwide, that loves the Musee des Arts Decoratifs in Paris. Its members grieved when between 1980 and 1982 the museum gradually closed some rooms, then closed down entirely for three years for renovation and refurbishing, mostly to give more space to a collection of 20th-century objects that had been in storage. And when DESIGN NOTEBOOK the museum reopened early this summer, they could have sung and danced in the streets.

title: MOSCOW QUESTIONS PRESS REPORTS ON 'STAR WARS' CONCESSION
description: Soviet arms negotiators said here today that reports indicating that Moscow was now willing to accept an arms treaty permitting American research on a space-based missile defense were incorrect.

title: Marine Buys Stake in Bank
description: In a move designed in part to thwart an unfriendly takeover bid of the Michigan National Bank by Detroit's Comerica Inc., the Marine Midland Banks of New York announced yesterday that it had invested $58 million to gain an equity interest in Michigan National.

title: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include operations of the Hooker Anchor and the Marine Chemical divisions which Rule Industries aquired in April.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ROMAN IN GLOAMING Amid all the transient chic of the gold coast that is the East Side in the fifties, Roma di Notte, 137 East 55th Street (832-1128), would seem to be almost as enduring as the empire city for which it is named. This restaurant-night club has been there for 35 years and it has maintained the same ambience, a mixture of catacombs and wine cellar that is carried with restraint rather than kitsch.

title: SOVIET AND CHINA SIN FIVE-YEAR TRADE PACT
description: The Soviet Union and China agreed today to almost double trade over the next five years, a move that diplomats assessed as a notable step in the revival of relations.

title: STAGE: NEAL BELL'S 'RAW YOUTH' OPENS AT PLAYWRIGHTS HORIZONS
description: NEAL BELL has come up with the cockamamie plot of the year for ''Raw Youth,'' his new play at the Playwrights Horizons Studio Theater. Mr. Bell asks us to believe that a middle-aged con man would be engaged by the F.B.I. to pose as a pimp in order to trap a homosexual (but married) Congressman with a male prostitute. And that's the credible part. For the prostitute, the con man recruits his own homosexual son, a crooked former policeman who has lately taken to dating a female vice-squad officer. ''The F.B.I. works in mysterious ways,'' explains Dad, and perhaps somewhere in the great beyond, even J. Edgar Hoover is nodding in agreement.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Turk Denies Any Role In Attempt to Kill Pope
description: A Turk accused of being the link between Soviet bloc intelligence services and a right-wing Turkish terrorist who shot Pope John Paul II in 1981 today denied having any part in a purported plot to kill the Pope.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earning figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: When Foes of Pornography Are Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Crown Zellerbach Files to Restructure
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation filed a plan yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to carry out its previously announced restructuring into three parts, but added that Sir James Goldsmith, who has been its takeover nemesis, did not approve.

title: JEWISH SETTLERS ARE CONVICTED IN TERROR CASES
description: An Israeli court today convicted 3 Jewish settlers of murder and 12 others of different violent crimes against Arabs, ending a 13-month trial of Jewish terrorists.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about a proposed Chinese-American nuclear energy accord incorrectly described a dispute over the interpretation of a key section. The disagreement arose because the Chinese apparently believed that the accord permitted certain nuclear advice they were providing to Pakistan.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 23
description: Year-ago shares outstanding include equivalent shares from dilutive stock options.

title: YANKS WIN IN 9TH ON WINFIELD HIT, 6-5
description: Fraternal and confident, the Yankees finished the first half of the regular season yesterday by rallying from a 4-0 deficit to beat the Kansas City Royals, 6-5, at the Stadium.

title: South Africans Pursue Fugitive Into Embassy
description: South African policemen burst into the Netherlands Embassy in Pretoria on Tuesday in pursuit of a Dutch political detainee who had escaped, diplomatic sources said today.

title: BIOSENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for the latest periods include a $70,000 inventory writedown associated with reductions in certain component costs.

title: OLIVER GIVES JAYS NEW CLOUT
description: Al Oliver, acquired a day earlier, and Lloyd Moseby each homered and knocked in three runs to pace the Toronto Blue Jays to an 11-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight.

title: COURT VOIDS ABORTION CURB IN JERSEY
description: A Federal judge today voided a state rule requiring that abortions after the 16th week of pregnancy be performed in licensed hospitals and not in clinics.

title: FATHERS ATTENDING CAESAEREAN BIRTHS
description: ELSE SNEDEMARK'S baby was already two weeks past due. After Miss Snedemark had been in intermittent labor for 39 hours, doctors decided to perform a Caesarean section. A local anesthetic was administered, making her numb from about the waist down, but otherwise leaving her conscious.

title: PRESIDENT ADDRESSES DELEGATES TO NAIROBI
description: President Reagan today told the United States delegates to the 1985 United Nations Decade for Women conference, which begins Monday in Nairobi, Kenya, that they should ''firmly believe that the business of this conference is women, not propaganda.''

title: Rating the Coach
description: Coaches at Eastern Michigan University have a new scoring system to worry about this fall - not one that affects on-the-field results, but a new evaluation system that will set the coaches' salary increases for the following season. Under a plan approved June 26 by the Board of Regents, the coaches will be scored by the athletic department in various categories relating to team performance, and the biggest raises will go to the coaches who get the highest scores.

title: Colt Profits Up 22.5%
description: Colt Industries announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose 22.5 percent, to $45.8 million, or $2.30 a share, from $37.4 million, or $1.61 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales slipped 5.2 percent, to $476.3 million, from $502.3 million. The diversified manufacturer of industrial products said results in the latest three months included a credit of $9.8 million relating to the 1982 disposition of the company's steelmaking facility in Midland, Pa.

title: MATHMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sri Lanka to Free 643 Held as Tamil Rebels
description: The Government said today that it planned to free 643 people suspected of being Tamil guerrillas and lift a night curfew in the Northern Province for the first time in eight months.

title: Accounts
description: * Omni magazine announced that it plans to increase its advertising rates by 10 percent with its October issue.

title: Key Sea-Land Investor Plays Down Intentions
description: When a group of companies controlled by Harold C. Simmons disclosed earlier this week that it intended to increase its stake in the Sea-Land Corporation to at least 15 percent, the New Jersey container and shipping company called the news ''most unwelcome.''

title: INQUIRY ON HUTTON COULD BE REOPENED
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that if E. F. Hutton & Company was found to have withheld documents in the three-year Federal investigation of a multibillion-dollar illegal bank overdraft scheme, the Justice Deparment would reopen its investigation.

title: Britain Sets Tax Weapo
description: The House of Commons unanimously approved a measure today that would enable Britain to retaliate against what it regards as double taxation of British-based companies by some American states.

title: NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE AMONG 6 BUILDINGS GAINING LANDMARK STATUS
description: The City's Landmarks Preservation Commission has conferred landmark status on the New York Stock Exchange, the neo-classical symbol of American finance, and on two twin-towered apartment buildings that help etch the Central Park West skyline.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $576,000 for the quarter and $1,289,000 for the six months. Per share figures reflect a five percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: Further Space Laser Tests Set
description: Satisfied with the results of an experiment that involved shooting a laser at the space shuttle last month, the Pentagon said today it would soon start new tests in which lasers will be directed at small, higher-flying rockets.

title: MEXICO CUTS PRICES OF ITS OIL
description: Mexico reduced the average price of its crude oil today by as much as $1.24 a barrel and announced a new pricing system that differentiates among geographical areas.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture yesterday with an article about life in North Korea was published in error. It showed Hong Kong, not Pyongyang.

title: 3 Fatally Stabbed In Brooklyn Home
description: Three people, including a 60-year-old woman and one of her sons, were found stabbed to death yesterday morning in their private home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Margaret Jory Dies; Was Ascap Director
description: Margaret Jory, a leading classical-music administrator, died of heart failure yesterday. She was 48 years old.

title: BALDRIDGE AND LEWIS HEAD BUDGET PROSPECTS
description: Malcolm Baldrige, the Secretary of Commerce, and Drew Lewis, a former Transportation Secretary, are first among many possible successors to David A. Stockman as budget director, President Reagan's chief of staff said today.

title: BIG BOARD SET TO OPEN AT 9:30
description: In an important step toward creation of a 24-hour trading system, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would begin trading at 9:30 A.M., a half-hour earlier than at present, starting Sept. 30. If the change receives the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it will mark the first time in more than a decade that the Big Board has extended its hours. The market now closes at 4 P.M.

title: AMERICANA IN EXHIBITION OF BUILDERS' CATALOGUES
description: SINCE the Industrial Revolution, manufacturers attempting to sell household goods have found catalogues to be one of the most effective ways of reaching the buyer. Elaborate, often colorfully illustrated pamphlets, posters, bills and directories advertised a wide assortment of objects -items as small as a keyhole and as large as a three-bedroom house.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $338,000 for the quarter and $588,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. WELCOMES SYRIAN ROLE AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were encouraged by Syria's decision to play a role in tightening security at Beirut International Airport, apparently in reaction to the American moves to close it down.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SIMULATING TROUBLE SPOTS FOR U.S. OPEN
description: JoAnne Carner dropped golf balls in the rough as she played a final practice round on the Upper Course at the Baltusrol Golf Club today in preparation for the start of the 40th United States Women's Open Thursday.

title: UNITED BANK CORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: Tom Massimino, 25, the oldest son of the Villanova basketball coach, Rollie Massimino, has been appointed assistant coach at Bradley University. . . . In an effort to keep major league baseball in Pittsburgh, Allegheny County commissioners have authorized three law firms to research ways the county can help to keep the Pirates stay in town, including the possibility of buying the team.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paul Jr. Guilty Plea
description: The race car driver John Paul Jr. has agreed to plead guilty to a Federal racketeering charge in exchange for the Government's agreeing to drop four drug-related counts. An Aug. 5 hearing was scheduled for Paul to enter the plea.

title: Topics;   Talking Back Classic Wisdom
description: ''Don't change the formula for Coca-Cola'' used to be a business aphorism for leaving well enough alone. And for 99 years the formula stood firm.

title: Coliseum-Site Race Nears the Finish Line
description: The rumor traffic around Columbus Circle yesterday was heavier than the vehicular kind and it all seemed to go in the same direction: that Boston Properties and Phibro-Salomon Inc. would win the race to develop the New York Coliseum site.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NIELSEN WINS STATE GOLF
description: Lonnie Nielsen, who says he is playing better than he did when he was a regular on the PGA Tour, overtook Jim Thorpe on the 16th hole today to win the Michelob New York State Open by a stroke. He scored 68, three under par for the Big G course of Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club, while Thorpe scrambled to a 70.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b.Net income. c-Including a gain of $6,554,131 from the sale of real estate.

title: Pressure Drop Investigated At Nuclear Plant in Arizona
description: Sheriff's deputies are investigating as a case of attempted criminal damage a sudden drop in water pressure in the unfinished Unit 2 reactor at the Palo Verde nuclear plant, 50 miles west of Phoenix.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 11, 1985
description: International

title: EGO, ETHICS AND THE 80'S
description: ARE we obsessed with self and indifferent to others, particularly the poor and deprived? ''Currents'' departs from its usual half-hour format and raises the question in a special one-hour program, ''Looking Out for Number One: The Ethics of the 80's?'' In fact, when a television program asks questions like that, it assumes the answer is yes. Otherwise, there would be no program.

title: Required Reading;   Efficient Performance
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, writing in the most recent edition of Management, a publication of the United States Office of Personnel Management:

title: Virginia Issue Tentatively Priced
description: The Virginia Housing Development Authority tentatively priced $120 million of residential mortgage revenue bonds yesterday, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Article 117258 -- No Title
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation reported a loss of $55.9 million for the third quarter ended May 25, compared with a loss of $13.9 million for the comparable period last year. Revenues for the quarter totaled $140.2 million, down from $157.5 million last year.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STACY KEACH WILL RETURN TO 'MIKE HAMMER'
description: Stacy Keach, recently released from a six-month jail term in England for smuggling cocaine, said today he is ''looking forward to putting on the hat and trenchcoat again'' and returning as the star of ''Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer.''

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
100 Chilean Youths Arrested in School
description: Riot policemen stormed into a school here today and arrested about 100 schoolchildren who were demanding free bus passes and free elections to student unions, witnesses said.

title: VOLUME UP
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, with investors relieved that progress appeared to have been made in talks on the Federal budget.

title: STOCKMAN BLOCKBUSTER
description: It is as much a part of the Washington scene these days as lobbying or embasssy parties or press conferences: A public figure leaves Government for private life and decides to write a book.

title: IN FEARFUL COSTA RICA, THE YANQUIS ARE WELCOME
description: As the United States gradually increases its military aid to Costa Rica, one thing seems missing in this country without an army: popular protest.

title: Prize-Money Plan
description: A memorandum prepared by the staff of Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn proposes shattering Boston Marathon tradition by awarding prize money totaling $292,500 and running the race on a Sunday rather than a Monday.
