Mayor Flynn is examining the possibilities out of concern that the historic race has declined by losing many top runners who are opting for more lucrative events.

title: SOVIET GENERAL AMPLIFIES OFFER OF 25% ARMS CUT
description: A senior Soviet general told an American legislator last week that Moscow's offer to reduce strategic nuclear forces by 25 percent or more applied to missile warheads as well as missiles.

title: SIDEWALK REPAIRS REPORTED FAR BEHIND SCHEDULE
description: The city's $74 million sidewalk replacement program is far behind schedule, plagued by overpayments to contractors and will cost twice twice as much as projected if it is to be completed on time, according to an audit by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Saints Sign Toles
description: The New Orleans Saints said they had signed Alvin Toles, a linebacker from Tennessee who was their No. 1 draft choice, to a series of one-year contracts. He is only the fourth 1985 first-round draftee to sign at a time when agents for other early picks have been accusing National Football League teams of trying to hold down offers. . . . The United States Football League Players Association has filed a grievance on behalf of the Tampa Bay Bandit players, who have not been paid for their final regular-season game. Bandit officials have acknowledged a cash flow problem in recent weeks, but the team's director of business operations, Ralph Campbell, said the club was working toward a solution.

title: 12,000 FIREFIGHTERS BATTLE BLAZES IN 11WESTERN STATES
description: The largest force of firefighters in the nation's history has been deployed to battle fast-moving brush and timber fires throughout the West, Federal officials said today.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON POPS IN THE PARK
description: ALTHOUGH the Boston Pops is currently celebrating its 100th season, the group had never played in Central Park before this week. On Monday night, John Williams and his forces handily repaired this omission with a program largely devoted to melodies from the movies on the Great Lawn. By 8 o'clock, thousands of men, women and children had assembled, to share the proverbial jug of wine and loaf of bread with a favorite thou, enjoy the clement weather and, not so incidentally, listen to some favorite songs.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Toronto-based manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, said that it had agreed to purchase the axial-flow combine harvester technology and related holdings of White Farm Manufacturing Canada Ltd., which has been in receivership and under the control of Peat Marwick Ltd. since April. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MUSIC: DAKOTA SINGS
description: DAKOTA STATON'S tough, sassy brand of jazz-blues singing bridges the gap between two generations. While the 53-year-old singer's biggest formative influence remains the late Dinah Washington, who projected the same ''I've-been-through-it-all'' womanly wisdom with more than a hint of sexual mayhem, Miss Staton's experiments in note-bending and abrupt timbral changes of pace anticipated the iconoclastic sophistication of Chaka Khan and Nell Carter.

title: 20-YEAR OLD PERSPECTIVE ON WORLD'S FAIR
description: IT is now nearly 20 years since the closing of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, and it is being commemorated by ''The Mighty Fair,'' an exhibition at the gallery of the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts.

title: OPERA: 'LA RONDINE' RETURNS TO CITY SEASON
description: WHEN the New York City Opera first produced ''La Rondine'' last summer, audiences greeted it with gasps of pleasure and noisy ovations. Puccini's most underappreciated opera had found a public. One had to wonder, however, whether such a fragile connoisseur's item would hold up the second time around, when the delightful surprise and novelty of the premiere had worn off.

title: Fishing Derby on Lake Erie
description: Not long ago, Lake Erie, polluted and overburdened with nutrients, was believed to be dying. But today it supports diverse and substantial sport and commercial fisheries, that, according to a spokesman for the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, produce more food fish than do the four other Great Lakes combined.

title: Article 117215 -- No Title
description: The St. James Theater on West 44th Street is being renovated at a cost of about $1.5 million by Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway houses.

title: TAKING ON THE 'IMPOSSIBLE' HOUSE: THREE RENOVATIONS IN PROGRESS
description: THE missions seemed impossible: to create a single-family dwelling from a tiny wedge-shaped three-story building that was uninhabited and uninhabitable; to restore a historic octagonal house with a two-story dome that was literally coming apart at the seams; to turn a former exhibition hall, dilapidated from years of neglect, into a family home and bed-and-breakfast guest house.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Including income on the sale of discontinued operations of $79,189,000 and an extraordinary credit of $959,000. c-Including income on the sale of discontinued operations of $12,185,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,020,000.

title: Contest at NOW
description: With only 10 days to go before the election, the two candidates for the presidency of the National Organization for Women are running decorous campaigns out of their Washington headquarters.

title: Water Diversion Plan Advances in California
description: A plan to divert water draining from Imperial Valley farms to huge areas of urban and suburban southern California has advanced to the public hearing stage with unanimous votes by two major water boards.

title: People
description: * Vicky Amon and Bradford L. Moses have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Warwick Advertising.

title: DEFECT IN IMMUNE SYSTEM FOUND IN VICTIMS OF AIDS, SCIENTISTS SAY
description: Government scientists reported today that they had identified a critical defect in the immune system of patients who suffer acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Bond Prices Turn Downward
description: Bond prices drifted lower and short-term interest rates edged higher yesterday as traders cautiously awaited signs of the Federal Reserve's next move.

title: Sealing a Terrorist Foxhole
description: An important first step has been taken by Britain and the United States to seal a legal foxhole that shelters terrorists - the ''political offense'' exception in their extradition treaty. The two Governments have signed a supplementary treaty that would deny fugitives the ability to avoid extradition by claiming that their crimes were ''political.'' The Senate's prompt ratification would encourage other countries to make the same sensible change.

title: NORTH KOREA TRIES HARD TO PORTRAY ITSELF AS PEACEFUL AND U.S. AS THE VILLAIN
description: Few sights that officials show visitors to this Communist nation are invested with greater symbolic importance than a huge wall that snakes across the Korean Peninsula from the Yellow Sea to the Sea of Japan.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

THE ALLIED ROLE IN 'STAR WARS';

AN IRRITANT TO JAPAN?
description: The Western Europeans are not the only ones being pressed to participate in research in the President's Strategic Defense Initiative. The Japanese, too, have been at the receiving end of the Administration's exhortations -somewhat less public pressures that nevertheless risk derailing an otherwise improving defense relationship.

title: Technology;   Picturephones: A New Effort
description: WALL STREET analysts wrote off the technology long ago, and telecommunications consultants are not much more hopeful. But picturephones - telephones with cameras and monitors attached so callers can see each other -may soon establish themselves in the market following some favorable scientific developments, proponents of the technology say.

title: Chess in the Park
description: All the faces of Bryant Park were showing yesterday.

title: TRIAL ON RACKETS DELAYED IN BOSTON
description: Three hours after it opened today, the long-delayed trial of six men whom Federal prosecutors describe as the leaders of Boston's organized crime syndicate was interrupted. A defendant collapsed, complained of heart pains and was hospitalized.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Over 40 million consumers every day in the United States enjoy Coca-Cola but thousands of dedicated Coca-Cola consumers have told us they still want the original taste as an option.

title: Contempt Finding Reversed For Writers in Belushi Case
description: A judge has vacated contempt-of-court orders against two writers who refused to testify about interviews with Cathy Evelyn Smith in which she is reported to have admitted administering the drugs that killed John Belushi, the comedian.

title: A SPECIAL ON TIME MACHINES
description: ''TIME TRAVEL: FACT, FICTION AND FANTASY'' won't damage your mind; it won't grip you, either. Mostly, it will make you want to see a good, old movie like ''The Time Machine'' with Rod Taylor. Lacking that, however, we have the one-hour special on Channel 5 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Jet Payroll Called Highest in N.F.L.
description: The New York Jets had the highest player payroll and the Houston Oilers the lowest in the National Football League last season, according to a confidential report by the players union obtained by The Rocky Mountain News.

title: Ethiopian Leader Sees Lack of Long-Term Aid
description: Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the Ethiopian leader, accused the West today of failing to provide adequate long-term aid to Africa.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Texaco Selling Coal Properties
description: Texaco Inc. said it had agreed to sell its interests in several coal mines in Colorado and Utah to the Cyprus Minerals Company. Texaco said the sale was the latest step in a plan to dispose of assets it acquired last year in the $10.1 billion purchase of the Getty Oil Company that do not fit into Texaco's long-term strategy.

title: ACTION PACKETS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
JERSEY SEES END TO WATER RATIONING
description: New Jersey is considering an end soon to the water rationing imposed on 2.3 million residents by Governor Kean nearly two months ago, officials in the State Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Opener of a four-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. This is first of four games, all at night. (Television -Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing James (Buddy) McGirt vs. Ralph Twinning, 10 rounds, welterweights, at the Felt Forum. First preliminary 7:30 P.M. McGirt, from Brentwood L.I., is 19-0-1. Twinning, from Muskegon, Mich., has a 28-8 record. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M.) Mike Tinley vs. Ray Gray, 10 rounds, middleweights, at the Trump Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. (Television -ESPN 9:30 P.M.) Golf U.S.G.A Women's Open at Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J. Opening round, 8 A.M. The three-time Open champion Hollis Stacy attempts to defend the title she won by one stroke at the Salem Country Club in Massachusetts last year. (Television - ESPN 5 P.M.). Anderson Memorial at Winged Foot, Mamaroneck, N.Y. 8 A.M. Second day in the better-ball team tournament. New Jersey State Golfers Association Open Championships, at Echo Lake, Westfield, N.J. Second day of stroke play. The final 36 holes will be played tomorrow. Tennis Union Savings Bank Huntington Clay Court men's singles, round of 16 championships, at Old Field Tennis Club, 400 Greenlawn Road, Greenlawn, L.I. 2 P.M. Admission is free. Eastern Masters Circuit men's 45 tournament, at the Cove Tennis Center, 60 Sea Cliff Avenue, Glen Cove, L.I. semifinals, 5 P.M. Other Events BASKETBALL: New Jersey Jammers vs.

title: ABC to Lay Off About 3% of Staff
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said that it planned to lay off between 300 and 350 people, or about 3 percent of its work force, by the end of August. The broadcasting and publishing company, which is in the process of being acquired by Capital Cities Communications Inc., said that the layoffs would come from all levels of employees.

title: North Carolina Hospital Issue
description: The North Carolina Medical Care Commission is offering $47.9 million of hospital revenue refunding bonds.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief report in Sports Pages yesterday about the 1985-86 National Hockey League schedule for metropolitan area teams described the Rangers' schedule incorrectly. They will open at home against Washington on Oct. 10, play at Hartford two nights later, then return home against the New Jersey Devils on Oct. 13.

title: TENDER LOVING HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $4 million for the quarter and $92 million for the 6 months.

title: HOLOCAUST FILM 'SHOAH' IS COMING TO NEW YORK
description: A 9 1/2-hour film on the Holocaust that has been hailed in Paris as a ''masterpiece'' will be shown in New York this fall.

title: MANAGER FORESEES PRYOR'S CAREER END
description: The sadly wasted career of Aaron Pryor may be over in the ''personal'' opinion of his manager, Buddy LaRosa.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS, CIVIL WRONGS AND MR. REYNOLDS
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE CITY;

Man Is Given Life For Killing Officer
description: A Bronx man was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for killing a police officer with a gun he had taken from the officer.

title: POLITICALLY ATTUNED ADMIRAL: WILLIAM CROWE JR.
description: In 1962, when William J. Crowe Jr. was fresh from his first command as skipper of the diesel attack submarine Trout, the logical step for an upwardly mobile Navy man was nuclear submarine school.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $173,000, or 4 cents per share, related to receipt of life insurance proceeds net of related expense.

title: No Way to Run a Railroad
description: My last three trips on the New Haven line of Metro-North - the rail system connecting New York City with its northern suburbs - featured the following experiences: a 20-minute delay caused by ''switching problems,'' whatever they were; a 30-minute delay during which the train backed up from east of the New Rochelle, N.Y., station to west of the New Rochelle station; and the piece de resistance - a train with three cars lacking air-conditioning, two without lights and the remaining three or four cars stuffed like peppers with refugees from the other cars.

title: The Times at the Palaces
description: The Times is celebrating its 200th anniversary today at Hampton Court Palace in Richmond, England. That's our cousin, The Times of London, a newspaper that won its independence under George III and has been ever since a pillar of English public life. Its history is the history of the newspaper, and we owe it much, even - since it invented both the editorial and the editorial ''we'' - our voice.

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $2,086,000 for the quarter and $2,566,000 for the year. c-Net loss after an extraordinary reversal of $1,633,000.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Civil Rights, Civil Wrongs and Mr. Reynolds
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Our Diplomats Are Probably Safest in Communist Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN'S MEDICAL CASE
description: In removing a painless benign growth from President Reagan's colon tomorrow, his doctors at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center will be finishing a job they started earlier. Last year they removed a tiny benign polyp from the President's colon and last March they found another, the one that is to be removed.

title: JAMES J. C. ANDREWS
description: James J. C. Andrews, a photographer and producer, died of pneumonia Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived in New York.

title: Fleet Financial Net Up
description: The Fleet Financial Group reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1985 climbed 33.6 percent, to $20.3 million, or $1.07 a share, from $15.2 million, or 85 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 5.6 percent, to $207 million, from $196 million. Fleet Financial, a bank holding company based in Providence, R.I., said that results were bolstered by strong earnings at its Fleet National Bank subsidiary, Rhode Island's biggest bank.

title: The Space Captain Of Women's Golf
description: The idea was to see the world. The method would just be an excuse, a way to get to new places. When Muffin Spencer-Devlin saw that her modeling career was not exactly skyrocketing, and realized that producers and directors were not going to beat down her door, she decided to search for a different approach to see the world.

title: Clark Stepping Down
description: George L. Clark Jr., who moved the New York Republican Party to the right after four decades of a more liberal bent, surprised many party members yesterday when he said he would not seek re-election as Republican state chairman in September.

title: U.S. HAS LITTLE USE FOR NORTH KOREA
description: There are no countries in the world that are held in lower esteem by the Reagan Administration than North Korea, State Department officials said today.

title: 42 MISSING YEARS: THE PUZZLE OF GLADYS BURR
description: Gladys Burr never knew why she was committed and never knew why she was released.

title: A Male President?
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: 'OLD' COKE COMING BACK AFTER OUTCRY BY FAITHFUL
description: In one of the most stunning about-faces in the history of marketing, the Coca-Cola Company yielded to thousands of irate consumers yesterday and said it would bring back the original Coke formula that it scrapped three months ago.

title: Goldberg Portrait
description: Almost 20 years after he resigned from the Supreme Court, Arthur J. Goldberg returned to the Court Tuesday for the unveiling of his official portrait. Mr. Goldberg, who is 76 years old, was appointed to the Court in 1962 by President Kennedy but resigned on July 25, 1965, when President Johnson asked him to succeed Adlai E. Stevenson as the chief United States representative at the United Nations.

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for 50 percent stock dividends paid in August 1984 and February and June 1985.

title: TWO BLASTS SINK GREENPEACE SHIP
description: Two explosions ripped through a Greenpeace protest vessel here today as it prepared for a campaign against French nuclear tests in the South Pacific. The ship's photographer was reported killed.

title: FILM: LITTIN'S 'MARUSIA'
description: IN ''Letters From Marusia,'' Miguel Littin mines the legend of a 1907 massacre in northern Chile for contemporary meaning. Mr. Littin, who was director of the Chile Film Studios under Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, has been in self-imposed exile in Mexico, where he wrote and directed this film, since the military coup that overthrew the Allende Government. In the legendary events of almost 80 years ago, he finds parallels with the events of 1973.

title: Dodgers Get Cabell
description: Less than 24 hours after they sent Al Oliver to Toronto for Len Matuszek, a first baseman, the Dodgers went out and acquired another first baseman, Enos Cabell, from the Houston Astros yesterday. In return, the Astros will receive the minor league pitcher Rafael Montalvo and a player to be named.

title: Deadly Bacteria Found In 2d Brand of Cheese
description: Listeria bacteria has been found in a second brand of Mexican-style cheese.

title: ARCHITECTURAL ADVICE FOR CO-OP BOARDS
description: IN hundreds of apartment buildings that have been converted to cooperative ownership over the last decade, owners are finding that the pride they feel in their own apartment is extending to a pride of ownership in the building.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS TAX DRIVE
description: President Reagan told Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee today that he was totally committed to overhauling the Federal income tax system, and he pledged to do all he could this fall to persuade Congress and the public to rally behind his tax proposals.

title: By Storer Trading
description: Storer Communications Inc.'s stock rose yesterday in heavier than normal volume as speculation increased that the company would soon receive a buyout bid from the Comcast Corporation, a cable television operator.

title: The U.N. Today: July 11, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Symposium on Palestinian issue -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Rumrill-Hoyt, at Last, Heralds New Accounts
description: Russ Berrie & Company of Oakland, N.J., which makes mugs, stuffed animals and other impulse gift items, after about a month with its first agency, Warwick Advertising, has switched the business to Rumrill-Hoyt. Billings are supposed to be $5 million.

title:
SCOUTING;

Fitting Finish To a Long Race
description: After 92 days of extraordinarily strenuous competition against each other, Marvin Skagerberg and Malcolm Campbell finished like true sportsmen yesterday, hitting the tape in tandem. The locale was Riverside Park near 73d Street, and the arrival of the two veteran ultramarathoners brought to an end a 3,600-mile-plus transcontinental odyssey that was billed as the longest foot race since 1929, when a New Jersey police officer named Johnny Salo captured a New York-to-Los Angeles stroll that took him 79 days.

title: METS' WINNING STREAK REACHES 9
description: Rick Aguilera, who was once concerned about his immediate future with the Mets, solidified his place in the pitching rotation with a 2-1 decision tonight over the Reds, his second consecutive complete game. The victory was the Mets' ninth straight - their longest winning streak since 1976 - and their seventh consecutive victory on the road. No Met team had ever won that many in a row on a trip.

title: Caterpillar's Net Doubles
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today that net income in the second quarter more than doubled, to $50 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with $24 million, or 25 cents a share, in the quarter last year.

title: BOBBY VALENTINE RETURNS
description: Every so often during nearly two months as the Texas Rangers' manager, Bobby Valentine has phoned Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager.

title: IN THE HOT SEAT DURING THE JERSEY DROUGHT
description: When the well runs dry, the psyche starts to sizzle.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THEATER: 'OPTIONS'
description: JO ANNA RUSH is back in her bathtub blowing bubbles and falling in love with the piano player, and Lydia Leroy of Long Island is made a legend once again as she rises to stardom on Broadway and falls to the gutter, but what they are doing in ''Options,'' a new musical revue by Walter Willison and Jefrey Silverman, is anybody's guess.

title: BAR GROUP ASSAILS PHILIPPINES AS ABUSING LAWYERS
description: The president of the American Bar Association expressed concern today over the treatment of human rights lawyers in the Philippines, saying they were arrested, harassed and sometimes killed in the last year.

title: WORKERS OPEN VALVES IN ERROR AT SHOREHAM
description: Technicians testing the Shoreham nuclear power plant improperly opened a valve system today and released air from the reactor containment building into the atmosphere, Federal and utility officials said. No radiation was released.

title: Icahn Reported In New Move
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier, has amassed a sizable stake in the American Hospital Supply Corporation, according to Wall Street sources. The medical products concern is involved in a takeover struggle.

title: BARS DESIGNED BY ARTISTS
description: BARS are the theme of an intriguing show at Art et Industrie in SoHo.

title: DAVE PARKER: BACK HOME AND HAPPY
description: He is nearly two seasons removed from the bittersweet years at Pittsburgh. But when Dave Parker remembers, everything still seems painfully alive, still seems to tug annoyingly at him. And he can't forget.

title: HERS
description: OCCASIONALLY, when I am beset by doubts and indecision, I search the papers to find out what the Supreme Court is doing lately. The notion of a ruling, any ruling, gives me hope. It reassures me that no matter how complex a problem seems, it can usually be straightened out, even if it takes nine people to do it.

title: RIGHT WING SEES ITS TIME TO STRIKE
description: For 16 years Senator James A. McClure has been trying to weaken Federal gun control laws. On Tuesday the Idaho Republican finally succeeded in getting his proposal through the Senate as a separate bill.

title: CARTER, STRAWBERRY ALL-STAR STARTERS
description: For the first time in their 24-year history, the Mets will have two starting players in an All-Star Game. That became official yesterday when Gary Carter and Darryl Strawberry were voted to starting positions on the National League team in next Tuesday night's game in Minneapolis.

title: JET'S 'BLACK BOX' IS RAISED FROM THE SEA
description: The voice recorder from the Air-India jumbo jet lost off the Irish coast last month with 329 people aboard was brought to the surface today, raising hopes that the mystery of the crash could be solved.

title: MAINE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BISHOP TUTU SAVES MAN FROM CROWD
description: Against the backdrop of a blazing automobile, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, argued and wrestled with a crowd of angry blacks today to rescue a man the crowd called a collaborator with the white authorities.

title: Changes Loom in Labor
description: Ford B. Ford, the No. 2 official in the Labor Department, is apparently being forced out as part of the shake-up of the department by Labor Secretary Bill Brock. Knowledgeable officials in the department and in private industry say that Mr. Ford, whose title is Under Secretary, is to be given a new, less sensitive job, as head of the Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE ANALOG DEVICES, INC- Joseph M. Hinchey, Senior Vice President-Finance, sold 34,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 8,718.

title: Nuclear Power vs. Oil
description: Nuclear power surpassed oil in 1984 as a source of electricity generation in the 24 countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Nuclear Energy Agency reported today. Nuclear power accounted for 18 percent, against oil's 11 percent. Both trailed coal (39 percent) and hydro power (22 percent).

title: STYLES CLASH FOR TITLE GAME
description: The opposing quarterbacks for the United States Football League championship game at Giants Stadium Sunday, Chuck Fusina of the Baltimore Stars and Bobby Hebert for the Oakland Invaders, are opposites in several other ways.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: The Wright Brothers Felled
description: Vandals have toppled two 300-pound granite pedestals holding the bronze busts of Orville and Wilbur Wright at the Wright Brothers National Memorial, and the bust of Orville Wright was stolen, the National Parks Service said. Damage was estimated at $10,000.

title: RECTISEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A ROBOT SUB IS ACHEIVING NEW DEPTHS
description: The deep-diving unmanned submarine that retrieved the voice recorder from wreckage of the Air India jumbo jet off Ireland is a robot of many talents. It is busy most of the time repairing and maintaining undersea telephone cables, but has also gone down to photograph a crashed helicopter off Norfolk, Va., and to locate and examine rockets that sank off Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Selection of Baby's Sex
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOBLAW COMPANIES LTD reports earnings for 12 wks to June 15
description: b-Including tax credits of $2.2 million for the 12 weeks and $3.6 million for the 24 weeks. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Bordeaux Court Explosion
description: A bomb exploded in the main courthouse in Bordeaux today, causing some damage but no casualties. A previously unknown group called the Punishables took responsibility.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID PALESTINIAN SITES
description: Israeli planes attacked three Palestinian positions in northern Lebanon today, killing 15 people and wounding 29, according to the police and hospitals.

title: The Silent Purge
description: A quiet convolution is going on inside the Soviet Union.

title: Haakon Chevalier, 83, Author and Translator
description: Haakon Chevalier, an author, translator and professor of French literature who left the United States in 1950 after being accused of ''anti-American activities,'' died Thursday in Paris, according to The Associated Press. He was 83 years old.

title: SHULTZ RESPONDS TO HANOI BID FOR TALKS ON MISSING AMERICANS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration was ready to work ''promptly and decisively'' with Vietnam to resolve the issue of missing Americans.

title: Loews Unit Sold
description: The Loews Corporation has completed the sale of its movie theater division to a group headed by A. Jerrold Perenchio, the former co-owner of Embassy Communications.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THINNER. By Richard Bachman. 309 pages. New American Library. $12.95. SKELETON CREW. By Stephen King. 512 pages. Putnam. $18.95.

title: Damn the Deficit! Full Spend Ahead!
description: President Reagan's ''framework'' budget deal with Speaker O'Neill is a flight from reality. The simultaneous news that Budget Director David Stockman is departing makes the outlook for deficit reduction even bleaker. The deficit crisis - and it is nothing less - is being blithely ignored, and the man who knows most about budget truths and consequences will no longer be around to goad us all.

title: Advertising;   Grey and L.H.S.&B. Join Hands
description: THE courtship that began two years ago in the buffet line at the Greenbrier has culminated in marriage as Grey Advertising, among the world's top 15 agencies, acquired a majority interest in Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, a New York agency with far more visibility than most agencies of its size.

title: Empty Stalls
description: Eastern Michigan's scoring system for coaches can be tallied by hand, but it takes a computer to decide which stables get stall space for their horses at Belmont Park.

title: TALKING BACK Calling Pitcairn
description: Pitcairn Island, a dot in the Pacific, has but 62 residents, most of them descendants of the Bounty's Fletcher Christian and his fellow troublemakers. But Heaven only knows how many relatives they've got in Providence, R.I., say, or Santa Fe, N.M.

title: EUROPEAN LEADERS' QUANDARY
description: President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative has put European leaders in a quandary.

title:
GARDENING;

TRIMMING THE TECHNICAL TERMINOLOGY OF PLANTS DOWN TO SIZE
description: WHILE gardening is usually delightfully low tech, the terminology can be a bit highfalutin.

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in Febuary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a State Court of Appeals ruling on emergency evacuation plans for the Shoreham nuclear plant incorrectly described the issuance of the majority opinion. It was unsigned.

title: CENTRAL BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
C.D. Yields Off Slightly
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed slight declines for the week ended yesterday.

title: SHUTTLE SET TO LIFT OFF TOMORROW ON A MISSION TO OBSERVE THE STARS
description: The countdown began today for the scheduled liftoff of the shuttle Challenger Friday on a seven-day mission that will transform the winged spaceplane into an advanced orbiting astronomical observatory.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Beatrice Is Offering 13 Million New Shares
description: The Beatrice Companies began offering 13 million common shares, at $31.25 each, yesterday through an international underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Proceeds will be used to reduce commercial paper borrowings from Beatrice's acquisition of Esmark Inc. in June 1984. The company said it had incurred variable rate indebtedness of about $2.7 billion related to the acquisition.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago per share figures are not available because the company went public in November 1984.

title: U.S. TO BACK PENALTIES FOR NEW DRUG THREAT
description: The Reagan Administration will propose legislation to combat the production of synthetic copies of illegal narcotics and hallucinogens, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today.

title: HOUSE ACTS TO ALLOW ANGOLA REBEL AID
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to repeal the ban on United States military aid to the guerrillas fighting the Marxist Government of Angola. The vote was 236 to 185 on an amendment to the foreign aid authorization bill.

title: Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America plans to offer repurchase agreements backed by individual single and multifamily mortgages, instead of the usual mortgage securities, to raise funds for its California thrift subsidiary, the American Savings and Loan Association. The company said it initially expects to raise $400 million to $500 million with the new instrument through agreements with Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Ciba-Geigy Stake In Laser Maker
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said it had signed an agreement with Spectra-Physics Inc. of San Jose, Calif., to buy up to 20 percent of Spectra-Physics for more than $33 million.

title: MUSICAL KNOW-HOW VS. KNOWLEDGE
description: AN article appearing in these pages a few Sundays back asked questions about how musicians are being trained and how they are going to make a living after that training is over. It has provoked an outpouring of letters -most of them stories of professional heartbreak from one-time conservatory stars or lamentations over careers that have languished.

title: Brokerage Executive Plunges to His Death
description: Alan W. Leeds, managing director of the retail municipal bond department at the securities company of L. F. Rothschild Unterberg Towbin, plunged to his death Tuesday from a 28th-floor apartment window on Park Avenue, the police said. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $9.8 million, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: HIGH BENZENE LEVEL DISCOVERED IN BLOOD OF PARK FIRE VICTIMS
description: A toxicologist testified today that the eight victims of a fun house fire last year had levels of benzene in their blood that were ''exceptionally high and unusual for fire victims.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 11, 1985
description: Companies

title: BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,488,459 for the quarter and the six months.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Horse and Wine Country
description: The state is better known for horses and tobacco, but viticulture is on the rise in Virginia and so the Smithsonian Institution is running a tour to the annual Virginia Wineries Festival in Culpepper Commonwealth Park in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains on July 20. There will be 18 Virginia wineries represented, as well as grape-stomping contests and a visit to the Rapidan River and Prince Michel vineyards. The Rapidan, according to the Smithsonian, ''prides itself on wines made in the finest German tradition and has recently begun the production of champagne.''

title: SHAMROCK WRITE-DOWN OF $810 MILLION PLANNED
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said yesterday that it would take an $810 million write-down of assets as part of a broad restructuring plan that would also call for the repurchase of at least 7 million shares and result in a net loss for the second quarter and the year.

title: ALEXANDER'S MOVE OUTSIDE THE FAMILY
description: Alexander's Inc., the New York retailer that was founded by George Farkas and run by his family for 66 years, has reached outside the family for the first time and has turned over daily control of the company to Roger A. Barrer and Louis Powell, who are expected to be formally named co-presidents shortly.

title: HUTTON PLEA FAULTED BY CHAIRMAN
description: E. F. Hutton & Company's embattled chairman, Robert Fomon, said in an interview yesterday that the brokerage house had mishandled its guilty plea two months ago to charges that it defrauded banks through a check overdrafting scheme.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 3O
description: b-Including a tax loss carryforward of $90,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a stock split paid June 1 in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend.

title: MOVE SEEN AIDING COKE'S TOTAL SALES
description: When the Coca-Cola Company locked away its fabled formula 7X in an Atlanta bank vault in late April and introduced a new, sweeter version of the world's best-selling soft drink, it took one of the great marketing gambles of all time.

title: TEXAS COURT UPHOLDS BARRING FAILING PUPILS FROM ACTIVITIES
description: The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that public school students have no inherent right to take part in extracurricular activities and struck down a lower court's attempt to overturn the state's ''no pass, no play'' rule.

title: NEW WATER CURBS AND USE OF HUDSON ORDERED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday ordered broad new water conservation measures that will affect nearly all office buildings and millions of workers in New York City. He also authorized adding Hudson River water to the regular reservoir supply.

title: GARDEN FAUCETS WITH SPECIAL FLAIR
description: DECORATIVE brass handles for outside faucets can be found in abundance at the New York Botanical Garden Shop-in-the-Garden. Called Flora and Fauna Faucets, they come in the following shapes: a snail ($16), a frog ($16), a hummingbird ($22), a swan ($30), a quail ($32), a mallard duck ($32), a sun ($32.50), a butterfly ($32.50) and a rose ($32.50).

title: Sri Lanka Police Report Plot Against President
description: The police said today that they had thwarted a bomb plot by Tamil terrorists to kill President J. R. Jayewardene.

title: FANS OF 'OLD' COKE WOULDN'T GIVE UP
description: Roy Champiomont, chairman of the Champiomont Marble Company in Houston, felt so strongly about the Coca-Cola Company's decision to change the 99-year-old formula for Coke last April that he wrote a protest song.

title: Red Sox Win On One-Hitter
description: Al Nipper and Steve Crawford combined on a one-hitter, and Steve Lyons knocked in three runs, two with a homer, to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 7-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight.

title: 'Unsung Heroes'
description: The drummer Greg Bandy will lead a group of ''Unsung Heroes'' - including the guitarist Jimmy Ponder, the keyboardist Lonnie Smith and the singer Andy Bey - in jazz concerts tomorrow at 8 and 11 P.M. at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (242-4140). Tickets are $10.

title: New G.M. Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation is laying off 3,800 more employees, at plants in Detroit and Norwood, Ohio, bringing the total on temporary layoff to 11,800. Another 14,000 employees have been indefinitely laid off.

title: Advertising;   Vision Centers Using 3 Agencies
description: Durfee & Solow Advertising here in the big city and Lincoln, Pitt & Associates of Woodbury, L.I., will be working together to service American Vision Centers, a chain of 57 outlets in 19 states.

title: Money Supply Up $4 Billion
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply surged by $4 billion in the week ended July 1, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The rise was double what economists had anticipated and dashed hopes that the Fed would move soon to help push interest rates lower.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES CORP OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chris-Craft Buys More Warner Stock
description: Chris-Craft Industries, which already owned 29.5 percent of Warner Communications Inc., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it had bought 116,900 more shares and arranged $175 million in bank credit lines to finance new purchases. The credit lines would make it possible to buy another 6 percent of Warner. The most recent purchase amounted to less than half of 1 percent.

title: RYAN PASSES 4,000 STRIKEOUTS AS MET STREAK ENDS
description: Nolan Ryan, who notched his first strikeout as a 19-year-old Met rookie in 1966, became the first pitcher in major league history to fan 4,000 batters when he got Danny Heep of the Mets to swing and miss on a curve ball in the sixth inning tonight.

title: Free Music and More
description: Above the rush-hour roar on Fifth Avenue, the music of a flute floated lightly into the dusk.

title: SHIFT FROM COLOMBIA IS SEEN
description: Clandestine cocaine laboratories in the New York area and Virginia, believed to be new bases for drug trafficking in the United States, were raided by law-enforcement authorities in the last two days, officials said yesterday.

title: US TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Red Sox Get Lollar
description: The Boston Red Sox, seeking pitching help to keep them in the American League East race, acquired Tim Lollar, a left-hander, from the Chicago White Sox yesterday. Lou Gorman, general manager of the Red Sox, said the team would also receive a player to be named in the deal, which sent Reid Nichols, an outfielder, to the White Sox.

title: SENATE APPROVES ECONOMIC MOVES AGAINST S. AFRICA The Senate confirmed 23 nominees for diplomatic posts, including Ambassador to Israel. Page A4.
description: The Senate approved legislation tonight imposing economic sanctions on the Government of South Africa. The vote was 80 to 12.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * R. Stephen Morris has been appointed vice president, ad director, of The Detroit Free Press.

title: SENATE VOTES CONFIRMATION OF 23 FOR DIPLOMATIC POSTS
description: After months of delay, the Senate tonight confirmed 23 nominees for diplomatic posts, including Thomas R. Pickering as Ambassador to Israel and Elliott Abrams as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter American Affairs.

title: RAFAEL CAMPOS
description: Rafael Campos, an actor whose 30-year film career began with ''Blackboard Jungle'' and included regular roles on television's ''Rhoda'' and ''Centennial,'' died of cancer Tuesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills. He was 49 years old.

title: Topics;   Deep and Wide More Than a Bridge
description: Before anyone could ride to Brooklyn, it was possible to walk. A footbridge was draped across the East River in 1877, from the towers that would eventually support the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Advertising;   Seven-Up Switches Agencies
description: WHILE all the world, it seems, is talking about Coca-Cola, the Seven-Up Company, a major competitor, has switched advertising agencies. The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, which works for the soft-drink company in a number of international markets, has now been assigned the domestic account, which bills in the neighborhood of $40 million.

title: Algeria Said to Seek Aid For Drought Refugees
description: More than 40,000 refugees from drought-affected areas of Mali and Niger have moved across the border into southern Algeria, and the Algerian Government has appealed for international aid, a United Nations official said today.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED TECHNOLOGIES OFF 67.6%; G.E. UP
description: The United Technologies Corporation, reeling from losses at its Mostek semiconductor division, said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter dropped 67.6 percent, and hinted that it might move to jettison the memory-chip maker.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1.

title: BROADWAY
description: NO one is saying a word, officially, about New York, but a new musical opening July 30 at the Goodspeed's Norma Terris Theater in Chester, Conn., may be headed in this direction. It is ''Georgia Avenue,'' based on Fannie Hurst's novel ''Imitation of Life.'' Set in Atlantic City during the Depression, it's about two women, their two daughters and a handsome fast-talking drifter.

title: ON THE RIGHT: LONG WAIT FOR FOREIGN POLICY HERO
description: They were key figures among the intellectual vanguard that endorsed Ronald Reagan.

title: Cyril and Methodius Were Bulgarian, and Wrote in Glagolitic
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. RECALLS CHEESE LINKED TO OUTBREAK OF FATAL DISEASE
description: The Food and Drug Administration today ordered a nationwide recall of Mexican-style cheese and other dairy products distributed by Cacique Fine Foods, saying they might contain the Listeria monocytogenes bacteria. Listeriosis, an illness caused by the bacteria, has been blamed for 61 deaths and stillbirths and 187 illnesses in California and six other states.

title: Picture Perfect
description: Assumption of political responsibility affects different people differently. Before Howard H. Baker Jr. became the Senate Republican leader in 1981 he had maintained a reasonably trim figure, but the heady experience of power, somehow or other, went to his waistline.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.A.S.B. Rule Could Thwart Greenmail
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board proposed a rule yesterday that could sharply curtail the payment of ''greenmail'' by companies, and thus make it harder for them to ward off takeover specialists.

title: SPOKESMAN FOR THE NATION'S LAWYERS: WILLIAM WENDALL FALSGRAF
description: The man who will be president of the American Bar Association for the next year was groomed for the job for two decades, acquaintances say, but he almost didn't make it.

title: MEDICARE MAY PAY PART OF REAGAN'S SURGERY
description: Medicare or President Reagan's private insurance will pay for the removal of a benign polyp from his lower intestine Friday, the White House said today.

title: Yeutter Starts Chip Inquiry
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the new United States trade representative, announced today that he was investigating a plea from the United States semiconductor industry that could lead to trade reprisals against Japan - the first such investigation under a new trade law.

title: No Money, No Work
description: Ten youngsters from Christopher Columbus High School in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx were chosen ''to be the eyes and ears of the community,'' patrolling the streets in cooperation with the Police Department.

title: ONE SMALL STEP IN BASEBALL TALKS
description: Negotiators in baseball's stalled labor talks agreed on one point yesterday: They would negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement without having the players acknowledge that the owners have severe financial problems.

title: Whose House?
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENTIST QUITS ANTIMISSILE PANEL, SAYING TASK IS IMPOSSIBLE
description: A computer scientist has resigned from an advisory panel on antimissile defense, asserting that it will never be possible to program a vast complex of battle management computers reliably or to assume they will work when confronted with a salvo of nuclear missiles.

title: Advertising;   Needham Gets Lottery
description: For the Los Angeles office of Needham Harper Worldwide, the wheel of fortune has delivered the newly formed California Lottery.

title: Plan Opposed By Goldsmith
description: In a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sir James Goldsmith said he intended to use his ''best efforts'' to defeat a restructuring plan proposed by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a San Francisco-based forest products company.

title: SPY SUSPECT LOSES BID FOR TRANSFER
description: A Federal district judge said today that there was ''strong evidence'' of the guilt of Yeoman 2d Class Michael Walker, one of four men charged in the Navy spy case, and denied his request for transfer from jail to a halfway house.

title: Golden Pacific Deposit Rule
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ruled yesterday that it would repay $16 million in deposits accepted from individuals outside the New York area by the Golden Pacific National Bank, which is based in New York's Chinatown and which was closed by Federal authorities last month.

title: Strategies of an Autoarchivist
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Stock Bid
description: CBS Inc. said the Securities and Exchange Commission had accepted its proposal to include interest-bearing notes as part of an offer to buy back shares. CBS said last week that it would spend nearly $1 billion to repurchase up to 21 percent of its stock in a bid to thwart a takeover attempt by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast entrepreneur. In a related development, the Federal Communications Commission said it would hold hearings Aug. 1 and 2 on Mr. Turner's offer.

title: Officials Say Supplies Of Vaccine Are Normal
description: Supplies of the widely used vaccine for diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, or whooping cough, have returned to normal after last winter's shortage, a Federal agency said today.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SINKING OF VESSEL IS LAID TO A BOMB
description: The police said today that the sinking of a 160-foot vessel belonging to the environmentalist group Greenpeace had been caused by a bomb.

title: Just Kidding, Pete
description: He has always been a big fan of Pete Rose, and so maybe everyone should have known that Mickey Mantle was just joking. The problem was that, though it was obviously just a throwaway line, it was not very obviously a joke. And so an eyebrow or two was raised by a passage in ''The Mick,'' an autobiography written by Mantle and Herb Gluck, which was recently published by Doubleday and Company.

title: Who's Watching the Kids?
description: Chances are good it's not their mothers who are watching the kids these days. Nearly 60 percent of women with children aged 3 to 5 are out working now. By 1990, more than half the mothers of all children under 6 will be.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BALUDUCCI KIN PLAN OWN STORE
description: Eight members of the Balducci family, which operates one of New York's top specialty food shops, are leaving the Greenwich Village businesss to open another store. Grace Balducci Doria, the daughter of Louis Balducci, the store's founder, said yesterday that she and her husband, Joseph Doria, and their six children will take over Fay & Allen's Food Halls on the Upper East Side.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Increasing Modesty
description: ''M.T.A. Gets You There.''

title: 'LIVE AID' CONCERT IS AIMING FOR THE SKY
description: In technical terms, it can be measured in superlatives: the largest potential television audience, the biggest intercontinental satellite hookup, the grandest stage, the most impressive list of rock-and-roll performers.

title: BIG STRIKES FOUND ON DECLINE IN U.S.
description: Faced with tougher business attitudes, high unemployment and new technology, workers have become increasingly wary of resorting to the strike, union officials and labor experts say.

title: THERE'S SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE ON THE SHORES OF THE CITY
description: NEW YORK is a city whose natives sail on the water, travel above and under it, romp, swim and fish in it, and just look dreamily at it. New York is no more Venice by the Sea than it is Baghdad on the Subway, but little in New York, from its people to its arts to its commerce to the city itself, would exist were it not for the confluence of ocean, bay, rivers and sound that also turn the water's edge into a great weekend playground.

title: LEVI STRAUSS MAY GO PRIVATE
description: The descendants of Levi Strauss, who 135 years ago started a tiny company by making canvas pants for miners, may move soon to recapture ownership of what has become the world's largest apparel maker.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BILL PROVISIONS AFFECT OFFTRACK BETTORS
description: The omnibus racing bill approved by the Legislature last week is best known for authorizing pick-six betting, extending simulcasting and providing some tax relief to harness tracks. But buried in the yards of fine print are numerous other provisions. Two of them would improve the plight of the estimated 110,000 New Yorkers who make bets with the Offtrack Betting Corporation each day.

title: Topics;   Deep and Wide Echoes at Sea
description: Scarab I, the robot submarine that recovered the flight recorders from the crashed Air-India 747, can lift 100 pounds and is deft enough to pick up a lobster. It retrieved the flight devices from a depth of 6,700 feet, the deepest such recovery on record.

title: Comecon Uncertainty
description: The European Economic Community is not going to rush resuming talks with Comecon, the Eastern European trade organization, Common Market sources said today. A spokesman said the market would propose an ''open'' answer to Comecon's June 14 request to establish formal relations.

title: YANKEES, ON 8 RUNS IN 4TH, TOP RANGERS
description: The Texas Rangers, who haven't won much of anything this season, might have won a battle last night, but they lost the game. The Yankees won, 11-7, because Don Mattingly stroked a three-run double and Don Baylor pinch-hit a grand slam in the fourth inning.

title: Arkansas Electric Sells $147.7 Million of Bonds
description: The National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corporation and the Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corporation yesterday announced the sale of $147.7 million of bonds, divided into three concurrent offerings, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: THEATER: 'GREETINGS,' AYCKBOURN COMEDY
description: ALAN AYCKBOURN is commonly labeled the English Neil Simon, and while that simple analogy does not tell the whole story, there's some truth to it. Mr. Ayckbourn is an incredibly prolific author of hit comedies about the middle class, and he has increasingly attempted to blend laughter and pathos in his work. Even so, there are real cultural differences separating the two writers - a fact that is most dramatically demonstrated by what happens when their plays cross the Atlantic. Mr. Simon has never been as popular in the West End as he is on Broadway, and such Ayckbourn London successes as ''The Norman Conquests'' and ''Bedroom Farce'' have failed to find equal favor in New York.

title: TV's Duty to Cover Terror
description: I hear echoes. And the rear-view mirror of my mind sees old images.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've heard the arguments about merit pay for at least 50 years and the issue does not go away.

title: Gold Christening Font Is Sold for $1.32 Million
description: A christening font made by the London silversmith Paul Storr for the Duke of Portland in the late 1790's was sold yesterday at Christie's in London for $1.32 million, an auction record for a gold object.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Helpful Hardware column in The Home Section yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for the David Kay Garden and Gift Catalogue. The number is 800-621-5199.

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OUT OF THE BLACKOUT. By Robert Barnard. 182 pages. Scribner's. $12.95. STORMS & SON. By Anthony Caputi. 210 pages. Atheneum. $14.95.

title: HUDSON VALLEY ALPENHORNS
description: There will be the sound of mammoth alpenhorns in the Hudson Valley this weekend, as well as a circus, a mock battle, a stone-house tour and star-watching.

title: Pepsi Welcomes Move
description: Dubbing the Coca-Cola Company's reformulated cola ''the Edsel of the 80's,'' Roger Enrico, president of Pepsi-Cola USA, said yesterday that his archrival's decision last April to change its flagship product represented a colossal marketing blunder.

title: Advertising;   Aurora Back in Fold At S.L.M.A. Agency
description: A decade or so ago, Scott Lancaster Mills Atha, a Los Angeles agency, began working for Tyco Industries, maker of racing car toy sets for kids and things like that. It resigned the business in order to take on the larger Aurora, which operated in the same area.

title: C.I.A. CLERK AND GHANAIAN CHARGED IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: A relative of the leader of Ghana and a woman who worked as a clerk for the Central Intelligence Agency in Ghana have been arrested and charged with espionage, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: REV. DR. POWEL DAWLEY
description: The Rev. Dr. Powel Mills Dawley, a former subdean and professor of ecclesiastical history at the General Theological Seminary, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Brunswick, Me., He was 78 years old.

title: Dining Out Guide: For 2, Under $50 (International)
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: ISRAELI TELLS HOW HE TRACKED MENGELE IN '62
description: Israeli agents, aided by former Nazis, tracked Josef Mengele to Paraguay and then to a Brazilian farm in 1962 but never moved in to capture him, according to a retired chief of Mossad, the Israeli secret service.

title: BRITISH SOLDIERS HURT IN BLAST
description: Six British soldiers were wounded in an explosion during a military exercise at Schwarmstedt, 25 miles southwest of Verden, last night, a British army spokesman said today.

title: Worldwide Ban Eased for British
description: Soccer's international ruling body today partially lifted a worldwide ban against British soccer clubs, allowing them to play games against non-European teams either in England or overseas.

title: HERMAN'S WORLD SPORTING OF GOODS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Church and State Again
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese and the Secretary of Education, William Bennett, have blasted the Supreme Court for four recent decisions upholding the rigid separation of church and state. Maybe they didn't read Mr. Justice Lewis Powell's concurring opinion in one of those cases.

title: PRESSURE ON CHAIRMAN OF CHICAGO BANK SEEN
description: Directors of the First National Bank of Chicago are under pressure from Federal regulators to make major management changes at the bank because of its persistent loan losses, according to bankers in Chicago and Government sources.

title: Next Time, Nicaragua, Do What India Does
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET NEGOTIATORS SEE A NEW IMPASSE ON DOMESTIC SPENDING CUTS
description: House and Senate budget negotiators said today that they might face a new impasse over domestic spending cuts. At the same time, many Senate Republicans were critical of President Reagan for undercutting them by dropping the Senate's proposed freeze on Social Security benefits without getting any new budget savings in return.

title: We Need a National Law to Regulate Charities
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss from discontinued operations of $96,852,000.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Head of Comerica Pursues Takeover
description: Comerica Inc. yesterday withdrew its offer of last January to acquire the Michigan National Corporation, but Donald R. Mandich, Comerica's 59-year-old chairman and chief executive, is determined to pursue the takeover.

title: Jerry Grote's 'Comeback'
description: Jerry Grote was not trying to make a point, although he is convinced that, at age 42, he could still catch in the major leagues. But as the manager of the Birmingham Barons, the Class AA farm club in the Detroit Tiger organization, he discovered between games of a doubleheader at Columbus, Ga., one night not long ago that he had run out of healthy bodies. Papo Rosado had a bad shoulder, and Steve Eagar had aggravated a thumb injury in catching the first game. The only other player with any catching experience had an ailing leg, and, since the field had been unplayable because of rain only the day before, Grote saw the risk of a further injury.

title: SHIFTS FOR 3 RANGERS
description: The lives of three members of last year's New York Rangers changed dramatically yesterday: Two became head coaches and one retired.

title: PRICE CUT PUTS MEXICO IN LEADING ROLE ON OIL
description: By cutting its oil prices late Wednesday, Mexico took on the reluctant role of an industry price leader, compelled to act as it lost markets to OPEC discounters, petroleum specialists said here today.

title: Bloodstock Merchants Fills President's Post
description: Ryan R. Mahan yesterday was promoted to president of Bloodstock Merchants Inc., a subsidiary of the Equine Corporation. He also took on the post of vice president of Equine.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 12, 1985
description: The Economy Major retailers had disappointing sales in June because of unseasonably cool weather and sluggish demand. At Sears, the biggest chain, volume fell 1.5 percent from June 1984. [Page D1.] A Treasury official said attacks on the Reagan tax plan that assert it would be unfavorable to middle-income taxpayers were ''not sustainable.'' But modest changes may be needed, he added. [D13.] House and Senate budget negotiators may face a new impasse over domestic spending cuts, they said. Many Senate Republicans were critical of President Reagan for dropping the Senate's proposed freeze of a cost-of-living increase for Social Security. [A13.] Companies Directors of First National Bank of Chicago are under pressure from Federal regulators to make major management changes at the bank because of its persistent loan losses, according to bankers in Chicago and Government sources. [D1.] Levi Strauss said a leveraged buyout offer may be made by descendants of its founder at $50 a share, or a total of $1 billion. The news sent Levi Strauss's common stock up $8.50, to $45.50. [D1.] United Technologies earnings tumbled because of losses at its Mostek semiconductor division. Net income was down 67.6 percent in the second quarter, to $54.8 million. General Electric rose 1.9 percent, to $590 million, while Westinghouse climbed 12.3 percent, to $143.9 million. [D3.] Chemical New York's profits jumped 39.7 percent, to $107.3 million, while Marine Midland gained 8 percent, to $28.5 million, and Irving rose 19.4 percent, to $31.4 million.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1985.

title: Market Place;   Falling-Dollar Stock Plays
description: THE ''foreign currency play'' - buying stocks of companies that benefit from the declining value of the dollar - is enjoying a renewed burst of popularity and adding sparkle to the equity market.

title: COUNCIL BACKS CURB ON WASTE FROM HOSPITALS
description: The City Council yesterday passed legislation to prohibit the disposal of potentially infectious medical waste in city landfills.

title: CITY AIDE CALLS POLICE TEST TOO EASY
description: The official who oversees the preparation of Civil Service examinations in the city testified yesterday that the last written test for police officers was so easy that a functional illiterate might have been able to pass.

title: 9 KILLED IN KUWAIT BOMBINGS
description: Bombs exploded in two popular cafes here today, killing 9 people and wounding 56, the police said. There was no immediate assertion of responsibility.

title: Garson Kanin Elected Head of Authors League
description: The writer Garson Kanin has been elected president of the Authors League of America, which represents 7,000 playwrights and 6,000 authors regarding copyright, taxation and free expression. Mr. Kanin has been a member for 40 years of the Dramatists Guild Council and the Authors Guild, which cooperate as the Authors League.

title: MYSTIQUE RETURNS TO THE STADIUM
description: This was during the World Series of 1983: An elevator stuffed with reporters stopped at a private level of the Philadelphia ball park, and a distinguished gray-haired chap took one step forward. The reporters began shuffling backward to make room for him, but the young elevator operator was having none of it.

title: HOUSE APPROVES FOREIGN AID BILL OPPOSING MARXISTS AROUND WORLD
description: The House passed a $12.6 billion foreign aid bill today that appears to reflect a growing determination on Capitol Hill to confront Communist and other leftist governments around the world.

title: A U.S. JUDGE BARS SEIZING LEGAL FEES
description: A Federal judge declared yesterday that it was unconstitutional for the Government to seize legal fees that criminal defendants paid to their lawyers in racketeering and narcotics cases.

title: Mancuso in 'Stingray,' Crime Drama on NBC
description: You can do a lot worse than ''Stingray.'' The NBC movie doesn't make an awful lot of sense, but it does have style. It is a mystery, sort of, and sometimes it looks like outtakes from ''Miami Vice,'' with leftovers from MTV. At the same time, there's no gore and the mysterious hero is meant to be a sweet guy. The movie - written by Stephen J. Cannell and directed by Richard Colla - will be shown Sunday night at 9 on Channel 4.

title: MIDATLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures are fully diluted.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Grasshopper Fight Expands
description: An additional $10 million has been made available to help fight grasshoppers in the West, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today. The additional money raised to $35 million the amount the Department of Agriculture has specified to pay for the aerial spraying of grasshoppers this year.

title: Blues Plentiful for Contest
description: 1Margate, N.J.: Large bluefish are plentiful offshore, and that bodes well for the American Bluefish Classic July 20, billed as the world's largest event for the species. First prize can be as much as $25,000. Boats, not anglers, may register for the event. The fee is $250, and registration extends through July 17. For information, call (609) 652-7775. Large numbers of medium-sized Atlantic bonito have appeared, and catches of yellowfin tuna are being made 50 miles offshore. Barnegat, N.J.: Day and night bluefishing is excellent, and Atlantic bonito have shown. Seaside Park, N.J.: Weakfish are being caught from jetties at Barnegat Inlet. Bluefish are in the inlet and along the beaches. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Half-day ocean trips for fluke continue, as do 7:30 P.M.-12:30 A.M. bluefish excursions. #2Sea Bright N.J.:Fluke are along the shore from Monmouth Beach to Sandy Hook, as are large and small bluefish and weakfish up to 14 pounds. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Fluke fishing is good, and bluefishing is excellent. Freeport, L.I.: Yellowfin tuna and mako sharks are being caught in 180 feet.

title: YOUNG MAY LEAVE U.S.F.L.
description: Against a backdrop of enthusiasm for the United States Football League's championship game Sunday, the league is faced with the possibility of losing one of its star players.

title: COCA-COLA'S BIG MISJUDGEMENT
description: When the Coca-Cola Company introduced a reformulated version of the world's best-selling soft drink on April 23, it was well aware that it might alienate some faithful Coke drinkers.

title: PRESIDENT OF CHINA ASSAILS U.S. MOVE ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: China's President, leaving for a tour of the United States and Canada, responded angrily today to a vote in the United States House of Representatives that condemned Peking's one-child-per-family policy.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 12, 1985
description: International

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $1,300,000 from the sale of property and $1,900,000 from the sale of securities wich were offset by a one-time charge of $3,100,000 related to First Atlanta's proposed merger with Wachovia Corp.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. Ron Darling will be going for his ninth victory of the season, and his opponent will be Joe Niekro, who recently won the 200th game of his career. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Drag Racing 16th annual National Hot Rod Association Budweiser Summernationals, at Old Bridge Madison Township Raceway Park, Englishtown, N.J. Gates open at 8 A.M. The field of 650 continues preliminary racing at 2 P.M. today and tomorrow to reduce the field to 300 for Sunday's finals. Golf United States Women's Open, at Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J., second round, 8 A.M. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.). Anderson Memorial, at Winged Foot Mamaroneck, N.Y., 8 A.M., third day and beginning of team-match play better-ball round of 16. PGA Anheuser-Busch Classic, at Williamsburg, Va,. second round. New Jersey State Golfers Association Open Championships, at Echo Lake, Westfield, N.J., final day and final 36 holes of stroke play. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. Favorites in the three $50,000 elimination heats for next Friday's $1 million Meadowlands Pace are Marauder, at 8-5, in the fifth, the entry of Nihilator and Chairmanoftheboard at 1-5 in the sixth and the entry of Pershing Square and Handsome Sum in the seventh race.

title: Becker Withdraws
description: Boris Becker, the 17-year-old West German who last Sunday became the youngest player to win the men's singles championship at Wimbledon, withdrew yesterday from the D.C. National Bank tennis tournament in Washington because of an ankle injury.

title: David Goddard Dies; Leading Plant Expert
description: David R. Goddard, provost emeritus of the University of Pennsylvania and former paid executive of the National Academy of Sciences, died Tuesday at Joseph Priestly House, a retirement community in the Philadelphia. He was 77 years old.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LOPEZ SHARES OPEN LEAD AT 70
description: After shooting a two-under-par 70 today to tie for the lead in the first round of the 40th United States Women's Open championship, Nancy Lopez said, ''I feel this is really my chance to win an Open.''

title: 2 Yankees to Start On All-Star Squad
description: Two Yankee outfielders, Rickey Henderson and Dave Winfield, were voted to starting positions on the American League team for the All-Star Game next Tuesday in Minneapolis, but Ron Guidry, the Yankees' top pitcher, gave up his chance to be on the team because he is scheduled to pitch for New York against Texas Sunday.

title: 14 College Dates At Meadowlands
description: A college basketball schedule of 14 dates, including the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern Regional semifinals and final March 21-23, was announced today for Byrne Meaowlands Arena by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Article 115405 -- No Title
description: Eastern Air Lines yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $25.5 million, or 37 cents a share, the largest second-quarter net income since 1979. In the second quarter last year, the Miami-based carrier reported a loss of $24.1 million.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a non-recurring gain of $2,845,000, or 55 cents a share, from the sale of a leasehold interest in an office building and an interest in London Interstate Bank Ltd. c-Including a gain of $3,652,000, or 70 cents a share, from the sale of a leasehold interest in an office building, interest in London Interstate Bank Ltd. and a change in reporting trust fees.

title: Neighborly Tip BRIEFING
description: When the President holds a bill-signing ceremony, the White House routinely invites sponsors of the legislation and lawmakers whose states and districts are directly involved so that they can all be in the historic picture.

title: U.S. Reports Defection Of High Czech Envoy
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the second-ranking Czechoslovak diplomat here had defected to the United States.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including from discontinued operations of $3.3 million.

title: THE SCREEN: 'EXPLORERS'
description: OF all the Spielberg-inspired fantasy films afoot at the moment, Joe Dante's ''Explorers'' is by far the most eccentric. It's charmingly odd at some moments, just plain goofy at others.

title: Man, 25, Is Held Without Bail In Pushing Death on Subway
description: A 25-year-old Queens man was ordered held without bail yesterday on a charge that he had killed a stranger by pushing him in front of an oncoming train at an IND station Tuesday in the Hammels, Queens.

title: Reaction to Price Cut
description: Energy prices and shares of oil companies fell yesterday in reaction to the Mexican oil price cut.

title: DETAILED DEFENSE OF TAX PLAN
description: Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said today that accusations that the Reagan Administration's tax proposals would be unfavorable to middle-income Americans were ''not sustainable'' and came from ''partisans'' trying to derail the plan for other reasons.

title: ALBERT V. DOHERTY
description: Albert V. Doherty, a former senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Tuesday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Hill was hired by the Knicks as an assistant to Coach Hubie Brown. The 36-year-old Hill, an assistant at the University of Kansas for the last eight years, replaces Rick Pitino, who became coach at Providence College. . . . The Los Angeles Lakers have notified Bob McAdoo, a 13-year player, that the team would not exercise the option on his contract for the 1985-86 season. McAdoo, a 33-year-old forward, is the third-leading scorer among active players with 18,493 points. . . . The Washington Redskins have given Mark Murphy, former all-pro safety, permission to deal with another National Football League team. . . . After a seven-month absence from organized basketball, Scooter McCray and Gerry Eaves, the former stars of the University of Louisville, are headed for Houston, where the Rockets are conducting a one-week tryout.

title: JERSEY OFFICIAL SAYS '77 ARMY REPORT URGED CLEANUP AT SITE OF MISSILE FIRE
description: New Jersey's chief environmental official said today that a 1977 Army report - declassified Wednesday - described the site of a 1960 nuclear-missile fire near here as a health hazard that should be cleaned up.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Federal Reserve
description: All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYear WeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of July 1 $596,000 R $592,000 $544,500 Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(7/10)#229,200 #226,900 #214,800 Reserve Position, Eight New York BanksDaily averages for two weeks ended July 3 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover)R (4) (50) #164 Borrowings at Federal Reserve#75 #160 #0 Net Federal Funds PurchasesR 6,500 #9,162 #6,913 Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit)R (6,579)(9,372)(6,749) Federal Reserve CreditDaily averages, week ended July 10 Gov'ts. and Agencies Held Outright#177,006 #176,124 #171,448 Gov'ts. and Agencies Under Repurchase#1,165 #682 #1,741 Float#786 R 716 #1,739 Other Assets#12,229 R 12,146 #9,059 Other Factors Affecting ReservesDaily averages, week ended July 10 Gold Stock#11,090 #11,090 #11,100 Special Drawing Rights#4,618 #4,618 #4,618 Currency in Circulation#188,710 #186,590 #177,399 Treasury Deposits#4,544 #4,409 #4,486 Other Items Gov't.

title: NICARAGUAN DIPLOMAT TO ACT FOR FASTING AIDE
description: Nicaragua's second-ranking diplomat, Deputy Foreign Minister Victor Hugo Tinoco, will become Acting Foreign Minister upon his return from a Central American tour Friday, officials said today.

title: DELIVERY OF CHILD-SUPPORT MONEY SHOWS SLIGHT NATIONAL RISE
description: There has been a slight increase in the number of mothers who receive the child support payments due to them, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: July 12, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Symposium on Palestinian issue -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ART: THE CONCEPTUALISTS
description: INDEPENDENT CURATORS INC., an exhibition service specializing in contemporary art, has been circulating shows for 10 years. A few surveyed the work of individuals, but most have been miscellanies illustrating themes or movements. The display now at the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 33 Washington Place, has the distinction of being the one private collection in the organization's repertory.

title: Baseball;   Blue Jays Beat Best in West
description: Willie Upshaw snapped a 3-3 tie with a fifth-inning single, and George Bell contributed a pair of run-scoring singles to lead the Toronto Blue Jays to a 5-3 victory over the California Angels tonight.
