title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Woman's Slayer Sentenced
description: A 24-year-old Syosset man was sentenced to 37 1/2 years to life in prison today for the rape and strangulation of a college student last year, a spokesman for the Nassau County District Attorney said. The man, Warren Bass, was convicted in May in the death of the student, Heidi Goldberg, 19, who was the daughter of the cartoonist Stanley Goldberg, creator of the Archie comic strip. The sentence, handed down by Judge Marvin Goodman of Nassau County Court was the maximum allowable, the spokesman, Ed Grilli, said.

title: HARTFORD TO GET HOUSING NEAR DOWNTOWN SECTION
description: Although long considered the insurance industry's capital city, until a few years ago there was no significant commercial development in Hartford, and its skyline went unchanged. Today the city is a boom town by anybody's standards. In the last three years it has seen more than three million square feet of office space rise in its central business district.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, and the London-based Midland Bank have agreed in principle to restructure their interests in Samuel Montagu Group, a London merchant banking group. The companies said Midland would buy Aetna's 40 percent interest in Samuel Montagu & Co.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAN AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including after-tax gains of $1,100,000, or 23 cents a share, from the sale of securities.

title: Top Yield of 8.9% On Austin Issues
description: The City of Austin, Tex., is offering $80 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Scotch Price Rise Set
description: The Distillers Company said today that it would raise prices 5 percent on Oct. 1 for its Scotch whisky sold in the United States.

title: Strange Passes on Open
description: Curtis Strange, the leading money winner on the men's pro golf tour this year, has told the organizers of next week's British Open that he was withdrawing to ''spend some much-needed time with my family.'' Strange said he was looking forward to next year's Open. His next visit to Britain is almost certain to be in September, as a member of the United States Ryder Cup team.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KOCH'S PETITIONS TOP RIVALS' BY 5 TO 1
description: In the first test of strength before the Democratic primary, candidates filed qualifying petitions yesterday, with Mayor Koch submitting at least five times as many signatures as either of his two principal challengers.

title: FIRST INDIANA FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lambert Retires
description: Jack Lambert, who set the standard for middle linebackers in the National Football League, announced his retirement yesterday after 11 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers. Lambert, 33 years old, was part of the Steel Curtain defense when the Steelers won four Super Bowls.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SPAIN IN BROOKLYN Spanish zarzuela favorites - arias and duets from 19th- and 20th-century Spanish operas - are on the program for tonight's Brooklyn Philharmonic concert in Prospect Park, part of the Celebrate Brooklyn festival. The orchestra will be conducted by Bruce Ferden, with the soprano Ilya Martinez and the baritone Rafael LeBrom as guest artists. Another festival concert on Sunday night is a celebration of Jewish traditions in music, with a five-member group called Kapelye performing Klezmer music and a trio called Alhambra offering Sephardic music performed on such authentic instruments as the vielle and the dumbek. Jeffrey Swerdlow, a classical guitarist, is also on Sunday's program. Both concerts are free and begin at 8 P.M. at the Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street in Brooklyn. Information: (718) 768-0699. MUSIC IN THE GARDEN This summer, Friday nights bring Summergarden, the Museum of Modern Art's series of free evening performances in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, and tonight's offering is a selection of contemporary dance pieces by Jennifer Muller and the Works. Miss Muller, a dancer and choreographer, is a veteran of the Jose Limon Company and the Louis Falco Dance Company, and has appeared with the New York City Ballet. This weekend's program will be performed to live music by the saxophonist Marty Ehrlich, the violinist David Sanella and the percussionists Pheeroan ak Laff and Aaron Mendelsohn. Entrance to Summergarden begins at 6 P.M. through the Garden Gate at 14 West 54th Street, with performances starting at 8 P.M. Information: 708-9850. Saturday FOLK MUSIC AT WAVE HILL An all-day festival of folk music from America and Britain is scheduled for Saturday, rain or shine, at the Wave Hill Environmental Center, a former estate overlooking the Hudson River in Riverdale.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ANYONE who contends that America is no longer a nation of steak eaters should journey across the East River some evening to Peter Luger, which is to carnivores what Brooks Brothers is to the plaid Bermuda shorts set. For nearly a century this landmark in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge, has been a crowded, no-frills, elbows-on-the-table steakhouse. The river has isolated it from the ebb and flow of food fads in Manhattan that have compelled similar establishments to water down their menus with such ''fancy food'' as escargots, veal piccata and shrimp scampi.

title: CITES AIR RAIDS FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: The United States said today that it was rushing 100 portable antiaircraft missiles and new air-to-air missiles to Pakistan to help it defend against increasing air incursions from Afghanistan flown by either Soviet or Afghan pilots.

title: SHANKER BACKS TEACHER MERIT PAY BASED ON STANDARD NATIONAL TEST
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, proposed today that merit pay be awarded to experienced teachers based on nationwide tests and standards.

title: SHULTZ ASSURES SOUTHEAST ASIANS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated today that the United States is resuming a more active role in Southeast Asia, with increased military, political and economic support for its friends in the region.

title: Insurance Is a Risky Business for Interstate Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK WITH A CARIBBEAN BEAT
description: WHEN the temperature hits 80 degrees and the air seems thicker than gelato, New York City can feel like a transplanted Caribbean island. Musically speaking, the city has everything but palm trees and coral reefs; the largest Caribbean-bred population north of Miami lives here, and many islanders have brought their music with them.

title: Rep. Hughes Criticizes Hutton
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee that is investigating E. F. Hutton & Company's check overdraft scheme accused the New York brokerage firm today of refusing to comply with the subcommittee's subpoena of internal Hutton documents, and of possible obstruction of justice.

title: Economic Scene;   The Departure Of Stockman
description: DAVID A. STOCKMAN'S departure from the Office of Management and Budget comes at a time when the White House, the Republican-led Senate and the Democratic-led House of Representatives are still struggling to put together a budget for the fiscal year 1986.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Edward F. Carlough, 81, Dies; Headed Sheet Metal Workers
description: Edward F. Carlough, president emeritus of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association who negotiated the first health, welfare and pension plans in the construction industry, died Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 81 years old.

title: COUNTDOWN PROCEEDING SMOOTHLY FOR SPACE SHUTLE BLASTOFF TODAY
description: Space officials said the countdown was proceeding smoothly today toward a liftoff Friday for the space shuttle Challenger.

title: IU Restructuring
description: The IU International Corporation announced a restructuring plan that would include cutting its quarterly dividend in half, to 15 cents.

title: CAIRO IS WARY BUT CALM OVER SUDAN-LIBYA PACT
description: The Sudan's growing ties with Libya, highlighted this week by an announcement of a mutual defense protocol, have stirred deep concern in Egypt.

title: Atoning for the Varsity
description: Colleges may earn millions off the labors of student-athletes yet leave them with little more than press clippings. A recent survey found that fewer than a third of college basketball players earn degrees, even though most somehow managed to remain eligible to play for four years.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SITE OF COLISEUM TO BE PURCHASED FOR $455 MILLION
description: A complex of offices, luxury condominiums and a hotel would replace the 30-year-old New York Coliseum under a proposal selected yesterday by city and state officials to redevelop the site, one of the most valuable tracts in midtown Manhattan. The proposed sale price is $455.1 million.

title: JAZZ: A LOOK BACK BY GEORGE RUSSELL
description: THE composer George Russell is treating his stint through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, as a full-scale career retrospective, culminating with his latest large work, ''The African Game.'' In Wednesday's first set, Mr. Russell and his 15-piece Living Time Orchestra made their way through his first 23 years in the jazz world, from the 1945 ''Cubano-Be Cubano-Bop'' to the 1968 ''Electronic Sonata for Souls Loved by Nature.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: ART auctions can mystify even the most knowledgeable collectors and dealers, who say that even after the gavel falls, they are frequently uncertain whether a work has been sold.

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT is said that the food at a good Japanese restaurant evokes sensations of the sea. At Hayato, a sushi bar and restaurant at 571 Third Avenue (between 37th and 38th Streets), the illusion is taken one step further. Patrons at the sushi bar and tables in the front dining room are treated to an audio-visual display projected on two walls that shows rolling ocean surf to the soothing background music of Kitaro, the composer of futuristic-sounding ''new age'' works.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gain of $786,000 for the quarter and the six months from the repurchase of debentures.

title: SECOND 'BLACK BOX' IS RECOVERED FROM ATLANTIC IN AIR-INDIA CRASH
description: A robot submarine retrieved the remaining ''black box'' from the sunken wreckage of an Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland today, giving investigators an improved chance of discovering why the plane crashed with the loss of 329 lives last month.

title: BADEN CRITICIZES INQUIRY BY JERSEY INTO PARK FIRE
description: A pathologist testified today that the state investigation of the fatal fire last year at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park near here was flawed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alimak Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., which makes freight elevators, tower cranes and underground hoisting equipment, has promoted Ulf Lundell to president.

title: Common Shares Offered by Insurer
description: The American International Group Inc., a New York-based insurance holding company, yesterday announced the public offering of 3.45 million common shares through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Panel Said to Favor Penalty for Roy Cohn
description: A disciplinary panel of the state court system, after finding wrongdoing by the lawyer Roy M. Cohn, involving fees or accounts of two of his law firm's clients, has reportedly decided to recommend that he be disciplined.

title: PROJECT STILL FACES HURDLES
description: It will take at least a year to complete the studies and approvals required before the project on the New York Coliseum site can get under way, city officials said yesterday.

title: False Start on Conservators
description: Is New York's judiciary serious about improving the way it chooses and regulates conservators of estates? Or is it acquiescing in the cronyism and inefficiency highlighted by the John Zaccaro case last year? The secretiveness with which the state's highest court has handled a reform proposal implies insufficient concern.

title: Life Is Tough
description: Robert Lepelletier, a racing fan from Alexandria, Va., explains why he was cool and calm when he collected $11,702 on a $2 bet Wednesday night, the largest exacta payoff in the history of Charles Town (W. Va.) Race Track: ''I don't have anything to spend the money on. I live next to the river. What do I need a swimming pool for?''

title: Protesters in Nevada Close Bombing Range
description: Opponents of expanded military operations in the area invaded three bombing ranges at Fallon Naval Air Station today, forcing officials to shut down the bomb-strewn areas in a search for camouflaged protesters.

title: WHEN LAWYERS COME TO TOWN
description: For some of the 9,200 lawyers who came to town this week, the American Bar Association convention was a chance to tour the Supreme Court's law library, to hear denunciations of terrorism from President Reagan and martial music from the Marine Band, to shuttle between lavish law firms' cocktail parties and expense-account restaurants.

title: AUCTION AIDE SAYS CHIEF KNEW OF LIE
description: A top official of Christie's said in a deposition three years ago that he told the company's chairman ''shortly after'' a 1981 auction that he had falsely reported the number of paintings sold.

title: CITY TRYING SUPPLICATION. NOT SEEDING, IN '85 DROUGHT
description: In the spring of 1950, gripped in a terrible drought, the city hired a rainmaker. And there was rain. City officials do not plan on hiring anyone this summer to conjure wetness from the clouds by sprinkling them with dry ice and smoking them with silver iodide - partly because the Mayor is busy exploring his own more metaphysical talent for precipitation.

title: KICKER FOR INVADERS PLANS TO SETTLE TITLE
description: The Baltimore Stars and the Oakland Invaders, who will play Sunday for the United States Football League championship at Giants Stadium, are evenly matched. An example was their last meeting 17 weeks ago when they played through four periods and one overtime session to a 17-17 tie.

title: Admiral Rickover Has Stroke; Condition Reported as Stable
description: Retired Adm. Hyman Rickover has suffered a stroke and is in stable condition at Bethesda Naval Hospital, Navy officials said today.

title: MARINE RISES 8%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent of Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth largest, yesterday reported a 39.7 percent jump in second-quarter net income, to $107.3 million.

title: LE CARRE, ON CHANNEL 13, DISCUSSES HIMSELF AND HIS WRITING
description: Dipping into its acquisitions warehouse, Public Television has put together a series called ''The Creative Edge.'' These interview-profiles will focus primarily on writers, including Patricia Highsmith, Ed McBain, Kurt Vonnegut and Joseph Heller. Tomorrow's premiere, directed for London Weekend Television by Don Featherstone, is devoted to John le Carre, author of the widely praised spy thrillers.

title: Explorers on Film
description: ''Four Who Dared,'' a series of film biographies of four explorers, continues tomorrow with the life of Francisco Pizarro at the Queens Museum, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: A Sense of Place
description: Liberalization of life in the military has reached a point where members of the armed forces are protesting to their Washington representatives about deprivations once pretty generally taken for granted. Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin confesses he was taken aback when an Air Force constituent complained he could not take a woman into his barracks after midnight. ''I joined to serve my country,'' he wrote, ''but I guess I'm in a convent.''

title: Cyril and Methodius Were Bulgarian, and Wrote in Glagolitic
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.S. REPORTS MOBILE INCINERATOR DESTROYED DIOXIN WASTES IN TEST
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had successfully destroyed dioxin-contaminated wastes with a new mobile incinerator.

title: Amex, Nasdaq Set Early Start
description: The American Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that they would begin trading at 9:30 A.M., a half-hour early, as of Sept. 30.

title: THE BIG BANK
description: President Reagan's diatribe against what he called ''a confederation of terrorist states'' engaged in ''acts of war against the government and people of the United States'' may have relieved his pent emotions. But it stained his statesmanly management of the Beirut hostage crisis.

title: An Arms Accord -Still Possible
description: Despite pre-emptive blame on both sides - including new rhetoric from Moscow about the prospect of failure - both superpowers have recently taken steps that suggest that agreement is possible in the Geneva arms control talks. Whether or not it is achieved will depend on the political will in both capitals.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LAW GIVES CITIES NEW TAX POWERS
description: A law signed today, aimed at healing Boston's longstanding fiscal problems, gives all Massachusetts municipalities authority to levy sales taxes and spend revenue from such taxes.

title: Delicacy of Competition
description: Likelihood of a serious rapprochement between the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China declined sharply the other evening when Chinese caviar was officially introduced in Washington. The new product, which is expected to be competitive in price with the traditional Russian delicacy in this country, made its debut at a champagne reception given by the Swedish Ambassador, Count Wilhelm Wachtmeister, and his wife, Ulla, at their home.

title: INDONESIAN EASES U.S.-VIETNAM TALKS
description: ''I'm a pretty persuasive fellow, don't you think?'' Mochtar Kusumaatmadja asks, interrupting one of his characteristic monologues with one of his characteristic asides.

title: JAPANESE: WHEN IN NEW YORK...
description: These are black-tie times for Japanese business executives in New York. Wives, in from Westchester, are taking hotel rooms to change clothes between parties. Caterers are carving dazzling ice sculptures and composing artful landscapes of vegetables, complete with mountains and rivers of colored salt. Everywhere there are gala receptions and cocktail parties, art openings and benefit dinners.

title: ART: USING CERAMICS TO ADORN ARCHITECTURE
description: WHEN the spare steel-and-glass box of Modernist architecture became the rage in the late 1920's, one of the fine old materials tossed out was ceramics, extensively employed to adorn the sumptuous Beaux-Arts buildings that were a hallmark of the Gilded Age. But now that we're in the Post-Modern era, the ornamental uses of this very sculptural material, with its rich possibilities for color and texture, seem once again apropos. Operating on that premise is the show ''Architectural Ceramics: Eight Concepts,'' at the American Craft Museum II, 77 West 45th Street (through Aug. 24). Though it's a little on the sketchy side for the purpose, it's intended to re-educate us in the decorative advantages of ceramic art for architecture.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $876 million, to $211.65 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: GREGORY MOSHER, director of the Lincoln Center Theater Company, studied the crowd having cocktails on the portico of Avery Fisher Hall and said, ''Tout le monde is here, that is all of our little world of Lincoln Center.'' And indeed, the moguls of culture at Lincoln Center had turned out in force for the opening night celebration of the 19th Mostly Mozart Festival, among them Avery Fisher; Beverly Sills, who brought her mother, Shirley Silverman; Charles Raymond, managing director of the New York City Ballet; Albert K. Webster, managing director of the New York Philharmonic; Martin E. Segal, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center, and Nathan Leventhal, its president.

title: Bridge: Freak Hands Offer a Chance For Creativity in the Bidding
description: Extreme freak hands involve considerable guesswork, but also offer opportunities for creative imagination in the bidding. Consider for example the diagramed deal, which was played recently at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street.

title: F.A.A. WORKING ON SYSTEM TO DETECT EXPLOSIVES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed an immediate 400 percent increase in funds for work on an explosives-detecting system it believes could be put into production in early 1988, Government officials said yesterday.

title: A State Regent Backed As Successor to Lance
description: Gov. Joe Frank Harris and Democrats in the state Legislature today chose a former legislator, John Henry Anderson, to succeed Bert Lance as party chairman.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S.F.L. Favored in Poll
description: A poll commissioned by the United States Football League to offset what Commissioner Harry Usher perceives as negative news media reports shows that the league does has a future.

title: PLAN TO BOYCOTT BEIRUT AIRPORT IS STALLED IN EUROPE
description: Although President Reagan's call for an international boycott of the Beirut airport has aroused little enthusiasm in Western Europe, some officials are holding out the possibility that a common pro-boycott position could emerge later this month. But the likelihood seems remote at this time.

title: A TRIO OF HANDEL OPERAS AT PURCHASE
description: The Pepsico Summerfare, less than an hour from Manhattan at the State University of New York in Purchase, has emerged from nowhere to become the New York area's liveliest, most imaginative summer festival. While the Westchester festival lasts four weeks, this, its second weekend, marks its musical climax.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NITZE DETAILS U.S. CHARGES SOVIET HAS OWN 'STAR WARS'
description: The Reagan Administration, answering Soviet criticism of American plans for a space-based missile defense, today amplified charges that Moscow had been conducting similar research for years.

title: Nicholas P. Thimmesch, 57; National Political Columnist
description: Nicholas Palen Thimmesch, a nationally syndicated columnist and resident journalist at the American Enterprise Institute, died this morning of cancer of the liver at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 57 years old.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THOMAS A. BURTON
description: Thomas A. Burton, a former partner in the law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, died of cancer yesterday at the Cabrini Medical Center Hospice.

title: WATER RATIONING IS LIFTED IN 93 JERSEY COMMUNITIES
description: Governor Kean today lifted the mandatory water-rationing program he imposed two months ago on about 2.3 million people in 93 communities in northeastern New Jersey. But he continued his ban mor ptioned region on May 16, as well as the 33 percent surcharge the state imposed on the water bills of businesses and apartment buildings.

title: Dow Advances 4.81 To Record 1,337.70
description: Stock prices scored moderate gains yesterday, but the rise was enough the send several indexes to record closings, and volume swelled to its best level in several weeks.

title: SOCIAL SECRET WEAPON
description: It is one of those very important but behind-the-scenes jobs that help set the tone and style of each new Administration: the post of White House social secretary.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LITTLE ITALY'S NEW PLACES FOR DINING AND SUNNING
description: On a warm, breezy day, a cafe in Little Italy can provide a delightful site for espresso sipping, pastry nibbling and people watching. In recent months, several new-style cafes have joined such favorite Old World spots as Ferrara and Caffe Roma to provide a wider choice of places to enjoy these lazy summer activities. In some cases, strobe lights and mirrors have replaced the old honeycomb tile floors and tin ceiling. Still, there is a wide assortment of alfresco arrangements - either on the front sidewalk or in the back garden in this ''cafe society.''

title: Shift by Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has scrapped plans to sell other companies excess capacity on its long-distance communications network, a company spokesman confirmed. Kodak's voice and data network is leased mainly from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and links about 225 company locations worldwide.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Febuary 1985.

title: Massey Contract
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said its Perkins Engines division had been awarded orders valued at $120 million for diesel engines to power tanks and armored personnel carriers for the British Army.

title: Sharon Extension
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said its exchange offers for two debentures had been undersubscribed and were being extended to July 24. Sharon said that through Wednesday, the original expiration date, it had received about 33 percent of its outstanding 13.5 percent debentures and about 31 percent of its 14.25 percent debentures. Separately, Sharon said it had sold nearly 1.1 million shares of Burnup & Sims Inc. to its parent, the NVF Company, for $8.2 million.

title: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS, GRADED, GET SOME HARD KNOCKS
description: Nearly a year ago, Japan's Prime Minister appointed a commission to reassess a national school system that he had described repeatedly as outmoded, uncreative, rigid and inhibiting.

title: SILENT APPLAUSE FOR ATHLETES
description: When Arne Olav Lovik arose at 5:30 this morning to go for a practice run along the coast, he could not see the sunrise or hear the seagulls. Flanked by two bicycle riders for guidance, the 33-year-old Norwegian athlete maneuvered through what he termed an ''easy'' 15 kilometers.

title: JUDGE'S CORRUPTION IS NEAR END IN CHICAGO
description: Richard F. LeFevour, a member of the Cook County Circuit Court since 1968, has been described by his defenders as an astute judge of horses who made thousands of dollars at the racetrack. His accusers say he was a judge on the take who made thousands of dollars by fixing cases for a fee.

title: NATIONAL COMMERCE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OFFICIALS THINK SPYING LED TO DEATH OF C.I.A. INFORMANT IN GHANA
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they believed at least one Central Intelligence Agency informant in Ghana was murdered after his identity was disclosed by an agency employee charged with espionage.

title: What the President's Tax Plan Would Do to Garbage Disposal
description: To the Editor:

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Acting Port Authority Chief
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey named its general counsel yesterday to serve as acting executive director until a permanent director is chosen. The counsel, 58-year-old Patrick J. Falvey, will assume his new position Aug. 17, when Peter C. Goldmark Jr. will step down as director. Mr. Falvey joined the authority as a law assistant in 1951.

title: Where We Are Losing The High-Tech Battles
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola Net Drops 73.4%
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it earned $26 million in its second quarter, a 73.4 percent decline from the period a year earlier, as the computer and semiconductor industries continued to languish.

title: HOYT STARS, ANDUJAR STEWS
description: LaMarr Hoyt, saying he was pitching to gain respect and not an All-Star start, outdueled Joaquin Andujar tonight to capture his 10th consecutive victory. He combined with Rich Gossage on a three-hitter as the San Diego Padres stopped the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
How to Repair Remedial Education
description: By deciding that public agencies may not pay for remedial education in parochial schools, the Supreme Court upheld an important principle but left educators with quite a problem: how to get badly needed remedial help to poor children attending church-run schools - 25,000 children in New York City alone are eligible. The U.S. Secretary of Education, William Bennett, suggests vouchers: direct payments to the children. Mayor Koch proposes trailers: instruction by public school teachers on neutral turf. Both ideas are worth considering.

title: Service With a Grimace
description: The United States now has a service economy.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-ago six months included an extraordinary gain of $11,760,000 or $5.07 a share from a single transaction.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JEREMIAH M. EVARTS
description: Jeremiah M. Evarts, a lawyer who served as an assistant corporation counsel during the administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dismal Forecast
description: Things would have been different, presumably, had the Generals got this far.

title: Truck Drivers Who Haul Autos Reject Contract
description: Truck drivers who haul new automobiles to dealers have rejected a new national contract, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today.

title: Shakespeare Infiltrated
description: The play was not the thing for everyone at the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORPORATION OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $193,000 for the quarter and $401,000 for the six months.

title:
PATENTS;

An Optimistic Report On Patent Waiting
description: Patent lawyers were given an optimistic report this week on the reduction of the time it takes for an inventor to get a patent. Donald J. Quigg, Acting Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, reported to the American Bar Association's patent section that the agency expects to reach by the end of 1987 its goal of reducing the pendency time to 18 months.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Making Sense of New York's Courts
description: Despite its rich legal tradition, New York has clung to a clumsy judicial structure designed mostly by accidents. The state's Supreme Court is not the highest but one of several trial courts with confusing names and overlapping functions. The highest court, misnamed the Court of Appeals, has not been trusted to manage its own docket. Most deplorably, the election of most judges subjects them to the humiliations and vagaries of partisan politics.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SALVADOR REBEL CHIEF: A MILITARIST WITHOUT DOUBTS
description: As a student revolutionary, he helped ignite the war in the streets that shook El Salvador in 1979. Today, as the senior commander of leftist guerrilla forces, he directs a military campaign that has forced the United States to make a major military commitment to this small country.

title: AMERICAN WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RICKOVER STABLE IN NAVAL HOSPITAL
description: Hyman G. Rickover, the retired admiral known as the father of the nuclear submarine fleet, was reported in stable condition today after suffering a serious stroke.

title: FORMER MINE WORKERS' PRESIDENT
description: Arnold R. Miller, who rose from obscurity as a disabled and jobless miner in Ohley, W. Va., to the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America, died early today at the Charleston Area Medical Center in Charleston, W. Va. He was 62 years old and had been in failing health for a decade.

title: SCRIPPS HOWARD BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Die in Mont Blanc Plunge
description: Two Frenchmen plunged 1,300 feet to their deaths on Mont Blanc today, raising the death toll from similar accidents on the range in the last week to 10.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Why Don't They All Play the Anthem?
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKNORTH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONTANA MAN, 54, GUILTY OF HOMOCIDE
description: The man charged with abducting an athlete in the mountains of Montana and slaying her would-be rescuer was found guilty by a jury here this afternoon.

title: Plea Bargaining
description: Shelby Greer was one of seven men charged in late May with selling cocaine by a Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh that heard testimony from at least 11 major league baseball players. Now the 29-year-old Philadelphian is considering making a plea bargain agreement with the United States Attorney's office, according to court records.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
American Air Settles Suit
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it and American Airlines had reached a proposed settlement of a 1983 civil suit that charged that the airline, and its then-president, Robert L. Crandall, had sought to monopolize passenger service.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOREIGN AID BILL MAY BE VETOED OVER STRICTURES
description: Senior Administration officials said today that there was a strong chance of a Presidential veto if Congressional conferees did not drastically change the foreign aid authorization bill that was passed by the House on Thursday.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary loss of $1,300,000 from penalties on prepayment of federal home loan bank advances. c-Including extraordinary gain of $545,000 from early extinguishment of debt less the prepayment penalties incurred in the second quarter.

title: Damaged Jet Engine Rains Debris on Florida
description: A Boeing 727 jetliner with engine trouble landed safely at Miami International Airport after raining about 100 bits of debris on a neighborhood, hitting cars and homes but causing no injuries, officials say.

title: CALIFORNIA AMPLIFIER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $791,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective in June 1985.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 301
description: b-Net loss. c-After loss from discontinued operations of $170,989 for the quarter and the year.

title: 23 POLICEMEN INJURED IN CLASHES ACROSS ULSTER
description: At least 23 policemen were hurt and 11 people were arrested today in Northern Ireland in clashes linked to Orange Day parades, the police said.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share results for 1985 reflect lower preferred dividend requirements.

title: STATE TO REQUEST PRIVATE HOSPITAL BE CLOSED DOWN
description: The State Department of Health said yesterday that it would seek to close Boulevard Hospital in Queens for its continued failure to correct more than 60 violations of the state hospital code involving patient care and other deficiencies.

title: City Workers' Art
description: They earned their livelihood working for the city, but turned to the arts for a hobby.

title: DANGERS OF SNUFF DEBATED
description: MILLIONS of young Americans, teen-age boys in particular, are using snuff, and a growing number of health officials say that the trend could lead to a significant rise in oral cancer in the future.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPRESSION LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Viewers' Choice
description: So you weren't much impressed by the news that the long night's journey into day undertaken by the Mets and the Atlanta Braves a week ago drew a 3.9 Nielsen rating in the New York television market at 3:45 A.M., the last checkpoint before the game ended at 5 minutes till 4. And, since the New York market comprises not only the five boroughs but 24 surrounding counties as well, you didn't fall out of your chair when you learned that a 3.9 meant more than 250,000 homes.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills 4 Marines in Okinawa
description: An American helicopter on a training flight crashed in Okinawa today, killing the four marines on board, a Marine Corps spokesman said.

title: READICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Behind the Navajo Relocation Is a Land Grab
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Should March on Washington
description: The year is 2025. We who were 20 in 1985 are turning 65. Thanks to improved health care, we will live longer than our parents. But we will not live as well as our parents and grandparents did as senior citizens. As a result of the snowballing effects of the deficit, we must put off retirement for many years: We can't afford it.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEW BATTLE AT FAMILY PLANNING OFFICE
description: Senator Jesse Helms has called it more damaging to American society than terrorism. The head of the American Life Lobby, the country's most vocal antiabortion group, says it has surely made teen-agers more promiscuous.

title: ASTRAL BELLEVUE PATHE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
MARC TWAIN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LOPEZ LEADS WOMEN'S OPEN BY A SHOT
description: Even though Nancy Lopez has 32 victories in the last eight years, more than any other professional golfer in that span, she has not yet achieved the ultimate victory in women's golf - a United States Women's Open championship.

title: TAX CHARGE IS CONSIDERED IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: A Federal grand jury in San Francisco is trying to find out what happened to hundreds of thousands of dollars said to have been paid by the Soviet Union to a Navy spy ring, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 13, 1985
description: International

title: GLOBAL CONCERT GIVES PHILADELPHIA A CHANCE TO INTRODUCE ITSELF TO THE WORLD
description: The city today prepared to welcome the world to Philadelphia while simultaneously promoting Philadelphia to the world.

title: Bond Prices Weaken by Close
description: Bond prices ended mixed yesterday, after rising in the morning on buying spurred by a Government report of a steep drop in June retail sales.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter does not consolidate the revenue of Pittway Corp, but included its share of Pittway's net earnings on the equity method.

title: CCB FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CLEANING UP
description: Horseplayers who suspect that California racing may have an edge on New York's these days have collected plenty of circumstantial evidence in recent weeks. Forzando II blew away the East's best older horses in the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park, then went back home and couldn't be found in the Hollywood Gold Cup. Sharannpour, sent east to avoid California's turf tigers, walked off with the first two major grass stakes of the summer at Belmont.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. SANCTIONS A POISON DEVICE TO KILL COYOTES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today approved the use of poisoned collars on sheep and goats to kill coyotes that attack the animals.

title: DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax loss carryforward credits of $2,119,000 for the quarter and $3,478,000 for the six months. c-After tax loss carryforward credit of $225,000 for the quarter and the six months. Results for the latest quarter include operations of Mohawk Rubber Co. and Master Shield Inc. which were acquired by the company in September 1984.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OPERA: GIANNA ROLANDI IN 'LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR'
description: Thursday night's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the New York City Opera was a poor advertisement for the company's current Bel Canto Festival. The definitions of bel canto are many, but in the end it is a celebration of the human voice in all its sensuous beauties. One looked long and longingly for such qualities on Thursday at the State Theater.

title: Overheard in Transit
description: Frank Field got on my bus the other day, and I was so surprised I sat down on the arm between two seats. There is a big bruise on my right thigh, but it was worth it. Dom DeLuise was giving recipes at 57th and 7th, and I stopped, nearly missing the M28. As I was waiting for the M30, Richard Kiley dodged me, Jack Palance ignored me, Greta Waitz raced past.

title: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
PRODUCER PRICES FLAT LAST MONTH
description: Prices at the producer level were unchanged in June, the Government said today, leading analysts to dismiss inflation as a major concern for the rest of this year.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $39,400 for the latest first quarter and $179,700 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SECURITY BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIFTH THIRD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST NORTHERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOPES FOR MORE TAXIS IN THE CITY STALL AGAIN IN POLITICAL GRIDLOCK
description: Mayor Koch opened 1985 with a proposal to double the number of yellow medallion taxis in the city. Four months later, facing a wave of opposition from cabdrivers, he pulled back and called for a 10 percent increase. Now even that plan, those most involved with it say, seems headed for oblivion.

title: RECIPES OF 40'S: LITTLE SPICE
description: If it is true that one person's junk is another's treasure, so it is that one person's discards are another's resources.

title: FED UNIT VOTED TO KEEP EASED POLICY
description: The Federal Reserve System's senior policy panel voted at its May 21 meeting to maintain an easier monetary policy that had evolved in the preceding weeks to combat a weakening of the economy, but not to push for lower interest rates, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Man Sentenced in Bombings
description: A 34-year-old man was sentenced in Federal District Court today to two years in prison in connection with 10 bombings of abortion-related facilities in Maryland, Delaware, Virginia and Washington, D.C., last year. The man, Kenneth Shields, had pleaded guilty to one count of receipt and possession of unregistered destructive devices. Mr. Shields, Thomas Spinks and Michael Bray were named in a Federal indictment in February in connection wth bombings.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Wednesday about reports of terrorist plots in the United States incorrectly characterized negotiations between Cable News Network and Federal authorities investigating the Beirut hijacking. The network has not turned over tapes of the incident; it said it planned to do so after receiving a subpoena it requested from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 'SOLDIERS STORY' SHARES PRIZE AT MOSCOW FILM FESTIVAL
description: An American film, Norman Jewison's ''Soldier's Story,'' shared top honors today with a Soviet and a Greek movie in the Moscow International Film Festival.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Garden State Games, at Rutgers Athletic Center, Piscataway, N.J., opening day. There will be bicycle races in and around New Brunswick and Piscataway beginning at 9:30 A.M., and the first day of men's decathlon and women's heptathlon begin at 10 A.M. There is lacrosse at noon and baseball at 1:30, as well as fencing, martial arts and archery before the opening ceremonies at 5 P.M. The games will continue at various sites through July 28. Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium. A two-inning Old-Timers game honoring Joe DiMaggio and featuring players from his era will begin about 1 P.M., followed by the regularly scheduled game about an hour later. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) Cubs vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Chicago. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Tigers vs. Minnesota Twins, at Detroit. (Radio -WCBS 7:20 P.M.) Boxing Tyrell Biggs vs. Eddie Richardson, six rounds, heavyweights, at Atlantis Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Golf United States Women's Open, at Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J., third round. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M. to 5 P.M.) PGA Anheuser Busch Classic, at Williamsburg, Va., third round. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.). Anderson Memorial, at Winged Foot Mamaroneck, N.Y. final day, 10 A.M. Harness Racing Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. The $145,000 final of the George Morton Levy Memorial Pace.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for 12 wks to June 2
Some Gulf Canada Assets Sought
description: Petro-Canada is negotiating to buy certain assets of Gulf Canada Ltd. from Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which has made a bid to acquire 60 percent of Gulf Canada from the Chevron Corporation, its United States parent, Government officials said.

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $476,243 for the quarter and $457,340 for the six months and tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $41,000 for the six months. c-Net income, including income from discontinued operations of $1,638,080 for the quarter and $1,649,290 for the six months and income from tax credits and gains on the early extinguishment of debt of $199,077 for the quarter and $2,138,197 for the six months.

title:
PATENTS;

Tightener For Wire In Surgery
description: DR. HARVEY A. KLEIN of Brooklyn, who describes himself as a mechanical engineer turned orthopedic surgeon, received a patent this week for what he calls a wire tightener and twister.

title: A SUDDEN HIATUS IN PINNEY'S CAREER
description: When summer's heat disappears and the leaves begin to change, Ray Pinney will be back home in Seattle, back in his seat overlooking the 35-yard line at Husky Stadium. He will take advantage of the autumn vacation the United States Football League has to offer. He will root again for the University of Washington, where his career began, while he waits for the next turn it will take.

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income including a gain of $409,000 in connection with an accounting change.

title: POLITICAL WARS IN THE 'PEACE TENT' IN KENYA
description: ''We will give our blood, we will give our youth for our freedom,'' shouted the chador-clad Iranian woman, part of her country's official delegation to the United Nations Decade for Women Conference, which is to open Monday. Another Iranian delegate lifted her chador, the black covering some Moslem women wear, to show that she had lost a foot in the Iran-Iraq war.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SUNWEST FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 3o
Kallur Is Released
description: Anders Kallur was given his unconditional release by the Islanders after six years with the team.

title: FIRST NATIONWIDE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Indiana Measles Cases Are Linked to Church
description: Nearly five dozen worshipers at a Baptist church have contracted measles since May in the worst outbreak of the disease in Indiana since a 1983 college epidemic, the State Board of Health said Thursday.

title: White Sox Moves
description: Tom Paciorek, a 13-year major league veteran who became expendable when the Chicago White Sox acquired utilityman Reid Nichols, was designated for reassignment by the American League team.

title: A DAY IN THE NURSING LIFE: STRESS OF HARRIED ROUTINE
description: The changing of the guard begins at 7 A.M. - the arrival of six young women at Einstein Hospital who day in, day out watch over the bathing, feeding, shaving, bandaging, medicating, monitoring, consoling of the 30 men and women in their charge.

title: RUSSIANS SAID TO RETURN 'BOAT PEOPLE' TO VIETNAM
description: Thirty-seven Vietnamese, believed to be ''boat people'' fleeing their homeland, have been returned to Vietnam by a Soviet freighter that plucked them from the South China Sea, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: THE DANCE: A TROUPE FROM PARIS
description: The American Dance Festival has led the way again in exploring the new and current dance explosion in France by presenting the United States debut of the experimental dance company that is part of the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax benefit of $470,000 for the quarter and the nine months. c-Net income.

title: HEADED INSURANCE COMPANY
description: William Jesse Kennedy Jr., former president and chairman of the board of North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company of Durham, N.C., one of the largest black-owned and black-managed companies in the country, died Monday at his home in Durham. He was 96 years old.

title: Back Bothers Guerrero
description: A back injury may keep the Dodger outfielder Pedro Guerrero out of the All-Star Game. Guerrero, whose bat has led the Dodgers' recent charge in the National League West, returned to Los Angeles from Chicago for a comprehensive examination by team doctors after aggravating an old back injury earlier this week.

title: Chargers Sign Johnson
description: Dan Fouts has a new target: Trumaine Johnson, who in two years in the United States Football League established himself as one of the league's elite receivers.

title: 2 MCDONALD'S IN DARIEN DO THEIR HIRING IN BRONX
description: After a three-month search for fast-food workers in this affluent New York suburb, the managers of two McDonald's restaurants here have resorted to busing in 150 workers daily from the Bronx.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE SURGE IN HOTEL BUILDING
description: The maids and bellhops at the Adolphus Hotel in Dallas, as at most downtown hotels in that city, have time on their hands because their opulently refurbished grand hotel is only 60 percent full. Throughout downtown and in the suburbs, however, yet 16 more hotels are being built to provide the area with another 2,000 rooms.

title: Seabrook Share Acquisition Talks
description: The Central Maine Power Company, which has been told by state regulators to sell its 6 percent share in the Seabrook nuclear project, is talking to a potential buyer.

title: NEW PROGRAMS SOUGHT FOR CARETAKERS OF THE AGED
description: Misguided government policies and budget cutbacks are undermining the efforts of family members to care for the infirm elderly, an expert on the problems of aging said yesterday. She called for new programs to ease the often crushing financial and emotional burdens borne by families who, research shows, are willing to make great sacrifices to support aged relatives.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE DUKE Duke Ellington died in 1974, but his memory and music live on, not least because of the fervor of the Duke Ellington Society, which was founded to promote the jazz of the Duke and of Billy Strayhorn, the composer and arranger with whom he closely worked. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., the society is sponsoring a special tribute to its hero at St. Peter's Church, at 54th Street and Lexington Avenue (935-2200), which has a jazz ministry and is an active supporter of the art.

title: State Taxes After Death
description: MANY people know that if they leave an estate exceeding a certain amount, the Federal tax collector will step in for a cut after their deaths. But some may not be aware that most states also impose death taxes that could be substantial.

title: Fees for Lawyers Increased
description: Lawyers assigned to represent poor defendents will get increases in the fees they can charge the state and counties from legislation signed into law today by Governor Cuomo. The law raises the hourly in-court rate to $40 from $25, and the out-of-court rate to $25 from $15. The maximum amount for each case will increase to $800 from $500.

title: Ford Expands Leasing Operation
description: The Ford Motor Company, in a move to expand into the area of equipment lease financing, said its Ford Motor Credit Company had formed a new equipment leasing company to engage in transactions ranging from $100,000 to $5 million.

title: F.C.C. ALLOWS TRUSTEE IN BROADCAST TAKEOVER
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved today for the first time the use of a trustee in takeovers of broadcast companies.

title: MATTINGLY LEADS YANKS INTO 2D
description: Don Mattingly, who is rapidly becoming a Picasso with a baseball bat, painted the entire Yankee Stadium outfield again last night, stroking the ball from one foul line to the other as he powered the Yankees to a 6-0 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: TURK IN ROME CASE DETAILS SMUGGLING
description: A Turk who Mehmet Ali Agca says was a key figure in a plot to shoot Pope John Paul II has given the Turkish police a detailed account of his involvement in arms and drug-smuggling operations that he says were based in Bulgaria, according to transcripts of a four-day interrogation here.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Catalyst Energy Development Corp. said it had entered into a construction contract with Bechtel National Inc., Oak Ridge, Tenn., a unit of Bechtel Group, and the city of New Martinsville, W. Va., for the construction of a 34-megawatt hydroelectric generating facility for a total cost of $95 million.

title: No Headline
description: The polyp found in President Reagan's large intestine is of a type that statistically has a substantial chance of proving to be malignant.

title: NBSC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Pledge Remembered
description: When Ricky Casuso was 12, his block in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was half-burned-down. One day, the future mayor and the future governor went to visit, to debate the future of the city's poorest neighborhoods.

title: Dow Rises by 0.90; Two Indexes Climb
description: Transportation stocks surged yesterday on Wall Street, but the overall market was only slightly higher as buyers were cautious after new signs of a weakening economy and strong money supply growth.

title: Retirements Raise Arco's Write-Off
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that about 6,000 employees, or nearly 16 percent of its work force, have taken part in the company's early-retirement plan designed to pare the company's payroll as part of its broad restructuring announced in April.

title: Baseball's Farm Fan Clubs
description: The Emil Verban Society of Washington has of late been dominating the baseball baloney circuit hereabouts. The Verban group mocks itself and its namesake, a former Chicago Cubs infielder whose journeyman record in seven years in the big leagues includes one home run and a lifetime batting average of .272, much of that against second-rate, wartime pitching. Many Verban society people call the Cubs the Cubbies, which the Chicago writer Mike Royko, among others, considers preciosity.

title: METS WORK OVERTIME AGAIN AND BEAT ASTROS, 3-2
description: Twenty-four hours after their nine-game winning streak ended, the Mets, leg weary and perhaps a bit worn, made a dramatic comeback here tonight.

title: IVB FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credit of $167,000.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
Still One-Party Mexico
description: Mexico's electoral system, as again displayed this week, is an undemocratic anomaly. Citizens may vote for parties of their choice but only one of them, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, is allowed to win. This puts Mexico in the uncomfortable company of Chile, Haiti, Paraguay, Cuba and Nicaragua - the other Latin Governments that permit no significant opposition. That is odd company for a society long associated with the cause of Latin American democracy.

title: THE JOYS OF SUMMER CAMP-FOR PARENTS
description: This is summer camp season in New York, a time when there is a mass exodus of children from the city and life becomes quite different for the parents left behind.

title: FIRE SAFETY WAS WEAK AT 6 FLAGS, EXPERT SAYS
description: A fire-protection engineer testified for the defense today that no sprinkler or smoke-alarm system would have saved lives in the fun-house fire that killed eight patrons last year at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park.

title: G.A.O. Is Critical of Midgetman
description: The General Accounting Office says the mobile land-based Midgetman missile under development is too small to carry some planned warheads to military targets in the Soviet Union.

title: A.M.C. Price Rise
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would increase the price of the average 1986 model Renault passenger car by $54, or seven-tenths of 1 percent. It said the prices of the average 1986 Jeep or Eagle would increase about $324, or 2.1 percent. A.M.C. said it already was shipping the new models, which will go on sale officially on Oct. 1.

title: Cordero Is Kicked
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the leading jockey at Belmont Park, was kicked in the stomach by Far 'n' Swift, his scheduled mount in the first race yesterday, while trying to climb aboard the filly in the paddock. Cordero was taken to Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park for X-rays but was released two hours later with abdominal bruises and is expected to ride today.

title: BECKER COMES HOME A HERO
description: Today in Boris Becker's hometown, it seemed that the 17-year-old may have been right when he said, after his victory at Wimbledon, that he had given Germany an idol.

title: Frenchman Sought by Police In Greenpeace Ship Bombing
description: The police said today that they were looking for a Frenchman who was seen near the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior before a bomb sank it.

title: Portuguese Parliament Dissolves and Vote Is Set
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes dissolved Parliament today and called elections for Oct. 6 amid speculation that Prime Minister Mario Soares, a Socialist, would soon declare himself a candidate for the presidency in a later election.

title: Orr Leaving Pentagon
description: The Secretary of the Air Force, Verne Orr, has told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that he wants to resign to return to California. Mr. Orr has been Air Force Secretary since the start of the first Reagan Administration. His plans after leaving the Pentaton are not known.

title: LOUISIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Article 118523 -- No Title
description: The liquidator of Laker Airways agreed yesterday to a $48 million out-of-court settlement of an antitrust suit against a dozen defendants, including some of the world's largest airlines. The three-year-old suit had also embroiled the Governments of the United States and Britain.

title: First Chicago Net Falls 80.9%
description: In line with its earlier projections, the First Chicago Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income plunged 80.9 percent, to $10.1 million, from $53 million in the comparable period of 1984. On a per-share basis, net income dropped to 4 cents, from 98 cents.

title: Spurs Sign Top Pick
description: Alfredrick Hughes of Loyola of Chicago has signed a contract with the San Antonio Spurs, becoming the first No. 1 draft choice in the National Basketball Association to come to terms with his team.

title: POP: O.M.D., FROM ENGLAND
description: Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark, the English pop group that has released six albums in the last six years, is a synthesizer-oriented band that successfully avoids many of the cliches of electronically based pop. At its most adventurous, the quartet manages to sound both hearty and arty, two qualities that don't ordinarily go together.

title: Why Don't They All Play the Anthem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Picks Library Dean
description: The executive director of the American Library Association has been named dean of the Columbia University School of Library Service, the university announced yesterday. The new dean, Robert Wedgeworth, a 47-year-old Texas native, will assume his duties Sept. 1.

title: JERSEY SEEKING HEALTH RECORDS FROM AIR FORCE
description: State environmental officials are asking the Air Force to provide the names and health records of all military personnel and civilian workers who were at the scene of a nuclear-missile fire in Plumstead Township in 1960.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN WESTWAY TRIAL
description: Testimony ended yesterday in the trial to determine whether a Federal judge should continue to block construction of the Westway highway and development project on the West Side.

title: Handcuffing A.T.&T. at Customer Expense
description: To the Editor:

title: Flowers in Art
description: They are every artist's dream models: beautiful, cooperative, uncomplaining. And they never blink.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEMPORARY SHIFT OF POWER POSSIBLE
description: The announcement that President Reagan would undergo general anesthesia and surgery Saturday raised questions tonight about a possible transfer of power to Vice President Bush.

title: RECENT RECORD OF GOOD HEALTH
description: In recent years, President Reagan's doctors have described him as healthy and fit. Although Mr. Reagan, at 74 years of age, is the oldest to have served as President, he seems to have aged much less in office than other Presidents who were much younger.

title: F.C.C. REJECTS 2 COMPLAINTS ON NEWS
description: The Federal Communications Commission rejected today complaints charging news distortion against two television networks. In both cases, the agency found that the complaints did not meet criteria for the violation of its rules.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN THE BEATING OF MAN IN CUFFS
description: A New York City police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he assaulted a handcuffed prisoner in a patrol car and in a cell at the 81st Precinct station house in Brooklyn.

title: Boxer in Hospital
description: Willie Machado, the welterweight boxer from Hartford, who was injured Thursday night in a bout at the Felt Forum, was listed in guarded condition yesterday in the intensive care unit at the Cornell Medical Center of New York Hospital.

title: India Gives to Africa Fund
description: India has donated $9.6 million to a fund that enables famine-stricken African countries to buy Indian wheat. Salman Haidar, a spokesman for the Ministry of External Affairs, said today that the fund would be administered by the Organization of African Unity. India has already contributed 100,000 tons of wheat for African relief.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 13, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The large polyp will be removed by an open abdominal incision.

title: George Duvivier Dies; Bassist for Top Bands
description: George Duvivier, a string bassist who played in the bands of Benny Goodman, Jimmie Lunceford and Coleman Hawkins and performed with the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Boston Pops, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: MUSIC: ASWAD PLAYS THE RITZ
description: Aswad, the group that played Wednesday at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street), is a typically British reggae band. More than most Jamaican bands, Aswad looks toward the economy of rock songwriting.

title: LANE TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $10,000. c-Net income.

title: G.O.P. RIFT WIDENS AS DOLE CRITICIZES REAGAN AND HOUSE
description: The crack in Republican unity widened today as the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, accused President Reagan and both parties in the House of ''surrendering to the deficit.''

title: Iraqi Planes Damage Turkish Tanker in Gulf
description: Iraqi warplanes crippled a Turkish supertanker today, setting its stern section on fire with a missile strike, Persian Gulf shipping sources said.

title: Guerrilla Raid Frees 104 at Salvador Jail
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked El Salvador's largest prison today with mortar and rifle fire and 104 prisoners escaped in the confusion, the prison commander said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table on the front page of Business Day yesterday with an article about Coca-Cola carried an incorrect label for the final column of figures. The figures represented the change, in percentage points, in the market share of the major soft drink brands from 1983 to 1984.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share net reflects 3-foir 2 stock split in March 1985.

title: In a Slower League
description: As to ballplaying in Washington, the competition is still hot on the Mall in the early evening hours when Capitol Hill teams pummel each other in slow-pitch, unisex softball. In one recent game, Tip's Irish Tide won by a score of 10-5 over the Boston Ted Sox.

title: BankAmerica To Revamp Unit
description: A reorganization of the world banking division of the BankAmerica Corporation is being planned, but a bank spokesman said no final decisions had been made on layoffs.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,654,761 for the quarter and $1,958,192 for the six months. c-Including capital gains of $5,798 for the quarter and $125,469 for the six months.

title: Letter: On Tax Reform;   The Facts of Life Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: ART EXPLOSION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Net losses are after a charge of $100,000 for inventory markdown reserve.

title:
PATENTS;

Vacuum Cane Picks Up Fallen Articles
description: A vacuum cane for picking up light articles from the floor was patented this week.

title: 2 Men Arraigned In Tax-Fraud Case
description: A Queens accountant and a jeweler who lives in Maywood, N.J., were arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court Thursday on charges of seeking to defraud the State of New York by requesting tax refunds totaling more than $240,000 for 80 fictitious individuals, according to District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau. A spokesman for Mr. Morgenthau, Mary de Bourbon, identified the men as Aris Estevez, 38 years old, an accountant who resides at 68-17 Alcott Street, Forest Hills, Queens, and Eduardo Cinca, a 44-year-old jeweler who lives at 173 East Central Avenue in Maywood.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Day-Care Commencement
description: With boys on the left and girls on the right, the 26 graduates in white caps and gowns belted out two versions of ''It's a Small World'' -one in English, one in Chinese.

title: TEACHER GROUP FORMS PROGRAM ON THINKING
description: The American Federation of Teachers announced today that it was forming a program to help teachers improve students' abilities to reason and form judgments.

title: DOLLAR, IN SHARP DROP, CLOSES BELOW 2.9 MARKS
description: The dollar tumbled dramatically yesterday, losing almost 2 percent of its value against the West German mark as foreign investors sold dollars in a nervous market.

title: BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Polishing Up A Golden Image
description: It was not until he found a young Olympic teammate smoking a cigarette before practice one day last year that it all came clear to Greg Louganis, the world's best diver and a smoker himself until 1984.

title: Poverticians Make Good Campaign Workers
description: You don't hear much about the war on poverty anymore. It's apparently been discredited. Certain of the field generals gave the war a bad name by using funds meant for the poor to make themselves powerful and rich.

title: A Productive Life Despite Hodgkin's Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: NAKASONE SEEN AS BIG WINNER IN TOKYO VOTE
description: Although his name was not to be found on the ballot, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone appears to have emerged as the big winner in Tokyo municipal elections that were won this week by his Liberal Democratic Party.

title: RETAIL SALES FELL 0.8% IN JUNE
description: Retail sales took their steepest plunge in 11 months in June, the Government reported today. And while the Reagan Administration talked of brighter days ahead, some economists said the eight-tenths of 1 percent decline in retail sales heightened worries about a possible recession.

title: AMERICANS TO HELP ON AIR-INDIA DATA
description: Representatives of the National Transportation Safety Board left today for India to help analyze information that may be obtained from the ''black boxes'' that were retrieved this week from the sunken wreckage of an Air-India jet that crashed off Ireland last month.

title: EX-COLUMBIA WORKER TAKES BLAME FOR ERRORS
description: A former laboratory technician at Columbia University has claimed sole responsibility for making the research errors in a disputed study of a blood pressure treatment that embarrassed the university and tarnished the reputations of two senior scientists.

title: COHN WILL FIGHT CALL FOR DISBARMENT
description: Roy M. Cohn said yesterday that he would ask a panel of judges to overturn a disciplinary committee's recommendation that he be disbarred and to order that the committee's proceedings be reopened.

title: Ward and Koch Defend Police Test
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, defending the department's test for prospective police officers against charges that it was too easy, said yesterday that he had not seen ''any dumb policemen since they hired me.''

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Public Art vs. Public Sentiment
description: The controversy over the ''Tilted Arc'' - Richard Serra's 112-foot metal sculpture - was not resolved on May 31 when the General Services Administration ruled that it will be moved from the plaza in front of the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in lower Manhattan. The debate continues to simmer over how public art should be chosen and when it can be removed from its chosen site.

title: MENOTTI, AT 74, SERENE DESPITE FESTIVAL CRITICS
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, the founder of ''The Festival of Two Worlds'' that sparked a renaissance of this medieval Umbrian hill town, can be fiery in talking about music critics. But at bottom, he is serene.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Traded Tim Lollar, pitcher, to Boston Red Sox for Reid Nichols, outfielder, and a player to be named later.

title: ASKS OVERSIGHT UNIT CHANGES
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today vetoed an aid measure for Connecticut municipalities and ordered the General Assembly into special session on July 22 to rewrite the legislation.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BROAD NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Army Cuts Bell Copter Payments
description: The Army announced today that it would withhold 50 percent of its monthly contract payments to Bell Helicopter because of what it called accounting deficiencies and that a criminal investigation was under way.

title: JAPAN ASSURES U.S. ON TRADE MATTERS
description: Japan told the United States today that by the end of the month the Government would have a plan of action to deal with trade problems between the two countries, a senior State Department official said.

title: OPERATION TODAY
description: President Reagan will undergo surgery Saturday to remove a large polyp that was discovered today in his large intestine, the White House said.

title: GIBSON, C R CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRITISH TV BATTLE FOR 'DALLAS'
description: The managing director of the independent Thames Television company resigned today after a real-life drama worthy of the television program ''Dallas,'' which he was accused of ''poaching'' from the BBC.

title: Whither the Beach Mouse
description: The Perdido Key beach mouse, which skitters around on the sands near the Alabama-Florida border on the Gulf of Mexico, is ''the nation's most critically endangered small mammal,'' according to the people here at the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The service says there are only 26 such creatures known to be still alive and calls them ''small'' and ''secretive.''

title: Bridge;   The Richard Freys Marking 50th Wedding Anniversary
description: Whether a bridge expert should choose as a spouse a player of equal ability, a player of slightly lesser ability or a nonplayer is a question that could be argued at great length.

title:
PATENTS;

Separating Uranium From Technetium
description: A chemical process for the separation of uranium from technetium in the recovery of spent nuclear fuel was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Patent No. 4,528,165 was granted to Horace A. Friedman of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee under an Energy Department contract.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of The Times;   Grant at the Front
description: THE PAPERS OF ULYSSES S. GRANT.

title: Padres Curb Drinking
description: Drunken, rowdy fans haven't been a problem this year at Jack Murphy Stadium in San Diego, but Padres officials recommended to the Stadium Authority Board of Governors that beer sales be halted after the seventh or eighth inning, a move described as a ''preventive measure'' by Elten Schiller, the club's senior vice president in charge of business operations. Beer sales at Anaheim Stadium were restricted last week after a brawl between Angels fans and the Boston Red Sox outfielder Rick Miller.

title: IN DROUGHT-RAVAGED SUDAN, SUDDEN DOWNPOURS SLOW AID
description: Heavy rains, an extraordinary phenomenon in the drought-ravaged western Sudan, are seriously hindering efforts to deliver food to hundreds of thousands of famine victims, according to relief workers who have recently returned from the region.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results restated to reflect the operations of CBT Corp.,aquired in June 1985 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: SHUTTLE MISSION ABORTED 3 SECONDS BEFORE BLASTOFF
description: With its main engines spewing orange flames, the space shuttle Challenger came to a cold stop today three seconds before liftoff as computers on board the ship detected a problem and stopped the launching.

title: Control Data Sets New Plant Closings
description: The Control Data Corporation, conceding that its troubles have spread to another of its divisions, said yesterday that it would close six of its minicomputer manufacturing operations for 11 days later this year because inventories are piling up.

title: Ex-Hostage Leaves Hospital
description: A former hostage from Trans World Airlines Flight 847, Simon Grossmayer, was released from Northwestern Memorial Hospital today after surgery to remove a potentially fatal skin cancer, his wife, Elaine, said. The tumor, a malignant melanoma, was discovered when Mr. Grossmayer, 57 years old, was examined in West Germany after he and 38 other Americans spent 17 days in captivity.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. In South Africa, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, saved an unidentified man from a crowd of angry blacks who said they suspected the man of collaborating with the Government authorities. 2. David A. Stockman, the White House budget director, announced he would resign Aug. 1. 3. The Hudson River. 4. The Coca-Cola Company announced that it would bring back Coke made from the original formula, breaking a pledge by the company's chairman when the new Coke was introduced, that the original formula would be placed in a vault, never to be used again. 5. The performance was an American premiere of Mozart's Symphony in A minor, numbered Kochel 16a, first performed in Europe in 1982. 6. The nations cited were Iran, Libya, Cuba, Nicaragua and North Korea. Syria was omitted as a gesture of gratitude to President Hafez al-Assad, for his pivotal role in the release of American hostages from Lebanon. 7. Students cannot take part in any extracurricular activity if they have a failing grade in any subject. 8. He is the first German, the first unseeded player and, at 17, the youngest person ever to win the trophy. 9. The verdict marked the first time a group of Israeli Jews had been convicted of being part of a terrorist organization. 10. True. 11. Could be. 12. If permission is granted, trading would open a half-hour earlier, at 9:30 A.M., an indication that the exchange is more concerned about capturing business from abroad than from the Middle West or western United States. 13.

title:
PATENTS;

Transmitting Voice And Data Together
