description: A digital data and voice communication system that permits space left vacant by voice to be filled with data has been invented for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEIRUT RADIO SAYS HIJACKERS ARE KNOWN
description: The state-run Beirut radio reported today that Lebanese authorities had identified the men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet last month and intended to prosecute them. The White House tentatively welcomed the report, which it called ''a step forward.''

title: A LOOK AT THE GRAYING OF AMERICA
description: AT a wedding reception recently, I was contentedly downing a caviar-coated blini, in preparation for carrying on a conversation with a most interesting woman who had informed me she ran a construction company, when a tall, handsome man sidled up.

title: Edwards Leads by A Stroke
description: Danny Edwards, who only two days ago changed his putting style, shot a three-under-par 68 today and overtook a faltering Lon Hinkle for the lead in the third round of the $500,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 14, 1985
description: International

title: TOP CHICAGO JUDGE GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: The judge who presides over Chicago's courts was found guilty today of taking thousands of dollars in bribes and other illegal payments throughout most of his judicial career.

title: ASHE IS INDUCTED INTO HALL OF FAME
description: Arthur Ashe today became the first black man inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, and then said he felt vindicated after his many years of struggling to get ahead in the predominantly white sport.

title: AFTER CENTURY, DUCK FARMS IN JEOPARDY
description: ABOUT a century ago, Eugene O. Wilcox came to Long Island from the Midwest. He settled in Speonk, among families including the Tuttles and the Hallocks, whose ancestors first touched the Island's shores in 1640.

title: THE TRUE COST OF SHEDDING HOUSEWORK
description: DURING office hours, Jane P. Metzroth, director of human resources at Salomon Brothers Inc. helps company executives find administrative assistants and secretaries. But in her off-hours, Miss Metzroth developed a subspecialty -hiring nannies and housekeepers - and eventually wrote a book about it. Now she uses her skills to help those same Salomon executives locate household help. Once a match is made, she lectures the new employers on their legal responsibilities, which she sums up succinctly as ''mountains of paper that take hours to complete.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

IRON PEOPLE
description: Wanted: Iron people.

title: WHY ZAYRE'S STORES BOUNCED BACK
description: IN 1980, when the Miami riots caused conflagrations at many businesses in the ghetto-like Liberty City area, the local Zayre discount store was one of the victims. But after the smoke settled, black leaders called Maurice Segall, president and chief executive of the Zayre Corporation, and urged him to reopen the store. ''We're already cleaning out the place and we will be back in business soon,'' he promised.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A WEEKEND IN THE COUNTRY Written and illustrated by Lee Lorenz. Unpaged. Englewood Cliffs, N. J.: Prentice-Hall. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8) WHEN I was growing up, I had a friend whose family had a farm in the country. They often went on weekends and in the summer they were there all the time. I spent many hours imagining what we would do together if I visited. Those pictures were easy to conjure up, but being a city child, I had an especially hard time envisioning how I would get to their farm. Yet on the hottest days of summer the trip seemed easy. Like Pig and Duck in Lee Lorenz's latest picture book, I thought I'd do just about anything to get out of the city. But it never occurred to me to call up and invite myself because, I guess, children haven't yet learned the fine art of mooching summer weekends that becomes second nature to many adults.

title: The Politics of the Death Penalty in America;   Meant to Be Selective
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHAEL EVERS MARRIES DAWN RAFFEL, AN EDITOR
description: Dawn Raffel, a daughter of Francine Goldfarb of Jackson, Mich., and Mark Raffel of Milwaukee, was married yesterday to Michael Evers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Evers of Garden City, L.I. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel and the Rev. Luke McCann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: THE GROWING PAINS OF A RURAL OASIS
description: A HOUSING-COST survey of 100 residential areas throughout the country has ranked the Monmouth County horse-farm township of Colts Neck as the second highest, just behind the Long Beach area of Los Angeles.

title: DELAWARE BAY GETS A PROTECTOR
description: A Republican administration in Delaware has come down on the side of ecology rather than that of industry in a battle over a proposal to permit the loading of coal ships off Big Stone Beach, at the mouth of Delaware Bay.

title: END OF AN ERA: DUBROW'S TO CLOSE
description: The owner of Dubrow's Cafeteria on Seventh Avenue and 38th Street has agreed to sell his lease to a developer, apparently clearing the for the construction of a new building on the 20,000-square-foot site.

title: TRACING THE LONG SHADOW CAST BY 'THE BIG CHILL'
description: Lawrence Kasdan may exert more quiet influence than any other American film maker working today. His ''Body Heat'' launched Kathleen Turner, who is emerging as the preeminent screen sophisticate of her era; his screenplays (some of them collaborative) for ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Return of the Jedi'' have helped set the tone for fantasy-adventure films for a long time to come. And if the western makes another comeback, Mr. Kasdan's ''Silverado'' will no doubt be widely credited with launching that trend.

title: U.S. TAX PLAN SEEN STIFLING L.I. GROWTH
description: THIS fall, the Director Door Company of Copiague will move to new quarters more than twice the size of the 10,000-square-foot facility it now occupies. The company's vice president, James Director, said the expansion will mean adding 30 new people to his work force.

title: PHILADELPHIA FOCUSES ON CORNER
description: THE preservationists and the champions of progress have been at it again in Philadelphia, but this time they haggled not over a whole building but over a corner of one.

title: FOOD WITH DESIGNER TOUCHES
description: RESTAURANTS in resort areas are often annuals, like zinnias in the garden that are replanted every year. For several seasons in succession at the restaurant in Westhampton that is called Hampton Square this year, there have been changes of management, chefs and name.

title: SCULPTURE, DRAWINGS AND PAINTINGS, TOO
description: THE sculptor Mel Edwards made news last month when his ''Holder of the Light,'' a 12-foot-tall work in stainless steel, was unveiled in Lafayette Gardens, on Grand Street in Jersey City.

title:
GARDENING;

IT IS NOT TOO LATE FOR SOME PLANTINGS
description: WHILE most of us have completed our seasonal planting and are ready to sit back and enjoy the fruits, vegetables and flowers of our labors, there always seems to be a spot here and there in the garden that needs a bit of color or something more to fill in.

title: SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S BUYING BINGE
description: ITS no-holds-barred advertising campaign for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher created a national furor in 1979. Its 90-second sci-fi spot for British Airways - showing the entire island of Manhattan coming in for a landing at Heathrow Airport -was one of the most talked-about commercials of 1983.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SALOME: Her Life and Work. By Angela Livingstone. (Moyer Bell Limited, Colonial Hill, R.F.D. 1, Mount Kisco, N.Y. 10549, $18.95.) According to this well-documented biography, Lou Andreas-Salome (1861-1937) was considered the equal of the male intellectuals of her day.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MONTGOLFIER BALLOON What better reason for becoming a Friend of the Sleepy Hollow Restorations by paying $20 ($40 for families) than to be present at the ascension of the Montgolfier balloon? Well, not the original, but an excellent replica. It is scheduled to waft into the mild blue yonder at dusk Saturday, the hour when the winds are deemed most favorable. The event will be held at Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson as a lure for new members and an evening of fun for old ones.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN:   ROCKVILLE CENTRE
description: MOVING to Rockville Centre, said Mary Jane Halley, ''is like joining a club with an unwritten tradition.''

title: DO COMMERCIALS DETER VIEWERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nora Joyce
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTIONS FROM POLICE OFFICER TEST THAT CITY OFFICIAL TERMED TOO EASY
description: On Dec. 15, a total of 37,501 men and women took a multiple-choice examination as the first step in joining New York City's Police Department and the Transit and Housing Authority police forces. A total of 26,331, some 70 percent, passed.

title: TEXTS OF REAGAN'S LETTERS
description: Following are the texts of President Reagan's letters to the President pro tem of the Senate and the Speaker of the House regarding the powers and duties of the President:

title: SOLITARY TRAVEL IS AN ADVENTURE OF ITS OWN
description: TO begin, we must acknowledge that there are disadvantages to solitary travel. What springs to mind is the extra cost charged for a single room, and to this there is no real solution. Beyond that are the difficulties of driving without a co-pilot to read maps and signs, the awkwardness of dining alone and the lack of someone to exclaim with, to laugh with, or to commiserate with when things go awry.

title: ON LECTURE CIRCUIT, TALK IS NOT CHEAP
description: A picture may be worth a thousand words, but on the lecture circuit, a few words are worth a thousand dollars.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday about the Henley Royal Regatta misstated the location of St. Andrews School, which competed in the Princess Elizabeth Challenge Cup. It is in Middletown, Del.

title: Herrera Wins 14th Leg; Hinault Still Leads Tour
description: Luis Herrera of Colombia won the 14th leg of the Tour de France cycling race today in 4 hours 56 minutes 32 seconds. Bernard Hinault of France, the favorite and four-time champion, maintained his overall lead.

title: New York City And Handguns
description: The article ''More Long Islanders Acquiring Handguns'' [June 9] quotes Officer Robert Fitzpatrick of the New York City Police Department's Pistol License Bureau as stating that 81 percent of the applications received by the city last year were approved.

title: IN BRAZIL'S NEW SCHOOLS, THE FIRST CLASS IS BREKFAST
description: THE school dining room was strangely quiet as the 8- , 9- and 10-year-olds dug into platefuls of beans, spaghetti, minced meat and cabbage. Their attention was undivided. Lunch is a key moment of their day; breakfast, a mid-morning snack and dinner are others.

title: HIGHS AND LOWS OF THE LONDON STAGE
description: A visitor doesn't even have to enter a theater to feel the particular excitement of London theatergoing this summer.

title: HUDSON WATER BEGINS MONTHLONG FLOW FROM CHELSEA STATION TO CITY TAPS
description: For the first time in 18 years, water from the Hudson River began entering New York City's drinking water system on Wednesday.

title: GAYE LISTER PLANS TO WED
description: Gaye Ormond Lister and Alexander Toland Bok plan to be married Sept. 21, her parents, John B. Lister of Old Westbury, L.I., and Mrs. Roessa O. Chiesman of Chipping Norton, England, have announced. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Bok of Boston.

title: KOCH FINALLY COMES OUT CAMPAIGNING
description: IT seemed like a boast when Edward I. Koch said after he was first elected mayor in 1977 that he planned to spend 12 years in City Hall.

title: Seven Afghans Defect With 2 Soviet Copters
description: A Pakistan Government spokesman said today that Afghan defectors had brought two advanced Soviet Mi-24 helicopter gunships to Pakistan.

title: SHARON PRESENTS VITAL 'CHORUS LINE'
description: ONE wishes that ''A Chorus Line'' at the Sharon Playhouse could fly forever. To be level-headed, you should see it before it closes Saturday night.

title: POLITICS IN BRIDGEPORT HEATING UP
description: IN the midst of summer, when people in most places are thinking about swimming and picnics and the sun, residents of Bridgeport are already embroiled in a heated campaign for the November mayoral election.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, THIS YEAR'S FIRES MAY BRING NEXT YEAR'S FLOODS
description: IN the aftermath of the latest explosion of wildfires in the West, many home owners reluctantly began to turn their attention from fire insurance to flood insurance.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS DRAW A BEAD ON THE ECONOMY
description: EL SALVADOR'S five-year civil war has taken a harsher turn in the last two months. Rebel forces have kidnapped mayors, machine-gunned American marines and Salvadoran civilians, and stepped up economic sabotage. The guerrillas have also returned to political action in the capital, backing strikes and demonstrations against the Government.

title: FIGHTING WORDS ON TERRORISM
description: If words were weapons, President Reagan would have certainly drawn blood last week. Lashing out at five nations he accused of sponsoring terrorism - Iran, Libya, North Korea, Cuba and Nicaragua - Mr. Reagan told the American Bar Association in Washington that he was ''not going to tolerate attacks from outlaw states run by the strangest collection of misfits, Looney Tunes and squalid criminals since the advent of the Third Reich.''

title: WHEN EVERY NIGHT HAS TO BE OPENING NIGHT
description: After nearly three years on Broadway, and 1,147 performances, ''Cats'' is still in the first of its nine lives.

title: A PLEA FOR MANDATORY RECYLCLING
description: THERE is nothing new about the concept of recycling in New Jersey. The recycling of many items was a way of life until disposable containers and ''convenience'' products gained acceptance during the consumption boom that followed World War II.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: FILM: 'COCA-COLA KID,' A CORPORATE SATIRE
description: IN ''The Coca-Cola Kid,'' which opens today at the Plaza, Dusan Makavejev appears to be taking aim at a target as big and red as the broad side of a barn. The film begins with an exceptionally long disclaimer disavowing any connection with the real Coca-Cola Company. But it then proceeds to tell a satirical story of the company's attempts - led by the title troubleshooter, played by Eric Roberts - to infiltrate a remote region of Australia, a region that happens to have a favorite local beverage of its own.

title: Molly Maguires
description: To the Editor: Robert McCracken Peck's article ''The Poconos Beyond the Billboards'' (Travel, June 16) revived many fond memories for this writer relative to the film production of ''The Molly Maguires'' in Eckley.

title: DEBRA CAMPBELL PLANNING TO WED
description: J. David Campbell of Phoenix, Ariz., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Debra Lynn Campbell, to J. Frederick Stillman 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. P. Gordon B. Stillman of New York and Wrightsville Beach, N.C. An October wedding is planned.

title: YALE ARCHIVE SAVES HOLOCAUST TAPES
description: LAUREL VLOCK first heard about the Holocaust as a child, when her parents were helping its victims during and after World War II. She stayed informed, read about the Holocaust, and considered herself knowledgeable and aware.

title: GARY ARKIN TO WED MISS KLEPPER
description: Leslie Klepper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lester Klepper of New York, was married last evening to Gary Mark Arkin, a son of Mrs. Bernard Rosen of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Howard Benjamin Arkin.

title:
GARDENING;

IT IS NOT TOO LATE FOR SOME PLANTINGS
description: WHILE most of us have completed our seasonal planting and are ready to sit back and enjoy the fruits, vegetables and flowers of our labors, there always seems to be a spot here and there in the garden that needs a bit of color or something more to fill in.

title: THE HUMAN COMEDY OF PEREYASLAV
description: FROM THE FAIR The Autobiography of Sholom Aleichem. Translated, edited and with an introduction by Curt Leviant. 288 pp. New York: Viking. $20.

title: ROSE AT 44: STILL HUSTLING, STILL HITTING
description: EVERY day since Opening Day this season, when the 44-year-old ballplayer ripped two hits - a run-scoring single and a two-run double to lead the Reds to a 4-1 victory over Montreal - The Cincinnati Post has run a color box about him on its front sports page. The headline on the box reads, ''Countdown to the Ty-breaker.''

title: BEFORE 'THE ASSAULT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bubka Sets Record With 19-8 1/4 Vault
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his world record in the pole vault today, clearing 19 feet 8 1/4 inches during the Paris International Track and Field Meet.

title: CORRECTION
description: In Eleanor Holmes Norton's article ''Restoring the Traditional Black Family'' (June 2), a passage dealing with the availability of marriage partners was misleading. It should have read: With large numbers of young men imprisoned, disabled by drugs or otherwise marginal and unavailable as marriage partners, there is an unusual disparity between the sheer numbers of marriageable black men and black women.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table accompanying an article in The Week in Review of July 7 on the Navy's ship-building program contained an incorrect figure for supply and repair ships operating in 1980. The correct figure is 97.

title: AIR-INDIA FLIGHT RECORDERS ARE TAKEN TO BOMBAY
description: The flight recorders of the Air-India jetliner that went down off Ireland were flown to Bombay today, and there were reports that an examination of the equipment would begin Monday in a search for clues to the June 23 disaster.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN HOSTAGES IN IRAN: The Conduct of a Crisis. By Warren Christopher, Harold H. Saunders, Gary Sick, Robert Carswell, Richard J. Davis, John E. Hoffman Jr. and Roberts B. Owen.

title: ALBEE REFLECTS ON VIRGINIA WOOLF
description: IT happened almost 23 years ago. A corrosive comedy drama - dealing with ''fun and games,'' ''Walpurgisnacht'' and ''the exorcism,'' as its three acts are respectively referred to - opened on Broadway in October 1962 and shook up the theater world. It indelibly implanted the name of an Off roadway plawright, Edward Albee, who had by then written such acclaimed one-act works as ''The Zoo Story'' and ''The Death of Bessie Smigh,'' in the theatrical hall of fame.

title: Israel's Worthy Double Standard
description: Even as its air force again claimed an eye for an eye in Lebanon last week, Israel's judicial arm declared private vengeance by Jews against Arabs to be terrorism and murder. At considerable political cost, this hard-pressed democracy will jail some of its most dedicated pioneers and decorated soldiers to proclaim the sanctity of life and law.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BEEKEEPING Would-be apiarists will want to make a beeline for a free program of the Western Connecticut Beekeepers Association at 8 P.M. Thursday at the Fairfield County Extension Center, Route 6, Bethel. Peter Philip, practically a novice himself, will give an illustrated talk on ''My Experiences as a First-Year Beekeeper.''

title: THE RECESSION ON THE RIVER
description: BY almost every measure, these are perhaps the hardest of times along the nation's rivers and waterways. Here, as elsewhere on the Mississippi, the volume of freight crossing the once-bustling docks has plunged 30 percent since its 1978 peak. Hundreds of barges stand idle waiting for cargo. Many of the towboat operators who earned their living moving grain, petrochemicals and coal down to New Orleans have gone bankrupt or are just barely hanging on. ''This industry is on its knees,'' said Howard Brent, the owner of Brent Towing, a family-owned business that has been working the river out of Greenville, Miss., since 1941. ''We're at a one-hundred-year low.''

title: IMPROVED BIGGS STOPS RICHARDSON IN 3RD
description: Tyrell Biggs continued to take giant steps by standing still. In only his fourth professional bout, Biggs maintained the rapid improvement over his amateur style and stopped Eddie Richardson in the third round today of a nationally televised bout from the Atlantis Casino Hotel.

title: THE SHIRTDRESS STILL UNRUFFLED
description: ELEGANT, tasteful, quiet: those are words that come to mind when describing the shirtdress. This all-American classic is so quiet, in fact, that when it slips out of sight, as it did for a few years recently, the silence was deafening.

title: DO COMMERCIALS DETER VIEWERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CAR BUFFS, ITS MILLVILLE OR BUST
description: Wheaton Village is a monument to South Jersey's glass-making industry and popular, though out-of-the-way mecca for those who love to collect glass.

title: DO COMMERCIALS DETER VIEWERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN A REGION OF VINEYARDS AND OLIVE GROVES
description: The layercake of cultures that is Apulia - a region inhabited by various peoples since prehistoric times -had been described to me by the nuns who taught me in my Roman childhood. I remember one sister, a native of Apulia, growing lyrical about the ancient olive groves, fecund vineyards, picturesque seashores and ravines and other natural beauties of her native soil.

title: MARLBORO'S CHAMBER-MUSIC MYSTIQUE
description: There is a seven-week, 35-year-old summer music event going on not far from from Brattleboro, Vt., which I think even its planners and participants would be hard pressed to identify with any precision.

title: ... AND IN TUSCALOOSA
description: Tuscaloosa, a city of 75,000 near Birmingham also governed since the early 1900's by a commission elected at large, voted last week too, and for a mayor-council system.

title: DISPUTE OVER POLICE TESTING
description: The New York City official who supervises Civil Service examinations said last week that standards on the written test for people seeking to become police officers had become so lax that a functional illiterate might be able to pass.

title: FELICE FLEGAL MARRIES
description: Felice Flegal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Flegal of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Kurt Alexander Furst, a son of Mrs. Harry R. Furst of Huntsville, Ala., and the late Mr. Furst. The Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: POLISH PRIDE IN RIVERHEAD
description: RIVERHEAD, which sits at the head of Peconic Bay where the North Fork meets the South Fork, has long struggled with an image problem. Over the last few years, however, a spirit of pride and identity has brought change to some of its neighborhoods.

title: MARBLE BATHS, TOO: TENEMENT CONDO
description: The four-story tenement at 379 First Avenue, near 22d Street, is certainly not the first Manhattan walk-up to be upgraded and converted to an owner-occupied residence, but it probably has more expensive features than most.

title: REAGAN TRANSFERS POWER TO BUSH FOR 8-HOUR PERIOD OF 'INCAPACITY'
description: President Reagan transferred his power to Vice President Bush for about eight hours today in a move that White House officials said temporarily made Mr. Bush the ''Acting President.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page June 30 about The Congressional Record misstated the history of its typography. In fact a political cartoon appeared in The Record in 1913. The Briefing column recalls the incident today on page 36.

title: TENNIS STARS TO VIE IN LIVINGSTON
description: WIMBLEDON was a keen disappointment for Jay Lapidus, the 26-year-old former Princeton University all-American, who was eliminated early in the world's most prestigious tennis tournament.

title: CARTOON FOR THE RECORD
description: Happily, it is not true, as was stated elsewhere on this page June 30, that the Congressional Record has never enlivened its endless gray report with a political cartoon. It is true, however, that this has not happened in quite a while.

title: TOPICS
description: THE season brings change in what we wear, what we eat and what we do. Some reflections are obvious: the garden beckons the trowel and watering can for seedlings; the academic arens ''changes the guard'' from one semester to the next. No major changes surfact from year to year - none except when something triggers memory or habit or an eternal truth...

title: DANCE IS THRIVING AGAIN IN FRANCE
description: ''For centuries, Paris was a dance capital and it remains so as well today.'' This sentence by Jacques Chirac, mayor of Paris, introduces a current exhibition in the French capital, entitled, ''Four Centuries of Ballet in Paris.'' Whether Mr. Chirac could have so confidently affirmed that Paris was a dance capital 10 years ago is problematical. Nonetheless, things have changed. The goings-on glimpsed on a visit in the last month, for instance, have been unusually varied.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BRIEFING BY PRESIDENT'S MEDICAL TEAM AFTER THE OPERATION
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing for reporters yesterday by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, and President Reagan's medical team, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: TRANSSEXUAL PLANS FUTURE IN LEGION
description: THE American Legion has not seen the last of its well-publicized transsexual, Bridgette Poi.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President is doing very, very, very well.'' - Capt. Dale Oller, head of President Reagan's surgical team. [1:6.]

title: WILL THE TRADE DEFICIT GO AWAY OR DOES IT NEED A SHOVE?
description: DISMAYED by surging imports which they blame for severe industrial unemployment, many members of Congress are demanding reprisals against countries that subsidize exports or set up barriers to goods from the United States. But with the dollar sliding in value last week against the Japanese and European currencies, some experts were predicting that the balance of trade would improve all by itself. There is certainly plenty of room for improvement. Last year, the United States trade deficit topped $123 billion, triple the imbalance in 1981. Since then, the deficit with developing countries has widened by more than $35 billion; with Europe, nearly $30 billion; with Japan, nearly $19 billion, and with Canada, $13 billion. In the face of such statistics, can free-trade theories retain their support? Clyde Farnsworth, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, discussed this and related issues with John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and Democrat of Michigan, one of the states hardest hit by foreign competition, and Bill Frenzel, Republican of Minnesota, a self-described ''free-trader'' and member of the trade subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. Excerpts follow. Question. Is this a new situation? Answer. This year, our trade imbalance is going to hit something on the order of $170 billion. For the first time, this country has become a net debtor nation. That hasn't been the case since 1914 or so. Q. What does that mean? A. If countries want to start pulling money out of this country, they can hurt us.

title: Before 'The Assault'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON GLOBE SEEKS AID IN TRIAL
description: SOME public relations practitioners seem to be taking a leaf out of the medical and legal books, developing ever narrower specialties to meet the needs of an ever more complicated society.

title: TRACING THE NUCLEAR NERVOUS SYSTEM
description: THE BUTTON The Pentagon's Strategic Command and Control System. By Daniel Ford. 270 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95. STRATEGIC COMMAND AND CONTROL Redefining the Nuclear Threat. By Bruce G. Blair. 341 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $12.95. TOTING up weapons has been a favorite pastime in the nuclear weapons debate. There are more than enough numbers to go around. To buttress the case for building and deploying the intercontinental MX missile, for example, supporters of the missile can compare United States and Soviet missile payload capacity - where the Soviet Union has a clear advantage. Critics have recourse to the total number of warheads and bombs, a category in which the United States has the lead. This bean-counting approach is an easy way to score debating points but it leaves out features of the American and Soviet nuclear forces that are not easily measured.

title: TRANSFER OF POWERS FOLLOWS PROCEDURES IN 25TH AMENDMENT
description: The 25th Amendment to the Constitution was designed to deal with serious ambiguities about who is in control of the Government when the President is unable to perform his duties.

title: THE LATEST VIDEO CAMERAS GO ANYWHERE AND DO EVERYTHING
description: More and more video fans are discovering the pleasure and the challenge of shooting their own tapes, with likely subjects ranging from family chronicles and travel mementos to elaborate ''videos'' conceived as a serious expression of an integrated artistic vision - part painting, part document, part drama. In response to this rising interest, much engineering development has been concentrated on home-video cameras, and the generally gratifying results are evident in many recent models.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Garden State Games, at Rutgers, Piscataway, N.J., 10 A.M. Second day of official competition in the men's decathlon, women's heptathlon, plus basketball, fencing, archery and other sports. Diving will be at Rahway River Park from 7 A.M. to noon. Admission is free. Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium. Although Ron Guidry has won 11 games, he will not be going to the All-Star Game Tuesday, and one reason is that he is starting today. (Television -Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. The Mets conclude their most productive trip of the season with Dwight Gooden starting. (Television -Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7 P.M.) Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Bicyling Tour de France, through July 21. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Same-day tape.) Boxing Milton McCrory, champion vs. Carlos Trujillo, 12 rounds, for World Boxing Council welterweight title at Monte Carlo. McCrory (26-0-1) won the vacant title in 1983 and has defended it three times. Trujillo is 19-2. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Cornelius Boza-Edwards vs. John Montes, 10 rounds, lightweights, at Tampa Fla. Boza-Edwards, the former W.B.C. junior lightweight champion, is 43-5 with 34 knockouts. Montes, from Whittier, Calif., is 29-2 with 22 knockouts.

title: WHAT VACATIONING EXECUTIVES ARE READING
description: It's summer - time for most people to settle back in a favorite easy chair or hammock with a good book. For those who head huge companies, the usual fare of reports, newspapers and trade journals must be read. But sandwiched between this required reading is some lighter fare: spy stories, autobiographies and a melange of fictional passions and intrigues.

title: CELESTE HOLM HONORED FOR SUPPORT OF THE ARTS
description: The actress Celeste Holm has been named this year's ''friend of the arts'' by the Town Hall Foundation. The award is given annually by the foundation to a person who has ''demonstrated exemplary interest in the development, enrichment and support of the arts.''

title: SUMMARY JUSTICE
description: 'If anyone wants to intercede on their behalf in the name of human rights, he had better do it today, because tomorrow will be too late.' rrLansana Conte, rrPresident of Guinea, just before sending Col. Diara Traore and his accused co-conspirators before a firing squad for trying to overthrow him.

title: NO SURPRISE IN MEXICO
description: The only real upset in last week's elections in Mexico was to the morale of the main opposition group, the National Action Party. The Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has kept a tight grip on the country for more than 50 years, yielded a few seats in Congress but retained all seven governorships at stake and practically everything else despite National Action's high hopes in at least two states.

title: MUSIC: 'VIVA VAVALDI!'
description: LINCOLN CENTER'S Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra offered an alliterative tribute to one of Mozart's great predecessors Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The program, entitled ''Viva Vivaldi!,'' included six of the composer's 700 concertos and a brief, lovely Sinfonia for Strings in B minor (R. 169).

title: REBEL RAID ON PRISON FREES 149
description: A total of 149 inmates escaped from El Salvador's main prison Friday during an attack believed to have been carried out by leftist rebels, an army spokesman said today.

title: COCA-COLA SWALLOWS ITS WORDS
description: WHEN consumer outcry forced The Coca-Cola Company to reintroduce its original formula last week, Roger Enrico, the president of Pepsi-Cola U.S.A., was quick to proclaim the 10-week-old new Coke ''the Edsel of the 80's.''

title: New York Reallocates Power for Other States
description: The New York Power Authority has revised its allocations of the hydroelectric power that it generates and sells to several neighboring states.

title: Q. & A. With State's Housing Chief
description: Last month, Governor Cuomo appointed a senior aide, William B. Eimicke, to the newly created position of Director of Housing with the responsibility of coordinating the activities of four state agencies concerned with housing issues.

title: POTOMAC MISFIT
description: THE FLOATING ISLAND A Tale of Washington. By Garrett Epps. 286 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.

title: Minimum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: PUTTING VALUES FIRST
description: THE SKEPTIC DISPOSITION IN CONTEMPORARY CRITICISM By Eugene Goodheart. 188 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $22.50.

title: Taking It
description: In ''Taking It'' (About Men, June 9), Leonard Kriegel writes of his quiet surrender to polio just at the time when many other polio victims, both men and women, are facing a renewed battle with their disease. After years of struggle to overcome or accept their handicaps, 20 to 30 percent of the estimated 250,000 surviving American polio patients are experiencing new symptoms of fatigue, joint and muscle pain, weakness in previously unaffected muscles and sleep disturbances.

title: Pennsylvanians Win Anderson
description: Warren Choate and Joe Reynolds of the Williamsport (Pa.) Country Club defeated Bill Cosgrove and Bruce Carter of Pleasant Valley, Mass., 3 and 2, this afternoon to win the Anderson Memorial Tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

title: Prosecutor Seeks Data On Turk in Rome Case
description: The prosecutor in the trial in Rome of eight men accused of conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II met Turkish officials here today to seek information about a Turkish defendant in the trial whom the police here interrogated for five days this week after his arrival from Bulgaria.

title: ANGOLA, ANGRY OVER REBEL AID ISSUE, ENDS U.S. TALKS
description: Angola, reacting angrily to recent Congressional votes, announced today that it was suspending talks with the United States for a settlement between Angola and South Africa.

title: DEBORAH STALKER WED TO MICHAEL AMBLER JR.
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Quogue, L.I., yesterday Deborah Marshall Stalker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Stalker of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married to Michael Nash Ambler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambler of New York and Quogue. Bishop Robert C. Witcher, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, performed the ceremony.

title: RTE. 1 OVERPASS: UNTYING A KNOT
description: Nassau Park Princeton, a 200-acre office, hotel and retail complex under construction near Princeton, N.J., has yet to open, but already the intersection at Route 1 and Quakerbridge Road, near what will be the development's main entrance, is a motorist's despair.

title: ACTOR EXCELS IN 'BUTTERFLIES'
description: LEONARD GERSHE'S ''Butterflies Are Free,'' at Theater three in Port Jefferson through July 27, was a longrunning Broadway success in 1979. It is the story of Don Baker, a young blind man who is breaking away from his mother and the security of his family home in Scarsdale.

title: Topics;   Excess Baggage The Junker Tax
description: Abandoned automobiles, stripped of license plates and often all usable parts as well, are cluttering the New York landscape. In 1980, contractors towed away 33,000 junkers; last year they towed 62,000.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Last Sept. 16, homeowners in Maywood and Rochelle Park were told by state environmental officials that their worries about thorium-contaminted soil were over. Some 160,000 cubic yards of the soil were removed and stored temporarily at the site where the thorium originted, a chemical plant now operated by the Stepan Chemical Company of Maywood.

title: Give Those Neanderthals a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: DENA ZEISEL AFFIANCED TO SCOTT M. HEIMBERG
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Zeisel of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dena Ellen Zeisel, to Scott Michael Heimberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Heimberg of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: DEFICIT POLTICS TAKES SOME NEW TURNS INTO OLD TRAPS
description: OVERSHADOWED by the hostage crisis and shakeups in Moscow, the Federal budget became news again last week, as President Reagan stepped directly into stalled Congressional negotiations to push a ''framework'' for compromise. So far, the effort has not produced a solution so much as underlined the hazards of deficit politics.

title: Gorbachev's Tightening Grip on Power
description: The major personnel changes that rocked the Kremlin this month confirm Mikhail S. Gorbachev's domination of foreign policy. Some of the specific changes were astonishing, but all are very much of a piece with other steps he has taken since coming to power.

title: WORKIN' ON THE (MINIATURE) RAILRODAD
description: IT seemed like a cataclysmic earthquake. The train tracks, trees, shrubbery, buildings and bridges convulsed violently as the men of the Westchester Railroad Club attacked their miniature model world with horrendously loud power tools.

title: A GOVERNOR ON THE SPOT
description: After Bill Sheffield was elected Governor of Alaska in 1982, he promised an open and businesslike approach to government. But according to a special grand jury, the hotel chain operator's idea of businesslike may have benefitted a private more the public interest.

title: Mosquito Control: A Dissent on Ditches
description: I am not at all in agreement with the article ''Fish to Be Used to Control Mosquitoes in a Test in Suffolk'' [June 9] , and the facts are clear.

title: LOUGANIS'S DIVING INSPIRES THE YOUNG
description: As 14-year-old Ali Buckley of Maplewood, N.J., received an autograph and then a kiss on the cheek from the Olympic diving champion yesterday, Greg Louganis, her expression reflected more than the star-struck emotions of a youngster who had just been touched by an idol. Deep in the blush and almost lost in a nervous smile was the look of an athlete who had seen, up close, what she eventually wants to achieve: the grace and skill of an Olympic gold medalist.

title: Socialists in Portugal Select a Candidate
description: Portugual's Socialists today named Antonio de Almeida Santos, a 59-year-old politician, as their choice for Prime Minister should the party win general elections in October, party sources said.

title: I FIND TRAFFIC COURT GUILTY
description: THE scales of justice bore the odor of fish left too long out of water. I had just experienced my first taste of traffic court. It had made as much sense as the television comedy series ''Night Court.'' Frankly, I would have preferred appearing before the show's Judge Harold T. Stone. You know he's certifiable.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Kurashiki
description: To the Editor: At last, an article on the beguiling little city of Kurashiki (''The Quiet Heart of Kurashiki'' by Susan Chira, Travel, June 23). It is indeed a cultural gem where one is immediately captivated by the startling contrasts of black tile designs on low white buildings.

title:
DINNG OUT;

A TASTE OF FRANCE IN RURAL SUSSEX
description: ONE of the more pleasant aspects of writing about restaurants is the pleasure of occasionally finding the proverbial ''hole in the wall'' with wonderful food.

title: MISS BEESLEY HAS WEDDING
description: Terry Ruth Beesley and Howard Phipps 3d were married yesterday at the Vernier Parish Church in Geneva, where the bride's father, J. Alan Beesley, is Canadian Ambassador and representative at the United Nations office. The Rev. Richard Frost, parish priest of the English-speaking community in Geneva, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: STATEN ISLAND'S SHORE PRIMED FOR GROWTH
description: AMBITIOUS plans for development on the north shore of Staten Island have been taking shape in the last few months, most of them along an underutilized stretch of waterfront that has long been considered to have strong development potential.

title: THE RAIN - AND THE PAIN
description: Standing near the bank of the Ashokan Reservoir in the Catskill Mountains, flanked by vast stretches of dry, caked bottom once covered by millions of gallons of drinking water, Mayor Koch announced last week that he was imposing stringent new restrictions on water use in New York City. The goal, the Mayor said, was to conserve several hundred million gallons each day, primarily by limiting water use by businesses and by central air conditioning systems that use city water. In reality, New York had no alternative. Water throughout the system fell last week to 55.4 percent of capacity. Ordinarily, the level is at about 94 percent at this time of year.

title: SEPT. 14 WEDDING FOR SUSAN DRAPER
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Draper of Swampscott, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Halford Draper to C. Stow Walker Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Walker of Providence, R.I. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14. Miss Draper, a television news producer for WCVB, the ABC affliate in Boston, graduated from the Buxton School in Williamstown, Mass., and Brown University.

title: AUSTRIA WINS BY A NARROW MARGIN
description: A major decision by the World Bridge Federation last year seemed largely academic at the time but has proved to be both far-sighted and important. The 1985 World Team Championship, scheduled to start Nov. 2, was moved from India to Brazil because the Indian Government would not provide an assurance that all competing teams would be admitted to the country.

title: PSYCHICS' CLIENTS IN BUSINESS SUITS
description: TEA is never served at the Gypsy Tea Kettle on Lexington Avenue. And the only gypsy there is on the neon sign in the front window. Despite that, on most afternoons after 5 P.M., men and women in business suits sit at small cafe tables waiting, they say, to gain insight into their past, present and future in a 15-minute ''psychic reading.''

title: MERRILY, MERRILY
description: In his 25 years in the House, Silvio O. Conte has discovered there is more than one way to get the attention of his colleagues. The Massachusetts Republican is pushing for owners of recreational boats to pay a $20 fee to the Coast Guard to cover the mounting cost of search and rescue operations, and the boaters, predictably, are resisting.

title: SUMMER THEATER: ONE SUCCESS STORY
description: SURROUNDED by lawns and groves where audiences are encouraged to have pre-performance picnics, one finds a 244-seat ''continental style'' theater, which means there is no center aisle. But it does have ''state of the art'' technology, according to its publicity representative, Nancy Seavy.

title: BELMONT REMATCH IS A RERUN
description: On paper, the $96,450 Lexington Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday looked like a virtual rerun of the Hill Prince three weeks earlier. But three factors raised the possibility of a different result: the race was three-sixteenths of a mile longer and being run on the inner turf course instead of the Widener turf course, and the top contenders all had different riders.

title:
About Men;

A NEED FOR MEDALS
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, ON a magazine assignment, I interviewed the commandant of the Marine Corps, who at the time was Gen. Robert H. Barrow. The general is a tall, handsome man, intelligent and eloquent with an almost courtly manner. But these were not the first things I noticed about him.

title: 'WE DO WHAT THE NETWORKS WANT'
description: ''My personal taste never enters into anything I do.'' Dick Clark was recently detailing some of the reasons behind his continuing success as both an on-camera personality and his off-camera role as the head of Dick Clark Productions, purveyors of television, radio and motion-picture entertainments.

title: AND THOU BESIDE ME BOILING A PIG'S HEAD
description: AN OMELETTE AND A GLASS OF WINE By Elizabeth David. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: The Awful Truth
description: IT HAD BEEN FIVE OR six years since I last spent two days driving the high-speed roads, so I had forgotten how awful it is.

title: TRYING TO SAVE THE STRIPED BASS
description: PHILIP G. COATES, chairman of the striped bass management board of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, is pleased with the progress being made to aid that beleaguered species.

title: BEST IN THE WEST
description: HELMUT SCHMIDT Helmsman of Germany. By Jonathan Carr. 208 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $25.

title: SHOULD THE MET PURSUE MODERN ART?
description: As construction proceeds on its huge new wing for modern art - to open in January 1987 - the Metropolitan Museum is on an acquisitions spree that is the envy of many a curator. Backed by donors (the Met has only small acquisitions funds of its own), William Lieberman, chairman of the department of 20th-century art, has been snapping up works assiduously, with notable forays into the current field. Last year, for instance, the department acquired by purchase or gift nearly 40 paintings, drawings, and sculptures made since 1980, including works by ''now'' names that range from Nicholas Africano to Joe Zucker to Adam Civjanovic.

title: CAN THE U.S.F.L. RETURN TO WHAT IT SET OUT TO DO?
description: When the Baltimore Stars and Oakland Invaders match up tonight for the United States Football League title, will the game signal the end of a three-year dream or serve as a launching pad for the most extensive and expensive head-to-head competition in the history of professional sports?

title: 'DISPOSAL DAYS' PLANNED
description: RIDGEFIELD'S hazardous household waste disposal day was such a success a year ago that a number of Connecticut communities are planning their own days to help those in doubt about how best to throw wastes out.

title: ELIZABETH WALD PLANS TO MARRY
description: Elizabeth T. Wald and Wayne Forman, graduates of the University of Colorado School of Law, plan to be married Sept. 29, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Wald of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: A NEW book by Eli Sagan, ''At the Dawn of Tyranny,'' (Knopf, New York, $22.95), asks us to look within ourselves for answers about society and the issues that confound us.

title: One Killed as Plane Hits Houses in Georgia
description: A Georgia Army National Guard airplane crashed into a residential neighborhood here today, killing one of the two crew members aboard and injuring an unknown number of people on the ground, the authorities said.

title: AN INVITING SEASON FOR FAIR DEVOTEES
description: BRIGHTLY painted whirligigs and live country music.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;

THE OTHER SIDE
description: EVEN at this late date, they are still Opponents, measured against the success of the New York Yankees. Most of them spent their careers watching the Yankees race toward the World Series, or being run over in October.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

HERE NIGHTINGALES MIGHT SING
description: Gramercy Park, its manicured lawn preserved behind cast-iron gates, appears to be the Manhattan equivalent of a London square. Yet its developer, Samuel Ruggles, had something else in mind when in 1831 he proposed the creation of a privately owned garden between 20th and 21st Streets and Third and Fourth Avenues.

title: CORRECTION
description: An report on June 23 in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the document on which John Hancock put his famous prominent signature. It was the Declaration of Independence, not the Constitution.

title: Up and Down and Up Year For Dykstra
description: Len Dykstra considered the question, staring into space in contemplation.

title: EVERYBODY'S GUIDE TO 1066 AND ALL SINCE
description: THE OXFORD COMPANION TO ENGLISH LITERATURE Fifth Edition. Edited by Margaret Drabble. 1,155 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: AN ORE CARRIER'S TROUBLED ODYSSEY
description: IT is daybreak but a cold clammy fog blocks out the sun. Throughout the night, long steel arms, reaching out from the dock, have poured tens of thousands of tons of iron ore into the ship's 20 cargo hatches.

title: STUDY URGES CITIES TO SPEED DECISIONS ON LANDMARKS
description: A REPORT for the Twentieth Century Fund on urban preservation policies in 20 cities, including New York, has urged the cities to survey their buildings comprehensively and make definitve decisions on whether they should be landmarked.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page article in some editions last Sunday about fiscal actions by the states misstated the amount by which tax cuts exceeded increases this year. It was $700 million.

title: SHANKER WARMS TO MERIT PAY
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, changed his mind last week about merit pay. He proposed that it be awarded to experienced teachers based on nationwide tests and standards.

title: Unplanned Marathon
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE NEW ORDER IN MOBILE
description: After seven years of arguing that what was good enough for 1911 was good enough for now, the leaders of Mobile, Ala., agreed to work on redesigning the city's form of government. Elections held last week were the first for a new mayor-city council system.

title: EAST GERMAN ACTION SAID TO HAVE FOILED JUNE PLOT ON U.S. JET
description: Sources in the West Berlin Senate said today that the East German authorities had foiled a plot to hijack an American airliner in West Berlin by two people carrying diplomatic passports from a Middle Eastern country.

title: ALBANY LETS OUT THE STATE UNIVERSITY'S LEASH
description: IF the 1960's were the boom years for American higher education, no institution grew faster than the State University of New York. Established in 1948, the university brought together 29 small public colleges with a combined enrollment of about 26,700 students. By 1959, it had grown to 33 campuses with 63,700 students. And by 1975, SUNY had become the largest university in the country - with 64 campuses, a student population approaching 400,000 and an annual budget of more than $1 billion.

title: 2 AMERICAN CREWS GAIN LUCERNE FINAL
description: Princeton University finished second today and joined Friday's qualifier, the Oklahoma City Rowing Club, in the final of Sunday's eight-oared championship, the most important event of the Lucerne International Rowing Regatta.

title: GREY ALBANS TO WED M. L. HIRSCHFIELD
description: The engagement of Gabrielle Victoria Albans and Michael Lane Hirschfeld, both lawyers in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Austrian Jr. of New York, stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Hirschfeld of Oceanside, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: FAILURE OF HOTEL-TAX BILL IS CENTER OF POLITICAL BATTLE
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke had harsh words for some members of the Westchester delegation in Albany last week, accusing them of ''sitting as a super county government and deciding what's best for us.'' He added: ''That's not how the game was played in the past.''

title: IN 40 YEARS OF NUCLEAR PEACE, LOS ALAMOS LIVES WITH BOMB
description: Forty years ago this week the flash of a hundred suns seared the New Mexican desert, the sand at Trinity Site fused into jade-green glass and the nuclear age was born.

title: TOPICS
description: THE neighborhood diner stands in the middle of the main street. A gathering place for most of the townspeople, it's the place to be seen in the trendiest tennis togs. It's the place for families with varied tastes to dine on good food inexpensively. It also serves as the perfect ending to an evening of dinner and a movie. The diner provides a different service for everyone.

title: HOW AN ARBITER COULD HELP REBUILD OUR PUBLIC WORKS
description: THE condition of the infrastructure and its effects on the physical, economic and social welfare of the nation, in general, and Connecticut, in particular, are in large measure easily understood: either the bridges, street lights or sewers work or they do not work. Even though we can understand those aspects of the infrastructure with which we come into daily contact, solutions for the infrastructure's rehabilitation are inordinately complex and made more difficult but the constantly changing focuses and concerns emanating from the body politic.

title: EDITOR WITH CLOUT
description: HERBERT CROLY OF THE NEW REPUBLIC The Life and Thought of an American Progressive. By David W. Levy. Illustrated. 335 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $32.50.

title: A 'BILL OF RIGHTS' FOR THE R.N.
description: DOES a nurse, as a human being and a professional, have the legal right to refuse to participate in the prescribed delivery of health care in a particular case because the procedure to be used, or the nature of the problem, is in direct opposition to the nurse's own moral, ethical, religious, philosophical or medical beliefs?

title: CAN CRIME BE CURBED? THE IDEAS OF 3 EXPERTS
description: If the United States wants to deter crime, rather than simply react to it, the neighborhood is the place to start, according to the head of the Eisenhower Foundation.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAWKS, DOVES, AND OWLS: An Agenda for Avoiding Nuclear War. Edited by Graham T. Allison, Albert Carnesale and Joseph S. Nye Jr.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SARATOGA
description: Known as the Queen of Spas a century ago, Saratoga Springs has reclaimed its place as a premier summer resort, offering ballet, symphony, theater, polo and racing as well as reminders of its gilded age. While Victorian visitors were preoccupied with gambling, racing and taking the mineral waters, today's visitors are as much drawn by the cultural activities at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center as by the thoroughbred races held every August at the country's oldest track (121 years).

title: GRATEFUL GIFT: SOVIET TRIP FOR FACULTY
description: One day more than a year ago, the wealthy father of two students at Phillips Academy here offered to bestow a gift of the school's choosing on its ambitious program of Russian studies.

title: THROUGH THE ROOF
description: THE average sales price of a single-family house in the county jumped 24 percent in the last year, to $225,570 in the second quarter of the year, or $44,071 higher than the $181,499 average for the same period last year, according to the Westchester County Board of Realtors.

title: ARTWORKS ENHANCE THE ELEGANCE OF REGION'S RESTORED TRAIN STATIONS
description: FROM the outside, the train station in Wilmington, Del., looks much like other turn-of-the-century stations in the Northeast. Just inside the door, however, is a startling sight: a vestibule decorated with brilliantly-colored ceramic tiles of unmistakably contemporary design.

title: TAKING IT
description: Leonard Kriegel's attitude toward female polio victims - ''a woman endured, but a man fought back'' - had no basis in the reality of my polio ward. During the epidemic year of 1953 in upper Michigan, survival from polio had no gender attributes.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Visions of Diana Ross Columbia Pictures/Musicvision 19 minutes. $19.95 In four of the six video clips that make up ''The Visions of Diana Ross,'' the former queen of Motown looks and acts much like the heroine of a romance novel.

title: Recent Sales
description: Matawan $50,000 500 Cliffwood Avenue *2* 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old condominium *2* apartment; wall-to-wall carpeting, garage *2* space, $95 monthly maintenance; taxes $1,200. Milburn $266,000 389 Wyoming Avenue *2* 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; *2* bay windows, sun room, built-in cabinets; taxes $4,183. New Milford $128,000 186 Boulevard *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; *2* fenced yard, intercom, patio; taxes $2,726. Paterson $88,000 453 Preakness Avenue *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 5-year-old town house; *2* central air-conditioning, balcony, garage; taxes $2,710. Rutherford $107,500 334 Park Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, older colonial; *2* enclosed porch, aluminum siding; taxes $1,715. Scotch Plains $215,000 31 Homestead Terrace *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; *2* pool, cathedral ceiling, fireplace; taxes $3,362. OTHER AREAS Milford, Conn. $153,900 Jennifer Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; quiet cul de sac, *2* central island kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes not yet available. Peekskill, N.Y. $156,500 11 Shipley Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old frame colonial; *2* eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $5,432. East Meadow, L.I. $116,000 215 Randall Avenue *2* 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2* dining room, 2-car garage, taxes $2,700.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CHARLATAN. By William Hamilton. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) In this accurately titled novel, the cartoonist William Hamilton tells the story of the self-serving Sonny Turchik, from Oregon, who at the age of 18 is convicted of breaking and entering (he simply wanted to live in an elegant house) and is given the choice of a probationary sentence or enlistment in the Marine Corps.

title: Topics;   Excess Baggage Carrying On
description: The Federal Aviation Administration says it's time to limit the amount of baggage airline passengers may carry on board. The increasing volume of carry-ons has become both a safety and security hazard says Donald Engen, the F.A.A. chairman.

title: Mass Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE WITH THE MILK LADY
description: FIRST LIGHT By Emily Ellison. 252 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: The Black Family
description: In her article ''Restoring the Traditional Black Family'' (June 2), Eleanor Holmes Norton writes that ''many boys meet little resistance to the ghetto message that associates manhood with sex but not responsibility.'' And with good reason: In a white male-dominated society that equates masculinity with power and achievement, black males incorporate early the despair and helplessness about their own possibility for achievement and ''masculinity.'' Mrs. Norton's recommendation for schools and institutions to become ''much more aggressive with boys on the true meaning and responsibilities of manhood . . .'' is hardly to the point.

title: James R. Lawson, 67, Harlem-Based Activist
description: James R. Lawson, a Harlem-based activist, died July 9 at Albert Einstein Hospital, after suffering a stroke June 27 at his home in the Bronx. He was 67 years old.

title: KATHLEEN HIGGINS ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Herbert N. Higgins of Fort Myers, Fla., and Falmouth, Mass., of the engagement of her daughter Kathleen Tryphon Higgins to Andrew Denison Ebbott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Ebbott of White Bear Lake, Minn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: A SUMPTUOUS MENU OF FRENCH MUSIC
description: Of a number of recent recordings of French music, the most outstanding is a transfer to a compact disk of Ravel's ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges'' (EMI CDC 7 47169 2). This delicate, transparent and precious opera has been available on a digital LP, but in its new incarnation it has added luster. Colette's story of a naughty child who is taught humanity by inanimate and living things who take on human form has never been easy to stage. Its fairytale atmosphere can be easily broken when presented visually, and it is better in most cases to just listen to it and imagine what's happening. Under the latter circumstances it is enchanting.

title: BOLIVIA VOTES TODAY AMID FEAR OF COUP OR FRAUD
description: Bolivians are to vote in general elections on Sunday, but many politicians and diplomats said they feared the vote count could be overtaken by a military coup or annulled because of fraud.

title: PATRICIA COTTER WEDS
description: Patricia Ellen Cotter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Cotter of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday to Brian John Hassinger, a son of Mr. and Mr. and Mrs. John N. Hassinger of Beavertown, Pa. Msgr. John R. Torney performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help. The bride, a law student at Suffolk University, graduated from Bucknell University, as did Mr. Hassinger. He is a structural engineer for United Engineers and Constructors in Seabrook, N.H.

title: A YANKEE REVOLUTION IN ENGLAND
description: They say that wars consist of long stretches of boredom interspersed with sudden flurries of terrifying violence. For the English extras slouched in their 18th-century American uniforms behind period ramparts, vast wicker baskets filled with earth, that was clearly true of making movies about wars, too. They put on dark glasses, they chatted, they smoked. One studied the Devonshire bird-life through binoculars, while others desultorily amused themselves in less constructive ways.

title: CHINESE LIBERALISM GOES ONLY SO FAR
description: FOR all that is changing, there is much to remind the outsider of the deep-rooted differences that still separate China from the West. Although Deng Xiaoping, the senior leader, is committed to rapid modernization, he has cautioned visitors not to expect wholesale Westernization. In its crudest terms, this means that China would like the wealth and technology associated with Western systems, but not their political and social culture.

title: TEACHERS GROUP SEEMS TO RELAX TESTING VIEW
description: The American Federation of Teachers ended a three-day conference here today, remaining opposed to the testing of experienced teachers but indicating a new willingness to examine both sides of the issue.

title: BRAHMIN BOSTON PRESERVED
description: Beacon Hill offers some of the choicest strolls in urban America, particularly for fanciers of American architecture, art and history, and the surprising city cul-de-sacs that combine all three. From the Bulfinch townhouses on Chestnut Street to the quaint private park in Louisburg Square, all the visitor need do is look up from the cobbled walk. But not all of the hill's landmarks are so unguarded. Indeed, some treasures the descendants of the old Brahmins would just as soon keep to themselves, thank you. And one of these is the large, understated, virtually unmarked building on Beacon Street - the hill's southern boundary. This is the Boston Athenaeum, an almost 200-year-old independent research and lending library: for generations of eminent Bostonians, the epicenter of their life of the mind as well as a repository of their Yankee culture.

title: HELP FOR AILING NEGATIVES AND PRINTS
description: WITH a click of the shutter, history can be captured in a photograph - but how long will that piece of history last? This question has confronted scientists and museum curators as well as the photographer who hopes to preserve family history in an album of snapshots. Now, a new book offers some guidance on the problem.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOODROW WILSON AND WORLD WAR I: 1917-1921. By Robert H. Ferrell. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) If there is a lesson to be drawn from Robert H. Ferrell's history, it is that political philosophers do not necessarily make good Presidents.

title: HYDE PARK BUCOLIC
description: BEFORE THE TRUMPET Young Franklin Roosevelt: 1882-1905. By Geoffrey C. Ward. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: DR. SYDNEY P. SCHIFF
description: Dr. Sydney P. Schiff, the Chief Coroner of Sullivan County for 18 years, died of cancer Wednesday at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 67 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

title: CREATIVE SENTENCES FOR YOUTHS
description: WHEN two East Hartford teen-agers were arrested for setting fire to some piles of leaves last fall, their sentence included washing down the fire truck at the local firehouse. The youths liked the firefighters so much they kept coming back to visit.

title: New Tulane Coach
description: Tulane, which dropped men's basketball as a result of a point-shaving scandal last spring, has hired Joline Matsunami to be the head coach of the women's basketball team, replacing Julia Yeater, who left in May.

title: RESORTS PRESSED ON USE OF BEACHES
description: NEW JERSEY'S beaches are being heated by more than the sun this summer.

title: DISCOVERING HOW THE AIDS VIRUS WORKS
description: The victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome typically suffer from infections and cancer that normal people would easily ward off, and deaths are caused by these maladies rather than by the AIDS virus itself. As of last week, 5,714 people have died of AIDS in this country; that accounts for about half of the identified victims of the disease since the official count started in 1979.

title: APULIA: AN ANCIENT, RUGGED LAND
description: When we told people last fall that we planned to spend a week or so in Apulia, we drew a lot of blank stares. Oh, an artistic Italian friend said he had heard that it was full of Romanesque churches, and a political British friend said he half remembered from his school days a maxim to the effect that ''it is better to be a prefect in Apulia than a subprefect in Rome,'' and someone else said that Luigi Barzini had described it as the undiscovered wonder of his country. But most people we talked to didn't even know where the place was.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

WHY DON'T TEACHERS TURN ON THE TV?
description: LAST summer I watched hopefully as Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, offered his projections for America's future. However, his anachronistic advice to parents to help their children become better educated by turning off the television made me sigh for the dismal future of education in a country in which nonprofessionals have too great an influence in an area in which they increasingly lack experience.

title: LOUISA S. BROWN PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Brown of Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louisa Shepard Brown, to John Brickman Troubh, a son of Raymond Stanley Troubh of New York and Elizabeth W. Vorenberg of Cambridge, Mass. The wedding is planned for October.

title: MARY E. T. PFEIFER MARRIED TO VICTOR A. MACHCINSKI JR.
description: Mary Ellen Theresa Pfeifer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Pfeifer of Middle Village and Breezy Point, Queens, was married yesterday to Victor Anthony Machcinski Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Machcinski of Danbury, Conn., and West Chatham, Mass. The Rev. August C. Bednartz performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: MIXED SIGNALS
description: Journalists in Washington take pride in pointing out how the bureaucrats they cover can act like pettifoggers. But sometimes, it seems to Government officials and even some reporters, the reporters themselves show they are no slouches when it comes to caviling.

title: ELISABETH SLOAN, ARCHITECTURE TRAINEE, MARRIED TO ARTHUR W. LICHTENBERGER
description: Elisabeth Hunter Sloan, a daughter of Mrs. Edward William Sloan 3d of Farmington, Conn., and the late Lieut. Col. Russell Palmer Hunter 3d, U.S.A.F., was married yesterday to Arthur Weston Lichtenberger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Tate Lichtenberger of Westfield, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Alan C. Tull performed the ceremony in the chapel at Trinity College in Hartford, where he is the Episcopal chaplain, assisted by the Rev. Jeffrey P. Fishwick, the bridegroom's brother-in-law.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED BY NASSAU AND U.S. IN SUIT ON POLICE TEST
description: The United States Justice Department and Nassau County agreed today to cooperate in producing a valid Civil Service test for police officers that does not discriminate against members of minority groups.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Prices Are Halved On Summer Clothing The Richard Oliver House, just off Route 22 in Bedford Village, has marked most summer clothing to half the original price and other goods to 30 percent off until July 27. The markdowns do not apply to accessories -whether belts, handbags, scarves and jewelry for women or socks, ties, multicolor cummerbunds, suspenders, walking sticks, soft luggage, shaving kits or gifts for men. Ultrasuede golf skirts remain $140 and sturdy canvas totes with zippered pockets at $23 to $31.

title: SAD AND SHAGGY DOWN EAST
description: THE CLEAR BLUE LOBSTER-WATER COUNTRY A Trilogy. By Leo Connellan. 158 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $8.95. ASPHALT GEORGICS By Hayden Carruth. 75 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $15. Paper, $6.95. WRITERS are one of the state of Maine's more dependable crops. To claim that they thrive as rankly as some of their wilder cousins, say, thistle, pokeweed, mullein or deadly nightshade, might be stretching a point. But like Wordsworth's daffodils they blossom copiously in recollection. Until around mid-century native and part-time residents did little to fluster the churches, colleges or chambers of commerce. Whenever some moral outrage was contemplated or committed, like Eliot's Macavity the Mystery Cat they were just not there. Portland's Longfellow and South Berwick's Sarah Orne Jewett were still the presiding good angels. The rebellions of voluntary exiles like E. A. Robinson, Edna Millay or Louise Bogan, such as they were, took place offstage.

title: CLOUDY DAYS AT BEHEMOTH AMALGAMATED
description: BEYOND HUMAN SCALE The Large Corporation at Risk. By Eli Ginzberg and George Vojta. 242 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.95.

title: BUT WHO NEEDS CLOSETS, ANYWAY?
description: CHRISTMAS 1982: Finally graduated from college.

title: Treating Brain Disorders
description: The prospect of this new technology is exciting indeed. For the practitioner and the patient, however, the future is cloudy.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: It's time to celebrate Mozart at Avery Fisher Hall again and if Gerard Schwarz has assembled as fleet and accomplished a Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra as he did the past two seasons, we are in for an exciting summer.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

GAUGING THE MARKET
description: There are encouraging signs that momentum is building in the coin market, and this should be demonstrated later this month when dealers and collectors gather in Chicago for Auction '85. The seventh in a series of annual midsummer extravaganzas, that sale should serve as an indicator of the market's quickening pulse.

title: MUSIC: THE BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC
description: A FEW minutes past 8 on Friday night, Bruce Ferden walked out onto the stage of the Prospect Park Band Shell, lifted his baton, then halted. With a smile, he motioned up to the sky, where a helicopter was passing over, its relentless ack-ack-ack threatening to drown out the first notes of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's zarzuela night.

title: Speaking With Other Species
description: Kanzi, a 4-year-old pygmy chimpanzee, has put new sparkle into an ebbing venture, the age-old desire of humans to communicate with other species.

title: INSURERS RAISE FEES TO DAY-CARE CENTERS
description: DAY-CARE centers in the county, like many across the United States, are reporting difficulties in obtaining liability insurance and say they are faced with the prospect of paying dramatically higher rates. According to members of the insurance industry and day-care providers, insurers perceive the centers as carrying a higher risk in the wake of several widely publicized cases of sexual abuse at day-care centers in different parts of the nation.

title: UNTYING THE KNOT
description: While it may often be difficult to find the overriding strategic theme in a complicated game, this problem is nothing compared to the one of finding a game that exemplifies a single theme in all its purity.

title: BAKER LEADING OPEN BY SHOT
description: Judy Clark, who has not won in eight years as a professional, shot a record seven-under-par 65 today in the third round of the 40th United States Women's Open championship. She moved into a tie for second as Kathy Baker, another non-winner, took the lead.

title: LIBRARY CRIME
description: AFTER long frustration in getting some book borrowers to return what they had checked out, the Alameda County Library in California threw the book at them last year.

title: The 6th Ave. Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Racing Fans Well Behaved
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CAMP FOR DOLLS
description: ''IT started out tongue in cheek,'' said Dr. Sanford Stein, a dentist. He placed a newspaper advertisement inviting the owners of Cabbage Patch Kids to send the dolls to summer camp.

title: '83 ECONOMIC EXPANSION TOUCHED EVERY NEW YORK COUNTY
description: Economic expansion touched every county in 1983 as total income and income per resident grew faster than inflation, a sign the state economy remains healthy, according to a State Commerce Department analyst.

title: Rice's Battle
description: One week after Rick Miller tangled with California Angel fans during a game in Anaheim, another Red Sox outfielder got involved with fans in the stands in Seattle Friday night. This time it was Jim Rice, who was chasing a foul pop down the left-field line in the third inning when a fan reached out at the last moment and took the ball from Rice's glove.

title: PROTESTS GREET COLLEGE'S PLAN TO PRESENT SATIRE ABOUT NUN
description: Plans by Nassau County Community College to present a one-act comedy about a Roman Catholic nun and her parochial-school pupils have generated protests by religious and political leaders.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: 17th-Century Best Sellers What did adults and children read in New England in the 17th century? In ''Images of Childhood'' (The Main Street Press), Anita Schorsch has found an answer in five invoices addressed in 1685 to a leading Boston bookseller.

title: GANDHI CASE: RAUCUOUS START IN SIKHS' TRIAL
description: The trial of three men accused of conspiring to assassinate Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has started on a raucous note, with the chief defense lawyer maintaining that a conspiracy to kill Mrs. Gandhi may have been hatched within her own family.

title: THE MUSIC OF ELLEN ZWILICH
description: DO YOU REMEMBER those time-lapse photog-raphy films they used to show in high-school biology classes?'' Ellen Taaffe Zwilich asks.

title: Reagan Tax Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY WE CAN'T BE GOOD
description: ETHICS AND THE LIMITS OF PHILOSOPHY By Bernard Williams. 230 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: Summer Crowds In Port Jefferson
description: I would like to comment on ''Port Jefferson, Irked by Teen-Age Crowds, Asks Parking Ban'' [June 16] .

title: STUDENT PAPER SUIT UNSETTLED
description: WHEN this town's Board of Education recently adopted a new policy on school-sponsored publications, teachers and student editors regarded the event as a tentative solution to a continuing problem.

title: HOLLYWOOD AND THE NOVELIST - IT'S A FICKLE ROMANCE, AT BEST
description: Asked recently whether he writes his books with the movies in mind, Erich Segal, author of the current best-selling novel, ''The Class,'' replied that these days all commercial authors have to think in terms of Hollywood. As the au-thor of both the novel and screenplay of ''Love Story,'' Mr. Segal obviously speaks with some authority. But those who take his words too much to heart run a big risk, according to some other well-known writers who collectively have produced dozens of successful novels - only some of which have become films - as well as numerous screenplays.

title: NUCLEAR HOT SPOT IN NEW JERSEY
description: A 1960 accident involving a nuclear warhead at McGuire Air Force Base in central New Jersey set off alarms last week in the offices of state and local officials responsible for protecting the welfare of civilians. The accident occurred June 7, 1960, when the fuel tanks on a nuclear-tipped missile standing in a silo ruptured and exploded. The warhead burned but did not explode. At the time, the Department of Defense managed to contain the political fallout from the accident, telling local officials that Air Force firefighters had limited radioactive contamination to the site. (The Air Force for years denied that the warhead had been destroyed.) The area was covered with concrete.

title: RESHAPING THE FINANCIAL SYSTEM
description: THE social object of skilled investment,'' John Maynard Keynes once wrote, ''should be to defeat the dark forces of time and ignorance which envelop our future.'' But, he continued, the actual objective of the most skilled today is ''to beat the gun - to outwit the crowd, and to pass the bad, or depreciating, half crown to the other fellow.'' Keynes made this statement in the 1930's, in the immediate aftermath of the Depression.

title: ORSON WELLES: THE UNFULFILLED PROMISE
description: MOST MORNINGS, Orson Welles is awake before 6. From bed, he starts into his ritual, dialing friends and associates across the country, around the world, to discuss his current film projects. Freddy, his batman, brings in breakfast. Lately, half a grapefruit or some other healthy food. ''I hate it,'' growls Welles, whose appetites remain undiminished.

title: A POLITICAL TREK
description: FREEDOM RISING By James North Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: MacMillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: GETTING GOOD MONEY OUT OF BAD
description: Eight years ago an Iowa farmer discovered that he had dropped his wallet containing $600 while working the fields. When he could not find it he surmised that it had been eaten by one of his cows.

title: AN ART PALACE FIT FOR PICASSO
description: Step by deliberate step, a grand design is under way in the museums - old, new and imminent - of Paris. In due time the so-called ''Grand Louvre'' will involve the reinstallation of virtually everything in that gigantic institution.
