The Musee d'Orsay, now slated to open in November 1986, will constitute the national museum of 19th-century art. The Musee National d'Art Moderne in the Pompidou Center has lately been completely remodeled by the Italian architect and designer Gae Aulenti and its reinstallation will be completed in November of this year. The Musee des Arts Decoratifs has just reopened, with many a new attraction (among them, one of the most amusing shops of its kind). And on Sept. 23 the long-awaited Picasso Museum will be opened in the Hotel Sale in the Marais.

title: IN MAINE, LOBSTER ON A ROLL
description: Whenever I go back to Maine, which I do as often as I can, I stop for a lobster roll and an order of fried clams at Doug's Seafood, an unpretentious fish shop, takeout store and restaurant on the outskirts of Rockland, the fishing port and ferry terminus on Penobscot Bay. Doug's is on what is known locally as the New County Road, a singularly unattractive stretch of Route 1 that connects Rockland with Thomaston, the next town south.

title: Greece Rescued 68 From the Hijacked Jet
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Explorers
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: PURCHASE IS HOST TO LONDON SYMPHONY
description: Ordinarily, orchestras embark on international tours with a good deal of panache. Lavishly publicized, they peregrinate from capital to capital, playing the showcase repertory in which their music director specializes.

title: BRITISH TO SEEK BOATING TITLE
description: A highly prized but long-forgotten title in the boating world, the Blue Riband, is about to be revived. It involves an attempt by a British team to better the trans-Atlantic speed record set in 1952 by the ocean liner S. S. United States. The record is 3 days and 10 hours. No other motor vessel in 33 years has been able to beat the liner's time.

title: THATCHER HAS TIME, BUT NOT MUCH ELSE
description: AS recently as six months ago, they were saying at the Palace of Westminister that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was a sure thing for a third consecutive term, something none of her predecessors managed. But now the politicians and the pundits are telling everyone who will listen that she probably won't make it - even though Mrs. Thatcher need not call a general election until June 1988, and will almost certainly wait at least until autumn 1987.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CONFESSION OF A MURDERER: Told in One Night. By Joseph Roth. Translated by Desmond I. Vesey. (Overlook, $16.95.) ''I wrote it too quickly,'' Joseph Roth confessed in a letter to Stefan Zweig after finishing this novel in 1936.

title: $49,000-TO-$74,000 UNITS: PRICED FOR THE FIRST-TIME JERSEY BUYER
description: Prospective home buyers don't need to be told that there is little new housing on the market these days for less than $50,000. But the developers of a 1,086-unit project in Ocean County, N.J., will be offering condominium units with two or three bedrooms at preconstruction prices starting at $49,000 and ranging up to $74,000.

title: DANGER IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LAST night I went on one of the most harrowing excursions of my life. I was walking my dog on my street and was nearly sideswiped by cars three times in 20 minutes. As my dog and I crawled out of a bed of pachysandra after the third near-miss, I realized that 25 miles per hour is a relative thing to some people.

title: THE DOLLAR'S DIP
description: For four weeks now, foreign exchange traders have been eager sellers of dollars and buyers of British pounds and, to a lesser extent, other major European currencies. Last Friday, for example, the pound jumped 6 cents, to $1.39.

title: DECANTER TEMPEST
description: WHEN Set Momjian, a Philadelphia antiques collector, bought a broken, but repaired, early Presidential wine decanter at auction for $1,100, he was elated. The White House curator, Clement E. Conger, was irked.

title: COURT PERMITS SABBATH AREA DEFINED BY CORDS, IN QUEENS
description: New York City did not violate the Constitution when it permitted Orthodox Jews in Queens to use city property to mark off a 90-block area for religious purposes, a state judge has ruled.

title: Arguello Comeback?
description: The final decision hasn't been made, but Alexis Arguello and his agent said prospects were good that the former world featherweight, junior lightweight and lightweight champion would attempt a comeback. ''I feel he can do it, he feels he can do it,''said William Miller, Arguello's trainer-agent.

title: AUCTION SURPASSES EXPECTATIONS
description: A price of $160,000 for the unique ''Livingston Cover'' and an $80,000 bid for one of the better centered United States 1918 airmail inverts were the headline makers at a generally strong philatelic auction conducted by the Robson Lowe Stamp Department of Christie, Manson & Woods International Inc. The auction, conducted June 18 in Christie's Galleries at 502 Park Avenue in New York City, drew some of America's leading philatelists to compete for the 127 lots featured in this select sale.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: July 14, 1985 Fiction

title: BASEBALL IN A MINNEAPOLIS LIVING ROOM
description: THE first great thrill at a baseball game is usually the moment when one ascends the last ramp, the light at the end of the tunnel promising a ball field. Suddenly, at the top, the picture opens majestically; the arms of the stands, the green grass, men in white uniforms clustered in batting practice; and beyond the bleachers, a string of street lights, stars, subway trains.

title: Auto Workers Approve New Pact in Wisconsin
description: A new, three-year contract that was the final hurdle to a concession plan demanded by the American Motors Corporation has been overwhelmingly approved by members of a United Automobile Workers local.

title: The Real Danny Rose
description: As I read Phil Berger's article ''The Business of Comedy'' (June 9), it became clear that veteran manager Jack Rollins - who nursed along the struggling acts that others wouldn't touch, who maintained an unusually close relationship between performer and manager, who was abandoned by the singer who was his first successful client and who said, ''I have to work with people who fulfill me emotionally'' - was the model for client Woody Allen's wonderful character Broadway Danny Rose. DEAN SLUYTER Plainfield, N.J.

title: State Power Agency Denied U.S. License For Upstate Project
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has denied the New York Power Authority a license to build a $1 billion electricity-generating plant in Prattsville, 40 miles southwest of here.

title: TWINS' 3 HOMERS HELP TOP TIGERS
description: Roy Smalley, Mike Stenhouse and Randy Bush hit bases-empty home runs tonight to help give Minnesota a 7-0 record against Detroit this season.

title: POP MUSIC
description: The Neville Brothers are a New Orleans institution - a one-family history of Crescent City rhythm-and-blues. In 1954, while he was in high school, the pianist Art Neville and his band, the Hawketts, recorded ''Mardi Gras Mambo,'' a song still heard every year during Mardi Gras.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: 'EVITA' IS A WINNER AT NEW FAIRFIELD'S CANDLEWOOD
description: ''EVITA'' is everywhere. Or so it seems, now that the performing rights to the Tim Rice-Andrew Lloyd Webber pop opera have been released.

title: BRUSH ARTISTS ENJOYING 3 SHOWS AT ONCE
description: WHEN several members of the Oriental Brush Artists Guild convened recently, each spoke of the ancient art in almost reverential tones.

title: An 'End Run' By Businesswomen
description: We would like to underscore several important points made in ''Office Power Rare for Women'' [June 9] . Studies done by Long Island's Women on the Job confirm that the barriers for women's economic advancement are still very strong.

title: Dyes That Stain
description: Ice cream, maraschino cherries and many children's foods, drugs and cosmetics owe their bright colors to dyes made from coal tar. But 10 of these coal-tar dyes are of questionable safety, and six are now known to cause cancer in animals. Why doesn't the Food and Drug Administration stir to protect consumers from these noxious substances?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NO MAGIC BULLET: A Social History of Venereal Disease in the United States Since 1880. By Allan M. Brandt. (Oxford, $19.95.)

title: METS TOP ASTROS WITH 14 HITS, 10-1
description: The Mets turned in one of their finest offensive performances of the season tonight, pounding four Houston pitchers for 14 hits en route to a 10-1 victory before 23,234 at the Astrodome.

title: MORE CD'S ARE ON THE WAY
description: As the demand for compact disks continues to outpace production, Denon America, the United States arm of the Japanese manufacturer of audio equipment and producer of audiophile recordings, is planning to break ground this summer for a compact disk plant. It will be located in Georgia or South Carolina, according to Robert Heiblim, vice president for sales and marketing of the American operation.

title: PHYSICIAN TO WED LAUREN B. KESSLER
description: The engagement of Lauren Beth Kessler to Dr. Scott Evan Eder has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Kessler of Montvale, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Daniel LeWinter of Fort Lee, N.J., and Harold N. Eder of Upper Grandview, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: AGENCIES PRESS HIRING GOALS
description: TWO years ago, the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities cautioned the legislature and the Governor that the number of black and Hispanic people within state government had increased less than 1.5 percent since 1977.

title: A HIGHWAY IS MORE THAN A WAY TO GO
description: I RIDE Interstate 684 often. It is a wide, divided six-lane road that Governor Rockefeller's administration built to connect northern Westchester with the Hutchinson River Parkway on the south, and to provide a link with other existing highways to the north, east and west. We didn't always feel kindly toward 684. The wrangling over the proposed route of the new highway tore communities apart with great bitterness. Some expressed horror at the thought of this projected monster that would bring the noise and dirt of heavy traffic into the midst of our rural expanses of estate lands. But the Governor and the Legislature were convinced that there was a need for the highway, and it was built.

title: A CITADEL THAT BRIDGES A GORGE AND THE YEARS
description: If you never visited the Costa del Sol before its present incarnation you can still imagine it: the rocky bluffs overlooking the ocean, the scattered castle ruins, the Spanish fishermen cleaning the day's catch on the stony beach. Today, however, the horizon is speckled with silhouetted cranes, and where there are no high-rises there are billboards announcing to English-speaking investors the terms for the latest urbinizacion (planned housing development). You might be in Atlantic City or Miami Beach or any American resort paved in concrete.

title: S O
description: >The condition of boxer Willie Machado was listed as serious yesterday at New York Hospital. The 22-year-old welterweight fractured a vertebrae when he hit his neck on the lower strand of the rope in a fight against Floyd Peaver Thursday night at Felt Forum. . . . Jimmy Rogers, an assistant with the Celtics, is a leading candidate for the Nets' head coaching position, according to the Boston Herald. The newspaper reported that Rogers, who has been with the Celtics for six years, was interviewed by the Nets Friday. . . . Vince Dooley, football coach at the University of Georgia, said upon returning from a European vacation that he was still giving ''very serious'' thought to running for the United States Senate but had not yet reached a decision.

title: HOW IT WORKS
description: ALTHOUGH planning for an emergency drill for the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station is at an impasse, the Long Island Lighting Company, which owns the plant, says it is prepared for any emergency as the plant operates at low power.

title: YANKS WIN, 3-1, BEHIND NIEKRO
description: Phil Niekro, who is older than some of the former players who participated in Old-Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium yesterday, watched the guests stumble around the field for two innings, then put on a pitching display that was the rejuvenation the Yankees had anxiously awaited from him for five weeks.

title: EILEEN BURNS IS MARRIED
description: Eileen Frances Burns, a planning analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, and Robert Donald Purcell, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Society of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth L. Patton performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Selma C. Burns of Lindenhurst, L.I., and Columbus, N.C., and the late Raymond P. Burns, and Robert D. Purcell of Las Vegas, Nev., and the late Helen Purcell.

title: A SCHOLAR URGES STUDY OF TERRORISM'S CAUSES
description: Although incidents of terrorism are increasing, only a ''tiny fraction'' of the academic community is examining the causes and prevention of violence, according to a leading behavioral scientist who heads the Carnegie Corporation.

title: THE MAGINIFICANT BONE-MISERY OF THE CITY
description: THE YEAR OF THE HOT JOCK And Other Stories. By Irvin Faust. 220 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: Sri Lanka Peace Talks Adjourn to Next Month
description: Tamil separatists and Sri Lankan officials adjourned talks in Bhutan today and agreed to meet there again on Aug. 12 for further negotiations on ending the ethnic crisis in Sri Lanka.

title: Parisians
description: To The Editor: I disagree with the generalization that Parisians are ''curt and surly - ill-natured and humorless'' (''Paris as a State of Mind,'' Travel, June 9). We found none of the above among dozens of men in the street, waiters, clerks, guards and one taxi driver.

title: JOHN ANDREW NELSON TO WED JANE CHATSKY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Chatzky of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Ellen Chatzky to John Andrew Nelson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin J. Nelson, also of Scarsdale. A September wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;

IT IS NOT TOO LATE FOR SOME PLANTINGS
description: WHILE most of us have completed our seasonal planting and are ready to sit back and enjoy the fruits, vegetables and flowers of our labors, there always seems to be a spot here and there in the garden that needs a bit of color or something more to fill in.

title:
DINING OUT;

SAMPLING SUSHI ACROSS THE COUNTY
description: LONG established in Manhattan, sushi bars have found their way in respectable numbers to the county at last, and to judge by the eager crowds we faced on recent visits, these congenial eating spots have arrived not a moment too soon. A few years ago Westchester had only one sushi establishment, the now-defunct Izumi in Bronxville. But a recent flurry of openings has brought the number to 10. We are pleased to report that, at best, their sushi is of quality high enough to compare favorably with the best in Manhattan; at worst, it is tired, port-in-a-storm sushi, but not inedible.

title: THE TALKING HEADS PRODUCE AN UNABASHED POP ALBUM
description: The new Talking Heads album, ''Little Creatures'' (Sire 25305-1), ends with an a-cappella choral refrain on the words, ''We're on a road to nowhere.'' It might sound like typical Talking Heads fare: musically experimental, minimally pessimistic, poetically artsy.

title: DANCE
description: Dance has headed for the hills - or at least the woods - this week. The fine Kenneth Rinker Dance Company will start off the week at PepsiCo Summerfare with a program on Thursday and Friday that includes the world premiere of Mr. Rinker's ''Night Trippers'' and a reworking of his recent ''Manhattan,'' a dark, video-game view of modern urban life.

title: SAY HE IS 'DOING BEAUTIFULLY'
description: President Reagan underwent major abdominal surgery today for removal of a polyp, and his doctors said he had withstood the operation very well.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LAMA: A Novel of Tibet. By Fredrick R. Hyde-Chambers. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) Politics is the central character in this tale about the Chinese invasion of Tibet during the late 1950's.

title: STILL A FRIEND OF U.S., SUDANESE SAYS
description: The Sudanese leader, Gen. Abdel Rahman Siwar el-Dahab, said today that ''a closer relationship'' was developing between his country and Libya but that he saw no reason why that should weaken ties with the United States.

title: SMALL ENTREPRENEURS JOIN TO BUY A SHOPPING CENTER
description: OPTIONS have been limited for the small suburban retailer or entrepreneur who wishes to buy his business site but cannot afford to purchase his own free-standing building.

title: ROCK 'N' ROLL LONNIE MACK
description: A SET of first-class roadhouse rock turned into a celebrity event when the Rolling Stones guitarists Keith Richard and Ron Wood joined Lonnie Mack on Thursday at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue.

title: MOVING UP DOWNTOWN
description: At the other end of the Manhattan skyline another company, Dean Witter Financial Services, agreed last week to take over 24 floors in the World Trade Center currently occupied by government agencies. Many of the agencies will move to offices in the outer boroughs as part of a state plan to spur commercial development outside of Manhattan.

title: NEW ROLE FOR AN ABANDONED SCHOOL
description: THIRTY years have passed since children attended Pennybridge School in Tarrytown. But at the age of 80, the building is about to welcome a new generation of children to its high-ceilinged, old-fashioned rooms.

title: TESTING AT SHOREHAM: LOOKING FOR THE FLAWS
description: AS the Shoreham nuclear power plant enters its second week of low-power testing, new questions have arisen: Will critical safety machinery operate according to design, or will technical problems that require lengthy and expensive repairs surface in the $4.5 billion facility?

title: AT 88 PAINTER OF KINGS IS STILL BUSY
description: When Michael Alexander Werboff sits down in his rent-stabilized apartment in upper Manhattan, kings, queens and maharajahs surround him.

title: ELIZABETH CLAYTON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Pittsford, N.Y., yesterday Elizabeth Ann Clayton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Clayton of Fairport, N.Y., was married to Geoffrey G. Towell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Gilmer Towell of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Gary C. Schindler performed the ceremony.

title: 19 Arrested During Protest Over New N.Y.U. Dormitory
description: Nineteen demonstrators were arrested and charged with trespassing yesterday at a rally to protest the construction of a New York University dormitory.

title: FRESH AIR FUND PROVIDES 2 WEEKS OF FUN AT SHORE
description: From the town beach here, Port Washington's stately homes protrude from the trees on the left, Mamaroneck sits across Long Island Sound in Westchester County and sailboats, their masts bare like trees in winter, rock gently in the water to the right.

title: STARS' KUGLER SAVORS TITLE GAME
description: The United States Football League's showcase contest tonight at Giants Stadium may not be the Super Bowl, but it is a championship game and that is good enough for Pete Kugler.

title: DESSERTS MADE FROM THE FRESH BERRIES OF SUMMER
description: FRESH berries are one of the great treats of summer. In England when I was a child, we used to spend many happy hours wandering along the hedgerwos or in the strawberry patches at the bottom of the garden, armed with a white enamel pail. Until we were offered money for our berries - a penny a cupful - the pail had not chance of reaching anywhere near its capacity.

title: BEL CANTO - UNDEFINABLE BUT DURABLE
description: What exactly do we mean by bel canto? The question arises in light of the New York City Opera's Bel Canto Festival, as the company is calling a group of five early 19th-century works on the current summer schedule. The term is bandied about confidently by singers, voice teachers and opera fanciers, though it would be difficult to find two people agreeing on exactly what they mean by the words. Those who have studied the subject most closely approach it skittishly, and with good reason. Cynics among the cognoscenti even resort to dismissive puns such as ''can't bellow'' or ''can belto.''

title:
INVESTING;

THE EXPERTS LOOK AT THE 'ROARING 80'S'
description: MAYBE it is just the summer heat. But in recent weeks more and more investment professionals across the country have been comparing the present economic and financial environment to that of the 1920's. In fact, the topic is starting to dominate discussions whenever Wall Street executives meet.

title: Talking: Basements;   Averting Leakage Problems
description: FEW topics depress suburban homeowners more than horror tales of leaky basements. Sometimes, a leak merely means a puddle or two after a rainstorm, or walls damp to the touch. But in other homes, it means an inch or more of water in the basement following a heavy rainfall.

title: OFFICERS FACE PROTESTANT IRE IN ULSTER CITY
description: In a soft rain, about 200 marchers from the Royal Black Perceptory, a Protestant organization, taunted and threatened police officers guarding a Roman Catholic neighborhood today but ultimately took their traditional Orange Day parade on a route that avoided the Catholics.

title: DIARIES' EPILGUE
description: A Hamburg court judge closed the book last week on the case of the bogus ''Hitler diaries.'' Judge Hans-Ulrich Schroeder found Gerd Heidemann (top), a former reporter for the West German magazine Stern, and Konrad Kujau, a dealer in Nazi memorabilia, guilty of fraud and forgery. Mr. Kujau, who confessed that he had forged the documents but said he had been merely an accessory to a larger swindle by Stern, was sentenced to 4 1/2 years in prison. Mr. Heidemann, who said he had negotiated in good faith for the magazine, received a sentence of four years and eight months.

title: ELISABETH C. ERK IS WED
description: Elisabeth Carlene Erk, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Frank C. Erk of Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark David Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Smith of Lloyd Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Ronald Patterson, pastor of the Mount Sinai (L.I.) Congregational Church, performed the ceremony at the Smith home. The bride's father is a professor of biochemistry at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The bridegroom's father is president of the James A. Smith Contracting Corporation in Huntington Station, L.I.

title: Taverns Should Serve Food
description: Manipulating the interaction of two significant facts could be helpful in the war against drunken driving. The first is that most drunken driving occurs late at night.

title: A CHANGING OF THE GUARD
description: When Army Gen. John W. Vessey Jr.'s tour as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff ended in June next year, according to betting around the Pentagon not too many months ago, the job most likely would fall to Adm. James D. Watkins, the chief of naval operations.

title: Durians
description: To the Editor: The article about Asian fruit (''A Cornucopia of Asian Fruit'' by Barbara Crossette, Travel, May 5) was delightful.

title: Pilot Killed as 2 Jets Collide at Air Show
description: One pilot was killed and one parachuted to safety when two jets in the Navy Blue Angels precision flying team collided in midair this afternoon during an air show at the Niagara Falls Air Force Base, officials said.

title: A REBEL NAMED 'GOD'S BLESSING' DIES
description: His name was Allah Berdi. Freely translated, it means ''God's blessing.''

title: CABARET: 'NEXT, PLEASE!'
description: THE notion that being on unemployment is akin to membership in a private club is the premise behind the cabaret revue ''Next, Please!'' In this snappy, barebones production that closed last night at the Westbank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street, six up-and-coming actor-singers - Stuart Bloom, Michael Brian, Alison Fraser, Peter Herber, Mary Testa and Jennifer Leigh Warren - portrayed a cross-section of genteel New York types down on their luck.

title: PUREX PACT: A TURNING POINT?
description: ''Eventually it may be found that the maximum population that can live on the Island will be determined by the amount of water available, and to make the limit as high as possible may require centralized and unified control and development; all wells in the right places and none in the wrong places.'' - Russel Suter Executive Engineer State of New York Water Power and Control Commission March 15, 1945 THE recent settlement of a four-year dispute over waste at the Purex site at Mitchel Field has focused new attention on the problem of contaminated areas and how to handle them. The Purex site has been cited by county officials as an example of what can happen to water sources in industrial areas throughout Long Island.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ''FROM the surface,'' writes Paul C. Dritsas, a marsh is ''silent, motionless, except for the movement of the water and the swaying of the grasses in the wind.'' Just below the surface, he goes on, the marsh is ''alive and well and doing what it has been for centuries.''

title: IN THE SEARCH FOR PROGRAMMING, NO HOLDS ARE BARRED
description: It seems a safe bet that anyone who complains of there being only 24 hours in a day has never worked as a programmer for a cable service.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Fly/Ride Europe 1985 By Ed Perkins and the editors of Consumer Reports Books. 214 pages. Consumer Reports Books. Paperback. $11.95. Anyone going to Europe - whether for the first time or the hundredth -can benefit greatly from this authoritative book, which exhaustively reviews all the transportation options to be considered when planning your trip as well as once you get there. It leads you clearly through such normally confusing subjects as bulk fares on international airlines, the legality of different types of discount air tickets and how to choose among the many intra-European rail, ferry and rental-car options. The easy-to-digest narrative is abundantly embellished with tables, listings and boldface boxes that contain blunt warnings and advice on how to cope with common pitfalls.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Taking My Turn Lyrics by Will Holt and music by Gary William Friedman Pacific Arts Video Records 87 minutes. $39.95 ''A people that turns its face on the elderly is afraid to face itself,'' says one of the characters in ''Taking My Turn,'' a musical whose objective is to face the fact of aging head on.

title: MARY F. DETMER TO MARRY SEPT. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Joseph Detmer of Glen Ellyn, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Florence Detmer, to Norwick Beauford Houston Goodspeed, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norwick Royall Givens Goodspeed of Fairfield, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 7.

title: 40 Years After the Birth Of the Atomic Age
description: Forty years ago Tuesday, on a rain-soaked New Mexico dawn, the atomic age was born in fury.

title: PINNING HOPES ON THE PESO
description: Every morning Larry Norton travels downtown to his men's clothing store on Convent Street, just steps from the bridge that daily brings his customers over the Rio Grande from Mexico. On the way, he checks what the speculators are charging to change pesos into dollars and then sets a rate, usually a little better than the street rate as an inducement to his customers. It is a ritual for thousands of American merchants along the 1,952-mile Mexican-American border. Laredo may be in Texas, but it lives and dies with Mexico.

title: PESTICIDES REPORTED MAKING MORE FARM WORKERS ILL
description: A growing number of farm workers are suffering illness from pesticides because laws to protect them are weak and poorly enforced, according to a report released today by the World Resources Institute.

title: JAZZ: LARRY VUCKOVICH
description: LARRY VUCKOVICH, a jazz pianist whose career has developed for the past 25 years on the West Coast, moved to the East Coast five months ago, bringing with him an outlook and a collection of influences that set him apart from most pianists who are heard regularly in New York.

title: ON NOT PLAYING BALL IN TEXAS
description: When the Texas State Board of Education instituted a rule in January that barred any student with a failing grade from taking part in out-of-class activities such as football, it set off protests from students and parents. A group of them sued and a Houston district judge declared the rule unconstitutional.

title: SOME ACTION AT LAST ON THE MISSING IN VIETNAM
description: THERE was optimism last week among many Government officials - and among surviving family members - that the mystery of 2,464 Americans still unaccounted for after the war in Indochina may be closer to resolution.

title: CAULKING SOME UNFAMILIAR PLACES
description: A ROUND every home are gaps and open joints where water, insects and cold air can enter. That's why it is important to use caulking compound. Although most homeowners seem to think that caulking is required only around window frames and door frames - some professional painters seem to think so, too -there are many other places where it should be used.

title: Treating Brain Disorders
description: The article by the Cherrys was a clear exposition of the scientific advances in diagnosing and treating disorders of the brain. The marriage between technology and medicine seemed made in heaven.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

AROUND THE LUNCH TABLE
description: FIRST of all, you don't go out to lunch, you ''do'' lunch.

title: SALLIE J. CHRISTIAN TO MARRY AUG. 17
description: Sallie Jean Christian, a staff assistant at the White House visitors' office, and United States Representative Charles Pashayan Jr., Republican of California, plan to be married Aug. 17.

title: RAWLEY COOPER IS WED TO CATHY D. SILVERSTEIN
description: Cathy Dianne Silverstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Silverstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Rawley Aldrich Cooper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. T. Cooper of Los Angeles. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel officiated at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title: 23 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: FOR LAWYERS, RHODE ISLAND TURNS TO OTHER STATES
description: When the State of Rhode Island tried Claus von Bulow this spring on charges of attempting to murder his wife, it used two prosecutors who graduated from the Suffolk University Law School in Boston.

title: MAYOR HELPS DELAWARE TOWN SHED RACIST IMAGE
description: In 1968 a series of racial disturbances cast a pall over the towering church spires and graceful Victiorian houses of this small town.

title: NEW BUS PACT AIDS PRIVATE CARRIERS
description: A HISTORIC agreement between NJ Transit and the state's privately owned bus companies appears to have resolved, at least for now, a lingering conflict between them.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Europe's Wonderful Little Hotels and Inns #738 pages. Congdon & Weed. Paperback. $16.95. Traveling, sometimes even armchair traveling, can call for an adventurous spirit, a devil-may-care attitude. Such qualities are requisite when armchair occupants are guided by the newest edition of ''Europe's Wonderful Little Hotels and Inns.''

title:
ART;

PHOTOGRAPHS THAT ENCOMPASS MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: THE personal vision that elvates certain photographs to the level of fine art is the subject of ''Image, Insight,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum. Each of the 13 photographers represented uses the camera to manupulate rather than record experience, pushing the viewer's perception beyond the superficial and into the realm of subjective interpretation.

title: ON THE TRACK OF THE COMPTOSAUR
description: A rich lode of dinosaur bones and other fossils of creatures that lived more than 100 million years ago has been uncovered in Texas, it was reported last week. The fossils, some of them apparently previously unknown species, were found last month in gullies 75 miles southwest of Forth Worth, by a geology student at Tarleton State University in Stephenville, Tex.

title: GLIMPSES OF LIFE BEHIND ETON'S WALLS
description: Eton College is arguably the most famous public (Americans: read private) school in the world. It has always been regarded as an exclusive enclave for Britain's aristocracy, and during the last 545 years it has educated many of their most illustrious sons.

title: CABLE TV
description: A colorful mix of background locales permeates the cable week's lineup of choice movies, starting with ''Padre Padrone'' (1977), a vivid drama of a Sardinian shepherd - Sunday on Bravo at 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. ''Cuba'' (1979) brims with color, as Sean Connery, Brooke Adams and a fine supporting cast throng a churning adventure of late-Batista Havana - Monday at 12:45 A.M. on Cinemax. A canvas of early 19th-century England gleams elegantly in ''The Draughtman's Contract'' (1982), a brilliantly eccentric tale of greed and murder - Wednesday at 1 P.M. on Bravo.

title: ''TAMING THE SHREW''
description: 'Taming of the Shrew'

title: THE DEFT GEOMETRY OF LOG-CABIN QUILTS
description: There are quilts, and there are quilts. The log-cabin quilt, to the collector, is of special interest. As with all quilts, it takes its name from the individual block that forms the basis of the design. In this case, the reference is not to an image of a log cabin but rather to the manner in which the design is created: thin strips of cloth are assembled in much the same way logs are layered in the building of a cabin. Whereas other quilts - both American and European - hark to ancient tile patterns (stars, flowers and the like), the log-cabin quilt is strictly an American invention.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Children's Songs and Stories With the Muppets Playhouse Video 56 minutes. $59.98 There's no dross in this collection of golden television moments, highlights of the long-running ''Muppet Show,'' chosen specially for children.

title: REFUSENIKS AND OTHER MINORITIES
description: SOVIET DISSENT Contemporary Movements for National, Religious, and Human Rights. By Ludmilla Alexeyeva. Translated by Carol Pearce and John Glad. Illustrated. 521 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $35.

title: MISS BRANCH TO MARRY PAUL MAS IN SEPTEMBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Callcote Branch of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Branch to Paul John Mas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mas of East Hanover, N.J. The wedding is planned for September.

title: THE BIG DEAL AT COLUMBUS CIRCLE
description: A partnership headed by Morton B. Zuckerman, the developer and publisher, last week won the bidding to buy the New York Coliseum and the four acres on which it sits from the city and a branch of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The group, Boston Properties, plans to erect two towers on the site at Columbus Circle to house offices, a hotel, condominium apartments and retail space.

title: PEEK AT FUTURE IN BIRDSBORO, PA.
description: TWENTY-EIGHT employees of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which has eliminated 38,000 jobs in the last five years, visited Birdsboro, Pa., southeast of Reading, the other day to take a peek at the future.

title: KEEPING THE CANNON ROLLING
description: FORMS OF ATTENTION By Frank Kermode. 93 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $9.95.

title: NO FISHING
description: FISHING off bridges, a pastoral practice in many communities, was condemned last year by the City Council Committee on Public Safety as a potential menace in New York.

title: SINGING TO CHILDREN'S FEELINGS
description: ''DEALING with emotions is a skill that can be taught,'' said Jane Murphy of Port Washington, ''and children from my experience really want to learn.''

title: ANTIQUE FIRE EQUIPMENT SEEKS A PERMANENT HOME
description: GEORGE WINZLER tied a red scarf around the collar of his starched white shirt and stood with his wife, Ethel, who wore a ruffled white blouse and a long, white apron tied over her billowing red and white checkered skirt. Mrs. Winzler tucked her feet, on which were white canvas running shoes, out of sight.

title: MILITARY AND CIVILIAN DOCTORS JOIN MEDICAL TEAM
description: President Reagan's surgery today was performed at one of the most modern military hospitals in the country, but the White House reached beyond the hospital staff to complete the surgical team.

title: FINDING A WATERY LINE WITH A MAP AND A LAW
description: Where does Manhattan end and Queens begin? The question is of more than mere cartographical interest to Leonid Tsygan and the City of New York.

title: MUSIC: THE CITY OPERA IN 'CARMEN'
description: ONE of the problems of Regieoper - opera in which the dominant interpretive presence is that of the stage director - is that it doesn't work well in repertory houses, which must revive major operas with changing casts and without intensive rehearsal periods. The City Opera's Frank Corsaro ''Carmen,'' which reappeared Friday, is only a year old, and its special protagonist, Victoria Vergara, is still in place, but already it has faded and blurred.

title: HOLDEN CAULFIELD'S KID SISTER GETS PREGNANT
description: THE BOOK OF PHOEBE By Mary-Ann Tirone Smith. 280 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95.

title: INTEGRATED SOFTWARE FOR THE THIN MAN
description: IN the battle for the Macintosh's mind raging among the purveyors of integrated software, Ensemble may have been first, but not, it turns out, the program with the most. Jazz, a new competitor from the Lotus Development Corporation, has more features, but it lacks a macro facility, which allows users to accomplish with one or two keystrokes what normally would require a dozen. Considering that Lotus's research indicates that most users of its best-selling 1-2-3 program take advantage of this feature, the omission is amazing. There is also Excel, from the Microsoft Corporation, which hopes to become the favorite integrated package for the Mac - once it is released.

title: KUWAITI ABDUCTED ON BEIRUT STREET
description: The Kuwaiti Embassy's press attache has been kidnapped, making him the 14th foreigner seized or missing in West Beirut in the last 16 months, the police said today.

title: 'L.' IS FOR LIMBO
description: IN the countdown to the United States Football League's third championship game tonight, the issue isn't what's the point spread: It's what's the point?

title: OLD PRINTING TECHNIQUES CREATE A NEW LOOK FOR PHOTOGRPAHS
description: AS cameras and films and processing techniques become ever faster and automatic, Robert Gumpper's approach to photography seems more and more anachronistic.

title: LOOKING FOR LAUGHS - AN UNREQUITED SUMMER PASTIME
description: Perhaps it is nothing more than the summer doldrums, but it seems more and more difficult to figure out what will get a laugh these days.

title: VOWS ARE EXCHANGED BY TICA FRECH AND DR. C. C. YOUNG, OPTHAMOLOGIST
description: The marriage of Patricia Powers Frech, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans A. Frech of New York, to Dr. Charles Chesley Young, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris N. Young of New York, took place yesterday in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony.

title: Good Luck to the Gipper
description: The capital is concerned now primarily about the health of the President. And so far, the news is reassuring.

title: SENTENCING OF SETTLERS DIVIDES ISRAEL
description: Soon after a three-judge court in Jerusalem convicted 15 Jewish settlers last week of crimes of violence against Arabs, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other influential Israelis said they should be pardoned. Their supporters cited the recent exchange of 1,150 Arab prisoners, including terrorists, for three Israeli soldiers held in Syria.

title: Gorbachev on Vacation
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, left Moscow today on vacation, the press agency Tass said. It did not say how long he would be gone or where he would spend his vacation, but Kremlin leaders traditionally have a two-month summer break in the Crimea.

title: Tokyo
description: To the Editor: I found Alan Davidson's article, ''Tokyo's Hot New Beverage? Coffee'' (Travel, June 2), not only replete with fascinating details, but also provocative.

title: Satisfaction in the Academic Thicket (Thorns Notwithstanding)
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: V.A.T. REFUNDS - A GUIDE FOR THE PERPLEXED
description: When the dollar is strong, little can pale Europe's attraction for American shoppers. They often learn, however, that they are paying considerably more than they ought to because of a frequently tenacious irritant called the Value Added Tax, or V.A.T. Theoretically, the tax should in most cases be refunded on purchases they take home, but it is often difficult to collect.

title: Thieves Bind Woman In $180,000 Robbery
description: Two men broke into a Long Island home early today, bound and gagged a 67-year-old woman and fled with cash and jewelry valued at $180,000, the police said.

title: Reagan's Surgeons Remove Growth From His Intestine; Say He Is 'Doing Beautifully'
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  President Reagan underwent major abdominal surgery today for removal of a polyp, and his doctors said he had withstood the operation very well.

title: BEGUILING VIETNAMESE IN WESTPORT
description: REMEMBERING the early days of the Vietnamese restaurant, Chez Bach, in its original location in Branford, and then visiting its new Westport spot is e like night and day. What was tentative five years ago has now become authoritative, and what seemed improvised is now totally professional.

title: TWO NEW FESTIVALS OPEN IN COUNTY
description: TWO new summer festivals have arrived in the county: a Sunday afternoon series bringing the classics, jazz and even Broadway show tunes to New Rochelle's Thornton-Donovan School and a chamber cycle offering new musical vistas at the Martha Guinsberg Pavilion in Crompond.

title: Brother Had Same Surgery
description: President Reagan's older brother, Neil Reagan, underwent the same type of intestinal surgery as the President, on July 3, his wife said today.

title: SALVADOR ARMY REPORTS NO RISE IN CASUALTIES
description: Salvadoran Army troops suffered roughly the same level of combat casualties in the last year as they did the year before, even as the army sharply increased its offensive operations against leftist rebels, according to the country's Defense Minister.

title: Reagan Vows to Act On Antimissile Plan
description: President Reagan today said that Americans would be ''the greatest fools on earth'' not to go ahead with research on a high-technology missile defense, and he said he would assert the country's right to do so when he meets with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in November.

title: Queens Man, 65, Is Arrested In Mercy-Killing of Ailing Wife
description: A 65-year-old Queens man told the police yesterday that he had suffocated his wife, who was suffering from lung cancer, after she begged him to kill her, the police said.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I have purchased a first-class Eurailpass and plan to travel from Paris to Viareggio, Italy, via Lyons, Turin and Genoa. I am told that seats can be reserved in this country only from Paris to Lyons and the rest must be reserved when I get to Paris. Is this true? - A. R., Queens. Answer: It sounds as if your travel agent may be reluctant to make the reservations. The secretary of the Eurailpass Committee in New York, Dag Scher, says that seat reservations for the journey can be made from this country. He advises a traveler facing this problem to get in touch with the railroad offfice that sold the Eurailpass and ask it to book the seats. Although a Eurailpass permits unlimited train travel in 16 countries, there are only four issuing offices for the passes in this country -the offices of the French, West German, Italian and Swiss railroads. The name of the railroad that sells a pass is stamped on the back of it. Normally it takes about two weeks to confirm reservations on a European train, says Mr. Scher, but on some popular routes - Paris-Lyons, for example - they can sometimes be arranged in 48 hours.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Shallowbrook, Somers, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 749-0749. Today - Seaside Classic, Old Field, L.I. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (516) 725-1953. Today - Gardnertown Farm, Newburgh, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (914) 564-6658.

title: P.L.O. SAID TO OFFER LIST OF PALESTINIANS FOR TALKS WITH U.S.
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has submitted to Jordan a list of 10 to 15 Palestinians who have the P.L.O.'s approval to take part in talks with the United States about ending the Arab-Israeli conflict, well-placed Palestinian and other sources said today.

title: Doctors' Income
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADCAST TV
description: With ''Diva'' (1981) and ''White Heat'' (1949) showing together on Saturday night, television movie buffs face a tough choice.

title: IF HISTORY REPEATS, TIGERS WON'T
description: RECENT history reveals these facts: No champion of either National League division or the American League West has repeated since 1978 and no American League East champion has repeated since the Yankees did in 1981. Of the 18 division winners since those respective repeat seasons, excluding the strike season of 1981, only two teams were in first place at the All-Star Game break the following season, the Chicago White Sox last season and the Atlanta Braves in 1983. The San Diego Padres, who had been in first place since May 7, could be the third of 22 division winners to achieve that status, but they slipped into second place in the National League West last night, half a game behind the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption last Sunday in Connecticut Weekly incorrectly identified Sharna Scofield. She is the owner and president of Four Seasons International Bed and Breakfast of West Simsbury, a reservation service.

title: Garden Design;   PAINTING THE LILLY
description: THE DAY LILIES THAT SURround a field of winter rye on a picturesque sliver of Monmouth County, N.J., farmland are in peak bloom this weekend. For the gardener, Betty Harwood, this means a chance to survey the 365 varieties that she has lovingly planted over the last 30 years.

title: ADMINISTRATION DEBATES ATTITUDES TOWARD SYRIA
description: Reagan Administration officials say that as long as Syria may be helpful in gaining the return of seven Americans still missing in Lebanon, President Reagan is ready to be restrained toward the Damascus Government.

title: No Headline
description: Renewals for the Elderly Question: I have a senior-citizen rent-increase exemption. The lease on my rent-stabilized apartment expires Dec. 1. Is my landlord required to offer me a new lease at my present rent or must I reapply to the tax-abatement program if he offers me one at the new rent-guideline rate? . . . E.M.L., Manhattan Answer: When you sign the new lease, send a copy to the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption Unit at 17 John Street, 4th floor, New York, N.Y. 10038. You will receive a new order exempting you from the amount of the increase. Your landlord will receive a tax-abatement certificate equivalent to the increase.

title: The Politics of the Death Penalty in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Herzog Pact Extended
description: The St. Louis Cardinals yesterday rewarded Manager Whitey Herzog for the club's first-place standing in the National League East. extending his contract through the 1988 season.

title: STANDS AND PHONE LINES JAMMED FOR AID CONCERT
description: Raising her voice above the cheers of thousands of spectators, Joan Baez offered a tender rendition of ''Amazing Grace'' to open the Philadelphia portion of a trans-Atlantic concert to aid famine victims in Africa.

title: FROM THE GALLEY
description: ALONG THE EASTERN SHORE of Bucks Harbor, dark points of spruce and hemlock are silhouetted against the apricot flush of dawn. The silky surface of the water, reflecting the shoreline, seems to sigh a little with the slackening tide. A loon calls softly, and the fragrance of wood smoke rises from the Charlie Noble, as the smokestack is called, over the Timberwind's galley where Naomi Kokonnen is preparing another wonderful breakfast: Shall it be French toast or blueberry pancakes? Shirred eggs or apricot muffins? Last night, I swore I could not eat another mouthful -ever. But such boastful claims evaporate in the appetite-building atmosphere of dawn on a sailboat off the coast of Maine.

title: JACQUELINE DANIELLE GELLES ENGAGED TO DEAN K. CUTLER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John S. Gelles of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Jacqueline Danielle Gelles to Dean Kent Cutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin G. Cutler, also of Scarsdale.

title: EMDEE SCHAEFER PLANS WEDDING FOR SEPTEMBER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Jay Schaefer 3d of Stonington, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Edmee Moran Schaefer to Charles Justin Zahringer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Zahringer Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is to be in September.

title: WHAT SUMMER PEOPLE DO
description: SUMMER people follow the ancient migratory route of their ancestors.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FEAR SPY RING IN NAVY PIERCED RADIO LINK
description: Senior intelligence officials and Congressional sources say they believe a purported Navy spy ring gave the Soviet Union years of access to the Navy's satellite communications network, which since the mid-1970's has transmitted virtually all of the service's sensitive messages.

title: HEATHER AND MICHELE CUSACK MARRIED IN A DOUBLE CEREMONY ON LONG ISLAND
description: The Cutchogue (L.I.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the weddings of Heather Kathryn Cusack to Kim Walfredo Tetrault and of her sister, Michele Cusack, to Robert Kent Pollak. The Rev. George Borthwick performed the double ceremony.

title: Commander of Soviet Forces In East Germany Leaves Post
description: The commander of Soviet troops in East Germany, Gen. Mikhail M. Zaitsev, is leaving that job, the East German press agency reported today.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

'I LIKE IT IN NEW JERSEY BECAUSE...'
description: WE ALL know that New Jersey is a wonderful place in which to live and work, but I have some special reasons for liking it. I thought I'd share them with you.

title: SMELTER ARSENIC'S EFFECTS ON MONTANA CHILDREN IS UNDER STUDY
description: Arsenic left in the soil by a copper smelter may pose a cancer threat to children here, according to a study by the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: A SON LEARNS HIS FATHER'S GAME
description: McRAE and Son. The sound has a nice ring to Brian McRae, the son.

title: BEFORE THE TOURISTS
description: VOICES OF THE OLD SEA By Norman Lewis. 202 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: NIMBLE VOICES OF AUTHORS REINFORCE THEIR WRITINGS
description: The voices of celebrated authors, still very much with us, can be heard in a spate of recent spoken-word releases. There are plenty of writers, to be sure, who should be read and not heard, but most of the men and women who braved the microphone for these efforts reveal nimble tongues as well as a way with words, and their distinctive voices actually reinforce the strength of their individual styles.

title: Pakistanis Prohibit Meetings In a Region of Shiite Unrest
description: After incidents of Shiite unrest, the authorities in Quetta in western Pakistan have banned meetings of more than four people and have ordered residents to stop carrying arms.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WHIMSY IN YONKERS The whimsy of Alexander Calder will permeate the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers Wednesday through Sept. 15 in an exhibition of the artist's creatures. They include insects, cats, dogs, kangaroos, elephants and fish, for instance, as well as ''watchama-Calders'' - amalgamations of animals with beaks and trunks and whatever else struck his fancy.

title: VIENNA WRY
description: IN THESE GREAT TIMES A Karl Kraus Reader. Edited by Harry Zohn. Translations by Joseph Fabry, Max Knight, Karl F. Ross and Harry Zohn. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Carcanet Press/Distributed by Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: SOMETHING IS WRONG IF THINGS GO RIGHT
description: IT was one of those weeks when everything went right, and that was not what I had in mind at all. Before, everything had been going wrong, and I had called upon the proper authorities to put things right. No sooner had the healers made their appearance when everything ran as smoothly as though they had just come out of the showroom or were in dress rehearsal for a television commercial.

title: On Language;   A FEAR OF METAPHORS
description: THE AMERICAN LAN-guage, long praised for its vigor, is now tired and feeble. Old energies of metaphor and image depart from educated speech and the language of editorial writers - to endure on the sports page or in street talk. Most of us talk and write so faintly, with such passivity, that our guiding spirit seems to be the stylist who writes directions on medicine bottles.

title: THE SENATE VOTES TO EASE GUN CONTROL
description: There was another of those intense debates that gun-control legislation almost always provokes on Capitol Hill last week, but this time the result was new. After years of unsuccessful lobbying by the National Rifle Association, the Senate voted 79 to 15 to substantially overhaul -and liberalize - the 1968 Gun Control Law. The vote also reflected public fears about personal safety and a perception of rising crime rates.

title: CONSUMER RATES
ART FOR NEW HAVEN'S NEIGHBORHOODS
description: A 25-FOOT-HIGH banner depicting scenes from shops in the area, was recently unfurled at a ceremony on Upper State Street in New Haven.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: KEYWORDS: A Vocabulary of Culture and Society, by Raymond Williams. (Oxford, $8.95.) The author believes his 131 key words disclose social and cultural history in the way they have come to be used. In 1976 Denis Donoghue, reviewing an earlier edition of the book, wrote here that he was troubled because the chosen words ''embody social and political attitudes, patterns and prejudices of conduct at large. Private feeling is mostly ignored.'' But he termed ''splendid'' the ''local insights,'' especially when Mr. Williams ''finds usage crossing the border between specific recognition and abstract relationship,'' as illustrated by the change from ''customer'' to ''consumer.'' THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) The witches are three divorced, middle-class, otherwise ordinary women in a small town, Eastwick, R.I., the site of their sorcery. Margaret Atwood observed last year in The Book Review that the witches may be products of ''Eastwick's -read America's - own fantasy life,'' She applauded ''the skill and inventiveness of the writing, the accuracy of the detail, the sheer energy of the witches and, above all, the practicality of the charms.'' PICASSO: The Complete Writings, by Gertrude Stein. (Beacon, $7.95.) Gertrude Stein met the 24-year-old artist when she was 31. Their friendship lasted 41 years. ''Picasso,'' originally published as ''Gertrude Stein on Picasso,'' is a documentary record of that relationship. Included are her 1938 essay on the painter and notes from unpublished notebooks. James R. Mellow wrote here that the essay, while not the most informative work on Picasso, is ''easily the most ingratiating: warm, discursive, full of vivid anecdotes, charming insights and . . . breathtaking generalizations.''

title: Best Travel Book
description: To the Editor:

title: BREKING WITH OPEC
description: In a world glutted with oil, it began to look last week like every producer for itself. Mexico, exasperated with the lack of cohesion among the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, announced price reductions for its crude and Saudi Arabia was reportedly threatening to create havoc by doubling its production.

title: VICTIM OR VICTOR?
description: CORRIGAN By Caroline Blackwood. 279 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: July 14, 1985 Fiction

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'VIENNESE GEMS'

title: STATE SEEKS WIDER ROLE ON COASTAL HOUSING
description: LEGISLATORS and officials of the state's Department of Environmental Protection have been meeting in recent weeks with building interests and environmentalists to plan major revisions to the laws and policies that control coastal development.

title: GOLDEN REWARDS OF TEACHING
description: It ws an enriching experience to read '' A Teacher Rejoices in His Career'' by Gordon Baptiste (Opinion Page, June 23). I am now finshing my third year of teaching math in a New York City junior high school.

title: 'Big Daddy' Back in Cockpit
description: Don (Big Daddy) Garlits is slim, fit and full of energy at the age of 53. A. J. Foyt and Richard Petty, Garlits's counterparts in Indy Car and stock-car racing, are finding it hard getting into the winner's circle these days. But after four years of virtual retirement, the biggest name in the history of drag racing is back - and winning. Today Garlits is going for one of the few races that have eluded him in his 30 years as a professional drag racer, the Budweiser Summernationals, in Old Bridge, N.J.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: GEOFFREY S. PERSELAY characterizes his new job as acting commissioner of the state's Department of Human Services as ''like the head of a big family.''

title: THE IN-HOUSE AIR POLLUTION THREAT
description: Those warnings to remain indoors on smoggy summer days might not always be such great advice. A fragmentary but growing body of evidence being collected by Government agencies, scientists and private industry indicates that indoor air pollution can often be as dangerous to health as polluted outdoor air -and sometimes more so. Legislation has been introduced in both the House and the Senate to provide money for a broad research program into the causes and cures of indoor pollution.

title: SUDAN AND LIBYA TIE A KNOT
description: The United States and Egypt had another reason last week to regret the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry in the Sudan in April.The new Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Osman Abdallah Mohamed, perhaps on his own initiative, signed a military pact with Libya, in an apparent move away from the close ties the Sudan had maintained with Washington and Cairo.

title: Hyde Collection
description: To the Editor: William Howarth's article ''Exploring the Wild Adirondacks'' (Travel, June 16) omitted one attraction that seasoned travelers to our region should not miss: the Hyde Collection.

title: ON MADRID'S STRAWBERRY TRAIN
description: In the 19th century, residents of Madrid would take the train on summer weekends to the town of Aranjuez to sample its sights and tastes, its strawberries in particular. Now, what came to be known as the Strawberry Train has undergone a nostalgic revival and this summer it is running weekends to mid-September along the same track as the original. As well as passengers it also transports tasty strawberries and tender asparagus to the markets of Madrid, 27 miles to the north.

title: AMENDMENT ON TRANSFER OF POWERS
description: Following is the text of the 25th Amendment to the Constitution:

title:
GARDENING;

IT IS NOT TOO LATE FOR SOME PLANTINGS
description: WHILE most of us have completed our seasonal planting and are ready to sit back and enjoy the fruits, vegetables and flowers of our labors, there always seems to be a spot here and there in the garden that needs a bit of color or something more to fill in.

title: A PLACE FOR PIGS
description: IT'S not that Suffold County legislator Joseph Rizzo doesn't like baby pigs.

title: GIANTS CAMP OPENS TODAY
description: Just when you thought professional football was ending, professional football is beginning.

title: PRUDENT MEDICAL PRACTICE
description: In removing a large polyp this afternoon from President Reagan's colon, Dr. Dale Oller and his team of surgeons did not know if it was malignant or benign, and so they acted according to prudent medical practice and proceeded as if the polyp was a cancer.

title: TWO NEW APPROACHES TO OLD LOUDSPEAKER PROBLEMS
description: Reinventing the wheel has become a metaphor for redundancy. Reinventing the loudspeaker, by contrast, occasionally leads to valid innovation.

title: VALERIE SOTER TO MARRY WALTER CLIFTON VICK JR.
description: Valerie Margaret Soter and Walter Clifton Vick Jr., who graduated in May from the Southern Methodist University Law School, plan to be married Aug. 17. The future bride is a daughter of William J. Soter of New York and Margaret Soter of Scarsdale, N.Y., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vick of Gulfport, Miss.

title: MALPRACTICE: DOCTORS BEGIN OWN INSURANCE
description: CONNECTICUT doctors have started their own insurance company, in hopes of reversing the rise in malpractice insurance costs.

title: Teaching School Is Worth It
description: As a third-year teacher in a private school in Fairfield County, ''Good Reasons to Be a Teacher'' [June 16] really hit home! Not unlike the son of the author, I vowed not to ''sell out,'' and I, too, managed only to live from paycheck to paycheck until a friend suggested that my idealistic goals for intellectual fulfillment and humanitarian work might best be realized in a classroom.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

THE FAMILY'S ROLE IN MENTAL ILLNESS
description: MENTAL illness, a major problem facing one of every four families in New Jersey, is compounded by the changes that have occurred in the mental-health system since 1965.

title: COMPOSERS WHO CHAMPIONED ACCESSIBILITY
description: Much ado has been made about a new Romanticism and a resurgence of tonal techniques in contemporary music. Audiences, alienated by years of highly rationalized serialism and atonality, have been quick to perceive this return to Romanticism as a heartening sign of a new accessibility in modern music. But while there has been a re-emergence of expressive, tonal musical styles, a viewpoint that stresses the ''new Romantics'' does so at the expense of those composers who stubbornly clung to an accessible idiom throughout our century.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Sophisticated Traveler: Great Tours and Detours. Edited by A. M. Rosenthal and Arthur Gelb, in association with Michael J. Leahy and Nora Kerr.

title: VOCAL CONCERTS HIGHLIGHTED
description: VOCAL and choral concerts are normally in short supply during the summer months, but you'd never know it over the next two weeks: Bach's ''Magnificat'' and Handel's ''Messiah'' are both coming up, and if you're willing to take a ride into Westchester, an evening of Bach cantatas and fully staged productions of no less than three Handel operas await you at the State University of New York in Purchase, along with other vocal enticements at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah.

title: MOSCOW DROPS A FEW HINTS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: The Soviet Union has been hinting at modest concessions that might eventually breathe new life into the deadlocked arms-control negotiations. But with the current round of Geneva talks scheduled to end on Tuesday, a breakthrough still seems distant unless the Russians move further - with or without encouragement from the United States.

title: U.S. Agency Delays Housing Deportees At Jail in Brooklyn
description: The Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service will wait until October to use a city jail in Brooklyn where 18 Cubans awaiting deportation fought with guards on July 6, according to city officials.

title: ANOTHER FIRST
description: Camille F. Murphy is used to firsts. She is the first director of the first and only countywide Office for Women in New York State, a position she has held for the last five years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THEY DARE TO SPEAK OUT: People and Institutions Confront Israel's Lobby. By Paul Findley. (Lawrence Hill, $16.95.) Paul Findley was a thoughtful, provocative and, to the pro-Israel lobby in Washington, provoking Republican Congressman from downstate Illinois.

title: The Politics of the Death Penalty in America;   Victims First
description: To the Editor:

title: AT LEAST THE GOALS SEEM CLEARER
description: MORE than 10,000 women met in Nairobi, Kenya, last week for an unofficial series of workshops that are overlapping an official conference beginning tomorrow to mark the end of the United Nations Decade for Women. Called Forum '85, the 1,000 workshops were focused on the themes of ''equality, development and peace.'' According to high-ranking United Nations officials, they were chosen in large part to satisfy the three factions into which the conference has divided: equality for the Western group, development for the third world and peace for the Eastern group. Most of the paragraphs on peace and disarmament in the official document of the conference to be discussed this week were Soviet-inspired. From the start, many of the workshops were marked by disputes between representatives of nations involved in disputes, such as Iraq and Iran. Elaine Sciolino, a New York Times reporter, interviewed several of the delegates about changes since they began working together 10 years ago and their expectations for the future. Excerpts follow.

title: A LESSON IN LOVE, LEARNED TOO LATE
description: A BIRD died - a parakeet named Pebbles who was called, simply, ''the blue bird.'' For a week we knew he was ill, though he made every effort to carry on in a nearly normal, birdlike fashion, pecking at his seeds, drinking from his cup and balancing, albeit precariously, from an upper perch in his cage. Still, the long periods he spent standing on the cage floor and his labored breathing alerted us to his distress.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: PICASSO IN MONTREAL, HAWAII BY SAIL
description: Museum Shows 81 Picassos New to Public For devotees of the art of Picasso, all roads may not lead to Quebec, but certainly one of the major thoroughfares leads these days to the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. It is there, from now until Nov. 10, that a major exhibition of 81 Picassos drawn from the personal collection of his wife, Jacqueline - and for the most part, never seen by the public -is in progress.

title: KEECY HADDEN WEDS WAYNE WEINER
description: Lucretia Grasselli Hadden, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Alexander Hadden Jr. of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Wayne Paul Weiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Weiner of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Michael Oppenheimer performed the ceremony at the Kirtland Club in Willoughby, Ohio.

title: OPEC'S DOMINANCE WEAKENS FURTHER
description: OPEC is finding it harder to re-establish its dominance over world oil markets. While the oil ministers as a group proclaim that something must be done to halt the fall in prices, unauthorized price discounts and production quota violations are rampant as individual nations try to protect their revenues. Saudi Arabia, the group's largest producer and usually a calming influence, has threatened to double its oil output. Outside the group, Mexico, whose output is greater than that of any individual OPEC member but which has taken a back seat to OPEC, cut its oil prices, saying it had been losing markets to OPEC. If OPEC ministers do not act at their July 22 meeting - by cutting the official price, enforcing production quotas or devising some other plan -some industry analysts believe the group may never regain control.

title: THE THIRD PHASE
description: County residents will have to install water restrictors in all showerheads under new water conservation measures announced last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. The tighter restrictions came as the county entered the third phase of a drought emergency.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BALLOONING FESTIVAL Not only will there be hot-air balloons - more than 70 - but the skies over Solberg Airport next weekend also will be filled with acrobatic airplanes, wing walkers and the West Point Black Knight Sky Divers. Sixty thousand spectators are expected.

title: VISIT FROM A 'MENTAL ASTRONAUT'
description: PAPER DAUGHTER Autobiography in Search of a Father. Volume Two. By Jill Johnston. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: MANHATTANVILLE MELDS PAST AND FUTURE
description: MARCIA A. Savage, the new president of Manhattanville College, advised a recent gathering of students ''to take time and dream.''

title: 'MACHISMO' ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Members of Congress have been feeling the same frustration as many other Americans over the country's apparent inability to combat international terrorists and Communist expansionism. Last week the image of Rambo, the movie hero who overcomes great odds to rescue American prisoners in Vietnam, was invoked a dozen times on the House floor as the lawmakers adopted a $12.6 billion foreign aid bill. Included in the legislation was aid to insurgents in Afghanistan and Cambodia and the resumption, after a nine-year ban, of American help to guerrilla forces fighting the Cuban-backed Government in Angola.

title: ELDERLY WITH MENTAL PROBLEMS AIDED
description: FOR THE last year and a half, the Senior Guidance Center here has been serving the mental-health needs of elderly Ocean County residents in what is said to be one of two programs of its kind in the state.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A SPECIAL AUCTION OF EARTHENWARE
description: AN ''armchair'' auction of the English Staffordshire earthenware that collectors call ''historical blue'' will be held after 6 P.M. on Wednesday. The difference between this and other auctions is that the bidders will be scattered across the country. They have mailed in their bids from their homes and will not know whether they have won or lost until a final sales list is mailed out to all bidders on Thursday.

title: THE LITERATURE OF NATURAL MAN
description: D. H. Lawrence died in March 1930, when I was just 13 years old and too unliterary to notice. At that time I read juvenile shockers in bed with a flashlight. I first became aware of the subversive power of even subliterature when my father threw into the kitchen fire my copy of the Boy's Magazine, which was just starting a serial about the end of the world. He would undoubtedly have seen a brief notice of Lawrence's death in The Daily Mail, knowing him vaguely, like the newspaper itself, as a purveyor of dirt. ''Good riddance to bad rubbish,'' he might have said, in something like Lawrence's own boyhood accent.

title: Treating Brain Disorders
description: What a hopeful article Laurence and Rona Cherry's ''Another Way of Looking at the Brain'' was (June 9). I teach children with learning disabilities, and have long been aware of their frustrations and sadness at not learning to read and write. Early detection and remediation of neurological disorders could make a significant difference in so many lives. MARI DE ROCHE Hartford

title: TOURISM BONANZA CONTINUES TO GROW
description: EARNINGS from tourism have tripled in Connecticut in the last eight years, and state officials are expecting another banner season this summer.

title: LAWYER REJECT BAN ON BIAS
description: After an emotional debate, the American Bar Association's House of Delegates last week turned back a call for legislation barring discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations. It was the second time that a resolution to extend the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 to homosexuals had been defeated, but supporters were encouraged by the narrow vote, 161 to 152.

title: Carter Meets Papandreou
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou conferred for two hours here today on Greek-American relations. Mr. Carter, who arrived here today from Geneva, had a working lunch with Mr. Papandreou before going sightseeing.

title: IS IT WRESTLING OR THEATER?
description: Roman emperors loved it. In derivative form it pleased medieval kings. And now that Roman low comedy has come down to us in the slightly bizarre but essentially faithful form of professional wrestling, why shouldn't capacity crowds pack such arenas as Madison Square Garden to see it and join its ever-increasing throngs of fans throughout the country?

title: STEIFF'S LAIR FOR BEARS
description: Teddy bears are not just kids' stuff. In late May, an adult bidder at Sotheby's in London walked away with a vintage-1905 Steiff bear for almost $2,500. In Giengen, a town of 13,000 in the West German state of Baden-Wurttemberg, local people were hardly surprised.

title: A RETURN TO CLASSICISM IN RIDGEFIELD
description: IN ''The Classic Tradition in Recent Painting and Sculpture,'' the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield has come up with a very good idea. This is to examine the return to figuration, not as a reaction to preceding modes, but as a manifestation that may have a significant place in art history.

title: SEAT BELTS: NOT EVERYONE HAS HEARD THE MESSAGE
description: BILLBOARDS along the New Jersey Turnpike carry warnings, tollbooth collectors are passing out reminders printed on small cards and radio announcements abound.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

STOCKMAN: SOME LINGERING QUESTIONS
description: DAVID A. STOCKMAN brought to the position of Director of the Office of Management and Budget an extraordinary combination of energy, intellect, a grasp of details and a zealot's commitment to reducing the Federal budget. He became the most visible, controversial and remarkable Federal budget director in the history of that office. Yet, his departure leaves several important questions lingering. How effective was he? Could someone else have been more effective? What are the lessons of his experience that bear on the Federal budget process and the selection of his successor?

title: QUINCY, MASS. BOYS CHARGED IN SLAYING OF HOMELESS MAN
description: Three teen-agers have been charged with beating a homeless man to death.

title: Loss to Cardinals Drops Padres to 2d
description: Tom Herr and Jack Clark each drove in two runs tonight and Danny Cox coasted to his 11th victory as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the San Diego Padres, 7-3.

title: WASTED YEARS
description: Gladys Burr won a settlement of $235,000 from Connecticut last week for 42 years wasted for reasons she had no control over and cannot fathom. In 1936, when she was 29 year old, Miss Burr was committed by her mother and family doctor to Norwich Hospital on the grounds she was retarded and psychotic.

title: FIRED CHIEF EXECUTIVES: SURVIVING THE FALL FROM THE TOP
description: BY now it is an old story: Top executive of large company ''resigns'' abruptly and gets the kind of huge severance payment that makes onlookers turn dollar-bill green with envy.

title: BREAK IN 1/4-INCH TUBE FORCES SHUTDOWN OF SHOREHAM PLANT
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant, at the end of the first week of testing its operating systems at low power, automatically shut down yesterday because a tube delivering pressurized air to a valve broke, an official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said.

title: 'EVITA' VISITS ELMSFORD
description: AFTER a few false alarms, ''Evita'' is at last upon us.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Talking column of May 19 about penthouses in cooperatives incorrectly described a court's ruling in a civil case involving a rooftop garden maintained by Barbara Hubshman at 1010 Fifth Avenue and water damage to apartments below.

title: Boxer Triumphs
description: Champion Turo's Cachet, a 3-year-old boxer owned by Leonard and Susan Magowitz of New York, was named best today at the 25th Anniversary Show of the Riverhead Kennel Club on the grounds of the Little Flower Children's Services. It was her second top award in six days.

title:
NATURE WATCH;

CHICORY
description: Cichorium mtybus Size: One to five feet.

title: Perconte's Status
description: Chuck Armstrong, the president of the Seattle Mariners, said he should know soon after the All-Star break this week whether to recall Jack Perconte, the team's popular second baseman, who was sent to the minors last week by the former general manager, Hal Keller. Perconte's demotion is the reason Keller is a former general manager.

title: A CAREFULLY SCHEDULED WEEK ON THE GOVERNOR'S CALENDAR
description: The coming week for Governor Cuomo - a blend of local ceremony, national politics and Washington testimony - will be busy. It began to take shape more than a year ago.

title: THE TAMING OF THE OLD WILD WEST
description: It was the fall of 1932 when I huffed and puffed and blew out an even 10 candles on my birthday cake. Most people of that vintage will tell you that 1932 was a bad year to celebrate a 10th birthday, or any other birthday, but I'm not sure that I agree. There were compensations for living in the threadbare Thirties. One of them was Street & Smith's Wild West Weekly.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SOMETHING IN COMMON. By Robert Robin. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) At the beginning of Robert Robin's first novel, Joel Stern has carefully surrounded himself with every element of the old American Dream, right down to the wife and two kids, the house in a prosperous Chicago suburb and a successful law practice.

title: LIFE AMONG THE DOMINOIDS: INCESSANT HUSTLE
description: It's a young man's game, this pizza business. The body must be fit. The mind should burn with ambition.

title: A SHOREHAM POWER FAILURE FOR COHALAN
description: When Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan dropped his opposition to the Shoreham nuclear plant two months ago, the Long Island Lighting Company agreed to pay $131 million in property taxes that it had withheld to protest his challenge. It became clear last week, though, that Lilco didn't get much for its money.

title: PERU PUTS DEMOCRACY TO THE TEST
description: PUSHING BACK A BOYISH mop of black hair and flashing a campaign-poster smile, Alan Garcia Perez leaned toward the outstretched hands of the cheering crowd and celebrated the survival of democracy in Peru. ''This is a vote of hope,'' he declared. ''The people have demonstrated that they want change within democracy.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS FINDING THAT HATRED HAS A HAIR TRIGGER
description: BISHOP Simeon Nkoane is much concerned these days with fire.

title: Repair of Space Shuttle Expected to Take Days
description: Teams of engineers prepared today to track down and replace a faulty part that halted a mission of the space shuttle Challenger Friday, just three seconds before blastoff.

title: Bowie Race Course Closes
description: Bowie Race Course ended 71 years of thoroughbred racing today as Regal Count scored a front-running victory by a neck in the $145,000 Governor's Cup Handicap, the feature race of the final program.

title:
LEISURE;
