DAYLILIES PROVIDE A WEALTH OF ORNAMENTATION
description: For many people daylilies are an addiction. An otherwise sane, sensible lawyer of my acquaintance and his equally reasonable wife began growing daylilies two years ago. They now have a collection of over two hundred named garden varieties (cultivars) and have joined the American Hemerocallis Society - a support group for daylily addicts.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: ELIZABETH WATTLES BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Wendalin Wattles, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gurdon B. Wattles of Bedford, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Robert Edmond Wilkes Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilkes of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. William E. Foley performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: KATHERINE GROSS ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gross of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Gross, to Peter Atterbury Thorne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Thorne of Greenwich, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: THE COHN CASE
description: A disciplinary panel of the state court system has determined that Roy M. Cohn, the politically well-connected New York lawyer, improperly used clients' money in two cases and had not been forthright about his actions. The panel, after taking some mitigating testimony on Mr. Cohn's behalf, has decided to recommend that he be disbarred, The New York Times reported last week. Mr. Cohn, who was counsel to Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy in the anti-Communist hearings of the early 1950's, characterized the state inquiry as a witch hunt.

title: 62 DEATHS FROM CHEESE TRACED TO SINGLE SOURCE
description: Officials investigating an outbreak of listeriosis, a bacterial infection blamed for 62 deaths and stillbirths since April, said today that they were convinced the contamination had been caused by unpasteurized milk used by a single cheese manufacturer.

title: PALESTINIANS BOMBED
description: Israeli planes attacked three Palestinian positions in northern Lebanon last week, killing 15 people and wounding 29 at sites near Tripoli, which Israel says are bases for Syrian-backed Palestinian guerrillas. The raid followed a series of bomb attacks in Israel and also came 24 hours after two suicide car-bomb attacks on checkpoints in southern Lebanon near the so-called security zone north of the Israeli border. Seventeen people were killed, most of them Lebanese civilians or members of the Christian-led militia set up by Israel to patrol the zone.

title: MUSIC: THE FORCE BEHIND THE NEWPORT FESTIVAL
description: MARK P. MALKOVICH 3d has his eye on musical talent - and his back to much of the conventional system for sifting and marketing it. As the maverick director of the Newport Music Festival, which is in the midst of its 17th season, Mr. Malkovich has displayed a knack for booking major new artists (pianists especially) before New York has heard them, for offbeat programming and for fostering the elusive atmosphere that makes a festival feel like a festival rather than another ho-hum stop on the concert circuit.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOOKING FOR BOBBY. By Gloria Norris. (Knopf, $15.95.) In her short stories (three of which have been included in recent O. Henry prize collections), Gloria Norris has displayed an economy of language and flair for the grotesque reminiscent of her fellow Southern writer Flannery O'Connor.

title: DECISION AWAITED ON ABORTION CLINIC
description: THE opponents' legal battle against abortion has reached a White Plains courtroom where a State Supreme Court judge is deciding whether to allow a right-to-life group to file suit against a White Plains abortion clinic.

title: POLICY ROLE IN ECLIPSE
description: Excerpts from an article by William J. Baroody Jr., president of the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, appearing in the institute's summer newsletter, Memorandum:

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: On a recent visit to China I had the misfortune to lose my wallet in Peking. It contained a few hundred dollars in cash and $1,900 in Barclays traveler's checks.

title: OFF BUSY ROUTE 22, CONDOMINIUMS MOVE IN
description: ROUTE 22 through Union County is considered by many to be one of the ugliest stretches of highway in New Jersey, a clashing jumble of billboards, neon signs and treacherous U-turns that has mortified planners and state officials for years.

title: LIBERALS FEUDING ON MAYORAL RACE
description: A citywide Liberal Party committee last week authorized City Council President Carol Bellamy to be the party's nominee for Mayor, but a day later state party leaders filed papers for Mayor Koch with the city Board of Elections.

title: High-Profile Prosecutor
description: As a former prosecutor for the city of New Brunswick as well as a practicing lawyer, I was interested in the article about United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani (''High-Profile Prosecutor,'' by Michael Winerip, June 9).

title: INVADER CHIEF ASSESSES LEAGUE'S FUTURE
description: The future of the United States Football League is tied inexorably to its $1.3 billion antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: Top China Propagandist Loses His Position
description: The Chinese Communist Party's top propagandist, Deng Liqun, who was widely seen as a leading opponent of liberal changes in China, has lost his post, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: FOES IN AFGHAN WAR OFTEN LIVE AND LET LIVE
description: The rebel commander, a bearlike man with a large black mustache who belied his appearance by sniffing a red rose, sat amid the ruins of an Afghan district center 70 miles south of the Soviet border.

title: French Paper Is Bombed
description: A bomb exploded early today outside the offices here of the regional newspaper Sud-Ouest, the police said. No one was hurt, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: A Quarrel . . .
description: At one of the many salad bars that have been sprouting up around town, a respectable-looking, middle-aged couple stood filling their plastic containers with a variety of greens and legumes.

title: Keeping Attendance
description: As Pete Rose inches ever closer to Ty Cobb's career record of 4,191 hits, he has suffered not the slightest hint of the disdain that was heaped on Roger Maris and Hank Aaron when Babe Ruth's home-run standards became endangered. This absence of malice suggests any number of possible causes, not the least of which is that the Babe was easily a more sympathetic historical figure than Cobb has ever been.

title: HOW TAX PACKAGE MAY SHAPE UP
description: President Reagan's chief tax-policy advisers and the members of Congress most closely involved in writing tax legislation agree that the House of Representatives will quite likely pass legislation this fall embracing the main principles of the President's plan to redesign the Federal income tax system.

title: WIEBE, BY 1 STROKE, WINS IN PLAYOFF
description: Mark Wiebe birdied the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today and registered a one-stroke victory over John Mahaffey in the $500,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: West German Killed in Cycling
description: Nikolaus Ruck of West Germany was killed in a crash during an international 24-hour motorcycling race today.

title: 90 Years Ago, an Operation On a President Was a Secret
description: When President Grover Cleveland was operated on in the mid-1890's, the press was told he was vacationing on the Hudson River, and the public did not find out about the surgery for almost a year, a historian at Ohio State University says.

title: FOR N.F.L., A SEASON OF SERENITY IS THE CALM BEFORE THE STORM
description: WELL, yes, there's this squabble about money for the rookies, agents insisting on more and club owners holding the line. But as the National Football League begins its 66th season this week, with the first training camps opening, most of the bigger headaches are still a year away.

title: Gale T. Pryor Is Wed to Karl D. Leabo
description: Gale Taylor Pryor, the daughter of Taylor Allderdice Pryor of San Francisco and Honolulu and Karen Pryor Lindbergh of Seattle, was married in Boston yesterday to Karl Devon Leabo, a son of Karl Bertram Leabo of San Francisco and Loi Shema Leabo of New York. The Very Rev. Thomas Kennedy, Dean of St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Boston, performed the ceremony at the Lindsey Chapel of Emmanuel Church.

title: NYSTROM CAPTURES SWISS OPEN FINAL
description: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, the defending champion, defeated Andreas Maurer of West Germany, 6-4, 1-6, 7-5, 6-3, today in a heat-plagued final of the $150,000 Swiss Open Tennis Championships.

title: Plumping for a Convict
description: Members of Congress send out millions of newsletters each year, and the few they receive in return are likely to be appeals for their vote for one cause or another. So some lawmakers were startled last week to receive a newsletter circulated in behalf of Dr. Jeffrey R. MacDonald, who was convicted of killing his wife and two daughters at Fort Bragg, N.C., in 1970.

title: 'FACADISM' ON THE RISE: PRESERVATION OR ILLUSION?
description: If the Landmarks Preservation Commission agrees, before long there will be a 19-story apartment tower squeezed behind the facades of a trio of old brownstones on East 79th Street just off Park Avenue. The brownstone fronts will remain, essentially as false fronts behind which the new tower will rise.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has named Joseph Bouckaert chief executive officer, succeeding Daniel D. Adams, who remains chairman.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball New Jersey Jammers vs. Rhode Island Gulls, at William Paterson College, Wayne, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Manute Bol, the 7-6 3/4 center, plays for the Gulls.

title: Fast-Food Chain Picks Della Femina on Coast
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners of California has become the ad agency for Carl Karcher Enterprises of Anaheim, operators of the Carl's Jr. chain of fast-food hamburger restaurants.

title: Girl Dies in Fall From Train
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed near here Saturday when she fell between the moving cars of an antique train of the Texas State Railroad, the authorities said. Her father, Rodger Keltner of Copperas Cove, had been helping move the girl, Christine Amanda Keltner, from one car to another on the train, said Rob Lunsford, a state trooper. The body was found beneath the train more than 400 feet from the spot where she fell, Mr. Lunsford said.

title: A BASTILLE DAY CELEBRATION IN JERSEY
description: The difference between the Fourth of July and Bastille Day, Jacky Dupont was saying, is that Americans celebrate the founding of their republic more seriously than do the French.

title: KOREA'S CHIP MAKERS RACE TO CATCH UP
description: Enveloped head to toe in protective suits, researchers bend over machines at the Lucky-Goldstar Research and Development Center here, checking silicon wafers that will be made into semiconductors. In these stark white rooms filled with equipment that towers over the researchers, the company is testing its own limits, pushing to develop better and more sophisticated semiconductors.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Fed Expected to Hold Course
description: As if recurring signs of a weakening economy and explosive monetary growth were not enough to create a policy problem for the Federal Reserve Board, the sinking dollar emerged last week as yet another worrisome force that economists believe will keep the Fed hamstrung.

title: Officials in Alaska Delay Impeachment Hearings
description: Impeachment proceedings against Gov. Bill Sheffield of Alaska, which were to begin Monday in a special session of the legislature, have been postponed for a week.

title: SMUGGLING COUNTS FILED AGAINST FIVE
description: Federal officials have arrested at least five men, including a Navy enlisted man, on charges of smuggling radar equipment and other military parts to Iran, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Lebanese Militias Duel In Beirut and Mountains
description: Christian, Moslem and Druse militias fought machine-gun and artillery battles until early today in Beirut's center and in the nearby Shuf Mountains.

title: Virginia Langner Married to Dr. Neal E. Luppescu
description: Virginia Langner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay B. Langner of New York and Ossining, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Neal E. Luppescu, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Luppescu of Roslyn, L.I., and Atlantis, Fla. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Ossining home of the bride's parents.

title: New Scenario Buoys T.W.A.
description: WHEN Trans World Airlines was last heard from, it was flying off into the sunset, wing-in-wing, with the Texas Air Corporation. Their planned merger would create the second-largest United States airline network, after United Airlines.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AFRICAN CONNECTION The art of Africa, once hard to come by in New York, is now frequently seen in New York museums and galleries. A very special show, with a special connection to New York, opens today: ''The Art of Cameroon'' comes to the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 77th Street (873-4225), bringing to view 150 items from that West African country.

title: Luden Account Moves
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton's main office in New York has been tapped by 104-year-old Luden's of Reading, Pa., makers not only of the cough drops that bear its name but also of 5th Avenue Candy Bar, Mellomint Peppermint Patties, Peanut Butter Frost and other sweet things.

title: OSHA Post Is Declined
description: Dr. Bernard Goldstein, the assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for research and development, has declined an offer from Secretary of Labor Bill Brock to become director of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration. Instead, Dr. Goldstein will return to the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, in Newark, where he headed the department of environmental and community health before coming to Washington two years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: A diagram in some copies yesterday accompanying a description of President Reagan's surgery failed to show the full extent of the section of bowel removed. In the procedure, a right hemicolectomy, approximately two feet of bowel were removed, beginning with part of the transverse colon and continuing along the entire ascending colon, plus the cecum of the colon and part of the adjoining section of the small intestine called the ileum.

title: Kristin Weber Marries Gary Daniel Friedman
description: The marriage of Kristin Weber and Gary Daniel Friedman took place yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Acting Justice Shirley Levittan of the State Supreme Court officiated.

title: Back to the Farm?
description: With Budget Director David A. Stockman's announced departure for Salomon Brothers Inc., it might appear that Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, one of the last of President Reagan's original cabinet members, would want to get back to running his 3,000-acre Illinois hog farm.

title: New Agency in Boston For John Hancock Life
description: In Boston the John Hancock Life Insurance Company - which, like so many other companies in its field, is broadening its financial services - is shifting its advertising account out of Arnold & Company and into Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus.

title: Snow on the Set
description: The Washington Post began printing daily cable television programs last week for the first time, including 12 channels and doubling its space devoted to TV listings. Despite the usefulness of such material to suburban readers, this struck some Washingtonians as iron-ic, because the District of Columbia is one of the last major cities in the country without even a contract to construct a cable system, much less access to such programming.

title: A COUNCIL PLAN SEEKS TO SHELD S.R.O. TENANTS
description: City housing officials say they expect a moratorium on the demolition and alteration of single-room-occupancy hotels, approved last week by the City Council, to shield S.R.O. tenants from building conversions and to give the city time to find ways to expand the low-income housing stock.

title: Sakharov Not Mentioned In Card From His Wife
description: A postcard from the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov to her daughter contained no mention of the Soviet physicist and dissident for the first time in months, the daughter said Saturday.

title: AIDES DESCRIBE REAGAN'S CHOICE IN TRANSFER OF POWER TO BUSH
description: President Reagan was presented Saturday with two options for delegating his constitutionalpowers to Vice President Bush, and he chose the one that suggested doubt as to the applicability of the 25th Amendment, a White House official said today.

title: Collapse of 30-Foot Trench Kills 4 Workers in Colorado
description: Four workers, including two would-be rescuers, are dead after the sides of a 30-foot-deep trench collapsed over the weekend.

title: ANGELS DEFEAT JAYS ON DISPUTED HOMER
description: Brian Downing's disputed two-run homer with two out in the ninth inning gave the Angels a 5-3 victory today over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Still in the F.D.I.C. Running
description: It has been 15 months since William M. Isaac's term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation expired. And it has been almost three months since the Reagan Administration began circulating the name of William Seidman, dean of the University of Arizona Business School, as Mr. Isaac's successor.

title: POLITICIAN IS AT HOME IN HIS JOB
description: Robert Mattson can't stand the rent, so he's moving into the kitchen.

title: ETHIOPIA REBELS SAY THEY CAPTURED NORTHERN CITY
description: Ethiopian rebels say they have won a major victory over Government forces in fighting in the northwestern part of the country this month.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PROSECUTOR FACING LEGAL TEAM IN TRIAL ON PARK FIRE
description: For 30 days of testimony here in the manslaughter trial of two corporations, the jury has seen a lone prosecutor at the state's table and five lawyers and executives at the defense table.

title: BOYS TOWN, NEB. (POP. 26 GIRLS, 415 BOYS)
description: Boys Town is not strictly Boys Town anymore. Jeanine Petrie, 16 years old, is here, the only girl in the weight-lifting class. Her sister, Jessica, 15, cuts men's hair in the barber class. And Tina John, 16, is the first girl to be chosen as a fire cadet.

title: LED CITY PRESERVATION MOVE
description: Geoffrey Platt, an architect who was the first chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, died Friday night at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: China Output Up 23.1%
description: China reported Friday that industrial production surged by 23.1 percent during the first six months of 1985 from a year earlier, a rate that Government officials said was threatening to stable economic growth. The official New China News Agency quoted a State Statistical Bureau spokesman as saying that the growth rate was so excessive it could upset attempts to introduce major economic changes.

title: Magazine Campaign Is Planned
description: THE Magazine Publishers Association is starting a new advertising campaign next week (in magazines, of course) with the usual goal in mind: more advertising dollars for its members.

title: PLAN LIGHT WORK
description: President Reagan's doctors said today that he was making a spectacular recovery from surgery and White House officials prepared for a long convalescence period in which he will carry a light work load.

title: MODERATE LIST OF NEW ISSUES SEEN
description: In the corporate market this week a moderate number of issues are expected to be offered, with a large number of shelf registrations still poised to come to market should interest rates move lower.

title: Strike Ended At Ford Plant
description: Thousands of workers ended a 19-day-old takeover of a factory at Ford Motor Argentina S.A. today after the police backed by helicopters and armored cars surrounded the plant, the official news agency Telam reported.

title: SURPRISE FINISH FOR AMERICANS
description: The finish in the eights races elicited incredulous gasps from the spectators witnessing the final of the Lucerne International Rowing Regatta today.

title: WILL JAPAN'S LEADER REMODEL MORE THAN A HOUSE?
description: Now and then a stray passer-by may stop, but no crowds stand outside the brick wall craning for a glimpse of the squat building that lies behind.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm amazed at how good I feel.'' - President Reagan, recovering from surgery. [A1:6.]

title: Well, You See, Doctor . . .
description: A Presidential stay at a hospital is always a traumatic experience for the institution.

title: RABBI EDWARD KLEIN, ACTIVIST
description: Rabbi Edward E. Klein, the longtime spiritual leader of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and a community activist on the West Side of Manhattan, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: A-Plant Stays Shut After Tube Repair
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant remained shut down for maintenance today after repairs were finished on a pressurized-air tube that broke Saturday, according to a spokesman for the Long Island Lighting Company, which owns the plant.

title: Atlantic and U.S. News Offering a Special Deal
description: Now that Atlantic magazine and U.S. News & World Report are both owned by the same party, Mortimer Zuckerman, certain advertising solicitation ploys can be employed.

title: Digging in Beverly Hills
description: Michigan Democrat John D. Dingell and his House Energy and Commerce Committee's oversight panel will dig for more of the truth behind the failure of the $2 billion Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association. There have been allegations that self-dealing, conflicts of interest and sloppy accounting practices led to the thrift unit's collapse earlier this year.

title: Washington Watch;   EQUALITY FOR STOCKHOLDERS
description: THE one-share, one-vote campaign continues on Capitol Hill, and Wall Street appears to be slowly coming around.

title: Elderly in Homes Found Poorly Fed
description: Five former mental patients have been found living undernourished and poorly clothed in a series of illegal boarding houses, a New Jersey State official said early today.

title: Chozas Captures 15th Leg in Tour
description: Eduardo Chozas of Spain won the 15th leg of the Tour de France cycling race today, but Bernard Hinault of France, the four-time winner and favorite, maintained his overall lead despite suffering a broken nose in Friday's competition.

title: Garlits Captures Drag Race Final
description: Don Garlits won his fourth race of the 1985 drag racing season today by defeating the 23-year-old rookie Darrell Gwynn of Miami in the final round of the 16th annual Budweiser Summernationals at Raceway Park.

title: INDIA ROLE GROWS IN SRI LANKA TALKS
description: In an expansion of its role as the major power in South Asia, India has begun to play an increasingly prominent part in the talks between the Government of Sri Lanka and leaders of the guerrilla insurgent groups there.

title: AFGHAN TRIP'S RIGORS AND REWARDS
description: How do you get to Afghanistan? For one thing, you buy a horse.

title: Stewart Heads Atheneum
description: Thomas A. Stewart, editor in chief of Atheneum Publishers since 1979, has been named president and publisher, the book company has announced. Mr. Stewart, a 1970 graduate of Harvard University, was previously a senior editor at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, and had been an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux and at Grossman Publishers. Alfred Knopf Jr., formerly president as well as chairman of the board, remains chairman of Atheneum.

title: AFGHANS SEEK RETURN OF COPTERS
description: Afghanistan demanded today that Pakistan return two Afghan Air Force helicopter gunships and their crews at once, saying the aircraft had got lost and strayed over the border. Pakistan says the men defected.

title: STAGE: AT THE METROPOLITAN, GRAND KABUKI'S 'SAKURA-HIME'
description: ONE of the surprises of Kabuki is how funny it can be and how readily its bawdy and ironic humor can be appreciated by a Westerner of the 1980's. Those who enjoy good silly humor - as well as costumes and sets of an unparalleled sumptuousness - should get over to the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Grand Kabuki of Japan plays through Saturday. And the piece to see is ''Sakura-hime Azuma Bunsho'' (''The Scarlet Princess of Edo''), which will be performed through Thursday by a cast headed by Bando Tamasaburo V and Kataoka Takao, two attractive younger Kabuki stars who are much idolized in Japan.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AWAKENING TWENTIES: A Memoir-History of a Literary Period. By Gorham Munson. 317 pages. Illustrated. Louisiana State University Press. $19.95.

title: HOSPITALS RETHINK REBUILDING PLANS
description: The decline in hospitalization in New York is having perhaps its greatest impact on the rebuilding plans of the city's largest teaching hospitals.

title: SAVING SPECIES FAR FROM THE PUBLIC EYE
description: For all the celebrated struggle of the National Zoo's pandas to mate in their glass house, an idyllic retreat is at hand that offers nonhuman creatures peace and therapy worthy of Masters and Johnson and protectiveness worthy of Noah.

title: BAKER WINS OPEN
description: Kathy Baker, who said she did not particularly like golf a few years ago, won the 40th United States Women's Open championship today by three shots over Judy Clark as the pressure of the final round took its toll on the more experienced players.

title: OPERA: GOUNOD'S 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: Gounod's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is an opera so burdened by self-imposed melodrama that lifting it onto some kind of functioning level for 20th-century audiences requires unusual energy and ingenuity.

title: SHULTZ AND AUSTRALIANS REAFFIRM TIES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in talks intended to reaffirm American defense links with Australia after a rupture with New Zealand, called today for democracies not to allow themselves to be split apart.

title: It's Kathy, Not Jan
description: TALL and blonde, Kathy Baker was walking toward the first tee at the Ladies Professional Golf Association's tournament in Tucson earlier this year when she noticed a young man suddenly stand straight and stare at her.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 15, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bally Mfg Corp Lilly (Eli) &Co Burlington Northern M/A Com Cooper Tire & Rub Mellon Bank Corp Dana Corp PSA Inc Goodrich (B F) Co Southern Co Johnson & Johnson Storage Equities Jorgensen (Earle M) Xerox Corp Kenwin Shops *2*TUESDAY Cincinnati Milacron Murray Ohio Mfg Equitable Resources Parker Drilling Hillenbrand Indust Public Service E & G Honeywell Inc San Jose Wtr Co Inter First Corp Scott Paper Interpublic Grp of Cos Security Pacific K Mart Corp Southern Ind G & E Learonal Inc V F Corp Lehman Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Nat'l Standard Barnes Group Pacific G & E Calfed Inc Products Res & Chem Carter-Wallace St Joseph Lt & Power Cessna Aircraft Todd Shipyards Chesebrough-Pond's Uniroyal Inc Dun & Bradstreet Vermont Amer Corp General Foods Voplex Corp Kansas Pwr & Lt Wisconsin P & L Mortgage & Realty Tr Zero Corp Murphy (G C) Corp *2*THURSDAY Alagasco Inc Grumman Corp Alex & Alex Svs Halliburton Co Archer-Daniels-Mid Hilton Hotels Ashland Oil Inc Kollmorgen Corp Barnett Bks of FL Mary Kay Cosmetics Black & Decker Corp Mesa Petroleum Bundy Corp Money Mgmt Corp Burlington Indust NY Times Co Cincinnati G & E PPG Indust Combustion Engineer Potlatch Corp Cont'l Corp (NY) Reynolds (R J) Diamond Shamrock Sherwin-Williams Diversified Energies Sundstrand Corp Fairfield Communit TECO Energy First Wisconsin Texas Industries Giant Food Thomas Industries Gillette Co Time Inc Gorman-Rupp Co *2*FRIDAY CP National Levi Strauss & Co Central Louisiana El Lomas & Nettleton Fin'l Combined Int'l Corp Media General Inc Commun Satellite Midland Ross Corp Fay's Drug Co Wachovia Corp Kay Corp *2*SATURDAY Michigan Energy Res Regal-Beloit

title: CITY RETAIL SALES FELL IN MONTH
description: New York City retail sales in June fell slightly under the year-earlier level, continuing a yearlong slump that has dismayed merchants. Seven of the city's largest retailers had an average decline of three-tenths of 1 percent compared with their sales of June 1984, according to a spot-check over the weekend.

title: BASEBALL'S TIME BOMB
description: ''DO You Know These Men?''

title: 5 Danes Die in German Crash
description: Five Danish tourists were killed and 48 were injured when their double-decker bus hit a crash barrier, spun around and overturned on a West German highway today, the police said. The bus was taking 73 Danes home from a vacation on Lake Garda in northern Italy when the accident occurred between Kassel and Gottingen, north of Frankfurt.

title: CHINESE COAL MONE BLAST KILLS 52
description: An explosion in a coal mine in southern China killed 52 miners, and rescue teams are searching for three workers still missing, a Guangdong Province official said today.

title: REPORTS OF CONCERT AID RANGE UP TO $50 MILLION
description: Estimates and talk about how much money was raised for famine relief through Saturday's ''Live Aid'' concert - the range of pledges, sales and sponsorships went from $20 million to more than $50 million - were almost as pervasive as the talk about possible on-stage reunions and surprise appearances that preceded the trans-Atlantic benefit.

title: MANY VICTIMS, NO VILLIANS IN INDIAN LAND DISPUTE
description: In 1975, Edward and Phyllis Hodgson fulfilled a longstanding ambition and bought 480 acres of land on the rolling prairie of northwestern Minnesota to raise beef cattle and grow wheat.

title: Japan Disputes U.S. Charges
description: Japanese semiconductor makers and Government officials criticized on Friday the United States decision to investigate a charge of unfair trade practices.

title: HOW L'ENFANT SHOWED DISLIKE FOR OHNay
description: After five years in the Commerce Department, Wayne Keyser decided to quit and devote himself to building a collection, not of postage stamps or jewels, but of trivia about this city and its residents.

title: Under Reconstruction
description: At Fordham, Rose Hill Gymnasium is being targeted for $300,000 worth of refurbishing, a freshening-up that coincides with its 60th birthday this fall. After nearly two decades of campus controversy on the merits of rebuilding or replacing the aged gym, the latest committee is scheduled to meet today and determine the specifics of what Dr. Joseph Cammarosano, the university's executive vice president, describes as ''cosmetic improvement.''

title: Restaurants: A Crowning . . .
description: Passers-by stopped in their tracks and stared upward. Huge rays poked from the roof, looking as if the Statue of Liberty was about to burst through, like a chorus girl from a cake.

title: CITY OPERA'S 2D SUMMER IS PULLING IN AUDIENCES
description: Armed with good news from the box office and some kind critical words for its first two productions of the season, the New York City Opera enters the third week of its second summer season with the same reasonably encouraging situation it had a year ago.

title: Francine Kane Is Married
description: Francine Kane, a daughter of the late Paul and Doris Kane, was married yesterday to Matthew Haines, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Haines of New York. Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum officiated at the Lotos Club. The bride, who is retaining her name, is the circulation and promotion manager for Town and Country and Connoisseur magazines. Mr. Haines received an M.B.A. degree last month from New York University.

title: GOLF'S BALANCE OF POWER SHIFTS
description: STEVE BALLESTEROS of Spain is as good a pick to win the British Open this week as any man in the field at Royal St. George's on the southeast coast of England. The Spaniard is not only the defending champion, but also won in 1979; he has been through the mill of The Open, as it is called in Britain. Also, Ballesteros is the premier player among the non-American stars of golf, perhaps the premier player over all.

title: U.S. EXAMINING LIST OF PALESTINIANS FOR TALKS
description: The State Department is examining a list of about a dozen Palestinians from which about four would be selected for inclusion in a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation that would hold talks with the United States this summer, department officials said today.

title: $5 Matinee Seats
description: Around the waterless fountain yesterday, the Lincoln Center plaza baked in the sun. But it was cool inside the New York State Theater, where students and elderly people lined up to buy discount $5 tickets for the matinee of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado.''

title: 2 in N.F.L. Denied Amateur Status
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation council today rejected applications by the National Football League players Renaldo Nehemiah and Willie Gault to have their amateur status reinstated for track and field events.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A year shy of its 60th anniversary, Frankie & Johnnie's Restaurant - a second-floor steakhouse that once packed in the theater crowd - has closed without notice or fanfare.

title: BRIEFS
description: Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Co., a unit of Bell Atlantic Corp., tentatively priced $110 million of 11 1/4 percent, 30-year debentures at 99 to yield 11.364 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: STEPPENWOLF THEATER'S 10-YEAR CLIMB TO SUCCESS
description: When the Steppenwolf Theater received a Tony Award last month in New York for excellence by a regional theater, Gary Sinise stepped to the stage of the Shubert Theater to make an acceptance speech. ''This really makes us reflect,'' said the artistic co-director of the company, ''on how many times we washed the floors and cleaned the toilets to get here.''

title: An Elephant Never . . .
description: No political party has a monopoly on short memory. Last month the College Young Democrats of America, soliciting advertisements for a convention program, included among samples a past ''Best Wishes'' greeting from ''Congressman Eugene V. Atkinson, 25th District, Pa.'' Mr. Atkinson switched to the Republican Party in 1981, as was noted by someone, presumably a Republican, who anonymously sent along the convention program.

title: CARDINALS EDGE PADRES BY 2-1
description: Tito Landrum's pinch-hit single scored Vince Coleman in the eighth inning today to give the Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Israel Plans More Layoffs
description: The Israeli Cabinet today announced plans for more dismissals of public workers as labor unions threatened strikes against the Government's anti-inflation austerity program.

title: STARS FOLLOW BRYANT TO SUCCESS AGAIN
description: As Kelvin Bryant has gone, so have the Philadelphia and Baltimore Stars in the three-year history of the United States Football League.

title: MUSIC: 'TAMERLANE' IS THE THIRD OF HANDEL'S OPERAS AT SUMMERFARE
description: ''Tamerlane,'' the third Handel opera production of this year's Pepsico Summerfare, was intended by the festival director, Christopher Hunt, as a practical alternative to the extremes of the other two - Peter Sellars's flamboyantly contemporary ''Giulio Cesare'' and Nicholas McGegan's scrupulously Baroque ''Teseo.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Suppose an American League player leads by a wide margin at his position in the fan balloting for the All-Star Game, then, just before the trading deadline of June 15, he is sent to a team in the National League. Does he still have a chance at starting in the game?

title: Wrong Way to Cut Trade Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OPERA: OSSINI' S'CENERENTOLA'
description: THE coloratura contralto is one of the rarest of voices, which is one good reason why some of Rossini's finest operas are not part of the standard repertory. His ''Cenerentola,'' which the New York City Opera revived last night, demands that special variety of female voice in the title role and the demand was supplied in spectacular fashion by Judith Forst. Miss Forst, who will be remembered as the best thing about last season's problematical ''Barber of Seville,'' had this listener checking his memory for comparisons by the time the night was over. That the names of Giulietta Simionato and Teresa Berganza popped up and were not summarily rejected should be testimony enough to Miss Forst's present abilities. As for her luck in productions, it continues to be bad: this ''Cenerentola'' is ugly to see and feebly directed.

title: From Concert to Transplant
description: Stephen P. Fallon, who was paged Saturday at the Live Aid concert in Philadelphia and told that a kidney was awaiting him at home, has undergone successful transplant surgery, a spokesman for Massachusetts General Hospital said today. Mr. Fallon, 25 years old, of Waltham, Mass., is in good condition and is recovering in the hospital's transplant unit, Martin Bander, a hospital spokesman, said. Mr. Bander said the donor was a New England woman.

title: AT NAIROBI WOMEN'S PARLEY, OLD WOUNDS STILL FESTER
description: As the United Nations prepares to open on Monday its official world conference ending the Decade for Women, the plight of Palestinian women remains perhaps the most controversial of the issues to be addressed by the meeting. The issue of statehood for Palestinians is being raised here as it has been at many other United Nations forums over the last two decades. Many participants are unsure as to whether it will cause the deep political divisions that afflicted the mid-decade meeting in Copenhagen five years ago.

title: U.S.-KOREA CHIP TIES GROW
description: American electronics companies are increasingly selling or licensing computer chip technology to Korean electronic companies, helping those companies rapidly advance in the semiconductor industry, executives and analysts say.

title: 2 COAST CARRIERS BATTLE OVER BUSIEST AIR ROUTE
description: In the ''California Corridor,'' the 350-mile stretch between Los Angeles and San Francisco that forms the nation's busiest air route, Aircal Inc. is waging a slick, multimillion-dollar marketing war against Pacific Southwest Airlines Inc. for the No. 1 position.

title: Ruth Green and Stephen Conn Marry
description: Ruth Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yeshayahu Anug of Jerusalem, was married yesterday to Stephen R. Conn, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Al Conn of Brooklyn. Rabbi Leonard J. Goldstein performed the ceremony in the garden of the bridegroom's home in Manhattan.

title: NOBLES OF RANGERS OFF DISABLED LIST
description: The Texas Rangers optioned the pitcher Bob Sebra to Oklahoma City of the American Association and activated the pitcher Dick Nobles yesterday.

title: Nina Berler
description: Marries Nina Carol Berler, an assistant secretary and unit manager, and James Edward Ryan, an assistant vice president, both at the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, were married yesterday at the Harrison (N.Y.) Conference Center. Mayor Vincent A. Suozzi of Glen Cove, L.I., officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Berler of Wantagh, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Ryan.

title: EXHIBITION PAYS TRIBUTE TO KUNITZ
description: Honoring a kindred spirit, a group of artists at a Cape Cod gallery yesterday celebrated the 80th birthday of the poet, critic, translator and teacher Stanley Kunitz - who wishes he had been a painter.

title: Catching Up
description: Despite the folding of the Cosmos last month, most of their players have been able to remain on the soccer field, indoors or outdoors, one way or another. Some, such as Dan Canter, Angelo DiBernardo, David Brcic and Steve Moyers, have caught on with the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: CARTER TO MISS ALL-STARS
description: Gary Carter, the Mets' catcher who was selected to the All-Star Game for the eighth time in his career, tonight withdrew himself from the roster because of an inflamed right knee.

title: Dr. Julius Katzive, Ex-Director Of Hospital Certification Unit
description: Dr. Julius A. Katzive, who directed the Bureau of Hospital Certification of the New York State Department of Health for 10 years, died at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View, Calif., Thursday, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.

title: ECONOMY CALLED KEY FOR DOLLAR
description: After an unbroken two-month stretch of stability, the calm in the foreign-exchange market has been shaken, with the dollar's value declining sharply and the markets suddenly turning volatile over the past two weeks. The dollar is at its lowest level in about 10 months.

title: ON AFGHAN SUPPLY LINE: KORANS, GUNS AND BLISTERS
description: The trails leading north from Pakistan to Afghanistan are alive with men carrying Korans and cartridge belts and leading mules, donkeys and camels piled high with weapons and ammunition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 15, 1985
description: International

title: MCCRORY RETAINS HIS TITLE
description: Milton McCrory of Detroit successfully defended his World Boxing Council welterweight title today with a third-round knockout of Carlos Trujillo of Panama in their scheduled 12-round fight.

title: Vermont Cow Brings $1.3 Million at Sale
description: Mist, a Holstein cow hailed as the probable matriarch of a dynasty of star milk producers, was bought Saturday by a group of investors for $1.3 million, the largest price ever paid for a cow at auction.

title: BASEBALL COMEDY SALUTE
description: MAJOR sports events now command the status symbol of their own entertainment special. Football's Super Bowl has long enjoyed a night-before gathering of assorted celebrities barely able to contain themselves over the mounting excitement. Now, baseball's All-Star Game, scheduled for NBC tomorrow night, is being heralded with ''A Comedy Salute to Baseball,'' tonight at 8 o'clock on NBC. It's a pastiche of familiar faces, sentiment and elbow-in-the-ribs humor, much of it in the men-will-be-boys style of those commercials for a certain beer.

title: Taiwan Fleet's Growth
description: Taiwan's container fleet will become the world's third largest at the end of this year, behind West Germany and the United States, the Communications Ministry said Friday.

title: SHUTOUT BY GOODEN
description: The Mets, behind the clutch pitching of Dwight Gooden, closed out their most successful trip in the franchise's history tonight as they defeated the Houston Astros, 1-0.

title: Janet Eisenstein Marries David Bergman in Jersey
description: The marriage of Janet Eisenstein, a security analyst with the Putnam Management Company in Boston, to David Jay Bergman, a senior consultant with Ernst & Whinney in Boston, took place yesterday at the Mayfair in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Norman Patz performed the ceremony.

title: Futures/Options;   3 Factors Influence Currencies
description: RARELY has a major trend in futures prices been so clearly determined by fundamental, technical and human factors as those in the foreign currency markets. Because these three are the major influences in all futures markets, it came as no surprise last week when all key foreign currencies futures posted strong gains.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ANGLICANS SPLIT ON RACE CONFLICT
description: South Africa's Anglican Church has ended an important synod racked by divisions that highlight a quandary facing many clerics as violence in the country's black townships seems to worsen.

title: Carter Faults Reagan For Terrorism Stand
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that President Reagan's denunciation of international terrorism was ''a mistake.''

title: KERTTU H. SHUBERT
description: Kerttu Helena Shubert, the widow of the theater chain owner John J. Shubert, died Friday in a Greenwich, Conn., hospital where she had been taken on Wednesday with a circulatory ailment.

title: A HELPING HAND FOR SCHOLARS' TRAVELS
description: When Richard Stites needed to visit Finland to look at materials for his study of utopianism as it relates to the first decade of Soviet history, he applied for a grant from a two-year-old Federal program.

title: STARS BEAT INVADERS FOR U.S.F.L. TITLE
description: With their best player, Kelvin Bryant, setting the tempo, the Baltimore Stars won the United States Football League's championship tonight. They defeated the Oakland Invaders, 28-24, in a contest that was close, competitive and controversial.

title: Stock Quotes by Phone
description: The International Information Network said Friday that it would begin offering stock quotes over the telephone in the Washington area next week.

title: The U.N. Today; July 15, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 3 P.M.

title: SOVEREIGN DON CAPTURES TREMONT
description: Sovereign Don is probably not among the five best 2-year-olds within the Wayne Lukas stable, but he was good enough to post an easy 1 1/4-length victory in the Tremont Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: NEW PHONE RESERCH GIANT
description: If a team of scientists, engineers and linguists has its way, the telephone of the future will dial a number at the sound of its user's voice. Local phone lines into homes will be equipped to transmit pictures and computer data simultaneously. And phone-answering machines will be so smart they will be able to pick out messages from specific individuals for playback.

title: KNOWING AND LOVING CONGRESS FOR 15 YEARS
description: Let others denigrate Congress as an ineffective institution, generating more wind than action, a haven for scoundrels, underachievers or worse. Although Congress-bashing is a popular pastime, Norman J. Ornstein, a political scientist and pre-emininent student of Capitol Hill, insists that the institution is a huge success.

title: New Problem for Louisiana Orchestra
description: The New Orleans Symphony Orchestra, which lost its conductor Philippe Entremont earlier this year and is planning its 50th season, now stands to lose its 64-year-old theater, the Orpheum, officials say.

title: NETTLES, AT AGE 40, IS STILL STARRING
description: Graig Nettles was recalling his experiences as an all-star recently when his Padre teammate Terry Kennedy came by and interrupted the conversation.

title: Robert S. Stephenson And Mary Bowen Wed
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Bowen, a daughter of Marjory Bayley of Canton, N.Y., and the late Croswell Bowen, to Robert Stanley Stephenson, a son of Ruth Rudman Stephenson of Spencerport, N.Y., and the late William E. Stephenson, took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Lexington, Mass. The Rev. John Fassett, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: DEADLINE TO BE SET
description: The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association will meet in Chicago today to set a deadline for talks between players and owners for a new collective agreement. The board is expected to designate a date in early August or mid-September.

title: A LEGEND AND HIS CATSKILLS RESORT FOR BLACKS
description: ''You get away from that hot, smelly city,'' said Geraldine James of Harlem. ''I have traveled all around and New York is the smelliest city in the summer.''

title: N.A.D. Settles Dispute On Skin Lotion Claims
description: A year ago a Federal judge refused to grant an injunction to either Procter & Gamble or Chesebrough-Pond's to prevent superiority claims on behalf of their respective skin lotions - Wondra and Vaseline Intensive Care Lotion. Immediately P.&G. lodged a complaint against its competitor's advertising claims with the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: YANKS, METS WIN AGAIN
description: When Ron Guidry arrived in spring training last February, he said he thought he could win 15 or 16 games this season. ''That was my goal,'' Guidry recalled yesterday. ''I just wanted to prove I could still pitch.''

title: Relations With Pretoria
description: Herman W. Nickel, the United States Ambassador to South Africa, who was recalled recently as an expression of displeasure with the racial policy of the Government there, is not expected to return to his post in Pretoria. Mr. Nickel, who has been there since 1982, has told colleagues since his return that he does not want ''to sit on my hands any more'' in South Africa, and the Reagan Administration is not disposed to fill the vacancy. Instead, the State Department is reported to be dispatching a new charge d'affaires, Richard C. Barkley, to become acting head of the embassy.

title: Plowing Ahead
description: If you thought that Rose vs. Cobb was the only such chase in professional baseball this year, then it's time you were introduced to the Connie Mack of the minor leagues. His name is Stan Wasiak, he is a 65-year-old manager all the way down at the Class A level - with the Los Angeles farm team at Vero Beach, Fla., to be precise - and sometime either late this month or early next he will have achieved 2,497 victories, more than any other field genius has compiled while beating the bushes.

title: SEAVER STOPS ORIOLES FOR 297TH VICTORY
description: Tom Seaver got his 297th career victory and struck out 11 as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Orioles, 5-3, today.

title: W.S. Teller Wed To Claudia Weill
description: Claudia Weill, a film, television and theater director, was married yesterday to Walter S. Teller, a partner in the Los Angeles entertainment law firm of Pollock, Bloom & Dekom. Rabbi Laura Geller performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Guy Weill, in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: OUTDOORS: A WORD ABOUT PLUGS AND JIGS
description: SOME anglers are less able to resist a new lure than the fish for which it is intended. This trait is more prevalent among young fishermen. Graying veterans will tell you that what worked for northern pike on Faraway Lake in 1940, will work today, by gum. The ideal lies somewhere between the dogged traditionalist and the impatient fellow who changes lures every five minutes.

title: New Moore Magazine Is Called The Golf Club
description: E. MacFarlan Moore, formerly of Times Mirror Magazines, has established the Moore Publishing Company in New Canaan, Conn., and will publish The Golf Club, a magazine intended to be distributed by golf pros at private clubs and also sold by subscription.

title: Executive at Cityfed Set to Lead Subsidiary
description: The Cityfed Financial Corporation has announced the election of James P. McTernan as president of its City Consumer Services Inc. subsidiary.

title: FLORIDA RESORT SHOCKED OVER CAR-BOMB SLAYINGS
description: The violent deaths of a Pennsylvania tobacco heiress and her son inside the guarded gates of a country club community have splintered the summer somnolence of this Gulf Coast resort.

title: BOLIVIA RIGHTIST TAKES LEAD IN THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, a retired military officer who ruled Bolivia for most of the 1970's, took an early lead today in the country's presidential election.

title: Bernard J. David Marries Lisa D. Zallinger, Banker
description: Lisa Day Zallinger, a marketing officer for the Fidelity Bank, and Bernard J. David, president and founder of General Information Services, both in Philadelphia, were married yesterday at the Wharton-Sinkler Estate in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: Sudanese Troops Fight With Rebels in South
description: Sudanese Government troops and the Sudanese People's Liberation Army are fighting heavily, Western diplomatic sources here said today.

title: WOMEN HOPING TO JOIN 'TROTTERS'
description: Undaunted by the midday sun, a solitary figure paused on an asphalt court and began his daily ball-handling ''touch drill,'' honing skills that make him the Harlem Globetrotters' preeminent dribbler. When they open their 60th season in October, they will be playing with a new red, white and blue ball, and this was Larry (Gator) Rivers's first chance to try one.

title: Bridge: Complex British Convention Gains Popularity in the U.S.
description: A complex British convention, the Multi Two-Diamond opening, has some popularity on this side of the Atlantic in a simplified form. On the diagramed deal two diamonds showed a weak two-bid in either hearts or spades, leaving the other three players in some confusion.

title: TRW Co-Founder Heads Venture Group
description: The Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, a division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, has announced the formation of a new joint venture to pursue venture capital opportunities in high technology, and has named Dr. Simon Ramo, a co-founder of TRW Inc., its chairman.

title: 'LIVE AID' PROVIDED REUNIONS OF 60'S BANDS
description: ''IT'S incredible, it's just absolutely incredible.'' MTV's video jockeys, blissfully unhampered by even the vaguest notions of rock's history and heritage, resorted to this formula again and again during the cable television channel's complete coverage of the marathon ''Live Aid'' concerts for famine relief at Wembley Stadium in London and John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia on Saturday.

title: MARRIAGE MYTH: ONENESS
description: THE rule of conduct for many couples is simple: whither one goes, the other will go; whatever one does, the other does too. Tell one a secret and the other is told; invite one to lunch and the other appears.

title: Chairman Moves To Revitalize IU
description: After he finished graduate school, John Gilray Christy spent six years in Washington working on international economic development issues. He liked the work, but he left.

title: 40 YEARS AGO, THE BOMB: THE QUESTIONS CAME LATER
description: THE creative urge that shook the earth 40 years ago with the detonation of the first atom bomb is today in the midst of a renaissance.

title: ADVERTISING;People
description: William F. Mattes, F. Michael Perkins and Harold L. Scutt Jr. promoted to senior vice president at Doyle Dane Bernbach/New York.

title: Ashland Oil to Sell Unit to Southmark
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had agreed to sell the Integon Corporation, its insurance subsidiary, to the Southmark Corporation for about $157 million. The sale is part of a divestiture program announced by Ashland last year, and should not have any impact on current net income, the company said.

title: Cooke's New Offer For Multimedia Set
description: Jack Kent Cooke, less than a week after the Federal Communications Commission allowed him to go ahead with his hostile takeover bid for Multimedia Inc., said today that he would make a tender offer of $70.01 a share for 6.73 million shares of Multimedia's outstanding stock.

title: EDUCATION;TEXAS EDUCATOR TALKS OF ELITICISM
description: GREAT universities seem to go through Camelot periods, heady eras in which they flourish. Over the last decade it has been the turn of the University of Texas at Austin for Camelot, a headlong rush into academic prestige fueled by the state's energy boom.

title: Live Aid Concert Total Estimated at $70 Million
description: A final total of the amount raised from the 16-hour Live Aid concerts Saturday will not be known until Thursday, organizers of the Live Aid Trust said today, but they estimated the total in pledges and rights to be $70 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There is a greater than 50 percent chance that the President has no cancer whatsoever, that there are no cancer cells in his body, and he is completely cured.'' - Dr. Steven Rosenberg, a member of President Reagan's surgical team. [A1:6.]

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball American League vs. National League, 56th All-Star Game, at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, Minneapolis. The American League manager, Sparky Anderson of the Detroit Tigers, has already won three of four games as manager of the National League and is trying to become the first to manage winning all-stars in both leagues. Manager Dick Williams of the San Diego Padres, a three-time loser as American League manager, now manages the National League. The National League has won 12 of the last 13 games. LaMarr Hoyt of the Padres and Jack Morris of the Tigers will be the starting pitchers.(Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.) Running Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge, at Tavern on the Green at 67th Street and West Drive, Central Park, 7:05 P.M. This 3.5 mile-race for more than 10,000 employees of local corporations is the second in the series this year. Track and Field Nikaia Games, at Nice, France. This is the seventh stop on the International Amateur Athletic Federation Mobil Grand Prix Circuit. Maccabiah Games, at Tel Aviv. The Games will be held through July 25. Other Events BASKETBALL: Long Island Knights vs. Wildwood (N.J.) Aces, at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WGBB 1240, 7:30 P.M.) BICYCLING: Tour de France, 16th stage. BOXING: Louis Rivera vs. Dwight Walker, 10 rounds, middleweights, at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary 8 P.M. GOLF: Women's Metropolitan Golfers Association Stroke Play Championships at the Glen Oaks Club, Old Westbury, L.I., 7:30 A.M. Final day. HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. The $100,000 New York Sire Stakes is the feature. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. The New Jersey Sire Stakes, 2-year old filly trot final, is the feature. (Television - MSG Network, midnight). Monticello, 7:30 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Monmouth Park, 1:30 P.M. Garden State Park, 8 P.M.

title: FRANK MILTON
description: Frank Milton, a theatrical producer and former actor, died of cancer Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;2d Witness Says She Saw Aquino Shot by Gunman
description: A second nightclub hostess broke two years of silence today to support the military assertion that a Communist gunman killed the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr..

title: SCOUTING;Keeping Pace
description: What? The Yanks and the Mets both two and a half games out at the break?

title: 60-Second Debate
description: Randall Robinson Co-chairman of the Free South Africa Movement and executive director of TransAfrica The demonstrations have had a dramatic impact. The Republican-controlled Senate, by a vote of 80 to 12, has repudiated the Administration's policy toward South Africa of constructive engagement. The House of Representatives has voted overwhelmingly for sanctions. State and local anti-apartheid measures have mushroomed. The growing American policy course change will produce significant results in Pretoria down the road.

title: THE ELUSIVE LESLIE WEXNER
description: THERE'S simply no keeping up with the elusive Leslie H. Wexner. In the year since the founder and chairman of The Limited failed to acquire Carter Hawley Hale Stores (Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman-Marcus and I. Magnin among them), he has turned his $1-billion company into a $2.5-billion empire.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Judge Says Suspect Must Remain in Canada
description: Charles Ng, a drifter suspected in up to 25 California killings, was ordered today to remain in custody in Canada until a hearing in September on local charges stemming from his arrest.

title: U.N. WOMEN'S PARLEY OPENS IN KENYA AFTER RULES FIGHT IS SETTLED
description: A conference marking the end of the United Nations Decade for Women opened here today after the United States delegation agreed to a compromise over its demands for a change in procedural rules.

title: CABINET MAY FALL OVER BELGIAN RIOT
description: Belgium's coalition Government was thrown into turmoil today by the resignation of a Deputy Prime Minister, who quit in a dispute over responsibility for the soccer riot here in May.

title: Consumer Debt Rises
description: Americans took on $9 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;LISTENING TO LARVAE CHEW
description: USING their ears and an array of electronic equipment, scientists have developed a system that can quickly detect the presence of Caribbean fruit fly larvae in grapefruit, loquat, guava and papaya without destroying the fruit, the United States Department of Agriculture has announced.

title: HOW 'BIG RIVER,' A STORY BEGUN IN A CAR, MADE IT TO BROADWAY
description: When ''Big River'' was playing in southern California last year, a prominent Broadway producer went to Roger Miller with some unsolicited advice. Maybe it would be wise, he told the musical's composer, if someone a bit more experienced took the show to New York.

title: MEXICO'S ELECTION: NATION'S IMAGE MAY HAVE LOST
description: The official results of Mexico's national elections were announced today, and they showed the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party winning all seven governorships that were at stake, all but five of the 300 elected seats in the Chamber of Deputies, and all but a handful of dozens of local and state offices.

title: Con Ed Debt Rating Review
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, one of the financially strongest electric utilities in the country, was listed yesterday as a candidate for higher debt ratings, Moody's Investors Service announced.

title: Advertising;Creative Management
description: AS a creative leader at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, Jack Keil recognized a need among newcomers to account management for a greater understanding of the creative product - advertising - and the people who produce it.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Johnson Missing
description: Pete Johnson missed a scheduled date with the scale, but Coach Don Shula reserved judgment on the future of the fullback of the Miami Dolphins. ''We don't know where Pete Johnson is,'' Shula said as 38 first-year players and selected veterans began pre-training camp workouts. Johnson weighed 286 pounds during mini-camp in May. He had been told he would not be offered a new contract if he were not down to 255 this week.

title: Flower Pot Kills Woman
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed yesterday when she was struck on the head by a flower pot that had been knocked off an eighth-floor ledge, apparently by a bolt of lightning, the police said. Witnesses told the police that the woman, Amelia Lynch of 2121 Westbury Court, in the Flatbush secton, was struck at about 4 P.M. as she was using a public telephone in front of a building at 704 Flatbush Avenue, a few blocks from her home. She was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: KOCH CONTRIBUTIONS TOP $5 MILLION, LEAVING RIVALS IN PRIMARY FARBEHIND
description: Mayor Koch has raised $5,032,983 in campaign contributions, far more than his two chief rivals, according to financial reports filed with the Board of Elections yesterday.

title: RIGHTS GROUP SAYS U.S. DISTORTS NICARAGUA REPORTS
description: A report issued today by a private human rights group accuses the Reagan Administration of manipulating and distorting information on human rights abuses in Nicaragua to justify United States support for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Guilty Plea in Bomb Scheme
description: A former police officer charged with planting a bomb on an Olympic bus last summer in a thwarted scheme to impress his superiors pleaded guilty today to a lesser charge of possessing an explosive. In exchange for the plea by the former officer, Jimmy Pearson, prosecutors were to seek dismissal of a more serious charge of possession of a destructive device at Mr. Pearson's sentencing, scheduled for Sept. 20 in Superior Court.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Ceremony on Rebuilding Of Philadelphia Houses
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode and neighborhood residents broke ground today for 61 houses to replace those destroyed by fire May 13 when the police tried to evict the radical group Move from its fortified rowhouse.

title: Cohalan Issues Order On a Shoreham Plan
description: The Suffolk County Executive issued a new executive order yesterday directing county agencies to analyze, but not actually test, a plan for protecting nearby residents in case of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Vichot Captures 16th Cycle Leg
description: Frederic Vichot of France won the 16th leg of the Tour de France cycling classic today, crossing the finish line alone, while his countryman, Bernard Hinault, retained the leader's yellow jersey.

title: Officer Shot While Guarding Building in the South Bronx
description: A police officer was shot in the lower back last night as he and another patrolman guarded a South Bronx building that had been struck by lightning, the police said.

title: Eastern Said To Weigh Bid
description: Leaders of unions representing Trans World Airlines employees said yesterday that Eastern Air Lines was still considering a bid for T.W.A., even though the labor talks over the weekend with Eastern executives failed to produce an agreement.

title: MEDICINE IN CITY IS SHIFTING FOCUS FROM HOSPITALS
description: As large New York teaching hospitals cut back, health officials say, medicine and surgery are being moved back toward the doctor's office, where modern medical practice began a century ago as a cottage industry.

title: U.S. Quality Is Criticized
description: American telecommunications equipment suffers from recurring defects as a result of ''sloppy work,'' the president of Japan's leading telecommunications company said today.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Trip Off
description: The New Zealand Rugby Union announced today it has canceled its national team's planned tour of South Africa after a judge issued an injunction barring the players from leaving the country.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Sheriff Says He Found Evidence of Satanic Cult
description: The authorities have put back the soil they had sifted for human bones, and they have packed up what they said was proof of a satanic cult.

title: WIRING WAS AT FAULT IN SUPPER CLUB FIRE JURY FINDS IN RETRIAL
description: A jury today found that outdated aluminum wiring was the chief cause of the 1977 Beverly Hills Supper Club fire that killed 165 people.

title: BIGGEST DROP IN 2 YEARS
description: The Commerce Department said yesterday that business inventories fell four-tenths of 1 percent in May from the previous month, the steepest decline in more than two years, but economists found the news encouraging.

title: COMMUNICATIONS UNION STARTS CRUCIAL CONVENTION
description: Lifetime employment security was the battle cry among leaders of the Communication Workers of America today as some 3,000 delegates began their 47th convention.

title: TV SPORTS;BASEBALL CATCHES THE VIEWERS
description: Women's golf or Ron Guidry and boxing? Summer football or Dwight Gooden? Some decisions are easier than others.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 16, 1985
description: Companies

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Ties Are Strong as Ever, U.S. and Australia Say
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister William G. Hayden of Australia ended a day of talks Monday with a declaration that their Governments' military ties were as strong and as close as ever.

title: FIVE FORMALLY CHARGED WITH STEALING AND SHIPPING JET PARTS TO IRAN
description: Five suspects, one of them an Iranian national arrested over the weekend in Britain, were charged today with selling spare parts for F-14 jets to Iran.

title: BASEBALL PLAYERS SET AUG. 6 AS DATE FOR WALKOUT
description: The executive board of the Major League Players Association today designated Aug. 6 as the date the players would strike if they do not reach agreement with the club owners on a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Lost Season
description: Unbelievable.'' That's how Steve Young, the Los Angeles Express quarterback, described his past season with the Los Angeles Express, which finished at 3-15, the worst record in the United States Football League. ''I had never been associated with a losing team in my life,'' said the former Brigham Young player. ''But this year was one thing going wrong after another. Though there was a lot of turmoil there, they had made a commitment to me and I had made a commitment to them.'' Young's commitment could be over. His agent, Leigh Steinberg, said last week that there may be a loophole in Young's $40 million contract that would enable him to jump to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, which hold his National Football League rights.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 16, 1985
description: International

title: NEW YORK;A ROY COHN SAMPLER
description: They're picking on Roy Cohn again. A disciplinary committee of the New York State court system has found him guilty of misusing clients' funds and has recommended disbarment. A panel of five judges from the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court will make the final decision.

title: PORT AUTHORITY, AMID POLITICS, SEEKS DIRECTOR
description: The ceilings are 11 feet 10 inches high - 3 feet 4 inches higher than those on any other floor of the World Trade Center. The view is a spectacular one of the Statue of Liberty, New York Harbor and a broad swath of New Jersey. And the walls just outside it are bedecked with large tapestries by Miro, Le Corbusier and Calder.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Mortgage rates fell sharply in early June, posting the largest month-to-month decline in more than two years, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Business and the Law;New Twists In Libel Cases
description: MANY corporations are becoming embroiled in libel suits, and that is forcing many businesses to pay closer attention to important new developments in libel law.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Continental Airlines Corp., Houston, is seeking government authority to provide nonstop service between Honolulu and Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Teachers Should Bargain for Benefits
description: New York's Constitution forbids the Legislature to reduce the pension terms of state and local government workers during their employment. But it imposes no ban on increasing their benefits, thus leaving the Governor's veto as the sole bar to the triumph of political generosity over prudence. Governor Cuomo should certainly veto the Legislature's last-minute gift to recently hired teachers, granting full pensions at 55 even though they agreed to age 62 when hired.

title: RUSSIAN SCIENTIST VANISHES IN SPAIN
description: A Soviet expert on computer modeling and on the potentially catastrophic effects of nuclear weapons in changing the world's climate disappeared while attending a meeting in Spain, according to his American colleagues.

title: Rational Fanatics
description: To the Editor:

title: THATCHER URGES THE PRESS TO HELP 'STARVE' TERRORISTS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, discussing the Trans World Airlines hijacking, told more than 6,000 American lawyers today that news organizations should be urged to voluntarily suppress information that might assist terrorists.

title: Soda, the Life of the Party
description: With all the hoopla about the escalating cola war, one topic has been ignored: the political implications.

title: Levi Strauss Buyout Plan
description: Robert D. Haas, president and chief executive of Levi Strauss & Company, and other members of the founding family submitted a proposal yesterday to the board to take the company private by offering $50 a share in what would be a $1.1 billion leveraged buyout.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SO far, it's been a well-kept secret. The women who frequent the New York Fashion Club don't want too many of their friends to know about it. ''My women don't want to see themselves coming and going,'' explained Rany Hirsch, who runs the club, which isn't really a club but a special place to shop. ''I have many one-of-a-kind things. I carry designers with an image of looking unique, different, not dependent on the fashions of the season.''

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;HENDERSON'S SIXTH DIMENSION
description: Until now, the best baseball players have been measured by five dimensions - hit for average, hit for power, throw, catch the ball and run. Rickey Henderson has added a sixth dimension. He not only can run, he steals bases. And when Sparky Anderson made out his American League batting order for tonight's All-Star Game, the Detroit Tigers' manager never hesitated in selecting the Yankees' center fielder as his leadoff hitter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Right Intentions, Wrong Number
description: When Hindalene Rosner saw ''1-800-LIVE-AID'' flash on her television screen in the early hours of the worldwide benefit concert, she had a feeling that things would get busy.

title: Israeli Labor Leaders Cancel A Strike Over Austerity Plan
description: Labor leaders today canceled a general strike over the Government's austerity program after all-night negotiations with Prime Minister Shimon Peres, a union spokesman said.

title: TAKING BOUFFANT OUT OF BALL GOWNS
description: Although the traditional ball gown is a scarce commodity in fall collections, opulence and elegance have by no means vanished from the evening scene. Ballrooms may seem less crowded as the doorway-wide skirt, propped by multitudinous petticoats, is displaced next season by slender, sultry dresses, perhaps in wool jersey. But entrances will be just as grand, and certainly closets and limousines will be more comfortable as slender dresses replace the conventional bouffant styles with their bare necklines and snug waists.

title: IN HAITI, SOME DISSIDENTS BREATHE A LITTLE EASIER
description: In the last few weeks, Hubert DeRonceray, a 53-year-old sociologist, has become involved in a public dispute with President Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;2 of Top Officers Promoted at May
description: The May Department Stores Company, the nation's third-largest department store chain, said yesterday that David C. Farrell, president and chief executive since 1979, had been named to fill the vacant chairmanship.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: Net Income Percent Change

title: ARTHUR ORNITZ
description: Arthur Ornitz, a Hollywood cinematographer, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: SCOUTING;Taking Stock At Halftime
description: The All-Star break has always been a time to look back on the first half of the major league baseball season, to reflect on the game's great attractions, old and new. As always, those attractions were many as spring turned to summer this year: Rose continued to stalk Cobb unwaveringly; a small group of pitchers, Tom Terrific among them, kept marching toward 300 victories; George Brett reported in great shape and rediscovered that he could bat over .350; the St. Louis Cardinals, inspired by Vince Coleman, learned anew how to win with speed; Carlton Fisk, approaching his 38th birthday, set a power-hitting pace that he had never before achieved, not even when he played at Fenway; Dwight Gooden showed that sophomore jinxes were for other people; Rickey Henderson made a leap from one coast to the other and proved none the worse for it; Dale Murphy sparkled, slumped and sparkled again; Ron Guidry got startling productivity out of his 34-year-old arm. And so on.

title: PLAYERS;STRAWBERRY IS AMBIVALENT
description: For nearly seven weeks, in the second half of May and virtually the entire month of June, Darryl Strawberry was the beneficiary of one of the great achievements in the history of the American electoral system. He was not especially proud of his distinction.

title: EARLY JULY CAR SALES DOWN 15%
description: Sales of domestically produced automobiles declined 15 percent in the first 10 days of July, according to reports today from the major automobile companies. The drop pushed the annual selling rate down to 7.5 million units, from an unusually strong 9.2 million rate in early July last year.

title: E.F. Hutton Recovers to Post Profit
description: E. F. Hutton & Company yesterday announced strong profits in the second quarter, with net income recovering to $25.1 million, from a $7.8 million loss in the second quarter of last year, when the brokerage industry was generally depressed.

title: Allied's Net Climbs 16.9%
description: The Allied Corporation, aided by the sale of part of its oil and gas business, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16.9 percent, to $152 million, or $1.61 a share, from $130 million, or $1.37 a share, a year earlier. Sales dipped four-tenths of 1 percent, to $2.75 billion, from $2.76 billion.

title: A NEW POLICE STATION, A NEW PERSPECTIVE
description: Lieut. Kenneth deSanctis of the 19th Precinct squirmed at the memory of the well-dressed dowager, there to report the loss of a $40,000 brooch, sitting in a station house where the ceilings had caved in, the windows were filthy and telephone wires snaked across the floor.

title: MT. WILSON'S TELESCOPE: LIGHTS OUT
description: THE evening had all the trappings of a retirement party: More than two dozen guests drank champagne and offered toasts to the honoree's many decades of distinguished service. After 68 years, almost 25,000 nights of viewing that had yielded some of the most profound discoveries of modern science, it was the last night of scheduled operations for the 100-inch telescope of the Mount Wilson Observatory.

title: DOW SLIDES 3.14 IN A MIXED MARKET
description: Technology issues carried the stock market for most of the session yesterday, but at the close prices were mixed as investors awaited word on President Reagan's health.

title: 50.1 MILLION LOSS AT WHEELING STEEL
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, today reported a loss of $50.1 million in the second quarter, contrasted with earnings a year earlier of $5.3 million, or 82 cents a share.

title: AIDES TO TAKE OVER SOME OF REAGAN'S TASKS
description: During President Reagan's convalescence, his top advisers will seek to take over some of his workload but still keep him sufficiently informed to make major decisions on foreign or domestic policy, White House officials said today.

title: PROBLEMS IN TESTS RAISE QUESTIONS ON SHOREHAM
description: Several problems have emerged during initial low-power testing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant during the past week, prompting Federal officials to question the design of one item and causing the plant's owner to shut the reactor for two days to make repairs.

title: Alienating Government From Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers;High-Tech Industry's Layoffs
description: A FIGURE to watch in the next few months is the rate of unemployment in the Boston metropolitan area. For May, it stood at 3 percent, one of the lowest in the nation. But in recent weeks some of the area's high-technology companies have announced layoffs, including 1,600 at Wang Laboratories and 1,300 at the Data General Corporation.
