title: PERIPHERALS;Some Ins and Outs of Modems
description: MODEMS - the devices that allow computers to talk to one another over regular telephone lines - come in internal and external versions. While both versions do essentially the same job, each has advantages and disadvantages, depending on how it is to be used.

title: L.I. College Trustees to Allow Staging of Controversial Play
description: The board of trustees of Nassau Community College voted 4 to 2 tonight to allow the performance of a campus production of the play ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All To You.''

title: EYEWITNESS ACCOUNT OF BOMB TEST
description: Detached from service at The New York Times to be a War Department historian, William L. Laurence witnessed the first explosion of an atomic bomb at Trinity Site in New Mexico July 16, 1945. He reported on the experience in an article published Sept. 26, 1945. Following is an excerpt.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago

title: GENERAL DENIES HE TOOK MONEY FROM SPY FUND FOR PERSONAL USE
description: A retired Air Force major general who is charged with embezzling Government funds testified today that he never took money for his own personal use from a secret espionage fund that he controlled.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Backers
description: Signatures on designating petitions aren't votes. But politicians take them as measures of candidates' strengths - and weaknesses.

title: LEBANESE PROSECUTOR ORDERS INQUIRY TO IDENTIFY T.W.A. HIJACKERS
description: A Lebanese state prosecutor announced today that he had ordered a judicial investigation to identify, arrest and formally charge the hijackers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner, and he said the killer of an American passenger could face a death sentence.

title: Combustion Unit
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said that subsidiaries of it and Amfac Inc. had agreed to build and operate a $145 million waste-to-energy plant for the city and county of Honolulu. It said the plant, which is the first such facility in Hawaii, would be designed and built by Combustion Engineering and operated for 20 years by the Amfac unit.

title: Throgs Neck Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BRIEF ASKS COURT TO REVERSE ABORTION RULING
description: The Reagan Administration asked the Supreme Court today to overrule its 1973 decision that established a constitutional right to abortion and to ''return the law to the condition in which it was before that case was decided.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Little Italy cafes misidentified one of those discussed. The cafe -which has a garden with a grape-vined trellis and a fountain - is La Locanda di Giotto, 25 Cleveland Place (at Spring Street), not the Backyard, at 23 Cleveland Place.

title: BRIEFING;A Mama Selection
description: When Vicki Lawrence kicks off a ''Be American. Shop American'' campaign this morning at the National Press Club, it won't represent exactly the kind of political marriage made in heaven. The campaign is sponsored by the United Food and Commercial Workers, which supported Mr. Mondale for President last year. Miss Lawrence, the indefatigable matriarch of the television program ''Mama's Family,'' is a Ronald Reagan Republican.

title: NANCY REAGAN MAINTAINS BUSINESS-AS-USUAL POISE
description: Shortly after standing at President Reagan's bedside as doctors told him today that they had found cancer, Nancy Reagan returned to the White House, changed clothes and stood in for her husband at a reception on the South Lawn.

title: Ethiopia Using Trucks for Resettlement
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Mortgage Bonds From Colorado
description: The Colorado Housing Finance Authority's $62.9 million issue of single-family, mortgage-revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2006, though underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: EARNINGS RISE SHARPLY AT CHASE AND MORGAN
description: Despite stubbornly high provisions for loan losses, two of the nation's largest bank holding companies -the Chase Manhattan Corporation and J.P. Morgan & Company - yesterday reported sharply increased earnings for the second quarter.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Soviet Spy Is Sentenced To 18-Year Prison Term
description: Svetlana Ogorodnikova, who admitted conspiring with Richard W. Miller, the former agent for Federal Bureau of Investigation, to spy for her native Soviet Union, was sentenced today to 18 years in Federal prison.

title: PEPSICO POSED FOR GROWTH
description: When the Coca-Cola Company startled the world by announcing that it would yield to consumer demand and bring back the original Coke, the only people more elated than diehard Coke drinkers were the Atlanta company's diehard competitors at Pepsico Inc.

title: SCOUTING;Hunger Run
description: It won't draw the attention that the Live Aid concert received, or raise anywhere close to that kind of money, but the New York Road Runners Club is doing its part to feed the hungry in Africa by staging a four-mile benefit race in Central Park next Sunday.

title: Farm Bank Seeks Aid
description: Member banks of the nation's largest farm lending system are being asked to contribute to a $435 million bailout of the seriously ailing Omaha district.

title: Eckerd Fends Off Takeover by Dart
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation, successfully heading off the possibility of a hostile takeover bid, said that it had repurchased the 5 percent stake in the company held by the Dart Group Corporation, for $29.50 a share, or a total of $55.6 million. Eckerd said the repurchase price for the 1.88 million shares was the same as the stock's closing price per share on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday. The stock had traded at about $26 a share before Dart's announcement in early June that it held 5 percent of Eckerd and was considering making a bid for the whole company.

title: REAGAN'S ILLNESS: MEDICAL OUTLOOK;CANCER OF THE COLON: A LEADING KILLER
description: Cancer of the colon, or large bowel, is one of the leading deadly cancers among Americans. This year, according to American Cancer Society estimates, 96,000 new cases will be diagnosed and 51,600 people will die of the disease. Only lung cancer is more deadly.

title: Man's First Glimpse of Plutonium
description: OTHER scientific discoveries in the past may have had an equal or greater effect on man's existence, but no other exploded in his face as did the first man-made element, plutonium. The announcement to the world of its existence was in the form of the nuclear bomb dropped over Nagasaki.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION;PARENTS' ROLE IN SCHOOLS: NEW ATTENTION FOR TICKLISH OLD ISSUE
description: SCHOOL administrators like to blame apathetic parents for the schools' failures. But these same school people tend to get nervous when faced with parents who insist on playing an active part in the schools.

title: Political Photographer Dies
description: Frank Cancellare, the photographer who took the picture of President Truman holding aloft a copy of The Chicago Tribune incorrectly declaring Thomas E. Dewey the winner of the 1948 Presidential election, died today. Mr. Cancellare, who was 75 years old on July 4, retired in 1980 after 52 years with Acme Newspictures, United Press and United Press International. At his retirement, he had covered every President from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Jimmy Carter.

title: Preferred Status for Homosexuals?
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PEOPLE WATCHING There are many ways of looking at the human figure, and artists have always found even more ways than mere people-watchers have. A new show that illustrates this opens today at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street (369-4880).

title: Offering by Tabacalera
description: Tabacalera, Spain's 350-year-old tobacco monopoly, will soon invite foreign investors to buy its shares for the first time, according to its chairman, Candido Velazquez.

title: U.S. REPORTED DENYING IMMUNITY TO EX-PARTNER OF SPY RING SUSPECT
description: Prosecutors have refused to grant immunity to the former business partner of a man accused of being part of a naval espionage ring and have called off her appearance before a Federal grand jury, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: The Irony of Israel's Democracy Project
description: The conviction last week of 15 Israeli Jews - three of them for murder and 12 for other violent crimes against Arabs - was deeply upsetting for Israelis. Whatever one thought of the conviction -it was the first time the Israeli judiciary had moved against Jewish terrorists - the episode also fans growing fears that our democracy may be threatened by unstoppable currents of lawless prejudice and brutality.

title: REAGAN'S ILLNESS: MEDICAL OUTLOOK;CANCER SURGEON 'CRACKERJACK'
description: Dr. Steven Rosenberg has faced tougher audiences than the White House press corps, which he impressed today with quiet assurance as he fielded questions on President Reagan's health.

title: Bridge: An Explanation Lies Behind Apparent Slip of the Tongue
description: If contestants in a competition were asked to guess the explanation for the curious bidding shown in the diagram, it can safely be predicted that there would be few correct answers. The obvious solution, that South had a slip of the tongue and intended to say four hearts is not correct. The real explanation is more complex.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Budd Opposed
description: British athletic officials reacted defiantly to a report that South African-born Zola Budd would face opposition from city authorities in Edinburgh at next week's international meet in that Scottish city. The Times of London quoted Mark Lazarowitz, a member of Edinburgh's City Council, as saying the 19-year-old runner ''will not be welcome'' at the July 21 meet. ''We want to make our stance on apartheid clear. We are totally opposed to it,'' the newspaper quoted Lazarowitz as saying. The newspaper said anti-apartheid banners inside the stadium and a refusal to allow Miss Budd to attend an athletes' reception were among the measures being discussed by local officials. Andy Norman, an official of the British Amatuer Athletics Board, said Miss Budd ''is too tough to be scared off by one newspaper article. She is a British citizen, one of our leading world-class athletes and this event has been built around her.'' . . . Meanwhile, Miss Budd has told the Seattle televsion station KING that she cut in too soon on Mary Decker Slaney in the controversial 3,000-meter final at the Los Angeles Olympics. Mrs. Slaney has said she was partly to blame because she failed to reach out and let Miss Budd know she was too close. Last week, Miss Budd, who wound up seventh in the 3,000 said she lost the race on purpose, slowing down when she heard the crowd booing her after Mrs. Slaney fell and could not continue.

title: SHUTTLE FLIGHT RESET AFTER VALVE IS REPAIRED
description: The aborted flight of the space shuttle Challenger was rescheduled today for July 29 after the replacement of a valve part believed responsible for halting the mission on Friday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced.

title: BRIEFING;Of Bombs and Peace
description: Marking the anniversary of the nation's, and the world's, first atomic bomb test 40 years ago today, the National Association of Atomic Veterans will hold an Atomic Veterans' Day Rally this afternoon on the east front steps of the Capitol. The rally is in honor of the nearly 350,000 American servicemen and servicewomen who took part in the nuclear weapons program from 1945 to 1963.

title: Wilander Wins U.S. Pro Title
description: Mats Wilander, the world's third-ranked tennis player, returned the United States Pro Tennis championship to Sweden tonight with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Martin Jaite of Argentina.

title: ALL OF FRANCE IS ASKING: WHO KILLED PETIT GREGORY?
description: Not many Frenchmen had heard of the Vologne River, a small, pretty stream flowing amid verdant fields and woods beneath this rural hamlet.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Animals' Rights Group In a College Office
description: About one hundred members of an animals' rights group occupied an office in the National Institute of Health for more than eight hours today to protest the granting of Federal funds to a University of Pennsylvania animal research laboratory.

title: CBS AND NBC PRESENT TWO PILOTS FOR SITCOMS
description: THERE are times when the networks demonstrably cannot win with the reviewers.

title: ADVERTISING;Times Mirror Magazine Posts Are Filled
description: Andrew J. Dempsey, 43, and James L. Kopper, 53, will join the Times Mirror Magazines as president, and executive vice president, respectively, on Aug. 5. They will report to Herbert K. Schnall, chairman.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTING;A Thrifty and Practical Computer From Korea
description: BY now many people assume that even if the label in front is that of an American company, the innards of a computer are manufactured in the Far East. Although Japan has yet to make inroads on the sales of whole personal computers under its own brand names, the country is a recognized master of all the components, from disk drives to memory chips. It is also on the leading edge of such newer technologies as compact disk memory, which essentially involves converting the more familiar musical version of the entity into something to which a computer can listen.

title: FAMILY OF THREE IS KILLED IN FIRE AT JERSEY STABLE
description: A fire engulfed a two-story stable at a riding school about sunrise today, killing a farmhand, his wife and their infant son in a small apartment and 16 horses quartered a floor below.

title: Working Profile:Donna Frame Tuttle;Up From Nepotism To Noteworthiness
description: When Donna Frame Tuttle was appointed by President Reagan as Under Secretary of Commerce for tourism and director of the United States Travel and Tourism Administration a year and a half ago, much of the tourism industry was outraged.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Comings and Goings
description: The Wake Forest basketball coach, Carl Tacy, resigned yesterday but gave no reason for his action. Tacy had a 222-149 record, including 15-14 last season, since becoming the coach in 1972. . . . The Idaho State men's basketball program has been placed on probation for two years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's committee on infractions, Frank J. Remington, the committee chairman, announced. An N.C.A.A. investigation had found the team's former coach and a former assistant had committed several violations,

title: I.B.M. NET OFF 12.9% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, still suffering from a sharp decline in demand for its midsized and mainframe computers, said today that its net income in the second quarter dropped 12.9 percent, to $1.41 billion, or $2.30 a share, compared with $1.62 billion, or $2.65 a share, in the 1984 quarter.

title: SCOUTING;Below Average
description: With Darryl Strawberry voted into the All-Star Game by the fans, the question arose whether any other nonpitcher had ever nailed down a starter's berth with a batting average as low as Strawberry's .229. Sure. Only two years ago, the man with the magic glove, Ozzie Smith, was voted the starting National League shortstop despite an average of only .205.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;E.E.C. Offering Is $240 Million
description: The European Economic Community is offering $240 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in three years at a price of 99.723 to yield 9.358 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BRIEFING;Of Congress and Peace
description: Yes, there is life after Congress, according to recent comments by three men who once held seats of power on Capitol Hill.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;The Moon and Lunacy
description: The full moon has been held since ancient times to be a cause of lunacy and an incitement to lunatic behavior; as recently as 1978, a Miami psychiatrist, Arnold Lieber, asserted in his book ''The Lunar Effect'' that scientific evidence supports such a notion.

title: Zimbabwe Protects Lives of Its Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Tokyo Listing, Sale Set By American Express
description: The American Express Company, eager to enlarge its role as a financial services company in Japan, yesterday announced plans to list its common stock on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and then to sell one million new shares in Japan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Rivalry Threatened
description: Ray Perkins, the Alabama football coach, hinted that the Alabama-Auburn football series might be jeopardized if Auburn insisted on playing the game in Auburn every other year, instead of at Legion Field in Birmingham, considered a neutral site. ''I think it would be a tragedy if Auburn moves the game, and it could lead to a bigger tragedy than that,'' Perkins said. He declined to give details, but there has been speculation that Alabama might drop Auburn from its schedule rather than play at Auburn. plays most of its home games in Tuscaloosa. Auburn is expanding its 72,169-seat Jordan-Hare stadium, and Coach Pat Dye, the Tigers' coach, said the game would be moved to Auburn when the school is the host. The teams are committed to play in Birmingham through 1987. Alabama will be the host team in 1988, so 1989 would be the first time the game could be played at Auburn.

title: 3D CAR EXPLOSION IN SOUTH LEBANON IN A WEEK KILLS 10
description: A car flying a Red Cross flag exploded today at a checkpoint at the edge of Israel's buffer zone in southern Lebanon, killing the driver, two Israeli-backed militiamen and seven Lebanese bystanders, according to reports from the scene.

title: CITY OPERA: ROSSINI'S 'CENERENTOLA' IS REVIVED
description: THE coloratura contralto is one of the rarest of voices, which is one good reason why some of Rossini's finest operas are not part of the standard repertory. His ''Cenerentola,'' which the New York City Opera revived Sunday night, demands that special variety of female voice in the title role, and the demand was supplied in spectacular fashion by Judith Forst. Miss Forst, who will be remembered as the best thing about last season's problematical ''Barber of Seville,'' had this listener checking his memory for comparisons by the time the night was over. That the names of Giulietta Simionato and Teresa Berganza popped up and were not summarily rejected should be testimony enough to Miss Forst's present abilities. As for her luck in productions, it continues to be bad: this ''Cenerentola'' is ugly to see and feebly directed.

title: BENEFITS AND DANGERS OF EXERCISE
description: AS physical fitness increasingly becomes an American passion that is pursued at times to the point of injury and even death, researchers are racing to clarify its effects on health and longevity and the physiological mechanisms that may account for them. Their studies ask whether in the long run the benefits of vigorous exercise outweigh its risks, particularly with regard to the heart.

title: From Woodstock to Philadelphia
description: Good morning, children of the 80's. This is your Woodstock, and it's long overdue.'' So remarked the folk singer Joan Baez as she greeted the crowd at the Philadelphia portion of Saturday's ''Live Aid'' concerts, a mass event that preyed upon the memory of the 1969 concert at Woodstock, symbolizing counterculture and generation gap. To raise money for African famine relief, ''Live Aid'' traded heavily on nostalgia and reunited several big-name musical groups from the 1960's.

title: PLAYS;YELLOW FLAG THWARTED FINAL DRIVE
description: Kelvin Bryant's long strides took him into the Oakland Invaders' end zone for his third touchdown of the game Sunday night, one that justified his selection as the outstanding performer in the United States Football League's championship game at Giants Stadium.

title: Officer at News Gets Dallas Job
description: Arthur E. Wible, the president and chief operating officer of The Daily News, has been named publisher and chief executive of The Dallas Times Herald, effective Aug. 1.

title: Peres Says the Israelis Want To Renew Ties With Moscow
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel wanted to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Where Interns Dwell
description: It was just after 8 A.M. at Georgetown University and a small crowd had gathered at the curb to wait for the G-2 bus. The young women wore sneakers over their stockings, the young men wore loafers under their khakis. Identification cards were clipped to most blazers, and just about everyone carried a pen and a legal pad.

title: BAXTER'S MERGER BID ACCEPTED
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation and Baxter Travenol Laboratories, two of the nation's largest producers of medical supplies, agreed yesterday to merge in a transaction valued at about $3.8 billion.

title: ADVERTISING;Accounts
description: Hershey Entertainment and Resort Companies to Keiler Advertising, Farmington, Conn., for Lake Compounce Amusement Park.

title: REAGAN'S ILLNESS: GOVERNMENTAL QUESTIONS;POWER TRANSFER SEEN AS PRECEDENT
description: Whether he intended to or not, President Reagan set a political precedent for a President to temporarily transfer power to the Vice President before being anesthetized for surgery, several legal experts said today.

title: 6 DEFORMED BABIES IN INDIA LINKED TO BHOPAL GAS LEAK
description: A state health minister said today that 36 pregnant women spontaneously aborted and that 6 gave births to deformed babies after the toxic gas leak at the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal here in December.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;New Drug for Sleeping Sickness
description: AFRICAN sleeping sickness, a parasitic disease of humans and animals that is spread by the bites of tsetse flies, is a major health hazard that severely hinders the economic development of Africa and contributes to a protein shortage there. An area the size of the United States within Africa is rendered unpopulated by cattle because of the prevalence of the trypanosome parasite that causes trypanosomiasis, or African sleeping sickness.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: UNDER THE BANYAN TREE AND OTHER STORIES. By R. K. Narayan. 193 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Hospitality, Western-Style
description: Toshihiro Kawashima, a prop man for the Grand Kabuki, barbecued frankfurters and corn on the cob. Tanaka Chojuro, a wardrobe assistant, won the swimming race. Three Japanese stagehands flipped spontaneous and simultaneous somersaults into the lake.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;Cleaning Up the Ganges
description: Declaring the sacred river Ganges unsafe for bathing, let alone drinking, the Government of India has begun a five-year cleanup program expected to cost nearly $200 million. Each day the 1,500 mile-long river, which carries a quarter of India's surface water, receives raw sewage from 100 cities along its banks as well as industrial effluents, pesticide and fertilizer runoff, the wastes of millions of bathing cattle and the remains, often incompletely cremated, of thousands of devout Hindus. Twice, the divine river has caught fire.

title: BRIEFING;A Democratic Selection
description: Nathan Landow, a wealthy Maryland real estate developer and strong supporter of Walter F. Mondale's race for President last year, has been tapped to head the committee that will choose the city where the Democrats will convene in 1988. Announcement of his appointment is expected this week by Paul G. Kirk Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Mayor of New York, Maker of Rains
description: Mayor Koch, who told a church congregation a few months ago that while ''it was the people who elected me, it was God who selected me,'' hinted yesterday that his relationship with the Deity might solve the drought.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball LOS ANGELES (NL) - Sent German Rivera, third baseman, to Houston to complete trade for Enos Cabell.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Rates Mixed in Light Trading
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday in light activity as many market participants were on the sidelines waiting for fresh information about the economy and Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: First Capital
description: The First Capital Holdings Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company unit of the Monarch Capital Corporation for $75 million.

title: BOLIVIAN RIGHTIST LEADS FOES BUT LACKS MAJORITY
description: Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, a retired military officer who once took power in a coup, was the leader today as vote counting continued from presidential elections Sunday.

title: WILL HEX HIT ALL-STAR GAME?
description: If the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome lives up to its reputation, this could be the strangest of All-Star Games.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON IMPROVEMENTS AT NEWARK JAIL
description: City officials today agreed to improve conditions at the city jail as part of a settlement of a lawsuit brought by the Federal Justice Department.

title: DANCE: TROUPE FROM PARIS AT AMERICAN FESTIVAL
description: Every so often a dancer of stunning individuality turns up in a field filled with excellence, and there is no question that France's latest sensation on these shores is Jean-Christophe Pare.

title: Checker Terms
description: The Checker Motors Corporation said it had received a buyout proposal of $62 a share, or $70 million, from a group of private investors and management. The payment would be $51 a share in cash and $11 a share in a subordinated debenture for each common share. Checker said a special committee of independent directors had been appointed to study the proposal. It said the acquirers include David Markin, the company's president and chairman, and Allen Tessler, a director of the company.

title: REAGAN'S ILLNESS: NATION IS INFORMED;EXPLANATIONS BY 2 CANCER SURGEONS AT BETHESDA NEWS PARLEY
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the briefing on President Reagan's health held yesterday by doctors at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center in Maryland, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Mugabe Dismisses a White
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today dismissed Agriculture Minister Denis Norman, the most prominent white in the Cabinet. Mr. Mugabe said he had made the decision because most whites backed the party of Ian D. Smith, the former Rhodesian leader, in elections last month. Mr. Norman has no political affiliation.

title: BAKER TRUSTS FAITH AS A GUIDE
description: Kathy Baker is just one of many athletes, including a number of women on the pro golf tour, who say they are born-again Christians. But the 24-year-old golfer expresses her beliefs more openly than most.

title: AUTHORITY ON COPYRIGHT LAW
description: T. Newman Lawler, an authority on copyright law who represented many leading entertainers, died Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a series of strokes. He was 77 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: IN THE NATION;THE DOUBLE AGENT
description: Forty years ago today, ''in the New Mexico desert, early on a Monday morning, 16 July 1945, the sun could be judged to rise twice.'' The ''false dawn'' was Trinity, the first nuclear explosion, as recalled by Philip Morrison, a physicist who witnessed it.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;8 Killed in South Africa In Renewed Violence
description: Violence swept black townships in South Africa, killing eight people and injuring dozens in three days, official and civilian sources reported today.

title: F.A.A. PLANS TO SPEED SECURITY WORK
description: The Transportation Department has approved an immediate speed-up in spending on research for systems to combat terrorism, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Pacificorp to Buy Unit of Orbanco
description: Pacificorp, which is based in Portland, Ore., and is primarily a utility, said it had agreed to buy the Northwest Acceptance Corporation, a telephone equipment leasing and financing company, from the Orbanco Financial Services Corporation for about $53 million in cash and a secured short-term note. Orbanco, which previously announced the sale of its principal subsidiary, Oregon Bank, to the BankAmerica Corporation, said the net worth of the leasing company, which is also based in Portland, is about $58 million. The subsidiary had revenue of $40 million and net income of $3 million for 1984. It serves about 13 million customers in 31 states, Orbanco said.

title: Boise Cascade Net Off 5.4%
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter fell 5.4 percent, to $31.7 million, or $1.07 a share, from $33.5 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier. Revenues slipped 2.4 percent, to $974.2 million, from $997.9 million.

title: Prize Money for Boston
description: The Boston Athletic Association voted tonight to award prize money in the Boston Marathon starting next spring.

title: SANITATIONMEN AND CITY AGREE ON 3-YEAR PACT
description: The city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association have reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract that provides pay increases of 6 percent each year.

title: Dr. Sigismund Peller; Studied Lung Cancer
description: Dr. Sigismund Peller, an internist and medical statistician who was among the first researchers to link cigarette smoking to lung cancer, died Friday in San Diego. He was 94 years old.

title: LASER WEAPON TEST FAILS
description: The Pentagon conducted the first in a series of laser experiments over the weekend in the research program to develop an antimissile shield, but the test in Hawaii was only partly successful because laser operators were unable to lock on the target properly, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Allen May Join Yankees
description: Neil Allen was wearing a Yankee cap and reciting the team's coming schedule the other day as if he knew something no one else did.

title: Gas Price Prediction
description: Gasoline prices have risen a dime a gallon since February despite a $2 per barrel decline in crude oil prices in the past year, but should begin dropping this fall, the Energy Secretary, John Herrington, said today. ''After the summer and heavy driving days are over, I would be amazed if there is not a price break,'' Mr. Herrington said after testifying before the fossil and synthetic fuels subcommittee of the House Energy Committee.

title: CONGRESS UNABLE TO REACH ACCORD ON RULES FOR MILITARY CONTRACTS
description: A House-Senate conference on military programs bogged down this afternoon in a dispute over new rules aimed at curbing abuses by military contractors, Congressional aides said.

title: ALIENATING GOVERNMENT FROM RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: Mexican Interzonal Provides Easy Triumph for Timman
description: Jam Timman, a 33-year-old Dutch grandmaster, achieved an easy triumph in the second Interzonal Tournament, held in Mendetaxco, Mexico. The winner's score was 12-3. The Interzonals are the second step in the two-year cycle that will qualify a challenger for the world championship next year.

title: REAGAN'S DOCTORS FIND CANCER IN TUMOR BUT REPORT REMOVAL LEAVES HISCHANCES EXCELLENT
description: Doctors announced today that the large tumor removed from President Reagan's abdomen was cancerous, but they said there was more than a 50 percent chance that he would live out his normal lifespan.

title: BIOPSY: STUDIES OF TISSUE
description: A biopsy involves removal of a small piece of suspect tissue for diagnosis and evaluation, both with the naked eye and under a microscope. When cancer is a possibility, the pathologist compares the tissue's size, color, shape, consistency and border characteristics with normal tissue of the same type. Often, this ''gross'' examination is strongly suggestive of cancer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Surgery for Ruland
description: Jeff Ruland, the center for the Washington Bullets, will reportedly undergo surgery to correct tendinitis in his right shoulder that forced him to miss 42 of the team's last 43 regular-season games in the National Basketball Association last season. The Bullets have also learned that Frank Johnson, the guard who missed most of the last half of the season with a broken bone in his right foot, broke the bone again.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atcor Inc., Harvey, Ill., which makes tubing and electrical products, has named David A. Shotts president of its Elcen Metal Products division.

title: At Sea With the Bounty
description: America's maritime industry operates inside an intricate web of Government-sanctioned privilege and obligation. That web is now being rent, not least by the pressure to reduce Federal subsidies. That's all to the good: most maritime regulation serves special interests at the expense of taxpayers, consumers and efficient producers.

title: CARTER WILL NOT FACE SURGERY
description: The Mets were able to breathe a bit easier today when they learned that Gary Carter would not need immediate surgery, as had been feared, for the right knee he injured in Saturday night's game against the Houston Astros.

title: Kennedy Center Lists Award Winners
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced today that Merce Cunningham, Irene Dunne, Bob Hope, Alan Jay Lerner, Frederick Loewe and Beverly Sills will be the recipients of the center's annual awards for 1985.

title: HESTON CHOOSES 'DYNASTY II' OVER A SENATE BID
description: This summer, Charlton Heston decided to join ''Dynasty II'' instead of run for the United States Senate.

title: Company to Pay Fine In Chemical Violations
description: Diamond Shamrock Inc., a chemicals manufacturer, has agreed to pay a $900,000 administrative fine for failure to notify the Environmental Protection Agency before it made or imported three new chemicals, the agency said today.

title: Market Place;Cautious View On Oil Stocks
description: MANY oil companies are expected to report higher second-quarter earnings, but a generally cautious view toward the group prevails on Wall Street. The main uncertainty, analysts agree, concerns the extent to which crude oil prices may decline.

title: MUSIC: SALONEN CONDUCTS SIBELIUS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Esa-Pekka Salonen is a name that, strange as it may look to non-Finnish eyes, keeps coming up in musical circles. It belongs to a conductor still in his 20's whose recent successes in Sweden, Australia and especially England have gotten him much talked about and appointed principal guest conductor of the London Philharmonia Orchestra. In America he's already conducted the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Minnesota Orchestra, but the orchestras of New York and Philadelphia won't have him as a guest until two seasons hence, so his Tanglewood debut with the Boston Symphony Orchestra tonight was a matter of special interest.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;CBS/Fox Video Chief Will Leave the Venture
description: CBS/Fox Video, the largest video cassette distributor in the country. said yesterday that Lawrence Hilford, president and chief executive officer, would leave the company.

title: OPERA: THE MIKADO
description: HERE'S a pretty how-de-do:

title: Verbatim Shows Optical Disk Drive
description: The Verbatim Corporation has introduced a prototype of an optical disk drive that can erase and write information on a disk rather than just read it. The product was shown at the National Computer Conference here.

title: TESTING A PLAN FOR RECYCLING OF CITY TRASH
description: A voluntary garbage recycling program will begin next spring in five residential sections of New York City.

title: A SURGEON OPERATES OUTSIDE HIS HOSPITAL
description: More and more of Dr. Frederick M. Golomb's surgical patients never see the inside of a hospital.

title: The Light in the Shadow
description: First the assassin's bullets, then the shadow of cancer. President Reagan has defied both grim threats with good fortune and remarkable serenity.

title: GAMES ARE OVER, BUT ACTION GOES ON
description: The blocking and tackling in the United States Football League ceased Sunday, when the Baltimore Stars beat the Oakland Invaders, 28-24, for the league championship. But the league's season off the field is far from over.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRAT PROMISES TO OFFER BUDGET CUT PLAN TODAY
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee said today that he would offer a ''very substantial'' budget plan Tuesday that would include ''additional cuts'' in domestic spending.

title: A.M.C. Loss Seen
description: The American Motors Corporation said it expected its loss in the second quarter that ended June 30 would exceed the $29 million loss in the first quarter. A spokesman said the company's president, Jose Dedeurwaerder, regards the losses this year as consistent with what company executives have said about the auto maker's five-year business plan to revive its financial position. A.M.C.'s major shareholder is the French auto maker Renault.

title: SIMMS OUT AS CAMP OPENS
description: The Giants opened training camp today with three players missing. In a year in which National Football League teams have been limiting salaries and bonuses for draftees, it could have been worse.

title: FUN HOUSE NEVER INSPECTED, TOWN FIRE INSPECTOR TESTIFIES
description: A Jackson Township fire inspector testified today that he had never inspected the Six Flags Great Adventure Haunted Castle, which burned May 11, 1984, killing eight patrons.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;$83 Million Issue In Pennsylvania
description: An issue of $83 million of Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency single-family, mortgage-revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2014, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Blast at Home of P.L.O. Aide
description: An explosion went off at the home of a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Nicosia early this morning, injuring one person, according to the Cypriot police.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: Police Lose Bid to Halt Inquiry in Philadelphia
description: A judge today dismissed a lawsuit filed earlier in the day by the city police union that sought to halt a mayoral commission's inquiry into a fire that killed 11 members of the radical group Move and burned 61 houses.

title: Trivia Time
description: The All-Star Game at Minneapolis last night kicked off a couple of weeks of celebrations in two major sports. Coming next: the Cooperstown inductions on July 28 and then, just six days after that, the inductions by the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Witness Links Violence To Supremacist Leader
description: The leader of the Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord ordered members of the group to commit crimes for monetary gain and to aid in the collapse of the Government, a former elder of the group testified Monday.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: JOHNSON'S CIRCUITOUS ROUTE TO THE N.F.L.
description: The movement of players from the United States Football League to the National Football League continued last week, when the San Diego Chargers signed Trumaine Johnson, the former wide receiver of the Arizona Outlaws.

title: DUNDEE HOPEFUL SET FOR BELATED DEBUT
description: It never takes much to excite Angelo Dundee, the eternal optimist who believes every new kid he signs is a potential champion.

title: Weekly Folds
description: The coming N.F.L. season will apparently have to make do without Pro Football Weekly.

title: FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits for the quarter and the six months and an extraordinary gain of $5,600,000 for the six months from the sale of six branch offices. c-Net loss.

title: CABARET: ANITA HOLLANDER
description: FACING the premise that the musical theater, judged by its lack of new shows during the past season, is in dire straits, Anita Hollander has put together a cabaret act that shows off the work of a new, rising generation of theater song writers.

title: MULTIVEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ARRAYS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income. Fiscal 1983 share earning has been equated from 37 cents to 32 cents a share.

title: VIRATEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Final Results Released In Mexican Election
description: Mexico's ruling party rolled to a landslide victory in the July 7 election, capturing 291 of the 300 congressional seats, according to official results released today.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,700,000 for the quarter and $6,600,000 for the six months.

title: FIRE SAFETY EXPERT SAYS PARK NEEDED SPRINKLERS
description: A fire-protection contractor testified today that he would have designed a sprinkler system for the Haunted Castle at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park that would have saved lives.

title: FILIPINO NEWS HUNTERS FIND THEY ARE ALSO PREY
description: Severino Arcones, the star commentator and manager of radio station DYFM, is ready to leave the office on an afternoon reporting foray.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE BREAKFAST DEBATE: TO EAT OR NOT TO EAT?
description: GENERATIONS of Americans have been brought up to believe that a good breakfast is one of life's essentials. Stoking up the body at the outset of the day, we have all been told, and told again, is as necessary as putting gasoline in the family car before starting a trip.

title: SEARLE, G D & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What We Mean When We Talk About Barbarism
description: To the Editor:

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $1,200,000 for the quarter and after a loss of $8,400,000 for the six months from discontinued operations. c-After losses of $200,000 for the quarter and $1,500,000 for the six months from discontinued operations.

title: BUS COMPANY IN THE BRONX TO HALT RUNS
description: One of the two private companies that provide express bus service between the Bronx and Manhattan said yesterday that it planned to discontinue the service on Aug. 4 The company, New York Bus Service in the northeast Bronx, carries 22,000 riders each weekday to midtown and Wall Street. It has offered the service, which costs $3 one way, since 1970.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAN FINDS WIFE AND 2 CHILDREN DEAD AT HOUSE
description: A 41-year-old woman and her two children were found dead in their home here early today, and the police said they believed that she had strangled them before asphyxiating herself.

title: Hunger in Summer
description: Words like soup kitchen, bread line and food pantry sound as if they belong to the 1930's, but soup kitchens, bread lines and food pantries are a sad fact of contemporary life. According to the New York State Committee Against Hunger, ''the most important conclusion to be drawn from the . . . documentation on emergency food programs is that they can no longer be considered 'emergency' programs at all.''

title: Destination: East Germany
description: The new United States Ambassador to East Germany is expected to be Francis J. Meehan, a veteran Foreign Service officer who previously served as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia and Poland.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR the past few months, Edward Bowley, who works in Lower Manhattan, has been absolutely fascinated - to say nothing about being puzzled - each time he glances down at a grating on Broad Street between Exchange Place and Wall Street.

title: F.B.I. Begins Arresting 35 in Black Hebrew Sect
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today began arresting 35 members of the Chicago-based Black Hebrew religious sect on numerous charges, including interstate transportation of stolen property, officials said.

title: GENERAL IS ACQUITTED IN EMBEZZLEMENT CASE
description: A retired two-star Air Force general was acquitted today of Federal charges that he embezzled money from a Swiss bank account that he administered for the Air Force to finance spy missions in the 1970's.

title: Making Their Moves
description: ''I've been in three real big tournaments - the nationals, one at Hunter and one where there were only grown-ups,'' said 10-year-old Patrick Ernst, who was taking careful notes yesterday of his moves so he could see later where he went wrong.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A & P)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Including a tax credit of $10,000,000. c-Including a tax credit of $5,250,000 and a pension credit of $135,000,000.

title: First Boston's Income Surges
description: First Boston Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter net income more than doubled, to $44.8 million, from $17.1 million a year earlier.

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOLDSMITH LIFTS CROWN STAKE
description: Sir James Goldsmith, continuing his takeover battle with management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, increased his interest in the San Francisco-based forest-products company yesterday to more than 40 percent.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NAFCO FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credit of $2,050,000 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: THE LIFE OF YOUR TIME
description: I liked ''Back to the Future'' as much as everybody said I would, though movies that fool around with time don't usually engage me.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Passenger Shot on Train
description: A passenger on a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train bound for New Canaan was shot today and a companion was charged with first-degree assault, the police said. The victim, Kim Lieu, 19 years old, of Jersey City, was shot in the chest at about 11 A.M., said the police, who identified his companion as Shak Ming Wong, 30, of New York. Mr. Lieu was taken to Stamford Hospital, where he was reported in stable condition.

title: FURRIERS FACE RENT PRESSURE
description: NEW YORK'S furriers have joined the groups of manufacturers being nudged from their traditional territory in Manhattan by rising rents and the demand for midtown office space.

title: BUSH, AFTER A MOMENT IN THE SUN, SLIPS BACK INTO REAGAN'S SHADOW
description: After eight hours as Acting President last Saturday, George Bush has quickly slipped back into the relative obscurity of the Vice Presidency.

title: Margeotes to Promote Tableware, Diamonds
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss was in the enviable position yesterday of having two new accounts to announce, each pegged at $4 million in billings.

title: UNION PLANS DRIVE TO ORGANIZE I.B.M.
description: Calling the International Business Machines Corporation ''viciously antiunion,'' the new head of the Communications Workers of America announced today that the union had begun a worldwide drive to organize the company's employees.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pasta Accord Is Approved
description: European Community agriculture ministers today approved a plan to reduce subsidies on pasta exports to the United States in an effort to defuse a trans-Atlantic trade dispute.

title: Iran Announces Date Of Presidential Election
description: Iran announced today that its fourth presidential election since the 1979 revolution would be held on Aug. 16.

title: Celtics Aide Rejects Nets
description: Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtics' assistant coach who was interviewed last Friday for the opening as the Nets' head coach, disqualified himself from consideration yesterday.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
$246 Million Issue Of Texas Bonds
description: A $246 million issue of San Antonio general obligation bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.02 percent for 8 3/4 percent bonds due in 2010, which underwriters led by Dillon, Read priced at 97 1/4.

title: HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Upjohn, Pfizer Gain; Lilly Off
description: Pfizer Inc. and the Upjohn Company, two major drug producers, reported higher earnings in the second quarter yesterday, while Eli Lilly & Company reported a slight decline.

title: Campbell Soup Plan Has a Predecessor
description: Recent news items about the Campbell Soup Company's plans for going national with its Campbell's Quality Soup Recipe Mix failed to note that this is at least the second time that the giant marketer of liquid soups is going to attempt to break into the dry soup category.

title: Mayoral Explanation
description: A new book about Mayor Koch called ''I, Koch'' reports that Mr. Koch once called Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a black Democrat of California, ''a Zulu warrior'' and ''a Watusi from Berkeley.''

title: Frontier Air Buyout Backed
description: Frontier Airlines' board approved the terms of an employee buyout of the carrier today in a move that would create the nation's first major privately owned commercial carrier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At the moment, it is one of the best guarded airports in the world. That is one less place to worry about.'' -David Kyd, spokesman for the International Air Transport Association, speaking of the Athens airport.

title: JIFFY LUBE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
DIEGO GIACOMETTI, 82, ARTISAN AND A DESIGNER OF FURNITURE
description: Diego Giacometti, the world renowned craftsman and the brother and partner of the sculptor-painter Alberto Giacometti, died of a heart attack Monday in the American Hospital in Paris. He was 82 years old and was preparing to return to his Paris home after a cataract operation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FINAL CUT: Dreams and Disaster in the Making of Heaven's Gate. By Steven Bach. 432 pages. Morrow. $19.95.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Times Mirror
description: The Times Mirror Company said that about 22.9 million shares had already been tendered under its offer to repurchase 7.5 million shares, or 10.9 percent of its common stock outstanding, for $60 each.

title: 3 Ex-G.E. Executives Charged in Defense Fraud
description: Three former senior executives with a division of the General Electric Company were indicted today on charges of defrauding the Defense Department of $800,000.

title: Turner Drops Trustee Plan
description: The Atlanta broadcaster Ted Turner withdrew a complex proposal today that might have allowed him to take control of the CBS television network without specific Federal approval.

title: THE EAST END GAME
IOWA FIRE THAT FORCED 10,000 TO FLEE IS QUELLED
description: Firefighters today controlled a blaze at an abandoned sewage plant that had spewed clouds of smoke containing hydrogen chloride for 21 hours.

title: The Line-Item Diversion
description: For more than a century, every President has wanted a veto power over individual items in appropriation bills. Congress, concerned more for its own power than for the Federal exchequer, has scotched the idea every time. The issue is once again before the Senate. It deserves the same fate.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER BUDGET COMPROMISE
description: In an effort to break the impasse over the Federal budget, House Democratic negotiators offered a compromise this afternoon that would reduce nonmilitary spending by $24 billion more than originally proposed over three years.

title: MUSIC: OHLSSON AND SITKOVETSKY AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: LIFE is not easy for former contest winners. They come before us with ready-made reputations as superior artists, certified by distinguished judges of instrumental and musical worth. As a result, feats that might draw gasps of appreciation when performed by nonmedalists tend to be taken for granted when performed by members of the contest elite. For them, being good is just not good enough.

title: SENATE APPROVES 29 APPOINTMENTS
description: By overwhelming margins, the Senate today confirmed three key diplomatic appointments, ending a monthlong battle with Senator Jesse Helms over nominations to State Department positions.

title: The Kaiser Health Plan In $95 Million Offering
description: The Kaiser Health Plan, one of the largest and financially strongest health care organizations in the country, is offering $95 million of bonds through the Colorado Health Facilities Authority to finance construction of a new hospital in Denver and to renovate other buildings.

title: EQUATORIAL COMMUNICATIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Union Deal
description: The First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said that it would acquire the Central Florida Bank Corporation for about $25 million in stock. First Union has already agreed to acquire the Atlantic Bancorporation of Jacksonville, Fla., and said it now plans to merge the two Florida banks when the acquisitions are completed later this year or early in 1986. First Union has assets of $8.2 billion, while Atlantic has assets of $3.8 billion and Central Florida Bank has $180 million.

title: JAZZ: PAT METHENY GROUP PERFORMS
description: THE guitarist Pat Metheny is one of the most creative and stylistically far-reaching assimilators of disparate jazz and pop idioms. With his longtime partner, the keyboardist and electronic wizard Lyle Mays, he has refined a multifaceted jazz-pop impressionism that blends Brazilian samba, American folk and the sunnier side of post be-bop jazz - along with contemporary electronics - into tone poems that, for all their derivations, maintain an identifiable personal stamp.

title: An Ace for Nicklaus
description: It has been seven years since he last won the British Open, but if a practice round is any gauge, Jack Nicklaus, a three-time Open winner, may be in contention again this year. Tuning up yesterday at the Royal St. George's course in Sandwich, England, where the 114th Open opens tomorrow, Nicklaus got a hole-in-one. The 156-yard eagle on the sixth hole was the 13th ace of his career and the first since the first round of the 1979 Open.

title: Reagan Whistles Dixie's Tune
description: Ronald Reagan knows how to whistle ''Dixie.'' Ask Tip O'Neill, the majority leader, who watched as the Southern wing of the Democratic majority in the House danced to the President's tune and gave him the votes he needed to win more aid for the Nicaraguan ''contras'' and thus escalate further the dangerous level of violence in Central America.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 31
MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADVICE ON COPING WITH OLD AGE
description: Dealing with the problems and challenges posed by aging - from accidents to arthritis, from senile dementia to sexuality - can be difficult. To help people cope with it, the National Institute on Aging in Bethesda, Md., has put together a handy guide called ''Age Pages.''

title: CITY STARTS ENFORCEMENT OF LATEST DROUGHT RULES
description: A force of 200 inspectors, surreptitiously carrying thermometers, is fanning out to check that temperatures in New York City office buildings cooled with city water are not below 78 degrees.

title: ARMY MEMO FAULTS AIR FORCE HANDLING OF MARINE WOUNDED
description: The handling of casualties by the Air Force after the 1983 truck bombing of the Marine Corps barracks in Lebanon is described as indefensible ''medically, morally, or ethically'' in an internal memorandum prepared by an Army officer.

title: Jersey Aides Report On Fatal Stable Fire
description: A stable fire that killed a three-member family and 16 horses Monday at a farm in Long Valley, N.J., apparently started in the floor or walls of an apartment in the barn, Morris County officials said.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
220 TEEN-AGE PILGRIMS IN THE MECCA OF DANCE
description: ''You see, we just want to dance,'' explained Kristin Brown, a 13-year-old ballet student from Dunwoody, Ga., who said she did not have time to go to the movies when her friends called, nor go to the parties - no, not even to hang out at the mall looking for boys. ''We probably aren't normal teen-agers,'' she said. ''But that's not all bad. Do you know any teen-agers?''

title: Weak Dollar's Beneficiaries
description: THE dollar's weakness against major world currencies is proving a boon to drug issues and certain other sectors of the stock market. By yesterday the dollar had dropped more than 15 percent in value from the high it set in February.

title: Fort Howard Mill
description: The Fort Howard Paper Company said it would build its new tissue mill on an 1,800-acre site in Effingham County, Ga. It said the first two paper machines and support facilities had estimated contruction costs of $450 million to $500 million and would be completed in the summer of 1987. The mill, planned as a four paper-machine operation, will provide about 1,000 permanent full-time jobs when all machines are installed.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 3o
HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,400,000 for the quarter 10,800,000 for the six months.

title: MAY '84 CHOICES CALLED STRICTLY MEDICAL
description: Key members of President Reagan's re-election team said today that the decision not to have additional medical tests after the discovery of a benign colon polyp in May 1984 was made solely by the President's doctors and was not influenced by campaign considerations.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STARTER BY DEFAULT IS ALL-STAR WINNER
description: LaMarr Hoyt had not pictured himself as the starting pitcher for the National League in the All-Star Game, and few others had envisioned him as a hero. Hoyt just wound up being both tonight.

title: 'FOREIGN LEGION' CYCLISTS MORE THAN CURIOSITY NOW
description: The ''foreign legion'' is conquering the Tour de France.

title: Three and a Half More Years!
description: When a President is stricken, the natural instinct of the nation is to close ranks. For a few months, probably until the end of 1985, the present mood of sympathy and unity is likely to prevail, but not for the last three and a half years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: NATIONAL PITCHERS OUTSHINE AMERICAN HITTERS
description: The Metrodome was supposed to yield some offense tonight and produce an All-Star Game filled with home runs and crazy bounces, but it refused. Instead the game belonged to the National League pitchers; to LaMarr Hoyt and Nolan Ryan.

title: Shift in Executives Set At Hammermill Paper
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said it planned to name its executive vice president, W. Craig McClelland to the post of chief executive, succeeding Albert F. Duval, who will retire when he turns 65 in November. Mr. McClelland has also been named president, succeeding Donald S. Leslie, who will assume the chairman's post from Mr. Duval.

title: CHARLES A. SUTER
description: Charles A. Suter, former president and chairman of the board of the Geigy Chemical Corporation, died in a nursing home in Arlesheim, Switzerland, Sunday.

title: ALASKA MUTUAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Junes 30
UPWARD MOBILITY FOR SALAD GREENS
description: SERVING salad greens as a hot vegetable is a culinary option that every household cook should keep in mind. For one thing, it prevents waste: Who has not felt guilty about discarding quantities of escarole, chicory and romaine that had lost the bloom of their youth in the refrigerator? For another, it provides a use for the leathery outer leaves.

title: That Art Gallery The U.S. Capitol
description: Most Americans do not think of the Capitol of the United States as an art gallery. But the building is filled with 785 pieces of art, many of vhem depicting scenes in American history.

title: Allis Pension Plan
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, saying it has too many retired employees and too little money, has asked permission to terminate a pension plan for thousands of production workers. The farm equipment manufacturer said it filed documents with the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to halt the plan at its West Allis, Wis., factory; in Minneapolis, and for former workers at five closed plants. The P.B.G.C., established in 1974, guarantees payment of benefits under private pension plans if it determines the plans' financing is no longer adequate.

title: GIANTS' KING PASSES A COMEBACK TEST
description: For Gordon King, today was a day to remember. For the first time in 19 1/2 months, after two operations on his broken left arm and hundreds of hours of tedious and often painful rehabilitation, he played football.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP-SEATTLE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRAM SETS 1,500-METER MARK OF 3:29.67
description: Steve Cram of Britain set a world record in the 1,500 meters tonight, running the distance in 3 minutes 29.67 seconds at the 10th Nikaia Grand Prix track meet.

title: CITY'S USE OF A WELFARE HOTEL BLOCKS HOUSING PLAN FOR POOR
description: A plan to rehabilitate low-income housing with a $10 million bank loan has been shelved because of the Koch administration's refusal to accept a stipulation that the city stop housing families with children in a welfare hotel near Times Square.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bloomingdale's has named Russel Stravitz executive vice president, stores merchandising, and Jeffrey Sherman executive vice president, finance and control and management information systems.

title: A CLASH ON FAMILY PLANNING AT KENYA PARLEY ON WOMEN
description: The exchange took place in a family planning workshop at the nongovernmental forum of the United Nations Decade for Women conference here. An Indian who opposes abortion told the audience that the way to control population is ''to get men to wait, to get their sexual desire under control.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Pepsico Inc. in some copies of Business Day yesterday misstated the company's 1983 nonfood sales. They amounted to $996 million.

title: BELGIAN KING REJECTS THE COALITION'S OFFER TO QUIT
description: The Prime Minister of Belgium submitted the resignation of his coalition Government today after it became split in the aftermath of a soccer stadium riot in May. But King Baudouin declined to accept the resignation, and Prime Minister Wilfried Martens agreed to govern with the same Cabinet.

title: FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
GLOBETROTTERS LOOKING FOR SOME NEW WIZARDS
description: Gradually, fitfully, the three women moving near the top of the key mastered the basics of the figure-eight weave. Soon they floated smoothly before Coach Larry (Gator) Rivers, stationed by the foul line, and, lo and behold, as the coach interspersed passing the basketball with making it undulate around his body to the familiar strains of Brother Bones's version of ''Sweet Georgia Brown,'' a bit of Harlem Globetrotter magic materialized in the steamy Charlotte Coliseum.

title: ABC Hires Reagan's Son
description: Ronald P. Reagan, the youngest of President Reagan's four children, has signed a contract to be an ''entertainment journalist'' for ABC-TV, the network said yesterday.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net gain of $1,500,000, or 6 cents a share, from reduction in United States pension.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ALAMITO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company declined to report revenues.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 15
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid April 10.

title: LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Senate Backs S.B.A. Funds
description: The Senate, rejecting a Reagan Administration plan to shut down the Small Business Administration, voted today to continue the agency for three years. The Senate bill, passed 94 to 3, authorizes $925 million through the fiscal year 1988.

title: BEIRUT TRIES SYRIAN-BACKED SECURITY
description: For the first time in a long time, militiamen were not in sight in Moslem West Beirut today. Instead, special security police officers in red berets moved in as a Syrian-sponsored security plan went into effect in West Beirut and at the international airport.

title: HEILEMAN, G BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
We, the Tardy People
description: The truth is, Washington is behind schedule in organizing for the 200th anniversary of the Constitution, and a certain amount of scurrying about now seems unavoidable. Despite Congressional authorization last year, President Reagan did not get around to naming the 17-member commission in charge of the celebration until two weeks ago or designating Chief Justice Warren E. Burger as its chairman.

title: SOVIET CALLS SECOND ROUND IN GENEVA AS UNSATISFACTORY AS THE FIRST
description: The Soviet Government press agency said today that the second round of arms talks in Geneva had been as unsatisfactory as the first and had been marred by an American ''smokescreen of empty words and indefinite promises.''

title: INSILICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Another Tulane Plea
description: Gary Kranz of New Rochelle, N.Y., became the fourth person yesterday to plead guilty to sports bribery charges in the Tulane basketball point-shaving scandal. Kranz, a 21-year-old former student at Tulane, pleaded guilty to 10 counts of sports bribery and two counts of conspiracy and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in the case. A spokesman for the district attorney's office said nine charges of distribution of cocaine and one count of possession of cocaine were dropped.

title: Weinhauer Squabble
description: Lawyers representing Arizona State and Bob Weinhauer, who was dismissed as the school's basketball coach last week after completing three years of a five-year commitment, were meeting yesterday in an effort to arrive at a financial settlement. But J. Russell Nelson, the Arizona State president, said he did not know if the matter could be resolved by a Friday deadline Weinhauer has set. According to Weinhauer's lawyer, if the university does not agree by then to pay the full $300,000 it had promised Weinhauer last month, he will take the matter to court. . . . Loris Smith, the general manager of the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, which will be the site of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's East Regional tournament next March, said the N.C.A.A. had informed him that the arena had been selected as the site of the 1987 East Regionals, marking the first time that a single facility has been chosen for the tournament two years in a row.

title: REAGAN'S MEDICAL FUTURE
description: For months and years to come President Reagan's physicians will be confronting the most important uncertainty in their patient's case: Has any cancer eluded their search? Does any still lurk in the President's body, seeding new growth elsewhere?

title: KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN STILL PLANS TO SEE GORBACHEV
description: Despite his cancer operation and convalescence, President Reaan intends to go through with plans to meet the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in November and to participate in talks with the Chinese President here next week, the White House said today.

title: SOTHEBY'S TO RECALL HEBREW BOOKS IT SOLD
description: Sotheby's agreed yesterday to recall from buyers a collection of rare Hebrew books and manuscripts sold at auction last summer and to redistribute them to institutions where they would be available for viewing by the public.

title: KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect for a 2-for-1 stock split payable July 15.

title: 7 YOUTHS IN JERSEY ARRESTED IN USE OF COMPUTERS TO GET SECRET DATA
description: Seven young people have been arrested and charged with conspiring to use their home computers to exchange stolen credit-card numbers and information on how to make free long-distance telephone calls, how to make explosives and how to call coded phone numbers in the Pentagon.

title: Congress;   The Nitty-Gritty of the Conference
description: After the House adopted legislation outlining Pentagon programs for the coming fiscal year, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, had a little chat with Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Honeywell Net Off 29%
description: Honeywell Inc. announced today that net income for the second quarter was $52.5 million, or $1.14 a share, down 29 percent from the $74.3 million, or $1.59 a share, earned in the same period a year ago. The company attributed the decline to the downturn in the computer industry and a weakness in the capital spending markets. Revenue was $1.55 billion, up from $1.47 billion.

title: Telephone Is Growing As Medium
description: LEVINE, HUNTLEY, SCHMIDT & BEAVER has quietly been working since June 5 for the International Information Network, which provides entertainment as well as information and an advertising medium.

title: THE ART OF SMALL-TOWN TEXAS BARBECUE
description: THERE is probably no more intrinsically American food than Texas barbecue, bound up as it is with images of powerful politicians, rich oil men and range hands on horseback. It is available widely, but in its purest form it is beef brisket, shoulder clod or sausage, served on butcher paper with cottony white bread in a storefront with peeling paint in a small town in central Texas. Accept no substitutes, say the connoisseurs.

title: Oceanic Changes
description: The Oceanic Society, a 16-year-old conservation group, is moving its headquarters to Washington this summer from Stamford, Conn. In addition to conducting education and research activities, the society will monitor and evaluate Government action in the capital and try to strengthen its role in stressing ''an environmental perspective in ocean policy-making.'' At the same time, the society will sell Oceans, its 40,000-circulation magazine, to a group of private investors headed by Christopher Roosevelt. Mr. Roosevelt, now president of the society, will be succeeded in that role by Clifton E. Curtis, former executive vice president.

title: 'FAERIE TALE THEATER' TRIBUTE
description: LAST March, Showtime's ''Faerie Tale Theater'' decided to celebrate its third anniversary of production with a costume party in Hollywood. Scenes from the event are included in ''Faerie Tale Theater's Greatest Moments,'' a self-congratulatory birthday card that can be seen on the pay-cable Showtime channel tonight at 8 o'clock. The festivities are a trifle limp, but this award-winning series deserves all the tribute it can get.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE APPROVES 1986 WATER BILL
description: The House today approved the first appropriation bill for 1986, a $15.3 billion energy and water program.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

''If I have to get up early, before 9 o'clock, I don't have breakfast except for freshly squeezed orange juice, a one-a-day vitamin and calcium. When I get up at 10 or 11, which is almost every day, I have brunch, a marvelous Mexican dish with crispy bacon, refried beans and whole-kernel corn. It's damn good and I've named it, 'A person could die with a smile on their face.' ''

title: A CELEBRATION OF LIFE ON SITE OF FIRST ATOM BLAST 40 YEARS AGO
description: Army rules said no speeches, protests or demonstrations would be allowed today at a low-key commemoration of the 40th anniversary of the world's first nuclear bomb explosion. But prayers were permitted, and a small ecumenical peace group held the Episcopal mass of the eucharist, a liturgical celebration of everlasting life, at the spot where many people feel that man first put global death within his reach.

title: LESLIE ARENDS, 40-YEAR HOUSE MEMBER, DIES
description: Leslie C. Arends, who represented Illinois for 40 years in Congress and served as House Republican whip for more than 30 years before he retired in 1975, died of a heart attack yesterday at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 89 years old and maintained a home in Washington as well as in Naples.

title: LOSS FOR HOTELS IN STRIKE IS PUT AT $16 MILLION
description: The 27-day New York City hotel strike cost the affected hotels $16.2 million in business, translating into $1.48 million in lost tax revenues, a new analysis says.

title: SEMINAR ENVISIONS U.S.-SOVIET MARS VENTURE

title: Another Author
description: Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky, is writing a book about the experience of being investigated for a year and a half by the Department of Justice. He doesn't have a title or a publisher yet, but he has engaged a literary agent, Edward J. Acton of New York, who recently negotiated a contract reportedly exceeding $1 million with Random House for a book by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Mr. Hubbard says he was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 19 months after he ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Kentucky in 1979.

title: A True Value For the Dollar
description: THE fall of the dollar in the past two weeks has shaken financial markets throughout the world. What is the dollar really worth - or, as the economists would put it, at what level will it reach a stable equilibrium? Will it get there gradually, making a so-called smooth landing, with benign effects on this country's industries and agriculture that have been hurt by an overvalued dollar, or will it plummet to a crash landing, with serious damage to the United States and the international economy?

Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, released the report by the Congressional Research Service. He said that the report also indicated the United States would remain heavily dependent on foreign borrowing through 1990.

And when each Yankee settled into his stance moments later the catcher Ozzie Virgil remembered them smiling. Probably out of gratitude for being able to smile.

title: 'BON APPETIT' IS AT THEIR FINGERTIPS

''I'm glad you're here tonight,'' she told her hearing-impaired students. ''I want to share my love of cooking with you. I hope you have a wonderful time.''

title: Many Questions At Wake Forest
description: There is nothing like the unexpected and unexplained resignation of a basketball coach to stir the Atlantic Coast Conference with a sense of intrigue. And so right now there are a lot of questions, though far fewer answers, about Carl Tacy's departure Monday from Wake Forest. ''After careful thought and deliberation,'' Tacy said in a statement announcing his resignation, ''I have reached a decision to make a job change which I believe is in the best interest of my family, the university and me.'' There was no elaboration whatever, and the coach has declined to talk to reporters about his decision.

SONNY ROLLINS, ALONE
description: SONNY ROLLINS has been saying that the unaccompanied tenor saxophone concert that he will give on Friday evening in the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden as part of its Summergarden series may be his last concert of this type. What he has not said, until he was asked the other day, is that it will also be the first. He has been playing a capella selections as part of his performances with his groups for many years but this will be the first time that he has done a full evening public concert as an unaccompanied saxophonist.

title: New York Needs a Housing Coalition
description: New York suffers from a housing shortage that has left it with an apartment vacancy rate of barely 2 percent. This condition has panicked apartment seekers, crammed illicit tenants into every third public housing unit and overwhelmed the shelters for the homeless. Yet despite the crisis, which threatens to undermine the city's economy, New York had reason to be content with the recent inaction of its Legislature.

title: Mets Get Paciorek

Paciorek, who has also played for the Dodgers, the Braves and the Mariners, was hitting .246 in 46 games - 37 as an outfielder - before the White Sox designated him for assignment four days ago.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
STAGE: SALOME JENS IN SEXTON POEMS
description: ''IT is difficult for one woman/ to act out a whole play,'' the poet Anne Sexton wrote; ''The play is my life,/my solo act.'' The invitation in those lines from ''The Play'' is irresistible. And the most enthralling hour of poetry in town now, and a magnificent moment of theater, is Salome Jens's enactment of 21 Sexton poems in ''. . . About Anne'' at the Women's Art Center. Her performance recalls the outlines of Mrs. Sexton's life, but what is more important, it reminds one of the sweep and range of her art, the leaping metaphors and startling images. For unlike some other stagings of Mrs. Sexton's poetry - her writings have been turned into drama and opera several times in the last 10 years - Miss Jens's concentrates not on the neurosis and eventual suicide of the poet in 1974, but on her poetry. Miss Jens's sense of a poetic line and her confident delivery of hundreds of them is most gratifying.

title: HIRSCHFELD IN LONDON
description: They were all there, clustered closely together on the second floor of London's National Theater. There was Tom Stoppard, looking like a very long and languid Mick Jagger, and Sir John Gielgud, fastidiously squinting over a neat beard, and Peter Ustinov, and Charlton Heston, and Beatrice Lillie, and Cole Porter, and even Franz Kafka, with his Mickey Mouse ears and black eyebrows and big luminous eyes.
