title: Former Officers Form Pooled Fund Venture
description: In his years as chief lending officer of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, George R. Baker had ample exposure to the financial problems of the bank's corporate borrowers. And, Gerald C. Meyers faced corporate financial and management problems of his own when he was chief executive of the American Motors Corporation.

title: ACCORD IS NEAR TO BAR DRILLING OFF WEST COAST
description: After more than a decade of debate between the Interior Department and members of the California Congressional delegation, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel today announced a tentative agreement to protect California's outer continental shelf from drilling for oil until the year 2000.

title: Letter: On Northern Ireland;   Bias in Ulster Is a U.S. Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Paine Webber in Black
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that it earned $12.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, in contrast to a $4 million loss a year earlier. Revenues increased 30.9 percent, to $493.8 million, from $377.3 million. Elsewhere, earnings at Jefferies Group Inc. were off 12 percent, to $2.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 31 cents.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (AT&T)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue figures are net of access charges and share earnings and net income reflect revised depreciation rates.

title: DELAY IN EUROPE'S SPACE PLAN
description: Representatives of the 10 Common Market countries and seven other Western European nations failed today to agree on the first steps of a program designed to compete with the United States antisatellite defense program.

title: More Than Mere Iceboxes
description: ''This is the remains of DDL.''

REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MICROSCOPIC BEADS MADE IN SPACE GO ON SALE
description: The Government today announced the sale of the first products made in space, plastic beads so small that 18,000 of them could fit on the head of a pin.

title: KEY STATE DEPARTMENT AIDE: ROZANNE LEJEANNE RIDGWAY
description: In 1957, when Rozanne LeJeanne Ridgway joined the United States Foreign Service, women were not particularly welcome, she recalls.

S. West Inc. and a writedown of $50.5 million for the 6 months from equipment depreciation.

title: Oil Price Cut By Egypt Seen
description: Egypt has decided to cut oil prices but has yet to decide how big the reductions will be, a senior Oil Ministry official said today.

title: Audrey Liberman Wed To Marcus S. Matson
description: Audrey Liberman, a daughter of Mrs. Julian Bach of New York and the late Herman N. Liberman Jr., was married yesterday to Marcus Scott Matson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Robert Matson of Chapel Hill, N.C. Justice Ira Gammerman of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather.

title: Belgian Premier Forges Limited 2-Month Agenda
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens called together his feuding deputies today and forged a limited agenda for the Government's last two months in office.

title: Bridge: An Excellent Slam Contract Foiled by Bad Trump Break
description: Teams led by Judy Becker, Peter Leventritt and Warren Rosner clashed Tuesday night at the Cavendish Club, 105 East 73d Street, in the first stage of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout final. This prominent event honors Waldemar von Zedtwitz, a great veteran who died just as the 1984-85 competition began last October.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Second quarter and 6 month results reflect the acquisition of Sullair Corp. in November 1984.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Why Subsidize the Monied Classes?
description: There was good news for taste buds the other day as the marketers of Coke put their old cola back on the shelves. But there was bad news for the economy as budget-battlers in Washington shelved COLA reform.

title: Brief on Death Penalty Is Barred in Spy Case
description: A Federal district judge has refused to allow eight Congressmen and a conservative legal group, the Washington Legal Foundation, to file a brief arguing that the death penalty could be applied to one of four men accused of being in a naval spy ring.

title: Still Hostile to a Woman's Right
description: As ten thousand women meet in Kenya to observe the end of the United Nations' Decade for Women, the Reagan Administration tried again this week to set back the calendar in its own benighted way. It asked the Supreme Court to overturn the 1973 decision recognizing a woman's right to decide to end a pregnancy.

title: Getting Well
description: The reference books are somewhat sketchy on the subject, but it appears that the Cleveland Indians may have at least approached a major league record: Most pitchers eligible to come off the disabled list immediately after the All-Star break. The Indians' number is four - Roy Smith, Rick Behenna, Ernie Camacho and Dave Von Ohlen - and, with that amount of reclaimed riches, Manager Pat Corrales could be forgiven for underscoring the obvious when he warned the rest of his staff: ''This is not a good time to be pitching bad.''

title: AMR Profits Sharply Higher
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that second-quarter net income was $173.9 million, or $2.98 a share, more than double the $71.4 million, or $1.36 a common share, of a year ago.

title: MULTIVEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. OPENS HEARING ON UNSAFE BRIDGES
description: Fearing what it called an unknown potential for disaster, the National Transportation Safety Board began hearings here today into the extent to which the corrosion of underwater steel pilings threatens road and highway bridges, especially in the Southeast.

GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-Including a net charge of $20,000,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and six months for writeoffs and shutdown costs related to the closure of a facility on June 30. c-Including a net gain of about $3,800,000, or five cents a share, for the quarter and six months from the sale of a plastics division and real estate.

title: LEBANON BAST WORRIES RED CROSS
description: Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today that the use of a stolen Red Cross vehicle in a car bombing in southern Lebanon this week had seriously hampered the agency's work in Lebanon.

title: GIANTS' SIMMS ACCEPTS 5-YEAR, $3.8 MILLION PACT
description: The wait ended today for the Giants. Phil Simms, their starting quarterback, agreed to a $3.8 million, five-year contract and reported to training camp here two days late.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 8
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $405,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and $228,000 for the nine months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $293,000 for the quarter and $883,000 for the nine months.

title: Soviet Reveals Airliner Crash
description: The Tashkent newspaper Pravda Vostoka said today that a Soviet airliner crashed July 10 on a flight from Karshi, via Ufa, to Leningrad, killing all aboard. Aeroflot uses the three-engine Tupolev-154, which carries up to 150 passengers, on the route. Most Soviet airliners fly with all seats occupied.

title: Atlanta Zoo Plan Approved
description: The Atlanta City Council has approved a $25 million, eight-year plan for the renovation of the Atlanta Zoo, which came under fire last year after the mysterious deaths of several animals. At present, zoo operations are handled by the city. Under the plan approved Monday, operations would be transferred to the Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium Authority next year.

title: General Foods Income
description: The General Foods Corporation said yesterday that its operating earnings improved during the fiscal first quarter, ended June 29.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net charge of $1,100,000 to establish a reserve for the disposition of two subsidiaries.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $440,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including securities gains of $1,173,000 for the latest 6 months and $43,000 for the year-ago 6 months.

title: Another Far Piece
description: The Socialist Government of the tiny Seychelles Islands in the Indian Ocean has taken steps to improve ties with the United States by retaining Peter Teeley, former press secretary to Vice President Bush, to represent its business dealings in this country. Mr. Teeley and David R. Macdonald, a Washington lawyer, have received an $18,000 retainer from the Seychelles and will draw monthly fees of $6,000.

title: National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation said it would invest $200 million to build a second steel caster and other modernized equipment for its Great Lakes facilities, increasing to more than 90 percent the portion of National Steel's metal produced by the modern continuous casting process. Other equipment for the division, near Detroit, includes a ladle metallurgy system for molten steel.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Including again of $2,172,000, or 5 cents a share, from the retirement of debentures.

title: STAGE: TEATRO DUE DI PARMA
description: Primed by the 1984 Olympic Arts Festival in Los Angeles, America has been deluged of late by international avant-garde mixed-media troupes that include a foreign language as part of the media they mix.

title: Sea-Land Meeting
description: Harold C. Simmons, who holds 9.1 percent of the Sea-Land Corporation, has requested a meeting with Joseph F. Abely, chairman of the New Jersey-based shipping concern, according to a copy of a letter enclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Simmons, a Dallas-based investor, said he thought the two men could both achieve their objectives ''in a peaceable and non-costly way.'' Mr. Simmons has filed notification with the Federal Trade Commission of the possibility that he may buy more than 15 percent of Sea-Land's shares outstanding.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,654,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for lease tax credits.

title: Comcast Gives A Storer Plan
description: The Comcast Corporation, which has bid $2.1 billion for Storer Communications Inc., said yesterday that Storer's seven television stations would be sold if it succeeded in acquiring the Miami broadcasting operation.

title: Sticking With Winners
description: They led the United States team to a 5-0 opening-round sweep of Japan, so it's hardly surprising that Arthur Ashe, the Davis Cup captain, has decided to stick with his winners for the second-round clash against West Germany next month. He again named Eliot Teltscher and Aaron Krickstein to handle the singles competition and reappointed the doubles team of Robert Seguso and Ken Flach.

title: JUDGE TELLS NEW YORK TO SUPERVISE ITS FOSTER CHILDREN BEYOND AGE 18
description: A State Supreme Court justice, ruling in a New York City case, yesterday upheld efforts by advocates for the homeless to enforce supervision for thousands of young people between the ages of 18 and 21 who leave foster care.

title: SALVADOR AIR ROLE IN WAR INCREASES
description: El Salvador's Air Force has come to play an essential role in the Government's war against leftist rebel forces and has almost doubled in size in the last year, according to both United States and Salvadoran officials.

title: The Budget Bustle
description: A White House official familiar with the maneuvering involved in the search for a successor to David A. Stockman as budget director says that James C. Miller 3d, the 43-year-old chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, appears to be the front runner.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium. Opener of a four-game weekend series and a 14-game home stand for the Mets, who last played at home July 3. The Mets have won seven out of eight games against Atlanta this season. (Television - SportsChannel and WTBS 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. This is the opener of a weekend series, the final four meetings between the clubs this year and the beginning of a 14-game, 15-day trip for the Yankees, who will not be home until Aug. 2 against the White Sox. (Radio -WABC 770, 1:15 P.M.) Golf British Open, at Royal St. George's Country Club, Sandwich, England. Seve Ballesteros's highest finishes on the PGA Tour were two third places last year, but he won the British Open, a non-PGA event. Bernhard Langer of West Germany, the Masters champion, will also be competing, but Andy North, the United States Open champion, will not. (Television -ESPN 9 A.M., live.) Ladies PGA Boston Five Classic, at Danvers, Mass., opening round. Laurie Rinker, who led or shared the lead in all four rounds of her first L.P.G.A. victory in this event last year, will be back to defend her title. Other Events ATHLETICS: Third annual Garden State Games. The major competition is the water polo at Rahway River Park, beginning at 6 P.M. Maccabiah Games at Tel Aviv. BASKETBALL: Wildwood Aces vs. Westchester Golden Apples at Hofstra, first game of doubleheader, 5:30 P.M. (Radio - WFAS 1230, 5:30 P.M.) Springfield Fame vs.

title: Tainted Watermelon Traced
description: A watermelon contaminated with the pesticide aldicarb was traced today to a farm in northern Florida, the Alabama Department of Agriculture and Industries reported. The department said tests of other watermelons taken Tuesday from the same load as the tainted melon had not turned up any other contamination.

title: Rickover's Condition Stable
description: Hyman G. Rickover, the retired admiral known as the father of the nuclear submarine fleet, remains ''in stable condition'' at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center in suburban Maryland, a spokesman at the medical center said today. The 85-year-old admiral, who retired in 1981 after 63 years in the Navy, was hospitalized July 4 after suffering a stroke.

title: SHULTZ, IN HONOLULU, DENOUNCES NEW ZEALAND
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz renewed criticism of New Zealand today, accusing it of undermining the United States nuclear deterrent and weakening its own security.

title: Sohio Petroleum
description: The Sohio Petroleum Company, an exploration and production subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said it would restructure the company and cut its 4,300-employee work force by about 600 workers. The company said it would close its western region office in San Francisco and its Rocky Mountain division office in Denver, merging some of its functions with those of its Dallas office. The Sohio Alaska Petroleum Company would assume production duties of the San Francisco office while its exploration functions would be handled by the Houston headquarters.

title: COAST BANK HAS LOSS OF $338 MILLION
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank company after Citicorp, stunned the financial world yesterday by announcing that it lost $338 million in the second quarter.

title: YANKEES GET ALLEN TO BOLSTER BULLPEN
description: The much-discussed deal for Neil Allen, the inconsistent relief pitcher considered important to the Yankee hopes in the American League East race, was finally completed today.

title: Leading Enlisted Man Is Named by the Navy
description: William H. Plackett, a 28-year veteran of the Navy, was selected today as that service's senior enlisted man by Adm. James D. Watkins.

title: Europe Starts Research Unit
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France would contribute $87 million this year toward the Eureka program for joint European high-technology research and promised more Government support in the future.

Smaller Raise in Rates For Telephones Urged
description: A rate increase requested by the New York Telephone Company should be limited to $119.2 million, two administrative law judges of the State Public Service Commission recommended today.

title: CONCERT: 60'S ROCK AT PIER 84
description: THE ''Happy Together'' Tour, a nostalgic package of four 1960's pop groups, rolled into New York on Tuesday evening and drew 7,000 fans to Pier 84, on the Hudson River at 44th Street. Neither the Turtles, the Grass Roots, the Buckinghams, Gary Lewis and the Playboys, nor the special guest star, Tommy James, belong to the heavyweight league of 60's pop stars. Even at their peak of popularity, between 1965 and 1971, these acts specialized in prefab teen-oriented pop of little social consequence. But at its best, as in the 1967 Turtles hit, ''Happy Together,'' this style, heavily influenced by the early Beatles, can still express a refreshing high-spirited optimism.

title: MINIATURE SOLAR PANELS FOR CHARGING BATTERIES
description: PHOTOVOLTAIC cells convert solar energy into electricity. This technology, used in the telecommunications and aerospace industries, is also used in solar-powered watches and calculators, which have been on the market for several years. Now, the Chronar Corporation, based in Princeton, N.J., has brought out two new miniature solar panels, called amorphous silicon photovoltaic panels. Each is a piece of glass coated with silicon and metal oxide; when sunlight hits the panel, an electric current is produced and light is converted into power.

description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson comes down firmly on the side of goodness tonight in ''Jesse Jackson: On the Record,'' the conclusion of a two-part interview that began last week. Goodness is an expendable commodity in politics; absolute goodness is unnerving. Mr. Jackson is unnerving.

title: ON THE FIRE LINE IN HELLGATE CANYON
description: The heavy drone of a DC-4 filled the sky as it swooped across the side of a grassy mountain engulfed in flame and smoke. Flying close to the treetops, the plane dropped its load of fire retardant slurry, a red gash in the sky that drifted slowly to the ground ahead of the advancing flames.

title: EASY, CHEAP WAYS TO GET NEW PLANTS
description: TRAYS of newly rooted plants are sheltered from the noonday sun beneath the dense jungle that is Victor Nelson's West Side Manhattan garden. Although city gardening can be expensive, Mr. Nelson has discovered that one method of controlling costs is to multiply by propagating. ''I also make friends with other gardeners and trade,'' he added.

description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has sought control of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, increased his stake yesterday in the forest-products company to nearly 42 percent, a spokesman said.

description: Alma H. Johnson, her hair shot through with gray, stood on her stoop on Yates Road in South Jamaica and surveyed the midafternoon activity.

title: Li Xiannian, Tough Survivor
description: A year or so ago, the 76-year-old President of China, Li Xiannian, chatting with me - we're about the same age - said: ''You and I are on the way out, but I think we are all happy to postpone our meeting with the Lord Yangwang -that is, God, as you call him.''

title: Octagon House Coming Full Circle
description: Back in 1814, after the British burned the White House, President Madison and his wife, Dolley, moved a couple of blocks west into a handsome mansion known as Octagon House. They remained there while the White House, charred and smudged, was being restored.

title: VICTORY WITHIN REACH OF WEARY HINAULT
description: Injured, weary and ailing, Bernard Hinault scraped through the Pyrenees today with a diminished lead in the Tour de France bicycle race, but one he is almost certain to maintain now that the mountains are past.

One of the latter was Dom Camera, the U.S.F.L.'s director of marketing since its founding in 1982, whose departure was forestalled by Commissioner Harry Usher's unusual arrangements.

description: The debate over the timing of President Reagan's cancer treatment intensified today when a doctor who examined Mr. Reagan said his medical team had recommended in March that the President receive a thorough examination of his colon as soon as possible.

description: Elizabeth Wanjara heard about the Decade for Women Conference on a transistor radio at her home in the town of Bungoma in western Kenya, 450 miles from here. With eight local women, she saved up by selling honey and knitting sweaters and bought herself a bus ticket.

The Road to the Majors
description: He's still a bit rusty after a six-week layoff, but at least his 42-year-old arm doesn't squeak, and after a brief tuneup in the minors Tommy John is on his way back to the majors. John, the former all-star pitcher who was dropped by the California Angels in June and signed by the Oakland A's last week, completed a stint with Modesto of the Class A California League Tuesday night, giving up 8 hits and 5 earned runs in six innings of an 8-6 victory over Salinas. He is expected to start for Oakland in Toronto on Sunday.

This fall, he will join the academy full time when he takes an endowed chair at the Lubin Graduate School of Business at Pace University in Manhattan.

description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $2,379,000 for the quarter and $2,992,000 for the 6 months.

title: The Lords Must Be Crazy
description: The first response is: They can't do this to us. They can't be serious about disrupting what could be the most exciting baseball season in New York since 1951. They couldn't cheapen the pennant races with both the Mets and Yankees trying to catch the front-runners.

title: A.T.& T.'S PROFITS UP ONLY 1.3%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that earnings rose only 1.3 percent in the quarter ended June 30, to $461 million, from $455 million. Revenues declined, to $8.55 billion, from $8.58 billion.

title: BELL ATLANTIC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SANTA FE SOUTHERN PACIFIC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRONTIER'S BUYOUT 'A LAST ALTERNATIVE'
description: Frontier Airlines agreed to an employee stock buyout at $17 a share as ''a last alternative'' after several other attempts to take the company private failed, Joseph R. O'Gorman Jr., the airline's president and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: U.S. Adding to U.N. Agency
description: The United States Government is adding $8 million to its 1985 contribution to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian refugees, the organization said today. The increase brings the total American donation this year to $75 million, according to a statement by the agency. The agency said it had cut more than $43 million from its budget in the last six months but still needed an additional $8 million for this year and was approaching other governments for voluntary contributions.

title: JAPAN COURT AGAIN DEPLORES INEQUITABLE ELECTION SYSTEM
description: Japan's Supreme Court ruled today that the most recent parliamentary elections, held in 1983, were unconstitutional because of procedural inequities that made some votes worth far more than others.

title: The Penalty for a Body Lying in a Hazard
description: To the Editor:

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCULPTURE IN WOOD, CERAMICS AND PAPER
description: Muted colors, organic forms and a meditative mood characterize ''Formations,'' an exhibition of 60 works in wood, ceramics and paper at the Twining Gallery.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SANDINISTA ASSERTS WAR HAS TAKEN 12,000 LIVES
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said this week that the war against United States-backed rebels had cost the lives of 12,000 Nicaraguans in the last four years.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIVING LIFE TO HANDEL'S STATIC OPERAS
description: THE Pepsico Summerfare's Handel festival has offered fascinating insights into the staging of this master's operas. Actually, two of the three productions did: Andrew Porter's sober staging of ''Tamerlane,'' employing a minimal production style that would only work with singers of enormous vocal skill or personal charisma, merely reaffirmed the difficulties that conventional opera companies face with Handel's operatic oeuvre.

title: THE CARE OF TEAK BENCHES
description: Benches of teakwood have been popular in the gardens and parks of England since the 1920's. There was good reason for this - the benches were solid indeed, and teak with its high natural oil content could withstand the elements all year round without finish or maintenance. It was also a convenient way of recycling the enormous amount of decking salvaged from the scrapped naval vessels and merchant ships left over from World War I. When left to its own resources, teak will gradually weather down and take on a silvery-gray look, one that blends in well in a garden setting. The more formal spic-and-span look resembling light straw was the order of the day for decking at sea, and this was achieved simply by using a salt water hose and stiff-bristle brooms or holystones - pieces of sandstone used for scrubbing a ship's deck. Badly soiled areas would be treated with hot fresh water, soft soap and washing soda, and a stiff scrubbing.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DETECTOR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: RECITAL: HIGGS, ORGANIST
description: THE free summer Tuesday-evening organ recital series at the Riverside Church continued this week with a fine offering from David Higgs. As associate organist of this church, he clearly knows its huge Aeolian-Skinner instrument intimately, and the result was a beautifully judged, coloristic array of registrations. And if the program never built to a really thrilling climax, that may well be mostly an inevitable consequence of this huge instrument and its spacious acoustical ambiance.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SHOPPERS in hardware stores and home centers can find many new tools and hardware items designed for home projects. A selection follows.

title: How the Trade War Spreads
description: America's copper mines are suffering from a long drought in demand for raw materials. Workers and communities that depend on a healthy copper industry need help in finding new sources of income. But the industry's chronic problem does not justify the demand that the United States oppose all international investment in cheaper copper.

title: A 19TH-CENTURY VILLAGE INTACT AND FULL OF VICTORIAN DETAILING
description: TUCKED away on the tip of an island in the St. Lawrence River, in the shadow of the bridge between the United States and Canada, is a Victorian summer colony that has spanned the passage of a century remarkably intact.

P.L.O. Aide Target of Bomb
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's acting chief representative in Cyprus, Malath Abdo, escaped uninjured when a bomb wrecked his home in a Nicosia suburb early today, the police and P.L.O. sources said. Mr. Abdo, 39 years old, and his family were asleep when the bomb exploded.

title: Greenpeace Gets A New Ship as Gift
description: Anonymous donors in the United States have provided a new ship for the conservation group Greenpeace, whose flagship was sunk in New Zealand last week, a Greenpeace spokesman said today.

title: In Re Politics v. Punches
description: In pressing its social agenda on a reluctant Supreme Court, the Reagan Administration appears to have concluded that there are more important goals than winning cases.

title: THEATER: 'MAX'S MILLIONS'
description: CUT by half, ''Max's Millions,'' now at the No Smoking Playhouse, could be a satisfying campy diversion. As it is, the playwrights have decided to indulge themselves instead of their audience. There are good lines in it, to be sure, and more than a little comic ingenuity, but two hours of this kind of broad farce is one too many.

title: MORE THAN A TOKEN CHANCE FOR A SUBWAY SERIES
description: The scene in Chicago refuses to fade. In a cramped office just off the visitors' clubhouse at Comiskey Park, Yogi Berra stood bravely and faced the news media one final time. He had been dismissed as the Yankees' manager just 16 games into the season, a move still considered hasty by some, and now Billy Martin was coming back again.

title: UNIVERSITY FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Changes in Cuban Housing Since the Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: CINEMAX EXPERIMENTING IN COMEDY
description: Comedy specials are in high demand by the pay-cable services. ''Comedy is very important to us,'' confirmed Bridget Potter, senior vice president in charge of original programming for both Home Box Office and Cinemax. ''If you look at the grosses for successful comedy films, you can understand why.''

title: MAN FOUND SLAIN IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A 43-year-old sales clerk at the Rand McNally & Company map store in Manhattan was found shot to death in Central Park Tuesday evening, the police said.

title: Rockwell Net Rises by 21%
description: The Rockwell International Corporation reported today that profits for the three months ended June 30 reached $160.2 million, or $1.07 a share, a 21 percent rise from $132.9 million, or 87 cents a share, in the 1984 period. Earnings per share were $1.07, up 23 percent from 87 cents a year earlier.

Miss Monroe, a frequent participant at the Marlboro Music Festival, studied with Charles Castleman, David Cerone and Ivan Galamian.

The offering is being made on a negotiated basis, in contrast to the competitive bidding for most general obligation offerings.

He is accused of exploiting his influence while deputy borough president on behalf of a business partner and is charged with 12 violations of the City Charter's code of ethics.

title: DRAFT STUDY PUTS ACID RAIN DAMAGE AT $5 BILLION FOR 17 STATES

title: Bethesda: A Place of Healing For Elite and Non-Elite
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt was enchanted by the site of a small, run-down farm with a small pond, in suburban Maryland. On automobile trips into the countryside, the President often asked his chauffeur to drive by the pond, which reminded him of the biblical Pool of Bethesda, a place of healing.

title: VOLCKER CALLS INFLATION CURBED
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that despite a surge in the money supply in May and June, inflation was well under control and that no tightening of monetary policy was necessary.

title: NATIONAL'S DOMINANCE STILL A MYSTERY
description: There are theories, but none of them really seem to matter anymore. For some reason, the National League keeps winning the All-Star Game.

title: U.S.-Texas Thrift Pact
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had reached an agreement with L. L. Bowman 3d, the Texas savings and loan commissioner, that would permit the bank board to resume processing applications for Federal deposit insurance from thrift institutions chartered by Texas.

Ballet Summer Workshop

Advanced students from the school's summer session will perform in the workshop, which is free, in new ballets by Daniel Duell, David McNaughton and Janis Pforsich.

title: ROGER SEYDOUX, FRENCH DIPLOMAT, DIES AT 77
description: Roger Seydoux, a French diplomat who was delegate to the United Nations from 1962 to 1967, died in a Paris hospital on July 3 after treatment for an undisclosed illness. He was 77 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE

title: Coming Back
description: If you were wondering:

Or, if Nordic is more to your interest, you might draw on the names of a very few men, most notably Bill Koch. But mention women's cross-country, and the only thing you're likely to draw is a blank.

title: STUDY SEES GAINS FROM U.S.-SOVIET SPACE EFFORTS
description: A Congressional study has concluded that valuable gains in science and important insights into Soviet society could flow from renewed space cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: OWNERS' LOSSES QUESTIONED
description: The Yankees' travel expenses are twice as much as the major league average, the Mets receive $5 million less than the Yankees for local broadcasting rights and the Los Angeles Dodgers pay their front-office personnel salaries that are four times the baseball average. The Dodgers, though, are ''the best managed team in sports'' and are ''baseball's answer to the Denver mint.''

description: The 21st century is said to hold a lot in store for this tiny 17th-century town. In the bush beyond Bitterness Street and Tranquillity Road, a giant rocket base is being built.

DR. BERNICE H. FLEISS
description: Dr. Bernice H. Fleiss, a former associate professor and dean of students at Hunter College, died at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem Monday. She was 67 years old.

title: HOW FED ZEROES IN ON A NEW ECONOMY
description: When the Federal Reserve Board broke the back of inflation in 1982, Paul A. Volcker, its chairman, performed his own brand of financial wizardry by encouraging his fellow board members to keep a tight rein on the money supply when the economy cried out for more. Now he is apparently determined to fight a new public enemy - the trade deficit - by keeping a loose grip on the money reins and fostering low interest rates.

title: CONTROL DATA FALLS
description: The Sperry Corporation, an apparent exception to an industry trend, reported yesterday that its earnings for the latest quarter more than doubled, as a result in part of strong revenues from its large computers serving businesses.

title: SENATE CONFEREES SPURN HOUSE PLAN ON BUDGET ACCORD
description: After a day of budget exchanges that were often bitter, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today rejected the compromise offer made by the House Democrats and said he did ''not see a way'' to reach an accord.

title: Yields at Banks Steady
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday, following three months of steady declines, while yields on money market mutual funds showed a slight downturn for the week.

title: NEW YORK IS AWASH BUT ITS RESERVOIRS AREN'T
description: This drought, the city's worst since the record drought of 1964, has become known as the Drought When It Rained. And rained. And rained. And rained. Almost six inches, or two inches above normal, fell on the city in May. More than four inches, or more than an inch above normal, came down in June. And this week it poured. Where are the browned-out lawns, the scraggly trees and the parched-looking parks of the droughts of yesteryear?

title: HERS
description: WHEN I was a child, I attended a little yeshiva in Trenton, where the boys studied Talmud and the girls went downstairs and made tuna fish sandwiches. The rabbi at our school - our principal -wrapped an enormous bandage up to one wrist so that he would not, God forbid, ever have to shake a woman's hand. Our rabbi did not touch women.

Under the bill, which takes effect Sept. 1, promoters must provide $7,500 in medical insurance and $100,000 in life insurance.

title: Technology;   Cell Cultures As 'Factories'
