Inside the vessels are thin, hollow plastic fibers, performing many of the same functions as capillaries. They circulate a mixture of nutrients and oxygen meant to simulate blood.

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gannett's Net Rises 20.3%
description: The Gannett Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 20.3 percent, to $71.8 million, or 90 cents a share, from $59.7 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating revenue increased to $556.9 million, up 13.3 percent from $491.7 million It was the 71st consecutive quarter of earnings gains since the communications company went public in 1967.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BID TO NAME REYNOLDS ENDED
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said this evening that the Reagan Administration did not plan further efforts to have William Bradford Reynolds, the Justice Department's civil rights chief, confirmed as Associate Attorney General.

title: PRESIDENT PLACED ON A LIQUID DIET AFTER 'BEST NIGHT'
description: President Reagan was removed from intravenous feeding today and placed on a liquid diet after sleeping through the night for the first time in the best of the five nights he has spent in the hospital, the White House said.

title: STAGE: BRENDA CURRIN IN 'SISTER AND MISS LEXIE'
description: AT first glance, Brenda Currin does not look like a possessed woman. With her simple cotton-print dress, sensible brown leather shoes and parted blond hair tucked behind large ears, the actress could be an anonymous high-school girl daydreaming in the back of a classroom. Once she speaks, however, it's clear that the Mississippi River is coursing through her veins. In ''Sister and Miss Lexie,'' her show at the Second Stage, Miss Currin's voice, body and spirit are completely inhabited by the small-town eccentrics and Gothic demons that haunt the Southern imagination of the writer Eudora Welty.

title: WHITE HOUSE CURBS QUESTIONS ON REAGAN'S HEALTH
description: The White House said today that speculation about President Reagan's medical examinations last year was ''distasteful'' and strongly defended efforts to limit interviews with doctors now treating Mr. Reagan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Monday about Washington trivia incorrectly reported Robert Todd Lincoln's whereabouts when his father, President Lincoln, was assassinated. He was in the White House and did not witness the assassination.

title: BOLD EFFECTS, COUNTRY STYLE, FOR A WEEKEND HOUSE
description: FEW people buy the perfect weekend house.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CUOMO TAKES CASE TO HOUSE
description: Governor Cuomo took his case against President Reagan's tax revision plan to Congress for the first time today, calling the arguments of the President and his supporters ''palpably contradictory'' and shaking some legislators with his sharp tongue.

title: Soviet Spokesman Rebuffs Questions on Reagan Health
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman today declined to say whether President Reagan's health could affect relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, saying it was unethical to speculate about a leader's ailments.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 25.

title: FREE-SPIRITED ESIGN FROM THE WEST
description: DURING his 60-year career, the Oklahoma architect Bruce Goff may not have achieved national notoriety, but cars regularly screeched to a halt in front of his houses. They were news in their Midwestern neighborhoods.

title: Dollar Lowest in Year
description: Rumors about the President's health and BankAmerica's soundness pushed the dollar to its lowest levels since last July. Page D18.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $371,000 for the quarter and $1,086,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $53,000 for the quarter and $439,000 for the 6 months.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., the chemical company based in Wayne, N.J., has elected Robert N. Hiatt group vice president, effective next Monday.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million for the quarter and $18.9 million for the six months and income of $75.7 million for the six months from an accounting change.

title: A $1,358,567.21 'UTOPIA' ALONG THE RAHWAY RIVER
description: The good citizens of Winfield gave themselves a terrific party in September. They hired a clown and a disk jockey, and had hot dogs and hamburgers and corn on the cob and a 4-by-5-foot cake, three tiers high, fashioned in the shape of the town, which, from the air, looks something like a pork chop.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUBBLE, HARVEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable August 9.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: July 18, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M.

title: FRANCE DENOUNCES U.S. AMBASSADOR
description: The French Foreign Ministry today protested what it called the ''unacceptable character'' of comments on French politics made to a newspaper by the departing United States Ambassador, Evan Galbraith.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $361,000 for the quarter and $934,000 for the nine months.

title: Trotters Pick 8 Women
description: The Harlem Globetrotters tonight selected eight women to attend the barnstorming basketball team's training camp in September. There, the Globetrotters are expected to pick one or two of them to become the first female Trotters.

title: AIR FORCE OFFICER'S MEMO SUGGESTS U.S. PLANS LONG STAY IN HONDURAS
description: An internal memorandum written by an Air Force civil engineer in Honduras suggests that the United States is planning to maintain a major military presence in that country for at least three to five years.

title: SAVERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the year-ago periods unavailable because the company went public on January 23.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Wheeling Backed on Wage Cuts
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday granted a request by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to void its labor contract with the United Steelworkers union.

title: BRITISH OPEN COURSE: DIFFICULT TO FIND
description: Seve Ballesteros remembers well the first time he saw the awesome expanse of Royal St. George's Golf Club, where he will begin defense of his British Open championship Thursday.

title: AIM TELEPHONES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gain of $16,000 from tax credit.

title: EASTERN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORATORIUM ON INCINERATORS IS URGED
description: A moratorium on garbage-burning incinerators, including those planned in New York City to ease the burden on rapidly filling dumps, was urged today by an influential environmental lobbying group.

title: MORGENTHAU ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR 4TH TERM
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan formally announced yesterday his candidacy for a fourth term, saying his office jails more defendants than any other prosecutor's office in the state.

title: WILLIAM H. GIVENS Jr.
description: William Harrison Givens Jr., senior vice president for pension operations of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Sunday.

title: YOUTH'S COMPUTER SEIZED IN JERSEY WAS USED FOR MAGAZINE 'BULLETIN BOARD'
description: The editor and publisher of a magazine for computer enthusiasts said today that one of the seven home computers seized last week by New Jersey law-enforcement officials was used to maintain an electronic bulletin board operated by the magazine.

title: Bonds Overcome Early Loss
description: Bond prices rose slightly and short-term interest rates drifted lower yesterday despite comments by Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, that were interpreted by some analysts as ruling out any immediate action by the Fed to help push interest rates lower.

title: Felled by Asthma
description: Razor Ruddoch, Canada's top heavyweight contender, said he was retiring from the ring at the age of 22 because of a recurring problem with asthma that he had managed to keep secret throughout his 11-1-1 professional career.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STAAR SURGICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Terpsichore at College
description: Alvin Ailey will become Professor Ailey on Sept. 1, when he takes his post as Distinguished Professor at the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A Far Piece
description: As Garrison Keillor might put it, he'll be a far piece from his beloved Lake Wobegon when he dines today with two Minnesota Democrats, Representatives Bruce F. Vento and Gerry Sikorski, and other members of Congress in the vast confines of the Rayburn House Office Building. Mr. Keillor, as devoted fans of his Saturday night radio broadcasts know, is the creator and host of ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' a folksy account of the doings in the mythical Minnesota village he calls Lake Wobegon.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $74,850,000.

title: DANIEL B. GOLDBERG
description: Daniel B. Goldberg, a former general solicitor in the law department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died, apparently of a heart attack, in a rafting accident near Santa Fe, N.M., last Thursday. He was 70 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: Norfolk Is Backed In Bid for Conrail
description: The Federal share of Conrail should be sold to the Norfolk Southern Corporation, the state Transportation Department said today. In return for the endorsement, the department said the company had agreed, among other things, to give the state the West Side line in Manhattan so trains from Albany and the north could go into Pennsylvania Station and to pay the $20 million estimated cost of the planned Harlem River freight yard.

title: COURT ACTS IN SUIT ON APPLIANCES
description: Saying the Reagan Administration ''openly violated Congressional intent,'' a Federal appeals court directed the Department of Energy to consider setting standards to make 13 home appliances more energy efficient.

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UAL Unit Sold
description: UAL Inc., parent of United AirLines, said it had sold its GAB Business Services Inc. unit to SGS North America Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Switzerland-based Societe Generale de Surveillance Holding S.A. GAB, which had revenues of more than $190 million in 1984, provides claims adjustment services to insurance underwriters through a nationwide network of 500 offices. Terms were not disclosed.

title: JUDITH FORST, CINDERELLA
description: The coloratura mezzo-soprano -that is, a mezzo-soprano who can sing runs, trills and embellishments -used to be a fabulous rarity in the opera world, but now that Marilyn Horne and Teresa Berganza have shown the way, more singers are training themselves in that direction.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Rim Wrecker
description: It's his season off, but Darryl Dawkins of the Nets was hard at work yesterday, slam-dunking up a storm. It was one of those youth clinics, this one the Mobile Big Apple Games clinic for 1,000 youngsters at the Felt Forum, and Dawkins, who teaches at some 60 instructional camps a summer, seemed to be in his element.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Canizaro, the principal owner of the peripatetic Portland Breakers, has missed a $300,000 payroll payment and is having trouble rounding up the additional capital he says he needs to keep the team afloat. But whatever happens, he says, the Breakers' moving days are over.

title: PENTAGON SAYS EUROPEAN FORCES HAVE PLAN TO AID TERROR VICTIMS
description: The Defense Department said today that the United States military command in Europe had initiated a medical plan to handle casualties of terrorist attacks in that region.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   A Fable of Flood and Drought
description: Sit still, dear children, for a story about ants and grasshoppers, neighbors afflicted by the same drought. The ants urged each other to stop taking showers and watering lawns and soon had water to spare. The grasshoppers kept splashing about as if the rains had never ended.

title: Carrier Doubles Cut in Work Force
description: The Carrier Corporation said that it would lay off 350 hourly and 30 salaried workers, effective Friday.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON WEAPON SYSTEMS
description: A House-Senate conference committee on military programs reached a tentative agreement today extending the life of many of the Pentagon's most bitterly contested weapon systems. The compromise would allow deployment of 50 MX missiles in existing silos, authorize the Air Force to proceed with testing of new antisatellite weapons and set a $2.75 billion ceiling on unrestricted research for President Reagan's proposed missile defense program.

title: Advertising;   Spending Could Top $100 Billion
description: ADVERTISING spending in the United States, which stood at $33.3 billion for the Bicentennial year in 1976, may pass $100 billion next year, a terrifying fact only to those who have seen the flick ''The Blob.''

title: Kirk Cleared by School
description: An investigation by Memphis State University has found no evidence to support reports that Coach Dana Kirk offered $10,000 to relatives of Keith Lee while Lee was being recruited four years ago, Thomas Carpenter, the university president, said today.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Afghans Report an Advance
description: The Afghan Government said today that its troops had won a victory over Moslem guerrillas in the 100-mile-long Panjsher Valley near the Pakistani border. Rebel leaders say their forces have the upper hand in the valley. Independent journalists are not allowed into the battle areas, so the conflicting reports cannot be resolved.

title: CABARET: SKAH SHAH AT S.O.B.'S
description: SKAH SHAH brought the infectious lilt of the Haitian compas to Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street, on Wednesday night. The 13-piece band - horns, percussion, guitars and keyboard -is a major draw in the Haitian community, and it delivers the breezy syncopations of Haitian dance music almost casually.

title: WAYNE KING, 84, A SAXOPHONIST
description: Wayne King, a saxophonist and bandleader whose soft, purring waltzes attracted a huge following in ballrooms, on records and on the radio for more than a decade before World War II, died Tuesday at his home in Paradise Valley, Ariz. He was 84 years old.

title: DIAMANDA GALAS, AVANT-GARDE DIVA
description: DIAMANDA GALAS is regarded by some as the Maria Callas of avant-garde music. To others, she is ''the soprano who screams.'' Either way, she is a fearless pioneer in the experimental field of integrating vocal music and electronics.

title: Strike Three?
description: The average salary for a major-league baseball player now stands at $329,000, a kingly sum to most fans. Yet the players say they have reason to strike on Aug. 6 unless they get better terms in a new contract.

title: Tough Luck
description: Hard-luck stories of the year: Sid Fernandez is only 3-5 for the Mets this season, but his earned run average in those five losses is 2.38. His American League counterpart is Toronto's Dave Stieb (9-5), whose e.r.a. in defeat is 2.68.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an inventory writedown of $35,000,000. c-Net income.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income includes $1,690,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RODINO TO PROPOSE IMMIGRATION BILL IN HOUSE
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he would introduce a comprehensive immigration bill next week. He said he planned to make the issue one of his top legislative priorities this year.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-After charges of $108.6 million for the quarter and $188.3 million for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $10.2 million for the quarter and $30.7 million for the year.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PACIFIC BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERSHISER DOWNS CARDS, 2-1
description: Bill Russell scored on Len Matuszek's sacrifice fly in the seventh inning tonight to break a 1-1 tie as the Los Angeles Dodgers edged the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-1.

title: RECORD 64 GIVES O'CONNOR THE LEAD
description: No one thought to mention any Irishmen when predicting that a number of non-Americans had a good chance of winning the 114th British Open. Seve Ballesteros of Spain, Bernhard Langer of West Germany and Greg Norman of Australia came to mind.

title: COURT RULING HINTS AT BROADER IMPACT
description: To child-care advocates, it is a classic case of using the courts to compel public officials to fulfill their legal obligations.

title: WHAT'S NEW AROUND TOWN IN OUTDOOR SCULPTURE
description: IF there is no feast of outdoor sculpture this summer, there is also no famine. This is the year in which the widely acclaimed Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum opened in Long Island City. And the controversy over Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc,'' in Federal Plaza, has probably focused more attention on public sculpture than ever before.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $42,000 for the latest first quarter and $121,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Interlan Inc. on March 1, 1985, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
US HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $993 from the sale of land a year ago. c-Net loss including a gain of $6,164,000 from the sale of land.

title: POP: FISHBONE PERFORMS
description: THE six Los Angeles teen-agers who make up Fishbone mugged, leaped, whooped, giggled, staggered, shouted and knocked out songs at manic tempos in the band's New York debut, Wednesday at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place.

title: MIDTOWN ATTACKER OF 9 WOMEN IN OFFICE BUILINGS IS SOUGHT
description: Nine women have been attacked at knifepoint -five of them sexually assaulted - in five midtown Manhattan office buildings since June 11, and the police said yesterday that they were searching for one man in the case.

title: SUSANNE K. LANGER, PHILOSOPHER, IS DEAD AT 89
description: Susanne K. Langer, a leading American philosopher whose work in esthetics profoundly affected 20th-century thinking in psychology and the social sciences, died Wednesday at her home in Old Lyme, Conn. She was 89 years old.

title: SENATE REBUFFS REAGAN OVER VETOES
description: The Senate today brushed aside a strongly worded appeal from President Reagan and failed to end a filibuster blocking legislation that would give the President vastly increased power to veto spending measures.

title: Candor and Policy
description: The spokesmen have told me more than I really wanted to know about President Reagan's colon. It is obviously important to keep the country, and thus the world, so well informed about the health of the man at America's helm that there is no room for rumor or invidious speculation.

title: DSC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HBO PRESENTS WHOOPI GOLDBERG
description: HOME BOX OFFICE, the pay-cable channel, has not been partial to taping stage productions, preferring instead to focus on such special ''live'' material as comedy performances. With ''Whoopi Goldberg Direct From Broadway,'' which is having its premiere tomorrow at 10 P.M., HBO has managed to get both. This hourlong production was taped last March at the Lyceum Theater, where Whoopi Goldberg, in a production supervised by Mike Nichols, had been holding forth in a one-woman show since the previous October. The television sampling, directed by Thomas Schlamme, was produced by Whoop Inc. in association with Broadway Video and D.I.R. Broadcasting.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Congress;   Morning After the Night the Budget Talks Sank
description: Why did it happen? And what next?

title: Nets Court Rodgers
description: The confusion that has clouded the Nets' search for a new head coach continued yesterday. At the same time that Dave Wohl, an assistant for the Los Angeles Lakers, was being interviewed, Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtic assistant who disqualified himself from consideration Tuesday because he did not want to move his family to New Jersey, was being given new consideration.

title: YELLOW FREIGHT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CREATIVE COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax benefits of $42,400 for the quarter and $53,400 for the nine months. c-Net loss.

title: ABC'S PROFIT UP BY 1%
description: The American Broadcasting Companies reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose 1 percent, to $73.1 million, or $2.51 a share, from $72.4 million, or $2.49 a share, a year earlier..

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Liberians Are Severing Relations With Soviet
description: Liberia announced today that it was severing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union after having arrested students who it said had given military secrets to Soviet diplomats here.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Seuffert Band Concert
description: The Seuffert Band will give two free outdoor performances this weekend in Queens.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had been named primary contractor in a $29 million deal to modernize New York State's Capitol District Communications System.

title: BROADWAY
description: SUMMER doldrums have settled over some areas of the theater but they're not even hovering around Musical Theater Works at Second Avenue and St. Marks Place. That's where Staret-The Directors Company is presenting a modern version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and revving up for a production next month of a movieland musical called ''Tales of Tinseltown.''

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LESSONS OF THE HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: Americans have notoriously short memories, but before we entirely forget the Beirut hostage crisis, we ought to try to make some sense of what it taught us about the new generation of Middle Eastern youth whose rage and alienation have drawn them to Islamic fundamentalism. Americans will not find it easy to come to terms with these young people, but we had better recognize now that we cannot hope to deal with them merely by talking tough.

title: DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FILM: 'MAN WITH ONE RED SHOE'
description: ''THE MAN WITH ONE RED SHOE'' was produced by Victor Drai, who also produced ''The Woman in Red'' and appears to be making a career out of demonstrating how poorly French farce can travel. Like ''The Woman in Red,'' which was based more successfully on a light Gallic comedy, ''The Man With One Red Shoe'' loses a lot in translation. As ''The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe,'' with Pierre Richard playing a perfect straight man in the title role, it was a slender but amusing comedy of errors. Now it's mostly just slight, and none of it elicits more than the mildest of chuckles.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Decision Seen On Merrill Post
description: Merrill Lynch & Company board members said yesterday they expected that Daniel P. Tully would be named president on Monday, after a regular monthly board meeting.

title: 2 Phone Units Show Gains
description: Two of the seven regional phone companies formed from last year's breakup of the Bell System reported higher earnings yesterday. The companies, the BellSouth Corporation and U S West Inc., credited higher demand for their services and vigorous cost control.

title: Ogden Sets Spinoff For 7 Subsidiaries
description: The Ogden Corporation is spinning off its troubled Avondale Shipyards and six other subsidiaries in a $375 million deal intended to give the new company's employees ownership of the corporation, company officials said today. The cash needed for the deal will be financed with a $190 million bank loan and $80 million in excess assets available from closing down the Ogden pension plan.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Ed Lynch, 7-5 this season, is 1-1 against the Braves and 4-2 against them in his career. Zane Smith, the Braves' starter, is 5-5 but has lost twice to the Mets. (Television - Channel 9 and WTBS, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. Joe Cowley, 1-1 against the Twins and 7-3 over all, is scheduled to start against Minnesota's John Butcher (6-8). (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8:30 P.M.) Boardsailing Myers's Rum Windsurfer Championships, at Sea Bright, N.J., 10:30 A.M. Between 150 and 200 competitors, including Chip Winans and Allie Rowe, defending men's and women's champions, begin three days of competition in slalom, distance, freestyle and triangle racing that can be viewed from the beach in the New Jersey Shore resort. The slalom is in the morning and the distance competition begins at 2:15 P.M. Golf British Open, at Royal St. George's Country Club, Sandwich, England, second round. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M., live) Ladies PGA Boston Five Classic, at Jamesville, N.Y., second round. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. Nihilator, winner of seven races in seven starts this season, not only has the speed but also the inside post in the $1,018,000 Meadowlands Pace. Nihilator, part of a five-horse Lou Guida-Robert Boni entry, is 1-5 on the early line to become the second horse to win this race, the richest pace for 3-year-olds, and the $2 million Woodrow Wilson, the richest pace for 2-year-olds.

title: VAGRANT HELD IN VANDALISM OF HISTORIC JEWISH CEMETERY
description: A pick-wielding vagrant damaged seven graves at a tiny burial ground tucked amid the bustle of Chinatown Monday night, desecrating the site of what is said to have been the first Jewish cemetery in the United States, the police said.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Murder Trial Jury Adjourns
description: After a second day of deliberation yesterday, the jury in the trial of Christopher Thomas, a Bronx man charged with killing 10 people in Brooklyn on Palm Sunday last year, adjourned without reaching a verdict. The jurors sent a note to State Supreme Court Justice Ronald J. Aiello saying that they were suffering from ''collective exhaustion.'' Deliberations are to resume this morning.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Europe High-Tech Plan
description: A conference of 17 West European nations has ended without agreement on how to start a joint high-technology project to compete with President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' program. The delegates at the meeting reaffirmed their political commitment to the French-inspired Eureka project but agreed on little more than to hold another meeting in West Germany before Nov. 15.

title: No Longer Anonymous
description: New York is a city of strangers, an endless series of brief encounters between anonymous people.

title: Participatory Dances
description: ''What are the children doing there?'' one man asked, as he watched youngsters weaving among the dancers at the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument in Riverside Park.

title: Dow Off by 7.05 In Profit Taking
description: News of weaker than expected economic growth in the second quarter touched off a bout of profit taking yesterday on Wall Street, pushing stock prices down after two consecutive big gains.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARSH & MCLENNAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Diner's Journal
description: OLD restaurants never die, they just change menus and tablecloths and reopen under a new name. Get ready for Metropolis, the reincarnation of the former DDL Foodshow on Columbus Avenue at 82d Street, a fancy food emporium and restaurant owned by Dino De Laurentiis that closed last year.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
VOLCKER'S REASONING ON DOLLAR
description: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that a further sharp decline in the dollar could spell trouble for the American economy and that the Fed had no intention of ''pushing it lower'' through monetary policy.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split payable July 29 to holders of record July 10.

title: Accounts
description: Chroma Copy International's U.S. advertising to David H. Block Advertising, Montclair, N.J.

title: Comptroller Selection
description: Robert L. Clarke, a Houston banking lawyer, Republican fund-raiser and friend of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, has been chosen by President Reagan for nomination as the next Comptroller of the Currency, an Administration official said today.

title: ARAB PAPER IN JERUSALEM LISTS PARLEY CANDIDATES
description: An Arab newspaper in Jerusalem today published a list of names of Palestinians suggested by Yasir Arafat for inclusion in a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation for preparatory Middle East peace talks with the United States.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (SAN DIEGO, CALIF)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: THE TOKYO QUARTET AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: ONE of the things that makes Mozart Mozart is that his surprises surprise, even after one knows them by heart. The beginning of the ''Dissonant'' Quartet, which the Tokyo String Quartet played in the recital preceding its Mostly Mozart concert Tuesday, still sounds strange, almost Berg-like. The Tokyo itself has something of a related quality, in that one remembers above all the polish and grace of their execution, yet can be newly surprised by those very qualities at each concert.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $492,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of the company's Home Health-Care operation. c-Including a gain of $2,133,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of an investment and a charge of $1,091,000 for the quarter and 6 months relating to republication expenses and inventory writeoff.

title: A & M FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 11
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect one week of operations of 49 Pizza Hut outlets acquired June 5 from El Kram Inc.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS BOYCOTTING WHITES' STORES
description: For a fourth successive day, thousands of blacks boycotted white-run shops in the restive Eastern Cape today, in a rare spillage of black protest into white areas.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Including charges of $1,075,000 for the quarter and $1,466,000 for the year to cover the costs of phasing out a division. c-Net income.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Button Woman Of Capitol Hill
description: Geraldine Thompson is a Capitol Hill elevator operator who not only pushes buttons but collects them as well. And she loves her collection so much she takes it to work with her every day.

title: Lebanon Tickets Banned
description: A United States ban on the sale of airline tickets to Lebanon took effect today as the White House endorsed the order, a Transportation Department spokesman said. Under the order, issued by the department Tuesday in response to last month's Trans World Airlines hijacking, all foreign and domestic airlines are prohibited from selling tickets in the United States with Lebanon as a destination even if the flights originate in another country and never enter the United States.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JOHN HENRY MAY BE RETIRED
description: John Henry, the richest race horse ever and the most popular of his time, has developed a tendon injury that may force his retirement, the 10-year-old gelding's trainer said yesterday.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Horse Racing;   Northern Dancer Colt Favorite for Sales
description: The stretch limos and private jets are cluttering up Lexington, Ky., again this weekend for the annual summer yearling sales. Most of the world's top breeders and buyers will warm up their bankrolls and bidding fingers beginning today at the slightly less glittery Fasig-Tipton sale, then really unload Monday and Tuesday at the Keeneland select sale.

title: WAR GOES ON IN INDONESIA ISLE
description: At the Cemetery of the Heroes in a quiet corner of this former capital of Portuguese Timor, new rows of simple white headstones on the graves of fallen Indonesians offer silent evidence that a decade-long guerrilla war is not yet over.

title: SCREEN: 'THE LEGEND OF BILLIE JEAN' OPENS
description: ''THE LEGEND OF BILLIE JEAN,'' which opens today at the Gemini and other theaters, is another unfortunate film about a nobody who gets to be a somebody, 80's-style. This entails appearing on television, getting one's name on Frisbees and T-shirts and ''I H So-and-So'' bumper stickers, being mentioned on talk shows, and winning the spontaneous applause of the crowd. Here, as in ''Turk 182!,'' the main character need hardly do anything in order to win this adulation.

title: MALPRACTICE COSTS VS. HEALTH CARE FOR WOMEN
description: About a week before they are scheduled to give birth, expectant mothers in Molokai, Hawaii, travel by airplane to Honolulu so that they can deliver their babies at the University of Hawaii Medical Center. The women have little choice. The four local physicians gave up obstetrics in January when they learned that they would each have to pay $24,000 a year for malpractice insurance.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of of Continental Baking Co., which was acquired in October 1984. Results for the year-ago 9 months reflect a net charge of $19.9 million related to the closing of the company's San Diego tuna cannery.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUCTIONS
description: FURNITURE from Truman Capote's New York apartment at United Nations Plaza - including chairs, tables, settees, bedside commodes and mirrors - will be auctioned at 10 A.M. Wednesday at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street.

title: Nominee Not Expected To Alter Antitrust Unit
description: Federal antitrust policy would not be substantially changed under Douglas H. Ginsburg, according to friends and associates of President Reagan's nominee to head the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: Solidarity Leaders Seek Boycott by Polish Voters
description: Underground leaders of the banned Solidarity union appealed to voters today to boycott Poland's first parliamentary elections since the 1980 labor upheaval.

title: Dining Out Guide: Salads
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Wallenberg Search Leads to a Soviet Dead End
description: To the Editor:

title: Phoenix Is Selling $117 Million Issue
description: A $117 million issue of Phoenix general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 4.50 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.60 percent in 1990, 7.75 percent in 1995, 8.30 percent in 2000 and 8.70 percent in 2006 through 2009. The underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch from Jerusalem last Thursday on the conviction of 15 Jewish settlers for terrorist acts against Arabs said a suspect in one case, Era Rappaport, fled Israel before the trial began and was being sought by the Israeli police. Mr. Rappaport, who holds American and Israeli citizenship, is reported to be living in the New York area.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Still in Training
description: There's nothing unusual about a boxer's running around a golf course to get in shape. But, at age 71 and suffering from diabetes, Jersey Joe Walcott has found it more prudent to walk around the 18-hole course by his home in Merchantville, N.J. No, the former heavyweight champion is not considering a comeback fight against Joe Frazier. He just wants to be in shape for a testimonial dinner on his behalf next Wednesday in Atlantic City.

title: 'July Funfest' in Queens
description: An afternoon of music, dance and storytelling is planned Sunday at the ''July Funfest'' in the auditorium of Public School 156, 229th Street and 137th Avenue, in Laurelton.

title: Important Hirings On Three Fronts
description: New people are expected in important jobs at Levy, Flaxman & Associates, an ad agency; Motor Trend, a magazine, and the A. C. Nielsen Company, the great measurer of things, particularly audiences.

title: BILLS GET FERRAGAMO
description: Vince Ferragamo, who lost his starting job as the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback last season, was traded yesterday to the Buffalo Bills for Tony Hunter, a tight end from Notre Dame and the Bills' first-round draft choice in 1983.

title: CRUMP, E H COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the six months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $44,000 for the quarter and $331,000 for the six months.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 19, 1985
description: The Economy

title: 56 ARRESTED IN SOUTH KOREA IN A CRACKDOWN ON STUDENTS
description: The South Korean Government has arrested 56 students and is seeking more than 20 others for what it termed anti-Government activities that aid North Korea, according to reports reaching here.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL BANKING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Plastic Surgeon Tries TV
description: DR. ELI MILCH, 37-year-old founder and operator of Park East Institute for Plastic Surgery, has tried newspaper and radio advertising and now is headed for television.

title: Ralston Purina Up 56%
description: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that it earned $57.1 million, or 71 cents a share, in its third fiscal quarter, up 56 percent, from $36.6 million, or 42 cents a share, in the same period of 1984. Sales rose to $1.39 billion, from $1.17 billion. William P. Stiritz, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the earnings of the grocery products and pet food businesses continued to be favorable.

title: AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANIES INC (ABC) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Aide Says Israel Plans To Free 100 Captives
description: Israel will free 100 Lebanese next week as part of its phased release of prisoners rounded up in southern Lebanon, a defense official said today.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EDMUND WILSON. By David Castronovo. 205 pages. Ungar. $15.50. DAVID CASTRONOVO opens his study of Edmund Wilson by emphasizing Wilson's clarity and directness, his affinities with the 18th-century Enlightenment, the extent to which he cultivated ''the aesthetics of plain communication.'' You may well be left wondering how far the work of such a writer really calls for an extended introduction, and in many ways it undoubtedly speaks for itself. But that still leaves room for a survey like the one Mr. Castronovo has undertaken, an account that attempts to set Wilson's career in perspective and sort out its dominant themes.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss after a nonrecurring charge of $1,438,000 related to the writedown of certain property, plant and equipment and for nonrecurring assessments by governmental and other agencies. c-After a nonrecurring charge of $3,641,000 related to the cost of consolidating certain videotronics operations, the closing of the company's production department and a related reserve for loss on disposal of excess fixed assets.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: LORI SINGER, who for a while seemed to be playing every teen-age role that wasn't offered to Molly Ringwald or Ally Sheedy, has finally grown up. In fact, it will be hard to think of her as a teen-ager again after her appearance as Maddy, the sexy, intense, career-driven Government agent in the Stan Dragoti comedy ''The Man With One Red Shoe,'' which opens today (review on page C13).

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE WONDERS OF AFRICAN ART EXPLORED IN 2 EXHIBITIONS
description: JUST by happenstance, two noteworthy shows of African art have opened this week, at two different institutions. They're interesting not only for their subject matter, which is engrossing enough (and not unrelated), but also because they illustrate two very different approaches - one traditional, the other innovative - to the presentation of work that is at once art and anthropology. The traditional presentation is ''The Art of Cameroon'' at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street (through Oct. 15), and the innovative one - as might be guessed from the title - is ''Sets, Series and Ensembles in African Art,'' at the Center for African Art, 54 East 68th Street (through Oct. 20).

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART: 'KARL BODMER'S AMERICA' AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: ''KARL BODMER'S AMERICA'' has arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art without fanfare. Yet as an account of pre-industrial America and its Indians that is also art, it deserves as much attention as any blockbuster.

title: GOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUYING TIME AT SHEA STADIUM
description: Gary Garter hobbled through the corridor toward the manager's office. You couldn't say there was pain on his face but you could say there was chagrin, the embarrassment an athlete feels when his body betrays him. ''What's up, Skip?'' Carter chirped. ''I don't know. What's up with you?'' Dave Johnson said, closing the door behind them.

title: THAIS MAY BAR VIETNAMESE BOAT PEOPLE
description: A Thai official said today that Vietnamese boat people might lose their right to asylum in Thailand because resettlement in third countries was proceeding too slowly.

title: NO PROGRESS IN BASEBALL TALKS
description: Baseball's labor negotiators met yesterday for the first time since the players set an Aug. 6 strike deadline, then recessed the talks for a new collective-bargaining agreement until Monday.

title: RECITAL: MANCINI DEBUT
description: ROCHELLE MANCINI'S New York recital debut at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, early Wednesday evening was the work of an excellent singer. Before the first note, one could look at the program - which interestingly compared a variety of styles and subjects - and already appreciate Miss Mancini's thoughtfulness.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LILY-TULIP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,024,000 for the quarter and $2,862,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bridge: A Major Event Will Be Held In New York This Weekend
description: This weekend, for the first time this year, enthusiasts in New York City have an opportunity to play in a major tournament without going outside the city boundaries. Scheduled events in the tournament, the Big Apple Regional at the Sheraton Centre, 53d Street and Seventh Avenue, are: Today, mixed pairs and individual, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams and newcomers pairs, 8 P.M.

title: PANEL TELLS OF SPENDING ABUSES
description: More than $2 billion of the money Americans are expected to spend on cataract surgery in 1985 will be lost to waste, fraud and abuse by doctors and medical manufacturing companies, according to a Congressional report.

title: THE 60 SINGLES ARE GAME AND GRACIOUS
description: Dodo Cheney of Santa Monica, Calif., plays tennis in pearls and a bopeep bonnet, mops her 68-year-old brow with a lace-trimmed wristband, and holds 149 more national tennis titles, singles and doubles, than any other player, male or female.

title: AFRICANS' CONFERENCE OPENS WITH A CALL FOR SELF-RELIANCE
description: The 21st meeting of the leaders of the Organization of African Unity opened today with a call for greater self-reliance, a sharp attack on the West and the election of a man regarded as a political moderate to be the new chairman.

title: Father and Son on Sax
description: Von and Chico Freeman, tenor saxophonists who are father and son, are leading a quintet - with Larry Willis on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Al Foster on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover tonight and tomorrow, an $8.50 cover Sunday and a one-drink minimum.

title: GHANA DENIES SEEKING SECRETS
description: The Ghanaian Government has denied that its security agents ever sought information from an American Central Intelligence Agency employee who was arrested here last week on espionage charges.

title: Maryland and Carolina Agencies Gain Accounts
description: There has been some advertising account movement to the south that has ramifications in the Big Apple. In Baltimore, Richardson, Myers & Donofrio in Baltimore has picked up the $8 million agricultural chemical account of ICI Americas Inc. of Wilmington, Del.

title: BOND PRICES PLUMMET, PERPLEXING ANALYSTS
description: In a tumultuous and puzzling trading session yesterday, the credit markets ignored fresh statistics showing a weak economy and low inflation and pushed short- and long-term interest rates up sharply.

title: HOWARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
8 SMITHSONIAN UNITS FACE SAFETY CHECKS FOR PCB FIRE THREAT
description: Smithsonian Institution buildings housing some of the nation's most treasured heirlooms will receive an emergency inspection after the discovery that electrical transformers in several of them may be leaking hazardous chemicals, officials said today.

title: QUAKER STATE OIL REFINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm Festival to Open Exhibition of Folk Art
description: A farm festival will open an exhibition of folk art tomorrow at the Delaware County Historical Association headquarters in Delhi, N.Y.

title: U.S. ANNOUNCES IT WILL EASE '86 AUTO FUEL ECONOMY RULE
description: The Department of Transportation, which has been highly critical of Government-mandated fuel economy standards for automobiles, formally announced today that it proposed to reduce the standard for the 1986 model year to an average of 26 miles to the gallon from 27.5 miles a gallon.

title: TOLEDO TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

EARNINGS;

Coca-Cola Has a 6% Increase
description: The Coca-Cola Company and Philip Morris Inc. - two of the nation's largest consumer companies - yesterday reported higher earnings in the second quarter. A third large consumer products company, R. J. Reynolds Industries, reported a 14.3 percent decline in profit; however, not counting a charge for discontinued operations in last year's quarter, the company posted a 12 percent earnings gain.

title: Knight-Ridder Net Off 2.1%
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter was down 2.1 percent, to $36.8 million, from $37.6 million in the 1984 quarter. Per-share earnings increased to 59 cents, from 58 cents, because of a stock buyback that resulted in fewer shares outstanding.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,189,000 for the quarter and $1,500,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $393,000 for the quarter and $1,157,000 for the 9 months.

title: KEY HOUSE PANEL DROPS ANTI-WESTWAY MEASURE
description: Westway today survived its first Congressional test, as an amendment sponsored by opponents of the $2 billion project was defeated by a key House panel. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: Doctor Shot to Death In Bronx Parking Lot
description: An eye surgeon was shot to death behind the office building he owned in the Bronx yesterday evening by a man with whom he had a disagreement over real estate, the police said.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brinkley on Washington
description: David Brinkley, who came to Washington in 1943 as a fledgling radio journalist, is writing a book about the city he has lived in ever since. Associates say the ABC television commentator has had a contract with Alfred A. Knopf for several years now and has finished about 90 percent of his manuscript.

title: Beatrice Debt Cut
description: The Beatrice Companies said that it had lowered its debt by $522 million with proceeds from a recent 14.4-million-share offering of its stock and the sale of its STP Corporation unit to the Union Carbide Corporation. Beatrice, a worldwide marketer of food and consumer products, said the offering raised $435 million. Union Carbide paid $87 million for STP, which had sales of about $97 million in 1984.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UP A WEAK 0.1% IN JUNE
description: Industrial production edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in June, exhibiting the continued weak growth that has plagued United States industry for the last year, the Government reported today.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST VALLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Truth in Spying
description: Arkady N. Shevchenko's contention that he spied for the United States in his last years as an official at the United Nations is getting some support from a former associate. Judy Chavez, the Washington woman who said the former Soviet diplomat had used government money to give her $35,000 to $40,000 in cash and gifts after his defection in 1978, backs up the version of his intelligence activity presented in his best-seller, ''Breaking With Moscow.''

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.8 million for the quarter and $4.6 million for the 6 months, a charge of $35 million in the quarter for the previously reported closing of a plant facility and a charge of $18 million for the quarter for the previously announced reduction of salaried personnel. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $488,000 for the quarter and $2.1 million for the 6 months and extraordinary credits of $3.6 million for the quarter and $8.1 million for the 6 months.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BUDD AND SLANEY TO MEET AGAIN IN 3,000
description: Zola Budd said today that she did not think she could beat Mary Decker Slaney when the two meet Saturday night for the first time since they tangled in the 1984 Olympic Games.

title: MUSIC: A NIGHT OF RAGAS
description: FANS of jazz saxophone battles or dueling bluegrass banjos would have appreciated the concert of South Indian music last Saturday night at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street. Accompanied by the mrdangam drumming of T. V. Gopalkrishnan, the extraordinary violinist T. N. Krishnan and his daughter, the violinist Viji Narayan, played nearly three hours of short and long ragas, trading improvisations in a spirit that was part pedagogy, part friendly competition.

title: SEA LAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Recruiting Inquiry
description: Tom Ford, the University of Houston athletic director, has announced the Southwest Conference school would conduct an internal investigation into its recruiting and signing of Tito Horford, a local high school basketball star. Sports Illustrated, in its current issue, reports that Donnie Schverak, an assistant basketball coach, broke National Collegiate Athletic Association rules by visiting Horford on July 25, 1984 in Santo Domingo.

title: CAPITAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $5,500. c-Including a tax credit of $22,000.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $504,000 for the quarter and $3,198,000 for the 6 months. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $184,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS A SOVIET ICBM IS LESS OF A THREAT TO MISSILE SILOS
description: United States intelligence officials, in a revised assessment of a Soviet missile known as the SS-19, now believe that it is too inaccurate to pose a threat to American missile silos, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN FUNERAL, A MOTHER'S SPECIAL PAIN
description: Eight years ago, the woman said, she attended the funeral of the black nationalist Steve Biko and was troubled by the problem of whether or not to take children to such events - to shelter them, that is, or to expose them to the harshnesses of this land.

title: The U.N. Today; July 19, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GIANTS TRY TO MOLD ARTIST FOR DEFENSE
description: Al Marvin is hardly a typical rookie in a professional football training camp. He is 26 years old. His weight of 308 pounds at minicamp less than two months ago is down to 285. Between high school and college, he spent three years working for minimum wage. He has been in trouble with the law.

title: THRIFT UNIT INSOLVENCY IN FLORIDA
description: The Sunrise Savings and Loan Association of Boynton Beach, Fla., which had grown spectacularly in recent years by lending heavily to construction projects, was taken over and declared insolvent today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT AMERICAN FIRST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Deliberate Deficit
description: To hear Larry Speakes tell it, President Reagan emerged from anesthesia righteously demanding action on the budget deficit ''this week.'' That sounds fine - except that it now appears that the deficit was deliberately created by Mr. Reagan in order to do away with Democratic social programs dating back to the New Deal.

title: THOUSAND TRAILS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CONDOMINIUM CONVERSION IN HOBOKEN
description: In 1979 Robert S. Cohen was a composer struggling to earn a living in regional theater and university teaching. He had two music degrees and knew little about business, but he managed to get a marketing job at a computer services company. He figured that if he was going to learn the job he had better go to the company's top marketing representative and ask if he could accompany him on a call.

title: THEATER: 'PARADE' BY DRESSER
description: WHEN a writer sets his play in a tacky motel called the Heart of America Travel Lodge, you can be fairly certain that he's not going to have nice things to say about the American heartland. Richard Dresser, the author of a new comedy titled ''The Hit Parade,'' does not disappoint. In this nasty assault on low-rent show business and its Middle American dupes, even the best of the trashy characters are morons or scoundrels. When one of them maintains that he frequents prostitutes because they are ''a better class of people'' than his usual companions, we have no reason to doubt that he speaks the truth.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC OF WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A COMEBACK FOR A REAL TRAIN STATION
description: Since he first became a redcap in 1948, when American railroads were approaching the sunset of their glory years, Fred Pettit has spent much of his working life at Philadelphia's 30th Street Station. ''I've never timed it up, exactly,'' he said in the evening rush hour the other day.

title: COMPUTER DESIGNATED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET MARSHAL REPORTED REINSTATED
description: In a significant military shake-up, the Soviet Union has rehabilitated Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, who was dismissed as Chief of the General Staff nine months ago, according to reliable information reaching here.

title: RX ON DIET: LOW FAT AND HIGHER FIBER
description: President Reagan's doctors have advised him to change his diet to one lower in fat and higher in fiber to reduce his risk of developing a second colon cancer. The advice reflects a new appreciation of the role that diet can play in provoking and preventing cancer, especially of the bowel.

title: Amex Trading Remains Calm
description: THE American Stock Exchange's market value index, which has lagged behind other major market indicators in registering new highs, is approaching its record, set nearly two years ago. So far, however, signs of torrid speculative activity often associated with the Amex in past bull markets appear to be absent.

title: ALLEN RELIEVED TO BE TRADED
description: Of all the people to encounter when the rumors of his trade to the Yankees were loudest, Neil Allen spotted Rich Gossage and Graig Nettles last Sunday.

title: I.B.M. SAYS PCII JUST DOESN'T EXIST
description: Seeking to put to rest a persistent and disruptive rumor, the new chief of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer group said yesterday that no replacement for the company's four-year-old basic PC was in the works.

title: Is It Time to Halt the Further Manhattanization of Manhattan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tip From Spitz
description: Mark Spitz, never lacking in self-assurance, carried the torch to open the Maccabiah Games in Tel Aviv, then considered the Israelis' monetary difficulties and said: ''The problem with long-term goals is that they begin to seem impossible, and people lose interest. You need to set short-term, feasible goals. That's what this Government should do.''

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,056,136, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,920,000, or 38 cents a share, for the six months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $658,650, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $901,032, or 18 cents a share, for the six months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 19, 1985
description: International

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Including income from discontinued operations of $9,335,000 for the quarter and $8,561,000 for the six months.

title: The Milk Cartel Rolls On
description: A gallon of milk that sells for about $2.29 in New York City sells for only about $2.04 across the river in New Jersey. Why the extra quarter? It's the price New Yorkers pay for a restrictive milk distribution law that Governor Cuomo needs to reinterpret.

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Guilty Plea in G.E. Case
description: The former manager of systems engineering for the General Electric Company's Re-entry division pleaded guilty today to two counts of making false statements to the Federal Government, just hours after three former colleagues pleaded not guilty to charges of fraud involving military contracts.

title: AMERICAN ECOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONSANTO TO ACQUIRE G. D. SEARLE
description: The Monsanto Company announced today that it would pay about $2.7 billion to acquire G.D. Searle & Company, the diversified drug company that makes aspartame, the artificial sweetener.

title: Judge and Lawyer Admit Chicago Bribery
description: Judge Wayne Olson of Cook County Circuit Court and James Costello, a Chicago lawyer, pleaded guilty today to charges resulting from a covert Federal investigation of judicial corruption here. Prosecutors said Judge Olson had taken bribes for steering cases to Mr. Costello.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GEORGIA PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net gains from discontinued operations of $18,000,000 for the quarter and $26,000,000 for the six months. c-Including a first quarter pre-tax gain of $19,000,000 from the sale of timberland.

title: 175 BALLOONS FESTOON MICHIGAN'S SKY
description: Robert Zoufal was standing like a straphanger, one hand above his head. With the wind pushing his hot-air balloon over the farms and factories of western Michigan, everything was quiet except when he tugged on the valve he was holding.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a foreign tax credit of $14 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: MERCK RISES 4.9%
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the country's second-largest chemical producer, after Du Pont, yesterday announced a 16.7 percent drop in net income in the second quarter, while Merck & Company, a producer of specialty chemicals and pharmaceuticals, reported a 4.9 percent rise. The Olin Corporation, an industrial and specialty chemicals concern, said it had a 52.1 percent decline.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ron Kittle, the White Sox slugger who has been out with a shoulder injury, will be spending some time in the minors after coming off the disabled list yesterday. He has been told to report to the Buffalo Bisons. . . . Steve Cram, who set a world 1,500-meter record in Nice, France, on Tuesday, said he would pass up a race against Sebastian Coe, the Olympic champion, in London today because of a calf injury.

title: Why Japan Really Won the Chip Race
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MCNEIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,776,000 for the quarter and $1,730,000 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $617,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: ROCK: AT 57, RUTH BROWN ENDURES
description: THE 57-year-old Ruth Brown, who was one of the seminal female voices in rock-and-roll's emergence, has the same kind of vocal staying power as Sarah Vaughan. Although she is not a fancy technician like Miss Vaughan, her clear, powerful delivery, steady tonal control, and energy level seem almost untouched by the passing of time.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: YOU can't have parties without people. When people leave New York City for their summer watering holes, the parties move with them - whether it's to Connecticut, the Hamptons, Saratoga, the Berkshires, the Catskills or the Jersey shore. This weekend, much of the social whirl will be centered on Long Island, with major benefits both in the Hamptons and on the North Shore.

title: Race Could Prove Costly
description: Officials at the Meadowlands said last night that they would be forced to allow show betting for the Meadowlands Pace tonight even though it appeared likely that a dominant five-horse entry led by Nihilator would produce a minus pool that could cost the track thousands of dollars.

title: MUSIC UNDER THE STARS AT DAMROSCH
description: RIGHT now, you don't need a ticket to hear a concert at Lincoln Center. Just show up, and bring a friend or two. Throughout the summer, there are free concerts in Damrosch Park and around Lincoln Center's central plaza. The center will be alive with music this weekend, and most of it will be out in the open air.

title: CORRECTION
description: The company earnings report and profits scoreboard in Business Day yesterday misstated the results of Castle & Cooke Inc. Corrected results appear today on page D5.

title: SIX OFFICERS GO ON TRIAL IN STEWART SLAYING CASE
description: The trial of six transit police officers began yesterday with the prosecutor saying his witnesses would include 27 students who had seen a Brooklyn man fatally beaten after being arrested in a subway station for scrawling graffiti.

title: ROTO-ROOTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mortgage Agency Sets Collateralized Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement this week with Epic Financial Services of Falls Church, Va., to offer up to $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations backed by mortgage securities assembled from various thrift institutions.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $14,000,000 for the quarter and $20,400,000 for the six months. c-Net loss.

title: West German Is Sentenced
description: A woman who had worked for the United States Army in West Germany was jailed today for eight and a half years for planning terrorist attacks on American military bases and arms depots. The woman, Gisela Dutzi, 33 years old, a technical draftsman and a member of the Red Army Faction guerrilla group, was found guilty of sketching maps of the installations and giving them to the group.

title: Auditor to Submit Papers on Hutton
description: Arthur Young & Company was instructed yesterday by E. F. Hutton & Company's law firm, Cahill Gordon & Reindel, to provide the Securities and Exchange Commission with most of its reports and work papers on Hutton's cash management system, which the commission is investigating.

title: Easing the Fall Of the Dollar
description: AMERICA'S ''other deficit'' - the trade deficit - is the biggest drag on United States economic growth. The tricky problem facing national policy makers is how to solve the nation's international trade problem without thrusting the domestic economy into a slump that would be more painful than the trade deficit itself.

title: New York Jazz Quartet
description: The pianist Roland Hanna, the saxophonist and flutist Frank Wess, the bassist George Mraz and the drummer Marvin (Smitty) Smith - collectively known as the New York Jazz Quartet - are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street.

title: METS WIN, 7-6, ON 5-RUN FIFTH
description: The Mets opened Act II of the season last night by outlasting the Atlanta Braves, 7-6, in a comedy of eight errors, three by Howard Johnson. But their attention was firmly fixed on the second game of the series tonight, which may decide whether Gary Carter undergoes immediate surgery on his right knee.

title: PSFS() reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Goldsmith Stake Up to About 46%
description: Sir James Goldsmith, continuing his battle with management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, increased his stake in the paper-and forest products company to nearly 46 percent, a spokesman for the British financier said yesterday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sir James said he had raised his stake to 43.2 percent, but his spokesman said ''he's been buying up shares since then.''

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT SLOW 1.7% RATE IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of only 1.7 percent in the spring, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Two Jets in Near-Crash
description: Two jet planes taxiing at Newark International Airport nearly collided today, jostling more than 200 passengers but causing no injuries, authorities said.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $596.8 million, to $212.24 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Unaccompanied Sax
description: The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins will play a free solo concert tonight at 8 o'clock in the Summergarden series of the Museum of Modern Art. The concert will be held in the sculpture garden. Information: 708-9750.

title: House Passes a Ban On Rebel Arms Aid
description: The House of Representatives today approved by a voice vote an authorization bill for intelligence agencies which would ban ''material assistance including arms, ammunition, equipment or other material which could be used to inflict serious bodily harm or death'' for the Nicaraguan rebels fighting the Sandinista Government.

title: 'Truffaut Plus' Series Of Films at Tully Hall
description: Screenings of Francois Truffaut's ''400 Blows'' and Jean-Luc Godard's ''Breathless'' on Aug. 9 will open a three-week retrospective called ''Truffaut Plus'' at Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Truffaut died last October at the age of 52.

title: COMMONWEALTH NATIONAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORPORATION OF INDIANA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Indian Music and Dance
description: An outdoor performance of Indian music and dance will be given on Sunday at 1 P.M. at the Bowne House Historical Society, 37-01 Bowne Street in Flushing, Queens.

title: Hewlett Plans U.S. Closings
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would close most of its manufacturing and administrative operations in the United States for one or two days each month to reduce expenses.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: First Bank System Names Chairman
description: First Bank System, the nation's 14th-largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that D. H. Ankeny Jr. would succeed George H. Dixon as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Dixon retires on Nov. 1.

title: W. CORDES SNYDER
description: W. Cordes Snyder, former chief executive of the Blaw-Knox Foundry at Pittsburgh, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at his home in Sewickley, Pa.

title: McCarver Selects His Dream Team
description: He starts with a word of caution: Almost all of his big-league life has been spent in the National League, first as a catcher with 21 years' tenure, later as a play-by-play man for the Phillies and now for the Mets, and so his choices are likely to be tilted. He also acknowledges being somewhat partial to people he once played with. Still, for all the New York baseball aficionados who regard him as the most insightful broadcaster they have ever heard, here are the names that come to Tim McCarver's mind when he is asked to select his dream team, the top players he has seen at each position since breaking in as a St. Louis rookie in 1959:

title: Marcos Seeks Study Of U.S. Base Accords
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos called today for a commission to study whether to renegotiate an agreement with the United States on military bases, and said the Philippines could do without American military aid if necessary.

title: CNW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: INTERIOR SECRETARY SAYS HE FAVORS EXPANSION OF WILDERNESS SYSTEM
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that the Reagan Administration strongly supported the creation of new wilderness areas and would give a high priority to protecting areas now being considered for inclusion in the wilderness system.

title: INSURERS TELL WHY COSTS ARE UP FOR DAY CARE
description: Insurance brokers who sell liability coverage to day care centers told a House panel today that their companies were sharply reducing coverage as a reaction to publicity about child abuse at such centers. At the same time, representatives of the day care industry said they could not operate with little or no insurance.

title: ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quoting Cuomo
description: If Governor Cuomo also decides to run for President in 1988, you can bet Senator Hart and any other Democrats who wind up in the New Hampshire primary will take note of an exchange in the House Ways and Means Committee this week.

description: The United States told Nicaragua today that it had intelligence reports indicating that individuals supported by Nicaragua were planning terrorist attacks against United States personnel in Honduras.

description: Arnold Palmer, the 55-year-old golf champion, has taken care of some old medical business.

title: YONKERS COUPLE DIE IN AN APPARENT SUICIDE PACT
description: An elderly couple, apparently despondent over ill health, were found dead of gunshot wounds in the rear courtyard of their apartment building today. The police said the couple had carried out a suicide pact.

title: 4 Held in Theft of U.S. Checks
description: The authorities have broken up a ring they say stole about 30,000 Treasury checks worth tens of millions of dollars from the mail and sent them overseas for cashing.

title: Billy Harper Quintet
description: The Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, near East Third Street, will present the tenor saxophonist Billy Harper with his quintet tomorrow at 9 and 10:30 P.M. Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 505-5660

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Christy, did you play all 18?'' -Henry Cotton to Christy O'Connor Jr., who shot a 64 to break Mr. Cotton's 51-year-old record at Royal St. George's golf course during the British Open. [A19:3.]

title: DAYTON POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Hart's Guns of 1985
description: Many political professionals in Washington are already convinced that Senator Gary Hart of Colorado will make another bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, having surprised many observers by winning a dozen party primaries and 13 caucus states on his first national outing last year. That belief becomes more prevalent as small pieces of evidence appear.

title: Politics;   Yuppie Is Dead, Long Live the 'New Collar' Voter
description: Pity the Democrats. Since last year's national elections they have been trying to figure out how to court the Yuppies, only to hear now that this trendy voter group is not worth so much time and effort.

title: CRUCIAL ELECTION LOOMS AT FEMINIST CONVENTION
description: A heated presidential election between two of the country's best-known feminists will be the major attraction when the National Organization for Women opens its annual three-day convention here Friday.

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: IBM Sale Abroad
description: The IBM World Trade Corporation is offering a bond issue of 150 million European Currency Units, due in five years, through Banque Nationale de Paris. The financing, worth about $118.7 million, consists of 8 1/4 percent bonds offered at par.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3-Month Loss At Inland Steel
description: The Inland Steel Company today reported a second-quarter net loss of $29.6 million, in contrast to a profit of $22.4 million, or 82 cents a share, a year before.

title: OPERA: 'LA BOHEME' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: THE New York Grand Opera, a familiar and welcome summer visitor to the Band Shell in Central Park, put on a substantial and very listenable performance of Puccini's ''Boheme'' on Wednesday night. Vincent La Selva, the founder and music director of the company, knows that opera depends above all on good voices and stylish singing, and both were in plentiful supply on this occasion. Proof of the singers' accomplishments lay in the fact that they quickly made one indifferent to the conflict between the reality of July heat and the opera's insistence that cold weather prevailed all around.

title: CABARET: DAVID GRISMAN
description: THE mandolinist David Grisman has taken a bluegrass-style band into previously uncharted realms, among them jazz, rock and Middle Eastern music. On Monday at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, he had his latest twists in genre bolstered by a drummer who rarely performs outside recording studios, Hal Blaine.
