TROUBLED NEWS AGENCY SEEKS TO VOID LABOR PACT
description: United Press International will file a motion in Federal Bankruptcy Court today to have the financially ailing news service's contract with its major union voided, according to the company's president.

title: Charger Arrested
description: Mike Green, the linebacker who led the Chargers in tackles the last two seasons, was arrested by narcotics officers in San Diego and charged with possession of a gram of cocaine, a felony.

title: League Curtails Season
description: The United States Basketball League announced today that it would end its inaugural season a month early because so many of its players are leaving to attend National Basketball Association camps.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BROOKLYN ON ITS TOES This weekend's fare is dance at Celebrate Brooklyn, the annual summer arts festival in Prospect Park, where the continuing dance program encompasses the work of promising newcomers as well as established dancers and choreographers. Tonight, Michiyo & Dancers, the com-pany headed by the Asian-American choreographer Michiyo Tanaka, will perform, followed by the Glenn Lund Dance Company - Laura Glenn and Gary Lund and their five-member troupe. Tomorrow evening's program will feature dances choreographed by Mark Morris and a perfo rmance by Peggy Lyma n and her company. On Sunday night, the Brooklyn Dance Consortium will showcase the work of four choreographers, Elise Long, Diane Martel, Mark Taylor and Theodora Yoshikami. All three programs are free and begin at 8 P.M. at the Prospect Park Band Shell at Prospect Park West and Ninth Street in Brooklyn. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Summerpier Program
description: The Summerpier series at the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, Fulton Street at the East River, will present free concerts tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock. Tonight, the trumpeter Lester Bowie will lead his group Brass Fantasy; tomorrow, the singer Carmen Lundy will perform. Information: 669-9424.

title: Debris Delays BMT and IRT
description: Four large chunks of concrete fell through a ventilation shaft into the 59th Street and Lexington Avenue station of the IRT and BMT lines yesterday, hitting a stopped train and causing widespread interruptions in service, transit officials said. No injuries were reported. Workers were using jackhammers to break up a sidewalk outside Bloomingdale's on 60th Street, and the pieces of sidewalk fell through the shaft, which had been hidden by the pavement.

title: VAN DORN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Papal Plot TrialHalted by Outbursts
description: The judge hearing the Papal assassination plot case angrily suspended today's session after a defense attorney became involved in a shouting match with the prosecution's leading witness, Mehmet Ali Agca.

title: BLUES: TWO SINGERS AT LONE STAR CAFE
description: TEXAS and Louisiana blues by way of Chicago filled the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street, on Tuesday. A double bill paired Lonnie Brooks, from Dubuisson, La., and Albert Collins, from Houston.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $515,000 from the sale of a plant. c-Including a net gain of $2,950,000 from the disposition of assets.

title: BROTHER'S CANCER MATCHES REAGAN'S
description: President Reagan's brother, Neil, had exactly the same type of cancerous colon polyp removed 10 days before the President's malignancy was discovered, and the cancers were situated in the same area of the colon, according to three of Neil Reagan's doctors.

title: Gamblers Deal Refused
description: Larry Fisher, the New York real estate developer, said through an intermediary yesterday that he had rejected a proposal that he invest in the financially strapped Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League with the aim of moving that franchise to Shea Stadium to play in the fall of 1986. Fisher had consulted this week with Jerry Argovitz, one of the Gamblers' three owners, who is seeking additional investors.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RELIANCE FINANCIAL
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, which is headed by the New York investor Saul P. Steinberg, said that it had acquired a 5.4 percent stake in the Texas Air Corporation for ''investment purposes.''

title: IRVING S. DIAMOND
description: Irving S. Diamond, a retired luggage manufacturer, died of heart disease Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Poppe Tyson Business
description: Poppe Tyson, the business-to-business advertising division of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, has become agency for U.S.I. Chemicals in Cincinnati, part of the chemical group of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. Billings for the advertising and public relations will come to $1 million, according to the agency. The client was formerly served by Marsteller, which became part of the HCM agency.

title: COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Who Says We Are the World?
description: There is scarcely a person on earth who is unaware of the recent rock concerts in London and Philadelphia to aid victims of starvation in Africa. Anyone who is anybody in the rock business performed. Even the Soviet Union contributed one of its groups. This was a true international event. But to what end? In Ethiopia, the victims of starvation are concentrated, for the most part, in the Tigre Valley, an area where the rebellion against Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam's hateful Communist regime has been organized. Little wonder, then, that food stocks sent to Ethiopia are rotting in storehouses in Addis Ababa and that Soviet ships bearing military equipment to fight the rebellion are permitted to unload while aid ships wait an average of nine days in the harbor before unloading.

title: BELLSOUTH CORPORATION BELLWETHER EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Loss at Mohawk Data
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, the troubled computer company controlled by Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, yesterday reported a loss of $119.9 million in its fourth quarter ended April 30.

title: Ultimate Test
description: Coach George Irvine of the Indiana Pacers, who plans a private tutoring session with Wayman Tisdale because the big rookie is still without a contract and will miss the team's summer camp, explains what's in store: ''After we build his confidence up, I'll play him one-on-one. If I beat him, we won't sign him.''

title: WHITE HOUSE DECISION HELD NEAR ON NOMINEE TO REPLACE STOCKMAN
description: The White House today neared a decision on a nominee to replace David A. Stockman as director of the Office of Management and Budget, with James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, considered the likely choice, according to White House officials.

title: THE SCREEN: 'WETHERBY'
description: ''WETHERBY'' has been written and directed for the screen by David Hare, the author of ''Plenty,'' with a playwright's ear for elegant dialogue and a playwright's portentous sense of symmetry. While the former is certainly welcome on the screen, the latter is less at home, and it serves to make ''Wetherby'' a peculiar hybrid not entirely suited to either medium. However, Mr. Hare has assembled a superb cast, and its ensemble work is very fine. His foremost casting coup is the pairing of Vanessa Redgrave and her daughter, the equally radiant Joely Richardson, who play the same woman at two key stages in her life.

title: Smoke Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAKEOUT IN FARMING: THE DILEMMA OF THE BANKS AND THE CORE OF THE LOSSES
description: Rarely before have so many Americans agonized so much over the economic plight of so few. Through winter and spring, the rest of the nation watched the struggles of farmers to hold off creditors, keep their land and find the new loans to seed the soil and carry them to another harvest.

STADIUM PLANS CHANGING TO LURE BACK THE JETS
description: In their most overt attempt to win back the New York Jets football team, state officials said yesterday that they had asked four developers to revise proposals for a Queens sports stadium to provide features believed to be favored by the team.

YANKS RUN INTO TROUBLE AT METRODOME
description: Two months later, Billy Martin hasn't changed his opinion about the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome.

title: Isabel Alfonsa of Borbon, 80; Was Aunt of King Juan Carlos
description: Princess Isabel Alfonsa of Borbon, aunt of King Juan Carlos, died of a heart attack today, a hospital spokesman said. She was 80 years old.

title: CONSTRUCTION HOIST TOPPLES AND 2 WORKERS ARE KILLED
description: A construction elevator toppled off the side of a building yesterday in midtown Manhattan and crashed 30 feet to the ground, killing two workers and injuring another who were installing it.

title: Technology Project Is Pressed
description: A 17-nation conference has given France a green light to press preparations for a Western European high-technology project but left details to be decided later.

title: ALASKA NATIONAL BANK OF THE NORTH reports earnings for Qtr to June 31
Midpoint for a Mall
description: A string quartet played, and balloons bobbed gaily from the music stands. Noontime crowds surged onto John Street, which had been cleared of cars.

title: Plan Reshaped By Argentina
description: Argentina has reshaped its pact with the International Monetary Fund, in line with a tough anti-inflation program begun a month ago, the Economy Ministry said tonight. A spokesman said agreement with the fund was expected next week.

title: COMPANIES TURN TO INCENTIVES
description: A year ago, the suggestion that Douglas W. Moul would aggressively push his division to generate more cash so that another division could build a new plant would probably have made him laugh. But today, rather than laughing, that is exactly what Mr. Moul, the general manager of one of the American Can Company's packaging divisions, is doing.

title: Bonds Offered By Transohio
description: The Transohio Savings Bank is offering $75 million of 10 1/8 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1992 at a price of 99.745, to yield 10.19 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Phone Cable Link
description: The New York Telephone Company has put in place the first underwater communications cable between Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: Children's Tylenol Recalled
description: Some containers of Tylenol Children's Elixir are being recalled nationwide as a precautionary measure because they may be contaminated with a mold and yeast combination, health officials said today. The contamination could cause skin welts and nausea, said Don Phillips, director of the Arkansas Health Department's division of pharmacy services. He said the recalled bottles bore these serial numbers: SH3865 for 16-ounce bottles; SL4309, SL4321, SP4462 SSF228, SSF229 and SSF223 for 4-ounce bottles. Robert Kniffin, spokesman for the Johnson & Johnson Company in New Brunswick, N.J., said the recall was from wholesalers only. &

title: STAGE: 'PEARLS,' AT JEWISH REPERTORY
description: ''PEARLS,'' the new musical drama at the Jewish Repertory Theater, is about as eclectic as they come in its melody and manner, and the wonder is that it works at all -but it does, and very, very nicely, too.

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 22, 1984.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: ''IF you're playing percussion, you can't just bang on the instrument,'' Tito Puente said the other day. ''Back in Africa, these instruments were always carrying messages, about marriages or deaths or gatherings. You have to say something when you play percussion - there is always a message there.''

title: APPLE COMPUTER POSTS A LOSS OF $17.2 MILLION
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it lost $17.2 million in its third fiscal quarter, the first quarterly loss for the personal computer pioneer since it incorporated in 1977.

title: IS TERMED 'TOTALLY BACK TO NORMAL'
description: Five days after his cancer surgery, President Reagan ate his first solid food today and was ''totally back to normal,'' the White House announced.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $1.9 million representing an additional assessment on thrifts by the Federal Savaings & Loan Insurance Corp. to rebuild its reserves.

title: CLOSING STATEMENTS TO JURORS ARE MADE IN PARK FIRE TRIAL
description: Eight teen-agers were killed in a fun-house fire last year because amusement park executives ''were too indifferent, reckless, greedy and callous'' to install sprinklers or smoke alarms despite repeated warnings, a jury was told today.

title: SHUFFLE IN SOVIET MILITARY
description: There were indications today that a high-level shuffle was under way in the Soviet military, with the apparent retirement of the chief political commissar of the armed forces and unconfirmed reports of other shifts.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: CREDIT should be given to Michael O' Keeffe, creator of the River Cafe in Brooklyn and its sibling, the Water Club, just upstream on the Manhattan side, for holding to the near-radical notion that good food and panoramic waterside views are not mutually exclusive. In fact, before Mr. O'Keeffe came along with the River Cafe in 1977, this major seaport city had no notable restaurants on the harbor at all.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $361,000 for the quarter and $934,000 for the nine months. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

Is It Time to Halt the Further Manhattanization of Manhattan?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ASSERTS ISRAEL CAN'T VETO TALKS WITH PALESTINIANS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that while it would take the views of Israel into account, it would not give it a veto over whether the United States should meet with a joint Jordanian-Palestinian group to set the stage for eventual peace talks with Israel.

title: ADVEST GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: G.E. Wins Settlement In Supper Club Fire
description: The General Electric Company, the last defendant in a suit involving a fatal fire in 1977 at the Beverly Hills Supper Club, reached a $10 million settlement today just before jury deliberations were to begin, the plaintiffs' attorney said.

title: 10 Killed in Protests By Students in India
description: Clashes claimed 10 more lives today in Gujarat state, and student leaders there said they would call off the agitation against government policies that started the violence four months ago.

title: FOSTER, L B CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Monday on the Live Aid concert incorrectly characterized Mary Travers's relationship with the folk group Peter, Paul and Mary.

description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $173,000 for the quarter and $868,000 for the six months.

title: LYNCH COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split declared May 21.

title: St. Peter's Basilica Repaired
description: The facade of St. Peter's Basilica is undergoing complete restoration for the first time since it was built more than 350 years ago. The facade, completed in 1614, is adorned with 18-foot marble statues that have suffered considerable damage over the years from atmospheric pollution, officials said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Placed Bob James, relief pitcher, on 15-day disabled list.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beecham Cosmetics Inc., Chicago, a subsidiary of the Beecham Group P.L.C., said Richard E. Meyer had resigned as president, chief executive officer and a director of the company and its subsidiaries.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the President's tax plan incorrectly identified the aide seated to the right of Governor Cuomo. He is Brad Johnson.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax settlement of $270,000.

title: U.S. Judge Favors Soviet Couple
description: Immigration officials violated the rights of the parents of a Russian teen-ager by refusing to let them take their son back to the Soviet Union three years ago, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FORT MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a Freddie Mac dividend of $297,040 or 16 cents a share. Year-ago results reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
General Mills in the Red
description: General Mills Inc., which has been divesting itself of many of its consumer goods operations, yesterday reported large losses in the fourth quarter and the full year ended May 26.

WALL TO WALL SOUND AND VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Re-enacting First Flight Of a Hot-Air Balloon
description: A re-enactment of the first manned hot-air balloon flight will take place at the Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson in Westchester County tomorrow about 7:15 P.M.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect a charge of about 8 cents a share related to the relocation of the company's Raleigh operations and costs associated with the pending sale of its Ponca City plant.

title: LINCOLN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ford Mini-Vans
description: The Ford Motor Company has started shipping its new Aerostar mini-van to dealers, joining Chrysler and General Motors in the market. Ford said that it had spent $350 million on equipment at its St. Louis plant to make Aerostar mini-vans for sale as both passenger and commercial vehicles. Ford officials said the Aerostar would be in dealer showroons late this month.

title: NICHOLAS HALASZ
description: Nicholas Halasz, the author of a book about Alfred Dreyfus, the French army officer wrongly accused of treason, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DR. THOMAS H. VAUGHN
description: Dr. Thomas H. Vaughn, a chemist and former executive of the Colgate-Palmolive Company and the Pabst Brewing Company, died at Brick Hospital in Brick Town, N.J., Monday. He was 75 years old and lived in Waretown, N.J.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net charge of $9,500,000 related to the restructuring of the company's German operations, United States accessories and work products division in Hampstead, Md. c-Net income.

title: More Bad Trade Laws
description: The Senate and House are racing to pass more unwise trade laws. Several years of surging imports and stalled exports have wiped out American jobs and stirred up voters. In the competitive haste to provide a ''solution,'' the Republicans who control the Senate and Democrats leading the House have turned again to crowd-pleasing protectionism. It's a quest that will do more harm than good, choking off yet more trade, the lifeblood of economic expansion everywhere.

title: Adviser's Fees
description: Much attention is directed at the $5,032,983 in campaign contributions that Mayor Koch has raised.

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRYSLER'S NET FALLS BY 25.7%
description: The Chrysler Corporation, hurt by the exhaustion of the company's tax-loss carry-forwards, today reported a 25.7 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.

title: Yugoslav Food Prices Up
description: Yugoslavia said today that the price of bread would rise 35 percent Friday and that the prices of some other vital foods and energy would also rise considerably. The price increases are likely to further increase the inflation rate, which was 76 percent for June.

title: Celebration of Indians
description: The second annual Indian Powwow will be held tomorrow and Sunday at the Harriman (N.Y.) State Park, starting at 10:30 A.M. each day.

title: Calling it Quits
description: He was the Mets' opening day pitcher a year ago and he's just 15 victories shy of the 200-mark, but at the age of 38, Mike Torrez has concluded that he's not going to make it back to a major league mound. Torrez, who has been languishing this season as a free agent with the Miami Marlins of the Class A Florida State League after being cut by the Mets last season, announced that he was retiring as a player after a final appearance with the Marlins last night. ''I've done everything I possibly could do to get back to the major leagues,'' he said, expressing puzzlement that he had not attracted major league attention after turning in a 7-7 record with a 2.95 earned-run average for the Marlins.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year ago net excludes $4,715,000 from elimination of prior years' taxes on disc income.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. BLAMED AT WOMEN'S PARLEY
description: Nicaraguan, Syrian and dissident South African delegates denounced United States foreign policies today at the United Nations women's conference here.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,987,000 for the quarter and $5,813,000 for the nine months. c-Net gain after losses from discontinued operations of $379,000 for the quarter and $1,361,000 for the nine months.

title: PIONEER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FROM FOSTER HOMES TO LIFE ON NEW YORK STREETS: 3 CASE STUDIES IN FAILURE
description: After a childhood he remembers as a series of beatings by a mother who drank a lot, Reggie Brown entered the foster-care system at age 13. Within a week of his 18th birthday, he was discharged from the last of a series of group homes. All he was given, he said, was cab fare and directions to the men's shelter.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Research Using Animals Is Ordered Halted
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and and Human Services, today ordered a halt to a University of Pennsylvania research project on head injuries.

title: U.S. POSTAL SERVICE FACES LOSSES OF UP TO $500 MILLION THIS YEAR
description: Despite rate increases in February and various cost cutting measures, the United States Postal Service is losing $1 million a day and faces a potential loss of $500 million this year, Postal Service officials said today.

title: NO U.S. GENERAL COMMANDS KOREAN FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Zellerbach To Renew Suit
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said yesterday that it would resume its litigation against Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has been fighting for control of the forest and paper products company.

title: AH, ICE
description: With this city's thermometer readings hovering around the 90's, producers of a forthcoming show at Wolf Trap Park, an outdoor theater in suburban Virginia, may find themselves tilting with ice as they seek to create a rink fit for the likes of such figure skating champions as Dorothy Hamill, Tai Babilonia and Randy Gardner.

title: Selmon May Retire
description: Lee Roy Selmon, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' end, widely regarded as one of the top defensive linemen in professional football, said yesterday that he is suffering from a painful back condition that might keep him out for the season and could end his career. The 30-year-old Selmon, who first noticed the pain on the flight home from the Pro Bowl in January, said the problem had since been diagnosed as a herniated disk, but that he had received conflicting opinions from three doctors about the proper course of treatment and his prospects for recovery. He said he would announce a decision about his plans for the season on Tuesday.

title: DEBITS AWEIGH!
description: Hard on the heels of recent scandals involving business misconduct in some military procurement contracts comes word that Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. is taking steps to assure that he runs a tight ship.

title:
PATENTS;

Automatic Lap Counter Records Exercise Moves
description: An automatic lap counter to be worn by swimmers and runners to record their exercise movements was patented this week by Jonathan Rabinowitz of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: 4 KILLED IN CLASHES IN WESTERN INDIA
description: Four people were killed and 16 were wounded today in clashes in the western city of Ahmadabad.

title: Schwab Cut Bank Stake
description: Charles R. Schwab, a director of the BankAmerica Corporation and chairman of its discount brokerage unit, sold about 350,000 shares of BankAmerica stock in June. BankAmerica reported Wednesday a $338 million quarterly loss. Hugo Quackenbush, a senior vice president at Charles Schwab & Company, said Mr. Schwab had used the money to repay debts.

title: New Look for Ramada
description: Ramada Inns Inc. said today that it plans to begin offering lodging in buildings with residential-style architecture and landscaping.

title: SCHROEDER AND 4 SONS TAKE IN A BALL GAME
description: William J. Schroeder, who has lived longer with a permanent artificial heart than any other human, spent a ''boys' night on the town'' with his four sons tonight at a minor league baseball game, a hospital spokesman said.

title: MARTIAL LAW IS LIFTED IN SOME PARTS OF TURKEY
description: T The authorities lifted martial law today in 6 of 24 provinces after six and a half years, but they showed no sign of ending it in the southeast of the country where Kurdish rebels skirmish almost daily with troops.

title: ON LUMBER: CANADA'S TIMBER PRICE ADVANTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: LIN BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMSTED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUSPECT IN COAST KILLINGS TO APPEAR IN LINEUP
description: Charles Ng, who is wanted in California on charges of murder, will appear in a lineup in Canada that will be viewed by a witness to a San Francisco slaying, the authorities said Thursday.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS PATRICK TO FULL TERM ON F.C.C.
description: The Senate today confirmed Dennis R. Patrick to a full seven-year term on the Federal Communications Commission.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $3,993,000 from the company's sale in an initial public offering in June of 1,100,000 common shares of Roto-Rooter Inc.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H. CO () reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAMPION OF THE FREE MARKET: JAMES CLIFFORD MILLER 3d
description: In the late 1960's, when James C. Miller 3d was a graduate student in economics at the University of Virginia, he wrote a doctoral thesis in which he set forth reasons for deregulating the airline industry. It was an unfashionable view at the time.

title: MET STREAK ENDED BY 4-HITTER, 1-0
description: The Mets' four-game winning streak came to an end last night when they managed only four hits off Zane Smith and Bruce Sutter and lost to the Atlanta Braves, 1-0. But they won an overnight reprieve on a more significant issue: Gary Carter's damaged right knee went nine innings without breaking down, and a decision on any surgery was postponed at least until today.

title: JENNINGS FACES STRONG RUSH FOR HIS JOB
description: For 11 seasons, Dave Jennings has been the Giants' punter. He has been an all-pro five times and a Pro Bowl punter four times. Today, he reported to the training camp at Pace University prepared for the fight of his life to keep his job.

title: American Brands Falls
description: American Brands Inc., a large tobacco and packaged goods company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings slipped 9.6 percent, to $85.9 million, or $1.48 a share, from $95 million, or $1.64 a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 3.1 percent, to $1.63 billion, from $1.68 billion.

title: Hernandez Is Warned
description: The umpires warned Keith Hernandez last night: Stand in foul territory when holding a runner on first base and you will be ejected.

title: Bell Is Traded
description: As was expected, the Texas Rangers traded Buddy Bell, the third baseman, to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday for Duane Walker, a reserve outfielder, and a player to be named. Bell, who is from Cincinnati and whose father, Gus Bell, starred as an outfielder for the Reds in the 1950's, asked to be traded last week.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pretax gain of $31,000 for the quarter and a pretax charge of $310,000 for the six months. c-Including pretax gains of $8,664,000 for the quarter and $10,603,000 for the six months representing equity in net income of real estate subsidiaries before tax credits of $2,500,000 for the quarter and $3,350,000 for the six months.

title: JOSEPH CLINTON CLARKE
description: Joseph Clinton Clarke, a finance officer and administrator with the Army Corps of Engineers and the Federal Atomic Energy Commission for 40 years, died Wednesday at his home in Creamridge, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: OFFICIALS SAY WIRETAPS PROVIDED KEY EVIDENCE IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: Federal prosecutors said today that information obtained from Government wiretaps led directly to the arrest of John A. Walker Jr., the former Navy man accused of running a spy ring.

title: U.S. FACTORY USE DROPS FOR 3D STRAIGHT MONTH
description: The operating rate at the nation's factories edged down again in June, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Government reported yesterday.

title: GONE WITH THE SCRIBES
description: It's been a long time since anybody has called baseball ''the national pastime.'' People under 30 may doubt that anybody ever did so, yet such is the truth.

title: AT BAT WITH JUGHEAD STEVENS AND THE INVADERS
description: Jughead Stevens threatens the very future of the game, walloping one pitch after another downrange in suborbital flights that sail high over the tall chain-link fence and crash down on the cars, buildings and residents of Amboy Street in Brownsville. Little kids retrieve the balls quickly to keep the game going, but as Jughead rockets them onto rooftops and into an adjacent backyard occupied by two vicious guard dogs, there are long breaks in the action.

title: COMPTEX RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to July 7
CHILE BOMB KILLS ONE NEAR A U.S. CONSULATE
description: A car packed with explosives blew up tonight across the street from the United States Consulate here, killing a man in a passing car and wounding two policemen who had been standing guard outside the consulate, the police reported.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Army Contracts
description: The Army said today that it narrowed the field of competitors for developing engines for the Army's helicopters of the 1990's to two corporate teams.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Third annual Garden State Games. Swimming, at Rahway River Park, 8 A.M. to noon. Gymnastics, at Dillon Gymnasium, Princeton University, 1:30 P.M. Wheelchair basketball games, at Ocean County College, Toms River, 5 P.M. Maccabiah Games, at Tel Aviv.

title: COURT OVERTURNS KEY F.C.C. RULE COVERING CABLE
description: A Federal appeals court panel today struck down Government regulations that require cable systems to carry without charge all television stations that are watched by a significant number of people in their communities.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $5,200,000 for the quarter and the six months. c-Including a gain of $9,400,000 from the sale of Pine Point Mines shares. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter and six months because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: New Securities Tied to Assets
description: THE wide acceptance by investors of mortgage-backed securities has led recently to a similar securities phenomenon: what Wall Street calls asset securitization. And as was the case with the development of mortgage-backed securities - such as those issued by the Government National Mortgage Association and known as Ginnie Maes - the securities represented in this new category are moving beyond their original institutional market and being sold to individual investors.

title: Playoff Canceled
description: The United States Basketball League announced today that it was canceling its playoffs and would instead award the league championship to the team with the best regular-season record.

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $401,000 for the quarter and $692,000 for the six months.

title: ALCOA'S PROFITS DROP 64%
description: The Aluminum Company of America yesterday reported a 64 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, primarily because of an after-tax charge of $15.6 million involving its Nantahala Power and Light Company subsidiary. But analysts, saying they were encouraged by the operating performance, increased their earnings estimates for the year.

title: GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATE CHIEFS PLAN NEW OFFER TO HOUSE ON BUDGET
description: The Senate majority leader and the Budget Committee chairman said today that Senate Republicans would make a legitimate counteroffer on the budget to the House next week.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $6,700,000, or 22 cents a share, from the settlement of litigation, a charge of $5,100,000 for a plant writedown and a charge of $1,700,000 for manufacturing facilities consolidation.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF ARIONA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY MANAGERS HELPED BRING NEW YORK BACK FROM THE BRINK
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITALS IN THE FREE MARKET
description: To the Editor:

title: AT LEAST 80 KILLED IN A DAM COLLAPSE IN NORTHERN ITALY
description: An earthen dam in the northern Italian mountains burst today, sending forth what one survivor called ''a wall of mud and water'' and killing at least 80 people. Officials said they expected the death toll to rise to 200 or more.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
J. DAVID LAWYERS UNDER FIRE
description: The sentencing late last month of J. David Dominelli to 20 years in Federal prison for fraud and income tax evasion closed a chapter in one of the biggest investment frauds in United States history. But for the lawyers and accountants who offered professional advice to Mr. Dominelli's San Diego financial empire, J. David & Company, the tale is far from over.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net charge of $20.6 million from plant closings and cutbacks and also environmental expenses at previously operated plants. c-Net income. d-After a loss of $5.2 million from discontinued operations.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net charge of $15,600,000 for the quarter and the six months in connection with a utility rate case involving a subsidiary.

title: 63D ST. TUNNEL PROBLEMS NOTED IN '74
description: As early as 1974, when the first sections of the 63d Street subway tunnel were being completed, transit officials were aware of significant water leaks in the structure, Transit Authority documents show.

title: NAVY SAYS ADMIRAL IS CLEARED BY REPORT ON WAR SOUVENIRS
description: The Navy said today that an investigation by the Pentagon inspector general had exonerated Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf 3d of wrongdoing for transporting automatic rifles home as souvenirs from the 1983 invasion of Grenada.

title: LTV PLANS TO SELL SPECIALTY STEEL UNIT
description: The LTV Corporation, acting to strengthen its balance sheet, said yesterday that it planned to sell its specialty steel products unit, the nation's second-largest producer of stainless steel, after Allegheny Ludlum.

title: FALLING CONCRETE CAUSES QUEENS PARK TO CLOSE
description: A large playground under the Queens end of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge has been closed because of pieces of concrete falling from the roadway.

title: Ready to Run
description: Vince Dooley, the University of Georgia football coach who is weighing a race for the Senate, said he will not announce his decision until next week, but there were indications yesterday that he has virtually made up his mind to make the race and has even decided on his replacement as coach. According to The Atlanta Constitution, Dooley, who is also Georgia's athletic director, has decided to recommend that his offensive coordinator, George Haffner, take over as interim head coach if he does seek the Democratic nomination. Dooley has said only that he would sever his connections with the university if he makes the race, and Haffner, who joined Dooley's staff in 1980 after stints at Iowa State, Pittsburgh and Texas A&M, said he knew nothing about Dooley's plans.

title: STAGE: 'MACBETH' BY ITALIAN TROUPE
description: At the end of the ''Macbeth'' performed in Italian by La Compagnia del Collettivo/Teatro Due di Parma, Macbeth's opinion is that life is like a movie, among other things. That is an apt hint toward understanding this astonishing piece of theater being staged as part of the Pepsico Summerfare on the State University of New York campus here. In it the cinematic techniques of Fellini are at least as evident as the methods of classical theater or the commedia dell'arte, and agitprop battles with poetry.

title: LIVE AID TURNS TO PLANS FOR FUTURE
description: The outpouring of financial generosity for African famine victims evoked by last weekend's ''Live Aid'' rock concerts surprised even its promoters and has led them to consider expanding emergency help to include long-range assistance.

title: KANSAS SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $21,243,000 on the sale of television stations.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROMISING BOXER GOES HOME AGAIN
description: The fighter was home now, and as he walked the familiar streets, the passing cars would slow for a friendly ''Hi, Pete,'' and in the projects, the windows would roll up and some neighbor's head would stick out - ''Hi, Pete.''

title: WORKER DIES IN L.I. ACCIDENT
description: One worker died and 11 others were injured today when deadly methane gas and raw sewage suddenly spewed from a malfunctioning pipe in the sewage treatment plant here, authorities said. An assistant superintendent at the plant, John Pinckney, 59 years old, of Long Beach, died of a heart attack after he was apparently overcome with the gas in the basement of the plant, the Long Beach City Manager, Edwin Eaton, said. The others - seven city employees and four firefighters -were taken to Long Beach Memorial Hospital.

title: ANTI-U.S. PROTEST IN BERLIN
description: About 100 demonstrators who were protesting United States policy toward Nicaragua stoned police cars and set fires today in a street here, a police spokesman said. The police used clubs and tear gas to break up the demonstrators, but there were no injuries or arrests, the spokesman said. The police said the demonstrators, apparently members of Berlin's radical squatter groups, began their protest shortly before midnight in the Kreuzberg district of the city.

title: DETREX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A FAD FOR THE YOUNG
description: They seem to be this summer's hit novelty, at least for the very, very young set. Plastic chain-link necklaces they are, in light purple, or fuchsia, or mauve, depending upon your eye.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GIGA-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
10-YEAR FIGHT ON CITY NOTES NEARS AN END
description: In 1974 and early 1975, as New York City skidded toward near bankruptcy, thousands of investors, many of them civil servants and retirees, bought more than $3 billion worth of its notes and bonds.

title: DEVALUATION IS WEIGHED
description: Citing uncontrollable trading, the Italian Government suspended foreign exchange trading today after the lira plunged in heavy selling.

title: Ex-Steeler Hurt
description: Jim Clack, who played guard and center for the Pittsburgh Steelers (1971-77) and center for the Giants (1978-81), is listed in very serious condition at Nash General Hospital in his home town of Rocky Mount, N.C. His wife, Patti, is listed in serious condition. They were injured when their automobile collided with a truck Wednesday morning. Both have undergone surgery.

title: Bridge;   Baby Pictures Are Diversion At a New York Tournament
description: A large number of players at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan today will be carefully examining a bunch of baby pictures.

title: PRESIDENT OF WANG RESIGNS
description: The president of Wang Laboratories, John F. Cunningham, resigned yesterday in what Wall Street analysts called another blow to the troubled maker of computers and office-automation equipment.

title: FUNDS COLLECTED TO SAVE 'ALL THINGS CONSIDERED'
description: National Public Radio has collected enough money to save the weekend edition of its news magazine, ''All Things Considered,'' a spokesman said today.

title: LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. The Live Aid concert. Abbie Hoffman. 2. The Palestine Liberation Organization gave Jordan a list of Palestinians Yasir Arafat has suggested as possible members of a delegation to take part in talks with the United States about ending the Arab-Israeli conflict. The list was conveyed by Jordan to the United States and by the United States to Israel, which rejected it. 3. Disagree. 4. The 100-inch telescope of the Mount Wilson Observatory in California was boarded up. 5. Governor Cuomo testified against President Reagan's plan on tax revision. 6. The question was from 78-year-old Henry Cotton to 36-year-old Christy O'Connor Jr., who had shot a 64 to break Mr. Cotton's 51-year-old record at Royal St. George's golf course in the British Open. 7. The shunting of casualities by the Air Force after the 1983 truck bombing of the Marine Corps barracks in Lebanon to an overburdened Air Force hospital instead of better-prepared Army hospitals. 8. The 1973 decision that established the constitutional right to obtain an abortion. 9. The village is Boys Town. 10. Young people may no longer be discharged from the city's foster care system until they have been given supervision and a place to live. 11. False. 12. Toward Uranus. 13. It was a way that L'Enfant could show his dislike of the Chief Justice of that day, John Jay. 14. The BankAmerica Corporation. 15. ''Iacocca'' became one of the adult hard-cover books to have surpassed the two million production mark. 16. Less. 17.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. ''It's your Woodstock,'' a performer told these spectators. What concert did they attend, and who coined the term ''Woodstock Nation'' after a concert in 1969? 2. A list of names circulated from nation to nation to nation. Identify the list and the nations. 3. Legal experts (agree/disagree) with President Reagan's suggestion that the drafters of the 25th Amendment, on the transfer of Presidential powers, did not intend it to be invoked in brief periods of incapacity, such as surgery. 4. The lights were turned out on an era of science after almost 25,000 nights of viewing that had yielded some of the most profound discoveries of modern science. What happened? 5. ''A central idea at the heart of our Republic is that we are one nation, not 50 nations, and that we are strongest when we stand together,'' said a speaker before the House Ways and Means Committee. Who is he and what was at issue? 6. ''Christy, did you play all 18?'' Who asked this question and what were the circumstances? 7. According to an internal memorandum prepared by an Army officer, an Air Force operation carried out in 1983 was indefensible ''medically, morally or ethically.'' To what does the memorandum refer? 8. The Reagan Administration called on the Supreme Court to reverse a landmark decision. What decision was it? 9. It is noteworthy that there are now 26 girls living in a little village west of Omaha. Explain. 10.

title:
PATENTS;

Sensitive Technique Aids Cancer Detection
description: A sensitive technique for detecting disease-causing substances, antigens and the antibodies produced in response to them was patented this week. The inventors are Yi-Her Jou and Richard B. Bankert, who did their research at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo and received patent 4,529,712.

title: GRAY AREA OF THE LAW
description: The 12 jurors passing on the fate of Christopher Thomas had to do more than weigh the evidence against him. They were asked to place themselves in his shoes and imagine whether he felt, in his drug-induced fury, that his acts were ''reasonable.'' The verdict they rendered yesterday hinted, in a sense, that their answer to the question was yes.

title: COLUMBUS CIRCLE FOLLY
description: Mayor Koch's announcement that a developer had been chosen for the Coliseum site, in midtown Manhattan, was received with overwhelming disappointment and intense embarrassment by the architectural community. The objection was not to the developer, Boston Properties, but to the selection process that deliberately disregarded design.

title: MATEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
1980 QUERY OF HUTTON PLAN CITED
description: A Congressional subcommittee was told today that, as early as March 1980, questions were raised within E. F. Hutton & Company over the legality of the firm's systematic overdrafts on the checking accounts of branch offices.

title: Cram Session
description: The way that bicycles fill the streets of most of its cities, with workers pedaling to and from their jobs, you might imagine that China had long since taken to cycling competition as naturally as Bernard Hinault takes to yellow jerseys. Not so, though. Indeed, the Chinese have rarely been very big on two-wheeler races, which is why they are now engaged in something of a cram session.

title: Shell-Arco Deal
description: The Shell Oil Company said that it had signed the previously announced agreement to buy 400 Atlantic Richfield Company service stations in eight Northeastern states and Washington, D.C., the companies said. The sale price was not disclosed. The sale is part of an Arco restructuring plan that calls for it to withdraw from the Northeastern market.

title: Nihilator's Victory Is the Track's Loss
description: Nihilator tied a world record tonight when he covered a mile in 1:50 3/5 and scored a 7 1/4-length victory in the $1,018,000 Meadowlands Pace, the second leg of the pacing triple crown series for 3-year-olds.

title: Electrical Fire Forces 2,000 To Leave Seagram Building
description: More than 2,000 office workers were forced to leave the Seagram Building yesterday afternoon when an electrical fire spread smoke through the lower floors of the midtown Manhattan building.

title: THE DANCE: A BROOKLYN MARATHON
description: The ambitious but delightfully informal Celebrate Brooklyn Festival - which runs through Sept. 22 at the Prospect Park Band Shell at Prospect Park West and Ninth Street in Brooklyn - includes modern and ethnic dance, Shakespeare, and pop, latin, Afro-American and rock music presented by performers ranging from Mark Morris and Peggy Lyman, tonight, to Women of the Calabash on Aug. 25.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
RECOGNITION FOR THOSE STILL MISSING
description: The music of the Army Band was punctuated by the firing of the four cannon. Minutes later, the helicopters were seen in the distance.

title: CLASHES AND LOOTING REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Arson, looting and stonethrowing continued across South Africa today, the police said.

title: 2 Stars of Music And a 44-Year Friendship
description: Benny Goodman was in the audience at the Ballroom watching Peggy Lee the other night, just as he had been in the audience at the Buttery in Chicago in 1941, where he discovered her.

title: INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
T.W.A. HIJACKING PROVES AID TO FREQUENT TRAVELER
description: An official at Trans World Airlines said today that the airline had credited a former hostage for the miles he traveled when the airline's hijacked Flight 847 was flown four times between Algeria and Lebanon in June.

title:
PATENTS;

Radar System Identifies Aircraft by Their Speed
description: A radar system for identifying aircraft by their speed has been invented for the Department of Transportation.

title: TAYLOR STORER
description: Taylor Storer, general manager of the New Music Distribution Service, died Thursday in St. Louis after a long illness. He was 29 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hospital Supply in Shifts
description: The board of the American Hospital Supply Corporation, which earlier this week accepted a $3.8 billion buyout offer from Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., has named Harold G. Bernthal, American Hospital Supply's president and chief operating officer, to the new post of vice chairman. Frank A. Ehmann, an executive vice president, was named to Mr. Bernthal's former posts.

title: Sunrise Depositors Throng Branches
description: Hundreds of worried depositors lined up today at the 14 branches of the Sunrise Savings and Loan Association after the insolvent institution was taken over by Federal regulators. About $10 million in deposits were withdrawn today, despite assurances from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board that all funds are safe.

title: CADILLAC FAIRVIEW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $5,900,000.

title: TAX REFORM'S STING IN PUERTO RICO
description: Some major bad news for Puerto Rico has stirred too little concern in Washington. The resource-poor but labor-rich island has benefited for decades from a special tax provision that generated half its manufacturing jobs. So Puerto Ricans were stunned to find the Treasury proposing its instant elimination as part of tax reform. Now President Reagan offers what looks like a compromise but isn't: the benefit would be phased out in five years, to be replaced by a gimmicky wage credit.

title: SENSITIVE EQUIPMENT HELD EARMARKED FOR IRAN
description: A Federal prosecutor said today sophisticated military hardware earmarked for shipment to Iran by an international smuggling ring included equipment whose loss would represent a ''serious breach'' of national security.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nicaragua has neither practiced nor supported terrorism, nor has it been involved in any terrorist act.'' -President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [3:5.]

title: FAMINE-RELIEF SHIPMENTS TO RESUME IN SUDAN
description: A washed-out rail link between the central and western regions of the Sudan has been restored, and shipments of emergency food supplies to famine-affected provinces will be resumed soon, United States officials said this week.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARCHITECTURE THAT DISSERVES NEW YORK
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, on Madison Avenue at 75th Street in Manhattan, is one of the most important works by Marcel Breuer, a master of the modern movement in architecture. Completed in 1966, his building has become a landmark - in its recognition by the public and architects if not by formal declaration. But the architecture of the Whitney is threatened by a proposed expansion that would adjoin it on the south side, surmount it above and bury portions of its distinctive outward-stepping facade.

title: FOR YOUNG JAPANESE CAMPERS, A SUMMER OF DISCIPLINED FUN
description: It is a few minutes before the lunch hour, and in the dining hall 11 children are methodically preparing the long rows of tables. Napkins are folded and placed precisely. Silverware follows with equal care.

title: TEHERAN URGES PILGRIMS TO BE ACTIVISTS IN MECCA
description: Teheran today urged Iran's 150,000 pilgrims to the holy city of Mecca next month to mix their religious experience with political activism, the Iranian press agency reported.

title: REAGAN TO LEAVE HOSPITAL TODAY FOR WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan is to return to the White House from the Bethesda Naval Medical Center on Saturday, one week after undergoing surgery in which a cancerous growth was removed from his colon.

title: Gamblers Deal May Go Down
description: A syndicate headed by a wealthy New York real estate man who wants to bring professional football back to Shea Stadium reportedly signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Houston Gamblers. But the deal may have been doomed before it was even struck.

title: SHIP OUR CARGO UNDER OUR FLAG
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRISTIE'S CHAIRMAN QUITS IN FALSE SALE CASE
description: David Bathurst, the chairman of Christie's New York and London operations, who has admitted that he falsely reported the number of paintings sold in a New York auction in 1981, resigned yesterday.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 7. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include operations of R. W. Harmon & Sons Inc., acquired Oct. 1, 1984.

title: PSYCHIATRIC TESTS SOUGHT FOR AGCA AT TRIAL IN ROME
description: A defense lawyer asked today that Mehmet Ali Agca be ordered to undergo psychiatric tests to determine whether the Turk, the chief witness for the prosecution, is capable of giving valid testimony.

title:
PATENTS;

Special Armor Is Devised
description: THE Goodyear Aerospace Corporation, which has produced military protective devices for years, has developed a new form called spaced armor. When installed around a shelter, the armor not only offers protection to personnel inside, but also lets them fire through it against an approaching enemy.

title: 'HATCHECK KING' IN THE 1940'S
description: Abraham Ellis, who became a millionaire by operating hatcheck concessions in the heyday of New York City nightclubs, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Orange, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: THE EMPEROR'S ARC
description: To the Editor:

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dow Sets Record 3d Time in Week
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record level for the third time this week. The market was given its impetus by institutional investors who took part in complicated buying strategies related to options expirations.

title: CLUETT PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-After a charge of $2,500,000 for restructuring which reduced net by 14 cents a share.

title: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
HANOVER COMPANIES reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $10,890,000.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
ISRAELI RADIO REPORTS A SOVIET OFFER ON NEW TIES
description: The Israeli state radio reported today that the Soviet Union had offered an arrangement under which diplomatic relations between the two countries could be restored. They were broken off in 1967.

title: FORT WAYNE MAYOR IS OUT, THEN IN
description: Fort Wayne, ''the city that saved itself,'' from three disastrous floods in the last seven years, is now riven because of politics.

title: MORE PROMISES THAN TAXIS
description: Is Mayor Koch really serious about improving New York's taxi service? Judging by the number of his proposals, revised proposals and alternatives to revised proposals, he has time for little else. Judging by the paucity of results, it's plain that his good intentions aren't enough. If New Yorkers are ever to get the first-rate taxi service they need, Mr. Koch will have to overcome his obvious reluctance to spend some political capital to stand up to the taxi industry.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect a writedown of $707,000 related to an acquisition.

title: HOW'S YOUR HEALTH?
description: Nothing seems to stir concern over the state of one's health more than a well-publicized illness of a White House figure.

title: LEGG MASON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TO MANUEL GARCIA, LOVE IS A SHAVED HEAD
description: When chemotherapy left Manuel Garcia with only patches of hair, and he shaved those off, he was concerned that ''I would be the only one.'' He need not have worried. His home and neighborhood is teeming with bald heads, all in the cause of love and concern for the 35-year-old Mr. Garcia in his fight against stomach cancer.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results include a one-time adjustment for fuel savings related to pre-commercial operations of unit 11 of the Mcguire nuclear station that increased earnings by eight cents a share.

title: NICARAGUAN, AT A RALLY, ACCUSES U.S. OF TERROR
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, addressing a vast crowd on the sixth anniversary of the Nicaraguan revolution, asserted today that it was the United States, not Nicaragua, that was supporting terrorism.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 1.7 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 1.7 million shares, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, in the month ended July 15, to 251.3 million shares. The record of 253 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 201.6 million shares.

title: MEDIATORS ENTER TALKS AT WHEELING STEEL
description: In an 11th-hour attempt to avert a threatened strike, Federal mediators today entered the stalled negotiations between the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and its unionized employees.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIRCAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $4,040,000 for the quarter and $4,985,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $1,394,000 for the quarter and $1,775,000 for the six months.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an $8,400,000 pre-tax inventory writedown.

title:
CONSUMER SATURDAY;

SOBER SIDE OF BOATING IS SAFETY
description: THE height of the boating season has arrived in the New York metropolitan area. On Saturdays and Sundays in July and August, local waterways are jammed with vessels carrying friends and food. But despite the good times that boating offers, a sober side cannot be ignored: Boating is dangerous if safety measures are not observed.

title: AMERICAN CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,132,000 for the quarter and $4,509,000 for the six months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $3,457,000, or 24 cents a share for the quarter and $6,824,000, or 48 cents, for the six months.

title: BENCH CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 20, 1985
description: International

title: BIG V SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EX-CARIBBEAN OFFICIAL GULITY OF SIX DRUG-RELATED COUNTS
description: The former chief minister of the Turks and Caicos Islands, charged in a drug smuggling case, was convicted today of six counts, including conspiracy, but acquitted of more severe drug smuggling charges. A second former minister was found guilty of conspiracy.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lockheed Net Up 11.5%
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 11.5 percent, to $87 million, or $1.32 a share, from $78 million, or $1.21 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 14.5 percent, to $2.21 billion, from $1.93 billion. ''Earnings for the full year will continue to show good gains over 1984's record results,'' when Lockheed earned $344 million, Roy Anderson, the aerospace company's chairman and chief executive, said.

title: SOVIET TELLS CONFERENCE IT WILL HALT COMMERCIAL WHALING BY 1987
description: In a move that conservationists said was another major step toward ending all commercial hunting of whales, the Soviet Union said this week that it would cease commercial whaling by 1987.

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SURGE IN STREET VENDORS EVOKES MIXED REVIEWS
description: A Washington man sells luggage from a curbside table. A Seattle couple peddle bagels in the shadow of the Monorail. In midtown Manhattan, half a dozen people hawk sunglasses and jewelry outside Saks Fifth Avenue. And in major cities around the country, the red-and-yellow umbrella is the sign of the sidewalk hotdog stand.

title: TEACHER IS PICKED FOR SHUTTLE TRIP
description: A high school teacher from New Hampshire, Sharon Christa McAuliffe, was named yesterday as the nation's first ordinary citizen scheduled to go in orbit aboard the space shuttle as a passenger.

title: Charles Manson Transferred
description: Charles Manson, convicted in the 1969 murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six others in two separate places, was returned to San Quentin Prison Thursday after nine years in the state's psychiatric prison in nearby Vacaville, prison officials said.

title: FPL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARD TIMES FOR HARD BULLETS
description: The Senate dealt a body blow to gun control this month by approving Senator McClure's bill to weaken the 17-year-old ban on interstate gun sales. Now it appears ready to make some amends by restricting armor-piercing ammunition. More than just a consolation prize, the bill would significantly enhance public safety, especially that of the police.

title: COOKE SELLS STAKE TO MULTIMEDIA
description: Multimedia Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Jack Kent Cooke's 10 percent stake for a large premium over what the newspaper, cable-TV and broadcast company is offering shareholders in its recapitalization plan.

title: CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about personal income misstated the increase in personal spending from May to June. It was six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: House Cuts Off Fund For Playboy in Braille
description: The House of Representatives says it will no longer pay for Braille editions of Playboy magazine stocked at the Library of Congress.

title: U.S. Seeking GATT Talks
description: The United States, frustrated by the failure of the 90-member council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to set a date for a new round of anti-protectionist trade talks, today called for a meeting of senior officials in September.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES CHAIRMAN OF F.T.C. AS BUDGET CHIEF
description: President Reagan, moving quickly to fill the post, today appointed James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, to succeed David A. Stockman as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Bellamy Moves to Challenge Farrell Nominating Petitions
description: Carol Bellamy's campaign took a legal step yesterday to make sure that if she challenges an opponent's nominating petitions and loses the challenge, she would be able to appeal in court.

title: HEART PATIENT STEPS FORWARD GRATEFUL FOR AN EXTENDED LIFE
description: The world's fourth recipient of a permanent artificial heart introduced himself to the world today and said he was living proof that a mechanical heart can lengthen and improve one's quality of life.

title: ROBERT C. HOFFMAN
description: Robert C. Hoffman, founder of the York Barbell Corporation, the nation's leading maker of Olympic-style weight-lifting equipment, died Thursday.

title: LIBERTY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

BOOKS OF THE TIMES;

BEHIND A REVOLUTION
description: NICARAGUA: Revolution in the Family.

title: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRAISE FOR CONGRESS (SURPRISE!)
description: It may not be the kind of news that snatches headlines, but a recent Harris poll in which Congress was given a positive rating for the first time in 20 years was an eye-opener.

title: Monsanto's Offer Pleases Investors
description: Investors reacted positively yesterday to the Monsanto Company's proposed $2.7 billion acquisition of G.D. Searle & Company, pushing Monsanto's stock was up $2.375, to $52.625, in heavy trading.

title: U.S. CANCELS PASTA DUTY RISE
description: The United States today suspended an increase in duties on Italian pasta that was ordered by President Reagan to retaliate against the Europeans' failure to resolve a dispute over citrus trade.

title: U.S. MAGISTRATE DENIES BAIL FOR GHANA MAN IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal magistrate found probable cause to hold a relative of Ghana's leader on espionage charges and rejected a request that a Ghanian national accused of conspiring to commit espionage be released to the custody of the Ghanian Ambassador to the United States.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advanced Micro Plunge
description: Advanced Micro Devices of Sunnyvale, Calif., a semiconductor maker, yesterday reported a 98.1 percent drop in earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended June 30 to $739,000, or 1 cent a share, from $38.2 million, or 66 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 1
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $3,123,000, or 63 cents a share. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,200,000 and including an extraordinary credit of $32,004,000 principally from termination of a pension and retirement plan.

title: Bond Prices Little Changed
description: Bond prices were little changed yesterday as the credit markets calmed after the tumultuous tumble in prices on Thursday.

title: DR. PEARL KIBRE
description: Dr. Pearl Kibre, a retired history professor and scholar in medieval studies at City University, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.

title: ADAMS-RUSSELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXTRON ENDS EFFORT TO SELL UNIT
description: Textron Inc. yesterday ended a five-month effort to sell its Bell Helicopter subsidiary, apparently because potential buyers balked after the Army disclosed last week that Bell was under investigation and that some payments would be withheld.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HENRY C. SEGAL
description: Henry C. Segal, for more than five decades editor and publisher of The American Israelite, a Jewish-American weekly newspaper, died Thursday at the Glen Manor Home for the Jewish Aged in Cincinnati.

title: NO WORLD SERIES AT WRIGLEY
description: The Chicago Cubs announced today that if the team qualified it would not play World Series games on its home field ''because of the light situation in Wrigley Field,'' the last major league park without lights.

title: BRITAIN DETAINS 29 IN MAY SOCCER RIOT
description: The British police are pressing an investigation into the involvement of British soccer fans in a stadium riot in Brussels in May in which 38 people died.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $255,000 for the quarter and $1,173,000 for the year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers said they had reached agreement on a multiyear contract with Steve Calabria, the quarterback from Carle Place, L.I., and Colgate University who was a ninth-round draft choice. Other terms were not disclosed. . . . Joe Cribbs, the running back for the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, said he has bought out the remaining two years of his contract with the Stallions for $750,000 and plans to be back in the National Football League by Thursday, according to his agent, Louis Burrell. . . . The Dallas Mavericks signed Uwe Blab, center from Indiana, the third of the team's three first-round draft choices.

title: U.S. OFFERS $100,000 FOR KILLERS OF 6 AMERICANS IN SAN SALVADOR
description: The United States offered a reward today of up to $100,000 for information leading to ''the effective prosecution and punishment'' of those who killed six Americans in San Salvador last month. They were among 13 people slain in the incident.

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain and cost of $8,139,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and the six months, related to the sale of the company's polyester and explosive businesses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 20, 1985
description: Companies

title: BRAIN-DEATH LAWS PROTECT FAMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE BIG ROLL IS OVER
description: Sam Rubin likes to say that when he walks from the craps table after shooting the dice, no one can tell from his expression whether he broke the bank or came up with snake eyes. That's the sign of a good loser. Another maxim for a crapshooter is that when your big run is over and the dice start to go cold, it's time to get up and leave before throwing back all your winnings.

title: Homes for Bikes
description: ''The human being on a bicycle is the most efficient means of transportation - rivaled only by the salmon,'' observed Kirkpatrick Sale, an author, at an opening of an exhibition of bicycle-shelter designs.

title: Body Is Found on Parkway
description: The body of a man, tentatively identified as a 22-year-old resident of Florida, was pushed from a southbound car on the Henry Hudson Parkway near 162d Street early yesterday, the police reported. A motorist found the body at 4:30 A.M. and alerted the police, who closed a southbound lane until the body was removed about 9 A.M. The police said the man apparently had been killed in the car at the scene by a single shot in the left temple.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A SPEECH FEST
description: All's quiet on the Capitol front this weekend, with neither the Senate nor the House in session.

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $1,300,000 for the quarter and $6,500,000 for the six months. c-Including gains of $1,500,000 for the quarter and $6,500,000 for the six months. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last month. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines Inc., Dallas, a unit of AMR Corp., has applied to the Transportation Department to begin nonstop service from Chicago to Paris next spring.

title: FRONTIER HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LIFE CARE COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BADGER METER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PATENTS;

Under-$100 Cost Seen For Videotex Terminal
description: An invention patented this week for Arthur D. Little Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., is regarded by the company as a low-cost videotex terminal that could be manufactured and sold for under $100.

title: CONTINENTAL TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an $11,900,000 pretax gain on the sale of the company's Alaska telephone properties.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: There were 12 weeks in the latest quarter compared with 13 a year ago and 52 weeks in the latest fiscal year compared with 53 a year earlier .

title: New Rules for Military Care
description: Military physicians will be required for the first time to obtain state medical licenses under a directive signed Thursday as part of a Pentagon campaign to assure quality medical care for military personnel and their families.

title: AMERICAN FRONTIER EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Young Can Talk
description: More news from the junior league:

title: JUDGE'S BANTERING EASES MOOD OF PARK FIRE TRIAL
description: During the eight-week trial growing out of the deaths of eight teen-agers last year in a fire at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, Judge Mark Addison has employed patience and humor in generous measure to deal with the frayed tempers and tedious technical testimony.

title: Muncie Returns
description: Chuck Muncie, the running back who was suspended last year after failing a drug test, was reinstated yesterday by Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, and then traded from the San Diego Chargers to the Minnesota Vikings. San Diego received an undisclosed draft choice, according to a team spokesman.

title: 31 Sex-Abuse Charges Filed Against 4 at Day-Care Center
description: A Westchester County grand jury today returned a 31-count indictment charging four people in the sexual abuse and endangered welfare of six young girls at a Mount Vernon day-care center.

title: POSTAL SERVICE FACING LOSSES OF UP TO $500 MILLION
description: Despite rate increases in February and various cost-cutting measures, the United States Postal Service is losing $1 million a day and faces a potential loss of $500 million this year, Postal Service officials said Thursday.

title: Kidnapping of Athlete Brings a 20-Year Term
description: Dan Nichols was sentenced today to 20 years and six months in prison for kidnapping an Olympic athlete to force her to live in the mountains with him.

title: Springsteen Fans Line Up
description: Some lounged on lawn chairs.

title: WOMEN JOINING TO DETER THE MIDTOWN ATTACKER
description: Thousands of women who work in midtown Manhattan office buildings have begun checking elevators for strangers before getting on, riding only in pairs or groups and getting off if they are left alone with strangers.

title: WORK ON SUNKEN BARGE
description: Crews working with two cranes and four winches today began efforts to right a drilling barge that capsized in a muddy channel May 20, killing 11 crewmen, a Coast Guard spokesman said. The spokesman said the crews planned to right the barge but leave it on the bottom of the waterway until it could be pumped out and refloated. Three tugboats were guiding the floating rig through the bayou to a new drilling site when it toppled, drowning half of the 22-man crew.

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Korea and Japan Auto Pact Is Set
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and South Korea's Hyundai Motor Company have agreed to produce a new passenger car called the Denonair, a Mitsubishi spokesman said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THEN AND NOW Flushing, in northern Queens, has a history that goes back to the days of Dutch rule and played an important role in our definition of freedom. When Peter Stuyvesant suppressed Quaker meetings at the Bowne House, complaints to the home office in Holland elicited assurances of religious tolerance. Stuyvesant is buried in Manhattan and the Bowne House, built in 1661, still stands in Flushing in a park at 37-01 Bowne Street, a block south of Northern Boulevard and two blocks east of Main Street.

title: COMSERV CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a charge of $12,800,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting charge.

title: IN ISRAEL, NEW FIGHT OVER PORK SALES TURNS PIGS INTO ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: The manager of Israel's biggest pork factory sits behind his desk wearing a long white butcher's coat on his back and a worried wrinkle on his brow.

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $900,000 for the closing down of the evening edition of the Winston-Salem newspaper. c-Including a pretax gain of $4 million from the sale of land.

title: SOVIET CALLS ITS RIGHTS FOES IN WEST SLAVE TRADERS WHO DEBAUCH GIRLS
description: A Soviet spokesman accused human rights advocates in the West today of being slave traders who run networks of houses of prostitution where they debauch young girls.

title: DEFENDANT IN THE KILLING OF 10 IS GUILTY OF REDUCED CHARGE
description: A Bronx man described in testimony as a drug dealer and cocaine addict was acquitted of murder yesterday but convicted on reduced charges of manslaughter in the killing of 10 people in a Brooklyn apartment last year.

title: 3 MISSING BOLTS CITED IN DEATHS AT BUILDING SITE
description: Three bolts missing from the framework of a construction elevator in midtown Manhattan caused its collapse Thursday, killing two workers and injuring another, the City Buildings Commissioner said yesterday.

title: YANKEES END FRUSTRATION IN METRODOME
description: Billy Martin wore a smile, which seemed a bit incongruous since he was still inside the Metrodome, a place that holds nothing for him but unpleasant memories.

title: U.S. WOMEN SPLIT WITH DELEGATES IN KENYA
description: As Forum '85, the informal gathering of more than 10,000 women here, ended today with jubilation, singing and dancing, American women were stunned to hear a member of the United States delegation to the official conference question the mandate of the Plan of Action adopted at the 1977 Houston women's conference. The plan, a national declaration of equality for American women, was drafted in response to the United Nations Decade for Women, which began in 1976.

title: CAMPAIGN OF SILENCE
description: ''Silence is golden'' were the opening words of Mayor Koch's statement last week announcing his candidacy for a third term. It would appear, however -from the conduct of his campaign to date - that his citation of the adage was not a reference to some new resolve to change his personality but rather the expression of a wish to keep his opponents muffled - and ignored.
