title: SMITHSONIAN TOLD TO CLEAN UP PCB'S
description: A Government inspector said today that the Smithsonian Institution was violating Federal environmental law by failing to clean up hazardous chemicals leaked from electrical transformers in several of its museums.

title: 20,000 YANKS IN BRITAIN: A LEGAL INVASION ENDS
description: They were packing up today at the Grosvenor House, and at Claridge's and the Dorchester, as the great American legal jamboree came to an end.

title: ANOTHER WAY TO BUTTER CORN, ITS ADVOCATES SAY
description: The local corn crop is coming to market, and this year I am more delighted than usual to see it in the stores. I have been waiting for 11 months to write a follow-up to last year's column on corn. Not only because of the mail, which offered further advice on how to butter, cook and keep corn - much of it instructive, some of it just funny - but also because the column prompted The Belleville (Ill.) News-Democrat to take a corn-buttering poll last August.

title: GRAHAM AND LYLE LEAD BRITISH OPEN
description: The cold, southwest wind that came in off the English Channel today carried a slanting rain that stung the faces and hands of golfers and spectators during the second round of the 114th British Open. It also helped carry Sandy Lyle and David Graham into a share of the lead and Jack Nicklaus out of the tournament, the first time he has missed the cut at the British Open.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A listing yesterday in the Weekend section of fairs and festivals gave an incorrect telephone number to call for information on the West 60th Street fair. The correct number to call is (718) 965-2011.

title: Pratt & Lambert
description: Pratt & Lambert Inc., a Buffalo-based maker of paints and chemicals, said it had received a leveraged buyout proposal of $32 a share, or $60.1 million, from the CM Capital Corporation. The buyer is an affiliate of Carl Marks & Company, a Manhattan-based securities firm. The proposal would be subject to approval from the Pratt & Lambert board and shareholders.

title: 2 Bronx Teen-Agers Arrested In Shooting of Police Officer
description: Two teen-agers were arrested last night and charged with shooting a police officer from the rooftop of a Bronx apartment building on Monday with a .22-caliber rifle, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Jerusalem dispatch yesterday about Palestinian candidates for preliminary Middle East peace talks incorrectly identified an economist and scholar mentioned as a possible alternate delegate or observer. He is Youssef Sayigh, not Feyez Sayigh.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from a division which was sold in December of $2,456,000 for the quarter and $4,728,000 for the six months.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $932,000 for the quarter and $1,232,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $345,000 for the quarter and $493,000 for the 6 months.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prof. Carlos Diaz-Alejandro, Expert on Latin Economics
description: Prof. Carlos Frederico Diaz-Alejandro, a specialist in Latin American economics who taught economics at Columbia University, died Wednesday of pneumonia at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAG LIMIT ON WOODCOCK IS REDUCED
description: THE DAILY bag limit in the upcoming fall and winter season for woodcock in the Atlantic Flyway has been reduced from five birds to three by the Fish and Wildlife Service, and few hunters will disagree with that decision.

title: CULTIVATING JOB SKILLS IN THE CHRONICALLY UNEMPLOYED
description: In a converted warehouse at 161 Hudson Street, while trucks are being loaded and unloaded at neighboring warehouses, people are taking typing lessons, learning clerical skills and being counseled about job interviews.

title: WHY SHOREHAM SHOULDN'T OPEN
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company's ill-starred Shoreham nuclear power plant should never be allowed to operate for a reason that seems to have escaped the current debate: Simply put, someday, it will have to shut down.

title: Electronic Signs, No; Good Lighting, Yes
description: The thought of my tax money being used to erect electronic traffic advisory signs makes my skin crawl [''New Traffic System Delay''] .

title: CHESTER CONCERT IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: AN unusual trio will collaborate in a ''A Musical Feast,'' at the Chester Meeting House on Aug. 3.

title: THREE NEW FILMS: FROM VISION TO REALITY
description: Clint Eastwood has grown accustomed lately to fancy questions about the esthetics of his films.

title: OFF THE HOOK
description: What was stolen: $19,000 in interest from a secret Swiss bank account or a retired two-star Air Force general's honor? A jury in West Palm Beach, Fla., decided last week that it was the latter, and it acquitted Maj. Gen. Richard B. Collins of embezzlement.

title: FOR MANY PLANTS, MOISTURE-LADEN GROUND IS AN IDEAL HOME
description: Nature does spectacular things in wet places. Cattails and rushes grow along damp roadbeds. I never see them without wishing I had my clippers.

title: CAROL CHAMBERLIN WED IN PRINCETON
description: Carol Lynn Chamberlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Patrick Edmund McCabe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. McCabe of New Britain, Conn. The Rev. Robert Robbins performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: NEW SURGE IN PLANS FOR COGENERATION
description: WHEN the Windham Energy Recovery Facility opened in 1981, it was the first large-scale cogeneration plant in the state, producing steam and heat for industry and using some of the steam to generate electricity.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ROSE BLANCHE By Christophe Gallaz and Roberto Innocenti. Illustrated by Roberto Innocenti. Translated by Martha Coventry and Richard Graglia. Illustrated. Unpaged. Mankato, Minn.: Creative Education. $14.95. (Ages 8 and up) IT is our duty to tell children some terrible truths. If the telling causes horror and sorrow, these are appropriate emotions for certain recent historical events, and it is necessary for the young to suffer this painful learning if the future is not to repeat the worst mistakes of the past. But we must be careful to do the telling right.

title: BUILDING BANNED ON THE NISSEQUOGUE
description: A BAN on building along the Nissequogue River in Smithtown has been passed by the State Legislature despite the reluctance of the sponsor of the bill in the Assembly to support its passage.

title: DESERVE JOB AID
description: AN IMPORTANT responsibility of Congress is not just to pass legislation, but also to make sure that new laws, once they are signed by the President, are properly carried out. There is little point in enacting good laws or creating needed programs if they are not enforced.

title: COATS' MILK CHEESE FROM THE CORREZE
description: In southwest France, sheep and goats and cows graze in green fields of lush grasses. In such pasturage country, good cheese is certain to be found. And, indeed, the Auvergne region is known for its cantal, a hard, strong cows' milk cheese, and several piquant blue cheeses similar to Roquefort, which are made of cows' milk rather than of sheeps' milk. Yet, when it comes to goats' milk cheese, cabecou reigns. Perhaps because it is relatively simple to produce, it is one of the most common cheeses in the area.

title: GRANT HELPS OLDER STUDENTS AT SMITH
description: Like most of the 2,500 students at Smith College, the 40 undergraduates who were admitted through the Charles Stewart Mott Scholars program were bright, articulate and concerned about the pursuit of academic excellence. They were also, almost to a woman, broke.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE STORY OF AVIS. By Elizabeth Stuart Phelps. Edited by Carol Farley Kessler. (Rutgers University Press, Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.) Elizabeth Stuart Phelps became a popular author in 1867, at the age of 23, with a rhapsodic first novel about heaven, ''The Gates Ajar.'' Then followed cautionary tales about talented women trapped by marriage and domestic routine. ''The Story of Avis'' (1877) is one of these. In this scholarly reissue it shows us a curious but common type of 19th-century middle-class feminism. Avis is a brilliant art student whose plans to pursue a career are thwarted by love and marriage. Although her husband, Philip, has vowed to respect her ambitions, he breaks his promise by failing to earn enough money to provide her with servants. Burdened with household responsibilities, Avis also faces the rapid cooling of Philip's ardor which (both she and the author agree) was only her due. Given the possibilities for inadvertent humor, the story moves with surprising power toward a gloomy finale that leaves Avis a careworn widow with a child to support and her genius wasted. In addition to the conflict between marriage and career - a new motif in women's fiction at that time - Phelps warns that a gifted woman's worst enemy is not society or men but her own disposition to give herself entirely, and for life, to the first man who arouses her. Unless careful training controls this tendency, she can only be the victim of her own ''supreme capacity of love.''

title: Reagan's Inflate-the-Deficit Game
description: The week of July 8 began with the announcement that David A. Stockman would be leaving as budget director and ended with the Senate Judiciary Committee approving two constitutional amendments requiring a balanced budget. This marks the transition from policy to panic. It suggests we pause for a moment's reflection.

title: NEW FACES PREVAIL IN HUDSON BALLOTING
description: THE changeover in municipal governments in Hudson Conty continued last weel when, in a special recsll election, an insurgent slate of candidates won all five seats on the North Bergen Township Commission.

title: OUT OF A JOB
description: After two and a half years in Albuquerque, the Silvers have been sold back to the Continental Basketball Association, and that means the team's coach, Norm Ellenberger, is out of a job once again. ''It really bothers me to go away leaving a job unfinished,'' he said after Pat McKernan, the club's president and general manager, announced that he could not afford to continue losing money on the team, which had a 34-68 mark in its years in Albuquerque. Ellenberger, who was dismissed as head coach of the University of New Mexico after a recruiting scandal in 1979, said he had not decided on his next step.

title: THE PEACE PROCESS IS TAKING A BACKSEAT TO THE POCKETBOOK
description: When it was learned early last week that Jordan had presented the United States with the names of Palestinians who might be able to take part in peace negotiations, a senior Israeli official was asked for his reaction to the list. His first words were: ''Is it linked to the dollar?''

title: CATHERINE V. CURRY AND ANDRES V. GIL, LAYWERS, ARE MARRIED IN PALM BEACH
description: Catherine V. Curry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Curry of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Andres Valerio Gil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Valerio R. Gil of Miami. The Rev. William J. Wood performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Edward.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FOUL BALL! Five Years in the American League. By Alison Gordon. (Dodd, Mead, $14.95.) As a sportswriter for The Toronto Star, Alison Gordon covered the Toronto Blue Jays for five years, from spring training of the third year of the baseball franchise's existence (1979) until the end of the 1983 season. Watching an inept and luckless expansion team grow into a pennant contender, she got to know, as she puts it, ''a raft of fascinating people,'' and describing those people is what Miss Gordon does best. Of course, she is obliged to include stories about what it is like to be a woman working in the macho world of baseball, particularly doing the locker room interviews essential to a sportswriter's job. She tells these tales but gathers them into one token chapter, as if she got bored, the way most female sportswriters eventually do, with voyeuristic questions about the locker room. ''No one wanted to talk about what the job was like, what the real challenges were,'' she writes. ''They didn't want to talk baseball. All they wanted to know was whether I saw lots of naked men.'' But her job amounted to much more than that, and ''Foul Ball!'' is about what it is like to cover baseball, not about what it is like to be a woman covering baseball. Some might argue that the author herself - a woman who turned 40, got married and pursued various nonsports interests during the time that she covered the Blue Jays - is a more interesting subject than the people she has written about.

title: Peddling Favor
description: There has long been a conflict in the streets of New York prompted by the desire to have food vendors, but not too many food vendors. They are a great convenience to pedestrians in search of a quick lunch. They are also a great nuisance to pedestrians and even auto traffic. They fill a gap in eating places in some parts of town. They unfairly compete with tax-paying eateries elsewhere. The food vendors, in short, are a problem for sensitive government. As Mayor Koch's latest surrender to the problem shows again, they are also a political force, probably because they represent a largely hidden, ill-controlled industry.

title: INFLATION IN CHECK
description: The Consumer Price Index for June, to be announced Tuesday, should show no major change in the inflation rate. For the second straight month, prices will rise two-tenths of a percent, or about 2.4 percent annually, said Martin A. Armstrong, chairman of Princeton Economic Consultants.

title: STRONG TOURISM SEASON IS REPORTED
description: New York State is enjoying a ''very strong'' tourist season this summer, with many resorts and motels having reported an 80 percent occupancy rate during the Fourth of July weekend, according to Commerce Department officials.

title:
DINING OUT;

AN OASIS AMID AN AIRPORT'S BUSTLE
description: PRISCILLA'S, the upscale restaurant in Marriott's handsome new hotel at the center of Newark International Airport, is a plush and intimate oasis amid the increasing bustle of the airport.

title: ELEANOR SOUTHWORTH TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Southworth Jr. of New York and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Ewart Southworth to Bruce Randolph Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Gene Thompson of Lima, Ohio.

title: GOING ONCE
description: After admitting that he had exaggerated the number of paintings sold at a New York auction, David Bathurst brought down the gavel last week on his career as chairman of Christie's New York and London operations. Mr. Bathurst announced in 1981 that three Impressionist paintings had been sold for a total of $5.6 million; in fact, only one was sold, for $2.2 million.

title:
ART;

AMERICANS 'OVER THERE'
description: DURING the 19th century Europe was a magnet for American artists. They were attracted by the opportunity to immerse themselves in the Continent's long artistic, literary and philosophical heritage, and while there they did their best to acquire the knowledge needed to allow their own art to follow these traditions.

title:
ANTIQUES;

WHEN 2 HEADS ARE BETTER THAN 1
description: ALONG the way toward careers in music and textile design, Bari and Phil Axelband discovered an attraction for each other and a deepening interest in the a vocation that has since become thier livelihood.

title: MARRIAGE OF CONVENIENCE
description: Those who think gasoline and sodas do not mix should look at the sales figures of roadside convenience stores. In 1984, gross sales of the nation's 58,000 convenience stores rose 13.6 percent to $50.1 billion.

title: IMPRESSIONISTS IN NEWARK
description: IMPRESSIONISM seems to be the art style that most people prefer today. While they admire other styles, Impressionism is the one they want on their walls at home.

title: ENGLAND
description: To the Editor: On June 30, the Travel section published a letter commending and recommending the services of the British Tourist Office to your readers. The letter writer's terminology may lead to confusion between the British Tourist Authority and the over 700 regionally operated Tourist Information Centers in Britain.

title: FERRAGAMO WELCOMED
description: He may have enjoyed his seven years in balmy California, but Vince Ferragamo, the Ram quarterback who was traded to the Buffalo Bills last week, is taking his transfer to the snow belt with good grace. ''I'm ready to go,'' he said.

title: HOLDING OUT, SELLING OUT
description: SHADOWS OF SILENCE By Arturo Azuela. Translated by Elena C. Murray. 278 pp. Indiana: University of Notre Dame Press. $20.

title: WHEN THE PRESIDENT BECOMES A PATIENT
description: ''The President has cancer.'' With these words, which he shared with the world only moments after telling President Reagan that his colon polyp was malignant, Dr. Steven Rosenberg turned a most intimate personal problem into one of the most extraordinary disclosures of a Presidential illness.

title: PROVIDING CARE AFTER FOSTER CARE
description: The thousands of youths who leave foster care after their 18th birthday must be supervised and trained by New York City, a state judge ruled last week. State law already required that those enrolled in foster care be supervised to the age of 21, but advocates for the homeless contended that the city had failed many people between the ages of 18 and 21.

title: DANI TICKTIN AND PETER JALLER KOPLIK ARE MARRIED
description: Diane Ticktin, a daughter of Nancy Sherwood Ticktin and Richard M. Ticktin, both of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Jaller Koplik, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael R. Koplik, also of New York. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: SHOULD AN AIRLINE BE LIABLE FOR POOR AIRPORT SECURITY?
description: The airport security failures revealed by recent acts of terrorism have raised a legal question that seems sure to figure in future lawsuits: To what extent are airlines financially liable to victims if the best available security was not used?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: KENTUCKY LOVE. By Joe Coomer. (St. Martin's/ Marek. $12.95.) Joe Coomer staked out the Appalachian territory in his stunning first novel, ''The Decatur Road.''

title: MEESE AND PUBLIC AFFAIRS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is reshaping the Office of Public Affairs at the Department of Justice.

title:
GARDENING;

TREES THAT FLOWER IN SUMMERTIME
description: WHILE there is an abundance of flowering trees that bloom in the spring, the number that bloom in the summer is quite limited. However, there are three trees thatare flowering now that are worthy of consideration when summer color is desired.

title: THE MAN IN THE MIDDLE RECALLS A LIFE IN THE RING
description: ''I'M on my 66th world championship, which is perhaps more than any other referee, living or dead.'' For people whose memories run back to the Friday nights when the ''Gillette Fight of the Week'' came from the old Madison Square Garden, where Johnny Addie was the ring announcer and the sportswriter Jimmy Powers delivered the blow-by-blow, the identity of the referee will come as no surprise.

title: Strict Policy on Sublets
description: Question: I'm getting married and my prospective wife's child has to finish high school in Westchester. When I asked if I could sublet my apartment in Ruppert Towers for two years I was told no. Is this true? . . . J. M-J., Manhattan Answer: It is the position of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which supervises Ruppert Towers, that Section 226b of the Real Property Law, commonly called the subletting law, does not apply to the city's Mitchell-Lama housing. Ruth Lerner, assistant commissioner, division of housing supervision, says there is such demand for this housing that the agency would not authorize a sublet except for a a compelling reason, such as serious illness. Fair Winds, or Foul? Question: The owner of my rent-stabilized building has been charging a fee for window air-conditioners even though we pay for electricity. Can he do this and can he charge this fee all year ? . . . M.F., Brooklyn Answer: Yes, he can charge the fee and it can be charged for the full year, says Martin A. Shlufman, the deputy Redinger counsel for rent administration for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. This surcharge may not exceed $10 a month and could be less if other tenants in the building are charged less. Mr. Shlufman says the division is reconsidering its air-conditioner policy for 1986. Gifts or Inheritance? Question: We are in our mid-60's and want to take advantage of the $10,000 annual exemption on gifts that each of us can give our child.

title: RENT BOARD WEIGHS MEANS TEST
description: A MEANS test for tenants has become the major issue in the yearly dispute between tenants and landlords before the Rent Guidelines Board as it considers rent levels for 62,000 apartments in 18 Westchester communities.

title: SUZANNE SCHECTER ENGAGED TO MARRY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Fred Schecter of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Elena Schecter, to Timothy Manasseh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Manasseh of Combe, England. The wedding is to be next summer.

title: COMPUTER MAKERS ARE WAITING TO HIT BOTTOM
description: For a decade the computer industry has prided itself on its role as the youngest and most vibrant segment of the nation's economy. It has grown at an outlandish pace, driven by its own zest for newer, faster and cheaper chips, smaller computers and versatile software.

title: AUTUMN LEAVES, FLUTES IN ST. PAUL
description: 8-Day Tours Of Fall Foliage In New England Though the itinerary incorporates such attractions as Lake Placid, the Adirondack Mountains, the United States Military Academy at West Point, Boston and Newport, the emphasis is on fall foliage.

title: THE GRAMMAR MAVEN MEETS A COMPUTER
description: The Underground Grammarian has embraced the new technology and come into the light. But, his loyal followers will be happy to learn, there is still sedition in his voice.

title: 'SELLING OF L.I.': OTHER VIEWS
description: On the eastern end of Long Island there is evidence yet of the Long Island that Linda B. Martin pines for in her poem-essay. But if Long Island's true character is to be preserved, it is not helped by the fuzzy nostalgic attitudes her writing will engender.

title: PROPHETS IN THEIR OWN COUNTRY
description: JOSEPH SMITH AND THE BEGINNINGS OF MORMONISM By Richard L. Bushman. Illustrated. 262 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $17.95.

title: WHENCE THE ENERGY?
description: House Republicans are all too familiar with small bare meeting rooms, having chafed in the minority for more than 30 years now, so their loyalists seize every opportunity to poke at the Democratic overlords.

title: Tax Reform Should Be Fair to All
description: I was pleased to read on June 23 that Congressmen McGrath and Downey are taking strong positions against the nullification of the state and property-tax deductions as proposed by President Reagan [''Congressmen Join Tax Fight''] .

title: BACK TO BASKETBALL
description: Sonja Hogg, who started the women's basketball program at Louisiana Tech in 1974 and saw the school become a perennial national power by the time she resigned last March, has found a new basketball challenge. She has signed on as head coach of the girls' basketball team at a high school outside Houston.

title: INCREASE IS FEARED IN BURLINGTON POOR
description: DESPITE decreases in the welfare caseload and unemployment rate, some private charities say the the number of homeless and hungry people in Burlington County is growing.

title: MURIEL GOES TO ROME
description: IN GOOD FAITH By Edith Reveley. 267 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $15.95.

title: MEDICARE ASSAILED ON HOME-CARE CAP
description: STRICT new rules limiting Medicare payments for home health care will severely strain the home health agencies that serve Medicare patients in New Jersey and could make it more difficult for some patients to receive the care that they need, officials of those agencies contend.

title: BIG BAND SOUND AT PLAYLAND REDOLENT OF ANOTHER ERA
description: FIREWORKS explode a rainbow of color into the sky and the band plays the music of the 1940's - the tunes of Glen Miller, Benny Goodman, Tommy Dorsey. Dancers spin each other across the floor while others take a break to admire the pyrotechnics. A cool breeze comes across the Long Island Sound, fluttering shirt sleeves and skirts.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: Some interesting data, which came to light recently in New York State, may be of interest to your readers.

title: LOVE OF WESTPORT IS SHOWN IN PHOTOS
description: WESTPORT, a Town in Connecticut,'' an exhibition of photographs by Larry Silver, reflects the photographer's love for the town that has been his home for 12 years.

title: Madison and Jefferson On Religious Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDAN'S NEW RULERS WATCH THEIR STEP
description: This time of year, a violent wind known as the habub often blows in from the desert, cloaking Khartoum in a nearly impenetrable fog of dust and sand. The political climate has been even more murky since a coup in April brought a military group to power.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NUCLEAR AMERICA: Military and Civilian Nuclear Power in the United States, 1940-1980. By Gerard H. Clarfield and William M. Wiecek. (Harper & Row, $19.95.)

title: DOG-TRACK DISPUTE ERUPTS OVER STEROID
description: THE issues surrounding the administration of testosterone to female dogs at the Plainfield Greyhound Park, the only greyhound track in the state, have prompted the resignation of the state veterinarian at the track, Dr. Edward A. Williams.

title: POST-PRANDIALS
description: Premium cigars and cognac are enjoying rising popularity as the baby-boom generation passes into middle age. ''Demographics have suddenly caused sales of cigars and cognac to explode,'' said Carol L. Colman, partner in Inferential Focus Inc., a market research organization.

title: HOMEMADE VILLA
description: IN RENOVATING SHINGLE-STYLE HOUSES, it has become fashionable to take this quintessentially American form and make it more American still - to carefully mend old-fashioned paned windows, cracked floorboards or leaky screened porches. And if expansions are called for, the instinct is to add on in a way that is essentially seamless - to look as though the new rooms have been around since the house was first built.

title: PROPOSED: TAX STAND-STILL ACT OF 1985
description: ADVOCATES of tax reform use a simple but beguiling logic: We have a lousy tax system; let's fix it. I am now convinced that we should follow a less obvious logic: We have a lousy tax system; let's leave it alone or it will get worse.

title: RACHEL LUCA IS MARRIED
description: Rachel Lynn Luca, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolfo Luca of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Robert Busher, a son of Culline Busher of Toms River, N.J., and James Busher of Newburgh, N.Y., and Syosset, L.I. The Rev. John Burns performed the ceremony at Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church.

title: SHOREHAM STIRRING INTEREST IN ELECTION
description: OFF-YEAR political campaigns for the 18 seats in the Suffolk County Legislature rarely raise civic passions. This year may be different.

title: PARK FOR YOUNG, YOUNG AT HEART
description: A WORLD in which the entertainment and happiness of children, not adults, are the primary concerns has opened on the oceanfront here.

title: SCREENING PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS
description: WHEN parents send their children to the public schools, they assume that teachers can write, read, compute and spell. Yet there have been instances in which parents have received notes from teachers, full of grammatical errors. They have sat in classrooms and noted words spelled incorrectly on the blackboard. Let's be honest: Some teachers certified by the state do not possess even minimal competency in basic skills.

title: CRIME
description: Writing about something he knows very well, a former California assistant district attorney named William P. Wood has written his first book, RAMPAGE (St. Martin's, $13.95), and it is about a district attorney in California.

title: Coming to the Defense Of a Battered Woman
description: It is incredible that in the year 1985 a woman can be languishing in prison for killing a man by whom she - and possibly also her child - might ultimately have been killed had she not beaten him to the punch [Westchester Journal, June 30] .

title: Bronx 'Showcase'
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTIC CITY PINS WIDER TOURIST ROLE ON INLET REVIVAL
description: Mayor James R. Usry, commenting that ''this might be the last area that we have that is Atlantic City,'' has pledged his support toward the development of Gardners Basin, an area set aside as a maritime theme park and tourist attraction 10 years ago, when Atlantic City was mourning the defeat of the first casino gambling reformation.

title: NEW TONGUES IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOMETHING has changed in my neighborhood. Sitting in my yard soaking up the sun, I heard unfamiliar sounds from a neighbor's garden. I couldn't hear well what they were saying - it's two houses away - but obviously it wasn't English.

title: STILL MORE OFFICE
description: The conversion of a former twist drill factory on Route 110 in Melville just south of the Long Island Expressway in Suffolk County underscores the evolution of this major north-south throughfare from a manufacturing strip to an office center.

title: CARO-KANN OFFERS CREATIVE DEFENSE
description: It has been said that when you win with the Caro-Kann Defense it's because you have used dull solidity to drive the opponent to distraction. Yet this defense is not altogether lacking in possibilities for creative play, although you may have to put in a lot of work to find them.

title: SAVINGS FOR THOSE WHO CAN GO AT THE DROP OF A HAT
description: One often hears questions about those last-minute clubs that advertise substantial discounts on charter flights, cruises and vacation packages. ''Are the clubs legitimate?'' readers ask. ''Are the bargains genuine?'' ''Is there something to beware of?''

title: A BOY'S FRESH AIR SEASON IN SOUTH
description: Peter Santiago plucked a raspberry off the bush. The 9-year-old popped the fruit into his mouth, then snatched another.

title: AS DEFENDING CHAMPIONS, 49ERS FEEL THE HEAT
description: THE WEATHER this time of year 90 miles northeast of here in Rocklin can be miserable. Searing heat. Temperatures as high as 105 degrees. Blinding sunlight. ''When there's a cloud in the sky, everybody claps,'' said Joe Montana. ''But you can go a month without seeing one.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency's assistant administrator for research and development, Dr. Bernard J. Goldstein of Westfield, has resigned and will return to New Jersey from Washington on Aug.5.

title: MARATHON GOLFERS
description: They may not be household names in the world of golf, but Mike McCollum and Ray Cutright have established what they believe is a world golfing record. The two club pros from Georgia played 513 holes of golf - 28 1/2 rounds - in 24 hours.

title: G.E. TRIO ACCUSED OF CHEATING THE PENTAGON
description: The Government's case against General Electric Company for overcharging on defense contracts became personal last week with the indictment of three former managers. The three men - Thomas E. Shaw of Lexington, Mass., Richard S. Davis of Springfield, Pa., and Forrest J. Yocum of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium. (Television - Channel 9, and WTBS, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: IN CONCERT
description: It wasn't only rock-and-roll, but they liked it. Mick Jagger, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney and a host of other rock stars performed last weekend in the ''Live Aid'' concerts, produced in London and Philadelphia and shared by a worldwide television and radio audience estimated by the promoters at 1.9 billion.

title: TOPS IN FLUSHING
description: The influx of newcomers, particularly Asian immigrants, into Flushing, Queens, has helped spur a boom in both residential and commercial development there. Now a 20-story, 214-unit apartment project, which its developers believe is the largest condominium to go up in Flushing, is under construction at 138-35 Elder Avenue, between Colden Street and Kissena Boulevard.

title: MARTIN SLATTERY ENGAGED TO WED MISS SUMMERLIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Summerlin of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandi Claire Summerlin, to Martin Francis Slattery of New York and Leucadia, Calif., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Slattery of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '85;

IN A MAN'S WORLD, A WOMAN FINDS HER PLACE AT HOME PLATE
description: SHE'S been beaned by oranges, and has had to be escorted by armed soldiers away from riotous fans in South America.

title: BYRNE SIGNS UP FOR A REMATCH
description: Chicago has no equal for bruising, divisive city elections. It is gaining a reputation for drawn-out preliminaries as well. Although voters do not queue up again to choose among municipal candidates until 1987, former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, one of the combatants in 1983's low-road campaign, last week announced that she would seek a rematch against Mayor Harold Washington.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM OFFENBACH TO COLE PORTER
description: Offenbach's 'Contes d'Hoffmann' A Royal Opera production, featuring Placido Domingo, Luciana Serra, Agnes Baltsa and Ileana Cotrubas, with Georges Pretre conducting the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House Thorn EMI Video 135 minutes. $39.95 In this live performance, cameras do not dictate the proceedings but are simply audience members at Covent Garden.

title: OLD PLAYER, NEW MET
description: LUIS ARROYO. Paul Blair. Harry Bright.

title: MORE WOMEN TAKE THE HELM IN SAILING
description: As a light wind picked up on Narragansett Bay, Janet Hannsz climbed onto the foredeck of a 24-foot racing sloop that was being used as a training vessel and leaned onto the mast for support.

title: OLD WORDS STILL RING TRUE
description: The state of Connecticut is one of the major beneficiaries of jobs created by military spending. The article by the Rev. Kevin Bean [''State's Defense Jobs Are Not That Secure,'' June 23] warning of the dangers of depending on such an economy, was most timely.

title: OF SCREAMS AND THE HEAT
description: The capital can be a particularly unpleasant place when heat and humidity compete in a race to reach the 100 mark. So when temperatures soared into the mid-90's this week and humidity lagged only a few points behind, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was moved to discourse on the cooling glories of ice cream.

title: STEPHEN CRANE AND HIS LURID SEASHORE LEGENDS
description: The New Jerse Shore, according to one notable source, is as crowded as night as it is by day.

title: WANDERLUST
description: IS THERE LIFE AFTER BEAUJOLAIS? AND Burgundy and Bordeaux? Yes, although you'd have a tough time proving it in the United States.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM OFFENBACH TO COLE PORTER
description: The Shmenges: The Last Polka Starring John Candy and Eugene Levy; directed by John Blanchard Vestron Video 55 minutes. $59.95 Yosh and Stan Shmenge, polka players extraordinary, are retiring -maybe.

title: LAUREN KIMBERLY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Lauren Whitman Kimberly, a daughter of Mrs. Bowman Gray 3d of New York and New Canaan, Conn., and Oliver Adams Kimberly Jr. of Weston, Conn., to Lawrence Fox Calahan 2d took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony.

title: TIGHT TIMES AT THE POSTAL SERVICE
description: The United States Postal Service, as every one knows, has never let a little sleet or gloom of night interfere with its appointed rounds, but a downpour of red ink might be another matter.

title: CYNTHIA ZABIN ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Cynthia Anne Zabin to David Samuel Wean, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Wean of Westwood, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Zabin of Fairfield, Conn. Miss Zabin and her fiance both graduated from Brandeis University with the class of '79.

title: WORDGAME CHAMPS
description: Gerald Eskenazi's malapropisms from the world of sports are topped only by my all-time favorite, uttered in total seriousness by a successful citizen of my acquaintance: ''Don't worry . . . I know which side of the street my bread is buttered on.'' LESTER $:EBER Grantham, N.H.

title: BOTTOM LINE ON ACID RAIN
description: What would it cost to repair or replace paint, stone, metals and other materials damaged each year by pollutants created by the burning of fossil fuels? According to a new study reported last week on the effects in 17 states of acid rain, $5 billion.

title: MISS CAMPBELL TO WED ROGER NETZER, LAWYER
description: Frances Shields Campbell, a candidate for a master's degree in journalism at New York University, and Roger David Netzer, an associate in the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, plan to be married Sept. 6.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: July 21, 1985 Fiction

title: A. J. BELLISIO ENGAGED TO BEVERLEY RUKEYSER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Rukeyser of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverley Jane Rukeyser, to Anthony J. Bellisio, the son of Mrs. Arthur A. Bellisio of Huntington, L.I., and the late Mr. Bellisio.

title: THE HUMBLING OF TWO BANKING STARS
description: SAMUEL H. ARMACOST, president and chief executive officer of BankAmerica, and Barry F. Sullivan, chairman and chief executive of the First Chicago Corporation, have much in common. Both have been rising stars in the banking community. Each has held the top post at his bank for approximately five years. And both are likable fellows whose styles contrast sharply with those of their autocratic predecessors. Now both men may be seeing their futures dim, along with their banks' profitability.

title: THE SAUDIS LEARN TO LIVE ON $25 BILLION A YEAR
description: A struggle with overtones of class warfare comes to a head tomorrow in Geneva, where the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will again try to restore discipline on production quotas and end cheating on prices. It pits the cartel's wealthiest members, Saudi Arabia and its Persian Gulf allies, against the poorer countries in a fight for power, money and, implicitly, political stability.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

PRINCETON SCIENTISTS HAVE 

* 

* 

* IN THEIR EYES
description: STARS being formed in the Milky Way - they're so new that they are still wrapped in birth cocoons of dust and gas - will be studied four other universites at the Apahe point Observatory, a $10 million fcitliy being built a top a mountain 70 miles from Alamogordo, N.M.

title: ROBERS OF GIANTS WILL MISS SEASON
description: William Roberts, who had been expected to start at left offensive tackle for the Giants this year, will be lost for the season. The second-year player underwent surgery Friday night to repair a torn ligament in the left knee, the result of a training-camp accident.

title: WATER DRESSING
description: ACTIVE sportsmen on the water know the value of good equipment. With apparel, the emphasis is often on garments that can keep a man dry and afloat.

title: KEVIN L. THURN ENGAGED TO SUZANNE BETH SEIDEN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Seiden of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Beth Seiden, to Kevin L. Thurm, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Thurm of Merrick, L.I.

title: CLAM SELLERS BARRED FROM ROADS
description: CONSUMERS looking for cheap lobsters and clams, once plentiful on roadsides in the Town of East Hampton, may be in for an extensive search this summer. The Town Council has revised the peddling ordinance in order to gain more control over who peddles what on town roads.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: July 21, 1985 Fiction

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

POSTCARDS
description: They cost only a penny to mail, so perhaps it was no wonder that people sent a staggering number of postcards during the early part of this century. From the thousands that found their way to the Hudson River Museum through memorabilia donations during the 1920's and 30's, about 900 will be on display from Wednesday through Oct. 13 in the exhibition, ''Wish You Were Here: Picture Postcards From the Hudson River Museum Collection.''

title: MAUREEN BROWN TO WED SEPT. 28
description: The engagement of Maureen Ann Brown to James Parton 3d has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Clement R. Brown Jr. of Flossmoor, Ill. The wedding is planned for Sept. 28.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

SERVICE ACADEMY FOR DEMOCRACY NEEDED
description: READING the newspaper can be a perilous business. A character in Doris Lessing's ''The Golden Notebook,'' who begins clipping articles about ominous world situations and pinning them to the walls of her living room, has a nervous breakdown. In the course of reading the daily paper recently, reporting chilling details of famine in Africa, the passage of the missile ''peacekeeper bill'' and the ambiguity of our foreign policy in Latin America, I noticed I had begun to save articles closer to home like the one reporting 40 percent of New York City children live in poverty, or that 60 million American adults cannot read the front page of a newspaper.

title: UNUSUAL OPERAS STEAL THE SPOTLIGHT FROM THE STANDARDS
description: Music critics are prone to complain, grumpily, about the narrowness of the repertory presented by mainstream American opera houses. But that complaint can hardly be leveled against record companies, which continue to pour forth operas rarely heard within the sacred confines of, say, the Metropolitan.

title: Mourning the Deported
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
MUST TV BE AT THE MERCY OF TERRORISTS?
description: How does terrorism play on television? It depends. Consider the two-part documentary ''Terror!'' Its point of view is clear; the exclamation point tells us that. Terrorism lies outside the pale; it is something to be abhorred. Ideologists define terrorism to their own ends, while the United Nations, the documentary notes, has been unwilling to define it at all. Most reasonable people, however, need no definition; they recognize terrorism when they see it. Terrorism is a bombing, an assassination, a hijacked plane. It is a violent act in a political context, and it is, as Arthur Hill, the narrator of the documentary, says, ''a part of the world we live in.''

title: FIXING THE FED
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE An Intentional Mystery. By Thibaut de Saint Phalle. Illustrated. 315 pp. New York: Praeger Publishers. Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $14.95. IT is curious so little has been written about the Federal Reserve System of the United States, whose main responsibilities are to control credit and the flow of money and to regulate private financial institutions. Great attention has been lavished on monetary policy and Government regulation of banking, yet these subjects are inextricably linked to the Federal Reserve System. To Thibaut de Saint Phalle's credit, ''The Federal Reserve: An Intentional Mystery'' seeks to fill the historical void, as well as provide a timely guide to issues now before Congress. His book is welcome because it treats a subject critical to our economic welfare, raises vexing questions, clarifies connections among diverse institutions and practices (most important, between domestic and international finance) and is written in language accessible to nonexperts.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DAYS BEFORE THE MAST Jeans, sneakers, shorts, a bathing suit and something warm for cool nights are all that is needed on cruises of one to five days aboard the Mystic Whaler or the Mystic Clipper. The handsome, diesel-powered schooners operate in winter out of Annapolis, Md,. on Chesapeake Bay, in summer from Mystic Schooner Cruises, 7 Holmes Street, Mystic, through Aug. 31.

title: AS ECONOMY FALLS, SO DOES THE DOLLAR
description: The dollar has been falling as traders worry about the United States economy. The dollar had already hit yearlong lows when President Reagan's illness further depressed it. News of the slowing American economy did little to help the currency, although it recovered some in late-week trading. The drop in the dollar makes American goods cheaper abroad and could help the nation's record trade deficit. But Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, does not want the dollar to fall too far, because it would hurt the Federal deficit as foreign investors withdrew funds.

title: LOCAL AIRPORTS TO BE REPAIRED
description: FOR several years, the cracks in the runways at the Waterbury-Oxford Airport in Oxford have been spreading faster than the state could repair them.

title: NEXT MOVE WILL BE METS'
description: Keith Hernandez says the Mets will pick the time and place for the next skirmish in the sniping between the Mets and St. Louis Cardinals.

title: DIARY OF A GIFTED PIANIST
description: William Kapell, a brilliant and successful pianist by his early 20's, dead in a 1953 plane crash at the age of 31, has long since entered into American musical folklore. This fall, Piano Quarterly plans to publish excerpts from Kapell's diaries, allowing not only a rare insight into the workings of genius but a portrait of a sensitive and committed young man. ''Kapell's widow, Dr. Anna Lou DeHavenon, offered me the diaries, and, of course, I was delighted to print them,'' Robert Silverman, Piano Quarterly's editor said in an interview last week.

title: DISPLACING RENTER AND MOVING IN
description: AN ongoing issue in hundreds of New York City's small multifamily buildings with rent-regulated tenants concerns the right of the owner to obtain possession of an apartment in order to move in or to have others in his immediate family move in.

title: BELGIAN COALITION FALLS APART
description: The rioting that resulted in 38 deaths just before the European Cup soccer match between British and Italian teams in Brussels two months ago claimed another victim last week: Belgium's coalition Government. Amid a dispute over who should take responsibility for the mayhem, Prime Minister Wilfried Martens turned in his resignation to King Baudouin.

title: STRONGER URBAN ACCENTS IN NORTHEAST ARE CALLED SIGN OF EVOLVING LANGUAGE
description: It is hardly a secret that residents of a certain city on Chesapeake Bay call their home town ''BALL-uh-mer.'' Or that to Philadelphians, their home state is ''Penn-suh-VAY-nyuh.''

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: The problem of hunger affects all of us, but it hurts children more than any other group. For this reason it is of particular importance to the New York City Board of Education.

title: MARY LERNER TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Byron R. Lerner of Metuchen, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Amy Jane Lerner to Jeffrey Bruce Jans, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Jans of Baltimore.

title: FRANCE BREEDS A NEW CROP OF AUTEURS
description: In the past, French exports tended to be medium-budget, slow-moving, intellectual films that explored social behavior and family life. During the 1970's, Eric Rohmer became a cult figure in America thanks to his highly intelligent studies of intimate relationships between people who share an exceptionally closed universe. Largely because of Mr. Rohmer and a number of other directors who came into their own during this period, foreigners came to expect that French movies were ones in which little or nothing happened. Characters, corseted into suits one size too small, moved about in small rooms or tiny gardens and occasionally traveled short distances in miniature cars or stuffy railroad compartments, living lives that could fit on the head of a pin. As a result, the image of France as a kind of Lilliput emerged.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: ONE SUMMER AT GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE. Written and illustrated by Poupa Montaufier. Carolrhoda Books. $12.95. (Ages 3 and up) The author's delightful primitive-style paintings, and stories translated from the French by Tobi Tobias, recall an idyllic summer spent in the 1950's with her grandmother Oma in the Alsace region of France.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CONCERT: ANDRE WATTS PLAYS AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: RAYMOND LEPPARD was back again on Friday conducting the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. His collaborator for the evening, Andre Watts, seemed a curious choice. Indeed, they are such different musicians that the Mozart E Flat Concerto (K. 271) - in which Mr. Leppard conducted and Mr. Watts played the piano solos -promised to be a confrontation of styles rather than a meeting of minds and hearts. We value Mr. Watts, that is, for his irrepressible exuberance and his communicative powers, while Mr. Leppard's immediacy of feeling seems always tempered and shaped by a second set of ears listening reflectively from a slight distance.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: IN BOLIVIA, A FORMER DICTATOR TRIES FOR A DEMOCRATIC RETURN
description: Most countries in Latin America have been moving from military rule to democratic civilian governments in the past few years but Bolivia's voters seemed to buck the trend last week. The largest single bloc - about 34 percent - voted in favor of retired Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, a right-wing former dictator who promised to restore order to the disastrously managed economy. The current left-of-center Government, headed President Hernan Siles Suarzo, decided it was unable to carry on and quit a year early.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GAINING GROUND: The Renewal of America's Small Farms, by J. Tevere MacFadyen. (Ballantine, $3.50.) ''Gaining Ground'' is a recent report on the crisis in American farming and on some small farmers who have survived. The author views corporate, industrialized farms as anathema. Small farms, he argues, mean a healthier soil and better and less expensive produce. Our reviewer, Douglas Unger, wrote last year that the book ''is rich with descriptions of on-the-farm experiences, and it is informed by a knowledge of the exhaustive work that goes along with farming's rewards. . . . 'Gaining Ground' is an inspiring link between two estranged cultures'' - the farmer and the consumer. BUDDING PROSPECTS: A Pastoral, by T. Coraghes-san Boyle. (Penguin, $6.95.) The 31-year-old hero of this novel about growing up is an English teacher who decides to make some money - real money. He accepts an offer to tend 2,000 marijuana plants in the hills of Mendocino County.

title: UPTON SINCLAIR'S PRINCETON HIDEWAY
description: The ramshackle two-story cabin in the woods behind Olivia Bowers's house offers little to suggest its historical past.

title: ELECTRONIC DOCTORS FOR AILING COMPUTERS
description: COMPUTERS have been replacing people in all types of professions, so it seems only logical that they should replace computer technicians as well. It is already happening to a limited degree, through a technique called remote diagnostics.

title: FORMER OLYMPIANS TRIUMPH
description: Mark Breland got his bout over in one round, Pernell (Pete) Whitaker got his through in two, thus leaving room today on their nationally televised boxing card for their Olympic teammate Meldrick Taylor. This may have satisfied Taylor and it may have dazzled the ABC viewers, but it did little for Roberto Medina.

title: TIGERS TOP RANGERS IN 15th
description: Barbaro Garbey slapped a one-out single to center, scoring Alan Trammell with the winning run in the 15th inning tonight as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Texas Rangers, 6-5.

title: DELAWARE FINDS ASBESTOS DANGER
description: ASBESTOS, once a common insulator and fire retardant in buildings, is now known to pose a health hazard when its fibers become airborne. Many states have begun programs to eliminate exposed asbestos from schools and public buildings, and Delaware commissioned two studies of the problem last year.

title: THE WOOD SHINGLE DEBATE: WHETHER TO PAINT OR TO STAIN
description: HOMEOWNERS who have wood shingles around the outside of their houses are often confused about whether to use a paint or a stain to protect the finish.

title: Life Insurance Is Not Stocks and Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: TRYING TO RANK SEAVER'S E.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS PENNED TO OUR FUTURE SELVES
description: It's the summer of 1971, but you'd never know that from the photographs in front of me. All these competent Kodachromes of umbrellas in Montparnasse and Art Deco Metro stations: they've posed for ages by now, been snapped and developed and carted home millions of times before and since I took my own share of them on those August days 14 years ago. In fact, if 1971 weren't written on the back of the prints, I wouldn't know these photographs weren't from other summer days in Paris, in 1973, or 1976. All of those trips were very different, but the pictures are more or less the same, until they stop: you reach a point where redundancy, however visually spectacular, convinces you there's not much point in having one more Notre Dame for your album.

title: DROUGHT TASK FORCE ADJUSTS RESTRICTIONS
description: WESTCHESTER County eased some restrictions on water usage last week following the first clear indications that residents were taking steps to conserve water in the continuing drought.

title: HE TESTS THE NATION'S TEACHERS, SCHOOLS
description: The Senate voted last week to confirm Chester E. Finn Jr., a professor at Vanderbilt University, as Assistant Secretary of Education for Research and Improvement. In that post the 40-year-old educator and author will direct a $100-million-a-year enterprise that gathers data on schools and student performance and supports academic research on how children learn, how teachers teach and how schools might be made more effective. In an interview with New York Times reporter Jonathan Friendly, Mr. Finn talked about his plans.

title: BUSINESS ETHICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A. WITH BRONX PLANNING CHIEF
description: Bernd Zimmermann, a former principal planner for the Manhattan office of the Department of City Planning, has been the director of the Bronx office since February 1984. In an interview, Mr. Zimmermann discussed the possibility of zoning changes to encourage more industrial development and housing, and plans for improvements in the Yankee Stadium and Hub areas.

title: KOCH FAR AHEAD IN MONEY RACE
description: The candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City filed their first disclosure reports on the campaign last week. The documents show that Carol Bellamy, president of the City Council and one of the two chief opponents of Mayor Koch, has enough money on hand to buy half a week of radio advertising before the primary election Sept. 10. Mr. Koch has enough to buy a radio station.

title: NO QUARTER GIVEN, NO DOLLAR SAVED
description: BUDGET talks between the House and the Senate have taken so bitter a turn that even if tempers cool, major deficit reduction this year may be difficult to achieve.

title: KRISTINA M. OLSEN TO WED NEXT FALL
description: Kristina Marie Olsen and David Dwares Wasserman plan to be married in November, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Richard Young Olsen of Granada Hills, Calif., have announced.

title: CHARLES C. CARTER WED TO MISS KAHRS
description: At St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Susan Ann Kahrs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Kahrs of New Canaan, was married to Charles Christopher Greiter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Greiter of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Allwein, Roman Catholic chaplain at Gettysburg College, the alma mater of the bride and bridegroom.

title: COMEDY CAMPERS PLAYING FOR LAUGHS
description: MORGEN KILBOURN, 11 years old, balanced a peacock feather on her nose. David Jones, who is 10, juggled three tennis balls. And Noah Schulz, 7 1/2, bared his teeth, clawed the air and roared like a lion.

title: JILL EDWARDS WED TO R. F. HOFFMAN
description: Jill Sara Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Edwards of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married there yesterday to Robert Frederic Hoffman, a son of Mrs. J. Richard Hoffman and the late Mr. Hoffman of Mount Airy, Philadelphia. The Rev. Wesley Crowther, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Episopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: MISS BRUNS IS WED TO THOMAS E. S. JOHNSON
description: Elizabeth Bruns, the advertising coordinator of Bon Appetit magazine, and Thomas Edward Sargent Johnson, a marketing representative with Allnet Communications in New York, plan to be married Aug. 24.

title: ABOLISH THE BOARD, DEREGULATE UNIONS
description: DURING the last 50 years, liberals and conservatives alike have attacked the National Labor Relations Board for its biased administration of national labor policy. In liberal times, business has accused the board of acting at the behest of large unions. Today, unions attack the board for the tardy processing of labor grievances against intransigent employers. Both sides take mandatory collective bargaining - the mainstay of the current law - as a given, and criticize the board for perceived deviations from the statutory plan.

title:
ANTIQUES;

FROM COUNTRY TO FORMAL AT NATHAN HALE SHOW
description: DEALERS from Maine to Maryland and as far west as Ohio will be in Coventry Saturday to sell antiques in the fields and meadows where Nathan Hale played as a child.

title: CAROLINE D. LANE TO MARRY TIMOTHY CALLIGAN AUG. 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marcus Lane of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Diana Lane, to Timothy Michael Calligan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dennis Calligan of Madison, N.J. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24.

title: MARTHA DALTON IS WED TO MARK E. CERASANO
description: Martha Ann Dalton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Dalton of Garden City and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark E. Cerasano, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Cerasano of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Connor performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Shelter Island.

title: EXPRESSIONISTS WHO POINT UP EACH OTHER'S STRENGTHS
description: There is a surprising and imaginative summer exhibition at the Robeson Center Gallery of Rutgers University in Newark. Organized by the gallery curator Alison Weld, it brings together recent work by two well-respected, unusually independent Expressionist artists. A selection of the ''abstractscapes'' by the painter George McNeil has never been shown as a group. It is rare to see as many as 25 works from the ''Lynch Fragment Series'' by the sculptor Mel Edwards.

title: COLECO MOVES OUT OF THE CABBAGE PATCH
description: OF course it makes sense that Arnold Greenberg's office is upstairs in what used to be a gymnasium in what used to be a junior high school. And that the stairway leading to the office starts where the foul line was. He is always tossing basketballs at hoops, hoping they drop. Arnold Greenberg's world, after all, is the world of play.

title: The Vacation is Part of the Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE I.R.S. TAPS YOU FOR AN AUDIT
description: FOR some of the nation's wealthiest citizens, an audit notice from the Internal Revenue Service is a commonplace event - a momentary nuisance that is forwarded to an accountant and then forgotten. But for most taxpayers, said Ernest Honecker, a senior manager at the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, ''a notice from the I.R.S. strikes the fear of the Lord into people.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JAGGER. By Carey Schofield. (Beaufort Books, Paper, $8.95.) This biography of Mick Jagger by a British journalist is a coolheaded, slickly written account of the singer's life, from his childhood in the London suburb of Dartford to his resplendent jet-setting existence today.

title: MAVERICK TALES ADD SPICE TO SUMMER
description: Considering the wide range of fantastic adventures on the screen this summer, it's astonishing that the overall effect should be so thin. Yes, audiences can visit space again (''Explorers''), or venture to the bottom of the sea (''Cocoon''). They can travel in time (''Back to the Future'') or embark on the action-packed kiddie adventure of a lifetime (''The Goonies''). They can even reacquaint themselves with the spaceling (''E.T.,'' now in re-release) who already looks like the granddaddy of them all. Why then, in the face of so much novelty, is there so little that's really new?

title: GIVING MINORITIES REINS OF POWER
description: ''People in the majority are making decisions about minority people -- I'd like to be a part of the decision-making process,'' said Lisa Jones, one of 18 black, Hispanic and Asian-American students seleted to participate in an eight-week summer program that prepares minority college students for policy-level jobs in government and nonprofit organizations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CONFESSIONAL. By Jack Higgins. (Stein & Day, $15.95.) The ninth novel by Jack Higgins - he has written three more under his real name, Harry Patterson -is one of those thrillers that cannot be described without giving away a key plot twist.

title: A CASE OF GALLOPING BLOAT
description: THIS IS THE summer of big tires on little pickup trucks. The effect is grotesque: tiny little truck bodies riding way up in the air on huge tires. Grotesque. Like gorillas wearing beanie caps.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

VIETNAM VETERANS NATIONAL MEDAL
description: The winning designs in the special Vietnam medal competition conducted by the United States Mint will appear on a new medal honoring American military veterans who served in the Vietnam War.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN YORKTOWN
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON never slept here,'' said Doris E. Auser, who is director of the Yorktown Museum in northern Westchester County. ''We're rather famous for that.'' Actually, in a county steeped in history, Yorktown is not particularly famous for anything, unlike its Virginia namesake, although there was one fairly inglorious Revolutionary War encounter:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WOODSTOCK WORKS The world premiere of a play by Michael Cristofer, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his work, ''The Shadow Box,'' will be the final fully staged production of the season at the River Arts Repertory in Woodstock. Titled ''Breaking Up Is Hard to Do,'' the Cristofer work will be seen at 8 P.M. Aug. 28 through Sept. 2. Mr. Cristofer has also been a member of the cast of ''The Sea Gull,'' in which Joanne Woodward completes a three-week run, the theater's first fully staged production of the season, at 8 this evening. She has also served as director of a staged reading in the New Works Series by John Lewter. It will be seen at 5 P.M. today and again at 8 P.M. tomorrow.

title: URSULA F. MATHERS WEDS C. C. NEHRT
description: Ursula Fraser Mathers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harris Mathers of Locust Valley, L.I., and Sutton, Vt., was married yesterday to Chadwick Charles Nehrt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lee C. Nehrt of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Calvin C. Adams performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Mathers home in Locust Valley.

title: EMPHASIS ON STRESS
description: YOU HAVE TWO minutes and 30 seconds to read and fully comprehend this piece. (Snap to it, and better not miss anything because you will be savagely tested and cruelly graded.) ''I once had anxiety,'' says a scrawny, straggly haired, self-hugging character in a syndicated strip by the cartoonist Jules Feiffer. ''Now I have stress.''

title: CATHERINE FIELD PLANS WEDDING
description: Dr. and Mrs. William W. Field of New Haven and Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Field, to Carl G. Gercke, a son of Mrs. Guy G. Gardiner of Crowley, La., and the late George J. Gercke. The wedding is planned for Sept. 7.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF IT The Lost 'It'
description: No one is in much doubt about what happens when people lose their nerve, cool, grip, temper, touch, heads or shirts. But what does it mean when they say, as they seem to be saying more and more, they are losing the indefinite it?

title: NEW ISSUE HONORS SOCIAL SECURITY ACT
description: The United States Postal Service has announced that a 22-cent commemorative stamp will be issued Aug. 14 to mark the 50th anniversary of the Social Security Act of 1935. The first day of issue ceremony will be hosted by the Social Security Administration at its national headquarters in Baltimore, Maryland.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS REVERAL ON ABORTION
description: Restricting access to abortion is prominent among President Reagan's social policy goals. Returning to the states powers that he views as usurped by the Federal Government is one of his political aims. Last week, with the personal approval of the President, the Justice Department brought the social and political agendas together, asking the Supreme Court to overrule itself and return jurisdiction to decide abortion cases ''to the condition in which it was before'' 1973.

title: ELIZABETH HEILMAN, EDITOR, ENGAGED TO JAMES BROOKE
description: Elizabeth Ann Heilman, the associate features editor of Town and Country magazine, and James Bettner Brooke, a reporter for The New York Times, plan to be married Sept. 7.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF IT Underground Courtesy
description: When the temperature is in the 80's and the humidity hits 100 percent, Murphy's Law in New York dictates that your subway car won't be air-conditioned. That's why riders on a recent rush-hour train weren't surprised that several cars had neither air conditioning nor lights.

title: ST. GEROGE'S TESTS THE HARDY GOLFER
description: There is a long-held belief, resulting in an occasional wager, that the first time a golfer with a 10 handicap or higher plays Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey he will not break 90. The score could be raised to 110, and the same wager could apply on a windy first attempt at Royal St. George's Golf Club, the site of this week's British Open.

title: Women and Power
description: To the Editor:

title: SECOND BEST IS BEST
description: Darrell Waltrip won the pole position for the Nascar Summer 500 at Pocono International Raceway in Long Pond, Pa., today, but it took a bit of help from race officials.

title: WHAT MADE THIS MAN? MENGELE
description: HIS BONES DO NOT SATISFY. JOSEF Mengele had come to symbolize the entire Nazi killing project. The need was to capture him and put him on trial, hear his confession, put him at our mercy. For many, that anticipated event took on the significance of confronting the Holocaust and restoring a moral universe.

title: IN CASE A CHILD VANISHES
description: EACH year in this country, hundreds of thousands of children disappear. In New Jersey alone, more than 10,000 missing person reports are anually; most involve juveniles.

title: Art
description: What have the Blunt-Tailed Dog, the Rattle Cat, the Blue-Tongued Fish, the Apple Monster and the Caldergator in common? They belong to the very special animal kingdom created by Alexander Calder over the course of his lifetime, a kingdom whose quirky members range in size from tiny pieces of jewelry to vast sculptures weighing several tons. From childhood on, Calder drew animals, painted them, carved them, welded them of metal and twisted them out of wire.

title: AN OLD HOMEMAKER NEVER DIES
description: IN reviving one's summer wardrobe, the hardest part of the job is deciding which garments to give away and which to keep.

title: STORMING THE RAMPARTS
description: In an English country restaurant not far from London, I ran the enemy to ground.

title: Legislation Is Needed On Abuse of Elderly
description: Your recent article dealing with abuse of the elderly in Westchester points up the compelling need for state legislation [''Abuse of Elderly Relatives Is Cited as Growing Problem,'' June 30] . While New York state has domestic-violence laws directed mainly at spouse abuse establishing civil remedies and injunctive relief for victims of domestic violence and there are sanctions in the Penal Code regarding abuse or injury to an individual of any age, there nevertheless remains a need to specifically address the special problems arising in the cases of elder abuse.

title: Paying Less With National Tax
description: Norman L. Macht's article [''We Need a National Sales Tax,'' June 30] was a breath of fresh air. One vital point he missed is that tax evasion is very difficult under this plan, therefore the tax base is broadened, and you and I will pay less.

title: WHEN TODAY'S ARTISTS RAID THE PAST
description: It's not terribly hard, in this age of appropriation (a term that almost all by itself defines post-Modernism) for artists to find ideas. The discovery that there is life after Modernism has opened up all the other centuries to them. Not that the past hasn't always been a rich source of material, but the present decade seems once again to have made a trend of its use. Combing the past restlessly for ''quotes,'' and maybe cued by the conservatism of our times, a number of current artists have wandered as far back as the shores of ancient Greece or Italy, browsing among and borrowing from the myths, legends and picturesque ruins of these antique cultures. And the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., a small suburban enclave of the here and now, has flushed out enough of them to make a show, ''The Classic Tradition in Recent Painting and Sculpture'' (through Sept. 1).

title: INMATES OPERATING OWN TV PROJECTS
description: AN inmate-run television-production unit, believed to be the first in the state and headed by an Emmy Award-winning television producer, has been formed at the Taconic Correctional Facility, a medium-security prison in Bedford Hills.

title: THE KIDS WHO KNEW TOO MUCH
description: They go by names like Vampire, Beowulf and Private Sector. They are all under 18 years old, and they apparently have never met, at least not face-to-face. But the authorities in New Jersey said last week that they were part of an electronic conspiracy in which home computers were used to exchange stolen credit-card numbers as well as information on how to make free long-distance telephone calls and explosives and how to call coded phone numbers in the Pentagon.

title: WHO'S INVITED?
description: 'It is a mistake to let this problem go unaddressed. What's going to happen if we don't act is that a psychology will develop that says, ''Don't let anybody in.'' ' rrRepresentative Peter W. Rodino Jr., rrNew Jersey Democrat and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, explaining why he would introduce a bill to overhaul immigration policy.

title: ANOTHER TRY AT PEACE IN BEIRUT
description: Syria ventured deeper into Lebanon last week, sending an army colonel and a squad of observers to supervise the latest attempt to restore order in predominantly Moslem West Beirut. Under a new agreement among Moslem leaders worked out in Damascus, heavily armed militiamen closed their offices and put away their uniforms. Some of them soon reappeared, however, still armed but in civilian garb. And nighttime mortar and grenade duels between Moslem and Christian militias continued across the Green Line dividing the capital. Syria has said it will extend the security plan to Christian East Beirut when the west side quiets down. That could mean a long wait.

title: FINE WORK
description: IF you have ever wanted to have the boss arrested, thrown in the slammer and hit with a nice, fat fine, you had your chance last week in White Plains.

title: CAR MAKERS ARE GETTING BACK IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT
description: Forcing Detroit to design engines that did not burn vast amounts of gasoline once seemed a No. 1 priority among Federal rule-makers. So did the building of cars and trucks that would not fold like accordions in accidents. Complaints from automobile manufacturers about the cost of the Government's rules were largely shrugged off.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: Joseph Lelyveld's article ''Hunger in America'' (June 16) is a much-needed account of the very difficult conditions faced by millions of Americans. The author's description and analysis of the conditions he found does not, however, seem to support the assertion in the article's subtitle that the so-called safety net is alive and well, albeit a little bit smaller than it used to be.

title: CONNORS MOVES INTO SEMIFINAL
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-4, today to move into the semifinals of the $200,000 D.C. National Bank Classic, The 32-year-old Connors, seeded No. 1 here, has advanced into semifinal rounds eight times this year but has yet to win a tournament. On Sunday, Connors will play Yannick Noah of France, seeded third, whom he has never lost to in five matches. Noah eliminated Aaron Krickstein, seeded fifth, 6-2, 6-4, in today's other semifinal.

title: THREE SALADS THAT HAVE EASTERN AURAS
description: ORIENTAL cuisines provide ample inspiration for summer salads. Curry spices, nut-rich sesame, hauntingly pungent fresh coriander, tangy but mellow rice vinegar, salty soy sauce and a quick flash of hot peppery flavors can enhance a variety of salad ingredients including vegetables, seafood, meats and poultry.

title: VIDEOTEX
description: To the Editor In ''When Technology Outpaces Needs'' (Executive Computer, June 9), Erik Sandberg-Diment asserts that videotex's technological advancement ''far exceeds the consumer demand.''

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Skokie,'' a two-and-a-half-hour dramatization of what happened in a Chicago suburb in 1977-78 when a small group of American Nazis threatened to hold a public demonstration, will be rebroadcast by CBS on Tuesday evening at 8:30. Skokie had special significance as the planned site.

title: ALBANY ART
description: LAST May, a man who ran a shoeshine stand nearby admitted slashing some of the huge contemporary paintings on the Empire State Plaza concourse at the State Capitol complex in Albany and defacing them with graffiti about the Pope and President Reagan.

title: 'THE BLUE ANGEL' BECOMES A BALLET
description: An expression of all-consuming jealously distorts the face of the French choreographer Roland Petit as his hands tighten around the slender, pale neck of Natalia Makarova, seemingly ready to squeeze the life out of the Russian ballerina. She struggles free from his lethal grasp as the rehearsal moves toward its dramatic denouement ending in death and isolation.

title: FIX-UP LAGGING AT PENN STATION
description: THE plan was designed to end the rush-hour mayhem that more than 70,000 riders of the Long Island Rail Road experience each weekday at Pennsylvania Station. Had it succeeded, by this summer commuters would have been strolling through widened corridors on the L.I.R.R.'s concourse. They would have been shuttled to train platforms on stainless-steel escalators. They would have been relaxing in an air-conditioned waiting area, assured of seats on their trains.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ISRAEL IN AMERICA: A Too-Comfortable Exile? By Jacob Neusner. (Beacon, $14.95.) In this readable discussion of the identity crisis of the American Jew, Jacob Neusner reflects on what it means to be Jewish.

title: ...HERE'S A NEW SCRIPT, SAYS LABOR OFFICIAL
description: UNFORTUNATELY for the fans, a strike threat dominates the baseball season again because of the off-field confrontations between the representatives of the club owners and the players.

title: JOHN EATON DEFENDS AMERICAN OPERA
description: The Problem of American Opera. Critics have diagnosed it, learned societies have pondered it, and composers have offered their various solutions. Some find hope in a return to Romanticism, others in an infusion from Broadway. But for John Eaton, whose new opera ''The Tempest'' receives its premiere in Santa Fe on Saturday, there is no problem at all. ''American opera does not need to be saved,'' he said in a recent interview, ''it only needs to be done,''

title: SONNY MAE OFFERING LOW-INTEREST MORTGAGES IN FALL
description: FOR would-be home buyers who are unable to qualify for a conventional mortgage, even at today's lower rates, hope is on the horizon. In September, the State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae, will sell $200 million in tax-exempt bonds, primarily to make low-interest mortgages available to first-time home buyers.

title: THE VIEW FROM LOCH FYNE
description: It seems to me that far too many Americans who visit Scotland let themselves be fobbed off with a couple of days in Edinburgh or Glasgow and a quick dash along the bonny, bonny banks of Loch Lomond. Or, if they are dedicated golfers, they enjoy a golfing vacation, which, admittedly, takes in what are some of the finest courses in the world, but go nowhere much else.

title: NEW YORK CITY TRIES NEW METHODS TO REDUCE NUMBER OF JAIL SUICIDES
description: James Dale had just finished a game of checkers. He mumbled something about being sleepy and retired to his bedroom, Cell 15-U at the Manhattan House of Detention, where he had been jailed two days before on robbery charges.

title: TASTY PORTUGESE IN BRIDGEPORT
description: FOR a taste of Portugal, at Portuguese prices to boot, you have only to go as far as Bridgeport and the pleasant, unpretentious restaurant Minabela, whose name translates roughly into ''small but beautiful.''

title: RECOVERING DATA FROM DAMAGED DISKS
description: WHEN an early-morning fire swept through the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas in 1980, technicians in the computer control room quickly unloaded two disk packs containing accounting records and the hotel's guest list and carried the disks as they ran down smoky corridors to the exit.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MARSALIS IN RED BANK When Wynton Marsalis performed with the long-established trumpet player Maynard Ferguson at a Kool Jazz Festival concert in Avery Fisher Hall last year, John S. Wilson, The New York Times critic, referred to him as ''the latest trumpet sensation.''

title: TRAIN LOVER'S GUIDE
description: The railroads through the Highlands of Scotland remain, for many, the best way of exploring the wildest and most romantic countryside in Britain. Take the train to Wick, or Thurso - Britain's most northerly station and close to John o'Groat's - and you will not see highway or house for tens of miles during its remotest section.

title: The Real Ring
description: To the Editor:
