title: LESSONS IN BACK SCRATCHING
description: Representative James J. Howard, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the Committee on Public Works and Transportation, was sitting down for a cup of coffee the other day when a balding, blue-suited figure burst upon him.

title: 'Star Wars' Violates The ABM Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: AMONG THE GENTRY
description: IT'S the $150,000 question in Old Greenwich, Conn. How can a postmaster, who earns $25,000 a year, afford to live, as required, in his delivery area, where home prices start at about $150,000?

title: FLEMINGTON, N.J., DEBATES PRISONERS
description: LAST month there were not enough prisoners to fill the new county jail in Flemington, N.J. This month the county faces the prospect that it will be filled, but with inmates from the state prisons.

title:
DINING OUT;

THREE-STAR FARE IN PURDYS
description: WE would choose, if we had to, winter as the best season to visit The Box Tree, but even when its hearths are cold and additional tables and diners crowd the tastefully appointed rooms, the restaurant never relinquishes its rare charm. A changing menu that eschews the trite and tired renews itself constantly, allowing the chef, Rudy Granser, to toss off recently inspired and seasonal combinations.

title:
GARDENING;

TREES THAT FLOWER IN SUMMERTIME
description: WHILE there is an abundance of flowering trees that bloom in the spring, the number that bloom in the summer is quite limited. However, there are three trees thatare flowering now that are worthy of consideration when summer color is desired.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY BOOKS THAT INSTRUCT AND INSPIRE
description: OF the thousands of photographic books now on the market, which are best at passing on inspiration, visual ideas, insights into the craft, and the history of the medium?

title: TENANTS GET THE EDGE IN OFFICE MARKET
description: THE Manhattan office-leasing market has swung further in tenants' favor over the last few months, with flat or falling rents in most locations, according to many brokers, tenants and real-estate consultants.

title: COUPLE CITE GAINS ON CYSTIC FIBROSIS
description: RESEARCH begun three years ago by Doctors Bronislaw and Amalia Slomiany, professors of medicine at New York Medical College in Valhalla, has led to the identification of the biochemical defect that causes cystic fibrosis. They have developed a test, which is awaiting approval by the Federal Drug Administration, which may enable pregnant women to be screened for the genetic component that causes the fatal disease.

title: IDA HAUGHLAND ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Ida Bente Haugland to Andrew Harris Hemmendinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Hemmendinger of Livingston, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lars Haugland of Stavanger, Norway.

title: MARK BRADLEY LICKER TO MARRY LISA KAHN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Kahn of New City, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jill zahn, to Mark Bradley Licker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Licker of Howard Beach, Queens.

title: PLAYERS ARE PUZZLED BY UEBERROTH
description: While the players prepare to play what may be the last two weeks of games this season, they wonder what game, if any, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth is playing. Ueberroth has met with players and agents in recent weeks, and they have emerged puzzled over what he has told them and what his motives might be.

title: UPLIFTING NEWS FROM NEW YORK'S UNDERGROUND
description: From the people who run New York City's subways, there was something completely different last week: good news. After two years in which subway cars jumped the tracks with alarming regularity, derailments have declined sharply this year.

title: SLIVER HOTEL
description: A 36-story building on East 55th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues that failed as a residential condominium is being converted to a hotel by Barclays Hotel Group, a British concern.

title: ALL IN ALL, THEY STILL $ NEW YORK
description: AN authentic-looking cowboy hat lay atop one suitcase and an ''I Love San Francisco'' sticker was plastered across another bag belonging to Slim Ulmann as he stood in the lobby of a Manhattan hotel the other day. Slim Ulmann is a restaurateur from Basel, Switzerland, and this was the end of his fifth tour of the United States. Despite the steep rise in cost since he started coming in 1976, he said, he still considered New York City a great place to visit.

title: A U.S. WARNING TO NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua has often accused the United States of planning a military attack, an allegation that helps the Sandinistas maintain tight discipline, whether they believe it or not. The Reagan Administration sees a virtue in keeping them wondering; it turned up the heat again last week, although Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser, reiterated that there were no plans for an invasion or even for a break in diplomatic relations.

title: FINGER LAKES TRACK TO CLOSE FOR 2 DAYS
description: Finger Lakes Race Track will not conduct thoroughbred racing for at least two days beginning Sunday because of a dispute over how much money horsemen should receive from the parimutuel handle.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Coppergate Farm, Three Bridges, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 766-5646.

title: DIANE KETCHAM
description: A RARE BREED ''I GUESS I may be the last of a dying breed,'' said David Halliday, the Riverhead dog warden, when told that, starting tomorrow, he may be the only Long Island dog warden still presiding over what is called a dog pound.

title: FICTIONS AND FANIES OF THE JANEITES
description: MANSFIELD REVISITED By Joan Aiken. 188 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $13.95.

title: STRAWBERRY'S HOME RUNS LEAD METS TO 16-4 VICTORY
description: The first omen may have come when Gary Carter got out of bed in the morning and his right knee did not buckle. Then Dwight Gooden took the mound in Shea Stadium in the afternoon, and won his eighth straight game. And, for the piece de resistance, Darryl Strawberry hit a grand slam, a three-run home run, a triple and knocked in seven runs.

title: ALONG OCEAN PARKWAY, A RUSH TOWARD CONVERSION
description: ONLY a few years ago, northern Ocean Parkway, in the Kensington section of Brooklyn, was considered a risky investment. The southern end, near Coney Island, was thought to be much more desirable.

title: ORCHESTRA PLAYERS AND EAR PLUGS
description: The symphony orchestra, looked at as a species, is about as likely an organism as a centipede. A strange hundred-legged creature, the orchestra manages to go about its business working wonders of coordination and cooperation when, by the looks of it, purposeful movement in any direction would seem out of the question. How an orchestra functions is a mystery to outsiders, and probably is only dimly understood by the legs themselves. But we know that 100-plus talented individuals must and often do coalesce into a quasi-military organization requiring corporate discipline such as Frederick the Great imposed on his Prussian troops. All this in the service of the supposedly contradictory ideals of art and commerce. The symphony orchestra is a triumph of illogic.

title: THE NETWORKS ARE EDGING INTO PRODUCTION
description: Television is on the verge of a significant transformation.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the home state of Sen. Pete V. Domenici was incorrectly identified in a July 14 Week in Review article on Federal budget politics. Mr. Domenici is a Republican of New Mexico.

title: THE 'REAL' G.N.P.
description: All economic statistics can be deceptive, but few more so than the gross national product. Last Thursday, for instance, the Commerce Department said second-quarter G.N.P. rose 1.7 percent, compared with a gain of just three-tenths of a percent in the first three months of 1985.

title: Helping S.R.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS FORD PLANS TO BECOME BRIDE OF ANDRE BALAZS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerard William Ford of New York and Greenfield Hill, Conn., have announced that their daughter Mary Katherine Ford and Andre Tomas Balazs plan to be married Nov. 16. Mr. Balazs is the son of Dr. Endre A. Balazs of New York and St. Tropez, France, and Dr. Eva K. Balazs of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Philadelphia People Who Lost Houses in Fire Get $711,000
description: The 60 families who lost their homes in the May 13 fire that began when the police bombed a house occupied by the radical group Move have each received a check for about $12,000, part of the money raised for them in charity drives.

title: THREE NEW FILMS: FROM VISION TO REALITY
description: One Monday night last May, midway through the Cannes Film Festival, some the principal figures involved in ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' which opens Friday at Cinema 1, sat down with a large audience to watch the movie. The two stars had never seen the final cut. William Hurt, who plays Molina, the romantic movie-struck homosexual, spent the first 20 minutes cringing in his seat and then became so absorbed that his self-consciousness evaporated.

title: A SCOTTISH CRUISE BY RAIL
description: The wind off the Atlantic was Force 7, nearly a gale, buffeting the little train on the single track between the mountains and the lochs. The mountaintops were hidden in cloud; squalls stormed across the water; rain beat upon the windows of the train. It was cold and getting dark. Our destination was half an hour away.

title: MAX ROACH REVISITED: A TRAILBLAZER OF MODERN JAZZ
description: Max Roach, the drummer, was a founding father of modern jazz. For the past three decades, he has led bands that introduced brilliant young musicians to the jazz public - Clifford Brown, Sonny Rollins, Eric Dolphy and Booker Little are only a few. But during the 60's, Mr. Roach's use of his albums to comment on social issues -especially on his ''We Insist: Freedom Now Sweet'' - made some record labels wary of him. And as rock gathered a more and more massive audience throughout the 60's and 70's, it was difficult for any uncompromising jazz artist to attract the interest of America's major record labels. Like many artists of his generation, Mr. Roach found a readier market for his recordings in Europe and Japan than in his own country.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: The facts about children living in poverty were documented recently in ''Children in Poverty,'' a study by the Congressional Research Service and the Congressional Budget Office for the Committee on Ways and Means.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A PARISH OF RICH WOMEN. By James Buchan. (Atheneum, $12.95.) Adam Murray, a young reporter, returns to London from Beirut, Lebanon, and is unmoored, unhappy. He falls in with the scions of the horsey set who instead snort horse - more commonly called heroin - and are all very unhappy. Failed romance shoves him back to Beirut, where he caroms between scenes of death in an unhappiness of global scale. Remarkably, this unpromising plot takes on life in the hands of James Buchan, a former Middle East correspondent for The Financial Times. It is a pale kind of life, though, peopled by Chelsea trendies and their parents, none sketched with more than two or three lines; Arab fighters, drivers and hoteliers who sound too much alike in their flowery speech; old British spook types who leave so much to the imagination that we aren't sure, two pages thence, whether we really met them at all. The grace of this minimalist first novel is in its unbroken swiftness: we are unbound from the weight of realistically depicted places and the suety waste of real people's talk; we move at the speed of Adam Murray's sharp mind. The problem is that we are unbound, too, from almost everyone who scurries through these chapters. We have only hints of past pain in the life of his lover, his ''dream tart,'' Mary Mark; we are not even quite clear what she looks like; he wants her but we are not sure why; she comes to grief, but do we care? Mr. Buchan's prose is spare and stylish, his dialogue leaves most things unsaid, his descriptions of London town houses, British manors or Beirut bunkers make us hold with our teeth to one or two details - we try to chew and bite mostly air.

title: TREASURES FROM THE BOOKS OF ISLAM
description: The power of the word in the art of the Arab people is the overriding theme of ''Treasures of Islam,'' an exhibition of 367 art works and hundreds of coins at the Rath Museum here through Oct. 27. The show, described by its organizers as the most impressive such documentation of the arts of the Islamic book in more than half a century, presents selections that are primarily from private collections assembled over the past two decades. A majority of the works have not been exhibited recently; some have never been shown.

title: AN ERA'S INNOCENCE IN ''BABES IN ARMS''
description: GIVEN Rodgers and Hart's everlasting songs, spiffy dancing devised by Randall Skinner and the cast's high spirits, one senses the makings of a musical in Ginger Rogers's new staging of ''Babes in Arms,'' circa 1937, at the Music Hall in Tarrytown.

title: WITHER THE WHIPS?
description: Legislative branch bureaucracy is not much different from executive branch bureaucracy.

title: EDINBURGH
description: There is always a crucial choice to be made by summer visitors to Scotland's ancient capital: to experience Edinburgh the Festive or Edinburgh for Real. Those who choose to immerse themselves in the Edinburgh International Festival and its attendant subfestivals and counterfestivals should be there from Aug. 9 to 31.

title: THE WOOD SHINGLE DEBATE: WHETHER TO PAINT OR STAIN
description: HOMEOWNERS who have wood shingles around the outside of their houses are often confused about whether to use a paint or a stain to protect the finish.

title: 'Selling of L.I.': Other Views
description: In her article ''The Selling of Long Island: Price of Progress Is Too High'' [Opinion Page, June 23] , Linda B. Martin expresses those very same sentiments that I have been trying to convey - admittedly, not as beautifully and as descriptively as she has - any time that a specific development posed a threat not just to my immediate community but rather to our town or country.

title: THE WIFE'S AWAY, BUT I WON'T PLAY
description: FOR generations, red-blooded American men at this time of year have looked forward with scarcely concealed glee to the approaching separation of spouses, as the wives and children went off to vacation while the men stayed at home in the sweatshop or behind the counter or at the office desk.

title: MIXING PROFITS AND MEDICINE
description: Readers of the New England Journal of Medicine may have been perplexed by the latest issue, published last week. One article reported that the takeover of teaching hospitals by private, profit-seeking hospital chains would imperil teaching, research and care of indigent patients; a second said the takeovers reflected the chains' commitment to teaching, research and indigent care; and a third cautioned that any conclusions on the effects of the takeovers were premature.

title: Cable TV
description: Good movie titles, like a splash of color, can be an inducement to home viewing. Take ''Midnight Express'' (1978), a darkly intriguing label for a jolting but gripping drama of a young American's (Brad Davis) ordeal in an Istanbul prison, after a sentence for drug-smuggling. It's showing over Cinemax on Monday at 10 A.M. and Wednesday at 1:20 A.M.

title: Beware Optimism About Gorbachev
description: After almost a decade of embarrassingly weak leaders, the Soviet Union finally has a strong helmsman prepared to set a fairly specific course. Unfortunately, however, there is nothing in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's record or his recent statements and actions to suggest that rapprochement with the United States is among his top priorities.

title: PILOTS CHART A TOUGH NEW COURSE
description: HENRY A. DUFFY is the pilots' pilot. As head of the Air Line Pilots' Association, the former Delta captain has for two years guided his 34,000-member union through the rough skies of airline deregulation. It has not been easy. Rampant competition and union-busting tactics have shattered the once-staid industry and threatened jobs. But Mr. Duffy has been the driving force - indeed the mastermind - behind a union that has shown the muscle and the wherewithal to assume a pivotal role in shaping the nation's airline industry.

title: AL UNSER JR. EMERGES, MUCH TO HIS FATHER'S DELIGHT
description: AL UNSER Jr. says that he cannot remember a time when he did not plan to make a career as a racing driver. And indeed, if a person was born to race Indy cars, it was Little Al Unser.

title: HUDSON TOWNS ARE FEELING GROWING PAINS
description: After a turbulent decade of development that changed the image of this waterfront city from husky to haughty, a new administration last week put the city's renaissance on hold.

title: ELIZABETH ANN LANGAN MARRIES ROGER M. DELL
description: The First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Ann Langan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Langan of Greenwich, and Roger Martin Dell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Glen Arthur Dell of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Douglas James Rumford performed the ceremony.

title: WENDY WEIL, R. S. RUSH 3D ARE ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Richard Weil 3d of Denver of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Hollings Weil, to Richard Stockton Rush 3d, the son of Ellen Davies Rush of San Francisco and Mr. Rush Jr. of Westminster, Vt.

title: ANOTHER TOUCHDOWN NEAR GIANTS STADIUM
description: DECADES of dreaming and doubting preceded the construction of the Meadowlands Sports Complex. But when Giants Stadium finally opened for play in 1975, the sports complex instantly became a symbol for the utilization of vast stretches of meadowlands that had until then been ridiculed and avoided.

title: THE CITY'S HEALTH CARE BUSINESS IS FLIRTING WITH RECESSION
description: After 20 years of learning to deal with explosive growth in the health care industry, New York City's private and public hospitals are experiencing a sharp decline in the length of hospital stays, and the decline promises to become even steeper next year. State health officials say that 25 percent of the city's 36,469 hospital beds are unnecessary, and they expect the surplus to grow.

title: GADDY BEGINS NEW ROLE IN NEW ROCHELLE SCHOOLS
description: PERHAPS it is only natural that Dr. James R. Gaddy would feel uneasy if he were not at New Rochelle High School come September. He has, after all, spent the last 16 Septembers of his life there as the school's principal.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM OFFENBACH TO COLE PORTER
description: High Society Starring Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly, Frank Sinatra, Celeste Holm, Louis Armstrong; directed by Charles Walters, 1956 MGM/UA Home Entertainment 112 minutes. $59.95 Considering the stellar talents involved in transforming Philip Barry's ''Philadelphia Story'' into a movie musical, ''High Society'' isn't as deliriously romantic a romp as the 1940 film starring Cary Grant, Katharine Hepburn and James Stewart.

title: U.N. CONFERENCE ON WOMEN OPENS IN CONTROVERSY
description: A conference in Nairobi, Kenya, marking the end of the United Nations Decade for Women opened last week with a dispute about rules and proceeded with disputes about substance.

title:
MUSIC;

2 ARTISTS IN WATERLOO DEBUT
description: ON SATURDAY night, the conductor Sixten Ehrling and the violin soloist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg will be making their first appearances with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra, as well as their first appearance together.

title: ANGER OF ISRAEL'S NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: The airlift last fall of thousands of Ethiopian Jews to Israel from refugee camps in the Sudan was viewed as a fulfillment of Israel's obligation to Jews throughout the world. The Ethiopians discovered, however, that acceptance did not follow their arrival.

title: AN ISLE OF LIGHT AND LOCHS
description: The Isle of Skye, a lobster-shaped island just off the northwest coast of Scotland, is distilled poetry. To the north and south are the rolling moors breached here and there by craggy hills and, at the waist, the frozen dance of the Cuillins, 24 somber volcanic shapes that rise out of the surrounding lochs. The essence of Skye's poetry is its light, whose clarity and intensity create the sharp contrast between white houses, green moors and blue sea, between the red and black Cuillins, between the challenge of the morning light and the serenity of dusk. The light does something else: you are not only looking at a view; you are in the view.

title: ELECTRONICS WARS
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

LOVE OF LANGUAGE
description: ''QUE piensa Vd. que nostoros hacemos?'' ''Qu'est-ce que vous faites?'' ''Sie graben ein loch in den burgersteig. Ich gehe spazieren.''

title: PLAYERS' REPORT CRITICIZED
description: Lee MacPhail, the chief negotiator for baseball's owners, contended yesterday that a players' union report challenging the owners' contention that they are losing money did not contradict the owners' view that baseball's 28 teams have serious financial problems. MacPhail said in a release, however, that the report ''simply grossly exaggerates the outside benefits of baseball ownership and ignores the operating losses of the teams.''

title: MAKING THE MOST OF IT A Zoning Bind
description: New York's Planning Commission will vote tomorrow on a zoning change that would further limit building size in most side blocks between 59th and 96th Streets on Manhattan's East Side. The sound objective is to discourage demolition of low-rise homes for apartment houses inconsistent with the character of the area.

title: THREE NEW FILMS: FROM VISION TO REALITY
description: Leafing through the pages of a yearbook from University Hills (Missouri) High School, Bob Gale came across a picture of his father, with four seemingly innocuous words inscribed under his name: Senior Class Vice President.

title: OF HECTOR, ORPHEUS AND MAX JACOB
description: THE NEAR WORLD By Carl Dennis. 75 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95. EARLY LIGHT By W. S. Di Piero. 58 pp. Salt Lake City: University of Utah Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Gerard Phelan, the Boston College receiver who caught the touchdown pass that made his roommate, Doug Flutie, a national hero, has failed to come to terms with the New England Patriots and is staying away from training camp while his agent continues negotiations. . . . Jim Byrne, the United States Football League's director of communications, has resigned to pursue other interests. . . . As expected, Steve Young, the Los Angeles Express quarterback, has begun contract negotiations with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: NEW HAVEN'S STATION RETURNS IN STYLE
description: FOR the last 15 years, rail passengers' first glimpse of New Haven was a boarded-up, red-brick train station. There was no hint that inside was a lavish terminal, harkening back to an era before airports, when railroad companies spared no expense in dressing up stations. While government officials developed architectural plans and searched for money for its rehabilitation, the station, built in 1920, collected dust.

title: The Vacation Is Part of the Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ART OUT EAST Art takes on special significance this week on the East End with the opening of three shows honoring three perennial favorites and one good cause. Today, Guild Hall in East Hampton pays tribute to Jimmy Ernst, the abstract painter who died last year. Culled from museums and private collections, ''Jimmy Ernst: A Survey, 1942-1983'' explores Ernst's colorful, varied career. The exhibition runs through Sept. 15 and can be seen from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays and 1 to 5 P.M. weekends at the cultural center on Main Street.

title: AWARDS TO VICTIMS OF CRIMES ON RISE
description: CRIME does pay. It has for thousands of victims and dependents of those killed or disabled during violent crimes in New Jersey.

title: TINA NICOLLE HUWILER WEDS DAVID MCCARY
description: Tina Nicolle Huwiler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Huwiler of New Canaan, Conn., and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Walter McCary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. McCary 3d of Excelsior, Minn. The Rev. Peter Francis performed the ceremony at St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid.

title: Jazz
description: Jimmy Witherspoon is a big, burly blues singer with a big, burly voice that matches his stature. But unlike some blues singers of his generation - Mr. Witherspoon has just entered his 60's - he does not depend only on power and energy to develop his songs.

title: ON THE GO WITH DAVID GEFFEN
description: IF ONLY THERE WERE A fireplace on the plane, this would feel like a cozy evening at home in Hollywood. On the floor sits the legendary comic and screenwriter Elaine May, playing Trivial Pursuit with her daughter Jeannie Berlin and a friend. Bernard Jacobs, who runs Broadway's Shubert Organization, and his wife, Betty, relax on a plush sofa discussing the projected earnings of ''Cats'' over the next 10 years, while an apple-cheeked waiter serves drinks and deli sandwiches. Perched on the side of an armchair is David Geffen, the host of the occasion, which is not an intimate party in Beverly Hills but a day trip to Seattle on a private jet belonging to Warner Communications.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map on June 16 with an article about the Adirondacks mislabeled a waterway south of Lake Champlain.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The United States Government is sitting and watching as this country's manufacturing capacity is being dismantled brick by brick.'' Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who wants to impose a 25 percent surcharge on imports from the Far East.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

EAST VILLAGE TALENTS INVADE THE EAST END
description: THE East Village gallery scene, a phenomenon that has its raucous and trendy side but nevertheless has proved to be a welcome shot in the arm for the New York art world, has sent two deputations to establish even more easterly outposts this summer.

title: SANDY BOWL TRIUMPHS ON RALLY IN THE STRETCH
description: Sandy Bowl, the favorite, overtook Fancy Crown in the stretch to win the $100,000 American Trotting Championship tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: WHITE HOUSE PREPARES FOR A POST-SURGICAL PRESIDENCY
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN returned to the White House yesterday, presenting a striking picture of the robustness his aides have been talking about all week, as he stood on the balcony of the residence smiling and waving to 2,000 supporters. But the abdominal surgery last weekend to remove a cancerous polyp has raised questions not only about the condition of Mr. Reagan but also about his Presidency - speculation that the White House itself prompted early on.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;

ANOTHER STRIKE? THE SAME OLD STORY, SAYS A FAN...
description: THE DAYS are dwindling to a precious few. The owners and players are getting ready to produce and present the fans with still another baseball strike. They are about to deprive us of the poise and pitching prowess of Dwight Gooden and the sight of Rickey Henderson uncoiling from that crouch, hitting a single and stealing a base. Does anybody out there care about what the fans think (or if we think at all)?

title: DODGERS STOP CARDS AGAIN
description: Fernando Valenzuela pitched a three-hitter and drove in a run and Bill Russell collected three hits and a run batted in tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-0.

title: THE TASTE OF TUSCANY AT A HILLTOP MONASTERY
description: One of the most remarkable dining experiences I've ever had occurred some months ago in the northern Italian hamlet of Cetona, ensconced in the Tuscan hills about midway between Rome and Florence.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;

ALL SORTS OF TILES AT VERSA TILE
description: VersaTile opened four months ago in Katonah to display samples of custom-designed, hand-painted and handcrafted tiles at competitive prices, from individual wall pieces or borders to a design for an entire room, floor and ceiling included. The showroom is closed Monday, when the owners, Dede Lifgren and Diane Fagergren, do their tile making to order at a workshop and kiln in Chappaqua.

title: REDEFINING THE CLUB MED FORMULA
description: IT'S late. A huge moon gleams across the bay, etching craggy mountain tops in silver. The Mediterranean slaps softly against miles of empty sand.

title: Peter Rodino Rides to the Rescue
description: A thunderbolt has just plunged down out of the cloud that darkens immigration reform: Representative Peter Rodino says he'll champion it in the House. So far, the reform bill proposed by Alan Simpson in the Senate has not even found a sponsor in the House. For the Simpson-Nobody bill suddenly to become the Simpson-Rodino bill may well be the crowning act of the New Jersey Democrat's 36-year House career. It's hard to imagine a more dramatic development in the long struggle to persuade America to take control of its borders.

title: FATHERING A CHESS PRODIGY
description: IN THE SPRING OF 1984, AT THE NATIONAL ELE-mentary Chess Championship in Syracuse, N.Y., a distraught father began to whisper moves to his son. Across the gymnasium floor, scores of other parents crowded close to the chessboards and nervously discussed the games within earshot of the players. Some of the 6-, 7- and 8-year-old children asked the parents to be quiet and to give them room to play. Two frustrated fathers began shoving each other, and one took a swing. Eventually, the irate tournament director ordered all parents out of the playing room. More than 100 fathers and mothers paced in the hall. The absence of desperate parents was a relief to the kids, no doubt, but being locked out heightened the already feverish anxiety of these poor people.

title: SLANEY TOPS BUDD IN THEIR REMATCH
description: Mary Decker Slaney resoundingly defeated Zola Budd tonight in a 3,000-meter rematch that brought together the two principals in the most controversial episode of the 1984 Summer Olympics at Los Angeles.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: When the Sublime Is All Wet When Nathaniel Hawthorne visited Niagara Falls in the 1830's, he found that the advance publicity had blinded him, as it often does, to the phenomenon itself. In ''Niagara Falls: Icon of the American Sublime'' (Cambridge), Elizabeth McKinsey tells us that after a few days Hawthorne rose above his disappointment and recovered his ''sense of the sublime.''

title: A CHANGE OF MIND
description: Almost forty years ago, in the first of his many successful books, Victor Mollo of England drew attention to a minor ethical breach which he called the ''fumble-and-flick.'' ''The essence of the maneuver,'' he wrote, ''is an indefinable fumble between two cards, followed by a swift, self-conscious flick. This artistic performance is intended to create the impression that the defender nearly played the wrong card, recovered just in time, and hopes that nothing has been spotted.''

title: WHY I LOVE CABLE TELEVISION
description: THERE have been times lately when I wonder if I will ever complete another book.

title: IN THE FEZ MARKET, MASTERS OF METAL
description: In Fez, the most perfectly preserved of Morocco's imperial cities, each neighborhood strikes the senses in a particular way. The Attarine (spice market) tickles the nose with the dainty scent of musk, henna and oil soap, while the tanneries assault the sinuses with acidic smells. The dyers' market dazzles the eyes with flashes of purple and yellow from fresh-tinted skeins of silk. Before a new city government put up lights in the deeper recesses of the old city, pedestrians navigated the alleyways of some residential neighborhoods primarily through their sense of touch.

title: FOOD D>THREE SALADS THAT HAVE EASTERN AURAS
description: ORIENTAL cuisines provide ample inspiration for summer salads. Curry spices, nut-rich sesame, hauntingly pungent fresh coriander, tangy but mellow rice vinegar, salty soy sauce and a quick flash of hot peppery flavors can enhance a variety of salad ingredients including vegetables, seafood, meats and poultry.

title: ECONOMY'S PULSE FEELS A BIT FAINTER
description: With its report that economic growth this spring was disappointing, its warning from Federal Reserve chief Paul A. Volcker not to count on the central bank to push interest rates much lower, and its continuing impasse on House and Senate negotiations to shrink the Federal budget deficit, last week did little to ease the creeping sense of uncertainty about the economic outlook.

title: WHERE TEX-MEX MEETS MESQUITE
description: THE popularity of Tex-Mex food and the rage for mesquite grilling coincide at Little Rock Rodeo in East Hampton. The Little Rock part of the name refers to the city in Arkansas, the hometown of the owner, where, for all we know, Tex-Mex and mesquite have also become popular but are hardly indigenous.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: NEW YORK HAMBURGERS A fortuitous combination of circumstances (a shortage of pork at a time when a pair of vendors needed meat to sell at the Erie County Fair) led to the invention of the hamburger 100 years ago this summer in the town of Hamburg, N.Y., or so local lore has it.

title: IT'S THE 16th-CENTURY HIT PARADE
description: The nod to the Beatles is, perhaps, not wholly out of place. For ''The King's Singers' Madrigal History Tour,'' a six-part overview of the madrigal that will have its American television premiere Thursday evening at 8 on Arts and Entertainment, looks at this form of secular choral music as, in effect, the Hit Parade of the 16th century. And all the more so because the series hosts' and principal performers are the King's Singers, the acclaimed ensemble of six Englishmen whose many concerts and recordings of close-harmony singing usually mix madrigals, motets and French chansons with tunes from the popular repertory, by such artists as Noel Coward, the Ink Spots, and John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

title: GUIDRY'S STREAK AT 12
description: The results were in by early afternoon. The Yankees turned on their television sets today, watched in earnest as Toronto lost to Oakland, and realized they had an opportunity to gain another game in the division race.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 10 FOOD OUTLETS FOR CODE VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 10 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My wife and I plan to fly to Bangor, Me., rent a car and drive to the Gaspe Peninsula in Quebec. Can you suggest points of interest and scenic drives to include in our itinerary? - E. W. W., Jackson, Miss. Answer: One option for the driver heading north from Bangor to the Gaspe Peninsula is to visit Baxter State Park, which is dominated by Mount Katahdin (5,267 feet), the highest point in Maine. The thickly forested park, a sanctuary for moose and deer, lies in the heart of the Maine wilderness. Travelers who prefer less rugged terrain could drive east from Bangor to Campobello Island, which is part of New Brunswick, Canada, and is reached from Lubec, Me., by the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial Bridge.

title: REMEMBERING HISTORIC MILE
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG MEDIA WORLD
description: Nathan Diehl celebrated his 12th birthday last week live and in color. Every moment, from Nathan's arrival at the television studio with his guests in a stretch limousine to the cutting of the cake, was recorded on Yorktown Cable 29.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM OFFENBACH TO COLE PORTER
description: Really Rosie Pictures, story and lyrics by Maurice Sendak; music composed and performed by Carole King CC Studios Inc. 30 minutes. $29.95 When ''Really Rosie'' was animated for commercial television a decade ago, it seemed, almost immediately, to attain the status of a children's classic.

title: A DEEP AND LASTING MAYONNAISE
description: THE TRICK OF THE GA BOLGA By Patrick McGinley. 288 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95. IT'S been 50 years now since Beckett, in praising O'Casey's homages to ''the principle of disintegration,'' gave us a phrase for the Irish comic vision. In its world disintegration seems purposive though impersonal; the universe, whatever parish priests choose to say, was created to insure the utter neatness of any local unraveling. All names are double, all meanings are double, all experience is disquietingly double.

title: LOST IN ITALY
description: To the Editor: Louis Inturrisi's delightful piece on getting directions from Italians brought back memories of a similar situation encountered on a whirlwind museum-hopping trip through the hill towns.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption accompanying the story ''Portrait of a Small Black Church'' (June 30) misidentified a road in Bedford, Pa. It is Central Way, a small street that intersects several of the main thoroughfares in Bedford, including Juliana Street.

title: JANICE M. KUZAVA BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J., yesterday Janice Marie Kuzava, the daughter of Viola Robbins of Abingdon, Md., and Walter Kuzava of Lanoka Harbor, N.J., was married to Robert B. Blancato, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Blancato of Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Norton performed the ceremony.

title: LIVING OFF THE RICHES OF THE LAND
description: Outside Scotland's cities and towns are dozens of fine country restaurants and hotels. The eating places listed below are all in rural settings and each has an exceptional reputation for its food. The hotels range in quality from international luxury class to beloved well-worn fishermen's retreats. Restaurants Peat Inn, Fife (St. Andrews, 6 miles), is a former inn and post office at a country crossroads with a high reputation for nouvelle cuisine, seeking out seafood supplies from the fishing harbor of Pittenweem (turbot, sole, angler fish) and going to Anstruther for lobster. Main courses cost $12 or $13 (lobster is usually $16) and might be spring lamb with a rich sauce flavored with armagnac. Wild wood pigeon may be available (gamey, and darker than farm pigeons) on a bed of homemade noodles with brandy and juniper-berry sauce. A specialty is fish-market, a selection of fresh seafoods in a leek-flavored sauce. Starters (perhaps lobster souffle in seafood sauce) are priced up to $5 and homemade desserts $4 or $5. A nice Provencale wine, red or white, is $8.75. A four-course set lunch is available; price $12.50. The restaurant is closed Sunday and Monday, and one week's holiday is taken in January, April and October. There is space for 44 diners, with a no-smoking area. Reservations are strongly advised for dinner. Telephone Peat Inn 206.

title: NEVER MIND THOSE LAWNS, I LIKE PAVEMENT
description: THIS is the season of cute articles on crab grass, backyards and suburban planting. Someone always has a spouse who goes overboard pinching back the petunias, or gets so importunate about his impatiens that he delivers them a lecture that is overheard by the neighbors, or so humorously disgusted with the weeds that he threatens to blacktop the lawn.

title: CAPITOL COEISTENCE GETS ANOTHER TEST
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL and the Republican-controlled General Assembly will face a new test of their ability to get along with each other when the legislators return tomorrow to the State Capitol for what amounts to two special sessions.

title: VIDEOTEX
description: To the Editor:

title: DISLOCATED SHAKESPEARE, DELIGHTFUL GORKY
description: Seeing this season's repertory at Stratford-on-Avon, one is faced by the inescapable conclusion that someone at the Royal Shakespeare Company has locked the costume shop and thrown away the key. Costuming is of the catch-as-catch-can variety. This leads to modern dress, or, more accurately, quasi-modern dress versions of ''Troilus and Cressida,'' ''As You Like It'' and ''The Merry Wives of Windsor.'' The approach is perhaps best exemplified by the appearance of Falstaff in billowing knickerbockers and argyle socks as if dressed for a weekend of golf.

title: WAREHAM, MASS., SETS A NEW GOAL
description: SINCE 1969 highway engineers in Massachusetts have been planning a highway for vacationers who go to Cape Cod through the middle of the state or Rhode Island. The new road, a four-mile southwestern extension of State Route 25, will afford direct access from Interstate 495 to the Bourne Bridge, in Buzzards Bay. It is expected to open in two years.

title: WHY COEXISTENCE CRUMBLED
description: THE JEWS OF ISLAM By Bernard Lewis. Illustrated. 245 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $17.50.

title: No Headline
description: MORAL TALES By Jules Laforgue. Translated with an introduction by William Jay Smith. Illustrated. 160 pp. New York: New Directions. $17.95.

title: LEGISLATORS OPPOSE DUMP-SITE DELAY
description: THE recent dicision by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to permit the dumping of sewage sludge off the North Jersey coast for an additional year has some New Jersey legislators pressing even harder to close the dump site.

title: WHERE PLAYS ARE WRAPPED IN THE STUFF OF MAGIC
description: In a loft across the street from the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater on Lafayette Street, transformations were underway. The cast for ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' needed 19th-century clothes. The show, a musical suggested by an unfinished Dickens novel about a man's disappearance and possible murder, is scheduled to open Aug. 21 in Central Park, with George Rose, Betty Buckley and Cleo Laine. But previews are to start Aug. 2, and just four weeks (and $13,000) had been allotted for costume-making.

title: HELPING DRIVES OVER 55
description: FOR two days this month, Arthur Gasparini, a 73-year-old Larchmont resident and retired employee of General Motors, and 40 other people over the age of 55 went back to school at the New Rochelle Public Library in order to become better drivers.

title: 'SELLING OF L.I.': OTHER VIEWS
description: I enthusiastically applaud Linda Martin's article. In fact, I've been looking for some sign, any sign, that people here are worried about the massive amounts of construction that we have been subjected to in recent months.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CRIMINAL TRESPASS. By Helen Hudson. (Putnam, $17.95.) Helen Hudson's latest novel - the first in 14 years - is a vivid portrait of Saryanna Simms, called Rannee, a young black woman who grows up during the Depression in the isolated backwater of Simms Quarter, Ala.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: Joseph Lelyveld's article struck a sympathetic chord with us until the family of 11 was cited as an example of the hardships facing many American families. It seems to us that critics of the current Administration all too quickly blame President Reagan's policies when discussing the problem of hunger -and hardship - in this country. But shouldn't people have to take responsibility for the number of children conceived? How many families in this day and age can support nine children without experiencing some degree of hardship? BRADLEY B. RIGHAM CARYL J. FRANKENBERGER Boston

title: JOAN MORRIS IS MARRIED TO CURTIS JOHN MIMMA
description: At St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Joan Margaret Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Adams Morris Jr. of Plandome Manor, L.I., was married to Curtis John Mimna, a son of Lieut. Col. Curtis T. Mimna, U.S.A., retired and Mrs. Mimna of McLean, Va.

title: 2 FRENCH BALLETS BY 15 COMPOSERS
description: In 1920, Rolf de Mare's avant-garde Swedish Ballet was heading for a Paris engagement, and Jean Cocteau was asked for a new work. He concocted a surrealist libretto and turned to a young band of composers known as Les Six for the music. Five of them, Georges Auric, Darius Milhaud, Francis Poulenc, Germaine Tailleferre and Arthur Honegger (Louis Durey bowed out), contributed 10 numbers to the ballet. It was called ''Les Maries de la Tour Eiffel'' (''The Wedding on the Eiffel Tower'') and it had its premiere on June 18, 1921. The music has now been recorded together with another 1920's multi-composer French ballet, ''L'Eventail de Jeanne'' (''Jeanne's Fan''), both for the first time in their entirety (Chandos ABRD 1119). The result is fascinating, certainly, if not always rewarding.

title: L'AMOUR, TOUJOURS
description: President Reagan will never ever again have to purchase a copy of the newest frontier novel by Louis L'Amour, one of his favorite authors.

title: Tax to Inhibit Consumption
description: The June 30 edition of Connecticut Weekly had two timely and well-done articles I would like to comment on. First was Peggy McCarthy's article on ''Inner Strength Gained Outdoors.''

title: LOST IN ITALY
description: To the Editor: I was enchanted and enlightened by Louis Inturrisi's article ''On Not Getting There From Here'' (Travel, June 16). It recalled one of my experiences driving alone with Berlitz Italian in Rome a few years ago.

title: TERMS FOR PARENTS OF LITTLE LEAGUERS
description: IT seems to me that along with the T-shirt and team hat, Little League should issue a handbook for parents of appropriate encouraging lines to yell during a game. Forthwith is a glossary of terms and definitions for the novice Little League parent.

title: PENELOPE FRANKLIN IS WED IN VIRGINIA
description: The marriage of Penelope Thornton Franklin, who received an M.B.A. degree in May from Columbia University, to Paul Henry McDonnell, a marketing representative in New York with the national accounts division of the International Business Machines Corporation, took place yesterday at St. George's Episcopal Church in Fredericksburg, Va. The Rev. Charles R. Sydnor Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: WOMEN AND POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE EASTER OFFENSIVE: Vietnam, 1972. By G. H. Turley. (Presidio Press, $18.95.) On March 30, 1972, the North Vietnamese launched one of their largest offensives of the Vietnam War. G. H. Turley, then a United States Marine lieutenant colonel, was on an orientation tour of South Vietnam's northernmost province, Quang Tri, when the Easter Offensive erupted.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: If you buy a whole chicken (the cheapest kind) and cut it up yourself and stretch it with rice, noodles or potatoes, or bake it in a pie, you can make at least two meals for two adults, with leftovers for soup.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of ''The Tall Building Artistically Reconsidered'' (June 23), a picture caption misidentified the designers of the building model shown.

title: A 'VILLAGE' DORM
description: Construction is expected to begin by the end of the month on a 16-story dormitory for New York University graduate studuents at Third Avenue and East Ninth Street in the East Village.

title: TIME WARP OFF RHODE ISLAND'S COAST
description: Mopeds have long since displaced the oxcarts, and guests no longer take the waters at the 133-year-old Spring House, but in many other respects Block Island remains a time warp of 19th-century vacation pleasures. Anchored in the Atlantic off the Rhode Island coast 14 miles east of the tip of Long Island's Montauk Point, this outpost of New England is the kind of wholesome, old-fashioned resort one rarely finds anymore.

title: WORKERS STILL NEED LABOR LAW'S SHIELD
description: ON the eve of its 50th anniversary, the National Labor Relations Board appears to be at a point of institutional crisis. From all quarters - labor, management and the universities - there is great dissatisfaction. Some firebrands have even called for the abolition of the board and the body of labor law that it enforces.

title: BOUNDING BASQUE WINS THE BROOKLYN
description: Bounding Basque, who seems to alternate extraordinary and awful performances, ran to form yesterday by rebounding from a dismal sixth-place finish in the Suburban Handicap to score an impressive upset victory in the $300,500 Brooklyn Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: U.S. CYCLIST WINS
description: Greg LeMond became the first American to win a stage in the Tour de France bicycle road race, finishing an individual time trial today five seconds faster than a teammate, Bernard Hinault of France.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED...BY TRYING
description: WHAT IS a successful corporate executive doing in the confines of a mini-off Broadway theater, overseeing a musical revue?

title: SOVIET WINS IN FENCING
description: The Soviet Union won the gold medal in the men's team saber competition today in the 10-day world fencing championships. Hungary clinched the bronze medal by beating France, 9-6.

title: HOW WERE WE IN VIETNAM?
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF AN AMERICAN ARMY U.S. Ground Forces in Vietnam, 1965-1973. By Shelby L. Stanton. Illustrated. 411 pp. Novato, Calif.: Presidio Press. $22.50.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTER REPAIR
description: THE business of selling computers may not be booming these days, but the business of repairing them is.

title: MIRANDA COX AFFIANCED TO E. B. FOLEY
description: The engagement of Miranda Cox and Edward B. Foley has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Rowland Cox of New York.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO REAL FOOD?
description: LAST evening I had dinner with friends I had not seen for several years. They, the newly married-for-the-third-time couple, live in upstate New York and are ''into,'' as I was informed, new-wave cooking.

title:
GARDENING;

TREES THAT FLOWER IN SUMMERTIME
description: WHILE there is an abundance of flowering trees that bloom in the spring, the number that bloom in the summer is quite limited. However, there are three trees thatare flowering now that are worthy of consideration when summer color is desired.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM OFFENBACH TO COLE PORTER
description: The Rhythmatist With Stewart Copeland; directed by J. P. Dutilleux A&M Video 58 minutes. $29.95 Stewart Copeland, the gifted drummer for the now-disbanded Police, traveled into the bush in Kenya, Burundi, Tanzania, Zaire and the Congo to make contact with traditional African music.

title: JUDY CLARK LEADS BY 4
description: Judy Clark had three bogeys in the last 10 holes today, but her seven birdies boosted her to a four-stroke lead over Rosie Jones and Jane Geddes after the third round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Boston Five Classic.

title: ANTHONY DOLLARS
description: WHEN the Susan B. Anthony dollar was introduced in 1979, people simply would not use the coins; they looked and felt like quarters. Banks declined to hand them out, and merchants said there was no place for them in cash-register drawers.

title: BED-AND-BREAKFASTS CHALLENGED
description: HOMES that offer a bed and breakfast to tourists are increasing across Long Island, but their growing popularity has led to complaints by neighbors and questions about whether the homes are operating legally.

title: ALIX KUHN ENGAGED TO STEPHEN BOWER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bowie Kuhn of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Roberts Kuhn, to Stephen Cutler Bower, the son of Betty Blanchard Bower of Washington and South Hero, Vt., and Robert T. Bower of Washington and Quogue, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A report by the state's new Office of Attorney Ethics indicates that the number of lawyers in New Jersey charged with unethical practices declined sharply last year under a tougher disciplinary system begun by the State Supreme Court. The new procedure is financed by an annual assesment levied against the states 37,801 laywers; before that, the financing came from public funds.

title: MAKING MACINTOSH MORE VERSATILE
description: APPLE Computer's travails in the microcomputer marketplace seem to continue unabated. Over the last couple of years, the company appears to have surrendered the small-business market as well as the so-called home market by neglecting any true development of its classic Apple II series. Instead, Apple has focused on the Macintosh office in an attempt to become a supplier to large corporations.

title: ANOTHER ROUND ENDS IN A DRAW
description: American and Soviet arms negotiators completed their second round of talks in Geneva last week with comments that suggested many more rounds will be needed if any agreement is to be reached.

title: ANOREXIA BECOMES ELECTRA
description: THE HUNGRY SELF Women, Eating, and Identity. By Kim Chernin. 213 pp. New York: Times Books. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PILLAR OF THE SKY. By Cecelia Holland. (Knopf, $17.95.) This historical novel, which speculates on the creation of Stonehenge, is successful in numerous individual scenes, though its length finally drags it down with what feels like the weight of its megalithic monument.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S EMERGENCY BECOMES OFFICIAL
description: The impression of growing crisis in South Africa was heightened yesterday when President P.W. Botha declared a state of emergency in 36 cities and towns, for months the scene of riots and other forms of protest by the country's increasingly militant black majority.

title:
INVESTING;

THE RESURGENT ITALIAN STOCK MARKET
description: ITALY, long considered the ''sick man of Europe,'' is alive and kicking - and the Italian stock market is reflecting that return to health.

title: HELEN OFFNER PLANS TO WED
description: A Sept. 21 wedding is planned by Helen L. Offner and Peter G. Clifford, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elliot M. Offner of Northampton, Mass., have announced.

title: GETTING TO KNOW PHILADELPHIA
description: PATTI LaBelle has begun belting out a new promotional song for her hometown. These are some of the lyrics:

title:
ART;

SCULPTURE AT THE WHITNEY
description: SCULPTURE is on the rise again, after having been eclipsed by painting the past few years. Recent sculpture shows the influence of Neo-Expressionist painting, but of course the true parent of sculpture is sculpture.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PINDAR. By D. S. Carne-Ross. (Yale University, Cloth, $25. Paper, $7.95.) It was long the fashion among scholars to say Pindar was the greatest Greek lyric poet but he could only be understood by scholars. He is a tough case: his chosen vehicle, the victory ode presented in elaborate public ceremony, did not survive him, nor did the musical and choreographic components of his poems. But D. S. Carne-Ross, who teaches classics at Boston University, assumes that a reader who can comprehend poetry at all can understand Pindar, and he opens up the work of the great Theban more clearly than anyone has yet done in English. The challenge was great. Mr. Carne-Ross's ''Pindar'' is one of two inaugural volumes (the other is Paolo Vivante's ''Homer'') in a new series, Hermes Books, intended to make the ancient writers available to readers with little or no Greek or Latin. And if the author had not succeeded so well one would have said it could not be done with Pindar. First he draws on the best recent scholarship to describe the structure of the odes, which he compares to classical sonatas. Then, in close readings of a handful of the 45 surviving odes - readings considerably enhanced by his translations and his use of a tremendous range of reference to modern poetry - he makes the reader familiar with Pindar's dramatic instinct, his exuberance, his love of wit and surprise, his sense of humor and his incomparable technical skill. Mr. Carne-Ross doesn't make Pindar easy, but he does make him understandable, even natural.

title: PRESIDENTS, DOCTORS, REPORTERS
description: The President is back at the White House, to everyone's relief, but his aides are still sore at the press for asking all those questions about his medical record. They say it's ''distasteful'' to intrude into the private relations between a doctor and his patient.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: The incoming president of William Paterson College in Wayne hasn't any qualms about his new responsibility of presiding over 10,000 students.

title: EVEN MINOR PERSONALITIES CAN SPAWN MAJOR CULTS
description: In the Soviet Union, where the first ''cult of personality'' was created for Lenin more than 60 years ago, the practice of exaggerated veneration is in disuse, on orders from on high. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader, has discouraged ''automatically laudatory phrases,'' says Paul K. Cook, the State Department's senior expert on Soviet affairs. Mr. Gorbachev has barred the use of ''head of the Politburo'' - not a legally valid title, but frequently used in the past, Mr. Cook continued, as ''an early step on the path to the cult.''

title: A QUICK FIX FOR HYBRID SYSTEMS
description: USED to be, the proud owner of a home-computer system made up of the best equipment - a personal computer from one company, a printer from another, a modem from yet another and other peripherals from still others - had to settle for less than the best deal when it came to repairs.

title: THE BIOGRAPHER AS DETECTIVE: WHAT WALTER LIPPMANN PREFERED TO FORGET
description: MY life with Walter Lippmann began casually enough and initially came about more by accident than design.

title: YACHTS RACE FROM ITALY TO BROOKLYN
description: International yacht racing has come to Brooklyn in the form of a 4,000-mile trans-Atlantic race from Italy. The reason the race ends in Brooklyn has little to do with sailing conditions on the East River. It does, however, have a lot to do with a sponsor, who happens to manufacture one of Italy's most popular chewing gums.

title: LANGER, GRAHAM LEAD BRITISH OPEN
description: Bernhard Langer, the West German who won the Masters Tournament in April, continued to come on strongly in the 114th British Open today as he gained a tie for the lead with David Graham in the third round at Royal St. George's.

title: No Headline
description: A STEADY rain pelted the windows of the Stop and Shop supermarket in Clinton one recent day.

title: END IS NEAR FOR TWO FESTIVALS
description: JULY is almost over, and so are two of the county's big summer festivals. If you have not taken in one of the orchestral concerts at Lyndhurst or kept up with the dozens of Summerfare events, your last chance is here.

title: KEEPING THE YIDDISH BOOK ALIVE AND HEALTHY
description: To celebrate the fifth anniversary of the National Yiddish Book Center, staff members planned a party and hoped for a crowd of 1,000. Much to their surprise, 3,000 people came, some traveling by chartered bus to this western Massachusetts town for the occasion.

title: JEAN MANDEL WED TO E. K. CLEMONS
description: Jean P. Mandel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Moss of Springfield, Pa., and Margate, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric K. Clemons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clemons of West Bayshore, L.I. Rabbi Mayer Selekman performed the ceremony at La Terrasse restaurant in Philadelphia.

title: RUSSIAN POETS IN THEIR YOUTH
description: A VANISHED PRESENT The Memoirs of Alexander Pasternak. Edited and translated by Ann Pasternak Slater. Illustrated. 214 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: HOUSING DEAL IS OFF
description: A plan to use a $10 million loan offered by a group of New York banks to rehabilitate housing for poor people has been shelved because city officials objected to the terms of the deal. The money would have paid for the rehabilitation of 200 vacant apartments owned by the city.

title: ODD COUPLE: ART AND THE AUTOMOBILE
description: ''WHEN I was a little kid in France, my godfather manufactured toys,'' says Jacques Vaucher. ''He made a lot of little cars and I was sort of a 4-year-old test driver.''

title: GOING TO THE MALL FOR BETTER HEALTH
description: GEORGE WISE has been spending many recent mornings walking briskly around the Connecticut Post Mall in Milford. He does not go there to shop, or even to browse by store windows, but to exercise.

title: HUNGER IN AMERICA
description: Joseph Lelyveld points out that Federal spending for the food stamp and child nutrition programs was severely cut in 1981. Although Congress has since held the line against further cuts proposed by the Administration, the impact of the cuts in 1981 is still being felt.

title: How Yevtushenko Added to 'Babi Yar' for Second Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CONTINENTAL SHELF MAY BE TAPPED OUT
description: Not so long ago, the outer continental shelf was widely regarded as the United States's ace in the hole in the high-stakes international energy game. Oil and gas from offshore wells on submerged Federal lands were going to help insure a reliable supply of domestic energy, ease dependence on foreign producers, strengthen national security and the economy.

title: KNEE PROBLEMS
description: Billy Sims, the Detroit running back who missed most of last season after undergoing knee surgery in October, said he had considered retiring because of continuing problems with the knee that surfaced during a recent tennis game.

title: WORDGAME CHAMPS
description: Gerald Eskenazi had me chuckling as he described various exchanges he's had with athletes and managers during his tenure as a sportswriter (''Wordgame Champs,'' On Language, June 16). His accounts of creative English usage, from malapropisms to spoonerisms, were entertaining.

title:
GARDENING;

TREES THAT FLOWER IN SUMMERTIME
description: WHILE there is an abundance of flowering trees that bloom in the spring, the number that bloom in the summer is quite limited. However, there are three trees thatare flowering now that are worthy of consideration when summer color is desired.

title: COMING TO GRIPS WITH CANCER
description: I OFTEN ask my broker, Mike, who is two years older than I (but more like a twin to me), how we suddenly came to be in midlife. Only yesterday, we were 20 and 22. We felt we would be forever young, or live forever, anyway.

title: PLAYS BLOSSOM AT THE O'NEILL CENTER
description: Kathleen McGhee-Anderson, a Los Angeles film and television writer, was at a professional gathering on the West Coast a few months ago when she and her colleagues were told that she had been chosen to take part in the annual O'Neill Theater Center National Playwrights Conference.

title: 'SELLING OF L.I.': OTHER VIEWS
description: I wish to respond to Linda B. Martin's article.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF IT Miss-Labels
description: When the world saw too much of 1984's Miss America, Vanessa Williams, she abdicated and the rest of her reign - a mere two weeks - was filled by Suzette Charles of New Jersey. New Jersey's hope for a longer reign is the new Miss New Jersey, Toni Georgiana.

title:
WINE;

'BOX' IS POPULAR FOR SUMMER
description: WINE-IN-THE-BOX continues to make inroads into the United States licensed beverage market with two types of packages now available at an increasing number of county shops. One product, termed a ''bag-in-a-box,'' is a wine-filled pouch made of thin layers of aluminum foil and plastic, enclosed in a cardboard carton - the contents served through a spigot.

title: NOTES FOR THE BUNKER
description: ''Take me out to the ball game, take me out with the crowd. . . .'' IT looks serious, and if there is indeed a baseball strike in the major leagues in two weeks, then we must be prepared. We must get up a survival kit for the long, hot days and nights ahead. Not like in 1981, when no one could believe the players would actually cross the foul line and form a picket line.

title: THE WAYS OF WON TON
description: FOR ALMOST AS LONG as I can remember, I have had a special liking for won ton. In my earliest youth, I knew it simply as the major garnish in won-ton soup and presumed that was the only reason for the dumpling's existence.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Activated Ron Gardenhire, infielder, and sent him to Tidewater of the International League on a rehabilitation assignment.

title: FEELING REJECTED? JOIN UPDIKE, MAILER, OATES...
description: ON a bleak day in the winter of 1843-44 in New York City a dark, slender, fine-boned man with a look of frayed elegance presented himself at the offices of Graham's Magazine, a journal he himself had edited until recently, and submitted to his former boss, George Graham, some verses he had written. Graham found no merit in them, but when the poet protested that he and his wife were nearly destitute, the publisher charitably decided to let his staff deliver the final verdict. And so, be-fore an impromptu jury of editors, office boys and pressmen, the poet declaimed his work. Graham's employees were no more enraptured than Graham, but taking pity on their old colleague, they softened the rejection by collecting $15 to ease his poverty. Such was the earliest known flight of Edgar Allan Poe's poem ''The Raven.'' Poe's excruciating experience at Graham's is only an extreme example of a conflict that has probably gone on, in some form or other, since the invention of the printing press. Laurence Sterne's ''Tristram Shandy'' went begging (publishers, as was said at the time, ''would not have anything to say to it, nor would they offer any price for it,'') until the author could raise a partial subsidy. Charles Lamb was driven to a fury by dismissive editors (''When my sonnet was rejected, I exclaimed, 'Damn the age' ''). And Emily Dickinson's verse was scorned by Houghton Mifflin as ''queer - the rhymes were all wrong'' when it was submitted after her death.

title: A CALM EYE ON DAILY DISASTERS
description: UNDER THE BANYAN TREE And Other Stories. By R. K. Narayan. 193 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: SANDY HOOK: IT ALSO BASKS AS A BOTANICAL AND AVIAN HAVEN
description: TOWARD the northern end of this sandy peninsula, near the lighthouse that guided sailing ships to safety even before the Revolutionary War, the bobwhite, a pheasant-like bird, whistled crisply in the early morning sun.

title: SHOW LOOKS AT LIFE IN RAMAPOS
description: THE Appalachian chain runs from Quebec to Alabama, but the rural culture that goes with these great mountains is one most people tend to associate with their southern end, certainly not New York and New Jersey. ''Woodsmen, Mountaineers and Bockies,'' at the Historical Society of Rockland County (20 Zukor Road, New City) through Aug. 18, proves otherwise.

title: A LITTLE MORE THAN YESTERDAY
description: Bobby socks and the bomb, motherhood and McCarthyism, Pillsbury bake-offs and demonstrations for the Rosenbergs: each existed alongside the other in America in the 1950's. In THE FIFTIES: Photographs of America (Pantheon, Cloth, $25.

title: A COLLEGE SUCCEEDS IN ST. CROIX
description: JAQUES COUSTEAU is on reruns on television, no longer on prime time. Earthwatch is old hat, and interest in ecology, one of the chief concerns of youth in the 1970's, is waning, along with other passions of that turbulent decade.

title: MISS STEVENSON PLANS TO BE MARRIED AUG. 10
description: Bruffey Trent Stevenson and Christopher Stradley Colbert plan to be married Aug. 10. The future bride is a daughter of Lauralee Trent Stevenson of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Maj. Gen. John D. Stevenson, U.S.A.F., retired, of Augusta, Ga., who have announced her engagement to the son of the late Lee Gable Ericson of Radnor, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: BETTINA S. GLUCK WEDS PAUL STUART HENDERSON
description: At the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Bettina Singer Gluck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Gluck of Sudbury, Mass., was married to Paul Stuart Henderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Henderson of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: FIRMLY CATHOLIC AND FRMLY JAPANESE
description: STAINED GLASS ELEGIES By Shusaku Endo. Translated by Van C. Gessel. 165 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $13.95.

title: THE ROAD TO POOH CORNER
description: SECRET GARDENS A Study of the Golden Age of Children's Literature. By Humphrey Carpenter. Illustrated. 235 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: POLL FINDS LOWER PRICES HURT NEW YORK FARMS
description: New York farmers believe that low prices they receive for milk and such produce as apples, grapes and vegetables are the major cause of hard times on the farm, according to a new economic survey of agriculture in the state.

title: HOW TO BUILD A BOAT, FROM SCRATCH
description: ''THERE is nothing - absolutely nothing,'' declared Rat in ''The Wind in the Willows,'' ''half so much worth doing as simply messing about in boats.''

title: DEFENSE CREDITED IN SEAVER'S 298th
description: Tom Seaver and Bert Blyleven, right-handers with 500 major league victories between them, gave a pitching clinic Friday night that ended with the White Sox beating the Cleveland Indians, 1-0, and Seaver winning the 298th game of his career.

title: MARY KAY SMITH WED
description: Mary Kay Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Smith of Hockessin, Del., was married yesterday to Nicholas F. LaRusso, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael X. LaRusso of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Essex House hotel. The bride's father, who is retired, was a lawyer in the corporate affairs department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours in Wilmington, Del. The bridegroom's father, also retired, was an accountant for McGraw-Hill Inc. in New York.

title: A VOICE DISCOVERS A DESTINY
description: LIKE most aspiring American opera singers, Katherine Luna would someday like to sing with the Metropolitan Opera Company. Lately, this dream doesn't seem as far-fetched for the Long Island-born-and-bred soprano as it once might have been.

title: MICHIGAN 500 IS POSTPONED
description: The Michigan 500 Indy-car race was postponed for a week after a pair of accidents caused by punctured tires during practice today cast doubt over the use of new radial tires provided for the $600,000 event.

title: CARAMOOR FESTIVAL, 40, LOOKS TO FUTURE
description: IN the late 1920's when Walter Tower Rosen, lawyer, banker and patron of the arts, was building Caramoor, his elegant, 56-room Mediterranean-style mansion on a windy road several miles from Katonah, he had no idea then that his love for music would produce one of the region's prominent festivals. In the early 1940's when the Protestant missionary family of the Nelsons in Costa Rica smiled at their precocious infant, John, it is unlikely their thoughts envisioned that their son would one day lead such a festival.

title: ALLISON GILCHRIST WED IN SPOKANE
description: Allison Fae Gilchrist, a daughter of Mrs. Clay Allen Gilchrist of Spokane, Wash., and the late Mr. Gilchrist, was married yesterday to Dr. Innis O'Rourke 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Rourke Jr. of Upper Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Joseph J. Pash performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Spokane.

title: NEIGHBORS JOIN TO SAVE A FARM
description: GUY A. PETERSON did not fancy himself a farmer. Nonetheless, the 40-year-old New Milford banker is now an owner of a 147-acre farm. He plans to sell the farm, but not before he can insure that the parcel, which includes corn-covered fields and a stand of chestnut trees, will be subject to ''reasonable, sane development,'' he said.

title: THE RAMPANT DIVERSITY OF MODERN DANCE
description: It was merely another week at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C.: France's most official contemporary dance company had just made its United States debut, showing off exceptionally polished dancers. The night before, on the same Duke University campus, a leading young troupe of the so-called ''downtown'' school of choreography in New York had presented its own dancers somewhat differently - dancers as apt to jump up and down inside aluminum trash cans as to go scooting around on typewriters on wheels.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Hot Prospects
description: The Mets' third annual farm-team game is set for 4 o'clock this afternoon at Shea Stadium, and it marks the New York debut of a 19-year-old who is the most prolific base-stealer in pro ball this season. He is Marcus Lawton, who has swiped 83 bases in 88 attempts for the Mets' Class A club at Columbia, S.C., thievery so exceptional that he is now being compared to Vince Coleman.

title: OPERA: BY DONIZETTI, 'DAUGHTER OF REGIMENT'
description: THE role of Marie in Donizetti's ''Daughter of the Regiment'' has always attracted coloratura soprano voices the way sugar water attracts hummingbirds. Although Joan Sutherland took charge of it at the Metropolitan Opera a couple of seasons ago with her own inimitable mixture of large-caliber fireworks and broad, jolly humor, Marie is made to order for a lighter, more delicate voice. Lily Pons, remember, owned the part at the Metropolitan for many years and other famous Maries have included Jenny Lind, Adelina Patti and Luisa Tetrazzini. Last night's Marie in the season's first ''Daughter of the Regiment'' at the New York City Opera, Erie Mills, restored the old opera to its traditional scale as an elegantly light work most suitable for a silvery, elegantly supple voice.

title: Dr. George B. Dearing, Ex-State U. President
description: Dr. George Bruce Dearing, a former president of the State University of New York at Binghamton and vice chancellor of the State University, died July 14 at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse after a long illness. He was 67 and lived in Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: ESSAY;READING YULI'S MIND
description: Hello, Americans!

title: TRACK BARRON WINS EASILY
description: Track Barron, who had turned from a speedball into a money-burner in his last two starts, snapped back into top form yesterday with an easy 6 3/4-length victory in the $68,750 Tom Fool Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: ISRAEL AND CHINA QUIETLY FORM TRADE BONDS
description: While reports surfaced last week about secret exchanges between Israel and the Soviet Union, a far more intense and lucrative relationship has been quietly developing between Israel and China, according to Israeli officials.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;TERRORISM ON TELEVISION: NETWORKS HAVE JOURNALISTIC RESPONSIBILITIES
description: TERRORISM is unlikely to go away; neither is the argument over how it is reported.

title: Kremlin's Propaganda Chief Is Named Envoy to Hungary
description: The head of the propaganda department of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, Boris I. Stukalin, was appointed Ambassador to Hungary today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: If I was a male leader, I'd be considered part of the youth crowd, like Gary Hart.'' - Eleanor Smeal, 45 years old, elected president of the National Organization for Women. [A8:4.]

title: Wise and Timely Use of Cleanup Funds Is Environmentalist Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR RACE AT LAST GETS IN FULL SWING
description: It took a while - longer than usual because one of the candidates waited longer than usual to confirm that he really was a candidate.

title: AILING JOHN HENRY IS RETIRED
description: John Henry, thoroughbred racing's leading career money winner, was retired today by his owner, Sam Rubin.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Palau Charges 4 Men In President's Murder
description: Four men have been arrested and charged with the assassination last month of President Haruo I. Remeliik of Palau, officials on that South Pacific island said today.

title: ADVERTISING;2 British Companies Acquiring U.S. Units
description: Last week was also a week for two British companies to make final arrangements to acquire American marketing research companies -Clancy, Shulman & Associates in Westport, Conn., and Ben Lipstein's Nabscan National Scanning Services.

title: ARGENTINES BRUSHING UP ON STABILITY
description: For Mario L. Pineiro, a 64-year-old Argentine executive, the prospect of living in a world without inflation is both attractive and unsettling.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART
description: AVERY FISHER HALL is arguably too big for most of Mostly Mozart, and it is certainly not the place for an original-instrument trio of flute, violin and cello whiling its amiable way through a simple work that was never intended to hold the interest of anyone beyond the players. So although Christopher Kreuger, Daniel Stepner and Myron Lutzke played it with deft elegance, the little G-major trio (Hob. IV:9) was not an opener calculated to stir enthusiasm for the ''Afternoon with Dr. Haydn'' offered yesterday afternoon by Christopher Hogwood (fortepianist and narrator) and a group of colleagues.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;A 'HOLDING PATTERN' FOR RATES
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, does not predict interest rates. When he comments on monetary policy and the outlook for the economy, however, credit market participants are quick to make their own rate predictions.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Never Too Early
description: When Vice President Bush announced on Friday that a 36-year-old social studies teacher from New Hampshire had been selected as the first ''ordinary citizen'' to fly into space aboard the shuttle Challenger, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, a Democrat who is a veteran of the Presidential primary wars, hardly had to pause a moment.

title: FILIPINOS OPPOSE BASES AFTER U.S. PLAN TO CUT AID
description: Senior Government officials, responding to a vote in the United States House of Representatives to reduce military aid to the Philippines, have called for the abrogation and renegotiation of the agreement on American military bases here.

title: CUOMO AND HIS EX-LAW FIRM BATTLE OVER FEES THAT COULD REACH MILLIONS
description: Governor Cuomo and his former law firm, through suit and countersuit, are locked in a court dispute over the distribution of legal fees that could reach several million dollars.

title: Connie Lynn Fruehling Is Married to Mark Finell
description: Connie Lynn Fruehling, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Raymond Fruehling of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Finell, a son of Edith Finell Millman of New York and Herman Finkelstein of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Robert Kirk, the bride's great-uncle, performed the Methodist ceremony at the Gill/ St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J., of which the bride is an alumna.

title: COMMODORE TO INTRODUCE ITS AMIGA
description: In the first introduction of a major home computer system since I.B.M. brought out its ill-fated PCjr two years ago, Commodore International Ltd. is expected to show its long-awaited Amiga machine tomorrow night, hoping the machine's dazzling color graphics and stereo sound capability will stem Commodore's multimillion-dollar losses.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WAY OF THE PHYSICIAN. By Jacob Needleman. 187 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Deregulated Air Fares Have Nearly Tripled
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: SONNY ROLLINS, SOLO, AT SUMMERGARDEN
