description: A series of six concerts devoted to mainstream and traditional jazz will begin tomorrow night at the 92d Street Y, billed as ''A Festival of Hot Jazz, Ragtime, Oldtime and Blues.'' The concerts will be given Tuesdays through Thursdays this week and next at 8 P.M.

title: WITHOUT SUSPENSE, HAITIANS VOTE TODAY ON PRESIDENT-FOR-LIFE
description: Fourteen years after his father appointed him President-for-Life, Jean-Claude Duvalier is holding a referendum here on Monday that amounts to a popularity poll.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Naming an Empire
description: When he became Parks Commissioner in April 1983, Henry J. Stern didn't know what he was getting into.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE;ASTROS END SKID AT 6 GAMES
description: Glenn Davis drove in two runs with a single and a homer as the Houston Astros ended a six-game losing streak today with a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: IMPACT OF AIDS: PATTERNS OF HOMOSEXUAL LIFE CHANGING
description: Four years since the public first became aware of AIDS, the lethal viral disease has brought profound changes to the lives of homosexual men in New York.

title: DOLLAR IS ON CANADA'S SIDE AT THE FALLS
description: When Emmanuel and Maria Wong arrived here this weekend from South Plainfield, N.J., they headed straight for the Canadian side of the famous waterfalls that mark the border between the United States and Canada.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Coast Financier Freed From Prison Term Early
description: C. Arnholt Smith, a financier, was released today after serving eight months of a one-year sentence for grand theft and tax evasion.

title: Advertising;An Agency That's Run Differently
description: JOHN L. TAYLOR, 51 years old, joined Jim Jordan Inc. as president in 1980. He did not get his name on the door. In January of the next year the agency merged with Case & McGrath, which promptly became Jordan, Case & McGrath. As you can see, still no name on the door.

title: CARDS WIN ON HOMER IN 10TH
description: Steve Braun, hitting only .162 and without a home run since 1983, slugged a two-run pinch homer in the top of the 10th inning to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-2 victory today over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: NIXON SAYS HE CONSIDERED USING ATOMIC WEAPONS ON 4 OCCASIONS
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon said in an interview published yesterday that he considered using nuclear weapons four times during his Presidency, including a ''massive escalation'' to end the Vietnam War.

title: OPEC MINISTERS ARE GATHERING AGAIN ON PRICES
description: Oil ministers are assembling here for Monday's critical OPEC meeting apparently still as divided over how to respond to weakening oil prices and a declining market share as they were at their inconclusive meeting in Vienna three weeks ago.

title: Required Reading;Violence on Television
description: Excerpts from a recent weekly column written for certain papers in his home state by Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois:

title: Radical Group in United Way
description: A branch of the radical group Move was approved by the United Way of Southeastern Pennsylvania in January as one of 2,400 agencies that can be designated by donors to receive their gifts, according to the authorities here.

title: YANKEES TOP TWINS
description: The Yankees know the season could come to an abrupt halt on Aug. 6, the date the players are threatening to go on strike. So they are making it their own deadline of sorts.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Tamil Rebels Ambush Sri Lanka Army Patrol
description: Sri Lanka security officials said today that separatist guerrillas ambushed an army patrol in northern Sri Lanka and killed at least one soldier. The officials said several of the attacking guerrillas were also believed killed.

title: SILENCE SEPARATES 2 SHORES, 2 WORLDS ALONG THE MEKONG
description: The din of daily life in an old Thai river town like this one conceals at first the silence that has fallen over the Mekong.

title: MUSIC AT TANGLEWOOD, BERNSTEIN AND BRAHMS
description: There are two Tanglewood tales to tell tonight - one about human beings and one about music. The two overlapped, of course, but in the end Leonard Bernstein's introduction of a completely unknown Polish pianist he'd heard on the radio - although the pianist gave a promising, often appealing performance - paled before the conductor's absolutely magisterial account of Brahms's Symphony No. 1.

title: Still Missing in Lebanon
description: What is the difference between 39 and 7? Fickle media and an indifferent public.

title: Bridge: Team Led by Bob Blanchard Wins Big Apple Tournament
description: A team led by Bob Blanchard defeated Dorothy Truscott's team yesterday afternoon to win the Big Apple Regional Knockout Team Championship at the Sheraton Centre, at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, by 23 international match points.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Two Comsat Officers Promoted to Top Posts
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation announced that Irving Goldstein, president since 1983, would succeed Joseph V. Charyk as chairman and chief executive officer on Oct. 1.

title: METS BATTER BRAVES BY 15-10
description: Maybe the students of mass behavior can explain it, or maybe the students of Met behavior can explain it. To Dave Johnson, it is best explained by the cyclical fluctuations of the sine curve in mathematics. To Howard Johnson, it is probably that ''hitters are dependent on each other.'' To Dale Murphy of the Atlanta Braves, it is simply ''strange.''

title: BRITISH TELECOM AND A.T.& T. VENTURE EXPECTED
description: In an example of what industry experts are calling an important trend in international communications, British Telecommunications P.L.C. is expected to announce this week a venture with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide rooftop-to-rooftop communications between New York and London.

title: BRIEFING;Texan as OSHA Contender
description: Marcus M. Key, a Texas physician and educator, has emerged as the leading candidate to head the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, according to Labor Department and industry sources. He would fill the vacancy left by the resignation earlier this year of Robert A. Rowland, a lawyer and Republican fund-raiser, also from Texas.

title: Yuppies, Whoever They Are, Are Here to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY LAYS BLAME IN DAM'S COLLAPSE
description: High Italian officials said today that private negligence and inadequate public precautions were to blame for the flood disaster here that took at least 198 lives.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bloomingdale's has named Russel Stravitz executive vice president, stores merchandising, and Jeffrey Sherman executive vice president, finance and control and management information systems.

title: Pam McGlynn Is Bride Of Charles B. Whittam
description: Patricia Ann McGlynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. McGlynn of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Barton Whittam, the son of Winifred Whittam of Formby, England, and the late Roger Henry Barton Whittam. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ It is refreshing to realize that the concept of women in jazz, as instrumentalists as well as singers, is no longer new, that the concept has become fact. This thought is prompted by the advent of the sixth annual ''Women in Jazz - Downtown'' series that today starts a two-week noontime run in Chase Manhattan Plaza.

title: AROUND THE NATION;4 Are Killed, 38 Injured As Bus Crashes in Texas
description: An overloaded church bus flipped over twice in a rain storm Saturday night and landed in a cotton field, killing four of the passengers and injuring 38, according to the authorities.

title: AS HE LOOKS TO RECORD, ROSE LOOKS BACK AT COBB
description: TY COBB sits quietly and stiffly in a dressing cubicle in the Cincinnati Reds' clubhouse in Riverfront Stadium. He sports a bronze Tigers' baseball cap and wears a bronze Tigers' uniform shirt, all 2 1/2 feet and 90 pounds of him. Sometimes one of the players puts a Reds' cap on his head, or a pair of outfielders' sun glasses on him, or, if the air conditioning gets drafty, a Reds' warmup jacket is draped around his shoulders.

title: New York's Corporate-Takeover Bill Is Good for Business
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION;Leak Is Repaired At Salem A-Plant
description: Workers at the Salem 2 nuclear power plant have finished repairing a leak in the plant's cooling system and were preparing today to restart the reactor, a spokesman said.

title: WORKING PROFILE: STUART M. BUTLER;SHIFTING BURDEN TO THE PRIVATE SECTOR
description: Stuart M. Butler arrived here from England in 1973, when the British Government was nationalizing almost everything in sight.

title: RELATIONSHIPS;ETHNIC IDENTITY IN OLD AGE
description: I HAD turned away from my Jewishness,'' Runya Schwab, 74 years old, said on the videotape. ''I married a militant atheist, and I considered myself to be more Socialist than anything else.''

title: U.S. Gives the Israelis Position on Arab Talks
description: The United States told Israel today that it was still considering a list of Palestinians proposed for preliminary Middle East peace talks but said such talks must lead to direct Arab-Israeli negotiations.

title: 9.25 BILLION NOTE AUCTION IS SETT
description: Treasury financing this week consists of a $9.25 billion auction of two-year notes on Wednesday as well as today's regular auction of Treasury bills due in three and six months. Looking ahead, government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans on July 31 to sell more than $21 billion of notes and bonds in the week of Aug. 5, divided among three-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Above It All
description: What may be New York's most spectacular walk does not travel through city streets at all, although it does travel - as much as seven feet up and down. Half of it is in New Jersey, much of it is 200 feet above water and all of it has been closed since February 1984.

title: POLES, WITH PLENTY OF PASSPORTS, LINE UP FOR VISAS
description: The longest and most tense lines forming here these days are not in front of meat stores or at the dollar shops selling imported goods, but in front of Western consulates where visas are sought.

title: West St. Water Main Breaks
description: A water main break caused pavement to collapse on West Street in lower Manhattan last night. City officials closed the northbound lane of the street and cautioned motorists to use other routes during the morning rush hour today. Officials at the scene said the 12-inch main cracked at 11 P.M. on West Street between Vesey and Barclay Streets. John Taylor, a supervisor in the city Department of Environmental Protection, said officials hoped to complete repairs this morning. There were no reports of interruption to telephone or electrical service in the area.

title: U.S. ASSAILED ON POPULATION AID
description: Actions by Congress and the Reagan Administration aimed at reducing or eliminating money for population control projects sponsored by the United Nations could hinder family-planning programs in more than 100 developing nations, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

title: Market Place;Analysts' View Of A.T.&T.
description: BEFORE the stock market opened for trading last Monday morning, Alice Bradie, the telecommunications analyst for E. F. Hutton & Company, cut her earnings estimates for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: FLORIDA DIVERS RETRIEVE TONS OF SILVER BARS
description: Millions of dollars in gold, silver and copper treasure from the scattered wreck of the Spanish galleon Nuestra Senora de Atocha was being brought to the surface by divers today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DOLE ASKS REAGAN TO PUSH CONGRESS ON '86 BUDGET PLAN
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that he hoped President Reagan, now that he was home from the hospital, would ''step into the breach'' and help the Senate and House reach a compromise on the budget and on a plan to cut the Federal deficit.

title: LEACH: EVERY FEW YEARS
description: TERRY LEACH did not permit himself the luxury of dreaming of a one-hitter yesterday. There was no point in that. The last time he pitched a one-hitter in the major leagues was also the last time he started a game in the major leagues.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 13 about a disputed scientific report by Columbia University researchers misidentified a co-author of the report. He is Dr. Robert B. Mellins.

title: Futures/Options;Concern Over Safety of Funds
description: HOW safe are the funds that futures traders entrust to their brokers? The question arose again last week when the Commodity Exchange in New York, the largest metals futures exchange, approved a plan to compensate customers of a now-defunct member concern, the Volume Investors Corporation.

title: ADVERTISING;VSI Publishing Starts 2d Fashion Magazine
description: The VSI Publishing Corporation, West German-owned, which already publishes Sportswear International eight times a year for the fashion trade in this country, has just brought out a slick quarterly consumer fashion magazine for both sexes called In Fashion. The cover price will be $2.50.

title: Victor J. Hammer, 83, Co-founder of Gallery
description: Victor J. Hammer, an art dealer and co-founder of the Hammer Galleries in Manhattan, died of heart disease yesterday at the John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: Leah Goldfarb Is Bride Of Richard A. Geismar
description: Leah Goldfarb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Goldfarb of Santa Monica, Calif., was married yesterday to Richard A. Geismar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Geismar of Hewlett, L.I. Rabbi Allen I. Freehling performed the ceremony at the University Synagogue in Brentwood, Calif The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is a sales agent for Richard Marks Realty Inc. in Manhattan. She graduated cum laude from the Columbia University School of General Studies. Her father, a lawyer, is a furniture manufacturer in Los Angeles and was formerly a lecturer in criminology at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: CONVICT CAN RUN, BUT HE CAN'T HIDE
description: Mike Blumberg, his 71-year-old manager, said he was ''dumbfounded'' when he learned that his 27-year-old boxer, Roberto Medina, a man he knew as ''a real friend, just like a son,'' was in reality a 29-year-old escaped convict named John E. Garcia.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Tough Turf
description: Brigham Young University's defending national football champions may very well tear up the field again this year, but their grounds manager, Roy Peterman, hopes not.

title: A STRONG AIR-INDIA IS BESET BY DOUBTS
description: The mysterious crash of an Indian jetliner last month has been a tragedy for the victims and a focus for renewed bitterness in a dispute between Hindus and Sikhs. But it has also posed an unusual challenge for Air-India.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Catching Up
description: Howard Karasick, the sports broadcaster in Sarasota, Fla., who was starving for a winning streak (Scouting, July 5), had to abstain from eating less than a week before his beloved Chicago White Sox took three consecutive games. ''Yeah, five days,'' says the 42-year-old Brooklyn native, ''and 15 pounds.'' Karasick, who has now pared down to 230, began his hunger strike the morning of July 2, when he announced it on his radio show, and he didn't eat again until the night of the July 6, when the Sox beat Cleveland and made it three straight for the first time since June 12.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: BANKS POST STRONG EARNINGS
description: The second quarter was a period of strong earnings for most of the nation's major bank holding companies, despite a continuing high level of loan losses.

title: THE CITY;Reward in Killing Of Fire Lieutenant
description: Mayor Koch yesterday offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the masked gunmen who shot an off-duty firefighter to death during a robbery in a Queens bar.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 22, 1985:

title: Holiday Corp. Net Falls 7.2%
description: The Holiday Corporation, a leading hotel company, reported Friday that its second-quarter earnings fell 7.2 percent despite a 3.4 percent rise in revenues.

title: LLOYD DEFEATS SHRIVER
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd overcame a service break in the second game of the match today and defeated Pam Shriver, 6-4, 6-1, in the final round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Newport tournament.

title: WAR LAW PACT FACES OBJECTION OF JOINT CHIEFS
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have recommended against United States ratification of internationally agreed revisions of the 1949 Geneva Conventions on treatment of combatants and war victims, according to Administration officials.

title: AS STEELWOKERS STRIKE, MILL TOWN SHOWS DECAY
description: As about 8,200 workers struck nine Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation plants in three states, small groups of pickets took turns today at an entrance to the company's plant here.

title: Miss Malkin and David Zornow Marry
description: Martha Lynn Malkin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron S. Malkin of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to David Merrill Zornow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Zornow of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Gary Fink performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: THE REGION;Day-Care Inquiry In Mt. Vernon
description: The Mayor of Mount Vernon said yesterday that he had ordered an inspection of all day-care centers operating in the city in the wake of the arrests last week of four people on charges of abusing children at a privately run center in the city.

title: Fritz Bultman Is Dead; A Painter and Sculptor
description: Fritz Bultman, an Abstract Expressionist painter and sculptor, died Saturday at his home in Provincetown, Mass., after a long illness. He was 66 years old and maintained homes and studios in Provincetown and on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Dorothy K. Roosevelt Dead; War Production Board Expert
description: Dorothy Kemp Roosevelt, at one time the sister-in-law of Eleanor Roosevelt, died today in her suburban Detroit home, family members said. She was 86 years old. Dorothy Roosevelt was the former wife of G. Hall Roosevelt, an investment counselor and engineer who was the brother of Eleanor Roosevelt and nephew of Theodore Roosevelt. G. Hall Roosevelt died in 1941.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE;BLUE JAYS HALT A'S, 11-4, AS BARFIELD STARS
description: Jesse Barfield collected three extra-base hits and three runs batted in and Damaso Garcia drove in a pair of runs today to give the Toronto Blue Jays an 11-4 victory over the Oakland A's and a split of their four-game series.

title: HARLEM CHILDREN LEARN DISCIPLINE THROUGH ARTS
description: In an upstairs room, seven solemn children were playing Vivaldi on violins. In the auditorium, the percussion group was pounding out what sounded suspiciously like chopsticks on drums, xylophones, marimbas, cymbals, wind chimes and tambourines. In another room, tots were practicing tap.

title: HINAULT WINNER AGAIN
description: As nearly half a million of his fellow Frenchmen cheered, Bernard Hinault won the Tour de France bicycle race today for the fifth and, he insists, probably the last time.

title: SHAKING A HERO IMAGE
description: It's a little hard to shake off the image of a hero. Ed Harris has been trying for the last couple of years. He played a fanatic mercenary in ''Under Fire,'' teamed with Goldie Hawn in ''Swing Shift,'' played Sally Field's philandering brother-in-law in ''Places in the Heart'' and starred in Louis Malle's ''Alamo Bay.''

title: Challenge Is Expected Of Farrell's Petitions
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy is expected to challenge the signatures on designating petitions for Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. today, in an attempt to have his name excluded from the ballot for the Democratic mayoral primary Sept. 10, Miss Bellamy's campaign manager said last night.

title: George W. Flynn Dies at 62; An Executive at Dow Jones
description: George William Flynn, a senior vice president at Dow Jones & Company, died of heart disease Saturday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 62 years old.

title: NOT FOR PUBLICATION,' ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: STILL slicing its way carefully through the intricate layers of life in South Africa, ''The Nadine Gordimer Stories'' tonight offers, on WNET/Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, a dramatization of ''Not for Publication.'' Miss Gordimer adapted her short story for this television film, which was directed by Richard Green.

title: EUROPE'S EUREKA PLAN REMIANS TO BE SHAPED
description: Senior ministers from 17 European countries formally introduced a French-inspired joint European high-technology research and development program named ''Eureka'' at a meeting here last week. But just what Eureka will amount to still remains unclear.

title: Washington Watch;U.S. Economic Policies Unified
description: IN April, President Reagan sought to streamline economic policymaking by consolidating various interagency councils in a new Economic Policy Council headed by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. The decision also enhanced the Treasury's authority over all matters of economic policy, national and international. So how is it going? ''I think it's functioning very well,'' Mr. Baker said last week. ''At least we now have everybody in one room, and we have all economic policy under one tent.'' The council has met eight times, most recently last Wednesday. ''We've made a number of recommendations to the President, each of which he has followed, I think without exception,'' Mr. Baker said. It was the new council that worked out the Administration's successful salvo in the ''pasta war'' with the European Economic Community - the threat to raise duties on European pasta if Europe did not begin removing its barriers against imports of American citrus fruit.

title: Man Wounds 4 and Himself
description: A man said to have been distraught over the breakup of his marriage ambushed his father-in-law's birthday party with a shotgun Saturday, wounding four people, and then turned the weapon on himself, the state police said today. The man, Neal Green Jr., 39 years old, of Hamburg, N.Y., was reported in serious condition at Olean General Hospital, the state police said. Mr. Green's estranged wife, Roxanne, was the most seriously wounded victim and and was listed in serious condition at Erie County Medical Center, the police said.

title: 3 DOCUMENTARIES LOOK AT COCAINE
description: COCAINE being the drug of choice among the affluent, some of whom doubtless watch public television, it seems right that Channel 13 should take a look at the subject. This week it is devoting four hours to it - three documentaries done by Brian Moser and a panel discussion produced by Douglas Lutz. The project begins tonight at 10 with a remarkably close-in look at the processing and sale of the drug in its earlier stages. The hour combines anthropology, chemistry and human interest in an adventurous mix.

title: EMERGENCY IN SOUTH AFRICA: BATTLE LINES HARDEN
description: A state of emergency came into force in the centers of South Africa's political turmoil today, and with it came a sense that battle lines had hardened and any residual hope of dialogue had withered.

title: Letter: On Energy Resources;Taxing Oil and Timing Its Storage
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Monsanto President Persistent on Searle
description: He says that he likes the necktie, but Richard J. Mahoney clearly had more than mere fashion on his mind when he went to work on Friday wearing a new purchase.

title: 2D-QUARTER PROFITS OFF MODERATELY
description: Corporate profits in the second quarter of the year appear to have been weak, a result of slow economic growth, the continued strength of the dollar, the widening trade deficit and a trend toward doing more business with foreign suppliers, according to economists.

title: NEW ENGLAND JOURNAL;SEA LOSS, A 'TOWN' NOT FOUND
description: Somewhere in the South Pacific, between Tahiti and Australia, Bill Dunlop, a sailor from Maine, disappeared a year ago in his nine-foot sailboat.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 22, 1985
description: Companies

title: Jockey, 24, Dies After a Collision
description: The jockey Charles Hinojosa died tonight two hours after his mount fell in the ninth race at Charles Town Race Course and another horse toppled onto him. He was 24 years old.

title: IN HARTFORD, CAPITOL RENOVATION UNCOVERS SOME STATE HISTORY
description: For months now, Connecticut's 106-year-old State Capitol has been revealing some of its hidden past.

title: HERO OF PORTUGAL REVOLUTION FACES TERRORISM TRIAL TODAY
description: What many here are calling one of the biggest political trials ever held in Portugal is scheduled to begin Monday in a courthouse specially built for it atop a steep hill overlooking this capital city.

title: Oil Search in China
description: China will open vast areas of its western interior to oil exploration by foreign companies, The People's Daily said today. It said 19 companies from the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Japan, West Germany, the Netherlands and Rumania had been invited to participate. The companies were not identified.

title: URBAN LEAGUE HEAD ASSAILS REAGAN'S CIVIL RIGHTS RECORD
description: John E. Jacob, the president of the National Urban League, assailed the Reagan Administration for its civil rights record tonight in a speech that was uncharacteristically blunt for the usually low-key leader.

title: THE NORTHEAST HOUSING BOOM
description: A resurgence in the housing industry is visible here, amid the construction cranes and bulldozers that are rebuilding much of the downtown area. It can been seen through the scaffolding that cloaks many of the old formerly abandoned mills and factories that are being rehabilitated into housing. It can be seen in the face of Bruce Polishook.

title: ADVERTISING;People
description: Richard P. Parker has been named senior vice president/creative director at Gillespie Advertising, Princeton, N.J.

title: NAVY SPY CASE PROPELLING EFFORTS TO FORTIFY U.S. ESPIONAGE LAWS
description: The arrest of four Navy men on charges of selling military secrets to the Soviet Union has spurred an emotional reaction in Congress that is likely to lead to widespread revision of Federal laws dealing with espionage and military secrecy, prominent lawmakers say.

title: CLARK WINS BY 3 SHOTS
description: Judy Clark fought off a challenge from Donna Caponi to win the Boston Five Classic by three strokes for her first victory in her eight years on the women's pro golf tour.

title: Cheaper Dollar, Costlier Deficit
description: A dollar now buys about 17 percent less foreign currency than it did in February. Is that the longed- for, gradual descent and ''soft landing'' for which economists have been hoping?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Politics on Broadway
description: Local political struggles are not usually sprinkled with stars. Then again, only one local legislative district includes the Great White Way: the Third Council District in Manhattan.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Kennedy Clan Honors Its Matriarch, 95
description: Members of the Kennedy family gathered today to celebrate the 95th birthday of Rose Kennedy after spending the afternoon sailing on Nantucket Sound.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Equal Opportunity
description: It's getting so it doesn't even raise an eyebrow anymore. But, for the record, Patti Ann Compo, an 11-year-old from Ontario, N.Y., near Rochester, has become the latest girl to demand a chance to play organized football with the boys.

title: RON GUIDRY'S STYLE CHANGING FOR BETTER
description: THE questions have become more frequent and less surprising each time Ron Guidry pitches. He began hearing them in June, when his streak reached eight, and again as the traditional break for the All-Star Game approached.

title: Fermat's Last Train
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Stop the Sale of Secrets
description: The recent spate of spying cases has generated public pressure to do something. Congress has responded with ill-considered plans - for reinstituting the death penalty and vastly expanding the use of polygraph tests - that do not solve the problem but run the risk of creating the impression that the problem has been solved. More important, these proposals, included in the Defense Department authorization bill now before Congress, could lead to violations of fundamental rights.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WAY OF THE PHYSICIAN. By Jacob Needleman. 187 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: AROUND THE NATION;TV Anomaly
description: Washington is a national dead spot as far as receiving cable television transmissions, its local government being thus far unable to find a contractor to furnish the service. But the production of cable telecasts is rapidly becoming a major local industry. The capital is currently the headquarters of a half-dozen companies that provide a wide variety of material for satellite transmission to cable systems all over the country. It is second only to New York in such activity.

title: ADVERTISING;Warwick Plus
description: Warwick Advertising has established Warwick Plus, which will be doing all of those marketing chores that at a larger agency might each require a separate subsidiary - such things as direct marketing, collateral and point-of-sale materials, audio visuals and film projects, promotion and public relations. The all-round man to run that show is Michael M. Graham, president of the unit and senior vice president of the parent.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Coast Fires Are Out; Floods Held New Danger
description: Rains over the weekend helped douse the last of a three-week siege of brush and forest fires that have blackened 375,000 acres of California, officials said today.

title: EXTRAS REPORTED IN MILITARY BUDGET
description: Despite the asserted eagerness of Congress to cut military spending, the House-Senate conference on the bill to authorize military programs for the 1986 fiscal year is considering $4.5 billion worth of items not requested by the Defense Department, according to Congressional staff members.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Yodo to Potomac
description: When Kabuki players go to Osaka for their traditional performances, the publicists would have us believe, they arrive by boat and crowds line the banks of the Yodo River to watch the white-faced pantomime and dance artists debark in their colorful costumes and march to the theater.

title: WOMAN IN THE NEWS;NEW HEAD OF NOW PREFERS ACTIVISM
description: Eleanor Smeal won an upset victory over Judy Goldsmith as president of the National Organization for Women today, and the first thing she did when she met the press was to put her arms around her husband and two children.

title: PROST TRIUMPHS IN BRITISH GRAND PRIX
description: Alain Prost of France, in a McLaren-TAG-Porsche, won the British Grand Prix today when the race came to a premature end after an official mistakenly ordered the black-and-white checkered flag to be unfurled a lap early.

title: REPUBLICANS WATCH A BITTER FEUD WITH ANXIETY
description: Senator Bob Dole was speaking recently to a group of college Republicans about tax redesign. Representative Jack F. Kemp, he cracked, wanted a business deduction for hair spray.

title: FIRE I. WATER TAXIS ADD CONVENIENCE AND BOTHER
description: Automobiles have long been banned in summer in this and other Fire Island resort villages. But when people here want to go to the next town for dinner or shopping, they call a taxi.

title: THOMAS D. NUNHEIMER
description: Thomas D. Nunheimer, a research microbiologist involved in the early production of penicillin and other antibiotics, died of a heart attack Thursday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Westinghouse Agrees To Tentative Labor Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and 12 unions representing nearly 21,000 workers reached a tentative contract agreement today, hours before a midnight strike deadline, company and union officials said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS POLICE DETAIN 113 UNDER EMERGENCY
description: The South African police, acting with near-absolute powers under a state of emergency, said today that they had detained 113 people since midnight, when the emergency came into force.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 22, 1985
description: International

title: AROUND THE NATION;Births Up, but Experts Don't Call It a Boom
description: Americans had more children in 1984 than the previous year, but the increase was only an echo of the baby boom of the 1950's and early 1960's, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: ADVERTISING;Checking on Running Of TV Commercials
description: Last week the Federal Communications Commission gave the O.K. to two companies that have already begun to set up electronic systems for verifying that television commercials have run as ordered, a service that has become more important as the result of the F.C.C. decision not to require that stations keep logs of commercial performance.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Garden State Games, hockey trials, at Brick Ice Palace, Brick Township, N.J. 9 A.M. Maccabiah Games, at Tel Aviv. Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City (Television -Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Tennis Volvo/New Jersey Championships, at Newark Academy, Livingston, N.J., noon and 7 P.M., opening round. Johan Kriek is the defending champion and seeded No. 1 in the men's draw of 32 players. Tim Mayotte is seeded second. U.S. Clay Court Championships, at Indianapolis. Andres Gomez of Ecuador is the defending champion, and this tournament could provide a preview of next month's Davis Cup matches that have Ecuador against Czechoslovakia and the United States against West Germany. Seventeen-year-old Boris Becker of West Germany, the Wimbledon winner, and Aaron Krickstein, the 17-year-old American, are both members of their Davis Cup teams and are in the field here. Other Events BASKETBALL: Lite Pro Am Summer Pro League doubleheader at Nat Holman Gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 7 and 8:30 P.M. HARNESS RACING: The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 8 P.M.). Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont Park, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel 6:30 and 11 P.M.) Monmouth Park, 1:30 P.M. Garden State, 8 P.M.

title: PROF. HERBERT GUTMAN, LABOR HISTORIAN, IS DEAD
description: Herbert G. Gutman, a distinguished professor of history at the Graduate Center of City University of New York and the historian of immigrants, workers and slaves, died yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, five weeks after suffering a heart attack at his home in Nyack, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: As a major league manager, does Yogi Berra have a better winning percentage than Billy Martin? How about as a Yankee manager?

title: SELF HELP FPR HYPERTENSION
description: Some residents of five poor counties where hypertension rates are high are making progress against high blood pressure in a self-help program.

title: Trade Deficit Record Likely
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that the United States trade deficit could reach a record $150 billion this year.

title: Children of 5 Boroughs To Present a Musical
description: Children who are spending their summer studying acting, dancing and singing will present a preview of their musical, ''Get It Together,'' Friday at 12:30 P.M. in the Central Park Band Shell.

title: LYLE EDGES LEADERS TO WIN OPEN
description: Sandy Lyle, a 27-year-old Englishman born to Scottish parents, today became the first golfer from Britain to win the British Open in 16 years when he capitalized on a surprising collapse by leaders in a major tournament.

title: Pensions Offer Incentive to New Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;COURAGE FOR THE MIDDLE EAST
description: The Middle East is stirring. There has been a new atmosphere for six months or more reflecting a mounting sense that it is time to try again for an Arab-Israeli settlement. Now, movement has begun, tentative first steps but more specific than anything that has happened since the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty in 1979. Soviet interest in restoring relations with Israel is the latest, most significant sign. Moscow has not confirmed details of the meeting between their two ambassadors in Paris last Tuesday, reported by Israeli radio. But there was no attempt to deny the meeting, or any sign of special irritation at the leakage.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS LINK OF CHEMICAL PLANTS AND TYPES OF CANCER
description: A preliminary study of chemical risks by Congressional aides has turned up data that suggest a link between high rates of respiratory cancer and the locations of petrochemical plants in 133 counties in 27 states east of the Rocky Mountains.

title: JET CAMP OPENS AMID QUESTIONS
description: The Jets open training camp this week at their Hofstra University training facility in Hempstead, L.I., with 75 players scheduled to report Wednesday and the remaining 25 veterans Friday. There seem to be as many questions and problems as there are players.

title: LIFE IN SUMMER STOCK: EARLY MORNING CHORES TO EVENING FOOTLIGHTS
description: Early Tuesday mornings, for the children's show, Bill Schlageter, the theater's general manager, always orders fresh tollhouse cookies from Dominick's Bakery and, by 7, he is up the hill, opening the playhouse. The sun has just begun to warm the vineyards on the hillsides when he arrives, and the birds are still noisy and bold.

title: DEVALUED LIRA SEEN AS 1ST STEP
description: The 7.8 percent devaluation of the lira announced on Saturday will calm the panic triggered by the currency's recent collapse but will not solve Italy's fundamental economic problems, analysts said today.

title: ORAZIO R. CARLUCCI
description: Orazio Raymond Carlucci, former director of the Army's Criminal Investigation Division in Europe and a hotel manager for 20 years, died Friday after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Chester, N.J.

title: FUTURISTIC STATE OFFICE BUILDING DAZZLES CHICAGO
description: The locals are calling it the spaceship and the star wars building. When it was dedicated a few weeks ago, the atrium was draped with a huge banner reading ''A Building for Year 2000,'' and since then the crowds have come to gawk as they have not at any new building in downtown Chicago in years.

title: OUTDOORS: CONTEST DRAWS NEW BREED OF FISHERMEN
description: WATCHING the start of Saturday's American Bluefish Classic, I was reminded anew that the once-traditional image of an angler as one who spends his days in sweet, contemplative silence on stream or lake must be modified.

title: MUSIC: DIAMANDA GALAS
description: DIAMANDA GALAS, the operatically trained experimental singer, calls her music ''intravenal, electro-acoustic voice work.'' The term is really a fancy name for a pyrotechnical vocal approach, enhanced by electronics, that vacillates between a studied primitivism and a dramatic, highly polished bel canto style.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Moslem-Hindu Clashes Kill 10 More in India
description: Ten people were killed and 20 were wounded today as Moslem-Hindu street battles rocked Ahmadabad, the largest city in India's western Gujarat state, the Press Trust of India said.

title: CAMPUSES' ROLE IN ARMS DEBATED AS 'STAR WARS' FUNDS ARE SOUGHT
description: Spurred by the Reagan Administration's project to develop a shield against nuclear missiles, military research is returning in force to top universities, reviving a heated debate over the universities' proper role in developing weapons systems.

title: ISRAELI-SOVIET TALKS 'ROUTINE'
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he was surprised by the ''tremendous'' press coverage given to a meeting in Paris between the Israeli and Soviet Ambassadors.

title: No Headline
description: When Manhattan moviegoers arrived at the Loews Tower East theater on Memorial Day weekend, they found the price of a ticket had jumped to $6, from $5. A comparable surprise awaited audiences at the RKO theaters on Broadway and on 86th Street.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Belmont Owner's Bid On General Refractories
description: Raymond G. Perelman, a Philadelphia investor, expects to make the General Refractories Company his own tomorrow although the producer of mineral and refractory products in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., is opposing the move.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;New Zealand Presses Inquiry on Ship Sinking
description: Three New Zealand detectives flew to the French territory of New Caledonia today to pursue this nation's investigation of the bombing that sank the Greenpeace vessel Rainbow Warrior.

title: Clack, Ex-Giant, Hurt in Accident
description: Jim Clack, a former offensive lineman for the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Giants, remained in intensive care today in a North Carolina hospital after a traffic accident in which he and his wife suffered multiple internal injuries.

title: THE CITY;Lanes on Parkway Are to Be Repaved
description: A half-mile stretch of the southbound Henry Hudson Parkway will be closed overnight for four nights this week for repaving, according to the State Department of Transportation.

title: Empty Gesture in Haiti
description: What might come of today's national referendum in Haiti on proposed constitutional reforms? Not much. Jean-Claude Duvalier, following in the footsteps of his father, Francois, reigns as President-for-Life. The rest is unimportant.

title: CITY OPERA: CAST CHANGES FOR 'PRINCE'
description: THREE alternate principals, one of them new to the company, were heard in the New York City Opera's Saturday matinee performance of ''The Student Prince.'' The newcomer is a tenor, Mark Thomsen, who sang Romberg's melodies with a clean, steady, unforced tone - a good Mozart sound, one would think. He didn't on this occasion show any great feeling for words or phrases, and the final impression was of a certain stiffness - but it needn't be final, as Mr. Thomsen is down for four other roles at the house this season. A good tenor is hard to find, and it will be interesting to see how he turns out.

title: ADVERTISING;Goldline Labs Picks Calvillo, Shevack
description: Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, one of the Mickelberry Group, has been appointed agency for Goldline Laboratories, manufacturer and distributor of generic over-the-counter and prescription drugs in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Billings will be almost $2 million.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Farm Credit Problem
description: The vast network of lending institutions known as the Farm Credit System is what Agriculture Secretary John R. Block calls his ''biggest new problem.''

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Morocco Investment Pact
description: The Reagan Administration will sign a bilateral investment treaty with the Moroccan Government this afternoon, the latest step in a three-year-old effort to remove legal hurdles for Americans who invest overseas. The treaty provides Americans with the same legal rights as their Moroccan counterparts, including compensation for expropriation and access to the courts.

title: AIDS CASES AND RISK GROUPS
description: AIDS continues to spread rampantly among those in the risk groups, but not outside them,'' said Dr. David J. Sencer, the New York City Health Commissioner. Of those contracting AIDS, only 1 percent are not in any of the risk groups, ''just as it was one year ago and two years ago,'' he said. ''The rate remains stable.'' Those at risk include homosexual and bisexual males; intravenous drug users; those from foreign countries where AIDS is believed to be endemic; hemophilacs and those receiving transfusions from infected donors, and the sex partners or children of those who have AIDS. The disease destroys the immune system's ability to fight infection, leaving victims vulnerable to such diseases as cancer and pneumonia.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;TV Channel Swaps Opposed
description: The Federal Communications Commission is probably going to shelve its proposal to allow noncommercial television stations to swap their more desirable channels in the VHF band (channels 2 through 13) for less desirable ones held by commercial stations in the UHF band (channels 14 through 83).

title: Petition Urges No Strike
description: Jeff Trischler went to the ball park early today, not to cheer the players but to gather petition signatures. Mr. Trischler is volunteering as part of a nationwide effort by baseball fans to persuade the players not to strike.

title: ADVERTISING;Durfee & Solow Gets Restaurant Account
description: Durfee & Solow Advertising will be creating the advertising for Lifestyle Restaurants, which will continue to handle its own media buying and placing.

title: GIVE SPIES THE DEATH PENALTY
description: On July 11 the House of Representatives, in its first roll-call on the death penalty since 1977, voted 320 to 101 to permit the execution of persons convicted by military courts of espionage in peacetime. This lopsided result was a clear response to the sharp rise of espionage cases in recent years, and especially to the alleged Walker spy ring in the Navy charged with selling military secrets to the Soviet Union for nearly two decades.

title: Sorenson Takes Public Links Golf
description: James Sorenson scored a 12-and-11 victory today over Jay Cooper in the scheduled 36-hole final of the 60th United States Men's Amateur Public Links Championship.

PENINSULA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: MEXICO OPPOSITION WEAKENED
description: The nearly final assignment of seats in Mexico's national Chamber of Deputies has resulted in a sharp loss of power for the country's two strongest opposition parties.

FIRST AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Boater Arraigned In 2 Deaths on L.I.
description: A Mattituck man was arraigned today on manslaughter charges in connection with the boating deaths of two teen-age brothers.

description: b-Includes gains of $14,852,000 for the quarter and $20,820,000 for the six months from the sale of investments and other assets. c-Includes gains of $7,205 for the year ago quarter and $14,369,000 for the year ago six monts for the sle of investments and other assets.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $8.2 million for the quarter and $41.1 million for the 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Topics;   Extraordinary Personal Preferences
description: The ''personals'' columns in The New Statesman, a British journal, are strikingly similar to those in The New York Review of Books. Both are from people who want ''sharing-caring relationships.''

title: FOREMAN OF JURY BLAMES TOWN FOR SIX FLAGS FIRE
description: Jackson Township officials, not the owners of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, were to blame in the fire in a fun house last year that killed eight teen-agers, the foreman of the Superior Court jury that acquitted Great Adventure Inc. and its parent company said yesterday.

title: THE DANCE: RINKER AT SUMMERFARE
description: KENNETH RINKER, whose modern dance company performed on Friday at the PepsiCo Summerfare festival in Purchase, N.Y., is a choreographer who seems never to stop thinking. His sense of invention is seductive: one wonders constantly what will happen next. But the juicy immediacy of his dance, present in even its coolest and most deliberate moments, is as seductive.

title: SOTO ENDS SLIDE, HANDCUFFS METS
description: Sid Fernandez pitched no-hit ball against the Cincinnati Reds for six innings last night in Shea Stadium, and even struck out 13 batters before he was finished. But, as Casey Stengel used to say, ''You got to get 27 outs to win.'' And he didn't.

title: COMPONENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVED AT U.N. IN 60'S AND 70'S
description: Piero Vinci, an Italian diplomat who served as his country's delegate to the United Nations in the 1960's and 1970's, died of a heart attack Wednesday while vacationing in Ischia. He was 73 years old and lived in Rome.

title: THE EFFECT IS LAVISH AS PARIS COUTURE OPENS
description: The gap between couture or custom-made clothes and ready-to-wear may be narrowing, but there still is a major difference between the two major categories of fashion here. In the fall and winter couture shows that opened Sunday, opulence and extravagance reigned. Utility and practicality were virtues that rarely came to mind. For both day and evening clothes, already elaborate fabrics were further embellished with fur, jewel embroidery and leather accents.

title: Gunslingers Released
description: The San Antonio Gunslingers released all 46 players yesterday minutes before a 5 P.M. deadline to pay the team for two overdue paychecks. General Manager Roger Gill said the United States Football League team intended to pay the players, but he would not say when.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net loss after discontinued operations of $410,417,000 for the quarter and $386,718,000 for the year.

title: KOCH VETOES BAN THAT HE PROPOSED ON FOOD PEDDLERS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday vetoed legislation he had proposed that would have banned food peddlers from most of midtown Manhattan. He said he had decided the bill was too restrictive.

title: Bridge: Westchester Team Outstrips A Field of Many Titleholders
description: At the conclusion of the Big Apple Regional Championships on Sunday night at the Sheraton Centre, a Westchester foursome outdistanced a field that included many national champions. Victory in the Flight A Swiss Teams went to Dr. Robert Klein of Dobbs Ferry, Barry Goldstein of Yonkers, Rick Goldstein of Chappaqua and Bill Lefko of Hartsdale.

title: OLD-TIME JAZZ CONCERTS OPEN TONIGHT AT THE Y
description: A series of six concerts devoted to mainstream and traditional jazz will begin tonight at the 92d Street Y, billed as ''A Festival of Hot Jazz, Ragtime, Oldtime and Blues.'' The concerts will be given Tuesdays through Thursdays this week and next at 8 P.M.

title: MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Presidency;   Convalescence? What Convalescence?
description: During President Reagan's weeklong hospitalization for cancer surgery, the White House kept passing the word that the President was ''champing at the bit'' and ''itching to get back to work.'' The confident refrain was that his illness would have no discernible political effect.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 23, 1985
description: International

title: RIVALS PURSUE IMPEACHMENT
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, saying that the Philippines was at a crucial turning point, appealed today to his countrymen to support the Government's efforts to achieve an economic recovery and to quell the Communist insurgency.

title: New Steps In Athens
description: Steps taken to improve security at the Athens airport may result in some delays but increased security, Greek officials said today.

title: 'ANSWERS,' SHORT PLAYS
description: IF nothing else, cable has provided a little more television room for the occasional worthwhile oddity. There is, for instance, ''Answers,'' a package of three short plays by Ernest Thompson, which has been floating around the Arts & Entertainment Network schedule for some time and will be repeated again tonight at 8.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Triple-Figure Cuts
description: The haircut was completed, and the customer went to the front desk to pay.

title: BRENTON BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Nets will continue their seemingly never-ending search for a new coach when they interview Dave Bliss Thursday. Bliss is currently the coach at S.M.U. . . . The Jets signed three draft choices: Doug Allen, wide receiver, a fourth-round choice from Arizona State; Troy Benson, linebacker, fifth round from Pittsburgh, and Bill Wallace, 12th round from Pittsburgh. . . . One day after announcing they had waived Joe Pisarcik, the veteran reserve quarterback, the Philadelphia Eagles signed Randall Cunningham, rookie quarterback, a second-round choice from Nevada-Las Vegas. . . . Jimmy Connors was fined $500 for cursing a chair umpire, Leon Lipp, during a dispute on a line call Sunday in a semifinal match in Washington he lost to Yannick Noah.

GENERAL SHALE PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: 'Be Nice to New Jersey'
description: Representative H. James Saxton was the first to applaud when he learned recently that the Lone Star Publications of San Antonio, Tex., has proposed a ''Be Nice to New Jersey Week,'' on the theory that the Garden State has been maligned by its critics. Mr. Saxton, a New Jersey Republican, couldn't agree more. He notes that for years detractors have poked fun at his state, with such jibes as ''If this is 'New' Jersey, just imagine what 'Old' Jersey was like,'' and ''New Jersey is a great state to live in; just ask all the people who have moved away.''

title: Deep-Sea Robots to Scan Area of Titanic's Grave
description: ADVANCED new undersea robots, using remote-controlled television, photography and sonar-mapping systems that can survive crushing pressure and pierce the inky darkness miles under the ocean surface, are poised to search the north Atlantic sea floor where the great ocean liner Titanic came to rest 73 years ago.

title: WEINBERGER UNDER POLITICAL SIEGE, BUT FEW EXPECT CHANGE OF COURSE
description: These have been months of political siege for Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

WINSTON LORD IS NAMED AS ENVOY
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Winston Lord as Ambassador to China, the White House said today.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY CALLS COST PINCH A POSSIBLE FACTOR IN OHIO REACTOR ACCIDENT
description: The financial strain of building costly new reactors may have contributed to problems that played a major role in an accident at an Ohio nuclear reactor in June, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House subcommittee last week.

title: Chess: 1985 U.S. Junior Title Won By Maxim Dlugy of Queens
description: Maxim Dlugy, a 19-year-old Queens international master, has won the 1985 United States Junior Championship. Dlugy scored 7-2 in the all-master round-robin invitational tournament held at the Manhattan Chess Club.

title: Towers, Towers, Everywhere
description: From the air, in a flying machine, they look stunning and awesome, the shimmering towers of Manhattan. From the ground, they still awe, but you must do your gaping at them in daytime darkness, for they erase light and also air.

title: Too Dry, Too Late
description: What explains New York City's drought? Not so much a lack of rain this spring and summer as a lack of snow last winter. The real mystery is why it took till midsummer for city officials to discover so obvious a fact, and why their attitude remains so casual even now.

title: ARRAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: What, No Cool Drinks?
description: A gleaming E train from Queens to Manhattan had everything in place but the air-conditioning.

LINCOLN COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: U.S. Swimmers Win More Gold
description: The United States swimming team captured six more gold medals in the Maccabiah Games today, increasing its total to 27.

title: Books: A Byte's Odyssey and Modernized Basic
description: THE market in books on personal computing is suffering from the same downturn in sales that is afflicting software, and for the same reason. There is simply too much junk being published, in a ''they will buy anything'' exuberance. However, the flamboyance seems to be abating, and as the number of volumes decreases, their quality appears to be increasing.

description: The space agency today set July 29 as a firm date for launching the space shuttle Challenger on a mission that was aborted 10 days ago just three seconds before liftoff.

PRESIDENT TO JOIN TALKS ON BUDGET

title: BENJAMIN MANDELKER
description: Benjamin Mandelker, a labor lawyer who most recently served as counsel to the firm of Jackson, Lewis, Schnitzler & Krupman, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: HUGHES TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: NIEKRO FIGHTING STIGMA OF BEING 46
description: There it was again, that line in the record book, just waiting for Phil Niekro to create the opportunity to jump off the pages. As Niekro went through the fifth, sixth and seventh innings on Sunday, his knuckleball jumped inside and outside and down, doing everything its creator could want. His screwball was so effective that it demanded that he mix his pitches more than usual. For more than three innings in the middle of the game, the Minnesota Twins were unable to hit the ball out of the infield, much less score a run.

title: RASMUSSEN LOSES AS ROYALS RALLY
description: Billy Martin won't divulge his plans, but it appears likely the Yankee manager is about to alter his pitching rotation within the next several days.

title: Arrest Warrant Issued For a Jaywalking Meese
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d never paid a $10 jaywalking ticket issued five years ago and a warrant for his arrest was re-issued today, officials said.

title: NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gergen, Former Reagan Aide, Takes Job at News Magazine
description: David Gergen, a former White House communications director, will become managing editor for news at U.S. News & World Report, the magazine announced today.

title: South Africa in Emergency
description: South Africa's new state of emergency amounts to martial law and cuts through much recent debate about the country's future. It proves again that a minority of whites cannot enjoy first-world prosperity and democracy while pursuing colonial dominion over blacks held in third-world conditions.

title: MALE SNAKES FIND ADVANTAGE IN APPEARING FEMALE

Exuding female-like chemical scents, the mimics entice the courtship of other males. By sowing confusion among their male rivals in this manner, the mimics improve their own chances for success in the desperate competition for bona fide female mates.

title: DANCE: 2 BY GELABERT AND AZZOPARDI
description: THE program notes for two dances performed by Cesc Gelabert and Lydia Azzopardi on Sunday afternoon at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N.Y., refer to quite specific inspirations. ''Alhambra,'' choreographed by Mr. Gelabert, a Spanish-born dancer, is said to refer to the architecture and environment of the Alhambra in Granada, Spain. ''Five to Two,'' choreographed by Miss Azzopardi, an English modern dancer, draws upon diary notes and letters from friends. It might have been a more interesting afternoon if any of that had been evident in the dances.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SPECIAL LEGACY. An Oral History of Soviet Jewish Emigres in the United States. By Sylvia Rothchild. 336 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. SYLVIA ROTHCHILD'S first experience of Jewish emigres from the Soviet Union was in 1972 when she visited Schonau, the transit camp just outside Vienna through which they passed on their way to the West. At that time most of them were bound for Israel, but in the years that followed an increasing number opted for the United States, and by the end of the 1970's some 65,000 of them had made their home here. Not long after their arrival, the William E. Wiener Oral History Library of the American Jewish Committee organized interviews with a large group of them -176 men and women in all, living in 25 American cities. One of the interviewers involved in the project was Miss Rothchild, who has now woven their testimony into a fascinating collective portrait.

title: Long Time Between Dates

But the No. 1-ranked Mrs. Lloyd remembered how to handle the world's No. 6 women's player, beating her, 6-4, 6-1, for a victory that stretched her unbeaten record against Miss Shriver to 15 matches.

Selectric typewriter layout. Instead, they shuffled keys around, shrank them or crowded them, wired them with springs and clickers to make obnoxious noises, devised subtle booby traps, fashioning contraptions that may eventually cause users to need orthopedic gloves.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot in Jaw

The police said Officer Gonzales, who was in a car with two other off-duty officers, got out to talk to two women, and followed them.

title: The Final Farewell
description: A lot of people talk about leaving such a will, but friends have not been surprised to learn that Elizabeth Wharton actually did it. The party is set for Friday evening, and invitations are being extended to, among others, all Washington alumni of U.P.I. and U.P. before it, which takes in a good deal of the capital press community.

BUSINESSES COPE UNDER WATER RULES
description: Some retailers are worried about trying to sell winter clothes in warm stores. A partner in a Manhattan law firm is sorry he installed incandescent lights when he remodeled his office a few years ago. But mainly, New Yorkers are adjusting to the latest drought restrictions on using water in the city.

description: Dr. Leo Alexander, a psychiatrist and neurologist who wrote the Nuremberg Code after World War II, which established moral, ethical and legal principles for experiments on humans, died Satuday. He was 79 years old.

description: The issue of Gov. Bill Sheffield's testimony to a grand jury when he said he had no recollection of a meeting in his office last Oct. 2 has become the focus of an impeachment proceeding against him.

description: With the death row population and the pace of executions both mounting, the next Supreme Court term could be the most important in a decade for the future of capital punishment.

description: The officer whose fatal shooting of a black man touched off three days of riots in the Overtown neighborhood in 1982 was justified in using deadly force, a police report on the shooting says.

title: KEACH TO NARRATE FILM ON COCAINE IN OFFICES
description: Capital Cities Television Productions, the production arm of the company that will merge with ABC early next year, will produce an hour documentary on cocaine abuse in the work place, its chief of production said yesterday. The program, to be broadcast over a syndicated network in September, will be narrated by Stacy Keach, the actor recently released from Reading Prison in England after having served time for cocaine possession.

title: CHEERS FOR UNGARO IN HIS 20TH YEAR
description: Emanuel Ungaro drew cheers this morning as he celebrated his 20th anniversary at the head of his own couture house with clothes that had an Edwardian grandeur. This slightly old-fashioned flavor was tempered with a contemporary snugness of fit and colors that were often riotous.

title: ROCK HUDSON IS ILL WITH LIVER CANCER IN PARIS HOSPITAL
description: Rock Hudson is seriously ill with inoperable liver cancer in a Paris hospital, his publicist said today.

The 30-minute production, on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight, looks at the Famous People Players, a theater troupe made up of handicapped young adults. Their message, gracefully delivered, is that if they can do it, so can you.

Ray Miller, the Twins' manager, said he had been impressed enough to consider signing the 27-year-old left-hander. . . . Herschel Walker and three of his New Jersey General teammates were named to the United States Football League all-star team announced by the league. The others were Kent Hull, center; James Lockette, defensive end, and Kerry Justin, cornerback.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TWILIGHT in Greenwich Village. Valerie Slade and a companion are strolling along a tree-lined street. All at once, the low, cool sound of a saxophone is wafting above them. They stop. Others do, too. They all look up, up, to a terrace partly concealed by dense foliage. The classical melody floats out over the evening. ''You are terrific,'' one man shouts up to a bush. An astonished boy of 10 or 12, horn in hand, peers down from behind some shrubbery. ''Play more, play more!'' cries out a young man, lifting his baby son above his head for a better view. The response is another soothing classical composition. The small street crowd applauds. The young musician looks down, less shyly now, and acknowledges his audience.

title: HOUSE RENEWS CLEAN WATER ACT WITH 9-YEAR, $21 BILLION PROGRAM
description: The House of Representatives today approved a nine-year program for sewer treatment facilities costing up to $21 billion as it voted to renew and strengthen the Clean Water Act.

Real Estate;   Big Lease Welcomed Downtown
description: THE World Trade Center, with its 10 million square feet of office space, is one of the linchpins of Manhattan's downtown office market. Conditions there can influence leasing all over the financial district. When the state decided in 1981 to vacate two million square feet of space in the center, the entire downtown market softened in anticipation. With new construction under way, the state's departure would mean additional space to be absorbed.

description: Every weekday afternoon, Filipino children huddle around television sets to watch a show that looks much like ''Sesame Street,'' but isn't.

title: HOFSISS HURT IN POOL MISHAP
description: Jack Hofsiss, the Tony Award-winning director, suffered severe neck and back injuries in a swimming pool accident over the weekend, and was listed in ''guarded'' condition yesterday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue, L.I. A hospital spokesman defined ''guarded'' as ''between critical and satisfactory.''

title: DISEASE IS CITED IN VETERANS' SUIT
description: Five Vietnam War veterans from Long Island who say they are suffering from a parasitic disease endemic to southeast Asia, filed a class-action medical malpractice suit yesterday against the Veterans Administration.

description: Dr. Richard M. Emberson, a former executive director of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, died on July 12 at his home in Eugene, Ore., after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: 10 Boeing 737's Ordered by KLM
description: KLM, the Dutch national airline, has ordered 10 of the Boeing Company's 737 passenger planes to replace part of its medium-range fleet, the airline said. The value of the order, KLM's first ever for Boeing medium-range planes, is estimated at $344 million, an airline spokesman said.

title: New Arena for Brooks?
description: He showed the nation that he knows how to deal with a Soviet threat, so it is hardly surprising that Herb Brooks, the coach who led the United States hockey team to an upset victory over the Soviet team and a gold medal in the 1980 Olympics, is being asked to consider a political career. Jim Ramstead, a Minnesota State Senator and a leader of the state's Independent-Republican Party, said Brooks had been asked to meet with party leaders to discuss the possibility of running for Governor against the Democratic incumbent, Rudy Perpich.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Y.&R. Unit Gets Disney Home Video
description: Young & Rubicam Entertainment is going to take over the advertising for Walt Disney Home Video, previously done in-house.

title: Housing Bonds In West Virginia
description: A $100 million bond issue of the West Virginia Housing Development Authority was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield on interest-bearing bonds due in 2015 of 9.10 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Bridge: A Surprisingly Strong Team Formed by Michael Becker
description: Experts usually enter a major event with the best team they can get, firmly intending to win, but there are exceptions for social reasons.

title: Boxer Is 'Critical'
description: Chris Schwenke, a 27-year-old boxer, collapsed after being knocked out in a light-heavyweight bout in Inglewood, Calif., Monday night, and was reported in critical but stable condition yesterday after undergoing brain surgery at a local hospital. Schwenke, clearly exhausted after trailing on points throughout a fight against Prince Mohammed, the World Boxing Council's No. 2 light heavyweight, was knocked out with 18 seconds remaining in the 10th and last round. He collapsed in the locker room 20 minutes later.

title: TINA TURNER, THE MAIN LADY ON TOUR
description: THE electricity Tina Turner generated as a headliner on the recent Live Aid telecast and her well-received film debut as the tough-minded Aunty Entity in ''Mad Max - Beyond Thunderdome'' are persuasive evidence that the extraordinary success of last year's ''comeback'' album, ''Private Dancer'' (EMI), was no fluke. Even ''We Don't Need Another Hero,'' Miss Turner's less-than-earthshaking new single from the Mad Max film, is spiraling up the charts. Apparently, many people are buying it simply because it's her first new record in over a year, and they're hungry for more.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Garden State Games, at Rutgers and Rahway. National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. Brian Boitano, who finished fifth in the men's figure skating at the 1984 Winter Olympics, is among the competitors in the event, which begins today, even though the opening ceremonies are not until Friday. Maccabiah Games, at Tel Aviv. Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M.) This will be the last appearance in New York this year for Pete Rose, who has the second-highest total of hits for a career. Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, 8:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M.) Expos vs. Atlanta Braves, at Montreal (Television - WTBS, 7:05 P.M.) Boxing Gregg Edelman vs. Randy Mitchem, 10 rounds junior welterweight at Atlantis Casino Hotel. First preliminary 8 P.M. Edelman, from Merchantville, N.J., is 16-1-1 with 13 knockouts. Mitchem, from Lincolnton, N.C., is 28-14, with 15 knockouts. Kid Gloves Tournament, at 1 Penn Plaza, noon. This tournament for boys 10-15 which spawned the Olympic gold medalist Mark Breland will be held just across from Madison Square Garden's Eighth Avenue Plaza. Tennis Volvo/New Jersey Championships, at Newark Academy, Livingston, N.J., beginning of the women's 8-player draw called The State of New Jersey Cup. Among those expected to compete are Andrea Jaeger, Molly Van Nostrand and Grace Kim, noon and 7 P.M. United States Clay Court Championships, at Indianapolis. Other Events BASKETBALL: Lite N.B.A. Pro Am Summer League doubleheader at Nat Holman Gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 7 and 8:30 P.M. BOWLING: P.B.A. Austin Open at Austin, Tex.

Baum, Myroslav Lubachivsky (a naturalized American based in Rome) and three additional retired members - Patrick O'Boyle, John F. Dearden and John J. Carberry.

SCREEN: 'TOSCA'S KISS'
description: CASA VERDI in Milan was founded by Giuseppe Verdi as a home for retired singers and musicians from the Italian opera. Although the royalties from Verdi's work ran out some years ago, the home carries on, and a Swiss movie maker , Daniel Schmid, had the engaging idea of doing a documentary about it. What he found in Casa Verdi, along with a piano in every corner of the resplendent public rooms, were elderly people adrift in music and memories.

title: 2 Dorsett Homes Seized
description: Two homes belonging to Tony Dorsett, star running back of the Dallas Cowboys, have been seized by the Internal Revenue Service yesterday in an effort to collect more than $400,000 in income taxes owed for three years. Marlene Gaysek, a spokesman for the I.R.S., told The Dallas Morning News the homes were in a subdivision north of Dallas and could be sold within 30 days if tax debts owed for 1979, 1980 and 1983 were not satisfied. . . . The San Francisco 49ers have signed their top draft choice, Jerry Rice, a wide receiver from Mississippi Valley State. Terms of the contract were not revealed, but it was believed to be worth $1.8 million over five years.

title: Vote Is Disputed At Refractories
description: Shareholders of the General Refractories Company voted today to elect Raymond G. Perelman, a Philadelphia investor, as chairman and to unseat the current board during a meeting the company branded as illegal.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS CONSIDER DROPPING ATTEMPT AT COMPROMISE ON BUDGET
description: Some Senate Republicans, frustrated by the Senate-House budget impasse, are suggesting that no 1986 Congressional budget at all might be better than a compromise that does not cut domestic spending enough.

title: FUND CITED
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest industrial company, yesterday reported a 44.8 percent drop in second-quarter profits, primarily because it set up a $545 million contingency fund after a court's recent ruling that the company had overcharged oil customers.

description: THE INTELLIGENCE MEN: Makers of the IQ Controversy. By Raymond E. Fancher. Illustrated. 269 pages. Norton. $17.95.

title: Japan's Unwanted Favor
description: Apparently shocked by the strength of protectionist sentiment in Washington, Japan now seems intent on cutting its $50 billion trade surplus with the United States. Unfortunately, its officials are said to be eyeing the path of least political resistance - not opening Japan to more imports but limiting its exports.

But the paperback compendium of futility, buffoonery and dishonesty in major league baseball is not for sale in the Baseball Hall of Fame's gift shop, which offers a wide variety of books on its favorite sport.

title: Utility Issues Tumble on Rate Fears
description: In a dramatic reversal, the stock market yesterday went from a major gain at midday to a sizable loss at the close as investors dumped interest-sensitive utility and telephone issues.

description: A French-speaking couple appeared in court today to be charged with placing bombs that sank a ship belonging to the environmental group Greenpeace and killed a crewman.

description: Francis D. J. Phillips, a former New York City police inspector who was one of the department's most decorated officers, died yesterday after a long illness at the Good Samaritan Nursing Home in Sayville, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

description: IN an industry that has seen its fair share of scandal, the newest outbreak is in, of all places, Austria, a nation where vintages have tended to be undistinguished. This scandal may make them unforgettable. Each day, the incident seems to increase in scope, involving more wine exported to more countries, now including the United States.

title: 3 YOUTHS SEIZED IN KILLING OF FIRE LIEUTENANT

GORDON KORMAN, OLD-PRO AUTHOR OF 10 BOOKS AT 21
description: He wrote his first novel when he was in the seventh grade, and by the time he was midway through adolescence he was a best-selling author. Now, at the advanced age of 21, Gordon Korman is an old hand at publishing juvenile fiction, with 10 books to his credit and more than a million copies sold. Far less well-known here than in his native Canada, Mr. Korman is somewhat reticent about his success; many of his friends at New York University, where he graduated recently as a dramatic and visual writing major, had no idea that their fellow student's school breaks tended to be devoted to making personal appearances.

title: Black & Decker Officer
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said yesterday that Nolan D. Archibald, a senior vice president of the Beatrice Companies, had been elected president and chief operating officer of the maker of power tools. He will take the jobs on Sept. 9, succeeding Laurence J. Farley, who will become chairman, filling a vacancy. Mr. Archibald, 42 years old, has worked for eight years at Beatrice, where there has been substantial management turnover lately. But he said said ''I'm leaving because of an outstanding opportunity at Black & Decker.''
