More Summonses Issued In Italian Dam Disaster
description: A state prosecutor investigating the flood disaster here last weekend that took some 200 lives has issued new judicial warnings, including summonses to most of the area's town councilors.

title: Changes Again for the Jets
description: The Jets' third training camp in the Joe Walton regime starts at 6 P.M. today. This one will be different, says the coach, who has produced a pair of 7-9 seasons.

title: DISNEY GETS TOP NAMES FOR 3-D FILM
description: George Lucas, Francis Ford Coppola and Michael Jackson are, respectively, producing, directing and starring in a 3-D musical film that will be shown exclusively at Disneyland and Disney World. The production of the movie, which Disney was trying to keep secret, was the reason for Mr. Jackson's absence from the Live Aid concert 10 days ago.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
HAITI SAYS DUVALIER WON VOTE
description: The Government's daily newspaper today declared a ''shining victory'' for President Jean-Claude Duvalier in a referendum here Monday, even though Government officials said the votes were still being tabulated and that not even a preliminary count was available.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIFFERENT FOOTWORK The usual noonday entertainment in the plazas of New York runs to dance, music or even theater, some form of performing art that allows office workers a midday respite between competitive bouts at work. A performance today at 1 Penn Plaza, however, gets back to basics in this most competitive of cities.

title: CERTIFIED COLLATERAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $106,000 for the quarter and $216,000 for the six months.

title: NUMERICA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Don't Stifle Workfare
description: The 18-year-old Federal Work Incentive Program, known as WIN, encourages welfare recipients to seek employment. It has seen more than its share of official indifference and now the Reagan Administration seems determined to cripple it. But the program has belatedly evoked considerable interest and produced experiments that show significant promise. What a waste to surrender now, after all that rhetoric about helping people off welfare.

title: We Must Recognize the Shame of Our Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.M. PROFIT DECLINED IN 2D QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that its net income in the second quarter fell 27.9 percent from a year earlier, when earnings were inflated by a tax credit. Without that, the profit drop would have been only 2 percent.

title: Edo de Waart to Head Minnesota Orchestra
description: Edo de Waart, the Dutch conductor, will become music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in the 1986-87 season.

title: ALLEN PACT BARS SOUTH AFRICA
description: Woody Allen has signed a three-movie contract with Orion Pictures that includes a clause prohibiting any of the movies from being released in South Africa.

title: CANADIAN GENERAL ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
$230.4 Million Offering By Washington State
description: A $230.4 million issue of Washington State's general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8.10 percent in 1995, 8.70 percent in 2000, 9 percent in 2005 and 9.10 percent in 2010, through underwriters led by Citibank. The bonds are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: MUELLER, PAUL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BECKER STRUGGLES BUT WINS IN 3 SETS
description: Boris Becker's 16-day joyride as tennis's bright new celebrity almost came to a crashing end tonight.

GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OLD FACE RETURNS TO HOLMES CORNER
description: Richie Giachetti stood on the side, looking somehow ambivalent. There was a news conference at the Plaza yesterday to publicize the Larry Holmes-Michael Spinks heavyweight title fight Sept. 21 in Las Vegas, Nev., and Giachetti, after a three-year exile, was back in the champion's corner. He did not look that happy.

title: FROZEN FOODS EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Sept. 12, 1984.

title: SENATE AGAIN REBUFFS PRESIDENT OVER BILL TO ENHANCE VETO POWER
description: Despite last-minute telephone calls from President Reagan to wavering lawmakers, the Senate today again refused to halt a filibuster blocking legislation that would give the President enhanced powers to veto spending measures.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MANY people justifiably consider the sauce known as americaine to be one of the greatest creations of the French kitchen. No one is certain who created the sauce or how it came by its name. It is generally agreed that it does not mean ''in the American style'' and that it was not created in the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 24, 1985
description: International

title: Paper Airplanes
description: In case you missed the Great International Paper Airplane Contest in Seattle last May, 30 of the prize-winning designs go on exhibit at the National Air and Space Museum today, in the shadow of the larger, more famous and more conventional aircraft. These are the pick of the 4,348 feather-weight hand-launched flyers from 21 countries that were judged variously on the basis of time aloft, distance covered, aerobatics and esthetic design.

title: Unit Shut Down At Salem A-Plant
description: A problem was discovered today in the cooling system of Unit No. 2 at the Salem nuclear power plant and the unit was shut down, according to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a co-owner of the plant.

description: b-Net income.

title: Consensus on Prices Eludes OPEC Meeting
description: OPEC oil ministers remained divided today over Saudi Arabia's demand for a cut in the official price of heavy crude oil. They plan to try again Wednesday, the third day of their conference here, to resolve their differences.

title: NUVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma.

description: Lawmakers from North and South Korea met today for the first time in 40 years to arrange talks on reunifying the Korean Peninsula but failed to agree on an agenda.

description: Israel's Chief Rabbis will no longer require newly arrived Ethiopian Jews to go through a symbolic conversion ritual to be recognized as full-fledged Jews, the rabbis announced today.

title: IN THE THIRD WORLD, A WOMAN'S WORK IS TRULY NEVER DONE
description: As dawn gradually blankets the darkness, the rural women of Kenya and other developing countries are already in the fields, digging, cultivating and planting to carve out for their families a pathway to survival.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ACTRESS DENIED ROLE BY EQUITY
description: Athol Fugard's ''Road to Mecca'' may receive its New York premiere this season from the Lincoln Center Theater Company. But such a production is likely to go on without the South African actress for whom Mr. Fugard wrote the lead role, because Actors Equity will not allow her to perform the role in the United States.

title: Edward Hutchinson, Ex-Congressman, Dies
description: Former Representative Edward Hutchinson, who was the ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee in the debate on impeaching President Nixon, died Monday. He was 70 years old.

The Olympic 3,000-meter champion was offered a piddling amount of money by the promoters of a race in London, apparently to insure she would not get in the way of a made-for-American-summer-television soap opera involving Mary Decker Slaney and Zola Budd.

YANKS LOSE AGAIN TO ROYALS
description: The Yankees lost another game and more ground in the American League East tonight and, as if on cue, Billy Martin, their temperamental manager, found an excuse.

title: Two Key Executives Quit Eastern Air Posts
description: Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that Morton Ehrlich and Russell L. Ray Jr., senior vice presidents and members of the office of the chairman, as well as potential candidates for Frank Borman's job as head of Eastern, had resigned.

title: 134 INDICTED IN NATIONWIDE DRUG DISTRIBUTION CASE
description: The Federal authorities today announced indictments against 134 people on charges of conspiring to distribute large quantities of heroin, cocaine and marijuana brought into the United States from Mexico.

title: URBAN LEAGUE OFFICIALS ARE ARRESTED AT EMBASSY
description: Forty-three demonstrators, including the president and other top officials of the National Urban League, were arrested today at the South African Embassy here in a protest over that Government's racial policies.

title: Sears Net Falls 25.4%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, hurt by slumping merchandising earnings, said yesterday that net income dropped 25.4 percent in the second quarter, to $265.5 million, or 72 cents a share, from $356 million, or 99 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter. Revenues rose 4.2 percent, to $9.84 billion, from $9.44 billion.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   From Rags to Hitches; Taxing Themselves
description: A New York law permits creation of business-improvement districts in which neighborhood merchants tax themselves for street cleaning, lighting, security and other amenities. Everyone likes the idea, yet for two years the program has been stalled in New York City by a dispute between the City Council and the Board of Estimate.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $14,000,000 from the sale of loans and securities.

description: NEW ORLEANS, July 23 (AP) -

title: Tribune Co. Widens Profit
description: The Tribune Company, which owns The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, said today that its second-quarter net income rose 18 percent, to $34.5 million, or 85 cents a share, from $29.2 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS DIVIDED OVER BILL ON ALIENS
description: As Congress once again takes up an immigration bill that would ban the hiring of illegal aliens, the Reagan Administration is sharply divided over a proposal to allow American farmers to employ hundreds of thousands of temporary workers from foreign countries.

Boeing and G.E. Offer Pentagon a Refund Plan
description: The Boeing Company and the General Electric Company, the nation's fifth- and sixth-largest weapons contractors, have offered refunds on equipment the Pentagon considers overpriced, the Defense Department announced today.

title: 441 ARE DETAINED BY SOUTH AFRICANS UNDER NEW RULES
description: The South African authorities said today that 441 people, most of them black, had been detained since a state of emergency went into effect at midnight Saturday.

description: Amid renewed hopes of a settlement, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi met today with the leader of the main Sikh political party, their first meeting since the Government crackdown on Sikh extremism last year.

title: U.S. Settles Suit on Suicide
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay $140,000 in an out-of-court settlement with the parents of a woman who committed suicide with pills prescribed by a doctor at a military hospital. The woman, Melissa Trevino, 19 years old, died in 1981 of an overdose of antidepressant pills prescribed by a doctor at Wilford Hall Air Force Medical Center, where she had been diagnosed as a suicide risk, according to the suit.

description: The House Ways and Means Committee, which is drafting a comprehensive bill to control the cost of Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, today rejected a proposal to establish a new tax on beneficiaries with incomes above a certain level.

description: This morning, for the first time since they opened training camp eight days ago, the Giants staged a full-speed scrimmage. Lee Rouson could not have been happier.

description: Israeli gunboats attacked a Honduran-registered cargo ship today off southern Lebanon and then shelled the nearby port of Sidon, the police and the state-controlled Beirut radio reported.

title: Mexico Economic Plans
description: Amid an unstable oil market, shrinking foreign income and heavy speculation against the peso, Mexico is preparing a new set of budget plans to bring the country's shaky economy under control. President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado said the Government would pursue ''radical structural changes that would demand still greater efforts from society.''

title: A VILLAGE FIGHTS TO SECURE A FUTURE

description: Vice President Bush said today that he felt the burden of his own responsibility more heavily when President Reagan went into surgery July 13 than he did when the President was shot in 1981.

title: MEMBER OF THE HOLLYWOOD 10
description: Alvah Bessie, an author and screenwriter and one of the ''Hollywood 10'' held in contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions during hearings in 1947 into alleged Communist influence in the film industry, died of a heart attack Sunday in Terra Linda, Calif., near San Francisco. He was 81 years old.

title: NIJINSKY II YEARLING BRINGS $13.1 MILLION
description: A son of Nijinsky II brought $13.1 million today at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale, breaking by $2.9 million the record for a thoroughbred sold at public auction.

description: The British Government cleared the way today for a $486 million takeover bid for the whisky distiller Arthur Bell by Guinness & Sons P.L.C. The Department of Trade and Industry said the bid would not be referred to the Monopolies Commission. Bell has rejected the bid and urged shareholders to keep their equities.

title: Yields Remain Steady
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were relatively unchanged for the second consecutive week, in the period ended yesterday, signaling a stabilization of rates after several months of steady declines, analysts said.

description: Zimbabwe's new Parliament, meeting for the first time since elections this month, renewed the country's state of emergency today.

CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Kay Kyser yesterday gave incorrect dates for the formation of his first band and his departure from Chapel Hill, N.C. He started the band while still in college and took it on the road after graduating from the University of North Carolina in 1928.

title: 13 ARE SEIZED ON CHARGE OF BRIBING INSPECTOR IN UNDERCOVER ROLE
description: Thirteen building owners and contractors were arrested Tuesday for offering bribes or illegal gratuities to a city building inspector engaged in undercover work, city officials announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about President Reagan's welcome for President Li Xiannian of China incorrectly described Grace Bumbry. Though she has occasionally sung soprano roles, she is a mezzo-soprano.

title: A No-Win Proposal On Abortion Rights
description: No matter where you stand on the debate over abortion, Roe v. Wade is a case that is difficult to like. The ''pro-life'' groups obviously oppose the United States Supreme Court's 1973 decision upholding a limited right to end pregnancy. But not even the ''pro-choice'' camp has been fully satisfied because the Court cast its decision largely in terms of a physician's right to prescribe treatment for a patient rather than as a firm endorsement of a woman's right to control her body.

title: United Will Base Fares on Distance
description: United Airlines announced a major restructuring of its domestic air fares yesterday, saying that coach ticket prices would be based on the distance traveled. The plan, which goes into effect Aug. 17, would result in fare increases for about two-thirds of its flights, the airline said.

title: JWT Profits Off
description: The JWT Group reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income was off 6.5 percent, to $5.8 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $6.2 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues were up 10.5 percent, to $141.5 million, from $128.1 million for the 1984 period.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

GARDENING;

LOOKING AT CHICORY, CLOVER AND DAISIES
description: ONE of the most agreeable sights I know is yellow goldfinches in a patch of french blue chicory blossoms on a sunny morning after the mist has risen. This morning, taking a break from processing and bottling honey, I carried my coffee out to the place where the chicory grows next to the barn and watched the goldfinches, a dozen or more of them, shimmering yellow birds trimmed with black and white, working their way up and down the stiff chicory stems looking for ripe seeds.

title: A DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVE
description: BUFFALO Sunlight was sinking behind the first-base stands at War Memorial Stadium, low enough at the start of the game between the Omaha Royals and the Buffalo Bisons that the batter stood in shadows while the pitcher stood in the light. Dave Cone, a hard-throwing right-hander for the Royals, threw an inside fastball to Ron Kittle of the Bisons, a pitch Kittle never saw. He just leaned back, and the ball buzzed under his elbow. "I thought, 'That's all I need. Get hit in the head,' " Kittle said. He is scheduled to return to the Chicago White Sox this morning, less than a week after he was sent here for the rehabilitation of shoulder miseries that have existed since April. Kittle's sense of perspective tells him that he will start a new part of the season, that a batting average of .195, based on just 149 times at bat, can rise dramatically with a few swings. But his memory provides the reminder that a fastball in the head is about the only circumstance he has not discovered during this dismal year. His story had once been an unacceptable movie plot, because there was too little for anyone to believe. Spinal-fusion surgery had ended his baseball career. He returned to Gary, Ind., to become an iron and steel worker until the White Sox rediscovered him, gave him a tryout, and watched him become the American League rookie of the year in 1983. He hit 67 home runs in his first two full major league seasons to match Frank Robinson for the sixth-highest total for the first two years. This season, at the age of 27, Kittle has had to confront the expectation to play when his body says it cannot. He ran into the left-field wall at Comiskey Park chasing a fly ball April 20, and several times since he has wondered how much damage was being done. He has known the confusion of being able to hit home runs in batting practice, and soon after being unable to comb his hair. "I was getting depressed," he said. "I didn't want to go to the ball yard. I couldn't carry a gallon of milk from the grocery store." The report from the White Sox continues to be that Kittle suffers from a sore shoulder. He feels the golf ball-size lump that sat on his right shoulder blade not long ago provided evidence of something more severe. "If that's an inflamed shoulder," he said, "I'd hate to see a broken shoulder." And then came the news, last month, when the team was in Seattle. The first child for Ron and Laurie Kittle, a girl, had died at birth. That night, he flew home. "It was the most depressing thing I ever did in my life," he said. "It was a hard experience to explain. I love kids. I'd trade every penny I've made for a baby." Suddenly a painful shoulder and the opinions of management did not seem very important anymore. Roland Hemond, the general manager, said Kittle had not been accused of being unwilling to play. "I don't know if they were questioning me or not," Kittle said. "I didn't care anymore. I have a lot of talent. I can hit a ball as hard or harder than anyone in baseball." There was the day he was needed to play left field, and told Tony LaRussa, the manager, he could not. "I said, 'I can't throw,' " Kittle said. "I just told him plain as that." The response, he said, was that he could make shorter throws to a cutoff man. "If I get the ball hit to me," he said, "I'm going to try to throw somebody out, and it's going to hurt. He's not inside my body. He didn't have the pain. Being a professional athlete, you're going to have aches and pains. But it was just getting to the point where I wasn't concentrating on baseball. Believe me, I think I know better. "Why should I go out at 50 percent, and have somebody steal bases on me, and have them say, 'Kittle can't throw'? There were probably 50 percent of the fans could throw the ball farther than I could. That's when I said I've got to worry about nobody else but me." He was placed on the disabled list and sent here, a trip that seems almost like a vacation. Kittle said he had had more fun this week than he had all season. He was batting .438 for the Bisons before he was hitless in five times at bat lastnight, but that was not important. He said his shoulder felt as good as it had since April. Kittle teased small children until they ran in fright, turned around, and came back giggling for more. He kibitzed as he collected baseballs during batting practice and tossed them in the direction of the shopping basket near the mound. He lingered in the clubhouse with teammates from past minor league teams who have been less fortunate. He remembered how Jose Castro of the Bisons had once been the victim of his success. Kittle hit 50 home runs at Edmonton in 1982. Castro batted behind Kittle, often when home runs had left pitchers in a less than pleasant frame of mind. "His whole body was black and blue," Kittle said. Soon he will be home again, close to his one-acre pond stocked with fish in his backyard, ready to start his season again. "I'm kind of nervous to go back up there," he said. "Not really nervous. Excited." He has always remembered that the White Sox gave him that chance, took him out of the mills, made him a hometown hero, and paid him more money than he ever dreamed he'd make. Now he will always remember that there are more important things. - PLAYERS

SUSAN SCHNUR
description: I HAD a spine disease in my late teens and early 20's, and I suppose you could say it pruned me back. No one particularly knew about my pain but me and the boyfriend who slept next to my body cast. At night, because of the pain, I cried myself to sleep with a feeling that was like searching for a small window along a vast wall; eventually, through the night, I would find that window and crawl through onto what felt like a narrow shelf: sleep.

title: THE DANCE: DESROSIERS TROUPE AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: The Robert Desrosiers Dance Theater from Toronto, which opened at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Tuesday night, fortunately ran true to form. A crocodile slithered across the stage, a spotted cow swung centrifugally from a rope attached to a spinning man, smoke poured out of three men's stovepipe hats, a nearly naked figure waved its arms while pinioned atop a red obelisk, and so forth.

title: SCANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMEDY: EMO PHILLIPS
description: ALTHOUGH Emo Phillips hails from Downer's Grove, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, the persona projected by the fast-rising standup comic is more like a befuddled visitor from another planet. Gazing blankly at the audience, his eyes round as buttons on a rag doll, Mr. Phillips continually runs his fingers through a sawed-off pageboy haircut and spouts absurdist aphorisms in an oddly childish voice. ''Ambiguity - it's the devil's volleyball,'' he proclaims. But the way he delivers such intellectual one-liners, they emerge radically deflated of meaning.

title: ACCORD FOCUSES ON LONGSTANDING SIKH DEMANDS
description: The agreement announced today between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Sikh politicians focused on political, economic, religious and territorial demands that Sikhs have been pressing, in some cases, for decades.

GENERAL FOODS IS DOWN
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., which in June agreed to be acquired by R. J. Reynolds Industries for $4.9 billion, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1985 edged up 1.3 percent as sales dropped 2 percent.

title: HOT MARKET FOR RADIO STATIONS
description: They may not have the cachet of television stations. And in the merger market, they do not command the same multimillion-dollar price tags. But radio stations are quietly changing hands these days at a record-breaking pace.

title: MAYOR KOCH CUTS RED TAPE, AND CHEF KEEPS ON COOKING
description: K-Paul's Louisiana Kitchen passed an inspection by the city's Health and Buildings Departments yesterday afternoon, and an order closing the restaurant at 77th Street and Columbus Avenue was removed from its door.

title: Perez Still Absent
description: Pascual Perez, the Atlanta pitcher who left the team after a disastrous outing against the Mets in New York Sunday, remained among the missing yesterday, and the Braves said that if they had not heard from him by this morning they would ask the National League for permission to transfer him from the suspended list to the restricted list, an administrative move that would allow them to call up another player to take Perez's place on the 25-player roster.

description: ROBERT PLANT sang a schizophrenic concert Tuesday at the Meadowlands'

title: SOVIET SAID TO HINT AT NEW ARMS OFFER
description: The Soviet side in the Geneva arms talks has raised the possibility of offering to make a 30 percent cutback in strategic nuclear missiles and bombers along with a related reduction in nuclear bombs and warheads, Administration officials said today.

title: PRESIDENT LOBBIES FOR AN '86 BUDGET
description: President Reagan today prodded Congressional leaders to act on a budget, asserting that the Federal Government should operate in the same manner as other governmental bodies.

description: For the first time since 1960, when a club from Havana was a member of the International League, a Cuban baseball team is set to compete in the United States.

description: James F. Parker, an artist and the director of the Paris campus of the Parsons School of Design, died July 14 of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old.

description: A $371.1 million issue of Fort Worth general obligation bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.50 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8 percent in 1995, 8.75 percent in 2000 and 8.80 percent in 2002, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

description: Jesse Barfield hit a two-run homer tonight, and Jimmy Key and two relievers combined for a seven-hitter as the Toronto Blue Jays beat Seattle, 3-1, for their ninth straight victory over the Mariners.

CITY BAR PANEL FAULTS LAWYERS FOR POOR
description: A report prepared by a committee of the City Bar Association has charged that the court-appointed and Legal Aid Society lawyers representing the city's poor are variously overworked, underpaid, incompetent or indifferent.

title: A MISSILE-BASE ART COLONY FOR NON-BOHEMIANS
description: Art, as any artist knows, defies convention - and sometimes the avant-garde as well. It need not, for example, take root in some peeling city loft where a wild bohemian in rumpled clothes throws paint on a canvas.

title: Man Killed in Coast Fire
description: Fire swept through a four-story apartment building today, killing one man and injuring 20 people, including some residents who escaped by leaping from windows, the authorities said. It took 75 firefighters about 45 minutes to extinguish the blaze, three miles west of downtown, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: GOVERNOR OF ALASKA IS SUPPORTED BY FORMER CHIEF AIDE AT HEARING
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield's truthfulness and integrity were defended Tuesday at a State Senate Rules Committee hearing by John Shively, the Governor's former chief of staff. Some had expected him to be critical of Mr. Sheffield.

title: CECO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Post's Net Up
description: The Washington Post Company said today that its second-quarter net income totaled $34.1 million, or $2.61 a share, for the second quarter of 1985, up 25.4 percent over $27.2 million, or $1.94, a year earlier.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Becker Playing For Vilas, Too
description: Guillermo Vilas, now 32 years old and struggling to regain the form that once placed him among the world's top tennis players, is not yet ready to call it a career. But, like most people with an eye on eventual retirement, he is paying attention to his investment portfolio. Among the properties that Vilas co-owns with his former coach and manager, Ion Tiriac, are six tennis clubs sprinkled throughout Europe, as well as a Long Island mansion. And now he has made an acquisition that may be the most lucrative yet: a piece of Boris Becker.

title: Veteran of 1898 War Is Dead
description: Albert Tanner, the last surviving Spanish-American War veteran in the state of Washington and the nation's fourth-oldest veteran, has died at a hospital here. Mr. Tanner, who was 105 years old, served in the Army from 1898 to 1902, and later fought in World War I.

title: FRED H. MOORE
description: Fred H. Moore, a former director and executive vice president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Saturday at Seton Hospital in Austin, Tex. Mr. Moore was 75 years old and lived in Austin.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on situation in South Africa.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Savings Bank, New York, has named Cheryl Bell senior vice president, marketing.

title: KERKORIAN ADVISER GETTING BIGGER ROLE
description: As legal adviser to Kirk Kerkorian for the last several years, Stephen D. Silbert has often been a spokesman for the low-profile Las Vegas financier, who controls the MGM/UA Entertainment Company and rarely talks to reporters.

title: BARON DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Great Phony Budget Battle
description: Washington is locked in battle over how to reduce the budget deficit. The deficit is real, dismayingly so, but the battle is a phony. Even as the White House, Senate and House variously pretend to wrestle down the deficit, they are acting daily to make it bigger. Will they ever stop playing games with the future?

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $6,867,000 for the quarter and the six months.

title: Interpublic President To Retire in September
description: J. Donald McNamara, the 61-year-old president of the Interpublic Group of Companies, who was the subject of retirement rumors in February, will be retiring in September, the holding company announced yesterday.

RECITAL: JOHN SCHAEFFER
description: ORGANISTS who aspire to careers as concert performers are often confronted with a problem: how to divorce their concert playing from the kind they do as church organists. The two are very different, but few organists distinguish between them clearly enough to win total success in the concert field.

title: TORY M.P.'S REBEL AGAINST THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher narrowly escaped a humiliating defeat in the House of Commons today when members of her party broke ranks to vote with the opposition against big pay increases for senior Government employees.

title: LIVING IN THE EMERGING FLATIRON DISTRICT
description: THE red brick, green copper and gray limestone facade opposite Karen Lee Sobol's loft is so vivid that it projects into her apartment like a slide in a show of 19th-century architectural ornamentation. At certain times of day, the ornament on her own building casts gently shaped shadows on the hardwood floor. Miss Sobol, an architect, chose to live in this apartment on Fifth Avenue in the 20's, she says, ''for the light and space, so I could draw and paint again without having to do it on a kitchen table.'' She often finds herself sketching the Renaissance-style arches and the carved fish and floral motifs on the building opposite.

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-There are no comparable results for the year-ago period because the company was not in operation prior to its intitial public offering on May 30, 1985.

title: QUIET CLASSIC ELEGANCE OF SAINT LAURENT STANDS OUT IN PARIS
description: The Saint Laurent show was unparalleled on two counts. In a season when the models are usually loaded with jewels and accessories, he sent them out practically unadorned. Oh, they wore earrings and often carried scarves, but that was about it. And in a season of neon brilliance in color, Saint Laurent stressed dark shades for day. Instead of black with navy, he focused on black with brown for a sober combination. It was quiet, remarkably effective, and the best show of the season.

title: Gains in Study Of Auto Fuel
description: THE ways in which gases ignite and burn inside an automobile's engine have long fascinated engineers, and studies have intensified in this decade, both because of new tools and because of the need for far better fuel economy and performance.

description: Debt Issues

title: BANK OF BOSTON DETAILS ITS FAILURES
description: The board of directors of the Bank of Boston Corporation, in a report issued yesterday on the bank's failure to properly report large cash transactions, described a persistent breakdown of the bank's controls spanning a number of years and reaching as high as the chairman's office.

Wallace Undergoes Surgery To Relieve Pain From Wounds
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama underwent almost five hours of spinal surgery today to alleviate leg pain that has dogged him since he was shot and partly paralyzed 13 years ago. He later told doctors that he felt some relief.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,969,000 for the quarter and $3,071,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $2,191,000 for the quarter and $4,896,000 for the 6 months.

title: COOR MENDS MINORITY FENCES
description: The subject of race relations at the Adolph Coors Company has not always gone down as smoothly as its beer. Two years ago, embroiled in lawsuits charging discrimination in hiring, and widely criticized for controversial remarks made by its chairman, the Colorado beer brewer was the object of a nationwide boycott by black and Hispanic groups.

title: Italy Arrests Owners Of Dam That Collapsed
description: The Italian authorities announced the arrest of three people today in connection with the collapse of a dam last week that killed at least 200 people in a Dolomite Mountain valley.

title: A Soft Shoe Vigil
description: The domestic footwear industry is going to put a little pressure on President Reagan this week. In Lafayette Park, across from the White House, representatives of the unions and management of the shoe business will begin a ''vigil'' this morning to urge quotas on imports, but the demonstration will be halted from 10 P.M. to 7 A.M., pretty civilized by vigil standards.

title: Those DC-Deer
description: Long before Dulles International Airport was built in 1962, deer romped happily around what was then a largely unpopulated area in the northern Virginia countryside just west of Washington. As airport officials know only too well, the deer have not been intimidated by jumbo jets into giving up entirely on their old haunts.

title: LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GAIN IN OIL STOCKS EASES DOW'S FALL
description: Helped by surprising strength in oil issues, the stock market yesterday was able to turn what might have been a substantial decline into a modest one.

title: U.S. GIVES UP EFFORT TO INDICT TEAMSTER CHIEF AS EMBEZZLER
description: After a four-year inquiry into charges of embezzlement, the Federal Government has decided not to prosecute Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, according to Labor and Justice Department officials.

title: Landmarks Panel Backs Carnegie Hall Project
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved a major restoration project for the exterior of Carnegie Hall. During a public hearing that began Tuesday and continued into early yesterday morning, the commission found the request ''sympathetic to the existing design'' and voted for it unanimously, 7 to 0.

title: Bridge: Developer of 'Breakthrough' Offers a Treatise on Bidding
description: Those who are interested in bidding theory will find much food for thought in ''Bridge in the 80's'' by Robert Sundby.

title: Our Drug Laws Create Sentencing Paradoxes
description: To the Editor:

title: A First Account
description: I. Goldberg & Partners, founded three weeks ago by the former co-creative director of Nadler & Larimer, has just picked up its first account, Nantucket Industries, which is licensed to manufacture Brut fashion underwear for men. Brut, the fragrance line, as all advertising fans know, was for years a Nadler & Larimer client.

title: Austerity?
description: The International Monetary Fund may press client countries in the third world to adopt austerity measures, but its officials aren't likely to have much familiarity with hardship themselves.

title: Philip Morris Issues Magazine for Smokers
description: Some cigarette companies may be curtailing the amount of money they are sinking into magazine advertising, but Philip Morris is not only increasing its spending but also bringing out a magazine of its own.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago sales figures have been restated.

title: COHU INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tribes Win on License Plates
description: Washington state must recognize license plates two Indian tribes use on tribal vehicles, just as it recognizes plates of the Federal Government, other states and foreign countries, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled. The Queets Band and the Muckleshoot Tribe adopted their own licenses after the state refused in 1974 to provide plates at the nominal fees charged to state and local agencies.

title: U.S. TO ACCUSE SOVIET IN HELSINKI
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the human rights situation in the Soviet Union had worsened in the 10 years since the signing of the Helsinki accord, which was supposed to make the situation better.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rates on Offering By R.J. Reynolds
description: Interest rates for this week's largest corporate financing - a two part offering totaling $500 million by R.J. Reynolds Industries - were announced yesterday by Dillon, Read & Company, lead underwriter for the sale.

title: VARIED TECHNIQUES AT CERAMICS SHOW
description: ON the Upper West Side, a realm of ice cream shops and trendy sportswear, the Departure Gallery is something different. David Morgan, who is a co-owner, moved the gallery from Madison Avenue last year. And because he started out as a ceramics collector himself, his summer show, which runs through Aug. 20, highlights that medium.

description: Yesterday, a week after Arthur Kretchmer, the editorial director, took on the additional title of associate publisher at Playboy, he announced that the three top guys in advertising sales had resigned.

title: NCNB Acquiring Bank in Florida
description: The NCNB Corporation, a bank holding company based in Charlotte, N.C., said it had agreed to acquire Pan American Banks Inc. of Miami for about $219 million, or twice Pan American's book value. The acquisition must be approved by regulators and stockholders of both companies.

BEHIND THE MASK: A SINGING UMPIRE
description: If the players in the big leagues go on strike Aug. 6, as threatened, one person in the game who has another career to fall back on is Joe West, the singing umpire, also known in country-music circles as the ''blue cowboy.''

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL CHIEF'S COPTER REPORTEDLY CRASHES NEAR BORDER
description: A helicopter carrying Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Sandinista hero who now leads a rebel force fighting the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua, was reported today to have crashed near the Nicaraguan-Costa Rican border Tuesday afternoon, and there were conflicting accounts about his fate and whereabouts.

title: 3 IN OPEC RESISTING SAUDI PLAN
description: OPEC's oil ministers broke up in disagreement again tonight after a sharp clash over pricing between Saudi Arabia and the organization's three most radical members - Algeria, Libya and Iran.

title: ISRAELIS FREE 100 MORE DETAINEES FROM LEBANON
description: A total of 100 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners were driven to the Lebanese border and freed today, leaving about 300 others still in Israeli custody, a military spokesman announced.

title: Robbery Suspect Shot by Officer
description: A Housing Authority police officer yesterday shot one of two robbery suspects who threatened him with a gun, wounding the suspect in the stomach, authorities said.

title: RAIDS REDUCE CALIFORNIA MARIJUANA PLANTING 40%
description: Illegal marijuana cultivation in the forested highlands of California's northern coast has been reduced 40 percent by a two-year campaign of federally financed helicopter raids against growers, according to police officials.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $3,094,000 from the repurchase of notes and debentures.

title: MIX OF PEOPLE AND BUSINESS
description: WHEN Peggy Tagliarino moved four years ago to the loft on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street where she runs a public relations concern, the area was so deserted after dark that she would grasp Chemical Mace in her pocket. Today she has abandoned the Mace, for the streets are alive, day and night, in the Flatiron district.

title: REILLY: ACE OF SPIES' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ON its second time around in public television's ''Mystery!'' series, the 12-part ''Reilly: Ace of Spies'' has reached that point - on WNET/ Channel 13 tonight at 9 - at which viewers inevitably begin to wonder what this British production is actually up to. Sidney Reilly, a shady character whose official biography is sketchy, is portrayed by Sam Neill (''My Brilliant Career'') with a dash and elegance clearly designed to elicit a good measure of admiration. Yet, looked at with just a touch of objectivity, the man was little more than a bounder, a thug and, all in all, a fool.

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results reflect pooling of interests aquisition.

title: DYNAMICS WILL CLOSE QUINCY SHIPYARD IN 1986
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's third-largest defense contractor, announced yesterday that it would close its shipyard at Quincy, Mass., following completion next year of a Navy ship construction program. The company blamed poor business conditions.

title: Sandy Bowl Is Favored
description: Lutin D'Isigny, the French-trained defending champion who set a world record in winning the 1984 race, drew the rail yesterday for the 27th annual Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night. But it was Sandy Bowl, the winner of the American trotting championship at Roosevelt last week, who emerged as the pre-race favorite among the eight horses representing five countries.

description: In preparation for the new school year, the Government is providing educational material to remind teen-age girls of toxic shock syndrome - a flulike illness that primarily strikes young women who use tampons.

title: Army Recruiting Gone Awry
description: ''Adventure!'' the unsolicited letter promised. ''Whether you're rappelling down a Western mountainside, parachuting over a stretch of the Great Plains or playing soccer with some new friends in Germany, you'll find travel and adventure others may only dream about.''

title: COLOMBIAN PLAN DOWN IN JUNGLE
description: A Colombian Air Force cargo plane providing commercial passenger service during a pilots' strike crashed today in a jungle during a rainstorm, apparently killing all of the approximately 80 people aboard, the authorities said.

title: RIGHTS HEAD ASSAILS CONGRESS
description: The chairman of the Commission on Civil Rights today accused Congress of using its General Accounting Office as an ''ideological watchdog'' to attack the commission's stand against the concept of paying women and men equally for performing different jobs having similar value.

title: REDS ACHEIVE SWEEP OF METS
description: The Cincinnati Reds completed a three-game sweep over the recently red-hot Mets yesterday when they scored an unearned run in the ninth inning to win, 3-2. And not even old Pete Rose could quite believe it.

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texaco Allowed To Divest Wyco
description: The Federal Trade Commission has announced that it approved Texaco Inc.'s proposed divestiture of its 40 percent interest in the Wyco Pipe Line Company, which carries refined petroleum products from Wyoming to Colorado.

description: On a day when Coach Joe Walton of the Jets said he needed leadership from his veteran players, one of them was shocked to find he had been demoted.

description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday after a session of desultory trading with no significant developments to point toward higher or lower rates.

Comings and Goings
description: Mike McGee, a free agent guard-forward for the Los Angeles Lakers, has agreed to a new contract that will bring him $1.4 million over four years. . . . Richard Todd, the quarterback who is unsigned, was among the holdouts at the New Orleans Saints' training camp yesterday in Ruston, La. . . . Chris Schwenke, the boxer who underwent emergency brain surgery after being knocked out Monday night, remained in critical but stable condition at a hospital in Inglewood, Calif. . . . David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said the Chinese Olympic basketball team had accepted an invitation to come to the United States later this year to train under N.B.A. coaches and participate in scrimmages and possibly some exhibition games against N.B.A. teams.

description: To win a place in the potentially lucrative Mexican computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation agreed to set up a semiconductor development center for local industry, purchase a variety of high-technology components from Mexican companies and produce software for Latin America in Mexico, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: LAWSUIT OVER PROOF OF HOLOCAUST ENDS WITH PAYMENT TO A SURVIVOR
description: A $50,000 reward offered for ''proof'' that the Nazi's gassed Jewish victims in concentration camps must be paid to an Auschwitz survivor under the terms of a court settlement, the survivor's lawyer said today.

title: BAPTIST PASTOR'S ACTIONS SPLIT MAINE COMMUNITY
description: When worshipers kneel to pray in the white clapboard Lee Baptist Church, hard by the high school and across from the general store at the center of this tiny town, the state police and sheriff's deputies cruise back and forth outside and sometimes stop passing cars. The pastor prays for peace and for arrests.

title: Weary Scouts
description: This is a time of year of immense importance in the National Football League, a time when the decisions made in the 28 training camps spread across the nation will help determine which teams stick around come late December. Which helps explain why, after a week at the Giants' camp at Pace University, eight of the club's scouts returned to their homes bleary-eyed early yesterday morning.

title: House Passes Agriculture Bill
description: The House today approved by a wide margin a $33.1 billion agriculture bill for the fiscal year 1986 that basically maintains services at the same level as last year.

title: NABISCO BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1 million for the quarter and the six months from discontinued operations. Results have been restated to reflect the decision to dispose of the company's industrial heating and refrigeration equipment business.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FIRST LOYALTY. By Richard Lourie. 405 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95. YOU know you are reading something unusual when, in the opening scene of Richard Lourie's superior cold-war thriller, ''First Loyalty,'' two Russian work-camp prisoners engaged in polishing television cabinets witness an attack on one fellow inmate by another who uses a sharp pencil as his lethal weapon.

title: The Crowned Heads
description: In the face of an impending players strike - the deadline, as baseball fans know, is Aug. 6 - the crowned heads of baseball admitted Monday that they were slightly off on recent statements about financial losses.

title: RODINO PLAN SEEN AIDING CHANCES OF BILL ON ALIENS
description: The immigration bill that Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, plans to introduce differs markedly from the bill in the Senate.

title: 'We Punish the World'
description: ''Rampant population growth underlies the third world's poverty and poses a major long-term threat to political stability and our planet's resource base.'' That's what Secretary of State Shultz told a Congressional committee two years ago. But Mr. Shultz's boss doesn't share his concern. On the contrary: the Reagan Administration is working hard against the programs that would defuse the population bomb. Only sensible and prompt action by a House-Senate conference can derail this destructive policy.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. There will be competition in cycling, springboard diving, team handball and figure skating, even though the official opening ceremonies will be held tomorrow. Maccabiah Games, at Tel Aviv, final day. Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden seeks his 15th victory of the season against a team he beat, 1-0, last time out. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Phillies vs. Atlanta Braves, at Philadelphia (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Boxing Mark Medal vs. Dexter Smith, junior middleweights, and Robert (PeeWee) Rucker vs. Milton Guest, welterweights, 10-round co-features at Felt Forum. First preliminary 7:30 P.M. This is the first fight for Medal, the former International Boxing Federation junior-middleweight champion, since he lost his title to Carlos Santos last November. He is 23-2 with 20 knockouts; Smith is 24-16-3 with 14 knockouts. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford Open, at Cromwell, Conn., opening round. This was one of the two PGA Tour stops on which Peter Jacobsen posted victories last season. The other was the Colonial Open. Ladies Professional Golf Association du Maurier Classic, at Montreal, opening round. Juli Inkster, a rookie last year, beat Ayako Okamoto by one stroke in this event. The tournament alternates between Montreal and Toronto. Tennis Volvo/New Jersey Championships, at Newark Academy, Livingston, N.J., noon and 7 P.M. United States Clay Court Championships, at Indianapolis.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. SAYS SOUTH AFRICA IS ASKING HIGH-LEVEL TALKS
description: South Africa has proposed holding high-level talks with the United States somewhere in Europe to explain its recent actions and try to end the chill in relations, Reagan Administration officials said today.

Official Quits as Head Of Health Care Agency
description: Carolyne K. Davis, who has headed the Medicare and Medicaid systems throughout four and a half years of budget cuts and program changes, resigned today.

title: INSPECTION SYSTEM
description: HEALTH DEPARTMENT inspectors usually have the power of life and death over restaurants in New York City. While an inspection is not required for a restaurant to open, once it is open inspections are conducted periodically.

title: LONGTIME SUPPORTER OF BALLET
description: Elaine Edelman Felt, a longtime supporter of the ballet and other performing arts in New York City, died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Deal, N.J.

title: PERES SEES BETTER EGYPT TIES
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres has told Israeli officials that there has recently been a marked improvement in relations between Israel and Egypt, according to a source close to the discussions. [Egyptian officials, reached by telephone, denied that there had been any change in Egypt's policy toward Israel.] The source said Mr. Peres had made the statement Tuesday in a review before the parliamentary committee on foreign affairs and security.

Secret Agents?
description: Her State Department escorts were nervous yesterday as they accompanied Lin Jiamei, wife of President Li Xiannian of China, to the Secret Agents Club at the Lab School of Washington, a school for children with learning disabilities. They were obviously afraid Madame Lin might suspect the club was a front for training spies.

RESCUING BALLET FROM MODERN DANCE
description: TWO of American Ballet Theater's most satisfying new productions in recent seasons have been Paul Taylor's ''Airs'' and Merce Cunningham's ''Duets.'' Last year, the company attracted attention with Twyla Tharp's ''Bach Partita'' and this season David Gordon's ''Field, Chair and Mountain'' stirred up controversy.

title: HOME APPLIANCES: COLORS TURN NEUTRAL
description: UNTIL the 1950's, major home appliances were white. Then color entered the kitchen with the introduction of pastels - pink, turquoise and yellow. The pastels were phased out in the 1960's in favor of more subdued colors - avocado, gold and copper - with shaded edging; later those colors were reintroduced as solids without the shading. At the same time, in the 1970's, a light brown called almond was introduced along with the high-tech black glass that is used on oven doors and microwave ovens.

title: Restoration of Funds In Head Research Asked
description: A group representing victims of head injuries urged today that Federal financing of research on such injuries continue despite protests by animal rights activists that such studies are cruel to primates.

CONFEREES AGREE TO RESTORE MONEY FOR ARMS SYSTEMS
description: A House-Senate conference committee tonight approved a compromise military budget that Congressional aides said would restore money for all the 22 weapon systems that either the House or the Senate had voted to kill.

title: JOINT PANEL SAYS REAGAN TAX PLAN WOULD CUT TOTAL REVENUE SLIGHTLY
description: President Reagan's tax revision plan would generate about $25 billion less revenue than the current tax system over the next five years, according to an authoritative Congressional report released tonight.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Editorial Notebook;   The Trials of Treasure Hunting
description: Philip IV of Spain ran a vast defense establishment and a deficit to match. His hopes of relief depended on the annual treasure fleets from Spain's gold and silver mines in the New World. But the fleet of 1622, late in leaving Havana, ran into a hurricane that shattered the heavy treasure galleons on the Florida Keys. The Nuestra Senora de Atocha, laden with 29 tons of silver and 3,500 ounces of gold, foundered on Sept. 6, 1622, with the loss of 143 lives.

title: HOUSE UNIT FINDS MISCONDUCT AT U.S. EMERGENCY AGENCY
description: A House committee unanimously adopted a report today that accused Louis O. Giuffrida of misconduct in directing the nation's disaster relief agency and recommended further investigation by the Justice Department.

description: Given television's preoccupation with ratings, there is little wonder that someone thought it a good idea to appeal to the demographic bulge that is the baby boom generation with a nostalgia-dipped summer series called ''Our Time.''

title: Court Suspends Refractories Offer
description: Belmont Industries, which is controlled by the Philadelphia investor Raymond G. Perelman, said a court in Montgomery, Pa., had issued an order suspending the General Refractories Company's exchange offer for its common stock and requiring Refractories to hold an annual meeting on Sept. 11. The exchange offer was intended to ward off Mr. Perelman by making it more expensive for him to liquidate the Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., company, although he has not said he would do so, The court also stayed all actions taken at a special shareholders meeting Tuesday at which shareholders were said to have voted to oust the current board in favor of a slate led by Mr. Perelman, who says he owns more than 40 percent of Refractories.

title: 'Hello, Mr. President'
description: Senator Byrd, who has experienced his share of Presidential arm-twisting in his long legislative career, offered a typical but imaginary example of it, with the President - ''Democrat or Republican'' -opening the conversation:

title: 3 Companies Approved As Intelsat Competitors
description: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized three American companies to offer limited competition to Intelsat, the nonprofit group of 109 countries that operates the only worldwide satellite communications system.

title: Role Reversal
description: It isn't often that he is shut down by someone a foot and a half shorter, especially when the someone is merely an adolescent, but that is what happened to Akeem Olajuwon at a Manhattan gymnasium yesterday.

TV STATION WINNERS REPORTED
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. has chosen the winning bidders for three remaining television stations that it and the American Broadcasting Companies agreed to sell to accomplish their merger, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Of Politics and Mail
description: The Democratic National Committee has parted company with a direct-mail fund-raising concern that increased the committee's active donor list from 60,000 to nearly 750,000 over the past four years. Democratic officials informed Craver, Mathews, Smith & Company yesterday that the committee would not renew its contract but would transfer the bulk of the operation to its own staff, with outside consultants sharing creative work.

description: b-Including a gain of $737,000 for an accounting change.

title: Spymania and Sparrowhawks
description: Congress has a new species of bird: spar-rowhawks. They are liberal Democrats posing as hawks by shrilly attacking small prey. In full twitter, the sparrowhawk flock has recently helped pass two ill-considered bills, now before a House-Senate conference, in reaction to the alleged spy ring run by former Navy warrant officer John A. Walker Jr. One bill would restore the death penalty for members of the armed services convicted of spying; the other would encourage random lie-detector tests among the 4 million people with security clearances. Both are ineffective, offensive to civil liberties and divert attention from methods that might actually deter espionage.

description: Three Belgian priests were ordered expelled from Haiti today. Among the three was the director of a Roman Catholic radio station that aired charges of fraud against a referendum in favor of Jean-Claude Duvalier's continuing to rule as Presidenct for Life.

title: Comings and Goings

Schwenke underwent brain surgery Tuesday to remove a blood clot. . . . Doug Brown, an administrator for Athletics West, one of the most prominent track clubs in the nation, has been named the head track coach at Tennessee.

description: The slow burning fuse of racism in South Africa is getting shorter. It is hard to determine whether the Reagan Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement'' made the deteriorating situation worse. Certainly, it hasn't made anything better.

description: The Marriott Corporation and Prime Motor Inns Inc. said that they had resumed discussions over a possible takeover of the Howard Johnson Company. In June, Marriott announced that it had broken off talks with the Imperial Group Ltd., the British conglomerate that bought Howard Johnson, the motel and restaurant chain, five years ago for about $600 million. Imperial Group is said to be seeking about $400 million for the chain.

title: FESTIVAL SEEKS OLYMPIC TIE
description: Since its inception in 1978, the National Sports Festival has become the major showcase for America's top amateur athletes during non-Olympic years. Perhaps more important, the festival has played a major role in creating a cohesive American amateur athletic community.

title: SOUTHWESTERN ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: A GOOD-SIZE slice of the city's resident film colony turned up at a party at the Carlyle Wednesday night to celebrate with Matilda Cuomo. Why? Well, in September the Deauville Film Festival will formally celebrate the 100th birthday of the late songwriter Jerome Kern. Jaynne Keyes, Deputy Commissioner of Governor Cuomo's Office for Motion Picture and Television Development, and Ruda Dauphin, United States director of the film festival, were at the door of the Carlyle's small ballroom sipping Champagne. They took turns kissing Bud Yorkin, the producer; Peter Newman, co-producer of ''1918''; Elaine Kaufman; Preston Robert Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation and chairman of the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau; Arlene Dahl, the actress; Ulu Grosbard, the director; the actors Darren McGavin, David Huddleston and Paul Sorvino, and former Mayors Robert F. Wagner and Abraham D. Beame, all of whom came to join Mrs. Cuomo for a cold lobster dinner and a toast to the state's film industry.

title: ON 116TH ST., A WALK-UP IS RECLAIMED
description: After the fire, most of the tenants, scattered to welfare hotels and the already overcrowded residences of friends all over the city, assumed they would never set foot inside their apartments at 80 East 116th Street again.

description: MILLIONS of American moviegoers may be willing to pay $5 (or $6, as the case may be) to see Steven Spielberg's new movie ''Back to the Future,'' but at least one ardent film fan refused to fork over the money.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DEBUT FOR PIANIST Her musicianship has already been hailed in Vienna and Warsaw, in London and Tokyo, but this weekend marks the New York debut of Mitsuko Uchida, a young Japanese pianist who will appear at the Mostly Mozart Festival tonight and tomorrow night. Conducted by David Zinman, the program will feature Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 in C (K. 467), known to some as the ''Elvira Madigan'' concerto; Haydn's Symphony No. 57 in D; Haydn's Cello Concerto in D, performed by Janos Starker; and Bizet's Symphony in C. The concerts will be held at 8 tonight and tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall, but Miss Uchida and Mr. Starker will also give a pre-concert recital from 7 to 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $8 and $13. Information: 874-2424.

title: PRICES CUT MODESTLY BY OPEC
description: OPEC ministers wound up their four-day meeting here by agreeing today to a slight cut in some oil prices. But analysts said the move merely underscores the organization's lack of unity and waning influence. The agreement still leaves OPEC's prices higher than those in today's free market.

title: DUTCH DANCER IN DEBUT
description: Pauline Daniels may look like a mischievous urchin when she appears on stage tonight at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N.Y. Her blue eyes stare boldly, her haircut is punkish, and her gamin's body small, wiry and darting.

title: CHARLES H. COLVIN
description: Charles Herbert Colvin, an aeronautical engineer who was the founder of the Pioneer Instruments Company in Brooklyn, died July 3 at St. Joseph Hospital in Ojai, Calif., after a long illness. He was 92 years old and lived in Ojai. Mr. Colvin, who was born in Sterling, Mass., founded Pioneer Instruments in 1919.

title: Dear Nancy Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan has received an unusual tribute from members of the House for her campaign to combat the use of alcohol and drugs among young people. A letter bearing 61 signatures praises the First Lady for stressing that solutions must be found ''in the family unit'' through ''decreasing the demand for drugs by emphasizing constructive ways to approach life's pressures and problems,'' rather than merely stricter law enforcement.

title: 'Jam War' Proclaimed By Sorrell Ridge

So the four young women wearing brief camouflage fatigues and carrying submachine guns did not look out of place, although Jan Leighton, an actor done up like Gen. George Patton, did.

title: ABUSES BY SALVADORAN GUERRILLAS
description: For several years, human rights groups concerned with El Salvador have focused the great bulk of their attention on abuses by Government forces. Though these forces continue to be responsible for most of the civilian suffering, a recent deterioration in the practices of the guerrillas makes it essential that we speak out more forcefully now to denounce their abuses against non-combatants.

title: Happy Day, McClendon
description: The Texas Breakfast Club, a Capitol Hill social group, yesterday observed the 75th birthday of one of the state's best-known though unelected Washington representatives, Sarah McClendon. Mrs. McClendon, who has represented a group of Texas newspapers in the capital as long as most Lone Star lawmakers can remember, is celebrated for harassing Presidents with persistent questions at their news conferences. (Her birthday was actually July 11, but the observance was said to be well within the Texas statute of limitations.)

title: 8th Audubon Festival Set for Sharon, Conn.

title: An Uncommon Rookie Struts His Stuff
description: He glided down the field, gave the defender a slight shoulder fake to get past him. Then Mel Lattany dug his right shoe into the turf to cut to the inside, but his foot slipped out from under him and he slid to the ground. Looking up in helpless frustration, he watched the ball whiz past.

title: Takeover Bill Rivals See Cuomo
description: Opposing teams of lobbyists - one led by former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York City, the other by Raymond T. Schuler, head of the state Business Council - met separately with Governor Cuomo today over a bill to make takeovers of New York-based corporations more difficult.

title: BINDLEY WESTERN INDUSTRY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1985.

title: Uncourtly Behavior
description: The young man had overstayed his time on the Queens Club court, which was not good form. Then when Sheila Boden, who was waiting to play with a companion, politely reminded him that the court was theirs, his reply seemed positively rude.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.A.W. APPROVAL SEEN ON SATURN PACT
description: The governing board of the United Automobile Workers union is expected to approve a labor agreement Friday that would give a major boost to the General Motors Corporation's Saturn project.

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BILL ON PUBLIC HOUSING GAINS
description: The House voted today to freeze the construction of public housing units next year at current levels, rejecting a committee recommendation to double the construction and pay for the increase with other reductions.

title: BIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Union Leaders at U.P.I. Set Vote on Strike Authorization
description: The executive committee of the union representing most of United Press International's employees in this country voted unanimously yesterday to schedule a membership vote on whether to authorize a strike in the event a bankruptcy judge voided the union's contract.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
PENTAGON OFFICIAL FAULTED ON CONSULTING PLAN
description: A senior Pentagon weapon procurement official came under fire from two members of Congress today for writing to top military contractors soliciting their business for a consulting company she planned to start upon leaving Government.

title: USACAFES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Iran and Iraq Report Increase in Fighting
description: Iran and Iraq reported an increase today in fighting in key sectors of the war front.

title: STEIB, JAYS THWART ANGELS, 7-0
description: Dave Stieb scattered seven hits and Damaso Garcia, Lloyd Moseby and Willie Upshaw each had two hits and two runs batted in tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the California Angels, 7-0.

title: 'KILLER BEES' COLONY IS FOUND AND EXTERMINATED IN CALIFORNIA
description: A colony of about 50 aggressive Africanized honey bees has been found in an oilfield near Lost Hills in Kern County in central California, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. The bees were killed with an aerosol insecticide.

title: GOODEN WINS HIS 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Dwight Gooden, who hasn't lost in two months, pitched the Mets to a 6-3 victory over the Houston Astros last night, ending the Mets' losing streak at three and extending his own winning streak to nine.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival VI, at Baton Rouge, La. Opening ceremonies. Competition began Wednesday. (Television - ESPN, 8 to 11 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 8:30 P.M. This is the first NBC Friday night game of the week. (Television - Channel 4, 8:15 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 8:20 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Murray Sutherland, champion, vs. Bobby Czyz, 12 rounds for the United States Boxing Association Super Middleweight title, at Atlantis Hotel Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 9 P.M. Sutherland (47-11-1 with 38 knockouts) is the former International Boxing Federation super middleweight champion. Czyz, often injured in training, has lost only once in 28 professional fights, to Mustafa Hamsho in November 1982. Czyz, from Wanaque, N.J., has 19 knockouts. (Television - MSG Network, 10 P.M.) Golf Merrill Lynch/Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am, at Newport, R.I., opening round. Roberto DeVicenzo is the defending champion of this 54-hole senior tournament. The first 36 holes are played as a pro-am, then the professionals play the final 18 on their own. Among the competitors are Arnold Palmer, Sam Snead and Billy Casper. Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford Open, at Cromwell, Conn., second round. Ladies PGA DuMaurier Classic, at Montreal, second round. Tennis United States Clay Court Championships, at Indianapolis. Volvo/New Jersey Championships, at Newark Academy, Livingston, N.J., noon and 7 P.M. Men's quarterfinals and women's semifinals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CINEMA OF PARADOX. French Filmmaking Under the German Occupation. By Evelyn Ehrlich. 235 pages. Illustrated. Columbia University Press. $25.

title: British Telecom Rooftop Service
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C., as expected, said yesterday that it would provide rooftop-to-rooftop communications between points in the United States and Britain.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.M. Is Said to Pick Plant Site
description: The General Motors Corporation has selected Spring Hill, Tenn., as the site for its Saturn project, which is to employ 6,000 people, according to published reports.

title: Market Place;   Stock Leaders: Shifting Trend
description: ON Tuesday the stock market suddenly reversed course in a move that some professionals believe symbolizes its changing leadership. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead nearly 10 points in early afternoon, finished at 1,351.81, down 5.83 points.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IF there is a Japanese equivalent to the new American grilleries that have become ubiquitous around town, it is the yakitori bar, in which portions of seafood and meat are brushed with special sauces and seared over charcoal. At Ozeki, a handsome 10-month-old restaurant on West 23d Street, this technique is performed with considerable skill.

title: Marietta Net Climbs 64.6%
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, helped by a one-time pretax gain of $100 million from the sale of a unit, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1985 soared 64.6 percent as sales increased 12.7 percent.

title: BROADWAY
description: SOMETIMES the show doesn't go on quite as scheduled - and everyone has a wonderful time.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chase Said To Hold Talks
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, is negotiating with Maryland officials to acquire a bankrupt savings and loan association in that state, according to banking sources.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AUCTION practices emerged this month as the hottest topic in the art market after the disclosure in court papers that David Bathurst, chairman of Christie's London and New York, had falsely reported the sale of three Impressionist paintings in New York in 1981, when in fact only one had been purchased. Mr. Bathurst, who was president of Christie's in New York when the auction took place, resigned as Christie's chairman last week.

title: KOCH NAMES A TASK FORCE TO LEAD THE DRIVE FOR WATER CONSERVATION
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named a task force of 169 business and civic leaders to encourage residents to conserve water, particularly at home.

title: SHOULD THE U.S. IMPOSE A TARIFF ON IMPORTED OIL?
description: Congressional budget writers, frustrated in their attempt to cut the Federal deficit, suddenly seized this week an idea that has been the subject of years of largely desultory discussion: a stiff special tariff on oil imports.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The South African Government must move away promptly from apartheid, which we find to be repugnant and which is a basic cause of the violence South Africa is witnessing today.

title: SCIENTIFIC MICRO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WALL ST. LAWYER WINS BACKING FOR U.S. JUDGE
description: A lawyer with a Wall Street firm, Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, was formally recommended yesterday for appointment as a Federal district judge.

title: Dry Witticism
description: Bob Lowry had to explain the local custom when he asked for water during lunch in the Museum of Modern Art dining room.

title: JOB OUTPUT RATE POSTS 0.5% GAIN
description: Business productivity in this year's second quarter rose at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, a turnaround from a decline in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Marino Out of Camp
description: Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins said yesterday he would not return to training camp until he has signed a new contract, which he said Joe Robbie, the Dolphins' owner, promised him last January.

title: AUSTRIA TO LIST ART SOLD BY NAZIS
description: The Austrian Government said yesterday that it would publish a list of 3,900 paintings, sculptures and art objects confiscated from Jews by the Nazis during World War II and that it would encourage owners and rightful heirs to claim them.

title: House Approves New Status For 2 Pacific Island Nations
description: Micronesia and the Marshall Islands in the Pacific would gain an independent status but rely on the United States for defense under a measure approved by the House of Representatives today, 360 to 12.

title: Rucker Defeats Guest on Decision
description: Robert (Pee Wee) Rucker, in perhaps the finest performance of his professional career, knocked down the former welterweight contender, Milton Guest of Mount Vernon, in the fifth round and went on to a unanimous 10-round decision last night at the Felt Forum.

title: BYSTROM BACK AND OPTIMISTIC
description: The sound of Marty Bystrom's voice is full of predictable optimism, perhaps because he has endured so many personal setbacks and so many annoying injuries that he has convinced himself they are all finally over.

title: $4.8 Billion Money Supply Fall
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply plunged $4.8 billion in the week ended July 15, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The decline was nearly double what economists had expected, although the credit markets reacted with uncharacteristic apathy.

title: French Tourist Office Picks Intermarco
description: Intermarco Advertising, New York, part of the Publicis Group of Paris, has been named agency for the French Government Tourist Office and the assignment will include promoting the French West Indies.

title: HOUSE PANEL WOULD EXPAND WELFARE
description: A key House committee has voted to bring thousands of additional people into the nation's main welfare program by making all needy two-parent families eligible for benefits.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $10,900,000 from the sale of shares of CB Pak Inc. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: A Fairness Question on Rev. Moon
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro is shown with her hand in what could be a cookie jar. Vice President Bush has one hand over his heart and the other holding a piece of paper labeled ''blind trust.'' A man in buttoned-down shirt represents the stock brokerage concern, E. F. Hutton. The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder of the Unification Church, is shown holding a Bible.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no share earnings for the latest periods because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.
