description: b-Including a gain of $6,830,000 from the sale of a subsidiary, income from discontinued operations of $1,848,000 and an extraordinary gain of $676,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $370,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Teamsters Strike Companies Delivering Autos to Dealers
description: About 20,000 drivers, maintenance workers and warehouse employees, members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, went on strike today against trucking companies that transport automobiles to dealerships.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 26, 1985
description: International

title: Lambert Stock Is Off $4.25
description: The Warner-Lambert Company's stock dropped $4.25, to $39.50, in heavy trading as Wall Street reacted with disappointment to a progress report on the company's heart drug, Lopid. With 3 million shares changing hands, it was the second-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Baltic Emigres in Protest
description: Hundreds of Baltic emigres demonstrated outside the Soviet Embassy here today to protest the Soviet annexation of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania 45 years ago. The demonstration took place as the Baltic World Conference, a Washington emigre group, opened a two-day meeting here to draw attention to developments in the Soviet Baltic republics.

title: Officer at Hughes Tool Also Given Chief's Title
description: The Hughes Tool Company, a leading maker of oil drilling equipment, has appointed its president, W. A. Kistler Jr., to the additional post of chief executive, effective Aug. 1. He succeeds J. R. Lesch, who remains chairman of the board and of the executive committee.

title: MCDOWELL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
COURT IS ASSAILED ON OVERTIME ISSUE
description: Governors and other public officials, predicting severe financial dislocation as a result of a Supreme Court decision five months ago, pressed Congress today to exempt public employees from coverage of Federal wage and hour standards.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.N. CHIEF IN HOSPITAL WITH ABDOMINAL PAINS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has been hospitalized with abdominal pains and is undergoing tests for inflammation of the colon, a spokesman said today.

RICHARDSON ELECRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GEORGIA U. COACH BARS SENATE RACE
description: To the dismay of state Democrats and the delight of Georgia Bulldog fans, Vincent J. Dooley, the popular University of Georgia coach, declared today that he would not quit football to become a candidate for the United States Senate.

title: THE JAPANESE SURGE IN U.S.
description: This week's announcement by the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan that it would build an automobile factory in the United States marks the development of an important new phase in the often turbulent economic relations between the two countries, according to Japanese officials and economists here.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a pre-tax charge of $5,200,000 from the settlement of litigation.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Economic Scene;   How to Soften Dollar Landing
description: HOW can a crash landing for the dollar -which might regenerate inflation, send interest rates soaring and plunge the United States and other countries into a recession - be prevented?

title: CIVIL RIGHTS CHIEF QUESTIONS COMMISSION'S FUTURE
description: Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said today that it might make sense to abolish the commission when it comes up for Congressional reauthorization in 1989.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $140,000. c-Operating earnings.

Perez Returning
description: The Atlanta Braves and their wandering pitcher, Pascual Perez, finally got back together yesterday. Perez met for 90 minutes with John Mullen, the club's general manager, and the two decided Perez will rejoin the team Tuesday, when they start a home series against San Diego.

title: COMPETITION THREATENING U.S. LEAD IN SPACE
description: Competition in launching spacecraft is spreading worldwide, beyond the United States and the Soviet Union, as other nations and several private companies seek to stake a claim in what is being viewed as possibly the next economic frontier.

title: Parallels to U.S. View
description: The Soviet statements today on research into space-based defense systems appear to parallel some points that the United States has been making in the Geneva talks, according to American accounts.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Killed as Plane Explodes
description: A single-engine airplane exploded in the air and crashed south of a small airport today, killing three people and scattering wreckage over an area of one square mile, the authorities said. Identities of the victims and the origin and destination of the plane were being withheld pending notification of relatives. Sheriff Jerry Russell of Canadian County said wreckage was scattered over about one square mile.

title: HOUSE-SENATE CONFERENCE APPROVES RESTRICTED AID TO REBELS
description: Senate and House negotiators early this morning approved a $25.4 billion compromise foreign aid bill that would provide nonmilitary aid for the insurgents fighting the Nicaraguan Government but would bar the Central Intelligence Agency or the Defense Department from distributing it.

title: Apple Officer's Lesser Role
description: Apple Computer Inc.'s co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, will have no role in the operations of the company ''now or in the future,'' Apple's president and chief executive, John Sculley, said at a meeting for securities analysts Wednesday.

title: On the Air
description: The National Hockey League yesterday signed a new three-year exclusive agreement with ESPN to televise 33 regular-season games nationally and some playoff games beginning with the coming season. No money figure given for the pact announced jointly by John Ziegler, president of the N.H.L., and J. William Grimes, the head of ESPN, but the network apparently outbid the USA Network, which had been carrying N.H.L. games for the past three years, first on a two-year deal and then on a one-year pact reportedly worth $4 million.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a pre-tax charge of $30,000,000 for the quarter and the six months.

title: President Resigns At News America
description: Donald D. Kummerfeld, president and chief operating officer of News America Publishing Inc., Rupert Murdoch's American holding company, has resigned.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF BROOKSVILLE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARCHITECTS DEBATE PLAN FOR WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: The subject was a building, and the speakers were the architect, a few dozen colleagues, a museum director, a college professor and an angry student in black suspenders.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Wednesday of Dr. Richard M. Emberson, a former executive director of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, listed his survivors incompletely. They include his wife, Virginia.

title: EDGCOMB STEEL OF NEW ENGLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Edgcomb Metals Co., acquired in June 1984. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split paid July 19.

title: NEW SENATE BUDGET PLAN PROPOSES OIL IMPORT FEE
description: For the first time, the Senate Republican leadership today proposed tax increases, including a new $5-a-barrel fee on imported oil, in a sweeping effort to break the budget impasse with the House.

title: TURK IS ON TRIAL OVER ISLAM AND SEX
description: A prominent Turkish Moslem clergyman went on trial in Istanbul today on a charge of ''advocating a return to Islamic practices in social life'' in publishing a best-selling book, ''Sexual Life According to Islam.''

title: MORRIS TESTS LIMITS OF IMPROVISATION
description: THE composer-cornetist-conductor Lawrence (Butch) Morris didn't set out to make categories obsolete. He just happens to be writing and performing pieces that extend jazz toward classical ''new music'' and new music into improvisation, and that make structure itself one more mutable element in a performance. Yet for all his experiments with form, Mr. Morris still writes melodies that leave audiences humming along, and he encourages his musicians to swing.

title: We Have to Find Domestic Fuel Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: RADIOS RESTRICTED AT SHEEP MEADOW AND 4 BEACHES
description: No more blaring radios at the Central Park Sheep Meadow or on small stretches of four city beaches.

title: Effects of 'Dog Days'
description: ''Sirius Summer,'' a free program on the effects of the ''dog days'' of summer on animals and plants, will be offered Sunday at 2 P.M. at Washington's Headquarters Museum, Virginia Road, North White Plains, N.Y. The program is named for the dog star constellation.

title: FEDERAL GRAND JURY BEGINS TO INVESTIGATE T.W.A. HIJACKINGS
description: A Federal grand jury here has begun investigating the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet last month, according to Justice Department officials. The grand jury, according to the officials, will view videotapes of the hijacking taken by the television networks and will hear testimony from some of the hostages.

title: 2 More Banks Fail in Kansas
description: Two more Kansas banks were shut down today by state and Federal regulators, bringing to 63 the number of failed banks so far this year, including eight in Kansas. But unlike other banks in Kansas and other grain-growing states, neither failed because of bad agricultural loans.

title: SCREEN: BABENCO'S 'KISS OF THE SPIDER WOMAN'
description: ''KISS OF THE SPIDER WOMAN'' begins with a theatrical-sounding homosexual describing the plot of an old movie (''her petite ankle slips into the perfumed water'') for the benefit of his prison cellmate, a political radical. There is nothing in this seemingly frivolous, beautifully staged opening to betray the film's tremendous reserves of seriousness and passion. Nor are there sufficient clues in the previous film careers of the director, Hector Babenco (the highly praised ''Pixote''), or the two stars, William Hurt and Raul Julia, to anticipate the stature of the work they do here. ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' is a brilliant achievement for all of them, staged with the perfect control and fierce originality that make it one of the best films in a long while.

title: ART: 'FLYING TIGERS,' SHOW IN SOUTHHAMPTON
description: AS of early 1942, there was a group of American volunteer fliers who, though outnumbered 10 to 1, did their best to defend Burma and Southeast China against the Japanese. They were experienced pilots who, according to Life magazine, had been ''bloodied'' in the air and were ''always looking for a fight.'' Operating with aircraft that had been rejected by the military as both flawed and obsolete, they had insignia designed for them by Walt Disney and were altogether a stalwart bunch of men.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Change Rejected in Aliens Bill
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today turned back an attempt to expand a proposed amnesty program for illegal aliens.

title: U.S. JUDGE BARS RELIGIOUS ISSUE IN ALIENS CASE
description: Church workers facing trial may not use religious arguments to justify transporting and sheltering Central American refugees in defiance of the immigration laws, a Federal judge ruled in an opinion filed here today.

title: Marsalis Quintet
description: The trumpeter Wynton Marsalis is leading a quintet tonight at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12.50 cover and a $6 minumum.

title: JETS WAIVE FULLBACK
description: Mike Augustyniak knew today's sentence from the Jets' physicians -that his football career was over -was a formality, that his football career had really ended months ago after knee surgery.

title: Colleges Are Warned About Measles Threat
description: Federal health officials today called for prompt action to combat measles epidemics on college campuses in light of 334 cases and three deaths at 25 universities this year.

title: STATE JUDGE IN QUEENS IS ACCUSED OF ACCEPTING BRIBES TO FIX CASES
description: Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of taking bribes totaling $47,000 to fix four criminal cases that came before him.

title: Jury Rules for Blacks Rejected by Restaurant
description: A Federal jury found today that the owners of a Virginia restaurant had turned away three black women because of their race. The jury awarded the women $1,503 in damages.

title: FILM: 'THOUSAND KISSES' ABOUT AN ISARELI MOTHER
description: CAN it be that all those jokes about the Jewish mother who makes an art of public suffering in order to keep her hold on her children have yet to reach Israel? (You've heard the punchlines: ''Never mind me, darling. I'll just sit here in the dark.'') At any rate, the joke does not seem to have reached Mira Recanati, the Israeli director and writer of ''A Thousand Little Kisses,'' which opens today at Film Forum II. She has chosen as her first feature film the story of a Tel Aviv mother named Ruta who decides to starve herself to keep her daughter, Alma, from leaving the nest.

description: Oil prices continued firm in the world market and oil company shares advanced broadly yesterday in the aftermath of the modest price cut by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

description: The handful of revolutionaries on this French island, who feel that Guadeloupe should become independent like most other Caribbean islands, have got their work cut out for them.

description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $1.46 billion, to $210.78 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

description: AS the result of the changes in status of the Sunday supplement Family Weekly, Parade magazine has picked up an additional 145 newspaper customers, bringing its total carrier force to 268 with a collective circulation of 29.8 million. You want reach? That's reach.

title: Country Boy Runs Home
description: They would go over to quaint Crosley Field, father and son, and root for the Reds against all comers, but when the St. Louis Cardinals came to town, the father would turn to the son and say: Watch the old guy in right field. I want you to play like him.

title: Feeling Better
description: Elsewhere within the Yankee family, the news is not so bright. Mickey Mantle's wife, Merlyn, suffered a stroke Tuesday and was admitted to St. Paul's Hospital in Dallas, from which she reported yesterday, ''I'm feeling a little better now, except for a headache.''

title: AIR PRODUCTS AND CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK'S OFFBEAT MUSEUMS
description: EPENDING on who does the counting, somewhere between 150 and 200 institutions call themselves museums in New York City. Some are mammoth, world-famous temples of culture like the Metropolitan or the American Museum of Natural History, where crowds jostle for the best view of a Botticelli or a brontosaurus. Most, however, are small, specialized and relatively little known. From turn-of-the-century subway cars or 2,700-year-old coins to Paul Robeson's costume in ''The Emperor Jones'' or a $21,000 toy boat, almost everything imaginable - and quite a few unimaginable things - can be found in these quirky little museums that are off the beaten track.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A SPORTY new wine bar has taken root on Columbus Avenue at 85th Street with the straightforward name of Grapes. The eccentric decor features white walls with jagged holes and crevices that expose the brick underneath; on several of the white sections color slides of fireworks and cityscapes are projected.

title: APPLIED COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $221,337, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of the company's United Kingdom subsidiary.

title: TRICO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tom Williams Is Dead at 99; Was World War I Flying Ace
description: Tom Williams, a World War I flying ace who was a founding member of the Royal Canadian Air Force, died in a hospital here today. He was 99 years old.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERIES OF VIDEOS BY AND ABOUT BLACKS
description: Yoruba ceremonies, Latin American and reggae music, race relations and teen-age suicide are the subjects of five videos to be shown today through Tuesday in a series of ''Dialogues With Black Videomakers.''

title: DYNATEC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to April 30
SECURITY COUNSIL CONSIDERING A RESOLUTION ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Security Council met Thursday at the request of France to consider a resolution calling on South Africa to repeal its five-day-old emergency decree.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,500,000 for the quarter and the nine months. c-Net income.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $411,000 for the quarter and $1,274,000 for the six months and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,523,000 for the quarter and the six months. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $506,000 for the quarter and $1,344,000 for the six months.

title: MUSIC: STRAUSS OPERA, IN SANTA FE
description: Aside from Offenbach's ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' and Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' the venturesome Santa Fe Opera's 1985 season is devoted entirely to the 20th century. There is a revival, with the same basic cast, of Richard Strauss's ''Liebe der Danae,'' which received its first professional American staging here in 1982. There is the American premiere of Hans Werner Henze's opera of 1983, ''The English Cat.'' And there is the world premiere of John Eaton's ''Tempest.'' Not bad, for the wild West - or for the unfortunately not quite so wild East, either.

title: THE USUAL SUSPECTS
description: When politicians don't know what to do about complicated problems - terrorism, say, or espionage - they have at least three panaceas to fall back on: Cracking down on the press, tightening ''security'' laws and making outraged speeches.

title: RUSSIAN AMPLIFIES DEMAND ON SPACE-DEFENSE RESEARCH
description: A Soviet arms negotiator appeared to draw a distinction today between pure scientific research into space-based defense weapons and more purposeful work leading to development of weapon components.

title: Astronomy Lecture
description: All the sky will be a stage for a free lecture and discussion sponsored by the Amateur Astronomers Association tomorrow from 7 to 10 P.M. at Great Kills Park, off Hylan Boulevard in the Great Kills section of Staten Island.

title: Gamblers Sale A Prime Issue
description: Talk continued yesterday in United States Football League circles that the Generals and the Houston Gamblers might merge. More important to Harry Usher, the league commissioner, is finding a buyer for the Gamblers so that the club's players get paid.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DANCING AND DISSENSION
description: Although 10,000 women came here for the United Nations world conference ending the Decade for Women and for Forum '85, the concurrent meeting of nongovernmental organizations, the women were not the only ones who enjoyed themselves.

title: Afghan Rebels Report Air Strike by Soviet
description: Guerrillas said today that Soviet air strikes in Afghanistan this month killed 23 civilians.

title: STAGE: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM'
description: THE time is the early 1960's, and the setting is a typical American high school. The principal is uptight, but the students are flexing their freedom. Offstage we hear a chorus of ''Chapel of Love,'' followed, in the course of the evening, by a jukebox reprise of other songs of the period. The show is not ''Leader of the Pack,'' but ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' as adapted to almost modern times by the director, Stephen Zuckerman.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Investment Firm To Buy Clevepak
description: The Clevepak Corporation, a producer of industrial supplies and equipment based in Purchase, N.Y., said it had agreed to be sold to Andlinger & Company for $15 a common share, or a total of more than $90 million, including cash and notes for preffered shares.

title: ANDAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $135,000 for the quarter and $290,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $545,000 for the quarter and $677,000 for the six months.

title: Court-Packing, Reagan-Style
description: President Reagan has long said he admires Franklin D. Roosevelt. Now he's repeating Mr. Roosevelt's worst mistake, and realizing the fears of his own critics, by threatening to pack the Federal courts with judges committed to a narrow ideological agenda.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THRIFT UNIT SHUT DOWN ON COAST
description: Federal regulators closed another large insolvent savings and loan association today, citing the institution's excessive growth in recent years through bad lending practices and direct investments in high-risk ventures.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CNA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCREEN: 'THE HEAVENLY KID' OPEN
description: GUARDIAN angel movies almost always have a little charm, but ''The Heavenly Kid'' has none. What it does have is a hero named Bobby (Lewis Smith), who dies in a car crash and returns 20 years later to befriend an awkward teen-age boy named Lenny (Jason Gedrick). The car crash is supposed to take place in the early 1960's, though the actors look old and the costumes are a mid-50's anachronism. Bobby is supposed to be a very cool guy, but Mr. Smith looks ill at ease in his black leather jacket and gives a gawky, colorless performance in the film's biggest role.

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
EXECUTIVES CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. has named as a director George V. Grune, chairman and chief executive of the Reader's Digest Association.

title: SPELLING AND COST, DIVIDE 2 RAMAPO DEVELOPMENTS
description: A six-foot-tall chain-link fence snakes across 52 acres of formerly wooded hills in this Rockland County community, marking a clear boundary between Ramapo and Ramapough.

title: EG & G INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,000,000 from Domestic International Sale Corp. benefits.

title: CERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.B.I. ALTERS POLICY TO PROTECT THOSE NAMED IN DOCUMENTS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has adopted new procedures to protect the privacy of individuals named in the agency's internal documents.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 26, 1985
description: The Economy

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ashton-Tate, Culver City, Calif., said it had signed an agreement with the McGraw-Hill Book Co. covering distribution of Ashton-Tate's line of computer-related books and disk packages.

title: 90-BED HOSPITAL IS ORDERED SHUT BY HEALTH DEPT.
description: The State Health Department today ordered a hospital here to close immediately and to transfer its patients, citing a number of violations of the state's hospital code.

title: BECKER REVEALING MORE OF HIS GAME
description: Boris Becker revealed a lot about himself this week. He said he likes rock music, especially by Foreigner and The Police, but he doesn't like hamburgers or the nickname Boom-Boom.

title: EGON SCHIELE: THE DRAFTSMAN AS PAINTER
description: ONE of the most exciting draftsmen in the history of art was the Austrian Expressionist Egon Schiele (1890-1918), whose early death ended a career just beginning to take off. And his paintings - or at least the 17 of them on view at the Serge Sabarsky Gallery, 987 Madison Avenue (through Sept. 14) - only serve to remind us of his stunning graphic gifts. At drawing he was, purely and simply, a genius; at painting he was more ordinary. The nervous, intense vitality of his line took primacy over everything else.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Tuesday about an interview with the director of the National Park Service gave an incorrect name for a private group that is working with the service. It is the National Parks and Conservation Association.

title: OWNERS' PROPOSAL IRKS BASEBALL UNION
description: Chances of averting a baseball strike Aug. 6, already remote, seemed to diminish even further yesterday when the owners' negotiators resubmitted a salary arbitration proposal that the union chief said was designed to anger the players and further frustrate efforts to reach an agreement.

title: Bridge: Small Step by the Declarer Can Bring a Large Reward
description: A declarer who looks for a small improvement in his chances can sometimes reap a big bonanza. An example is the diagramed deal, from the recent Goldman Pairs final in Hempstead, L.I.

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXAS ESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILLCOX & GIBBS, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,243,000 for the quarter and $2,474,000 for the six months. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,229,000 for the quarter and $2,420,000 for the year ago six months.

title: ROCK GOES BACK TO THE FUTURE
description: ''BACK TO THE FUTURE'' happens to be one of the summer's hottest movies. But the title of the film, in which a teen-ager of the 1980's travels back in time to the mid-50's, could just as well describe the pop musical mood of the summer of '85 - nostalgic and escapist. A decade ago - in the post-countercultural climate of the 70's - the divisions between what seemed ''old'' and ''new'' in pop music seemed relatively clear. But those divisions have blurred, and today, acts that 10 years ago might have been dismissed as ''oldies'' continue to command a youthful reverence that once upon a time would have been more elusive.

title: FILM: 'AFTER THE FALL'
description: IT would be hard to imagine a bigger waste of time than ''After the Fall of New York,'' a cheap, grisly action film masquerading as a futuristic fantasy. Even by bargain-basement sci-fi standards, this Italian-French co-production, which opens today at the R.K.O. Warner Twin and other theaters, is mindless and unsightly.

title: 4 TROOPERS IN JERSEY INDICTED IN THE DEATH OF PRISONER IN 1982
description: Four state policemen were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with the 1982 death, in police custody, of a man arrested for drunken driving on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: WITCO CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Minow Doubts On Turner Bid
description: Newton N. Minow, a CBS Inc. board member and a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told a Federal judge today that he considered Ted Turner's buyout offer for CBS ''dead on arrival.''

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Interpublic Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday became the third publicly held advertising company to announce its second-quarter earnings and the first able to announce that they had improved. Net income was up 3.7 percent from the second quarter of 1984, to $15.3 million from $14.7 million, or $1.40 a share, compared with $1.36. Revenues were $180.7 million, up 6.6 percent from $169.5 million.

title: NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $803,000 for the quarter and $1,809,000 for the 6 months.

title: Mechanics Fixed, Pitcher in Gear
description: Dody Rather's first year in professional baseball was something that Dody would rather not dwell on. But the second year, in contrast, has really been a matter to crow about.

ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SIKH MILITANTS REJECT ACCORD
description: An agreement between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Sikh leaders was rejected by two militant Sikh groups today, and two moderate leaders were reported to have called the pact a betrayal of Sikh interests.

title: CRADDOCK-TERRY SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $279,000 for the quarter and $1,371,000 for the nine months. c-After a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $650,000.

title: Magazine Change
description: Madison Avenue magazine, one of the advertising trade publications of lesser importance, is being completely redone under Jack Scott, the new publisher; John Chervokas, the new editor in chief, and Suren Ermoyen, the new art director. And to accommodate all of Mr. Ermoyen's graphic innovations, the monthly, beginning with the September issue, is going to giant size, 11 by 14 inches, the size of Advertising Age.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains from $65,000 for the quarter and $49,719,000, or $1.25 a share, on the sale of an aircraft. c-Including gains of $14,067,000 for the quarter and $68,252,000 for the year from the sale of an aircraft.

title: NICARAGUA REBEL SAID TO BE SAFE
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader whose helicopter was reported to have crashed, is injured and exhausted, and is recovering at a camp in the jungles of southern Nicaragua, a leader of his rebel group said today.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ACCORD IS REACHED ON AID TO INFANTS
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops and officials of the Americn Jewish Congress, who have taken opposite positions on abortion rights, announced an agreement yesterday on principles for the treatment of infants with severe disabilities.

title: Intel Settles U.S. Claims
description: The Justice Department said today that it had reached an agreement to recover $560,000 from the Intel Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., for providing false or misleading pricing data to obtain Federal contracts for computer software.

title: Fiber Optic System Halted by Sponsors
description: One of the largest and most ambitious attempts to build a nationwide fiber optic communications system was suspended yesterday after the sponsors concluded they had too few customers to begin construction. It was not clear whether the project would be resumed.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the year-ago periods do not include an extraordinary credit of $4,357,000, or 50 cents a share, relating to litigation provision adjustment previously reported in the second quarter of 1984. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

Dow Musters Gain, But Market Mixed
description: Technology stocks teamed up with the oils to break a three-day slide on Wall Street, but the market only managed a mixed performance as secondary issues remained weak.

title: WITNESS SAYS STEWART WAS CALM AFTER ARREST
description: The token clerk on duty at the subway station where Michael Stewart was arrested in the early morning hours of Sept. 15, 1983, testified yesterday that the Brooklyn man did not flee up the stairs at a hectic pace and did not appear intoxicated.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CIRCADIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $226,000 for the quarter and $481,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $64,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $276,000 for the year.

title: SCREEN: DISNEY'S 'BLACK CAULDRON'
description: THE black cauldron that gives a title to the latest Walt Disney animated feature contains the spirits of dead warriors, and the movie, which opens today at Radio City Music Hall, tells of the exertions of a boy named Taran to keep the cauldron from the evil horned king, lest he bring those ''deathless warriors'' to life and conquer the world. The tale is based on ''The Chronicles of Prydain,'' a series of books for youngsters by Lloyd Alexander that won critical and popular attention in the mid-1960's.

title: COMEDIAN AND MOVIE ACTOR
description: Mickey Shaughnessy, a barrel-chested, pug-faced comedian who appeared in 41 movies, including ''From Here to Eternity,'' died of heart failure Tuesday in Cape May Courthouse, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Wildwood, N.J.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $31,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ex-Official's 'Surprise': Marijuana on His Farm
description: Leo O'Brien, a former Vermont Agriculture Commissioner, said today that hundreds of marijuana plants on his land were ''weeds that had grown wild'' for years behind his barn.

title: The Presidency;   Mastering the Art of Legislative Persuasion
description: President Reagan was on the telephone again, and Senator Robert C. Byrd was not amused. Mr. Reagan was telephoning senators in an effort to break a filibuster against a bill that would expand the President's veto authority, which was opposed by Mr. Byrd.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Japan Air, Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said Japan Air Lines had ordered its fourth 747-300 jumbo jetliner and had signed a letter of intent to buy four additional planes. Jack Gamble, bureau director for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company's Pacific-Asia division, said the 747 is to be delivered in April 1986.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPEND A BUCK SET FOR CREME FRAICHE
description: In the Jersey Derby two months ago, Spend a Buck was 1-to-20 and Creme Fraiche was 20-to-1. Spend a Buck won, but the morning line for their rematch in tomorrow's Haskell Invitational Handicap at Monmouth Park has them closely matched, Spend a Buck at 7-to-5 and Creme Fraiche 9-to-5.

title: Croquet Tournament In Columbia County
description: A croquet tournament will be held tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. at the Clermont State Historic Site on the Hudson River at Clermont in Columbia County.

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIEDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIANT YELOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Revenue figures were not available.

title: TWO NEW MOVIES ON CABLE, 'MURDER IN SPACE' AND 'BLACKOUT'
description: THE only new television movies in town this week are on pay-cable, and both are having their premieres Sunday at 8 P.M. Showtime has ''Murder in Space,'' a spaceship mystery with a gimmick, and Home Box Office is offering ''Blackout,'' a thriller starring Richard Widmark as a former policeman with an obsession. Neither effort is remotely memorable, but the obsession easily wins out over the gimmick.

title: JET IS STILL HELD AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: The red and white Trans World Airlines jet that was hijacked last month is still parked at a far corner of the runway here, and a Shiite Moslem leader says that until the United States drops its retaliatory efforts to ''isolate'' the Beirut airport, the $15 million aircraft will stay where it is.

title: California Court Rules In TV Pirates' Favor
description: The California Supreme Court ruled today that pay television pirates can keep selling equipment to pick up uncoded microwave signals.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SYSTEM INERGRATORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Happy Day, McLellan
description: Diana McLellan, the acknowledged grande dame of Washington gossip columnists, is going straight.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $358,000.

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2 percent stock dividend distributed Febuary 1985.

title: DISPUTES ON KEY ISSUES STALL KENYA PARLEY
description: Negotiations on the key document of the United Nations Decade for Women conference broke down today, leaving virtually no hope that the conference would end Friday with a universally acceptable document.

title: Emerging in India: More Than Peace
description: When Rajiv Gandhi was catapulted to the leadership of the world's largest democracy by his mother's assassination last year, he was inexperienced and untested. His spectacular triumph in the election soon after owed more to sympathy for his martyred mother than to any achievement of his own. The success of his recent trips to Moscow and Washington was, likewise, discounted as deriving from his youth and charm.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $687,000 for the quarter and $2,115,000 for the 6 months from the sale of property.

U.S. OFFICIALS BID SOUTH AFRICA OPEN TALK WITH BLACKS
description: The United States today urged talks between the white Government and the black leadership in South Africa as American officials voiced concern about the deteriorating situation there.

title: RIVERSIDE TROUPE'S 'SHREW' BEGINS PARK TOUR
description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company opens its ninth Summer Parks Tour tonight with what the director Maureen Clarke describes as ''sweaty Shakespeare.''

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.Year-ago revenue figures have been restated.

title: The Man on the Spot in New York's '75 Crisis
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Including capital gains of $847,198 for the quarter and $669,036 for the six months. c-After a capital loss of $60,159 for the quarter and including a capital gain of $219,473 for the six months.

title: CALIFORNIA FARMS REELING, TOO
description: From grapes and almonds, to cotton and rice, farmers in California have long had more options to make money than farmers in other parts of the country.

title: E.S.M. Auditor Is Penalized
description: Alexander Grant & Company, the accounting firm that audited the collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., was prohibited today from accepting any new business in Florida for 60 days.

title: MINE KILLS 61 ON TRAIN IN BURMA
description: The official Burmese press agency said today that 61 passengers had been killed and 112 wounded when rebels set off a land mine under a passing train 146 miles north of here.

title: GIANTS' GODFREY SUFFERS A SPRAIN
description: The Giants' offensive line, which has had enough problems, suffered another dent today. It could have been worse.

title: ART: JAPANESE FOLK WORKS ON DISPLAY AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: IN the beginning, Japan made no distinction between art and craft. Then along came Commodore Perry and, in his wake, all manner of Western blessings, including the notion of the artist as a unique, inspired being who produced only ''fine'' art. Nevertheless, it took an additional 70 or so years for folk art to be viewed as a separate entity warranting its own name, mingei. This was coined by Yanagi Soetsu (1889-1961), who was Japan's counterpart of William Morris and the founder of its Arts and Crafts Movement - made necessary, of course, by the havoc Westernization had wreaked.

title: Trade Bill Talks Begin
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, opened negotiations with the Democrats today to limit debate and amendments for a Senate Finance Committee bill that would require the President to take action to curtail imports from Japan.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $159,373 for the quarter and $159,373 for the year ago six months from discontinued operations.

title: Smart Kids, Too, Need Time to Be Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR'S APPOINTEE SAID LEASE IN ALASKA WAS PAYOFF, AIDE SAYS
description: A state official says that he was told by one of Gov. Bill Sheffield's Cabinet officers that a Fairbanks office lease the Governor's staff was pushing represented a political payoff.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: S.I. GRAND JURY TO HEAR CASE INVOLVING BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: The Staten Island District Attorney said yesterday that a grand jury would investigate charges that Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti used his office when he was deputy borough president to help a business partner.

title: Lyle Stays Home
description: Sandy Lyle of Scotland, the British Open champion, has turned down an invitation to play in the P.G.A. Championship in Denver, Aug. 8-11, choosing to compete in the Glasgow Open. Apart from the prestige, the P.G.A. carries five times the prize money offered at the Scottish event.

title: Ex-Packer Returns
description: Mike Butler is happy to be heading back to the Green Bay Packers after two seasons in the United States Football League. The Tampa Bay Bandits have released the defensive end from the final two years of a $1.2 million contract he signed in 1984.

title: American Ticket Change
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would match most of the fares announced Wednesday by United Airlines, which said it would begin basing its ticket prices on mileage traveled. Both airlines will offer reductions of 45 percent below coach fares on tickets bought 14 days in advance.

title: BY ANY OTHER NAME, CONSERVATIVE
description: ''We're like a fish in water. We're in our environment.''

title: PART OF AIDS VIRUS PRODUCED
description: A key gene from a virus linked to acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has been inserted into bacteria to produce a protein that may serve as an accurate diagnostic test and perhaps eventually as a vaccine for the deadly disease, researchers say.

title: Festival Opens
description: A cheering crowd of 50,000 in Baton Rouge staged a massive celebration of Louisiana and the state's governor, Edwin Edwards, declared the sixth National Sports Festival officially opened last night.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

Minor Issues Are Cleared
description: In an atmosphere more conciliatory than the one that prevailed 24 hours earlier, baseball's labor negotiators reached or neared agreement yesterday on approximately 20 issues they described as minor and mostly noneconomic. The owners' negotiators also made new proposals on another 20 minor issues.

title: NEW ZEALAND SEEKING 3 IN GREENPEACE BOMBING
description: The police issued warrants today for three crew members of a French-registered yacht believed to be somewhere in the Pacific after having left Auckland the day before the Greenpeace flagship was bombed.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $1.7 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $27.6 million from disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $4.4 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $25.9million from the disposal of discontinued opreations.

title: A WHITE HOUSE DEPARTURE
description: The official announcement has not been made, but Roger B. Porter, a deputy assistant to the President for economic affairs, will be leaving the White House this summer to become a professor of business and government at Harvard University. Mr. Porter is expected to continue as a special White House consultant. His successor as director of the Office of Policy Development and executive secretary of the Economic Policy Council has not been named.

title: AIDE SAYS PRESSER WAS TIED TO F.B.I.
description: The Justice Department decided not to prosecute Jackie L. Presser, the teamsters' union president, after learning that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had approved some of the actions on which Mr. Presser might have faced charges, an official of the department said today.

description: b-Net income.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 ISRAELIS ARE FUOND DEAD, AND RAMPAGE FOLLOWS
description: The police announced today that searchers had found what they believed to be the bodies of two Jewish school teachers missing since Sunday in northern Israel. Despite a statement by the police indicating that the deaths did not appear to be the work of terrorists, the announcement immediately sparked an anti-Arab rampage by residents of the teachers' town.

title: 2 Girls Killed in Jersey Fire
description: Two 11-year-old girls spending the night alone in a house were killed and two police officers injured in a fire in this affluent Bergen County community, officials said.

title: LED 'HUMP' FLIGHTS OVER THE HIMALAYAS
description: William Langhorne Bond, a former vice president of the China National Aviation Corportion who, in World War II, helped organize the air route that brought supplies from Burma to China over the ''hump'' of the Himalaya Mountains, died July 16 in Ponte Vedra, Fla. He was 91 years old and a resident of Warrenton, Va.

title: OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PRETORIA REPORTS 118 ARRESTS, RAISING TOTAL TO 910
description: The South African authorities said today that they had detained 118 people overnight, bringing to 910 the number held without charges under an emergency decree that took effect Sunday.

title:
PATENTS;

GUARDING ACCESS TO COMPUTERS
description: PAUL J. LEVINE of Woodbridge, Va., an engineer who works on computer communications, was granted a patent this week for a system to prevent unauthorized access to a central computer that releases its output to recognized customers over telephone lines.

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS COMPROMISES ON SUBPOENA FOR VIDEOTAPES OF HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: CBS said yesterday that it had reached a compromise with the Justice Department regarding the Government's subpoena of videotapes the network made in the recent crisis involving the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet. It said it would provide only those materials ''relevant to crimes committed during the hijacking.''

title: AMERICAN FIRST CORP (OKLAHOMA) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: PROTESTS AND LOOTING SPREAD IN GUADELOUPE

title: CO-FOUNDER HARLEM TROUPE
description: Karel Shook, an internationally renowned ballet master, author and co-founder of the Dance Theater of Harlem, died Thursday at his home in Englewood, N.J., after a long illness. He was 64 years old. Mr. Shook, who was white, was one of the few ballet masters in the 1950's who taught and encouraged blacks in ballet. Among his students were Arthur Mitchell, Alvin Ailey, Carmen de Lavallade and Geoffrey Holder.

title: MET ROOKIE'S START DRENCHED BY RAIN
description: A lot of skullduggery and roster maneuvering and warming up went down the drain last night in Shea Stadium when the Mets and Houston Astros were rained out after a delay of nearly two hours. They will make up the game with a twilight-night doubleheader starting at 5:35 tonight.

title: JAZZ: STRIDE PIANIST AT 92d STREET Y
description: After opening its series of six programs on Tuesday evening with some joyful ragtime, the 92d Street Y's ''Jazz in July'' festival turned on Wednesday to another lively form of jazz - stride piano. With six stride pianists on stage playing singly, as duos and even as a trio that raced around the stage playing musical chairs and stride piano simultaneously, this light-hearted, rhythmic piano style that is most closely associated with Fats Waller and James P. Johnson was given an unusually full display.

title: TEAMSTER NEW CAR HAULERS STAGE NATIONWIDE WALKOUT

title: MANHATTAN OUTPACED BY BOOM IN SUBURBAN OFFICE CONSTRUCTION
description: Even as the real-estate market in Manhattan continues to surge, twice as much office space is being built this year in the suburbs around New York City than in Manhattan, according to real-estate experts.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Savings Bank said its board has approved conversion to a Federal capital stock savings bank, from a mutual savings bank.

title: SATURDAY NEW QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This was one of severa bars bieng clebrated in Key West, fla. What were the circumstances? 2. A foreign country whose current investment in another nation amounts to about $1.6 billion announced suspension of further investments there. What countries were involved and what were the circumstances? 3. Vice President Bush said he felt the burden of his own responsbility more heavily (when President Reagan was shot in 1981/when Mr. Reagan underwent surgery July 13). 4. ''There's nothing wrong in acknowledging something you've done has errors in it,'' said Mayor Koch as, for the first time, he vetoed a bill the City Council had approved at his request. What bill was it? 5. After a shaky start, New York City is letting the good times roll for five weeks at a restaurant on Columbus Avenue and 77th Street. Explain. 6. The United States and China signed a nuclear cooperation pact that opens the way for the sale of American nuclear reactors and technology. The Chinese gave unwritten assurances about two provisions of the pact. What were they? 7. ''If I was a male leader, I'd be considered part of the youth crowd, like Gary Hart,'' said Eleanor Smeal. Who is she and what were the circumstances? 8. The Mets, with a .229 batting average that put them next to last in the National League, set a team record last weekend.

title: NOW'S PRESIDENT: ASSESSING THE ELECTION
description: As the smoke cleared this week after one of the most heated presidential elections in the 19-year history of the National Organization for Women, NOW leaders tried to assess Eleanor Smeal's upset victory over Judy Goldsmith.

title: VIRILE BE THE SCRIBBLERS
description: Writers have to do something besides write or he-men will think they are sissies. This is why Ernest Hemingway went around shooting things and attending wars. There are many other famous examples.

description: Anywhere else in Africa, a sudden state of emergency after months of unrest might evoke the image of tanks in front of a stuccoed palace and troops controlling traffic at intersections. Not in South Africa.

title: DETERMINING VALUE OF SPEND A BUCK
description: Unless Hurricane Bob returns to drench the racing town of Oceanport, N.J., more than 35,000 people will be at Monmouth Park today to see a horse named Spend a Buck run in the Haskell Handicap. Given that this is more than double what the track would ordinarily draw, it must be assumed that many in the stands will be novices or the most casual of fans, making a special trip to see a colt who has done more for New Jersey racing than the Garden State Parkway.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch on Wednesday from Dedham, Mass., about a libel suit against The Boston Globe, inaccurately described testimony by John R. Lakian. Mr. Lakian, who sought the Republican nomination for Governor in 1982, is suing over an article published then by The Globe, which challenged his assertions about his background. The article quoted him as saying that all candidates exaggerated their credentials ''slightly.'' Mr. Lakian testified Tuesday that he had indeed expressed that sentiment in an interview and stood by it, but he said the quotation and others were not fully or accurately printed by The Globe.

England is a dull country without television commercials, suitable only for daydreams about meeting Princess Di.

title: GIVENCHY'S MODERN CLASSICS
description: Hubert de Givenchy takes the traditionalist approach to fashion. His couture collection, introduced on the last day of the fall and winter showings, enhanced the case for classicism. Though he broke no new ground and certainly showed no wild clothes, his collection had a good sense of freshness and a youthful vigor. The clothes were close to the body and, with a few exceptions for evening, never overelaborate. They had a modern, contemporary look, appropriate to cosmopolitan centers anywhere in the world.

Mr. Jackson, who comes from a gospel background and has played the local cabaret circuit, is a romantic pop-funk belter whose style suggests a slightly less ornate Luther Vandross. He recently scored a major hit with a languid, pulsating ballad, ''Rock Me Tonight,'' that is the title song of a best-selling album.

ERUPTION AT HAWAII VOLCANO
description: The Kilauea volcano began spewing molten rock 1,000 feet into the air before dawn today, beginning the 35th phase of its long-running eruption. The latest outbreak of the eruption, which first began in January 1983, occurred at a vent about midway down the mountain's eastern slope, 12 miles from the 4,000-foot summit. The most recent outbreak was July 6, and lasted 14 hours.

title: SHIFT THE TAX DEADLINE

title: SPRINKEL SAYS RATES MAY RISE
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's new chief economist, said today that he thought a stronger economy during the balance of the year would halt the decline in interest rates, and perhaps even push them up a bit.

description: Companies

title: E.P.A. CAUTIONS SMITHSONIAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today notified the Smithsonian Institution that it was violating Federal rules controlling polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, at three of its most important museums.

description: Nancy Reagan said today that doctors who publicly discussed President Reagan's cancer surgery acted in an unprofessional manner.

NBC LOOKS AT POWER OF THE PENSION FUNDS
description: ''The Biggest Lump of Money in the World'' is just that - more than a trillion dollars, rising to, say, $4 trillion in the next 15 years. The money is controlled by pension funds, and ''The Biggest Lump,'' an ''NBC White Paper'' at 10 o'clock tonight, is a documentary whose time has come. What do you do with so much money? Pension funds have grown mightily in the last decade. Congress saw to this in 1974, when it passed the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or Erisa, and relieved their tax burden. Some $100 billion is now placed in the funds each year, and this, in turn, is invested, mostly in common stocks. Increasingly now, ''stockholder'' means ''pension fund.''

title: Hitachi Trade Program
description: Hitachi Ltd., the company that has become the focus of American complaints about unfair Japanese trade practices in the electronics business, is planning to announce next week, in a televised news conference to several cities throughout the United States, a major program aimed at easing trade tensions by increasing Hitachi's purchases of supplies from American manufacturers, a spokesman for the company said today. Separately, Hitachi confirmed that the head of its American semiconductor operations, Shinji Ohnishi, is being transferred back to Japan. There have been press reports in Japan that Hitachi will design its computers and other machinery to use more American computer chips.

title: Mary Engel, Ex-Editor Of American Investor
description: Mary June Montgomery Engel, former editor of the American Investor, the monthly magazine of the American Stock Exchange, died July 18 at her home in San Francisco. She was 65 years old.

title: TODAY
description: Athletics Third annual Garden State Games, at Rutgers Stadium, Piscataway, N.J., 10 A.M. Track and field finals, final day. National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. The men's and women's short-skating program, women's platform-diving final, track and field and swimming competion will be shown. (Television - ESPN, 2 to 5 P.M. and 8 to 11 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, doubleheader at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Dodgers vs. Chicago Cubs, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Golf Merrill Lynch/Golf Digest Commemorative, at Newport, R.I. First round of tournament, which was shortened to 36 holes by yesterday's rain. Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford Open, at Cromwell, Conn., third round. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) L Harness Racing Roosevelt, 8 P.M. The $250,000 Roosevelt International Trot, with Sandy Bowl, representing the United States, as the early favorite and Lutin D'Isigny, the defending champion from France, as second choice. (Television - Channel 9, 11:30 P.M.) The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. New Jersey Sire Stakes 4-year-old pace. (Television - MSG Network, midnight) Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing Monmouth Park, 1:30 P.M. The $300,000-added Haskell Invitational. The Kentucky Derby winner Spend a Buck is favored. If Spend a Buck can win this race and the Pegasus Sept. 26 at the Meadowlands, he will add another $1 million bonus onto his earnings, which are currently $3,330,524.

title: Team Spirit
description: Richard Byrd, the rookie defensive lineman for the Oilers, explains why he decided to join a group of other Houston players who, as a sign of solidarity, have shaved their heads: ''I guess it was voluntary. There were about 10 guys around me, so I volunteered.''

title: UNITED WATER RESOURCES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
CHEAPER LINES BY DESIGNERS
description: As Douglas and Jeanne Johns of Baltimore wandered through the Anne Klein II section on the third floor of Lord & Taylor in Manhattan, a black and tan blazer displayed above the racks caught their attention. The price tag said $248. ''Not bad,'' Mr. Johns said to his wife.

title: PHONE LINE REOPENED FOR LIVE AID DONATIONS
description: The phone line for making contributions to the African relief fund generated by the televised Live Aid concert two weeks ago has been reopened, and those wishing to make contributions can call 800-LIVE-AID to submit pledges.

title: AMID EXCITEMENT, SMALL TOWN HOPES G.M. WILL BE GOOD NEIGHBOR
description: Already this is not quite the little farming town it was even a month ago.

description: With the sand of Battery Park as a stage and the Hudson River as a backdrop, the choreographer John Bernd directed a remake of ''Home & Away and the Life Between.'' It took place Sunday and Wednesday as part of Creative Time's Art on the Beach series of collaborative performances.

title: JACK COOKE: GENIAL BUT TOUGH
description: Jack Kent Cooke likes to portray himself as a man who loves the finer things in life. That includes music: He used to play the clarinet and saxophone and still plays piano and composes songs. That includes thoroughbreds: He has two horse farms and loves to ride.

title: DROP IN DRUG COST MAY ALLOW ALL-OUT ATTACK ON A PARASITE
description: A drug that takes only a single dose to effectively treat all forms of schistosomiasis, a debilitating parasitic disease that infects one in every 20 people in the world, has fallen so sharply in cost that the World Health Organization now believes it can be used for an all-out attack on the scourge.

title: REVISED MILITARY BUDGET: PENTAGON GETS EVERYTHING, BUT NOT MORE
description: Congress this year has appeared to be torn at times between standing up to a hostile world and standing up to a profligate Pentagon.

title: NEW YORK AREA SEES SLOWDOWN IN JOB GROWTH
description: The New York metropolitan region gained 43,000 jobs in the first half of 1985, but the gain represented significantly slower employment growth and a renewed decline in manufacturing, according to a midyear survey by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Dog Days?
description: Marge Schott, the colorful owner of the Cincinnati Reds, sees a role for her 170-pound St. Bernard in the stalled baseball labor talks: ''Put the negotiators in a room with my Schottzie. And lock the door at dinner time, when Schottzie is hungry.''

The 31 runs were the most the team ever scored in two consecutive games. 9. The tournament, which could be called the corporate baseball championship, reflects Japanese loyalty to employers. title: U.S. REVERSES STAND
description: Secretary of State Shultz's rejection of the request that the United States resume negotiations with Nicaragua comes three months after President Reagan promised he would reopen the talks.

title: Coach Reprimanded
description: University of Houston officials have imposed sanctions on an assistant basketball coach and the basketball program because of reported irregularities in the recruiting of 7-foot-1-inch Tito Horford. Following an in-house investigation, Athletic Director Tom Ford has confirmed that an assistant basketball coach, Donnie Schverak, violated two minor National Collegiate Athletic Association rules by visiting Horford in the Dominican Republic in July 1984. The school has barred Schverak from off-campus recruiting for a year, and the basketball program will be stripped of two scholarships.

P.L.O. SENDS ARMS, ARAFAT SAYS
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was quoted today as saying that his group was sending personnel and weapons back into southern Lebanon.

title: FARMERS END LONG FEUD BY KILLING EACH OTHER
description: Two farmers shooting from their pickup trucks killed each other in a parking lot, ending a 40-year feud that began when they were children, officials and residents say.

title: JOAN BISACCA IS WED TO A SALES CONSULTANT
description: Joan Bisacca and Bruce O'Such were married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Joseph McCormick, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF A WANTED MAN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today paid a 5-year-old jaywalking ticket, a Municipal Court spokesman announced today. But arrest warrants are still out for the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, and for a prominent Washington lobbyist, William Timmons. The spokesman, Christopher Crawford, said all three men were arrested here in 1980 for jaywalking. Mr. Meese's $10 fine grew to $130.50 with penalties.

The report was prepared by two professors for the association's committee on criminal advocacy, not by the committee itself.

title: CONFEREES SHIFT WATER PLAN COSTS TO THE LOCALITIES
description: Localities will have to bear more of the cost of future water projects subsidized by the Federal Government, Congressional negotiators agreed today.

title: ODE ON THE R-62A: SUBWAY CAR OR A WHISPERING SILVER MIRAGE?
description: The first impression given by the brand-new cars that have begun to go into service on the No. 1 line of the West Side IRT is one of unreality: These silver trains, sleek and miraculously clean, seem like mirages. After all, riding on the IRT is usually a matter of serving time in one of the city's most squalid environments - noisy, smelly, crowded and overrun with a ceaseless supply of graffiti. Are they not in violation of all that New York stands for, these cars that are cool and quiet and comfortable, where everything works and graffiti are nowhere to be found?

STEPHEN CRANE PAPERS ACQUIRED BY UNIVERSITY
description: A major cache of 62 letters and other material written by Stephen Crane - the intrepid New York street reporter, foreign correspondent and author of ''The Red Badge of Courage,'' who left a small but lasting body of work before he died at the age of 28 in 1900 - has been acquired by Syracuse University from the widow of a private collector.

title: STATE DROPPING ITS PLAN TO SHUT GRANT'S COTTAGE
description: The state has reversed its decision to close the historic site it maintains at the Saratoga County house where Ulysses S. Grant spent the last days of his life.

title: HUSSEIN CALLS FOR ARAB WORKING GROUP ON MIDEAST
description: King Hussein of Jordan called on Arab governments today to form a working group to address critical problems confronting the region.

title: SUIT FEARS HURT STOCK OF ROBINS
description: The price of the A. H. Robins Company's stock fell sharply for the second straight day as investors worried about a possible bankruptcy filing by the pharmaceutical company.

title: AUCTION-HOUSE SALES INCREASE WORLDWIDE
description: Auction sales increased worldwide last season, according to preliminary figures released this week by the three largest international art-auction houses - Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips Son & Neale.

title: JOHN BEATS BREWERS, 7-3, IN A'S DEBUT
description: Tommy John, in his debut with Oakland, pitched six strong innings for the victory, and Dwayne Murphy and Mike Davis had home runs tonight to lead the A's past the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-3.

description: Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc. said yesterday that it was reorganizing its government securities department, following large trading losses in the last 15 months.

title: POLICE SEIZE 300 ON DRUG COUNTS IN VILLAGE PARK
description: More than 300 narcotics arrests have been made in Washington Square Park in the last three weeks as part of a new crackdown on drug trafficking there, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Vessel Is Freed From Ice in Antarctic
description: A Soviet icebreaker sliced through the last stretch of a drifting Antarctic ice field surrounding the research vessel Mikhail Somov today, freeing the ship and its crew after 133 days.

DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When He's Bad, He's Still Better
description: Dwight Gooden, who isn't quite perfect, was reached by Houston for two homers Thursday night and has now yielded 11 in 170Z innings this year. That is four more dingers than were rung up against him in 218 innings all last season, when his ratio was one per 31.1 innings, almost exactly twice as good as his 1985 rate of one per 15.5.

title: POP: TETES NOIRES IN CONCERT
description: Close harmonies and a wry fascination with sex roles fill the songs of Tetes Noires. Wednesday at Folk City, the six-woman band from Minneapolis played songs about religious cultists, male prostitution, wet T-shirt contests, makeup and nuclear war - songs that are both catchy and double-edged.

title: FRIENDS WATCH MAN DROWN
description: Friends of a 31-year-old man stood by and watched him drown in a park swimming area, thinking he was jesting when he cried for help, Mayor Jim Wedge said today. The victim, Jimmy Dean Racer of Patriot, Ohio, waded out to a floating diving platform Wednesday when he was pushed into the water by a child who was unaware Mr. Racer could not swim, the Mayor said, adding: ''He said, 'Help me, I can't swim.' His friends and family were standing right there, but they assumed he was kidding and did nothing.''

title: Owner for Gamblers
description: A partnership headed by Steve Ross, a New York real estate developer, agreed yesterday to buy the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League. The team will be moved out of Houston, Ross said, and renamed.

title: HOTEL PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Borg-Warner
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that it was preparing to spin off its air-conditioning subsidiary.

description: Year-ago per share figures reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January.

SERGEANTS CONVICTED IN THEFT OF WEAPONS
description: Two members of the Army's Special Forces were convicted today of stealing tons of Army weapons, then trying to trade the arms for cocaine and cash from Federal agents posing as smugglers.

title: GIANTS' OLIVER GAINS INSIGHT IN ABSENCE
description: Jack Oliver's first two weeks as a professional football player have been instructive and almost destructive. He has reported to camp, left camp, returned to camp and learned more about himself.

title: KOCH SAYS SUPPLY SYSTEM IS SAFE
description: Low levels of plutonium were found in a sample of New York City water, Mayor Koch announced yesterday, but he said the water was ''absolutely safe to drink.''

title: 'OPPORTUNITY' FOR BLACKS?
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, has a novel idea. Precisely because the Republican Party has recently been cold to blacks, he thinks they should join up in large numbers and bore away from within. Judging from the response of the Urban League this week, Mr. Dole is likely to find some takers. But probably not many. History suggests that something more substantial will be needed to entice sizable numbers of blacks into Republican ranks.

title: U.N. WOMEN'S CONFERENCE DROPS REFERENCE TO ZIONISM AS RACISM
description: Western nations scored a major victory at the United Nations Decade for Women conference here Friday when the participants agreed to drop language equating Zionism with racism from the final document.

title: A Dying Breed
description: Of all the Steelers he played with on the four championship clubs of the 1970's, only John Stallworth and Donnie Shell remain.

title: Now a Price For All That Jazz
description: For 16 years, a small, smoky jazz institution called Bradley's has been admired among musicians and jazz fans as the only place in town that offered top talent for free.

description: b-Net loss.

title: FORD NET DOWN 23.1% AS SALES SLIP
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that net income in the second quarter fell 23.1 percent, to $699 million, or $3.75 a share, from a record $909.1 million, or $4.95 a share, in the comparable period last year.

title: Investigation Of Cash Deals
description: The Treasury is holding discussions with representatives of the Bank of America and the Crocker National Bank about failing to report large cash transactions, a Treasury spokesman said today.

title: MAKE NATURAL-GAS PRICING FAIRER
description: In one stunning stroke, Federal regulators propose to undo the rules that encourage waste of natural gas and retard its production. The question now is whether Congress will allow it.

title: LTV Posts Huge Loss, Cites Shutdown of Mill
description: The LTV Corporation reported yesterday a second-quarter loss of $472.3million, which included a previously announced $400 million charge to indefinitely idle its big Aliquippa steel works near Pittsburgh.

title: RANGERS WIN WITH FIVE IN 8TH
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 26 - Ron Guidry was on the mound with Dave Righetti in the bullpen, and that has usually meant good fortune for the Yankees. But it failed tonight. Guidry wilted under the 94-degree temperature at Arlington Stadium, and Righetti was unable to slow a Texas stampede in the eighth inning. The Rangers pulled out a 9-8 victory, sending the Yankees reeling to their fourth consecutive defeat.

title: LOST BONANZA FOR BOSTONIANS
description: AZALEE and Chester Buffalo of Boston thought they had an anonymous benefactor when $116,000 showed up in their account at the Boston Bank of Commerce, law-enforcement officials say, so they spent all the money.

title: SUZANNE WELLS IS WED
description: Suzanne Speiser Wells, the daughter of Col. Robin G. Speiser, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Speiser of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Sherburne Wood, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Wood of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Christine Tremaine performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J. Jennifer and Katie Wells, daughters of the bride by her previous marriage, which ended in divorce, attended the couple.

title: SECOND-GUESSING STATE BUDGETS, LINE BY LINE
description: After the Texas Legislature passed the state's new budget in May, Gov. Mark White took up his pen and did what the President of the United States cannot: He vetoed seven items from the appropriations.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DENOUNCES U.N. VOTE ON SANCTIONS
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that his country's black-ruled neighbors would pay a far higher price than South Africa if international economic sanctions were imposed on his country.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEW GATSBYS: Fortunes and Misfortunes of Commodity Traders. By Bob Tamarkin. (Morrow, $18.95.) After reading this book, one wonders why newspapers place commodities reports in their business sections instead of near their astrology columns.

title:
DINING OUT;

BUCKS COUNTY: A TOUCH OF GREECE
description: IT'S SOMEWHAT disconcerting when a telephone is answered with the words ''Good evening, it's Greek to me,'' until you remember that it's the name of the restaurant you were calling for a reservation and not someone being facetious.

title: PORT CHESTER WINS RULING ON CLUB LEASE AT HARBOR
description: HALF a dozen men in T-shirts and old pants sat with their feet on the porch railing and looked out disconsolately at the weathered docks and the rows of small runabouts, their outboard motors tilted up at the stern.

title: OFFICE TENANTS RATE SERVICES
description: A SURVEY of the opinions of office tenants about the buildings they occupy has found that those on the Avenue of the Americas outrank those on Park and Third Avenues in the estimation of the occupants.

title: FATHERHOOD POSTPONED
description: MY FIRST wife and I were out of sync when it came to children. When I wanted them, she didn't, and vice versa. Perhaps that should have told us something, though even now I'm not sure quite what. In any case, the marriage was over before I knew it - literally - and once we were separated, people kept saying wasn't it fortunate there hadn't been any children. I couldn't argue with that.

title: POLITICS
description: FOR decades, the battle cry in the state's large Democratic-controlled counties was:

title: Lebanese Are Barred From Kuwait's Airline
description: Kuwait has barred all Lebanese citizens from traveling on its national airline, aviation sources said today.

title: PUBLIC LAW ORGANIZATIONS ARE UNITING TO ADVOCATE THE CONSERVATIVE CAUSE
description: In the years of the Nixon Administration, a number of conservative lawyers and politicians urged the creation of a network of conservative public law centers that would balance the rising influence of consumer, environmental and civil libertarian law organizations.

title: REAL FACES AND PLACES
description: LOOKING AT CITIES By Allan B. Jacobs. Illustrated. 153 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

description: FINAL CUT Dreams and Disaster in the Making of ''Heaven's Gate.'' By Steven Bach. 432 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: MARTHA KENERSON TO WED IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Ryder Kenerson of St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Lynne Kenerson, to William Blaikie Bierce, a son of Augustine Hicks Lawrence Jr., of Delray Beach, Fla., Wilmington, Del., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., and the late Thurber Hoffman Bierce of Englewood, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: CARBOHYDRATES AND CAPITALISM
description: SWEETNESS AND POWER The Place of Sugar in Modern History. By Sidney W. Mintz. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $20.

title: No Headline
description: THE problems of physical and psychological tension in performance will be the subject of attention and study this week at Westminster Choir College here.

title: CANOEING UPPER DELAWARE'S ELOQUENT SILENCE
description: The river runs gentle here, slipping its way quietly through a valley of maples and oaks southwest past the mountains toward the sea.

title: Attack Sub Commissioned
description: The Navy today commissioned the fast-attack submarine Providence, the 32d Los Angeles-class submarine and the first in its class designed to carry the Tomahawk cruise missile in vertical launch tubes. The Groton police said nine protesters had been arrested when they blocked traffic outside the main gate of the New London Naval Submarine Base, where the Providence was commissioned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PHILADELPHIA FARE RISES TO $1
description: A ride on the transit system here will cost $1 starting Aug. 4.

title: LOCAL INCENTIVES DRAW INDUSTRY TO POORER AREAS
description: While Congress has been deadlocked for four years on President Reagan's ideas for reviving blighted urban areas, half the states and hundreds of cities are offering a range of incentives to attract jobs and industry to ''enterprise zones'' such as he proposed.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

'OPTIMISM' COLORS IMAGES OF 20th CENTURY SOVIET LIFE
description: The two exhibitions of Soviet photography that are opening next Friday at the International Center of Photography are of unusual interest for the glimpses they give of an unfamiliar branch of modern photography. Both introduce to Western audiences a number of unfamiliar, sometimes quite extraordinary, images. And both make clear how different the Soviet idea of photography is from our own.

title: IN EUROPE, TOO, IT'S BACK TO BASICS
description: In a dramatic swing of the pendulum, the idea of progressive education has given way in Great Britain and France to conservative theory and practice. The guiding doctrine in Francois Mitterrand's socialist France is indistinguishable from that in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Britain or Ronald Reagan's America. The emphasis is on the Three R's, high grades and tests. Science, mathematics and computer literacy are enjoying favor, along with demands that the schools serve the job market.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Q & A column on June 23, Victoria Island was incorrectly given as the stop on a jetfoil route from Seattle to the city of Vancouver, British Columbia. The island should have been identified as Vancouver Island.

title: Perilous Economies In Airport Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Art
description: One of the most beautiful of recent art books was devoted to the watercolors that were made in the early 1830's by Karl Bodmer, a Swiss painter who traveled from Boston to the Montana Territory by way of the Ohio and Missouri rivers. Bodmer's work has both a natural dignity and a ring of truth, and it was a delight to follow him, page by page, as he made his slow, observant way through territory that was as yet untouched by art.

title: ARAB LEADERS TO MEET NEXT MONTH, MOROCCAN SAYS
description: King Hassan II of Morocco announced tonight that an Arab summit meeting, the first in three years, would be held in Casablanca starting Aug. 7.

title: SPECIAL PRODUCTION OF ''TALLEY'S FOLLY''
description: ''TALLEY'S FOLLY'' by Lanford Wilson is all too often done in small theaters for all the wrong reasons.

title: BICYCLING: IT'S NEVER TOO LATE TO LEARN
