description: ''I STILL can't believe I'm not the only New Yorker who never learned to ride a bike,'' Roslyn Sholin, a financial consultant, was saying on a recent Saturday morning. Like the 20 other men and women -ages ranging from early 20's to early 50's - who were walking their three-speed bicycles toward Central Park, Miss Sholin had decided to acquire that particular skill this summer. The means: ''How to Ride a Bicycle,'' four two-hour classes given by Westwinds Discovery Center, a Manhattan adult-education facility.

title: ...AND A NIGHTMARE ABOUT OPERA'S FUTURE
description: The other evening I had a nightmare. I dreamed I was present at the creation of a new form of theater that was fated to replace opera, plays, films and all other forms of drama. In my semi-conscious state I felt something like the excitement that must have stirred the Florentine band of connoisseurs known as the Camerata when, around the year 1600, they brought into being the art we now know as opera. The thought flashed across my mind, like a subtitle, that opera and other categories of music drama would never again be the same. I had been granted a vision of a wondrous future in which all art would be processed in highly condensed form, like uncut heroin, and served up to audiences in short, jolting injections.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 28, 1985
description: International

title: THE TEACHING OF WRITING
description: To the Editor:

title: PERFECTIONIST RECONSIDERS AND CONDUCTS ON VIDEOTAPE
description: ''We have to compromise on so many things,'' said Sergiu Celibidache, a trace of resignation coloring the voice of a man known as one of the world's most ardently uncompromising conductors. Born in Rumania in 1912 and formerly the principal conductor of some half-dozen major European orchestras, including the Berlin Philharmonic, Mr. Celibidache has earned considerable renown in music circles for the steadfastness of his convictions and the fastidiousness of his methods -which includes demanding three times the number of rehearsals as is now customary from the ensembles he leads.

title: 1,000 Are Evacuated Near Warehouse Fire
description: The authorities decided today to build an earthen dam around a burning warehouse and flood it with water to extinguish a two-day-old fire that forced 1,000 residents from nearby homes with clouds of irritating fumes.

title: MUSIC SCHOOL GROWTH CURBED
description: A CEDARHURST woman has won a court fight to stop a music school next door to her house from expanding, and from giving any horn and drum lessons.

title: FLORENCE SUMMER: ICE CREM CON BRIO
description: Eating ice cream in Italy is a national pastime, for the young and the old, all day long and all year round, though it is in summer, of course, that eating ice cream becomes a way of life. In the evenings, when the air is cooler, families sit together on the edge of fountains enjoying ice cream while young people on scooters cluster outside the ice cream bars and share conos (cones) or coppettas (little cardboard cups).

title: COLLEGE ROLE CITED IN HIGH-TECH SURGE
description: THE state's Chancellor of Higher Education, T. Edward Hollander, says that ''a long-time-coming, but very welcome'' clamor has arisen in business, industrial and local government circles for help from colleges and universities in research and scientific and technical expertise.

title: CUOMO POLITICAL FUND HAS GIFTS OF $240,000
description: Governor Cuomo's campaign fund has received more than $240,000 in cash contributions this year, according to a report by the state's Board of Elections.

title: STEPPING STONES FROM SCRATCH
description: ONE of the easiest ways for the do-it-yourselfer to build a paved walk or path is in the form of a series of stepping stones - masonry blocks that are set into the turf so that the top of each stone is flush with the ground. Many people feel that this type of paved walk blends in more naturally with the landscaping than a solid ribbon of concrete and is generally more pleasing to look at.

title: DANCE: LUCINDA CHILDS
description: THE Lucinda Childs Dance Company got off to a ravishing start in a performance on Thursday at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase. Opening the program was the radiant ''Dance No. 1'' from ''Dance,'' a kind of track run for angels set to shimmering modular music by Philip Glass.

title: GERMAN ROMANTICISM: COMPLEX, CRYSTALLINE VISION
description: Once upon a time there was a bunch of painters who were both completely of their time and way ahead of it. It was common ground with poets, storytellers, philosophers and even an art-loving king that their work had a crystalline quality, a disdain for faking and fuss, that set it apart. Long before the American Luminists, they made something transcendental out of everyday light. Long before George Caleb Bingham, they made something very grand out of a heap of men floating downstream on a broad flat boat on a broad flat river.

title: IN NOVA SCOTIA, MUSHROOMS TO GO
description: You may find thousands of potters all over the world practicing a craft older than civiliztion itself, but you probably will not find any like the Lorenzens of Nova Scotia. They create clay copies of many species of mushrooms that grow wild in their Atlantic province.

title: THEY HAVE TO BE BETTER THAN GOOD
description: GERMANY TODAY A Personal Report. By Walter Laqueur. 231 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: THE TEACHING OF WRITING
description: To the Editor:

title: Testing The Water
description: New Yorkers concerned about drinking water drawn from the Hudson River had something new to worry about last week: plutonium. Flanked by city health officials, Federal energy experts and several nuclear scientists, Mayor Koch announced at a news conference Friday night that very low levels of the radioactive isotope plutonium-239 had been detected in New York City's reservoirs.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NEW MUSICAL ''Georgia Avenue,'' a new musical about two women who operate an Atlantic City shop in the 1930's, opens at the Norma Terris Theater in Chester on Tuesday and runs through Aug. 25. The show has a book by Joe Masteroff, the co-author of ''Cabaret'' and ''She Loves Me,'' and music by Howard Marren, who composed the scores for ''Love'' and ''Portrait of Jennie'' Off Broadway.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

SPIRIT OF SUMMER STOCK THRIVES ON L.I.
description: THE scene is straight out of Hollywood's Golden Oldie musical days: young dancers and singers going through their paces in chicken coops turned into rehearsal halls; a barn echoing with the sound of carpenters hammering away on sets; a shed humming with the whir of machines stitching costumes.

title: Haiti Says 99.9% Backed President in Referendum
description: At least 99.9 percent of the electorate approved President Jean-Claude Duvalier's life term in office in a referendum this week, the Government said Friday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HANDLES By Jan Mark. 162 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: AMERICAN HIGHLAND EVENTS, CLIMBING HIMALAYAS
description: 10th Annual Scottish Games In New England With pipers and drummers and dancers and fiddlers and such feats of strength as tossing the caber, shot-put and hurling a sheaf of hay, the 10th anniversary of the New Hampshire Highland Games are scheduled for Sept. 14 and 15.

title: BOMBING IS SAID TO CAUSE DEEP CONCERN IN BURMA
description: The speed with which the usually secretive Government announced the bombing of a passenger train Wednesday indicated that the attack was considered very serious, according to diplomats here.

title: ELECTRONIC MAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHILD'S 'BEING ALONE': OTHER ASPECTS
description: While the plight of children who need help for emotional and behavioral problems deserves attention, the way the article highlighted it does more to induce guilt in parents than to offer help to children.

title: THE TEACHING OF WRITING
description: To the Editor:

title: Time, Tempers Run Short in Budget Wrangle
description: ''Let's not make this a struggle between the Speaker and the President,'' Representative William H. Gray 3d, the Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said last week. ''That's ludicrous.'' But as President Reagan went off to Camp David after his first week back in the White House following cancer surgery, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. sat in his office calling for Mr. Reagan's approval on ''even part'' of a sweeping new Senate plan for breaking the deficit-reduction impasse before taking any action. At the White House, Presidential spokeman Larry Speakes said Mr. Reagan would not comment on the specifics until the House responded and there was ''some sort of jelling on the Hill.''

title: MAYORAL MATH DICTATES TWO-WAY RACE
description: The campaigns of Mayor Koch's two main challengers crashed head-on last week, and New York City politicians who were examining the wreckage were not sure that there would be any survivors.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: July 28, 1985 Fiction

title: A PROBLEM UNDER BOSTON
description: AS Boston became too crowded for the small, choked-off peninsula the Massachusetts Bay Company settled 350 years ago, the city began to make more land by filling in the tidal swamps of the Back Bay.

title: JAN JACOBI PLANS TO MARRY
description: Jan Ellen Jacobi, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and David Hutchison Stewart, a financial consultant in Toronto, plan to be married in October. Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Jacobi of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Margery Stewart of Montreal and the late William T. Stewart.

title: AT FRESH AIR CAMP, A LEGEND CAUSES EXCITEMENT
description: The children lay fast asleep in the shingled cabins. Outside, the stillness of the Sharpe Reservation was punctuated only by the quick-moving feet of camp counselors who hurriedly placed bits of ''evidence'' around the campgrounds.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about New York City's program to combat suicide in jails misidentified Hortense Wiley, who trains inmates as suicide-prevention aides. She is a corrections officer, not a police officer.

title: PLANTINGS TO MATCH VICTORIAN ORNATENESS
description: When Peggy Gerry saw the historic Obadiah Washington Valentine House in Roslyn, L.I., she was so entranced by the roaring brook, mature trees and borrowed scenery from an adjoining park that she forgot to ask the realtor if the house had bedrooms or a bath. For Peggy Gerry and her husband, Roger, the creation of a Victorian setting for their stately Greek Revival house has been an ongoing challenge.

title: THE DEROGATOR
description: IN THIS MOVIE I HAVE in mind, to star Arnold Schwarzenegger or somebody with more spectral pectorals, the central character is dreaded throughout the linguistic world as ''The Derogator.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HEARING OUT JAMES T. FARRELL: Selected Lectures. Edited by Donald Phelps. (The Smith, Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.95.) James T. Farrell (1904-79) was our most authoritative realistic novelist of the 1930's - Studs Lonigan and the rest of Farrell's Chicago Irish brood are practically immortal.

title: PROTECTING YOURSELF FROM DEFAULT
description: Paying for travel is easy.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To the Editor: I read with great personal interest the letter about the tactics used by a group of teen-age girls in the Paris subway in an attempt to steal a billfold (Travel, June 30).

title: SUMMATIONS ENDING IN RADICALS' CONSPIRACY TRIAL
description: Summations are ending in the trial of eight revolutionaries accused of plotting armed robberies and prison escapes.

title: Progress Made On Pentagon Spending Plan
description: Under pressure to watch expenses, the Pentagon by and large would rather save a billion here and there by ordering up smaller batches of a controversial weapon than do without. Last week, when House and Senate conferees announced they agreed on a military authorization bill for 1986 that slowed the five-year build-up of military spending, it appeared that Pentagon lobbying had helped rescue nearly two dozen weapons that either the House or the Senate had wanted to kill.

title: RIVALRY GIVES WAY TO HARMONY FOR TWO COMPOSERS
description: If ever Russia produced a pair of thoroughly antagonistic souls, they were surely her two composers most celebrated today, Modest Mussorgsky and Piotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky. As far as each was concerned, the other was a fool.

title: HOBBY HIGHLIGHTS
description: The United States Postal Service issued last Thursday an eight-cent Great Americans Series stamp depicting General Henry Knox. The issue, which honors the 200th anniversary year of his appointment as the first Secretary of War, had its first day of issue in Thomaston, Me.

title: A Special Tax Just to Cut the Deficit
description: The $200 billion per year budget deficit is a classic example of political paralysis.

title: BANK REGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: BACH AND WEILL AT SUMMERFARE FESTIVAL
description: INCONGRUITY is a geometric term, while music and theater are affairs of the heart. So watching Peter Sellars's odd juxtaposition of Kurt Weill and J. S. Bach at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase on Thursday night, one would have been wise to store away analyses and rationalizations and let the eyes and the ears have their way.

title: It's Time for an Israeli-Arab Change of Tone;   The Enemy Within
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FORTUNATE SON. By Dave Marsh. (Random House, Paper, $9.95.) Dave Marsh carries his high-mindedness like a chip on his shoulder, daring anyone who does not share his sense of rock music's moral vision to slap it away.

title: BRIDGEPORT TRIES TO TAME GRAFFITI
description: BEFORE this summer, Richard Virgilio's artistry could be seen throughout the East Side of Bridgeport - spray-painted on walls amid a growing clutter of graffiti.

title: IN MEMORIAM
description: To the Editor:

title: DISNEY IS SETTING ITS SIGHTS ON THE PG SET
description: Once upon a time, teen-agers liked Walt Disney movies. Then the world changed. The over-13's dropped out of the Disney market. Next to go were many 11- and 12-year-olds. ''Kid stuff,'' they said. Walt Disney's audience grew younger and younger, smaller and smaller. By the 1980's, the very name ''Disney'' had become box-office poison.

title: A BELGAIN IN THE SIERRA NEVADA
description: GOLD SEEKER Adventures of a Belgian Argonaut During the Gold Rush Years. By Jean-Nicolas Perlot. Edited and with an introduction by Howard R. Lamar. Translated by Helen Harding Bretnor. Illustrated. 45l pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: THERE IS A COUSINHOOD OF MAN
description: THE MOUNTAIN OF NAMES A History of the Human Family. By Alex Shoumatoff. 318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: NOISE LEVEL REPORTED DOWN AS CITY'S BEACHGOERS PLUG IN
description: At Coney Island yesterday, advertising airplanes were touting earphones - a sign of the city's new ban on playing radios and cassette players out loud on parts of four city beaches and at the Central Park Sheep Meadow.

title: HIT-AND-RUN GUILT
description: LOOKING through my window, a New England forest takes me in. Oak and spruce, hemlock and pine, their branches drip from a week of intermittent rain. Finally, the drought is over. Even the deer will be safe, no longer needing to venture into backyards or across busy roads in search of water.

title: MEANDERING ALONG GERMANY'S MOSELLE
description: ''Who needs the Black Forest?'' joked Eduard Quint, 80 years old and fit, looking over the Moselle Valley.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO PUT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he favored moving rapidly on legislation imposing economic sanctions against South Africa, and that he expected President Reagan to go along.

title: Q AND A
description: When a Cotenant Dies . . . Question: A friend and I rented an apartment May 1, 1947. The apartment was rented in my friend's name. The rent was paid from a joint checking account with his signature. My friend died in June. I paid the rent for April and May from the same joint checking account with my signature. When I sent in a check for June with my signature, it was returned. I have lived in this rent-controlled apartment for 38 years, paid city and state taxes and my voter registration is here. What can I do to avoid being evicted? . . . H.F., Manhattan Answer: If the landlord should try to evict you, you can defend the action on the ground that you were a cotenant, says Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration in the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The kind of proof you need is exactly what you have - tax records, voter registration, canceled checks and proof of residence.

title: Shops Remain Closed In Guadeloupe Protest
description: Separatists dismantled roadblocks today, but shops and businesses remained closed on the fourth day of a general strike on this French Caribbean island.

title: INTEREST BLOCS
description: 'Since when are 108 million people a special interest? That's a hell of a nerve. I can't understand it, and I doubt very much if any of you gentlemen can understand it.' rrFormer Senator Jacob K. Javits, rrtestifying before Congress against President Reagan's plan to end the deduction for state and local taxes, a proposal that he called unfair to residents of New York and 15 other high-tax states.

title: DR. FIGUEROA IS THE BRIDE OF GARY J. SCHMIDT ON L.I.
description: Dr. Delia Figueroa, a physician, and Gary Jay Schmidt, a paramedic, both at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, were married yesterday at St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church in Elmont, L.I. The Rev. James Lisante performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim.

title: Indonesian Mission in China
description: An Indonesian trade mission arrived here today in an effort to reopen commercial relations. Indonesia suspended them in 1967 on the ground that China had supported a Communist coup attempt in Indonesia two years earlier.

title: CASEY AND LISA BIRGE NOLEN, SISTERS, ARE ENGAGED TO BE MARRIED IN THE FALL
description: Catherine Chapin Nolen plans to marry Lincoln Cable Jackson in October and her younger sister, Lisa Birge Nolen, will marry James Strong Birmingham in November. The engagements were announced by the sisters' parents, Chapin Nolen of Bedford, N.Y., and Barbara H. Nolen of Tamworth, N.H.

title: BLAST AT EMBASSY IN LISBON
description: A small bomb exploded outside the South African Embassy here early today, shattering its windows and door and damaging two parked cars, the police said. No injuries were reported.

title: Blackmun Assesses the Court
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court says the current Court is ''not a great Court, but I think not the worst Court we have had in history.'' But individually, he paints a picture of a court that is feeling the aches and pains of old age.

title:
ART;

AT SQUIBB: A DISPLAY OF HOW LITTLE CHANGE THERE REALLY IS
description: THE current exhibition at the Squibb Gallery here has an exciting premise: the art in it changes over time. In reality, however, what one sees is more noble or stately than exciting. With the help of nature, the art changes very slowly, even imperceptibly.

title: Recent Releases
description: On the Comet Best Film & Video Corp. 76 minutes. $39.95 In 1970, the great Czechoslovak film maker Karel Zeman completed his fantastical reworking of Jules Verne's novel ''Off on a Comet,'' and only now has it come to the home screen in this English-dubbed version.

title: NIXON GUARDS
description: FORMER President Richard M. Nixon announced last March that he would do without the Secret Service detail that has been with him since he left office 11 years ago this week.

title: THE MIGHTY P.E.N./FAULKNER PRIZE
description: ''My experience was pure bliss,'' said the writer Cynthia Ozick. ''We came to Washington, we were put up in a lovely, small hotel, all the nominees came to know each other. I think we became friends.''

title: MEMORABLE MUSICAL
description: ONE HAS to go a long way to find first-class productions of grand old musicals, let alone any grand new ones.

title: SEEING CITY STREETS THROUGH L.I. EYES
description: WALKING through Pennsylvania Station, I receive my first impression that I have left the haven of the suburbs. As the occupants of each car of each train converge in a flow of traffic through the station's corridors and out toward the street, the homeless sit by storefronts that have not yet opened, some yawning, others gazing straight ahead, others yelling to the crowd about the injustices that befall them.

title: UCONN RESEARCHERS TESTING KELP FARM
description: SEAWEED might seem a bit unsavory to the uninitiated, but two University of Connecticut researchers are trying to determine whether kelp could be a commercial crop in the state's coastal waters.

title: SEX AMONG THE AGED: ROLE FOR MOTHER NATURE
description: HOW strange that the sexual revolution, which has freed men and women from sexual inhibitions, gives no quarter to the elderly, with the result that many a sexagenarian feels ashamed by his or her sexuality.

title: Topics;   Outdoor Amenities Moveable Feasters
description: New Yorkers are always noshing. Their office desks are littered with the crumbs of bagels and monster muffins, and their wastebaskets with coffee cartons.

title:
DINING OUT;

EATING OUT AT THE ACADEMY
description: JUST minutes away from the west end of the Bear Mountain Bridge, the Hotel Thayer nestles in 1,600 scenic acres, the compound of the United States Military Academy. This hostelry (part of the Academy but operated privately) does a brisk business accommodating not only cadets, their families and friends but also visitors who find the United States Military Academy's football games, parades, verdant acreage and Hudson River views sufficient reason for a day's excursion. And the hotel dining room makes a logical conclusion to a day spent there.

title: No More Money Down the Queens Subway Tube
description: Federal officials last week put the stops on a $31 million payment that was to have helped finance the completion of a new subway tunnel linking Manhattan and Queens. Ralph M. Stanley, head of the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, said there had been ''wholly inadequate'' management of the tunnel's construction by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Why should Saudi Arabia be the Atlas of OPEC? If it wants to produce its full quota, it should go ahead and do so. No country has the moral right to stop another producing its quota.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: July 28, 1985 Fiction

title: COUNTDOWN FOR COMET EXHILARATES ASTRONOMERS OF ALL AGES
description: THIRTY rapt first graders stared upward into an artificial evening sky as the planetarium and observatory director at Milford's Joseph A. Foran High School, Alan Sacharow, conducted a guided tour of the universe.

title: TELLER NETWORK
description: EIGHT banks and other financial institutions linked computers last March to allow customers of any one to get cash and make balance inquiries at the automated teller machines of the others.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'LONG ISLAND JAM'

title: TERESA S. NAMUTH BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Tessa Suzanne Namuth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Namuth of New York and Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter C. Papademetriou, the son of Annemarie Papademetriou of Chatham, N.J., and the late Theodore Papademetriou. The Rev. Jeffrey Walker performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Dune Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: ANCIENT ARMIES CLASH IN SILENCE AT GOLAN SITE
description: The few people who have visited the remains of the first-century fortified city of Gamla, in the Golan Heights, may think of it as Israel's second Masada. But Gamla's archeologists maintain that their little-known site is really the first Masada. The famed Masada fortress, they say, comes second -- and in some ways a poor second.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To the Editor: Recent articles and letters about travel mishaps involving crime in the Paris Metro and elsewhere prompt me to recount my own experiences during a trip in the fall of 1982.

title: DOVES AND GORBACHEV OPEN SOVIET FESTIVAL
description: As children sang, crowds chanted political slogans and hundreds of doves swirled through the Lenin Stadium, Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened the 12th international festival of youth and students.

title: IN THE TURNTABLE DEBATE, SILENCE IS GOLDEN
description: With interest in the new compact disk players at an apparent peak, it was natural to expect that conventional LP turntables would suffer public neglect. Yet in certain segments of the audio market, this has proved not to be so. At least in cities like New York, where a sizable number of people are seriously involved with recorded music, several audio dealers have been reporting something of a run on LP record players.

title: CONSERVATIVES PUSH TO INDUCE SHULTZ TO LEAVE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has become a target of a new drive by Republican conservatives who accuse him of handling terrorism too gingerly and of being too soft in dealing with the Soviet Union.

title: CATHY WHITLOCK, P. DEL. HARRISON TO WED SEPT. 14
description: Dr. and Mrs. James William Whitlock of Nashville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathy Dawn Whitlock, to Peter DeLancey Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Henry Harrison of Topsfield, Mass. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: 2 ACTORS NURTURE REPERTORY GROUP
description: ''WE'RE the newest and the only show in town,'' Christopher Tracy said of Workshop Productions, a Greenwich-based repertory company. He and his wife, Gina Russell Tracy, formed the company as co-producers three months ago, with Mr. Tracy the technical director and Mrs. Tracy the artistic director.

title: Article 146077 -- No Title
description: FOR thousands of motorists caught in traffic jams leaving White Plains during the evening rush hours, this week may bring a dramatic change.

title: MISS SCHAAF BECOMES BRIDE OF MARK A. RILEY
description: Monika Schaaf, the daughter of Mrs. Horace J. Duncan of Athens, Ga., was married yesterday to Mark A. Riely, the son of Mary Elizabeth Riely of New York and the late John A. Riely. The Rev. Paul V. Callahan performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title:
GARDENING;

PROBLEMS CAUSED BY THE HEAT
description: THE hot but often humid weather of summer can play havoc with the garden.

title: SHORT CUTS TO CULTURE SHOCK
description: ''THIS,'' a friend told me last year, and by ''this'' he meant Nassau County, ''is Queens 15 years ago,'' and then he moved to Florida. The prophesy was not Delphic. We'd been talking about business shifts and failures and general population shifts and drifts, and in that context we included the incidence of crime.

title: GO-GO MUSIC: CHUCK BROWN AND BAND
description: BY the time Chuck Brown finished his set Thursday at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, there wasn't a dry brow in the house. Mr. Brown and his band, the Soul Searchers, had been playing nonstop go-go funk for two hours and everyone in the room was dancing.

title: JENNIFER L. MASLOW AND F. C. MORGAN, TEACHERS IN LAKE PLACID, PLAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lynne Maslow to Frederick Converse Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Morgan 2d of Mill Neck, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: GREAT ADVENTURE JUROR ABSOLVES TOWNSHIP IN FIRE
description: A juror in the Great Adventure fire trial says he and at least two other jurors disagree with the jury foreman's statement that Jackson Township officials are to blame in the fatal blaze.

title: ENTER SUCCESS, FOLLOWED BY PROBLEMS
description: In one section of her autobiography, the literary agent Audrey Wood recounts the triumphs of Tennessee Williams, from ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' through ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' She entitles the chapter ''The Catastrophe of Success.'' The phrase is hardly flippant, for Williams met head-on the consequences of achievement - self-doubt and heightened expectations, sudden wealth and celebrity status - and his collision with fame, like so much else in his life, was a study in excess.

title: Survey of Police Chiefs Finds Gains and Flaws
description: The nation's police chiefs are better educated than they were a decade ago, but many remain underqualified and inattentive to the political tasks required of them, says a study made public today.

title: STORY-TELLING BY PHOTO
description: ALTHOUGH many photographers may be unaware of it, what they essentially do with their cameras is take one continuing picture story. When photographs accumulated over several months or years - not to say a lifetime - are reviewed, they add up to a natural tale of people and events, a chronicle representing the photographer's visual autobiography.

title: PAYING THE PRICE
description: THERE'S A MEN'S shop on Fifth Avenue that won't let you in unless you have an appointment. It employs a doorman to keep people out. The newspaper in which I read about this shop said it is famous for its stupendously high prices.

title: PLANNING FOR WEEKEND GUESTS
description: WHEN house guests come for the weekend, a host or hostess often spends an alarming amount of time in the kitchen. A little extra organization beforehand, however, can do much to alleviate the sense that one is improvising meals one after the other with no discernible interval.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE ''toughest cases'' that Mary-Ann Thompson, an attorney, takes on are old houses. A resident of Vincentown, in Burlington County, she has made a pastime of rescuing ''desperate'' buildings, those that are about to be destroyed and, with them, their history.

title: Reagan Seals A China Deal
description: It may have been a ''tortuous road,'' as Li Xiannian, the Chinese President, described the last two centuries of relations with the United States, but there was fresh evidence last week that the two nations had rounded a cooperative bend. President Reagan welcomed the Chinese leader to Washington by signing a pact that clears the way for Peking to buy American reactors and other nuclear technology.

title: Herbert Askwith, Publisher And Consultant, Dies at 100
description: Herbert Askwith, a public-relations consultant, writer r and former publishing executive, died Thursday at New Rochelle Hospital after a brief illness. He was 100 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: On the Sidelines
description: In politics, as in football, there's a time to run and a time to pass. After weeks of soul-searching, during which time he became the state's leading news story, Vince Dooley, the popular University of Georgia football coach and athletic director, decided not to make a bid for the United States Senate.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To The Editor: I was fascinated by the Practical Traveler article by Irvin Molotsky in your June 16 issue for two reasons: my own wallet was stolen in Paris this spring and the technique used on Mr. Molotsky is identical to that one depicted in a film that was playing this spring in Paris, ''Le The au Harem d'Archimede,'' which was widely praised and the subject of a full-page laudatory article in Le Monde (May 2, 1985).

title: AMERICANIZING CANADIAN RETAILERS
description: EARLIER this year, the Hudson's Bay Company, which owns two Canadian department store chains, Simpsons and The Bay, sold its corporate jet, thinned out its management ranks and moved its remaining senior executives from the expensive Bay Building to the Simpsons Tower to save on rent. Later this summer, these executives will leave their roomy quarters on the Tower's top floor to sixth-floor space that is smaller and cheaper.

title: G.M. PACT SEEKS HIGH DEGREE OF COOPERATION
description: The agreement between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation for the manufacture of the company's new Saturn car calls for a level of cooperation between management and labor that has few precedents in American heavy industry.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week:

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Video a Go Go MusicVision 25 minutes. $19.95 ''Video a Go Go'' smoothly segues six recent hits into a frothy, low-budget video dance party.

title: REAGAN URGES 'ENTERPRISE ZONES'
description: President Reagan said today that his policies were helping black people escape poverty and charged that Congress was hindering his efforts by refusing to establish zones in poor neighborhoods in which businesses would be offered incentives to create jobs.

title: THERESA MARIE CARROLL WED
description: Theresa Marie Carroll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Carroll of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Anthony Joseph Reda, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony F. Reda of Granite Springs, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Martin performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Her father is president of the G.T.E. Investment Management Corporation in Stamford, Conn. His father is an engineer for the Nestle Corporation in White Plains.

title: The Muppie-izing of America
description: Yuppies are nearly muppies. Their exchange of the ''y'' for the ''m'' also promises major changes for America.

title: HAITI'S PRESIDENT FOR LIFE IS TAKING NO CHANCES
description: All through the day, battered buses and fancifully painted pickup trucks with canopies and plank seats pulled up at the gleaming whitewashed city hall, delivering voters. Uniformed men with rifles and submachine guns guided them into the building, four and five abreast, packed close together.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To the Editor: Let's talk about the toothpaste caper as it is practiced at 1:30 in the afternoon on the Gran Via in Madrid.

title: REVOSOTOMG AMCOEMT TRIER
description: I know now what I really travel for: architecture and food. I like to go to places where I am certain of finding both of these, but sometimes I like a detour or two. A few months ago, for the first time in almost 30 years, I went back to Trier.

title: ROBERT PLANT FINDS A NEW STYLE AFTER LED ZEPPELIN
description: Robert Plant breaks away from Led Zeppelin once and for all on his third album, ''Shaken 'n' Stirred.'' That's not an easy move. Along with Jimmy Page's guitar, Mr. Plant's voice was a focal point of Led Zeppelin's songs, immediately recognizable in the way Mr. Plant wrenched words around the guitar lines. Beyond that, it must be tough to turn away from music that attracted one of rock's largest and most loyal audiences - as could be seen when a reunion of Led Zeppelin's surviving members galvanized the audience at Philadelphia's Live Aid concert.

title: RAISING SECURITY CONSCIOUSNESS
description: THERE are still a few red marks on my posterior left from a chance encounter with some flying particles of rock salt in my youth. These were added to my collection of childhood scars as a couple of fellow mischief makers and I were busy scaling the exterior of some four- and five-story factory buildings. Our objective was the flat, skylit roof of a bread factory, from which one could watch neatly wrapped baked goods trundling along a line of moving belts toward the waiting packing boxes.

title: WILLIAM T. COSTELLO WEDS LYNN CHRISTINE MCGEEHAN
description: The marriage of Lynn Christine McGeehan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John D. McGeehan of Chatham, N.J., to William Thomas Costello, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Costello of Milton, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert Hoffmann, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Joseph in Stirling, N.J.

title: IN DARIEN, WOMAN SAVES 'MUSIC MAN'
description: IN the opening number of ''The Music Man'' - The Traveling Salesmen's rapid-fire ''Rock Island'' - everything seems to be popping at The Darien Dinner Theater. The beat is there, and one instantly wants to sing and chug-a-lug-along.

title:
GARDENING;

PROBLEMS CAUSED BY THE HEAT
description: THE hot but often humid weather of summer can play havoc with the garden.

title: MOCK TRAIN ROBBERY ON DELAWARE AND ULSTER
description: A chance to witness a mock train robbery is being offered by the Delaware and Ulster Rail Ride today on trains that leave the Arkville Station at 12:30 P.M. each day.

title: JERSEY CORN: TALL (AND DEAR)
description: ''BEST corn you'll ever have,''

title: ALONG AN EAST EUROPEAN BORDER
description: This is a cautionary tale for travelers - an experience of delay and frustration at the border of Rumania, a Soviet bloc country, in the spring of this year. Both times we crossed the border, once entering Rumania by car and once leaving, at different points, we were delayed for nearly two hours, far longer than many other cars.

title: FROM PATE TO HOT DOGS, TOURISM RISES
description: Just down the street from the White House, President Reagan is posing for a photograph with a troop of Boy Scouts from Yarmouth, Mass. Turn the corner, and he is narrowly avoiding a tourist's clenched fist. All told, seven life-size cardboard cutouts of Mr. Reagan have popped up around town, and tourists are invited to pose with them for $5 a photograph (''Use own camera, $2'').

title: BIG BUILDERS LEARN TO THINK SMALL
description: A FEW miles from its futuristic headquarters in Irvine, Calif., the Fluor Corporation is building an $18 million sewage treatment plant for a planned community near Mission Viejo.

title: BERMUDA
description: With temperatures in the 80's, Bermuda's beaches, streets, night spots and hotels abound with visitors displaying the symptoms of time spent in the height of summer: wide grins of unaccustomed relaxation and limbs ranging in color from lobster red to chestnut brown. Despite the almost constant presence of a cooling sea breeze at this time of year, the sun is very strong and gradual exposure is the only way to avoid a painful initiation to the charms of this small and restful island. How to Get There Bermuda is some 600 miles off the Carolina coast, or less than two hours' flying time from most major East Coast cities. Eastern, Pan American and American Airlines fly from New York to Bermuda seven days a week. A round-trip ticket for a trip of 2 to 45 days costs $314 during the week. Weekend travel costs $340.

title: THE ANECDOTE PALS
description: Edward W. Bradley, chairman of the New Jersey Governor's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, has concluded that he and President Reagan are on the same wavelength when it comes to anecdotes. Mr. Bradley, it may be recalled, is the man President Reagan telephoned some weeks ago to apologize for stealing a story about the man who kept missing a golf ball next to an anthill, with one of the ants suggesting that to survive it was necessary to get on the ball.

title: CLIMATE SHIFT LAID TO CORE OF EARTH
description: A team of French scientists has suggested that some climate changes may originate in the earth's core.

title: SUSAN MOORE MARRIED TO GREGORY H. FARLEY
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Susan Cunnyham Moore, the daughter of Mrs. James M. Quinn Jr. of Sarasota, Fla., and Charles H. Moore of Greenwich, was married to Gregory Hunt Farley, a son of Mrs. Robert Healy of Garden City, L.I., and Joseph H. Farley of Greenport, L.I. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: FIELD FOR DEMOCRATIC CHIEF NARROWS TO 2 AS YONKERS LEADER DECLINES TO ENTER
description: THE contest to replace Thomas F. Carty as leader of the Democratic Party in Westchester became more sharply focused last week when Ralph Arred, the Yonkers Democratic leader, decided after weeks of ''testing the waters'' that he would not enter the race.

title: Nicaraguan Rebel Aide Says He'll Abandon Armed Efforts
description: A leading official of a Nicaraguan rebel group said today that he was abandoning armed efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: SPENDING FREEZE GAINING IN HOUSE DESPITE DEADLOCK
description: An impasse in Congress over the budget has caused great uncertainty about how much money the Federal Government will spend next year. Nevertheless, the usual legislation to establish or renew programs and to appropriate money is moving forward on Capitol Hill.

title: SAN FRANCISCO TRIES TO TAME THE SKYSCRAPER
description: There is no city in America in which the skyscraper is more disliked than here.

title: C. S. WELLES WED TO MISS WHITNEY
description: Catherine Shipman Whitney, a daughter of Jane Robinson Whitney of West Hartford, Conn., and Howard Frederick Whitney of Salem, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher Scott Welles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Keith Welles of Bowling Green, Ohio. The Rev. James Crowder performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Farmington, Conn.

title: CHANEL TODAY
description: THE VIEW from Kitty D'Alessio's 44th-floor office is the entirety of northern Manhattan, but her eyes are elsewhere, studying the neutral-hued carpet where ranks of manila folders lie, all pressing matters for the president of Chanel Inc. Chanel's first New York boutique will open next spring at 5 East 57th Street. Coco, Chanel's new fragrance, will be introduced to New York on Sept. 23 at a special dinner and couture show following the season's opening of the Metropolitan Opera. On Miss D'Alessio's desk are more things to attend to: a videotape from Richard Avedon, who is planning the Coco television commercial he will shoot this fall, and a black Chanel press kit signed with a glittery gold marker pen, ''To Kitty from Karl,'' containing the day's communications from Chanel's Paris-based designer, Karl Lagerfeld. Miss D'Alessio's time is short. There is much to be done. She is flying to Palm Beach for an overnight stay to scout sites for a boutique, returning to New York, then taking the Concorde to Paris the following day for the first of several consultations with Mr. Lagerfeld before his couture collection is presented.

title: It's Time for an Israeli-Arab Change of Tone;   First Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR ACTORS, THE 'SOAPS' ARE SERIOUS BUSINESS
description: Smiling his infectious smile, handsome Dr. Chris Chapin leans across the book trolley, his gifted fingers running along the spine of a Reader's Digest condensed novel.

title: KAREN L. CORNELIUS, A LAWYER, PLANS TO MARRY A SECURITIES ANALYST SEPT. 8
description: Karen L. Cornelius, a June graduate of the University of Chicago Law School, and Carl B. Schecter, a securities analyst and vice president at Andco Securities in New York, plan to be married Sept. 8.

title: THE FARMER IS BEING STRANGLED
description: THAT which initially appears as a benefit may, in the long run, work more harm than good. So it is with New Jersey's farmland assessment.

title: A SCARLATTI BIRTHDAY BASH
description: ''The music ranges from the courtly to the savage, from a well-nigh saccha-rine urbanity to an acrid violence. There is hardly an aspect of Spanish life, or Spanish popular music and dance, that has not found itself a place in the microcosm that Scarlatti created with his sonatas.''

title: The Solution For East End Traffic
description: The solution to the traffic problem described on June 30 [''Drivers Jamming Back Roads in Hamptons''] is simple. It is staring us all in the face: Don't do anything!

title: A NEW MAGAZINE
description: Washington has a new magazine, Museum: Washington. The newsstand price is $1.95, but you can probably get one free if you arrive on the right airline or stay at the right hotel.

title: ANDREW ZELMAN WED TO ELLEN N. HASTINGS
description: Ellen N. Hastings, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Hastings 2d of Fryeburg, Me., was married July 13 to Andrew Zelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Zelman of Hiram, Me., and Boynton Beach, Fla., and formerly of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Richard W. Beebe performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Fryeburg.

title: 7 ARTISTS IN A 'BRIGHT' MT. VERNON SHOW
description: ''FREE EXPRESSIONS,'' the title of the show now at Mount Vernon's Center for the Arts, implies that there is still an academy to be flouted, that there are still rules of art to be broken. Were this so, the artist's lot would be much easier (the reviewer's, too).

title: CELEBRATING STATE'S FOUNDING
description: IT is birthday time in Connecticut, with upcoming concerts marking the 350th anniversaries of Saybrook and Connecticut Colonies, the 300th for the City of Danbury, and continuing tributes to the tricentennial trio of Bach, Handel and Scarlatti.

title: CONVERSION OF A RENTAL DEVELOPER
description: WHEN the State Legislature adjourned late last month without resolving the issues surrounding rent increases to cover major building improvements, Herman I. Kraus, one of the few developers of moderately priced rental housing in the city, decided to go into the condominium conversion business. ''Rental housing is tomorrow's dinosaur,'' he said.

title: SEGREGATED RECREATION
description: TENNIS, foreign films, alpine skiing and classical music do not constitute a terribly strange set of interests for a young, energetic American woman. However, as a young, energetic, black American woman who enjoys all of these leisure activities, I constantly face disbelievers who regard me with shock or suspicion whenever I discuss my favorite pastimes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN. By Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $17.95.) The murder victim, an eminent New York psychiatrist named Simon Ellerbee, is a ''saint'' - at least to his patients and fellow analysts.

title: ELIZABETH KIM, LAW STUDENT, WEDS BRIAN A. MANNION, MEDICAL STUDENT
description: Elizabeth Mi Li Campbell Kim, a second-year law student at Fordham University, and Brian Alfred Mannion, a second-year medical student at New York University, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Terence German performed the ceremony.

title: Rescuers Search for Missing After Japan Landslide Kills 5
description: Rescue workers searched through tons of earth and rubble today for 21 people from a home for the aged who were believed buried by a landslide in which at least five other people died in a town north of Tokyo, the police said.

title: E.P.A. ORDERED TO SEEK CURBS ON ACID RAIN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been ordered by a Federal judge to require seven Middle West and border states to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide and other pollutants said to cause acid precipitation in the Northeast and Canada.

title: HOLLY MACAULAY WED IN VIRGINIA
description: Holly Helene Macaulay, the daughter of Comdr. Angus Macaulay, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Macaulay of Charlottesville, Va., and Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to Edward John Casey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Casey of Milford, Conn.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

IN THE DAYS OF THE SILVER LADY
description: Social historians say that to understand a culture we must look closely at its relation to its artifacts. In AUTOMANIA: Man and the Motor Car (Little, Brown, $19.95), Julian Pettifer, a British broadcast journalist, and Nigel Turner, a British film producer, write that ''the car is arguably the most powerful instrument of social change'' and ''has reshaped society in its image.''

title: MORE FAMILIES ADOPTING DISABLED CHILDREN
description: THREE years ago, after Roger and Nancy Kleinberg of this Ocean County community adopted a 20-month-old blind, hydrocephalic girl, they decided to join a support group for adoptive parents. However, they soon found that they had little in common with the other members, almost all of whom had adopted healthy children.

title: BIRDIE AFRICA
description: AFTER the bomb had been dropped on the roof and as the fire roared out of control in West Philadelphia, the badly burned boy escaped from the building at 6221 Osage Avenue, used as headquarters by the Move group. Because the boy was so small and malnourished, the police gave his age as 9; in fact, he was 13. He was admitted to Children's Hospital with burns covering his arms and legs.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Toombs Development Company of New Canaan, Conn., is expected to break ground next month for a controversial mixed-use project. Called Princeton Forrestal Village, it will be situated across U.S. 1 from the Princeton Forrestal Center in Plainsboro.

title: CITY SEEKS SOURCE OF TAINTED WATER
description: Officials are trying to narrow down where in New York City's vast reservoir and pipeline system elevated levels of plutonium originated.

title: Making Their Way
description: In Washington, it's clear that the Administration's efforts to control illegal immigration have failed, but here in California the failure is in many ways a success.

title: Teamster Chief In the Clear
description: In his nearly two decades in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Jackie Presser, the union's president since 1983, has always been known as someone who did the things he said he would. One of them is to avoid being indicted.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To the Editor: We found the vicoli (alleyways) of Florence and Rome to be as nice as those described in Louis Inturrisi's article ''Narrow Slices of Italy's Past'' (Travel, March 10).

title:
GARDENING;

PROBLEMS CAUSED BY THE HEAT
description: THE hot but often humid weather of summer can play havoc with the garden.

title: LUCIE GUERNSEY TO WED IN FALL
description: The engagement of Lucie Love Guernsey to Lewis Charles Kleinhans 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Guernsey of Litchfield, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Melvin B. Twitty of North Palm Beach, Fla., and Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Kleinhans Jr.

title: WIRE ROPE
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH DEVOTES DAY TO POLITICS
description: Politics, not plutonium, was dominant yesterday as Mayor Koch campaigned in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: TAX PLAN SEEN AS THREAT TO L.I. REAL ESTATE
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposed tax plan, if approved in its present form, would have a severe effect on Long Island real estate, according to industry and political leaders.

title: THERE'S NOTHING DATED ABOUT THE BARD'S VIEW OF CHASTITY
description: The notion of chastity has a quaint ring to it. It seems to belong to a distant time, along with maiden aunts and antimacassars. That may be one reason why Joseph Papp chose to play for laughs the ''Measure for Measure,'' that opened Shakespeare in the Park this season (the production closed last Sunday). How, after all, could he expect a young audience, bred on sexual permissiveness and the pill, to take seriously a heroine's efforts to defend her virginity from the vile intentions of a powerful male? Done straight, it might have struck them as Victorian melodrama. Yet the characters and issues in ''Measure for Measure'' are no more dated than the Moral Majority.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PET BUSINESS;

ACCESSORIES: HAVEN FOR SMALL BUSINESS
description: A QUICK look at the array of pet products on a typical supermarket shelf would indicate that only a few players rule the industry. Dog and cat food from Ralston Purina, Carnation, Heinz and Quaker Oats; toys, treats, rawhide bones and other accessories from the Hartz Mountain Corporation; maybe some Sergeant's (A.H. Robins) flea collars. But looks can be deceiving. In fact, hundreds of small companies make everything from cuttle bones to carpet deodorant, to be sold in pet stores, grooming parlors and hobby shops. None of them come close to attaining the sales figures of the mass-merchandise suppliers, but they are rich in entrepreneurial spirit.

title: TWILIGHT BASEBALL: A TRADITION LIVES ON
description: IN popularity, it is fighting a losing battle to slow-pitch softball, the game in which everyone is a hitter and hardly anyone ever strikes out.

title: SCHOOL RULING BY HIGH COURT PUZZLES MANY
description: WITH a little more than a month left before school begins, education officials in the state are grappling with a recent Supreme Court ruling that prohibits public school teachers from conducting remedial programs in parochial schools, a service that has been given for the past 20 years.

title: PROFITS OF BOOK ON KILLER AWARDED TO SURVIVORS
description: A New Jersey judge has ordered the writer and the publisher of a book about a convicted murderer to turn over any profits from the book for distribution among the victims' survivors and attorneys.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THEOLOGIANS UNDER HITLER: Gerhard Kittel, Paul Althaus and Emanuel Hirsch. By Robert P. Ericksen. (Yale University, $20.) Among the scandals of Germany during the Hitler period was the failure of the German Protestant churches to mobilize opposition to Nazism.

title: REPORT ON A REVOLUTION
description: NICARAGUA Revolution in the Family. By Shirley Christian. 337 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. On that tableland scored by rivers, Our thoughts have bodies; the menacing shapes of our fever Are precise and alive, Auden wrote of Spain in 1937. And so: To-day the deliberate increase in the chances of death, The conscious acceptance of guilt in the necessary murder; To-day the expending of powers On the flat ephemeral pamphlet and the boring meeting.

title: BIG CITICORP PLAN
description: Citicorp is considering the construction of an executive office building with one million square feet in Long Island City, Queens, the bank confirmed last week.

title:
ANTIQUES;

COOKING THE 18TH-CENTURY WAY
description: IF you want to prepare fine apple fritters, advised Hannah Glasse to readers of her cookbook, ''The Art of Cookery Made Plain and Easy,'' ''your apples must be Golden Pippins pared and chopped with a knife.''

title: STARTING OVER IN MINDANAO
description: HE crouches a bit, gropes into the green leafy foliage and plucks an oblong-shaped woody fruit with rumpled reddish-orange skin - a cocoa pod. ''This,'' says Carlos Villa-Abrille, gesturing toward the dense thicket of 10-foot-high cocoa bushes around him ''is the future.''

title: CASTRO, MARKING REVOLUTION, TALKS OF DEBTS
description: In a strikingly mild address here tonight marking the 32d anniversary of the beginning of the Cuban revolution, Fidel Castro focused on the Latin American debt crisis and domestic affairs. He referred only obliquely to his old enemy, the United States, and never mentioned it by name.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GODFIRES. By William Hoffman. (Viking, $16.95.) In Howell County, Va., the local sheriff is still busting hippies, the Ministerial Alliance keeps track of who visits the liquor store, and racial conflict persists.

title: EX-ATHLETE'S NEW FIELD: TICKET SALES
description: ''NOW,'' said Brian Appel of West Hempstead, ''the public can truly get the best available seat without coming to the box office.''

title: CHINESE BOTH SWEET AND SOUR
description: SWEET is the name of a Chinese restaurant that opened this year in Port Washington.

title: FOR A WELSH TOWN IN DECLINE, LONDON SEEMS A WORLD AWAY
description: Not too many years ago, Japanese businessmen were a regular sight on the streets of this tough seaside town in South Wales.

title: THE HARD SEARCH FOR PROPERTY INSURANCE
description: RECENT news reports have described the drastic rate increases inflicted upon businesses seeking property and casualty insurance, but little has been said about the prospects for individual drivers, homeowners and renters. Unfortunately, the huge losses that insurers have suffered recently are putting rate pressure on the so-called personal lines as well as on commercial insurance. Although the increases have been far less dramatic, personal premiums are continuing their steady climb, with auto rates leading the upward trend. Industry spokesmen also warn that insurance will be harder to get for ''bad risks,'' including those people with poor driving records, for example, or whose homes are far from fire stations.

title: Music
description: A little over 60 years ago - on Feb. 12, 1924, to be exact - the band leader Paul Whiteman presented a program he called ''An Experiment in Modern Music'' at the now-defunct Aeolian Hall on West 43d Street. Whiteman's purpose in putting together the concert was to ''legitimize'' jazz, which at that time was considered an exotic and even rather scandalous entertainment.

title: A CENTENNIAL PUTS THE SPOTLIGHT ON ALBAN BERG'S ART
description: Not surprisingly, Handel and Bach have received a good deal more attention from the record companies in their tricentennial year than Alban Berg has in his centennial. Perhaps being three times older, they deserve three times more attention in our past-obsessed musical culture. But Berg was a great composer, too, and he speaks to our modern sensibility in a way that the Baroque masters never can.

title: U.S. DELEGATE PROTESTS CONFERENCE ON WOMEN
description: Maureen Reagan, the head of the American delegation to the United Nations Decade for Women conference, said today that the United States should reconsider participating in such sessions.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CLAMOR AT THE GATES: The New American Immigration. Edited by Nathan Glazer. (ICS Press, Suite 750, 785 Market St., San Francisco, Calif. 94103, Cloth, $25.95.

title: COLLEGE ACQUIRES RARE PHOTOS
description: IN the back of a stately old house surrounded by the well-kept lawn of Wesleyan University in Middletown, the Davison Art Center has been amassing one of the state's leading collections of historical and fine-art photography. The recent addition of rare, vintage photographs by Eugene Atget underscores the center's commitment to the field.

title: ARTS GROUPS GET $7 MILLION IN GRANTS
description: At its annual meeting here last week, the State Council on the Arts announced the awarding of $7,711,280 in grants for fiscal 1986.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: WHEN THE TIDE IS LOW. By Sheila Cole. Illustrated by Virginia Wright-Frierson. Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $11.75. (Ages 4 to 8) A little girl wants to go to the beach and her mother says they will when the tide is low.

title: AN EX-COMMUTER 'ARRIVES'
description: I WAS lucky. I found an empty seat next to the man cradling a birthday gift. Our fatigued brigade of commuters waited in the steamy car. Doors closed. Then opened. A familiar announcement: ''Attention all passengers. The Metro-North 7:20 train will be 30 minutes late.'' My seat companion sighed, ''It' my son's 11th birthday. Tonight's the first time I've left early in months.''

title: ADAM C. BARKER IS TO BE MARRIED TO MISS MARSDEN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eric Charles Marsden of Blandford, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mary Marsden, to Adam Campbell Barker, an associate with the New York law firm of Webster & Sheffield. He is the son of Baroness Trumpington and W. Alan Barker of Sandwich, England.

title: POTTERSVILLE IS READY FOR ITS BIG EVENT
description: THIS affluent Somerset County community of about 600 has nothing out of the ordinary to encourage public attention.

title: UNAFFILIATED, INTENSE AND STIMULATING l>By Phyllis Braff
description: WHEN curators spend considerable time evaluating the work of potential candidates for a major exhibition, the results usually warrant serious attention from those interested in today's more vital art forms.

title: TRACY BALL ENGAGED TO WILLIAM R. GREER
description: Announcement has been made by Margaret Logan of Boston and George M. Ball of Charlotte, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Tracy Jean Ball, to William Robson Greer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander P. Greer of Spokane, Wash. A January wedding is planned.

title: THE LAST OF THE BIG-TIME POLYMATHS
description: EDMUND WILSON By David Castronovo. 205 pp. New York: Frederick Ungar. $15.50.

title: BOSTON SCHOOL OFFICIAL ASSAILED FOR REMARKS
description: A member of the School Committee has apologized for comments he made last week about a Hispanic candidate for the school superintendency, whom he said was ''very articulate and not the traditional Hispanic.''

title: LIKE THE WORLD SERIES ON WHEELS
description: BREAKAWAY On the Road With the Tour de France. By Samuel Abt. Illustrated. 178 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: WEST VIRGINIANS' GOAL: CUT FUMES BUT SAVE JOBS
description: While the air is still unmistakably tainted with the pungent emissions of 20 or so chemical plants, a fresh breeze may be blowing through the Kanawha Valley of West Virginia.

title: WHERE I OUGHT TO BE: A WRITER'S SENSE OF PLACE
description: IN a tribal view of the world, where one place has been inhabited for generations, the landscape becomes enlivened by a sense of group and family history. Unlike most contemporary writers, a traditional storyteller fixes listeners in an unchanging landscape combined of myth and reality. People and place are inseparable. The Tewa Pueblo, for example, begin their story underground, in complete darkness. When a mole comes to visit, they learn there is another world above and decide to go there. In this new place the light is so intense that they put their hands over their eyes to shield them. Grandmother Spider suggests that they adjust their vision to the light by gradually removing their hands and she points them to Sandia Mountain, the place where they will live. A great deal of wandering, bickering, lessons learned and even bloodshed occur, but once there, they stay for good.

title: WRONG TUNES
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVELOPING STAMFORD'S 'LAST TARGET'
description: A POPULAR gathering place for many of Stamford's young professionals is a new restaurant called The Rusty Scupper. It is situated on the east side of the harbor, overlooking Long Island Sound and a bobbing jungle of yachts and sailboats anchored in a marina.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PET BUSINESS;

WANT A PUPPY? CHECK THE CLASSIFIEDS
description: DOGS and cats are far and away America's most popular pets. Yet many pet shops refuse to carry them. A survey of pet stores by Pets Supplies Marketing showed that only about 32 percent sold cats and a mere 28 percent carried dogs. Contrast that to reptiles and amphibians (40 percent), or fish and birds (83 and 71 percent). Industry experts, in fact, say pet stores sell less than 10 percent of the millions of dogs and cats that change hands every year.

title:
ART;

STEICHEN AS A PAINTER: A RARE GIFT
description: SOME time between 1920 and 1923, when Edward Steichen decided to end his career as a painter and devote his creative energies exclusively to photography, he burned the canvases in his studio in France. On returning to New York, he shredded his remaining work and threw it in the garbage.

title: RUMSON
description: WHEN Bruce Springsteen moved into one of Rumson's most distinctive estates last year, few residents were fazed by the rock star's presence. That may be because many of the 8,000 residents of this wealthy Jersey Shore community exude a little of the star-quality themselves.

title: Koch Eases Up On Vendors
description: Mayor Koch reversed himself last week and decided to make more room at the table for the vendors who sell food from carts on the sidewalks. He vetoed a bill he had asked the City Council to pass that would have banned food vending on more than 300 blocks of Manhattan, then immediately proposed a measure that would cover only 217 blocks. ''There's nothing wrong in acknowledging something you've done has errors in it,'' said Mr. Koch.

title: PEELING A CENTURY FROM A HISTORIC COACH
description: THE scene in the Stony Brook barn combines the excitement of an archeological dig and the technology of a science-fiction epic. Three space-age women, clad in shorts, with respirators over their faces, are returning to its original condition a large 19th-century coach, called an omnibus, which was named for the young Victorian heroine of a daring sea rescue.

title: ALEXANDRA BIRD WED TO JOHN REID JR. ON L.I.
description: Alexandra Mann, a daughter of William H. Mann of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Mercedes Spradling Mann, was married yesterday to John Reid Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid of Princeton, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I. Msgr. Christopher Huntington performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Southampton home of the bride's father.

title: MISS TREGURTHA ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Tregurtha of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Ann Tregurtha to Thomas Stothart Croskey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Croskey of Cincinnati. A Sept. 14 wedding is planned.

title: DAVID ZORENSKY WEDS HELEN DECAMP HOBART
description: Helen DeCamp Hobart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Hobart Jr., of Troy, Ohio, was married yesterday to David Franklin Zorensky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Isaac Zorensky of St. Louis. The Rev. Pierce Klemmt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: MORE INNOCENCE
description: To the Editor: We read with great interest and heartache the article ''Innocence Abroad No More.''

title: SOVIET FOUND AHEAD IN ARMS
description: A new appraisal of the military balance between the superpowers says the United States still lags behind the Soviet Union after having spent $1 trillion since President Reagan took office in 1981.

title: FALL WEDDING SET BY RUTH COBRINK
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Cobrinik of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Cobrinik, to Peter Schuyler Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Williams of Short Hills, N.J., and Bridgehampton, L.I. An October wedding is planned. The future bride, an associate in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, graduated summa cum laude from Hunter College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a J.D. degree from the Columbia University Law School, where she was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar.

title: 'PALE' REMAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSAN R. HILL MARRIED TO DAVID SQUIRE CODY
description: The wedding of Susan Robertson Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Donald Hill of Irvington and Pilot Knob, N.Y., to David Squire Cody, the son of Coleman Ferrell Cody of Needham and Cataumet, Mass., and the late Barbara Baldwin Cody, took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Irvington. The Rev. David H. Foubert performed the ceremony.

title: RESIDENTS WARNED ABOUT HURRICANES
description: ALMOST 90 percent of the people living in flood-hazard areas along Connecticut's coast have moved there since the last major hurricane hit 30 years ago, according to a recent survey done by the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: UNDER SIEGE IN THE GERMAN IVORY TOWER
description: PHILOSOPHICAL APPRENTICESHIPS By Hans-Georg Gadamer. Translated by Robert R. Sullivan. Illustrated. 198 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $17.50.

title: SUSAN HOLAK IS BRIDE OF WILLIAM HAVLENA JR.
description: Susan Leah Holak, an assistant professor of marketing at the University of Texas at Dallas, and William Joseph Havlena Jr., an assistant professor of marketing at Southern Methodist University, were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. William Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: ELIZABETH ARNDT ENGAGED
description: Elizabeth Tacy Arndt and Allan J. Gray plan to be married Sept. 7, her parents, Mrs. W. Page Wodell of Lyme, Conn., and Willis C. Arndt of West Hartford, Conn., have announced. Mr. Gray is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Gray of Corning, N.Y.

title: OPEC CUTS PRICES AT SAUDIS' URGING
description: OPEC agreed to small price cuts on its medium and heavy grades of crude oil. But Iran, Algeria and Libya, OPEC's more radical members, say they will not go along. The price cuts, although mostly symbolic, marked a victory for Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister. Saudi Arabia wants to produce more, but fears a glut. It had wanted even bigger price cuts, but won out over strong opposition to any cuts at all.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer entry error, the best seller list for hardcover nonfiction on page 26 of The Times Book Review today incorrectly includes one title, shown as No. 8.

title: The Fire This Time
description: What is happening in South Af-rica has to be understood as something more than another turn in the cycle of protest and repression. The illegitimacy of a political system has finally caught up with it. There can be no return to normalcy in Pretoria's sense, meaning government by and for the white minority. The crisis can be resolved only by the establishment of a new legitimacy.

title: A TEX-MEX FEAST
description: TO BE BLUNT ABOUT IT, certain recipes are far more memorable than others.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in the Sports section last Sunday accompanying several pictures of the San Francisco 49ers misidentified one of the players. The player wearing No. 33 was Roger Craig, not Wendell Tyler.

title:
INVESTING;

USING INTUITION TO UNCOVER STOCK VALUES
description: INFERENTIAL FOCUS does not provide the number-crunching securities analysis that is so popular on Wall Street these days. The New York-based financial think tank strives for what it calls nontraditional ''right-brain,'' or intuitive, research. The company's four principals read almost 200 trade journals, and draw inferences about changing business trends and life styles. The object: to be the first to spot such trends and to link them to business activity and opportunities for investors and business executives.

title: ON PLAYWRITING, FILM STEREOTYPES AND MOZART
description: To the Editor: In her article ''Writing Plays Is an Act of Faith'' [June 23] , Marsha Norman says that the playwright is ''the primary life force, the constantly beating heart of the theater,'' and I agree. Yet, the implication of her piece is that by theater she means New York's commercial theater. The most prominent arena for theater is indeed quivering near death, suffering from a terminal dependency on money. Her saying that she will quit writing plays if she can't earn a living from them will only serve to firm up the sick correlation between money and art, success and quality.

title: RUSSIA WANTS A BABY BOOM OF ITS OWN
description: Turgun Abdurakhmanov was an only child, a fact that brought a measure of sorrow and even shame to his family, he says. So when he married, his mother enjoined him to ''be fruitful and multiply.'' Mr. Abdurakhmanov told the story under a spreading plane tree in the spacious courtyard of his traditional Uzbek house as he picked at succulent lamb pilaf in the traditional way, with four fingers of his right hand. His wife, Muborak, a plump and shy woman of 46 with halting Russian, repeatedly added small splashes of green tea to the cups of visitors - a mark of hospitality, since filling them to the brim would imply ''drink up and be gone.''

title: MILAY
description: To the Editor: Emilie Harting's engaging description of the Whitehall Inn (Travel, May 19) makes one want to reach for a suitcase and rush for the next plane, train or bus to Camden, Me. My pleasure in the article did not waver until I came to the paragraph about Edna St. Vincent Millay's plans for visiting New York City.

title: PENNSYLVANIA HONORS STUDENT IS ACQUITTED OF RAPE CHARGE
description: A judge in Common Pleas Court has found a University of Pennsylvania honors student not guilty of rape charges brought by an 18-year-old woman from Rosemont College.

title: MAYA OHL BRIDE OF NAVAL OFFICER
description: Maya Ohl and Lieut. (j.g.) Kevin Boreen, U.S.N., were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Chester, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Walter Reid performed the ceremony.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THE INCURABLE PUNSTER
description: MY wife and I seldom get invited to parties anymore, and the number of people whom I can call friends seems to be dwindling steadily. In October, while others are tailgating at the Yale Bowl, I am standing in my backyard, gazing wistfully at falling leaves and thinking I could work for a tree-trimming company - as a branch manager. If I did a good job, I could take a bough.

title: The Unlearned Lesson of the Atomic Age
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A CERTAIN TENDENCY OF THE HOLLYWOOD CINEMA, 1930-1980. By Robert B. Ray. (Princeton University, Cloth, $45. Paper, $14.50.) Robert B. Ray, an assistant professor of English at the University of Florida, Gainesville, demonstrates how the treatment of such recurrent conflicts as the frontier mentality versus stability, and permanence and material success versus the simple life, in popular American films between 1930 and 1980 reflects Americans' changing hopes and fears.

title: THE SOIL AND THE VINE
description: It is commonly said that the Romans brought the vine to Germany or, more precisely, to those northern European river valleys that later became part of Germany. In fact, scholars believe the vines and the wine may well have been there long before the legions; Roman winemakers probably never would have thought of planting vines in such a hostile climate if they hadn't found them there when they arrived. The Moselle vineyards, for example, lie on a parallel a bit north of Newfoundland.

title: LIBERALS, RACCOONS HAVE THEIR DAY
description: THE liberal conspiracy has gone further than I had suspected. If you think the bleeding hearts have turned the streets and subways over to the criminals, wait till you try defending yourself against a savage raccoon in your own home.

title: CHALLENGER LOSES LIBEL BOUT
description: WHEN Daniel Tilli wrote to a Pennsylvania newspaper in 1983 to complain about Larry Holmes's choice of challengers to his World Boxing Council crown, he said the council should be requiring the fighter to take on higher-ranked opponents. ''How much was the payoff to the W.B.C.?'' Mr. Tilli, of Palmer Township, asked in the letter to The Easton Express.

title: Again, Fiscal Abuse Of Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

PROBLEMS CAUSED BY THE HEAT
description: THE hot but often humid weather of summer can play havoc with the garden.

title: FISHING FOR BASS AND BUCKS
description: IT IS A SWEAT-POPPING AFTERNOON IN Clewiston, Fla., 90 degrees in the shade and the moisture in the air over Lake Okeechobee hangs on the fishermen milling in front of Roland Martin's marina, looking for their next day's fishing partners. Martin, a sun-bleached blond with high cheekbones in a tanned face and a gut beginning to push his waistline out, is nervously twisting a beer can into ragged remnants of aluminum. ''Nah, I'm not nervous,'' he says. ''Well, maybe in my own way.'' He tosses away the beer can, what's left of it, and scratches numbers on a piece of paper. Anyway he figures, he's in second place.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GOEBBELS AND GLADYS. By Keith Colquhoun. (Academy Chicago, $13.95.) Despite his name, Hedley Verity is a London newspaperman whose disdain for the truth is equaled only by his contempt for his readers.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Range of Offerings In Sound Showroom Front Row Sound in White Plains is a showroom for listening to and selecting sound equipment whether basic, install-it-yourself brand name speaker models or for contemplating more elaborate custom-designed deluxe media systems with microprocessor control. The shop has installed seven re-upholstered seats, vintage 1928, from Peekskill's Paramount Theater to enable easy listening for near and distant drummers.

title: SUMMER'S LONG LOOK
description: THE last time very short skirts were in vogue - way back in miniskirt era of the 60's - long skirts ran away and hid. Now, however, when miniskirts are making something of a comeback, long skirts are proudly strutting their stuff, too.

title: 11-YEAR-OLD TEACHES COMPUTER CLASS
description: IT is not unusual to find children learning about computers these days, but 11-year-old David Quick has gone one step farther. He is teaching.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PET BUSINESS;

THE END OF THE MOM-AND-POP STORE
description: PET owners who push their shopping carts through the carpeted aisles of The Pet Department, a 7,800-square-foot pet products store in Los Angeles, can be overwhelmed with choices. The store stocks more than 5,000 items, from avocado-based dog food to honey-coated bird treats. Uniformed employees help customers choose among a dozen types of dog dishes and 500 different leashes while music plays softly in the background. ''It's a pet supermarket,'' said Larry Miller, a former NBC television executive whose three Los Angeles Pet Department stores will take in about $3 million this year.

title: Fire at Washington Hilton
description: A fire in the boiler room of the Washington Hilton Hotel was quickly extinguished today. About 100 people were evacuated, and no one was hurt. The 3,800 guests went to other hotels.

title: RAIL STATION FOR CORPORATE PARK
description: AT 11:22 A.M. tomorrow the first stop will be made by a Metro-North train at the new Merritt 7 station in Norwalk, the only privately built railroad station in the state.

title: CHARM AND WIT MARK 'GOOD DOCTOR'
description: THE vast expanse of a Broadway theater overpowered Neil Simon's ''The Good Doctor'' when it opened in 1973. The play rattled around the stage like a dried pea in an empty beer barrel. In the small, intimate space of the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, however, the play expands with charm and wit.

title: SIMON T. RODD IS WED TO SUSAN LEIGH BROWN
description: Susan Leigh Brown, a daughter of Mrs. George Hardin Brown and the late Mr. Brown of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Simon Tobias Rodd, a son of Stella Croker of Greenwich, Conn., and Leonard Rodd of Kent, England. The Rev. Robert Miner of St. Saviour's Episcopal Church in Old Greenwich, performed the ceremony in the garden of Mrs. Brown's home.

title: MIDDLE CLASS
description: To the Editor:

title: 150 in Michigan Stricken By Salmonella Poisoning
description: Efforts to identify the source of 150 reported cases of salmonella poisoning have been hampered by a lack of food samples to test, a health official says.

title: City Gets a Soaking, But Not Its Reservoirs
description: New York City and its suburbs were soaked by about two inches of rain Friday night and Saturday morning but only about half an inch of rain fell in the city's Delaware and Catskills reservoirs, according to a city environmental official.

title:
REGULATING GOVERNMENT SECURITIES;

NEW RULES SHOULD BE COST-EFFECTIVE
description: DO we need more regulation of the Government securities market?

title: JOHN D. HARPER, 91, SERVED AS CHAIRMAN OF ALCOA UNTIL 1975
description: John D. Harper, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America, died of heart trouble here Friday. He was 75 years old.

title: LEIGH ORCESTER MARRIES A BANKER
