description: The wedding of Leigh Morton Worcester, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Worcester of Greenwich, Conn., and Benjamin Carpenter 3d, a son of Mr. Carpenter Jr. of Stonington, Conn., and Carol Carpenter of Glen Ridge, N.J., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich. The Rev. David Toomey, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony.

title: LOCALITIES SHIFT TO PRIVATE FIREFIGHTERS
description: Private fire departments, which thrived when the nation was young, are serving a growing number of communities in a move that has touched off a sharp dispute concerning efficiency and competence.

title: MOON'S JAILING MAY HAVE EASED THINGS FOR HIS FLOCK
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon has not yet finished serving his term for federal tax evasion, but he has reassumed control of his Unification Church, commuting to the headquarters in Manhattan from a halfway house in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. DENIAL OF VISAS OVER POLITICS OF FOREIGNERS: THE BATTLE IS HEATING UP
description: Twenty years ago, Pablo Neruda, one of Latin America's greatest poets, a Nobel laureate who calls himself a pacifist, was barred from the United States because he was a member of the Chilean Communist Party.

title: COUNTDOWN STARTS FOR DELAYED SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The countdown began today for a second attempt to launch the space shuttle Challenger on an ambitious seven-day mission to observe the earth, sun and stars with a battery of advanced telescopes. The liftoff is scheduled for 3:23 P.M. Monday.

title: VINTAGE 'PAGLIACCI' RETAINS ITS LUSTER
description: In 1892, midway through a career that had produced only mediocre rewards, Ruggiero Leoncavallo composed the opera ''Pagliacci'' to his own libretto. A hit at its Milan premiere the same year, the taut tale of adultery and revenge in a clever theatrical setting was quicklypicked up by the Vienna Opera, London's Covent Garden and New York's Metropolitan with success that still shows no signs of abating. In 1907, The Gramophone Company went to Milan and recorded the complete opera at La Scala, in the co-operative presence of Leoncavallo himself, although Carlo Sabaino actually wielded the baton. The only known complete copy of these landmark disks is in the hands of Yale University, where it was carefully taped for release by Pearl Records as a two-LP set (OPAL 826/7).

title: Will the G.O.P. Repay Workers?
description: Nassau Republican leaders still maintain that public employees were not forced to kick back one percent of their salaries to the party, but the organization's lawyers agreed last week to return money to workers who thought otherwise.

title: ARTWORK THAT PREMIERED IN COUNTY TRAVELS TO -- MAINE
description: THE old rhyme goes ''one potato, two potato, three potato, four . . .'' but how about 3,000 spuds or more. Put a ton of russets together in an art work, and then the inquiries come in from ''Ripley's Believe It or Not,'' and reporters from the trade publications Produce News and Spudman show up for the opening.

title: THE STAGE: 'CHEKHOV,' A MINIATURIST'S VIEW
description: AS a performance artist, Stuart Sherman is a miniaturist, specializing in cameo imagery. Unlike Robert Wilson and other grand-scale conceptualists who take a Proustian, expansive approach to time and theater, he is quick-paced, and his world can fit on a tabletop. Blink, and the ''play'' has ended. Mr. Sherman is currently in residence at the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street, with ''Chekhov,'' a sampler of pieces, live, on film and on slides.

title: MISS ADAIR IS MARRIED
description: Elizabeth Robinson Adair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arja Philip Adair of Montrose, Pa., and Bradenton, Fla., was married yesterday to Lance Barrow Davis, a son of True Davis of Washington and the late Virginia Motter Davis. The Rev. James Moon performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Chapel of the Transfiguration in Moose, Wyo., assisted by the resident Episcopal chaplain, the Rev. Lester Thrasher.

title: THE THIRD WORLD: BACK TO THE FARM
description: RISING above the splendid beaches and swarming markets in the West African capital of Lome, Togo, are a steel mill, an oil refinery, a 36-story luxury hotel, and a ceramics and brick factory. A patina of rust and disillusionment begrimes these dreams of past decades: The oil refinery is closed, the steel mill has been leased to an American, the hotel is mostly empty and the factory no longer makes ceramics.

title: A HARMONIOUS STRUGGLE
description: ONE LAST MIRROR By Andrew Harvey. 150 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My teen-age son is planning on touring Europe and would like to know how to get information on youth hostels abroad. I believe he is eligible for a student card allowing free admission to museums. Where can he get one? - A. C. D., Falmouth, Mass. Answer:By becoming a member of American Youth Hostels, the traveler is entitled to stay at youth hostels in other parts of the world as well as in the United States. A year's membership can be obtained by sending $10 (for those aged under 18 or over 59) or $20 (aged 18 to 59) and $1 for postage to American Youth Hostels, National Administrative Office, 1332 I Street NW, Suite 800, Washington, D.C. 20005. (The phone number is 202-783-6161.) Birth date should also be enclosed. The member receives a handbook giving details of the 300 or so hostels in this country, a membership card and the organization's quarterly Knapsack magazine.

title: COSTA RICA'S JUNGLE TRAIN
description: When the novelist Anthony Trollope went to Costa Rica from the West Indies in 1858, he was determined to traverse the all-but-impenetrable route from San Jose to the Atlantic. The portly Trollope, working as a postal inspector, found the going hard. ''A continued seat of five hours on a mule,'' he wrote, ''under a burning sun, is not refreshing to a man who is not accustomed to such exercise.'' It was not until 1890, when a rail line built to ship the coffee crop to the sea was completed, that a direct route was established.

title: CHEAP LAUGHS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Light. No Tunnel Either.
description: The double-deck 63d Street tunnel beneath the East River, designed for trains on its lower level and subway cars on the upper, carries neither. Long a monument to New York's over-optimism, the tunnel has become a symbol also of amazingly bad management.

title: A DIFFERENT TACK
description: In a break with tradition, low-rise multifamily housing is taking the condominium form in new construction in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

title: JAPANESE VISITORS WORK AT SHELTERS
description: BEFORE she left Kyoto, Japan, for New Haven, 23-year-old Nobana Nakagima made a promise to a grade-school child at her church. The boy had told her that all he knew about the United States was what he saw on television: pictures of the Olympics and Election Day celebrations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GHOST OF A CHANCE. By Linda Crawford. (Arbor House, $15.95.) Linda Crawford's engaging fourth novel charts an intertwined year in the lives of two women: Kate Wylie, a reluctant ghostwriter, and Beryl Swarr, an unremarkable Middle Western bank teller.

title: MALIZ FINNEGAN EXCHANGES VOWS WITH L. T. FONG
description: Maliz E. Finnegan and Lawrence Tang Fong, who received M.B.A. degrees in May from Columbia University, were married yesterday in the Chapel of the Most Blessed Trinity on the Boston College campus in Newton, Mass. Msgr. John D. Day performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: 'FREE TRADE' IS IMPOVERISHING THE WEST
description: FOR most of this century, United States trade policy has been based on the belief that unregulated international trade, or ''free trade,'' fits a theoretical pattern that automatically makes it beneficial to the nations involved. Thus, ''barriers to trade'' and ''protectionism'' are harmful. The difficulty with this elegantly simple theory is that it bears little relation to reality.

title: RENTING A SMALL SPACE
description: THE small-business owner or professional who has never before sought office space frequently approaches the search with trepidation. That is primarily because office leases usually contain escalator clauses with a potential, before the lease runs out, of turning a base rent that sounds like a bargain into a fiscal nightmare.

title: Doctor Seized on Drug Count
description: A 43-year-old Brooklyn doctor has been arrested on charges of selling $24,000 worth of cocaine to undercover detectives, the police said yesterday.

title: IMPERFECT SCIENCE, IMPORTANT CONCLUSIONS
description: The Government periodically issues reports reciting specifications of Soviet weapons with the itemized precision of a hardware catalogue. They are sources of fascination for Soviet-watchers, and they underpin auhoritative studies such as the weighty reappraisal of the superpower balance released last week by a Library of Congress expert, John M. Collins.

title: UGANDA LEADER REPORTEDLY OUT IN ARMY COUP
description: President Milton Obote of Uganda was overthrown today in a bloodless military coup, according to radio reports from the Ugandan capital and other sources in that East African country.

title: BURLINGTON COUNTY COMES ALIVE
description: A HELICOPTER view of Burlington County's growth in the Delaware Valley reveals new office buildings, homes and shopping malls sprouting in tidy clusters among farms and forests. But heavily traveled roads, as seen from the ground during rush hours, are beginning to tell a different story.

title: SIMPLE LIFE? IT'S SIMPLY IMPOSSIBLE
description: ''SIMPLIFY, simplify,'' said Thoreau. My friends agree. ''We love the simple life,'' says he. ''The simplest pleasures are best,'' says she.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

PEACE RIBBONS
description: The 18-by-36-inch ''ribbons'' depicting ''what you cannot bear to imagine as lost forever in nuclear war'' are arriving in record numbers, said Sister Bette Ann Jaster of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor in Ossining who is coordinating ''Piece Work for Peace'' in state.

title: SOUTHHOLD DEBATE OVER HORSES
description: TOWN officials in Southold, near the eastern tip of Long Island's North Fork, ran into trouble recently when they tried to keep horses out of the neighbors' backyards.

title: ANSON WRIGHT PLANS TO BE WED SEPT. 14
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Wright Jr. of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Anson Elisabeth Wright, to Christian Nolen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Nolen, also of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: A 'Reef of Silver'
description: A hurricane caused the sinking of the Nuestra Senora de Atocha in 1622, and a tropical storm last week briefly kept divers from probing the site of the wreck 54 feet below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico, 40 miles west of Key West, Fla.

title: PRAISING PIPE ORGANS
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY TREASURES CRAFTED IN GLASS
description: What the Corning Museum of Glass describes as its most important object - a 10th-century Islamic ewer - is one of three extraordinary glass vessels that went on view this month for an indefinite period at the upstate museum. The two other glass rarities - an enameled 15th-century Venetian beaker and a Roman cup caged in a web of glass, dating from about 300 A.D. - are exceptional, too.

title: KATHRYN A. MARIANI PLANS TO WED MARC P. GOODRICH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Mariani of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Warwick, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Anne Mariani, to Marc P. Goodrich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Goodrich of West Deptford, N.J. An Oct. 5 wedding is planned. The future bride studied at the Parsons School of Design and she and Mr. Goodrich graduated from the University of Dayton.

title: RESHAPING A CITY GOVERMENT
description: THE Justice Department, civil rights groups and local officials in Bessemer, Ala., agreed last week on a plan to revamp the city government and end what the city now says was a discriminatory annexation policy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MEMORY AND DESIRE. By Inga Dean. (Viking, $15.95.) In this elegant, accomplished first novel, Inga Dean tells of a woman haunted and redeemed by her past.

title: HARLEM'S LOEW'S VICTORIA SET FOR A $2.6 MILLION RENOVATION
description: Harlem's main commercial strip, after more than 15 years without a first-run movie theater, is set to get one in a renovation project that officials call another sign of the area's improving image and fortunes.

title: JENNIFER D. MOORE AND JAMES FIELD TO MARRY SEPT. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dongan Reynolds Moore of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Dongan Moore to James Lowell Field, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Parton Field of Englewood, Fla., and Sylvan Beach, Mich. A Sept. 7 wedding is planned.

title: NASSAU JUDGE IS ADMONISHED FOR SERIES OF SEXIST REMARKS
description: A Nassau County District Court judge has been admonished by a state panel for a series of sexist remarks about female lawyers, state officials said.

title: An African Tragedy Unfolds
description: Suddenly, the debates about how Americans or Frenchmen should protest South Africa's apartheid sound trivial, even self-indulgent. No distant agitation or disinvestment can make much difference now; Pretoria's new emergency and martial law are propelling a vicious cycle of rebellion and repression toward race war. The war may tear at conscience and poison emotions in multiracial societies like ours, but it seems impervious to mediation.

title: Cable TV
description: Vintage movie buffs will find some interesting sounds this cable week. ''It's a Date'' (1940) offers a good, typical potpourri of songs by young Deanna Durbin. The picture itself - Wednesday morning at 10 on Showtime - is quite charming, with winning help from Kay Francis and Walter Pidgeon.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FREEBIES, IN COUNTY. . .

title: No South African Solution in Sight
description: Now that the storm is finally breaking in South Africa, it is time for the United States to accept the central reality of what will be a long and cruel crisis: There is no solution in sight.

title: MISS MASTERSON WEDS A. S. CECIL
description: Mary Jo Masterson, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Patrick Masterson of Eggertsville, N.Y., and the late Dr. Masterson, was married yesterday, to Andrew Stuart Cecil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cumming Cecil of Rye, N.Y. Msgr. John Martin Ryan performed the ceremony at St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church in Eggertsville.

title: NEW LANGUAGE?
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Killed in Crash of Plane
description: Three Minnesotans and a New York man were killed Thursday when their single-engine plane crashed at the Flying Cloud Airport here, the authorities said. The victims were John Renaker, 62 years old, of Clifton Park, N.Y.; his son, Eric Dean Renaker, 26, of Minneapolis; Kathy Christman, 25, of Sauk Rapids, Minn., and her son, Ian Christman, 5, the Hennepin County Medical Examiner's office said.

title: ALL THAT'S LEFT IS SEX
description: MY MERRY MORNINGS Stories From Prague. By Ivan Klima. Translated by George Theiner. 154 pp. New York: Readers International. $14.95.

title: NEW ARMY SLAYINGS IN GUATEMALA REPORTED BY VILLAGERS AND CHURCH
description: At least 60 Indian peasants living in and around this small town have been killed or have ''disappeared'' in the last seven months, almost all of them victims of the Guatemalan Army, according to local residents and the Archbishop of Guatemala.

title: TANSIT-RELIEF PLANS
description: ALTHOUGH the number of Manhattan-bound New Jersey commuters is projected to increase by 50,000 between now and 1990, peak rush-hour congestion could be significantly relieved by then, a recent study by the Trans-Hudson Task Force suggests.

title: NEW YORK CITES FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 28 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: WINDHAM'S GOVERNMENT GETTING MANY NEW LEADERS
description: BY this fall, there will be many new faces in the Windham town government.

title: THE URBAN LEAGUE TRIES TO SHAKE ITS SOFT-SPOKEN IMAGE
description: At a reception in Dallas last month for delegates attending the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a white corporate executive said in a private conversation that while he supported the N.A.A.C.P., he still wondered why it was not less confrontational in its tactics, why it was not ''more like the Urban League.''

title: DID MAX FOX SELL OUT?
description: WISHFUL THINKING By Howard Blum. 286 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95 ''WISHFUL THINKING,'' the first novel by the journalist Howard Blum, has arrived to remind us that success does not come cheap to those who rent, trade or sell their souls for it. It reminds us, too, that one of the most influential souls owned by any generation in recent years was that of the 1950's. Call it Beat or Hip or Cool, it was the first anti-establishment sensibility anybody under 50 has personally experienced.

title: SCARSDALE'S FUTURE
description: WHAT is going to happen to Scarsdale?

title: THEATER STUDENTS EARN EQUITY POINTS AT VASSAR THIS SUMMER
description: The burning subject at Vassar this summer is theater.

title: THE ICING ON THE CONDOMINIUM CAKE
description: IN THE Wizard of Oz, Dorothy clicks the heels of her ruby-red slippers three times to whisk herself back to a simple house in Kansas. If she were a modern-day New Yorker, she could tap her heels together and come home to a whirlpool, marble bathroom, concierge and a good deal more in the middle of Manhattan - if she could afford it.

title: RANGEL AND SMOKE
description: Given the Federal budget crunch, it was not surprising that the House Ways and Means Committee voted last week to continue the 16-cent-a-pack tax on cigarettes rather than allowing the tax to drop to 8 cents Oct. 1. But what surprised many was the fact that Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, led the successful move to earmark one cent of the tax to help tobacco farmers.

title: YESTERYEARS' AUDIENCES
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

WALTER'S
description: IN the 1930's there was the rubber hot dog. At a spot already famous for its fine real hot dogs, a bogus one gained a certain amount of notoriety.

title: WHAT FACTORS TO DEEP IN MIND BEFORE INVESTING IN A 'DISH'
description: Currently selling at the brisk clip of about 50,000 per month, satellite antennas - to nearly everyone's surprise -have become the hottest ticket in video.

title: THE COUNTERATTACK
description: Risk and opportunity go hand in hand in the chess openings - solid defenses that do not chance violent overthrow also offer small chance to win, while the defenses that offer exciting vistas of counterattack are also prone to be brilliantly smashed from time to time.

title: HAS SALVADOR'S ARMY DONE AN ABOUT-FACE?
description: After six years of intense international scrutiny and the pressures of guerrilla war, El Salvador's armed forces have moved away from methods that gave them a reputation as a corrupt and repressive institution. It is still unclear, however, whether less frequent use of repression and acceptance of civilian rule are deep and lasting changes or merely tactical moves to retain United States aid.

title: YET ANOTHER PAC
description: With political action committees claiming to represent virtually every identifiable segment of American life, it was inevitable that a special interest group would step forward on behalf of young, upwardly mobile professionals. The group is American Citizens for Political Action of Falls Church, Va., and its letterhead displays the rugged sculpture of Mount Rushmore and the motto ''Financing Tomorrow's Leaders Today.''

title: LOIS S. CARUSO FIANCEE OF ANTHONY J. LUPO JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Caruso of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lois Susan Caruso to Anthony Joseph Lupo Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lupo of Patchogue, L.I., and Treasure Island, Fla. The wedding is planned for Sept. 22.

title: WHEN THE STARS DECIDE WHAT THEY'D LIKE TO SING
description: Would we be hearing Verdi's ''Attila'' at the New York City Opera tonight were it not for Samuel Ramey or someone like him? Some operas are before us because everybody likes the music; others are there because beloved singers want to sing them.

title: THE DRAW WILL BE BIG APARTMENTS
description: A proposal by Harry B. Helmsley for a $200 million residential and office complex in Fort Lee, N.J., is in the midst of the town's zoning approval processes and its fate is uncertain. But meanwhile, the architect, Vijay Kale, gave additional details of the project that suggest that the aim is to attract wealthy buyers to relatively large apartments. There are no studios in the apartment mix and the smallest apartment would be 1,245 square feet.

title: RESTORATION
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL REUNION: TEARS AMID THE CHEERS
description: THE ''do-wop'' drifting from the dashboard speaker provides the perfect background music for my thoughts: Black and white photographic images of the faces in my high school yearbook, superimposed on the wire webs of the Brooklyn Bridge and the glitter of the tour boats cruising the nighttime river.

title: AFTER MOTHJER WAS MURDERED
description: SAVAGE GRACE By Natalie Robins and Steven M. L. Aronson. Illustrated. 492 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: A LITERARY FILM-MAKING TEAM HAS A GO AT E.M. FORSTER
description: The scene: a tiny, red-brick railway station in rural Sussex on a sizzling hot summer's day. Boxes of flowers hang from the station beams. Edwardian figures in straw boaters and mutton-chop whiskers saunter by. A poster temptingly offers saloon passage on a trans-Atlantic liner for 10 guineas. Sudddenly a steam-engined train puffs in, and from it steps a figure who is recognizably Maggie Smith in tight wing collar and flower-decked hat. Marching up to the ticket collector, she realizes she has got off at the wrong station and collides with a young man clutching a bicycle. At this point, one of the chickens in heaped-up baskets on the station platform noisily lays an egg.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FOR THE last year, the calendar section of this column has attempted to keep readers informed about upcoming events, such as meetings, public hearings and social or recreational activities related to the environment.

title: A REGION THE RECOVERY NEVER REACHED
description: While most steel towns in the region were withering away, this tiny city on the west bank of the Ohio River seemed for a time to represent the steel industry's brightest hope for the future.

title: LANDOWNERS DISPUTE U.S. ATTEMPT TO MOVE TRAIL
description: The way Arthur A. Delmolino sees it, not much has changed since the last battle of Shays' Rebellion was fought in a pasture near his barn nearly two centuries ago.

title: HOW I BOUGHT A BOOKSTORE AND ONLY LOST $32.60
description: LAST winter, failing to find ''The Mind of a Mnemonist'' by the Russian experimental psychologist A. R. Luria in the Strand Book Store at Broadway and 12th Street, I noticed as I left that across Broadway the door to the Sylvan Book Shop, which had been closed for the past six months, was open. I had occasionally visited the Sylvan to flip through the 1950's paperbacks and the back issues of Evergreen Review. The stock did not change very much, and the white-haired man who ran the place was friendly though inefficient. In a world of bookstores, the Sylvan was strictly second rate, but since I do not own a videocassette recorder or enjoy sports after October, browsing was my idea of entertainment.

title: IS THERE TIME TO TALK ABOUT APARTHEID?
description: After paying only modest attention to South Africa for four years, the Reagan Administration last week was forced to give urgent foreign policy priority to what Secretary of State George P. Shultz called ''a very painful part of the world'' and a situation that ''wrenches at us so deeply.''

title: WHEN THE POLKA RETURNS TO OCEAN BEACH
description: MORRIS BILKAS and his wife, Susan Browne, drove across the country to get to Ocean Beach Park. John and Helen Tephly of Montville said they couldn't imagine any other place to spend mid-July. And Leo LaFontaine of Oklahoma stretched a family vacation a few days just so he, too, could spend some time at Ocean Beach.

description: A car bomb exploded outside military command headquarters on the eve of the presidential inauguration, and near the hotel where six Latin American presidents were staying, the police said.

description: Because the National Organization for Women has so few friends in high places in Washington, Eleanor Smeal has been arguing that low-key lobbying has not paid off. Last weekend, after winning back NOW's presidency, she at once promised a decidedly more combative approach.

description: ON Robins Island, Robert Tuthill, the caretaker, slows his Jeep in front of his house to meet Buttons, a tame deer waiting to be hand-fed slices of bread.

title: SECURITY TIGHTENED FOR 2 PUNJAB LEADERS
description: The Punjab state government has tightened security for its Governor and the main Sikh political leader after intelligence reports suggested that they might become the targets of terrorist attacks, a leading official said here today.

title: DIANE M. SHAW IS WED TO KENNETH A. WASCH
description: Diane Marie Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Shaw of Amherst, Mass., was married yesterday to Kenneth Alan Wasch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Wasch of East Hills, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Derr Jr., a United Church of Christ minister and professor of religion at Smith College, the bride's alma mater, performed the ceremony at the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at the college.

title: Toll Increases to 220 In Italian Dam Break
description: Rescue workers digging through a hardened river of mud removed two bodies today, raising to 220 the number of people known to have been killed in the dam break that buried the Alpine resort of Stava.

description: Veronique Emelie Hovde, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Newbury Hovde of Nantucket, Mass., New York and Cannes, France, was married yesterday to Jon Van Zandt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Van Zandt of Lakehurst, N.J., by the Rev. Phillip Chase, who performed a Protestant ceremony at the Edson Hill Manor in Stowe, Vt. The bride is a registered nurse in Key West, Fla., where her husband owns an automotive repair business.

title: A CRUSADER FOR MODERN DANCE
description: IT WAS more than 30 years ago that Shirley Ubell, then a young artist in modern dance, set out on a ''crusade'' that resulted in the Center for Modern Dance Education here, the first nonprofit school of its type in the state.

description: If you see a French film comedy these days - like ''La Chevre,'' currently at the Embassy 72d Street - chances are you'll have a sense of deja vu about two years from now while watching a new Hollywood release. Indeed, some people may already be experiencing that sense of familiarity with ''The Man With One Red Shoe,'' since the film is a remake of the French classic, ''The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe.''

title: TOO MUCH REHETORIC, NOT ENOUGH POLITICS
description: NATION AGAINST NATION What Happened to the U.N. Dream and What the U.S. Can Do About It. By Thomas M. Franck. 334 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

description: NO SENSE OF IRONY STAINED THE SPECTACLE OF VICtory aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, no sense of shadows to rise years later.

description: SUMMER signals a welcome end to school for most youngsters, but one New Jersey school where students are eager to spend their summer days opens tomorrow.

description: To the Editor:

title: WHY ACCEPT SECOND-BEST?
description: OUR office recently was renovated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: IN THE CLEAR LIGHT. By Fiona Kidman. (Norton, $13.95.) A mournful, elegiac quality runs through this novel, as if all the characters were dead before the story began. And in some sense this is true, for the lives of these people, spent in New Zealand just before and during World War II, are pitifully thwarted and blighted. The women stand for countless hours on queues for rations to feed husbands they don't love and children they didn't want. During the war, they maintain a dreary respectability or sell themselves to soldiers. The men work hopelessly in the ''swampy peatland'' and the gold mines and later go off to die in the Pacific. The children wander aimlessly, begging for ''choc-lit.'' The novel's central character is Clara, born late in life to an incompetent mother and raised carelessly by an indiffer-ent older sister. Clara endures a barren and often baffling childhood on the wrong side of the tracks, flowers briefly in a passionate but doomed romance with a golden boy from the right side and withers quickly into degradation and despair in exile from her hometown. She lives fast, becoming old and wise at 20, having learned all there is to know about love with the help of a noble black Yank. When Clara looks back on her childhood, reconstructing her parents' and sister's lives, she is imaginative and generous, and the melancholy tone of the story seems earned and is often moving.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HEADQUARTERS, SORT OF THERE'S no official home-sweet-home yet for Islandia, the newest village on Long Island, and for Village Clerk Marie Zielenski that's a major problem.

title: MESMERIZING DRAMAS OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: Slipped into the public-TV schedule with decidedly muted fanfare, ''The Nadine Gordimer Stories: Scenes From South Africa'' turns out to be this summer's television sleeper. The seven-part series, being carried on WNET/Channel 13 Monday evenings at 9, got off to an impressive start a few weeks ago, has been getting even better and, taken as a whole, will finally add up to a memorable achievement. As it happens, South Africa has currently exploded into ominous headlines once again, and the productions, all but one filmed in South Africa, can be considered timely. But Miss Gordimer wrote these particular stories in the 1960's and 70's. They reveal nothing new. They simply document with utterly convincing precision why the present turmoil, bubbling out of apocalyptic visions for the future, was inevitable.

title: DOWN TO THE WIRE AT THE FINAL DEAL
description: The score is tied. It is the last game of the world series, the last hole in the Masters at Augusta, or the last-set tie-breaker at Flushing Meadows.
