description: Joanne Addington Passano, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Moore Passano Jr. of Gibson Island, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher Hammond Bartlett 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Barry Bartlett of New York and Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Charles Danner performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Baltimore.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Better Second Half?

title: MELTS OF SILVER COINS HAVE AFFECTED COLLECTORS
description: The value of a coin is normally based on how many were made. In years to come, however, the value of silver United States coins may hinge on how many were lost. Millions of coins have been melted for recapture of their metal and the impact on coin collecting is likely to be enormous.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

ROSTER OF NEW MEDALS
description: The United States Capitol Historical Society has issued the eighth in a series of annual medals commemorating the bicentennial of United States independence. This year's medal pays tribute to famous women of the American Revolutionary era.

title: Cleveland Had Surgery on the East River and in Extreme Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE INFLUENCE OF CHANEL
description: MOST CLOTHES-CONSCIOUS WOMEN ARE AWARE OF THE CHANEL style, if only obliquely. So strong was the statement made by the late Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel in her heyday that vestiges of it have been showing up ever since. Her ornamental accessories - bow-tied hair ribbons; cascades of gold chains, stones and pearls; double-cuff bracelets; chain belts; quilted bags - have become basics. So has the use of wool jersey and soft tweeds to sculpture suits as pliable as sweater sets. The little Chanel suit look - cardigan jacket with a high, snug armhole and contrasting piping, the neat skirt ending below the knee - has been copied up and down the price spectrum, and has come to stand for a safe way to dress properly. In truth, its saturation had taken the Chanel look from the peaks of chic in the early 1930's to the depths of banality by the early 1980's. There were a few exceptions. When Mademoiselle Chanel came out of retirement in the 1950's, for one. And later, when designers such as Yves Saint Laurent and Sonia Rykiel have occasionally reworked the Chanel concept. But though the house of Chanel had remained in operation since Mademoiselle's death in 1971, the credit for keeping the legend alive really belongs to New York's Adolfo, who kept churning out variations of the Chanel theme. Polite plagiarism though it might be, his American customers looked all the better for it. So the situation rested until Karl Lagerfeld was hired to head Chanel's design studio.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FLYING OVER CHICOPEE Tiny model planes will race, fight and do tricks at the Westover Air Force Base in Chicopee, Mass., near Springfield, through Thursday. The national competition, which began yesterday, is being put on by the Academy of Model Aeronautics, which has been holding such events for more than 50 years.

title: HOSPITALS, IN SHIFT, OFFER 'HOUSE CALLS'
description: AREA hospitals are practicing the preventive medicine they preach by offering free lectures.

title: SHOREHAM LEGAL FIGHT MIRED IN CONFUSION
description: AS the Shoreham nuclear power plant controversy continues, confusion reigns in Suffolk County over who will represent the county position in key court proceedings and before the Federal Government.

title: A WRITER CUT OFF FROM WORDS
description: OUT IN THE WORLD Selected Letters of Jane Bowles. 1935-1970. Edited by Millicent Dillon. Illustrated. 319 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $12.50.

title: ALIENATED SIKH YOUTHS SEEN AS DANGER TO ACCORD
description: Reports from all over Punjab suggested today that the accord between Sikh leaders and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, which Sikh political leaders approved on Friday, was winning wide acceptance.

title: AS WESTWAY SPUTTERS, ANY WAY SEEMS TO WORK JUST FINE
description: AS New York City was groping for a symbol of recovery in 1976, a group of business and labor leaders assembled the ingredients of an urban renaissance. They included a new convention center, an expanded Port Authority Bus Terminal, the Battery Park City complex and a bumper crop of hotels and office towers. All they needed, they thought, was a catalyst. They believed they had one in Westway.

title: ROMANTIC PIANISTS DISPLAY MASTERY ON PIANO ROLL DISKS
description: Even before flat disks became a popular medium for music, there was the player piano. Records did not hit their stride until around 1904, but as early as 1890 a mechanism had been developed to play back piano music by means of punched paper tape activated by a bellows. Welte-Mignon was one of the famous pioneers, and the Welte process attracted many famous pianists at the turn of the century. But not until the 1920's did such firms as Duo-Art and Ampico refine the player piano mechanism so that a degree of dynamics, nuance and pedal effects could be heard.

title: AFTER FOSTER CARE, ONE MAN'S UNCHARTED COURSE
description: Dwayne Lee Gosso, a 23-year-old child of the bureaucracy, has returned again to the state prison system in which he was born.

title: TAKING MONSANTO ANOTHER STEP BEYOND BASIC CHEMICALS
description: EARLY this month, Richard J. Mahoney, in the midst of rethinking his strategic plan for Monsanto, summoned a small group of analysts to the chemical company's St. Louis headquarters. Mr. Mahoney's recent bid for parts of G. D. Searle & Company, a lackluster pharmaceutical company that also makes Nutrasweet, had been rejected. Now the 51-year-old chief executive wanted to know what the analysts would think of Monsanto's forging joint ventures with Upjohn or another leading drug company.

title: FOR SALE: BRIDGE OVER THE RIPPOWAM
description: WHEN Norman Hascoe bought his house in the Belle Haven section of Greenwich, the feature that clinched the deal for him was the bridge.

title: Deal is Reached On Aid to Rebels
description: While the Reagan Administration barred further talks with Nicaragua last week, two House-Senate conference committees reopened the aid pipeline to the anti-Sandinista rebels after a Congressionally ordered two-year hiatus. Brushing aside Administration objections, however, the committees prohibited the Central Intelligence Agency or the Defense Department from distributing the aid.

title: ELIZABETH KIRK WEDS PHILIP CLARK LEFFEL 3D
description: Elizabeth Jane Kirk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bennett Kirk Jr. of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Philip Clark Leffel 3d, a son of Joan Roberts of Corning, N.Y., and Sanibel Island, Fla., and the late Mr. Leffel Jr. The Rev. Foster C. Wilson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: PUBLIC POWER: LET'S VOTE ON IT
description: I HAVE watched with keen interest and wide-eyed amazement the recent deliberations of our political, business and labor leaders in Nassau and Suffolk Counties as they attempt to respond to the rate crisis about to descend like an unwanted guest on the Long Island community as a result of the Long Island Lighting Company's ill-conceived investment in the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: HE WAS THE 'IDEA MAN' FOR DIAGHILV AND BALANCHINE
description: Boris Kochno, now 81 years old, met Serge Diaghilev at the age of 17 in 1921, became his secretary and loyal assistant, wrote the scenarios for many ballets in Diaghilev's Ballets Russes -including most by the young George Balanchine. After Diaghilev died in 1929, Kochno and Balanchine joined forces to collaborate on the ballets in London in the Cochran Revue of 1930, that year's edition of a well-known variety show. They were a team again as choreographer and librettist respectively in 1931-32 when Rene Blum founded the Ballets de Monte Carlo, later the Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo. Mr. Kochno resigned from that company after Balanchine was dismissed by Col. W. de Basil, the troupe's new manager.

title: HOW THEY COVERED THE LANDSLIDE
description: WAKE US WHEN IT'S OVER Presidential Politics of 1984. By Jack W. Germond and Jules Witcover. 567 pp. New York: Macmillan. $19.95. VISIONS OF AMERICA How We Saw the 1984 Election. By William A. Henry 3d. 275 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: PROTECTIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I really do think the United States should rethink its amount of participation that we have in these kinds of conferences.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE PET BUSINESS
description: THERE are about 98 million dogs and cats in the United States, a number greater than the human population of all but seven nations. Well over half of America's households are home to a furred, finned or feathered friend of some kind. Those pets are the foundation of an $8.5 billion-a-year industry that translates peoples' love for animals into profits.

title: TRIUMPHANT SIKH IN PUNJAB ACCORD: HARCHAND SINGH LONGOWAL
description: When Harchand Singh Longowal placed his signature alongside that of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on Wednesday on the accord to end the three-year Sikh confrontation with the Indian Government, many here saw it as an improbable triumph for an unlikely politician.

title: THE RAMBLAS
description: To the Editor: The photograph of the Ramblas boulevard, taken by Jack Manning and published in the Travel Section of May 12, moved me to all the yearnings and wishes of being in Barcleona.

title: Scientists Who Hog Data
description: Many scientists are reluctant or unwilling to share the raw data on which their published articles are based, notes a National Academy of Sciences committee. It recommends that sharing of data should be a ''regular practice.'' The advice leans in the right direction. Sharing of data by researchers is a necessity, not merely a desirable goal.

title: DOWN AND OUT IN THE YUKON TERRITORY
description: This mining community is named after a card game. When luck was good, the gaping pit seven miles northeast of town produced 6 percent of the world's lead-zinc concentrate, generating more income than the 1898 Klondike Gold Rush. It accounted for 40 percent of the private Yukon economy, and Faro became the second biggest town in the California-sized territory.

title: PREDECESSOR
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS SACKEN WED TO J. S. ESTBURN JR
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Deborah Dawson Sacken, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Sacken of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and John Sergeant Eastburn Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eastburn of Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: VIOLENT ECHOES OF PORTUGAL'S REVOLUTION
description: The far-left terrorist band called FP-25 last week underscored Portugal's struggle with political violence by shooting a key witness and thereby forcing the adjournment of a mass trial of its members.

title: TALES OF HOLLYWOOD ARE INCREDIBLE BUT TRUE
description: The recent trend toward tell-all accounts of Hollywood's corporate machinations has amounted to more than idle gossip. To be sure, the tidbits of who-did-what-to-whom hold their intrinsic fascination, especially to those who view the finished product and often wonder how it got that way. But what's more significant is the way in which these books, like David McClintick's ''Indecent Exposure,'' detailing the scandal at Columbia Pictures that began with David Begelman's embezzlement of corporate funds, and now Steven Bach's ''Final Cut,'' an insider's account of the ''Heaven's Gate'' fiasco, tell Hollywood stories that would be wholly unbelievable if they didn't happen to be true. Nowhere else could opinions be so changeable and decisions so cynical, could illogic hold such sway - not even in the movies.

title: STUDENTS REARRANGE LIFE IN THE LAB
description: MICHAEL BURKART, a 15-year-old student at Northport High School, made his way around the crowded laboratory, nervous and excited. While most biology students dissect frogs and learn how plants grow, he was one of a handful of students learning how to manipulate life.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on July 14 about cartoons in The Congressional Record misstated the origin of Senator Benjamin R. Tillman's nickname. The Senator, who represented South Carolina from 1895 to 1918, was known as Pitchfork Ben after promising to ''stick my pitchfork'' through President Grover Cleveland's ribs.

title: DENISE THOMAS, A C. P. A., IS MARRIED TO GARY HINDES
description: Denise Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Thomas of Union, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary E. Hindes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Hindes of Peotone, Ill. The Rev. Patrick A. Brady performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 14 about artworks in railroad stations in the Northeast misidentified the branch administrator of the Whitney Museum of American Art. She is Pamela Perkins, not Pamela Jenkins.

title: LOFT FIXTURES
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE BEGINS AT WESTERN UNION
description: A union representing 6,500 employees of the Western Union Corporation went on strike early today after negotiations failed to produce a new contract.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE TO RISING COST OF HOUSING
description: IT was a balmy summer evening and the Post Road Mobile Home Park was humming with activity. As a cooling wind stirred across a field dotted with trees, residents of the park mowed their lawns, trimmed hedges and weeded vegetable gardens. One of the biggest gardens belongs to a widow in her 80's.

title: A REPORT FROM THE MUSICAL BATTLEFIELD
description: The liveliest and most radical force on the classical music scene today is the authentic performance movement - the effort to match each work with the instruments and performing styles in use when it was written. It does not yet dominate concert life, but its gathering force is inexorable. What the movement proposes is nothing less than a fundamental shift in the principles of musical interpretation. That prospect has sparked a musical debate of surprisingly fierce intensity.

title: THE PIGEON GAME: A FADING SPORT IN NEW YORK
description: From Joe Cirillo's Brooklyn rooftop the buildings of Manhattan, pressed shoulder to shoulder, look like a stage set propped against the sky.

title: SINGIG OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadcast TV
description: Grappling for a distinctive indentity in last season's glut of police/detective shows, ''Miami Vice'' got off to a snappily promising start as a two-hour made-for-TV movie; it will be rebroadcast on NBC on Sunday evening at 9. The carefully contrasted partners are Ricardo Tubbs (Philip Michael Thomas), a New York cop prowling around Florida in search of his brother's killer, and Sonny Crockett (Don Johnson), former football star, Vietnam veteran and now offbeat undercover Miami policeman.

title: A Child's 'Being Alone': Other Aspects
description: The article ''New Crisis for Young: Being Alone'' [June 30] raises numerous serious issues for our times. But it does fail to identify the dimensions of the problem even in the communities specifically mentioned.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: A Star Is Born Starring Janet Gaynor, Fredric March, Adolphe Menjou, Lionel Stander, Andy Devine, May Robson; directed by William Wellman, 1937 Prism 111 minutes. $19.95 As a potent drama of success and failure in a rarefied setting, this story about a rising movie star wed to a sliding, doomed actor has the advantage of a remarkably balanced script by Dorothy Parker, Alan Campbell and Robert Carson.

title: CONTESTS SHAPING FOR SUPERVISOR IN 17 COMMUNITIES
description: LAST month Domenick J. Porco of Eastchester, rejoicing in the birth of a new daughter, received a congratulatory message from James P. Doody, the Town Supervisor. Soon afterward, Mr. Porco reciprocated, venturing to Town Hall to congratulate Mr. Doody on his birthday and to have a piece of cake. Early this November, however, only one man will be offering congratulations, this time for an election victory. Each predicts it will be the other.

title: U.P.I. PRESIDENT FOR A DECADE
description: A. Mims Thomason, a former president and chairman of the board of United Press International, died of pneumonia Friday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Thomason, who also suffered from Parkinson's disease, was 74 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: ABIGAIL LABER MARRIES RUSSELL FAUX, A WRITER
description: Abigail Laber, a daughter of Austin Laber of New York, New Milford, Conn., and Key West, Fla., and Jeri Laber of New York, was married yesterday to Russell Faux, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Faux of Sandpoint, Idaho. The ceremony was performed by Barbara Raines, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York, at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Cook's Tour
description: Mayor Koch rolled out the red carpet (and swept aside some health code violations) for the chef Paul Prudhomme last week. The owner of K-Paul's Louisiana Kitchen in New Orleans, Mr. Prudhomme had brought his Cajun cooking for a five-week run in New York City.

title: It's Time for an Israeli-Arab Change of Tone
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Murdered Dreams While there have been many descriptions of being a patient in a psychiatric ward, Jill Johnston's version in ''Paper Daughter'' (Knopf) has lost none of the force of the experience.

title: COMRADE WU HAS A LOVE LETTER
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS And Other Stories. By Feng Jicai. Translated with an introduction by Susan Wilf Chen. 255 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: KATHLEEN BIRD, A REPORTER, BRIDE OF ARTHUR J. MAURICE
description: Kathleen Bird, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Bird of Trenton, was married yesterday to Arthur J. Maurice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Maurice of Lynn, Mass. Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the Mayor of Princeton Borough, N.J., performed the ceremony at Princeton University.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HAMPTON RETURNING Lionel Hampton, the vibraphonist, is returning to New Brunswick for the fifth straight year to present a free outdoor concert in Buccleuch Park Thursday evening.

title: IT'S ALL IN THE FAMILY AT MUNCASTER
description: The journey from London to Muncaster Castle in the Lake District is about six hours by road but can take the traveler back at least 80 years.

title: A COURSE IN LATIN, 'IN MEDIUS REX'
description: SURPRISED by the unexpectedness of it, I slipped into high school Latin the other day. It happened in a university continuing-education class. (Continuing education is what you do when your kids go away from home to continue their education and you have to occupy that suburban euphemism, an ''empty nest.'') '' 'In medias rex,' '' said our young doctoral-candidate instructor, ''is the technique Homer used when he wrote into the middle of the Trojan war instead of boring you with the battle preparations. Start your story with action. 'In medias rex.' ''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: FOUR LIVES IN THE BEBOP BUSINESS, by A. B. Spellman. (Limelight, $8.95.) In 1966 John S. Wilson wrote here that the emergence of be-bop in the mid-1940's coincided with the desire of musicians to present jazz as a serious art form even though it had to be done in an entertainment milieu. Mr. Wilson said A. B. Spellman focuses ''with a perceptive and understanding eye'' on this development and its impact on the musicians Ornette Coleman, Jackie McLean, the late Herbie Nichols and Cecil Taylor. THE DEATH OF THE HEART, by Elizabeth Bowen. (Penguin, $5.95.) A 16-year-old girl learns in Elizabeth Bowen's 1939 novel that in the process of growing up, the capacity to love is crippled. The story is set in the upper-middle-class London home of Anna and Thomas Quayne; the adolescent is his naive half-sister.

title: STATE MEDICAL BOARD ACTS ON RIGHTS OF PATIENTS AND DOCTORS
description: IN WHAT it describes as a guide for both doctors and the public, the state's Board of Medical Examiners has issued a broad policy statement on the withholding or withdrawing of medical treatment.

title: THREE-STAR ELEGANCE IN STAMFORD
description: IT has only been a matter of time. With so many corporate headquarters moving into Stamford, it was probably inevitable that a ''premier cru'' restaurant would be close behind.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING IN PATERSON GOING CO-OP
description: IN the far northwestern corner of Paterson, on a slight rise where the city brushes against the suburbs of Totowa and North Haledon, stands Brooks-Sloate Terrace, Paterson's second oldest public housing complex and one of the city's most unusual developments.

title: Report on Conrail Sale Expected
description: The United States Railway Association, the agency responsible for monitoring Conrail and Amtrak, is expected to release this week a study critical of all the major players in the Administration-backed plan to sell the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: Getting Over a Rule
description: In almost any other city, a tycoon can make himself or his corporation famous in relatively short order by building a skyscraper taller than anyone else's and naming it appropriately. But this shortcut to distinction is not available in Washington, where buildings taller than the Capitol are prohibited, to maintain the symbolic pre-eminence.

title: Hold the Plutonium
description: A party of six settled down at a table in a First Avenue restaurant Saturday night and asked for water all around.

title: ELDER HOLDS ON TO TAKE PLAYOFF
description: Lee Elder eagled the first playoff hole to win the Merrill Lynch/Golf Digest Commemorative Pro Am today after losing a five-stroke lead and allowing Peter Thomson to tie him in the regulation 36 holes.

title: LEVINE, HUNTLEY ADDS SUBARU DISTRIBUTORSHIP
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, which is the national agency for Subaru, the Japanese automobile manufacturer, has just become agency for its eighth regional Subaru distributor.

title: Soviet Output Reported Up
description: Soviet industrial output and productivity rose moderately in the first half of 1985, with natural gas production up 10 percent from a year earlier, the Tass press agency said Friday.

title: DELAY SEEN IN EFFICIENT CAR MODELS
description: The decision by Federal authorities to ease the fuel economy standards for the domestic automobile industry is not likely to revive the gas guzzlers of old, although it may delay the introduction of more efficient models.

title: PENTAGON DENIES USE OF PLANE FOR TRIP BY HOUSE COMMITTEE
description: Members of one House committee will not be among colleagues taking off aboard military aircraft for various parts of the world after Congress begins a recess this week.

title: Racer's Edge
description: There is nothing new, of course, about using computers to design racing cars. As long ago as 1964, the Ford Motor Company made extensive use of computers in drawing the plans for its LeMans Challengers. And today, even shops that produce machinery for local Saturday night short-track racers often run stress analysis and computer graphics programs to turn out faster cars.

title: ILLINOIS CITY HANGS OUT 'FOR SALE' SIGN
description: If this was not the World's Largest Garage Sale, no one bothered to tell Ruth Smalley.

title: Where Chimpanzees Use Sign Language
description: To the Editor:

title: JAYS DEFEAT ANGELS FOR EIGHTH IN ROW
description: Doyle Alexander pitched an eight-hitter as the Blue Jays defeated the California Angels, 5-1, today to sweep their four-game series. Toronto tied a club record with its eighth straight victory.

title: REMNANT OF INTERSTATE GOING AWAY
description: It is known as the Potomac River Freeway. It goes nowhere.

title: AMERICA'S CHANCE TO SPUR SOUTH AFRICAN NEGOTIATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration is fiddling while South Africa burns. As the United States awaits the results of its ''constructive engagement'' policy, chances for a peaceful process of change are fast disappearing. We must try now to spur South Africa's white leadership into seizing what may be a final chance to negotiate an orderly transition to majority rule.

title: Can We Deny the Starving in Ethiopia Because of Their Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTION BY UEBERROTH OPPOSED
description: Minor issues again held the attention of baseball's negotiators at a three-hour bargaining session last night, but Commissioner Peter Ueberroth became a topic of discussion afterward and no one seemed to be eager to have him step into the crawling talks.

title: OVERFISHING AND POLLUTION IMPERIL CLAM INDUSTRY
description: The Long Island clamming industry, once the nation's leader, has fallen into a decline that some experts fear could lead to virtual extinction.

title: Shoemaker Rests
description: Bill Shoemaker, whose hip was injured in a fall during the third race Friday at Del Mar, skipped his mounts Saturday and will not ride again until Monday. The 53-year-old Shoemaker complained of back pain after his horse, Basic Image clipped heels and fell. Shoemaker was taken to Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla and released after X-rays proved negative.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: MARTIN IS AILING
description: Missing text

title: BUD GRANT: A BALANCE ON LIFE BUT A TILT TOWARD FOOTBALL
description: ''I have absolutely no idea of what people do in August'' - Bud Grant, July 1984.

title: U.N. AND AID GROUPS SEEK TO SAVE DWINDLING THIRD WORLD FORESTS
description: An ambitious, country-by-country strategy to save the dwindling forests of the third world has emerged from an unusual collaboration among private groups, international aid agencies, the United Nations and governments of the developing countries.

title: TOP BRITISH BANKER CONFRONTS CRISES
description: When Robin Leigh-Pemberton succeeded the widely respected Gordon Richardson as governor of the Bank of England two years ago, the City of London rippled with privately expressed qualms, and newspapers wrote unenthusiastic editorials.

title: BOOKS: ECCENTRIC LOT
description: HERE it is midsummer, and you mean to say you haven't traveled anywhere yet?

title: PHILIPPINE CAPITALIST LOOKS OVERSEAS
description: Enrique Zobel, one of the richest men in the Philippines and perhaps its most prominent business executive, is characteristically blunt about the investment outlook in his country these days.

title: Smoky Joe Wood, Ex-Pitcher, Is Dead; Was 34-5 in 1912
description: Joe Wood, a former Boston Red Sox pitcher known to old-time fans as Smoky Joe, died Saturday at a convalescent home. He was 95 years old .

title: THE HOME OF ROLLS-ROYCE SLIDES INTO A RECESSION
description: They used to say that the East Midlands - the industrial area centered on Leicester and Derby and Coventry - was immune to recession.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: China Reports Revenue Rise
description: China's finance minister, Wang Bingqian, reported today that state revenue exceeded expenditure in the first half of this year by ''the highest margin in recent years.''

title: TRAVERS NEXT START FOR SPEND A BUCK
description: The next start for Spend a Buck, the Kentucky Derby winner who was upset by Skip Trial in the Haskell Invitational Saturday at Monmouth Park, will be the Travers Stakes on Aug. 17 at Saratoga.

title: Hutton Hearings Continue
description: After trying to squeeze new information on E. F. Hutton's overdrafting scheme out of its top executives, including the chairman, Robert Fomon, the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime is going after middle-level employees.

title: A More Active Role For Goldsmith Aide
description: At first, Roland A. E. Franklin sounded somewhat ill at ease when reached at his Fifth Avenue office.

title: CARDS' STIEVE RETIRES
description: Citing age and injuries, Terry Stieve, 31-year-old offensive guard for the St. Louis Cardinals, announced yesterday he was retiring from professional football.

title: West German Youths Quit Moscow Festival
description: Six West German youth groups announced today that they were pulling out of the Moscow Youth Festival.

title: 'BAG HUSTLERS' STILL STALK TRAIN AND BUD RIDERS
description: Despite what city and Amtrak police call increased enforcement efforts, young men continue to harass travelers arriving in Manhattan by train or interstate bus, by hailing taxis for the passengers, then demanding payments.

title: Twins Seeking To Sign Howe
description: The Minnesota Twins are ''making every effort'' to sign the former Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher Steve Howe, the Twins' president, Howard Fox, said today.

title: ART FOR CHILDREN ON TV: PRODUCER FIELD NARROWS
description: ''There has not been a regular arts program for children on television since Lenny Bernstein's music series on CBS in the early 1960's,'' Francis S. M. Hodsoll, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said the other day.

title: The Holocaust, Proved
description: In America, courts are asked to settle questions about almost everything, even history, and now a Los Angeles case has in effect determined that yes, the Holocaust did take place. For anyone to deny it is a transcendent obscenity of our time, yet that's just the position of an organization called the Institute for Historical Review. It offered a $50,000 reward to anyone who could prove that the Nazis gassed Jews, but then had to be sued by an Auschwitz survivor who did so.

title: CLOTHIER'S FATE A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: HOW does Harry Rothman do it?

title: I.C.C. to Consider Streamlining
description: The beleaguered Interstate Commerce Commission will meet Wednesday to consider yet another plan for streamlining its operations in the face of continued Congressional criticism.

title: FARMERS YEARNING FOR RAIN IN PARCHED PLAINS STATES
description: A record-breaking drought across the High Plains is parching millions of acres of range land and threatening water supplies in Montana.

title: McCallum Wins By Knockout in 8
description: Mike McCallum, the unbeaten World Boxing Association junior-middleweight champ, successfully defended his crown today with an eighth-round knockout of David Braxton, the W.B.C.'s top contender.

title: Edward Kennedy Jr. Decides Against Bid for O'Neill Seat
description: Edward M. Kennedy Jr. said today he would not run next year for the seat of the retiring Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., but would instead keep working as an advocate for the disabled.

title: 5 Commack Men Are Charged With Raping Woman at Party
description: Five Commack men were arrested and charged with raping an 18-year-old woman at a party last night, the police said.

title: Anti-Soviet March in Finland
description: About 400 emigres from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia marched on the Soviet Embassy here today in the largest anti-Soviet demonstration in Finland since protests over the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Hundreds of police officers cordoned off the embassy during the march. The emigres said they were protesting Soviet human rights abuses and Soviet rule in the three Baltic states.

title: UGANDAN OFFICERS SUSPEND CONSTITUTION
description: The military officers who seized power Saturday in a coup said today that they had suspended the Constitution and closed Uganda's borders.

title: BOSTON LOOKS PAST COMPUTERS
description: In the two decades since American computer companies began seeing a market in every office, factory and home, this city of world-class research has blossomed into a center of world-class manufacturing.

title: Can We Deny the Starving in Ethiopia Because of Their Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Men More Likely To Serve Time in Prison
description: Black men are six times more likely than white men to serve time in a state prison, the Justice Department said today.

title: Bulls Gain On Foreign Currency
description: FOREIGN currency futures bulls continued to forage through the market last week, feeding on the continued weakness in the dollar. They enjoyed their best meal late Friday, when their buying forced those who had sold short earlier in the day to pay dearly to buy back contracts.

title: WEARY METS LOSE TO ASTROS
description: On the day after they scored 23 runs in a doubleheader, the Mets sort of rested yesterday. And except for Darryl Strawberry, who knocked in all their runs with two home runs, they were tamed by 40-year-old Joe Niekro and his knuckleball and overpowered by the Houston Astros, 12-4.

title: A Bottle of Champagne, The Bridge and Thou
description: Romance hangs from every strand of the Brooklyn Bridge, as much a part of its magic as the gracefully arched roadway between those noble towers.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Rod Carew gets his 3,000th hit, will he and Pete Rose be the only players to reach that milestone who are not in the Hall of Fame? Who are the players with the most hits not enshrined?

title: Nancy L. Filler Is Wed To P.M. Schoenholtz
description: Nancy L. Filler, the daughter of Mrs. Harry F. Lesh p nc t' I Leshrday to Peter M. Schoenholtz, the son of Dr. Jack C. Schoenholtz of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Mrs. James Hill of Columbus, N.M. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor officiated at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Joan Schoenholtz.

title: MUSIC OF THE BAYOUS AT NEW YORK CLUBS
description: New York City is about to become Cajun country north. Music will join food, the other essential for Cajun-Creole good times, just as the humidity reaches bayou levels. For most of this month, New York will enjoy more Cajun, Creole and New Orleans music than shows up any place north of the ''crawfish circuit'' from New Orleans to Houston.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Keeping Track
description: The Albany-area locals, the city slickers figure, will be all but giving away their money, not having seen the horses' previous races at Belmont Park.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page July 17 about paintings in the Capitol misidentified a painter and incorrectly attributed all paintings in the building's Rotunda to him. There are eight paintings there, four by John Trumbull and four by other artists.

title: CIVILIAN DOCTORS TO VIEW QUALITY OF MILITARY CARE
description: The Defense Department has made what it calls an ''unprecedented decision'' to allow civilian doctors to monitor systematically the quality of care administered in the military health-care program, a Pentagon source said today.

title: JUNE ORDERS FOR TOOLS ROSE 5.5%
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rose 5.5 percent in June from May and jumped 22.6 percent from their June 1984 level as the industry continued to rebound from the disappointing levels of orders and shipments earlier in the year.

title: NAMIBIAN OUTPOST SHELLED BY REBELS
description: South African-led forces were reported tonight to be pursuing insurgents in South-West Africa after a rebel mortar attack Saturday night on Oshakati, a fortified outpost just south of the Angolan border.

title: Quiet Polish Holiday
description: There is a diplomatic subspecies in Washington that closely tracks the national holidays of every country that maintains an embassy here, largely in hopes of cadging an invitation to the inevitable elegant reception. That group was sorely disappointed last week when the Polish Embassy failed to entertain on July 22, the anniversary of Polish liberation after World War II.

title: EMPLOYEES STRIKE AT WESTERN UNION
description: Western Union was struck by 6,500 technicians, operators and clerks early today after contract talks broke down, but nonunion employees staffed offices across the country.

title: Serious Crime Dropped in '84
description: Serious crime nationwide dropped 2 percent in 1984, marking the third consecutive annual decline, but violent crime rose by 1 percent, with rape increasing 7 percent, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: 100-Passenger Cruiser Aground South of Cape
description: A newly built pleasure cruiser with more than 100 people aboard struck a reef today in the Elizabeth Islands south of Cape Cod.

title: Reagan Opposes Terror, Selectively
description: Bombs exploded in 25 abortion and family-planning clinics throughout America in 1984. Eighteen directors of abortion clinics were threatened with death. Opponents of abortion invaded one clinic and trampled employees. A doctor who headed an abortion clinic and his wife were abducted and held for eight days.

title: TALLADEGA 500 TO YARBOROUGH
description: Cale Yarborough pulled away on the next-to-last lap today and won the Talladega 500 Nascar Grand National race by one second over Neil Bonnett. It was Yarborough's first Talladega 500 victory, and his first victory since June 10 of last year.

title: Cutting Social Security Is the Wrong Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Small Investor Participation
description: RETAIL brokerage customers, according to a new study financed by the Securities Industry Association, account for a far larger share of New York Stock Exchange trading than is generally believed.

title: Free Wristwatch Offer Unwinds and Runs Out
description: Want a free digital wristwatch?

title: Putting Theory To Practice
description: THE Norwalk, Conn., agency formerly known as Knudsen-Moore is in transition. That is one reason you will not find it in Norwalk any more.

title: PURISTS SAVOR THE RELAXING DELIGHTS OF NEW YORK ON DESERTED WEEKEND
description: Going to the Hamptons can be wonderfully pleasant, of course, if you can't arrange to stay in the city on weekends.

title: OUTDOORS: THE VALUE OF EEL AS BAIT
description: FOR those who care to go to the trouble of using it, the American eel is one of the most effective and versatile striped-bass baits, one that has accounted for three of the four all-tackle records for the species.

title: Channel Swimmer
description: Nicky Farrugia of Malta today became the first person to swim the 54-mile channel between Sicily and Malta. Farrugia, 24 years old, swam the Malta Channel in a metal cage to protect himself from sharks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 29, 1985
description: International

title: FEARS RISE IN WEST VILLAGE CO-OP AS NEIGHBOR IS HELD IN RAPE OF NEIGHBOR
description: For the last two years, unknown to each other, they shared life in the same seven-story cooperative apartment building in Greenwich Village.

title: WALTER R. VECCHIO
description: Walter R. Vecchio, a freelance photographer whose work appeared in Life and Look magazines, died July 21 at his Manhattan apartment.

title: MUSIC: SHAW CONDUCTS A BACH MASS
description: ROBERT SHAW conducted the 240-member Westminster Choir in Bach's B Minor Mass at the Riverside Church on Saturday night and in the process made a plea for old-fashioned modernism in an interpretive world increasingly dominated by authentic performance practices.

title: NASA MAY ALTER COUNTDOWNS TO REDUCE DELAYS
description: As the countdown toward the scheduled liftoff Monday of the space shuttle Challenger continued smoothly today, space agency officials said they might alter countdown procedures to avoid the type of last-second problems that forced the postponement of this mission two weeks ago.

title: 'CRAZY IDEAS' FOR THE HULL
description: AROUND the corner from the saltbox charm of Thames Street, the lettering on the door reads:

title: ALASKA GRAND JURY'S AUTHORITY IS QUESTIONED
description: The Alaska Senate hearing on whether to impeach Gov. Bill Sheffield will turn this week to whether the grand jury that recommended the impeachment inquiry acted within its authority.

title: CONGRESS IS TOLD OF REACTOR PERIL
description: More than a year before the accident that forced the closing of the Toledo Edison Company's Davis-Besse nuclear power plant June 9, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had identified the sequence of events there as more likely to cause serious damage than any sequence at any other plant in the country.

title: OPERA: 'TRANSFORMATIONS' BY SUSA AT WOLF TRAP
description: ROBERT SHAW conducted the 240-member Westminster Choir in Bach's B Minor Mass at the Riverside Church on Saturday night and in the process made a plea for old-fashioned modernism in an interpretive world increasingly dominated by authentic performance practises.

title: WORK PRESSURES WORRY HIS WIFE
description: President Reagan returned to the White House today from a relaxing weekend at Camp David as his wife, Nancy, expressed concern that pressures to get back to work could interfere with his recuperation from major surgery 15 days ago.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Purchased the contract of Joel Skinner, catcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. Assigned Steve Fireovid, pitcher, to Buffalo.

title: Jeanne Seibold Wed to Michael Teitler
description: Jeanne Hall Seibold, an associate in the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, was married yesterday to Michael F. Teitler, a member of the New York law firm of Teitler & Teitler, of which his father, Samuel L. Teitler of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, is a senior partner. Donald C. Christ, acting village justice of Mill Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Port Washington, L.I.

title: ASSAYING REVENUE EFFECT OF TAX PLAN
description: Administration officials were, in the words of a man at the Treasury Department, ''wildly encouraged'' by a long-awaited Congressional staff study released last week on the potential revenue effects of President Reagan's tax revision plan.

title: 2 Climbers at Park Killed by Lightning
description: Two rock climbers were killed by lightning over the weekend, and three others were injured, park officials said today.

title: 3 MORE FIND OSLO TRACK TO THEIR LIKING
description: Bislett Stadium has produced 45 world records in track and field since 1924, but until Saturday never as many as three on a single night.

title: Catching Up
description: Ernie DiGregorio, the 34-year-old former Providence College star who aspires to return to the National Basketball Association as a referee, got his first formal officiating instruction earlier this month at the National Basketball Association's rookie-league camp in Los Angeles. It went pretty well, for the most part,'' he says.

title: LOU BROCK'S LIBERATION
description: IT started, Lou Brock recalled, with a radio broadcast, KMOX in St. Louis reaching all the way down to Colliston, La. There was a baseball game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the St. Louis Cardinals, and on that Brooklyn Dodger team was a black man named Jackie Robinson.

title: REBELLION WILL CONTINUE, LEADER OF MISKITOS SAYS
description: A leader of Nicaragua's Miskito Indians said Saturday that the recent return of several thousand Miskitos to their traditional lands along the Coco River would not halt the Indian rebellion against the Sandinista Government.

title: SYRIA WILL BOYCOTT ARAB MEETING
description: Syria announced today that it would boycott an emergency Arab summit meeting called by King Hassan II of Morocco.

title: 'NEW STAGE' SEEN FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: A State Department study has concluded that the political situation in South Africa has entered ''a new stage'' and that the current round of unrest there is much more widespread than in past years.

title: FOR CARTER, AN OLD JOB IN HOUSING
description: After a 26-hour bus ride from Georgia, Jimmy Carter, carpenter, arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon. Two hours later, the former President was introduced to Richard Ernst, who will be his foreman for the next week.

title: CARDS END HOYT'S STREAK AT 11
description: LaMarr Hoyt had a personal 11-game winning streak snapped as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Padres, 4-2, today.

title: PERU'S NEW CHIEF TO LIMIT PAYMENTS ON FOREIGN DEBT
description: In the boldest move yet by a Latin American debtor nation, Peru's new President, Alan Garcia Perez, announced today that his Government would limit payments on the country's foreign debt to a percentage of its export earnings.

title: The Trouble With Letting a Computer Choose a Conservator
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW CHAMPION IN FIGURE SKATING
description: On the flight from Memphis, Debi Thomas, the 18-year-old figure skater from San Jose, Calif., tried to busy herself by rearranging the tapes in her cassette case and leafing through a dozen magazines. But the same discomforting thought kept cutting through her attempted distractions: She was the favorite to win the women's figure skating competition here at the National Sports Festival.

title: Controversy at Hearings On Indiana Time Zones
description: A week of hearings on southwest Indiana's confusing and controversial time zones produced agreement on only one point - no one wants to live near a time zone border.

title: CITY OPERA: SAMUEL RAMEY IN VERDI'S 'ATTILA'
description: IT was Samuel Ramey night at the New York City Opera and something to cheer about. He of the subterranean bass and Nautilus physique took on the title role once again last evening in Verdi's ''Attila,'' one of his favorite parts, and showed us how much animal excitement can be churned up in Verdi's early operas when voices of suitable caliber can be put onstage. ''Attila'' is the composer's ninth opera and one of his patriotic screeds. Though barely credible as drama, it contains episodes of undistilled Verdian vocalism that no admirer of the composer's virile style can fail to respond to - if the right voices are available.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday about Federal Home Loan Mortgage securities incorrectly stated the yield on 30-year certificates. It was 11.22 percent.

title: Mexico Holds Oil Price
description: Mexico''s oil export prices for August will remain at the July level, the state-run oil company, Pemex, announced today. Mexico last month cut its crude oil prices by up to $1.50 per barrel and announced varying price cuts for customers in the United States, Latin America, the Far East and Europe.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the earnings of Delta Air Lines incorrectly reported its profit on the sale of aircraft in the most recent quarter. It was $65,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Healthcare Management Inc., Dallas, promoted Mark L. Plaumann from vice president and chief accounting officer to senior vice president of finance and administration, and chief financial officer.

title: MUSIC: MITSUKO UCHIDA HAS NEW YORK DEBUT
description: A SIGNIFICANT new Mozart pianist made her local debut Friday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: DOOLEY CALLS HIS PLAY AS TIME RUNS OUT
description: IT became, over the last month, the biggest news story in the state: Vincent J. Dooley, the man who has turned the University of Georgia Bulldogs into a major national power, was suddenly talking about quitting football for politics. After 21 seasons as coach, Dooley said he might run as a Democrat in next year's United States Senate race.

title: Iraq Says Its Troops Killed 478 Iranians
description: Iraq said its forces killed 478 Iranian soldiers and wounded many others today in a dawn commando attack on a mountain on the northern war front.

title: SOVIET HUMAN RIGHTS BATTLE: ONLY ISOLATED VOICES REMAIN
description: Naum Meiman laughs when he remembers the noisy scenes in his apartment, where groups of dissidents used to gather with Western reporters in the heyday of the human rights movement.

title: JAPANESE PREPARE PLAN TO INCREASE BUYING OF IMPORTS
description: Japan plans to announce a package of measures Tuesday that are designed to satisfy growing international trade complaints and provide greater access to its markets by foreign exporters.

title: The Trouble With Letting a Computer Choose a Conservator
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM FASHION'S TIDES
description: Going fishing is a popular summer pleasure, but some women of style prefer to do their angling by wearing necklaces dominated by fish.

title: Sihanouk Accuses Khmer Rouge of Attacks
description: Strains in the guerrilla alliance opposing the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia sharpened today with a charge by Prince Norodom Sihanouk that the Communist Khmer Rouge had been turning its guns on his group of fighters.

title: U.S. GOVERNMENT LOST $7 BILLION ON OFFSHORE LEASES, STUDY FINDS
description: The Interior Department's accelerated program of offshore oil and gas leasing lost the Federal Government about $7 billion in revenue, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Failing Foster Children Twice
description: The courts have forced New York City to face up to a dismaying truth. For all its social services, it substantially fails foster children. These children, whom life has kicked around already, often suffer neglect within the foster-care system and are inadequately prepared to live outside it.

title: 007's Auto
description: What Washington needs, the Counter Spy Shop has decided, is a terrorist-proof passenger auto equipped to repel any surprise attack, escape under fire or fight back, depending on the circumstances. Just such a vehicle, an elaborately converted black Mercedes 500, goes on sale today at the shop for a price that appears to be negotiable but is said to approach $250,000.

title: PIPELINE PLAN SPARKS DISSENT
description: SOME 270 companies, trade associations and other parties have dumped 6,000 pages of comments on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in response to its proposal in late May for a sweeping revision in the way the Government regulates natural gas pipelines.

title: D'AMATO WANTS SENATE TO STUDY 63D ST. TUNNEL
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he would ask a Senate subcommittee to investigate the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's handling of Federal funds for the 63d Street subway tunnel and other capital projects.

title: OPERA: IN SANTA FE, HENZE'S 'ENGLISH CAT'
description: The German composer Hans Werner Henze has devoted much of his life to opera, but it's doubtful he's created a more charming work, or that any opera has received a more charming production, than ''The English Cat'' seen here in Santa Fe.

title: OIL PRICE FALL PERILS BRAZIL ALCOHOL FUEL
description: Long heralded for its success in reducing Brazil's dependence on imported oil, the country's alcohol fuel program is suddenly being scrutinized in a more critical light as a result of recent declines in world oil prices.

title: Helene Alexopoulos Wed To Lance Aldan Warrick
description: Helene Alexopoulos, the daughter of Mary Alexopoulos of Oak Park, Ill., and George Alexopoulos of Athens, was married yesterday to Lance Aldan Warrick, a son of Dawn Eleanor Warrick of Bothell, Wash., and Robert Eldon Warrick of Seattle. The Very Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: President's Calls
description: Sparring between Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, and reporters covering President Reagan tends to develop a special vocabulary. Last week's contribution came when Mr. Speakes reported that the President had made three ''bipartisan'' telephone calls to Senators about the budget on one day, meaning he talked to legislators of both parties. But the following day, he said, such calls on Mr. Reagan's schedule would be ''unipartisan, because there ain't but one.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Alan Garcia has been elected by 20 million Peruvians and not by international bank officials. Peru has one overwhelming creditor: it is our own people.'' - President Alan Garcia Perez of Peru [A1:2.]

title: BRADLEY WINS BY 1
description: Pat Bradley sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today for a one-stroke victory over Jane Geddes in the $300,000 DuMaurier Classic.

title: David Zucker, 79, Long Active In Conservative Judaism, Dies
description: David Zucker, a leading New York figure in Conservative Judaism, died yesterday in Parkway Regional Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and in North Miami Beach.

title: UNCERTAIN TRUCE QUIETS NICARAGUA'S INDIAN FRONT
description: At first sight this damp village on the tropical savanna looks like many others in eastern Nicaragua. But suddenly a visitor notices that the armed men who run the town are not Sandinistas but anti-Government rebels.

title: IN NAIROBI, CONSENSUS
description: What most of the delegates will remember about their three weeks in July in Nairobi is that despite the odds the United Nations Decade for Women ended on a note of unity and a shared sense of purpose.

title: At Hispanic Fair, a Blend Of Latin and Pop Sounds
description: When visitors were not inspecting handicrafts from Panama, Guatemala or Mexico, they were lining up for free samples of Pepsi-Cola, Benson and Hedges cigarettes or Drake's pastries.

title: Israelis Hold 3 Arab Youths In the Slaying of 2 Teachers
description: The security forces announced today that they had arrested suspects in the killing of two Israeli teachers who disappeared a week ago and whose bodies were found Friday in a cave on Mount Gilboa.

title: 2 OUTINGS FOR SPORT OF POLITICS
description: Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, who does not have a reputation as an outdoorsman, invited reporters last week to go rafting with him on a river in the High Sierras.

title: U.S. SEEKS INCREASE IN AIDS RESEARCH FUNDS
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking a 48 percent increase in funds for research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, the mysterious disease that has killed more than 5,900 Americans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 29, 1985
description: International

title: U.S. Proposes Phone Rules
description: The Government has proposed sweeping rule revisions in order to allow Americans to program high-powered phone company computers to leave or take messages, ring several phones to deliver a message at a set time, screen unwanted calls or set priorities for accepting incoming calls.

title: Gas Prices Dip Over 2 Weeks
description: Gasoline prices dropped slightly during the last two weeks, and the decrease, the first in more than five months, reflected dealer anticipation of a cut in oil prices by OPEC, an analyst said today.

title: THE REV. J. D. GREY
description: The Rev. J. D. Grey, pastor of First Baptist Church for 35 years and president of the Southern Baptist Convention in 1951 and 1952, died Friday at Southern Baptist Hospital. Mr. Grey, 77 years old, was a native of Princeton, Ky., and a graduate of Union University in Jackson, Tenn., and the Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary in Fort Worth.

title: Cuomo Praises Action By Court on Acid Rain
description: Governor Cuomo has called a ruling by a Federal District Court last week a ''milestone'' in efforts to obtain Federal recognition that acid rain is a national issue.

title: SAFETY AGENCY BEGINS STUDY OF AIRPORT RUNWAY HAZARDS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has begun a special inquiry into hazardous incidents involving control of planes at the nation's airports.

title: HOW TO GET THE U.S. TO PAY FOR A FOUR-LANE ROAD
description: U.S. 72 runs from Iuka 25 miles to Corinth in northeastern Mississippi. It used to be a two-lane road, but now it has four brand-new federally financed lanes.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of fairs and festivals in Weekend on Friday gave incorrect dates for a crafts fair at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y. It will be held Sept. 28 and 29.

title: WINS ON DCISION
description: Joey Olivo of Los Angeles won a unanimous decision from Choi Munjin of South Korea today and retained his World Boxing Association junior flyweight title in a 15-round bout.

title: THE DANCE: LEWITZKY
description: Bella Lewitzky, commonly regarded as one of the company's leading dancers in American modern-dance in the 1940's and 1950's, no longer performs. But she does continue to choreograph for the company she established in 1966 in Los Angeles - and it is this troupe of young dancers, the Lewitzky Dance Company, that opened Friday night at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Westchester.

title: Bemused By Coincidence
description: David W. Schropfer is a regular churchgoer, and is therefore only bemused by a coincidence of numbers in his life.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AUTOMAT The last of the Horn & Hardart Automats remains, down to the art deco lettering of its name, at Third Avenue and East 42d Street. It still has the sandwiches in little windows that turn when coins are inserted in the slots. There are modifications at the fierce animal heads out of which the coffee pours; one must buy a token to get the liquid refreshment. The tables and the decor have the same look and, happy to report, so do the customers, particularly those with time on their hands between rush hours.

title: 2 Bumped at Park By Carriage Horse
description: A horse pulling a carriage broke loose on Central Park South and bolted onto a sidewalk, slightly injuring two pedestrians, the police said yesterday.

title: FOREIGN PROP FOR U.S. ISSUES
description: Foreign buying of Treasury securities has helped keep a lid on American interest rates the last few years, as overseas purchases helped finance the Federal budget deficit and reduced the amount of securities to be absorbed by domestic investors.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. Men's basketball, men's and women's volleyball and swimming. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs.

title: A LESSON FOR GASTINEAU
description: On Mark Gastineau's last day of enforced ''community service'' at the Rikers Island jail, someone told him, ''Bum-rush the quarterback.''

title: Injury Sidelines Klecko
description: Joe Klecko was to be the pivotal player in the Jets' new 3-4 defensive alignment this season. He was going to be the lineman in the middle in the new position of nose tackle.

title: PERFECTION AT FESTIVAL
description: Greg Louganis, Brian Boitano and Jimmy Moore reached perfection today at the National Sports Festival.

title: FISK BUILDS STRENGTH-AND HIS HOME RUN TOTAL
description: SHORTLY before the clocks tolled midnight last Friday, a solitary figure entered a tiny cubicle in Comiskey Park and began to lift weights. Carlton Fisk appeared tired but happy. This was understandable. The White Sox had won at the 11th hour, scoring two runs in the bottom of the ninth inning to beat the Baltimore Orioles, 9-8.

title: COMPUTERIZED SYSTEMS FOR VOTING SEEN AS VULNERABLE TO TAMPERING
description: The computer program that was used to count more than one-third of the votes cast in the Presidential election last year is very vulnerable to manipulation and fraud, according to expert witnesses in court actions challenging local and Congressional elections in three states.

title: A Modest Boon
description: The Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, signed here at a 35-nation summit in 1975, was the high point of detente, soon to start breaking down. That helps explain why both expectations and disappointments were too great.

title: BLISS LOOKS BACK ON YEARS AT MET
description: Sometime today, a caravan is scheduled to depart New York for Prince Edward Island, Canada. The assembled car, truck and van will contain Anthony A. Bliss, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, his wife, Sally, miscellaneous family members and retainers, and furniture from both his Met office and the Manhattan apartment the company has maintained for him these past 11 years.

title: ITALIAN DAM DISASTER BRINGS SEARING SELF-CRITICISM
description: The dam break that killed more than 200 people in northern Italy last week has underscored what officials describe as the inadequacy of this country's environmental laws and bred a searingly self-critical national debate.

title: New Taxes, by Any Other Name
description: No matter how big the deficit becomes, President Reagan adamantly opposes cutting it with new taxes. Congress has thus been forced to look for the ultimate in fiscal invention: non-new non-taxes. The exercise is gimmicky, but not all bad. Indeed, three of these non-new non-taxes are probably essential.

title: BONDS OF LONG-TERM MARRIAGES
description: ALAN and Phyllis Entin have been happily married for over 20 years. Yet like many long-term couples they feel like relics from another age as they watch a growing number of people around them changing partners.

title: Four Brothers Are Dead After Philadelphia Fire
description: Four young brothers died in upstairs bedrooms when fire swept through their two-story rowhouse this morning, but their parents and two other boys escaped, the authorities said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meeting for the week of July 29,1985: *2*MONDAY Airborne Freight Kennametal Inc ArmstrongWorld Ind Kentucky Utilities Consol Freightways Koppers Co Foster Wheeler Sargent Welch Sc Heleman Brewing Triangle Industries *2*TUESDAY American Brands Nobel Affiliates Ball Corp North European Oil Rlty Cameron Iron Works U G I Corp Enserch Corp Union Camp Corp Gulton Indus Inc Wendy's Intl Kiser Alum & Chem *2*WEDNESDAY Altel Corp Houghton Mifflin American Genl Corp LaFarge Corp Bethelhem Steel New Jersey Resources Celanese Corp Oneida Ltd Cenergy Corp Pacific Lumber Chevron Corp Public Serv Co Ind Equifax Corp Squibb Corp Exxon Corp Standex Intl Corp Freeport McMoRan Tribune Co Grainger (WW) Unfirst Corp Hercules Inc *2*THURSDAY Ahmanson (HF) & Co Mass Merchandisers Avon Products Mercantile Stores Bemis Co Inc Ranco Inc Chemed Corp Standard Brands Paint Coastal Corp Supermarkets Gen Corp Dart & Draft West Company GTE Corp Zurn Industries *2*FRIDAY ASA Ltd Morrison-Knudsen Florida Steel Corp Sterling Drug Hutton (EF) Washington Water Pwr

title: UNDERSTANDING MENTAL DISORDER IN CHILDREN
description: ''We have no wish to alarm any of the parents who read our book,'' Dr. Herman Roiphe said. The psychiatrist glanced at his wife, Anne, seated next to him in his book-lined Fifth Avenue office.

title: Bridge: Some Experts Willing to Try New Tacks in Their Bidding
description: Most experts are orthodox and predictable in their bidding habits, at any rate in simple opening and responding situations. The bid they make with a given hand this year is likely to be the same next year, in similar circumstances with the same partner.

title: AFRICAN TRAIN JOURNEY
description: HERE it is midsummer, and you mean to say you haven't traveled anywhere yet?

title: Cutting Social Security Is the Wrong Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS' PATTERSON FILLING IN
description: A year ago, Elvis Patterson, a rookie free agent, struggled before he made the Giants' season-opening roster. This year, he is struggling to become a starter, at least until Mark Haynes arrives.

title: Clevepak Deal Widens Andlinger & Co. Focus
description: To much of the business world, Andlinger & Company, a private investment banking and management operation, is not particularly well known.

title: IMPROBABLE COALITION GROWS WIDER
description: Before the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition was formed in 1976, joining the farmland to the industrial heartland with a hyphen, few people had ever thought to connect the two, Larry Zabar, executive director of the coalition, said the other day.

title: One-Year Bills to Be Sold Thursday
description: The only Treasury sales scheduled for this week are for bills due in 3, 6 and 12 months. But government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce on Wednesday the details for more than $21 billion of note and bond sales next week.

title: Electrician Suffers Burns In Fire at Hotel
description: An electrician was burned seriously and 10 other workers suffered smoke inhalation today after an electrical transformer exploded and burned at a major hotel that had been cleared of its 3,800 guests Saturday after a similar explosion.

title: PUBLISHING: RECANTED RAPE CHARGE
description: IN recent years, everyone from people convicted of Watergate-related crimes to hired killers for the mob have sold their stories to big commercial houses, but not everyone in the public eye has gone the commercial route.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Boy Wonder
description: The latest Wunderkind produced by a major nonteam athletic event is Boris Becker, on top of the world after his Wimbledon triumph at age 17. Now all he need do is escape the boy-wonder jinx. Consider how a number of other early bloomers have fared over the decades after capturing top prize in some of the most glamorous contests in all of sports:

title: Letter: On Energy Resources;   Look to Replacing Oil, Despite Glut
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Wanted: Villain
description: America's right wing sorely misses Nelson Rockefeller. Politics without a villain is like a lens without a focal point, and old Who-else-but-Nelse was a perfect villain.

title: New GATX President Stresses Service Units
description: The GATX Corporation has announced that J. Warren Samborn has been named president and chief operating officer.

title: The Soul of Cabbage
description: The urge to quantify has always been strong in Washington, which may account for informal circulation in the Government of the following unexplained list:

title: The Mass Murders In the Katyn Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW KOCH AND AIDES HANDLED PLUTONIUM THREAT
description: Last April 1, a clerk working in City Hall's cluttered mail room opened a letter addressed to Mayor Koch in order to route it to the appropriate office.

title: LENDL WINS FIRST CLAY FINAL
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, losing only 11 points on his eight service games, continued his mastery over Andres Gomez with a 6-1, 6-3 victory today in the final of the United States Open Clay Court tennis championships.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TRACER. By Frederick Barthelme. 126 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: Singapore Technology
description: Singapore's Economic Development Board said today that it would set up a $100 million fund (in Singapore dollars) to promote high technology. The money would be used to invest in joint ventures in microelectronics, telecommunications, robotics, biotechnology and laser optics in Singapore and abroad, a statement said. The fund, part of a plan to stimulate Singapore's sluggish economy, is intended to promote the transfer of technology and investments to Singapore.

title: Dr. Walter Stewart, 69, Dies; Psychoanalyst and Professor
description: Dr. Walter A. Stewart, a psychoanalyst and former professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday of a liver ailment at his home in Gladstone, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: Israel Says Jets Attacked Base in Eastern Lebanon
description: Israeli Air Force jets today raided a Palestinian guerrilla base in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, setting a command headquarters for a Libyan-backed faction on fire, Beirut radios and the Israeli command reported.

title: FEMALE CIRCUMCISION IS DEBATED IN THRID WORLD
description: For Assitan Diallo, it is difficult to differentiate between the pain she felt and the pain she saw.

title: JOHN RUBINSTEIN'S LIFE IS A MULTIMEDIA EVENT
description: Stars of television series usually have television sets, refrigerators and other luxuries in their dressing rooms. But John Rubinstein, who recently began filming his second season of CBS's popular detective series ''Crazy Like a Fox,'' may be the first actor to have a piano in his trailer. He's using it between scenes to compose the songs for a Broadway musical.

title: NEW EVIDENCE POINTS TO GROWTH OF THE BRAIN EVEN LATE IN LIFE
description: EVIDENCE is building that development and growth of the brain go on into old age. It was once thought that the brain was fixed by late childhood, according to innate genetic design.

title: General Mills Unit
description: Munford Inc. said it agreed to acquire the Leewards Creative Crafts Inc. unit of General Mills Inc. Terms of the transaction, expected to be completed by Aug. 31, were not disclosed. Munford said Leewards, with 46 retail stores, had revenues in excess of $61 million for the year ended in May.

title: War Game Addict Guilty of Fraud
description: A 19-year-old computer enthusiast who said he was addicted to a space war game and used stolen credit card numbers to charge playing time was placed on probation and ordered to make restitution after pleading guilty to wire fraud, a Federal official said today.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $17,144,000 for the latest quarter and $24,144,000 for the 6 months.c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,775,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: ST JUDE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLISH STUDENT LEADERS ASSAIL NEW CONTROLS ON UNIVERSITIES
description: Fifteen student representatives from 10 Polish universities gathered here today to denounce Parliament's adoption of a law that limits academic freedom.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MORE PRISONS AREN'T THE ANSWER
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has offered public lands to states that would build prisons on them. Imprison more offenders, he argues, and you have less crime. Crime is down, he says, because the prison population is up. But does imprisoning more people lower crime rates?

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ON A SCOTTISH ISLAND, SERENTITY'S PRICE IS POVERTY
description: When the politicians in London talk about The Other Britain, about the areas of the country where life is hard, they almost always talk about urban deprivation. Few speak up for the rural poor.

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN REBUFFS SENATE ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan refused today to support the two central elements of the latest Senate budget plan: tax increases, including an oil import fee, and alternate-year adjustments of Social Security benefits to account for inflation.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sharon Urges Israel to Strike P.L.O. Headquarters in Jordan
description: Ariel Sharon called today for Israeli military attacks against P.L.O. headquarters in Jordan in response to terrorist attacks in Israel.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $367,000 for the quarter and $755,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $1,041,000 for the 6 months.

title: SIKH PACT: THE RISKS
description: Luck, political maneuvering and willingness to take risks all helped produce the historic accord that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Sikh political leaders reached last week. But these same factors also point to the delicacy of the agreement, the difficulties that lie ahead and the dangers of further agitation and bloodshed.

title: We Should Promote AIDS Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM ON FRENCH TELEVISION SHOWS SAKHAROV LEAVING CLINIC JULY 11
description: A French television network today broadcast excerpts of a film showing Andrei D. Sakharov, the exiled Soviet physicist and rights advocate, leaving a clinic in Gorky, apparently in good health, and being reunited with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAY PACIFIC HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect as of Jan. 1, 1984 the company's Nov. 7, 1984 acquisition of Bay Pacific Associates and Bay Pacific Management Corp.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net gains of $136,000 for the quarter and $144,000 for the 6 months from the sale of properties and investments. c-After net losses of $62,000 for the quarter and $58,000 for the 6 months from the sale of properties and investments.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 18 about CBS public-service announcements to help find missing children cited broadcasters' efforts incompletely. Since last year, ''Good Morning America'' on ABC has broadcast information on missing children.

title: Chess: Maya Chiburdanidze Scores Strong Victory in Yugoslavia
description: One of the finest performances by a woman in the history of the game was achieved by Maya Chiburdanidze of the Soviet Union in winning the traditional Banja Luka International Tournament in Yugoslavia. The 24-year-old women's world champion scored 8 1/2-4 1/2 against all-male opposition that included eight grandmasters and four international masters.

title: $225 Million Pittsburgh Sale
description: Pittsburgh is offering $225 million of general obligation refunding bonds, which were tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.23 percent for bonds due in 2007, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WITNESS TELLS STEWART JURY HEW SAW ASSAULTS BY POLICE
description: A former auxiliary police officer testified yesterday that he had seen Transit Authority police officers slap and kick Michael Stewart after the young man was arrested at a subway station on a charge of scrawling graffiti on a wall.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net loss.Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 6.

title: AGUILERA IMPRESSIVE IN VICTORY
description: Rick Aguilera, a rookie pitcher with only two and a half years in professional baseball and with a recently sore forearm, went to the mound in Shea Stadium last night and tested both himself and his arm before a crowd of 30,693 and a national television audience.

title: Propane Blast In Connecticut
description: A propane gas tank exploded today at a Main Street restaurant here, destroying the building and injuring at least one passer-by, the local authorities said.

title: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MANSIONS Our town's branch office of Washington's Smithsonian Institution is the Cooper-Hewitt Museum - which is also known as the National Museum of Design. Long before it became a museum, this was the building where Andrew Carnegie hung his hat in New York, a 1903 mixed Renaissance-Georgian mansion with many rooms, a large garden in the rear, a little greenhouse at one end and heaven only knows how many hatstands.

title: Let's Face Up to AIDS
description: By now the public is far more technically literate about cancer of the colon and AIDS -acquired immune deficiency syndrome - than anyone would have imagined a few weeks ago. However, it remains to be seen whether our medical literacy will be accompanied by social understanding or public support for improved treatment and research programs to mitigate killer cancers and AIDS.

title: STAGE: 'FIORELLO!' AT GOODSPEED OPERA
description: IN order to hit the bull's-eye, a successful revival of ''Fiorello!'', the 1959 Broadway musical biography of former New York Mayor Fiorello La Guardia's rise to prominence, must have at its center an actor of riveting charisma. At the Goodspeed Opera House, in East Haddam, Conn., where the show has been sturdily remounted, the task of portraying New York's ''Little Flower'' falls to the likable but ultimately uncommanding actor-singer Jack Hallett.

title: U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT PARLEY: JOUSTING FOR POSITION
description: The Soviet Union's announcement that it would halt nuclear testing from Aug. 6 until the end of the year is seen by American officials as the latest in a pattern of foreign policy moves by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to put pressure on President Reagan before their November meeting.

title: OLD FASHION FOODS INC reports earnings for Year to May 25
description: b-Including a net gain of $197,000, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of land.

title: COMMODORE INTRODUCES NEW AMIGA
description: COMMODORE'S new Amiga A1000 computer was unveiled at Lincoln Center last week amid flashing lasers, rip-snorting jazz, rented tuxedos and rented celebrities, including Andy Warhol, who was there to bestow the first 15 minutes of fame on the machine. Yet even surrounded by all the glitter, the Amiga stood out clearly as the evening's star performer. When it reaches the stores here in mid-September it will be one of the most technologically advanced computers available for the home and business markets.

title: On Being a Hostage
description: Two men who know first-hand the rigors of being held hostage in a foreign country will be among the witnesses this morning at a House subcommittee hearing examining the role and responsibility of television in terrorist situations. Testifying will be L. Bruce Laingen, the highest ranking diplomat among the Americans held hostage in Iran for 444 days a few years ago, and Jeremy Levin, the chief of the Beirut bureau of Cable News Network, who was freed in February after being held hostage for 11 months in Lebanon.

title: LIFE IN TUSCON: DANGEROUS 'MONSOONS' HELP BEAT THE HEAT

title: On Being a Chocoholic

Featured attraction at tonight's fund-raising gathering at the Reserve Officers Association building will be chocolate ice cream. All you can eat for just $50.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was well nigh impossible to find a parking space anywhere along Main Street or Job's Lane in Southampton on Friday. That's what happens when it rains: If people can't go to the beach, they go shopping. It's still possible to pick up cotton sweaters or pants and all manner of T-shirt and sweatshirt clothing, which is just about all anyone wears out there in the summer.

Mr. Nolen made his New York City Opera debut last year in Stephen Sondheim's ''Sweeney Todd.'' Mr. Nolen replaces George Hearn who withdrew from the role due to his busy performance schedule, said an opera spokesman. Mr. Hearn is scheduled to make his debut with the City Opera in Wright and Forrest's ''Kismet'' on Oct. 3.

description: Pauline Daniels, a Dutch modern dancer who is part of the Dansproduktie company from Amsterdam, performed four solos under the umbrella title of ''Profile'' Sunday afternoon at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N. Y. If the choreography in each case was not remarkable, the dancer was. Miss Daniels knows how to project emotion out of form, and her dancing accents both emotion and form. She is quick, strong and clear.

description: IF Mrs. Henry Parish 2d is the queen of American interior design, and there are those who insist she is, then her partner, the shy, scholarly Albert Hadley, is the king.
