title: SUSPECT ON TRIAL IN ROME MAY AID TURKISH INQUIRY
description: Officials here say they believe the return to this country of a Turk suspected of being a racketeer may cast further light on the operations of international smuggling rings that, the Turkish officials say, use Bulgaria as a base.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS MAKE NEW OFFERS ON NUCLEAR TESTS
description: President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, each offered new proposals on the testing of nuclear weapons today.

title: Net Triples At Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, which owns 81 percent of Continental Airlines and 70 percent of New York Air, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings tripled, to $41 million, or $2.69 a share, from $13.4 million, or 77 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 49.8 percent, to $495.1 million, from $330.6 million, in the period.

title: PUZZLING CRYSTALS PLUNGE SCIENTISTS INTO UNCERTAINTY
description: MOST solid things are made of crystals, and for nearly two centuries scientists assumed that every crystal must have an orderly structure, its constituent atoms fixed at predictable, periodic positions within a lattice framework. But the discovery of a new type of crystal that violates some of the accepted rules has touched off an explosion of conjecture and research that may lead to the founding of a new branch of science.

title: IT BIDS U.S. DO SAME
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it was suspending the testing of nuclear weapons, beginning Aug. 6, the 40th anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima.

description: FINANCIAL planning is gaining popularity with companies as an executive perquisite, according to the Hay Group, a benefits specialist. And that means more jobs for financial planners.

description: Syria said an Israeli air attack in Lebanon early today killed ''a number of inhabitants, mostly women, children and old men.''

title: Ford Spending

He told a University of Michigan seminar that much of the money will go for upgrading the company's manufacturing technology as well as for new products. Last year, Ford's capital spending was $3.52 billion, compared with $2.33 billion in 1983.

title: Guadeloupe Activist Is Freed From Jail
description: A Guadeloupe independence activist was released from prison today, and pro-independence groups responded by ending a six-day-old general strike that had paralyzed this Caribbean island.

title: BILL TO LIMIT ANTITRUST LIABILITY OPPOSED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration came out today in flat opposition to a major change in antitrust law that would limit the liability of companies convicted of price-fixing or other anticompetitive behavior.

title: Life Cyclists
description: Feeling a bit old? Forget it. Try taking a 4,200-mile cross-country bicycle tour. William H. Appel, at the age of 64, decided to give it a go, and word is that he is pedaling near the head of the pack on the Harvard Ride for Life marathon due to arrive at the Capitol today on its way from San Francisco to Boston.

title: 'LOVE, LONG DISTANCE,' CBS COMEDY

They have been married five years and are the principals of ''Love, Long Distance,'' a half-hour pilot for a comedy series about a ''commuter marriage'' that has its premiere on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight. It is smoothly put together and threatens to break no new ground in television entertainment.

title: Working Profile: Stephen S. Trott;   PRESSURE AND THE PROSECUTOR
description: As Stephen S. Trott tells it, at first he was a hero of the Black Panther movement, when, as a deputy district attorney in Los Angeles, he prosecuted a rival group for killing Panther members in a 1960's schoolroom shootout. But then the Panthers themselves instigated a shooting, and as the prosecuting attorney in the case Mr. Trott quickly became the enemy.

title: Roger C. Damon, 78, Is Dead; Ex-Chairman of Boston Bank
description: Roger C. Damon, the former chairman and chief executive officer of the First National Bank of Boston, died after a brief illness Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 78 years old. Mr. Damon, who had a national reputation as an innovator in banking, joined the First National Bank as a teller after graduating from Yale University in 1929.

He spends his spare time on a weekly budget of $100 persuading Broadway's most glittering and employable stars to perform and talk about themselves gratis in a church.

title: No Experience Necessary
description: Preparing for his first season as head football coach at Columbia, Jim Garrett assessed the squad he inherited and decided it needed help -quickly. Last season, the Lions went 0-9, the final touch on a 4-43-2 coaching record over five seasons for Bob Naso.

title: Cable Confronts the Constitution
description: If a cable television system is defined as a public utility, it must deliver vital services on terms set by government. If it is more like a newspaper, a distributor of ideas, then it enjoys constitutional protection against government interference. Which is it? A Federal appeals court in Washington has now leaned heavily toward constitutional protection, striking down a Federal requirement that cable systems carry all local broadcasts.

description: Margie Martinez, her T-shirt stained with sweat, emerged smiling and breathless from the sanitation workers' testing center at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn yesterday. She had just finished lifting and tossing 147 garbage bags weighing a total of 2,975 pounds into simulated trash bins in 27 minutes. She scored 100 percent.

description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said today that it is trying to form a consortium to buy Texaco Inc.'s 50 percent stake in a $1.2 billion copper mining project in Chile. Broken Hill already owns 50 percent of the Escondida project through its Utah Development Company subsidiary.

title: Let Them Eat Less
description: ''If there is one person in this country hungry, that is one too many, and we're going to do what we can to alleviate that situation.'' That's how President Reagan responded to accusations in 1983 that his Administration did not care about hunger. Now, a Physician Task Force on Hunger in America estimates that 20 million Americans go hungry at some point every month. What is the Administration doing to alleviate that situation? It wants further cuts in food stamps.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.7 million for the quarter and $11,336,000 for the year.

title: California Health Offering Is Priced
description: A $108 million issue of California Health Facilities Authority hospital refunding revenue bonds for Sutter Community Hospital was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LIMITATIONS OF PLUTONIUM TESTS CITED
description: An expert on plutonium testing said yesterday that inherent limitations on the accuracy of laboratory procedures could easily account for elevated levels of the substance reported in a sample of New York City water.

title: A False Alarm Well Doused
description: ''Femto'' is the scientific prefix for one-millionth of a billionth. Spare a femto-second of sympathy for the terrorist who threatened to spike New York City's drinking water with plutonium. How could he have foreseen that the city's bureaucracy would take three months to forward the dramatic threat to Mayor Koch?

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an unusual net charge of $9,600,000 associated with the work force reductions.

title: LIBERATION OF WOMEN SCHOLARS IN 50'S
description: THE well-known advertising slogan ''You've come a long way, Baby,'' playfully celebrating women's progress, might better be reworded ''You had a long way to go'' when applied to the top rungs of the academic ladder. It explains why today only few full professorships are held by women.

title: Boeing Profit 33.3% Higher
description: The Boeing Company, the world's largest maker of commercial jets, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings climbed 33.3 percent to $136 million, or 93 cents a share, from $102 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 23 percent to $3.37 billion, from $2.74 billion.

title: POLICE BRUTALITY CASES, ONCE A MINORITY-AREA CONCERN, NOW FOUND WIDELY
description: Many of the nation's cities, large and not so large, are having serious problems involving complaints of police use of excessive force, an emotional issue that appears to be taking a mounting toll on municipal finances and civic harmony.

description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a stock split paid as a 50 percent stock dividend on April 9, 1985 to shareholders of record March 26.

BOTHA DECLINES REQUEST BY TUTU FOR CRISIS TALKS
description: President P. W. Botha rejected a call today by Bishop Desmond M. Tutu for urgent talks to discuss defusing the nation's crisis.

title: DANCE: LEWITSKY GROUP
description: BELLA LEWITZKY is major American modern dance choreographer, based in Los Angeles, whose work is seldom seen on the East Coast. But works performed by the Lewitzky Dance Company on Saturday at the PepsiCo Summerfare festival in Purchase were a disappointment. Miss Lewitzky is clearly an accomplished and seasoned choreographer in full control of her material, but the material is handled in a way that seldom seems to penetrate the squeaky-clean, distanced surface of the dance.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Three men were arrested yesterday on charges of practicing law without a license, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday. The three did not work together, his office said.

United States District Court Judge Consuelo Marshall said that the matter should be arbitrated by National Basketball Association Commissioner David Stern as provided for in the league's constitution.

title: SQUATTERS AND CITY CLASH ON HOUSING

title: Timid Diplomacy
description: The failure of ''constructive engagement'' - the Reagan Administration's attempt to use friendly persuasion to promote reform in South Africa - has critical implications for American policy toward repressive regimes around the world. Although not officially labeled constructive engagement, that is precisely the principle that guides our relations with Taiwan, Chile and the Philippines, among other countries -and, as in South Africa, it has had just the opposite of the desired effect on these authoritarian governments.

title: DH TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'KIDS JUST KIDS,' BY AND FOR YOUNG
description: ''KIDS JUST KIDS'' is done by, and intended for, the young. Its three hosts -boy and girl, 13 years old; girl, 14 - report stories for their peers. Why is Madonna so popular? What is it like competing at double-Dutch jump rope? The young - early and pre-teen - will identify; the rest of us will not, but we may be interested, either a little or in part. The WNBC-TV production will be seen on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight.

title: Vera Cravath Gibbs, 89, Dies; Was Active in Opera Groups
description: Vera Cravath Gibbs, a former member of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association and widow of William Francis Gibbs, the naval architect, died Saturday at her home in Rockport, Mass., following a heart attack. She was 89 years old.

title: SECURITY AT INTERNATIONAL AIRPORTS HAS TOUGHENED SINCE HIJACKING
description: Security has noticeably improved at many international airports after the hijacking to Beirut last month of a Trans World Airlines jetliner and the crash of an Air-India plane off Ireland, according to a recent survey.

description: The State Appellate Court today upheld a lower court's order barring Yale Literary Magazine from using the word ''Yale'' in its name because the publication had not complied with university regulations.

He will replace Bruce Nelson, 33 years old, and Ira Madris, 45, already executive vice presidents, who become creative directors of McCann's domestic operation.

title: ALL ABOARD FOR DINNER ON A SLOW TRAIN

''As we passed through Lyle, Minnesota,'' he said, ''we entered a place some of us fondly know as God's Country.'' He was referring to the state of Iowa. His comment drew an equal number of cheers and boos from the 95 people on board the Star Clipper. The cheers were from the Iowans; the boos from Minnesotans.

title: NEW SOLUTIONS TO OLD PUZZLE: PAIRING WINE AND FOOD
description: PAIRING food and wine, like matching ties and shirts, was a less intimidating task a generation ago. In the same way that striped ties called for solid shirts and solid shirts meant sporting striped ties, everyone knew, with a reassuring certainty, that red wines went with meat and white wines went with fish. It was, admittedly, an oversimplification, but sticking to these rules meant not being embarrassed in polite company.

title: DANCE: MORRIS TROUPE AT PEPSICO SUMMERFARE
description: VERY much a child of his time, Mark Morris choreographs dances that swing wildly between the irreverent and the formal or sophisticated. One category is not necessarily exclusive of the other, as the Mark Morris Dance Group's concert demonstrated Sunday night at the close of the Pepsico Summerfare Festival in Purchase, N. Y. Except for a piece titled ''Lovey,'' all the works on the program were premieres in the New York area. ''Love, You Have Won,'' named after its score - a Vivaldi cantata - featured Mr. Morris and Guillermo Resto in 18th century shirts and tights down to the knee, as two Baroque gentlemen. A quality of preciousness was wittily incorporated into the movement - a flick of the wrists, small side steps, a light bounce, and pantomime of sign language and a generalized prancing motif.

title: Hospital Offering From Michigan
description: The Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is offering $90 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. For shorter maturities, yields range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8.20 percent in 1995 and 9 1/8 percent in 2004.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: RELY tampons have not been sold for nearly five years and toxic shock syndrome no longer makes headlines. Indeed, for many people the disease has been all but forgotten. Forgotten, perhaps, but not gone.

title: ANALYSTS WARY ON RETAILERS
description: A WEEK ago, when Sears, Roebuck & Company reported a 25.4 percent drop in its second-quarter income, the news sparked declines not only in Sears stock but also in those of a half-dozen other major retail issues.

title: PAYMENTS TO DYNAMICS RESUMED BY PENTAGON
description: The Defense Department announced today that it had resumed contract payments to the General Dynamics Corporation after withholding $437.8 million in a dispute over the costs of weapon programs.

title: Egypt's Oil Prices
description: Egypt has informed its crude oil customers that its July export prices were $1.50 to $2 a barrel below contracted prices but that prices for June and August had not yet been determined, Hammad Ayoub, a senior oil ministry official, said today. He said consultations on June's prices were continuing.

title: AFRICA'S SACRED MUSIC
description: THE public will have a rare chance to hear sacred African rhythms and chants, Friday at the Museum of Modern Art. At 8 P.M., the free Summergarden concert series will present a benbe, the public part of a santeria ritual. Santeria - the religion of orishas, or nature deities, that came to the new world with West African slaves - is thriving here, although many New Yorkers may not know it. And the rhythms of santeria, at least those of the less potent orishas, are deeply imbedded in Latin popular music.

description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a strong second-quarter performance in its steel unit, even though profits over all dipped 5 percent from the same period a year ago. Profits from its Marathon oil and gas operations declined slightly.

title: IN SAN FRANCISCO, CLASSIC CUISINE IS ONE CHEF'S COUP
description: Rene Verdon, the first professional chef on the White House staff, was putting the finishing touches to the shrimp aspic he had just unmolded in the small kitchen of his San Francisco home. ''If I had been a 'yes' man, I might still be in the White House,'' he said.

title: Hill, Holliday, Connors Gets Newsday Account
description: Newsday, long a Long Island newspaper, has retained an ad agency for the first time and that agency is the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus.

title: SUGAR CONES MADE AT HOME
description: THE best quality cold cuts layered between inferior bread do not make a memorable sandwich. In the same way, the best ice cream on a stale or tasteless cone is an unfortunate combination. A company called Vitantonio has come to the rescue with a new utensil called the Sugar Coner for making fresh cones at home.

title: Oklahoma Power Agency
description: The Oklahoma Municipal Power Authority yesterday made its debut in the public bond market, with a $167.7 million offering of electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: U.S. POSTS $13.4 BILLION TRADE GAP
description: The United States posted a $13.4 billion trade deficit in June, the second highest on record, the Commerce Department said today. It said that demand for foreign cars and oil soared.

NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

2-Day Closings at Peru Banks
description: The three-day-old Government of President Alan Garcia Perez today closed all banks, financial institutions and exchange houses, raising fears that it is planning currency controls.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE telephone order is for sushi, sashimi and futomaki. The delivery is from East, a Japanese restaurant on Third Avenue near 27th Street. The destination for the food: an apartment building at First Avenue and 35th Street. The deliveryman for East this particular evening is Takeyoshi Hara. And therein lies our tale.

AARON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Self-Interest Vs. Civic Spirit
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has scuttled the Senate's latest proposal for reducing the budget deficit without offering Congress any new plan for stanching the flow of red ink. The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said the President's decision means ''the ball game is over.''

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods are after a charge of $5,700,000 associated with an early retirement program and environmental cleanup work at the company's Union, N.J. plant.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in June 1985.
